headline: General Mills Is Serving Wheaties, the Breakfast of Champions, to Younger Consumers
text: HOW do you sell a cereal known for decades as “The breakfast of champions” to younger consumers who may believe “champions” is a quaint word and may perceive breakfast as something from a food truck, washed down with an energy drink?

headline: At Walgreen, Renouncing Corporate Citizenship
text: A little less than two years ago, Gregory D. Wasson, the chief executive of Walgreen, sought a series of tax breaks from Illinois, where his company is based.

headline: Mergers Hit a 7-Year High, Propelled by a Series of Blockbuster Deals
text: Deal makers have been thinking big this year.

headline: Texas: Panel Rules Agent Can Be Sued Over Shooting Teenager Across Border
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled Monday that a Border Patrol agent could be sued by the family of a 15-year-old Mexican boy he shot and killed even though the boy was in Mexico at the time of the episode. The agent, Jesus Mesa Jr., shot Sergio Adrian Hernandez Guereca on June 7, 2010, through a barbed wire border fence near El Paso. Mr. Mesa and the Obama administration argued that the agent could not be sued because constitutional protections did not apply since the youth was not in the United States. A three-judge panel of the court, in New Orleans, rejected that argument, saying the agent’s conduct was obviously unlawful, so he did not qualify for immunity.

headline: Official Seeks Restored Trust in Military Care
text: The Pentagon’s senior health-affairs official said Monday that the armed forces’ global network of hospitals and clinics must work to restore trust in the caliber of health care following disclosures of shortcomings in maternity and surgical care and a pattern of avoidable errors that have led to injuries and contributed to some deaths.

headline: UnitedHealth, an Insurer Switching Roles, Helps Hospitals on Medicare Billing
text: To hospitals, billions of dollars depend on how they define a patient’s stay.

headline: Russian Hackers Targeting Oil and Gas Companies
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Russian hackers have been systematically targeting hundreds of Western oil and gas companies, as well as energy investment firms, according to private cybersecurity researchers.

headline: Argentina Faces a Deadline for Hedge Fund Payments
text: Argentina’s government has 30 days to decide whether it should try to make peace with a group of New York hedge funds that it has bitterly fought for years in a dispute that could change the global market for government bonds.

headline: Veteran Wages a New Fight: For His Home
text: To find Stanley Theodore’s house, turn down 182nd Street in Springfield Gardens, Queens, and look for the ramshackle house with the grand old oak tree and the six-foot-wide American flag draped from the front window.

headline: N.C.A.A. Is Reopening Inquiry Into Academic Violations at North Carolina
text: The N.C.A.A. announced on Monday that it was reopening an investigation into whether the University of North Carolina athletics program violated rules in connection with a department that held dozens of bogus classes that distributed inflated grades to athletes.

headline: Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph to Pay for Failure to Report Abuse
text: CHICAGO — A Roman Catholic diocese in Missouri has been ordered to pay $1.1 million to victims of sexual abuse for breaking its promises on improving the way it deals with abuse cases.

headline: Ukrainian President Ends Cease-Fire With Rebels
text: MOSCOW — President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said early Tuesday that he had ordered a resumption of military efforts to crush a pro-Russian separatist rebellion in eastern Ukraine, formally ending a cease-fire after 10 days because, he said, rebels had refused to put down their weapons and had persisted in attacking government troops.

headline: A Conduit for Russian Gas, Tangled in Europe’s Conflicts
text: The port of Varna on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast was supposed to be the gateway for a major new pipeline, directly connecting Europe to Russia’s vast natural gas supplies. Now the project has stalled, as Bulgaria finds itself torn between the European Union and Russia in the escalating conflict over Ukraine.

headline: African Teams Head Home, Cash in Hand
text: BRASÍLIA — This has been a history-making World Cup for Africa, and not just for the number of contentious meetings, suspensions and threatened player boycotts. For the first time, two teams from the soccer-adoring continent advanced to the knockout stage of the tournament.

headline: More Cases on Religion Await, With Eye on Opinion by Alito
text: WASHINGTON — Battles over health care and religious rights are sure to continue, even after the Supreme Court ruled Monday that family-owned for-profit corporations like Hobby Lobby are not required to provide insurance coverage of contraceptives to their employees if the companies object on religious grounds.

headline: For Iraq, Potential Leader With a Tarnished Past
text: BAGHDAD — He took millions of dollars from the C.I.A., founded and was accused of defrauding the second-biggest bank in Jordan and sold the Bush administration a bill of goods on weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

headline: ISIS’ Goals for Iraq and Syria
text: Background on ISIS, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: A Creative Algeria Surprises but Cannot Defeat Germany
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — It was 2-1 for Algeria in 1982 in one of the biggest shocks in World Cup history. It was 2-1 for Germany 32 years later on a cool and drizzly Monday night.

headline: V.A. Nominee McDonald Faced Criticism at Procter & Gamble
text: When Robert A. McDonald took control of Procter & Gamble five years ago, the markets were already shifting beneath his feet.

headline: A Long History of Rebellion in the Mountains of Pakistan
text: The North Waziristan tribal agency in northwestern Pakistan has been the focus of a lot of firepower: The C.I.A. has made it ground zero for its drone strike campaign, the Pakistani military has sporadically unleashed raids and barrages there, and now it has been stormed by Pakistani infantry forces trying to clear out entrenched militant groups.

headline: ISIS Threatens Al Qaeda as Flagship Movement of Extremists
text: AMMAN, Jordan — As Syria’s civil war raged, a Kuwaiti Islamist, Ghanim al-Mteiri, funneled cash from wealthy donors in the Persian Gulf to Syria’s affiliate of Al Qaeda in hopes that it would overthrow the government and lay the foundations of an Islamic state.

headline: Christie Vetoes 2015 Pension-Paying Budget
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey vetoed a state budget on Monday that would have paid the pension contributions he promised in signature legislation three years ago, risking a rebuke from a court that last week said he had a contractual obligation to make them.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 30, 2014
Obama Discusses Immigration Reform
text: President Obama announced in the White House Rose Garden that he would take executive action on immigration legislation.

headline: In Case of Shootout, Who Kicks for U.S.?
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — All around this country, from bars in Porto Alegre to beaches in Recife, Brazilian fans on Saturday endured the tension, followed by the pure, unadulterated relief, that comes with watching your team take part in, and win, a penalty shootout.

headline: World Cup 2014: Belgium Eliminates U.S.A., 2-1
text: Tim Howard single-handedly kept it a scoreless match until extra time, when Belgium broke through for two goals. Team U.S.A. responded with a goal, but ran out of time.

headline: No Bombast (for Now) as Toronto Mayor Comes Back
text: OTTAWA — Rob Ford, his trousers eight sizes smaller, returned to his remaining duties as mayor of Toronto and his re-election campaign on Monday, about two months after abruptly leaving town for a drug and alcohol rehabilitation program.

headline: Burden of Proof
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I do love a smooth puzzle that gets me humming. Whenever you see Gary Cee’s byline, you can almost always be assured that there will be a musical element in his puzzle. After all, that’s what Mr. Cee does for a living. I think it’s a nice homage to his livelihood, don’t you?

headline: The Evolution of Trust
text: I’m one of those people who thought Airbnb would never work. I thought people would never rent out space in their homes to near strangers. But I was clearly wrong. Eleven million travelers have stayed in Airbnb destinations, according to data shared by the company. Roughly 550,000 homes are now being shared by hosts. Airbnb is more popular in Europe than it is even in the United States. Paris is the largest destination city.

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Switzerland, 1-0
text: Deep into extra time, Ángel Di María scored for Argentina off a pass from Lionel Messi to defeat Switzerland.

headline: From 9/11 to BP to G.M.
text: The title of Kenneth Feinberg’s 2012 book is: “Who Gets What: Fair Compensation After Tragedy and Financial Upheaval.” It is part memoir and part meditation on some of the well-known compensation systems he has administered during the course of his career, from the Agent Orange settlement to the 9/11 fund to the Gulf coast compensation fund that Feinberg managed for BP. “Where is it written,” he muses at one point, “that the tort system, and the tort system alone, must be the guiding force in determining who gets what?” It’s a good question.

headline: Limiting Rights: A Hit to Collective Bargaining
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday excusing certain workers paid by public funds from having to contribute any fees to the unions that represent them was not the deathblow to public-sector unions that many feared it would be. But there was no mistaking the ominous antipathy toward collective bargaining and workers’ rights behind Justice Samuel Alito Jr.’s majority opinion, which was joined by the four conservative members of the court.

headline: Limiting Rights: Imposing Religion on Workers
text: The Supreme Court’s deeply dismaying decision on Monday in the Hobby Lobby case swept aside accepted principles of corporate law and religious liberty to grant owners of closely held, for-profit companies an unprecedented right to impose their religious views on employees.

headline: Chilean Court Rules U.S. Had Role in Murders
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The United States military intelligence services played a pivotal role in setting up the murders of two American citizens in 1973, providing the Chilean military with the information that led to their deaths, a court here has ruled.

headline: G.M. Victim Compensation: How the Plan Works
text: Earlier this year, after General Motors announced a recall of 2.6 million Chevrolet Cobalts and other small cars because of a fatal flaw in an ignition switch, it hired Kenneth R. Feinberg, an expert on victim payment funds, to develop a compensation plan for those killed or injured by the defect.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Immigration Challenge
text: President Obama on Monday asked Congress for help in coping with the surge of tens of thousands of unaccompanied child migrants from Central America to the Texas border. He said the administration needed more money to care for them and “additional authority to exercise discretion” in quickly sending them home.

headline: Nancy Garden Dies at 76; Wrote Young-Adult Novel of Lesbians
text: Nancy Garden, whose enduring novel of 1982, “Annie on My Mind,” was among the first young-adult books to portray a lesbian relationship, died on June 23 at her home in Carlisle, Mass. She was 76.

headline: Reduced Charge for Boy in Fatal Bronx Stabbing
text: The teenager accused of fatally stabbing another student outside a Bronx middle school last month will face a reduced charge in a grand jury indictment announced on Monday.

headline: Whistle in Mouth, Target on Back
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — A college basketball game has broken out in the middle of the World Cup.

headline: Census Estimates Show Another Increase in New York City’s Non-Hispanic White Population
text: Kevin Gallagher and Sharon Almog, both teachers, considered moving to New Jersey with their two children several years ago when they were squeezed out of the apartment they were subletting in Stuyvesant Town, the sprawling complex that has long been a haven for working- and middle-class families in Manhattan. They considered moving again just recently while debating whether to renovate the 850-square-foot loft they own in Greenwich Village.

headline: A Grieving Father Pulls a Thread That Unravels BNP’s Illegal Deals
text: A bus bombing two decades ago — and a New Jersey father’s quest for justice — inadvertently set off a chain of events that led American prosecutors to accuse some of the world’s biggest banks of transferring money for nations like Iran.

headline: Knicks’ Top Draft Selection Focuses on His Situation, Not on Anthony’s
text: Cleanthony Early had been associated with the Knicks for less than a week, and even he was aware that nothing was for certain. On the eve of free agency, with Carmelo Anthony set to explore his options on a cross-country junket, Early was asked about the idea of playing with Anthony next season — or not.

headline: Holder Announces BNP Paribas Plea Deal
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that BNP Paribas will plead guilty to criminal charges and pay a $8.9 billion fine for violating sanctions.

headline: Apartment Inventory Is Up in Manhattan; Prices Are, Too
text: The good news for Manhattan apartment seekers: After a two-year shortage of apartments for sale, inventory is finally inching up again. The bad news: There still are too few apartments to go around, especially for those with a budget of $1 million or less.

headline: Cashen’s Gift on the Mets Was Magic
text: Mets fans these days can’t help being reminded of the 1980s. Turn on a game and Keith Hernandez and Ron Darling, two linchpins of the standout Mets teams from that decade, are engaged with the play-by-play announcer Gary Cohen in discussing the latest, often unsuccessful incarnation of the club.

headline: Weekends at a Bronx Beach That Feature Backboards Instead of Surfboards
text: On a recent Sunday, oohs and aahs rose from the bleachers as a lanky guard for Diamond/BQE took flight before mostly shirtless onlookers still dripping wet from the waters of Long Island Sound. “Air Jamaica with the slam!” the announcer called as the dunk rattled the backboard.

headline: Arizona Town Recalls Wildfire, and 19 Who Died Battling It
text: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Church bells rang out at 4:42 p.m. on Monday, marking the moment that 19 firefighters were last heard from before losing their lives in a raging wildfire on June 30, 2013, the deadliest day for firefighters since Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: A Ruling That Both Sides Can Run With
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday that the government cannot force certain employers to pay for birth control was more than a rebuke to President Obama. It was vindication of the conservative movement’s efforts to chip away at laws it finds objectionable by raising questions of freedom of expression.

headline: Mets Waste Lead in Loss to Braves
text: ATLANTA — On Monday afternoon, Terry Collins announced that David Wright, his star who had been found to have a bruised left rotator cuff, would avoid the disabled list. Instead, he would get more treatment and rest and rejoin the team for its game Friday against the Texas Rangers. That was good news for the Mets.

headline: Mexican Soldiers Wage Bloody Battle With Gang
text: MEXICO CITY — A gun battle between Mexican soldiers and an armed group that attacked a convoy left at least 22 people dead on Monday in one of the bloodiest confrontations the military has had in the drug war.

headline: Job Seeker Wounds 2 Then Kills Himself at Brooklyn Workshop, Police Say
text: Inside a cavernous iron workshop near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Monday morning, a man in a fishing hat and sneakers arrived asking for a job.

headline: Blade, a Helicopter-Booking App, to Partner With Uber
text: A start-up that fancies itself an Uber for helicopter rides is hooking up with Uber itself.

headline: Word of the Day | politic
text: politic •\ˈpä-lə-ˌtik\• adjective

headline: California Prosecutor Sues G.M. Over Sprawling Recall
text: A California prosecutor on Monday charged General Motors with unfair business practices and deceptive marketing for concealing ignition-related defects and others in order to boost its bottom line.

headline: Yankees Rally Twice but Fall Closer to .500
text: In the American League East, where a team has yet to set itself apart from the rest of the division, the Yankees, who have treaded water for much of the season, and even the last-place Tampa Bay Rays are still very much alive at the midway point of the season.

headline: 17 Companies File Casino Plans With New York State in Push for 4 Gambling Licenses
text: Seventeen companies on Monday unveiled lavish and increasingly expensive proposals for New York casino-resorts in communities from Albany to Tuxedo Park and Binghamton, officially starting the competition for four state-issued gambling licenses.

headline: New York’s Happiest
text: Police Academy graduates celebrated on Monday after the New York Police Department’s ceremony at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: July 1, 2014
text: What to watch for in today’s matches at the World Cup, the final two Round of 16 games to determine the last of the quarterfinalists:

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 9:40 P.M. (Flix) AMÉLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amélie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. Writing in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell called this comedy by Jean-Pierre Jeunet “a sugar-rush of a movie.” With its “hypnotic sense of romance” and “a heroine who constantly flirts with failure,” he added, the film’s “fastidious complex of flesh and fantasy is a dazzling achievement.”

headline: Hong Kong Survey Finds Record Dissatisfaction With Beijing
text: As Hong Kong prepared for its annual pro-democracy march Tuesday on the anniversary of the territory’s return to Chinese sovereignty, a survey of residents has found record levels of dissatisfaction with Beijing’s policies toward the city.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 1, 2014
text: “Hamas is responsible, and Hamas will pay.”

headline: Corrections: July 1, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Officer’s Conviction in Cannibalism Case Overturned
text: The 2013 conviction of a former New York City police officer in a plot to kidnap, torture, kill and eat women was overturned late Monday by a federal judge who said there was not sufficient evidence to support it.

headline: Student Crossword | Economics Basics
text: Test your knowledge of the fundamentals of economics by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Huge Crowds Turn Out for Pro-Democracy March in Hong Kong, Defying Beijing
text: HONG KONG — The appeal of democratic ideas drew thousands of protesters into the streets of Hong Kong on Tuesday in a defiant but largely peaceful march advocating free and open elections for the territory’s chief executive.

headline: As Iraqi Violence Rages, Lawmakers Fail to Reach Deal on New Government
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s major parties initially thought they had a deal ready when they sat down Tuesday to form a new government, but the effort collapsed in factional acrimony in less than half an hour.

headline: China Reaches Out to Myanmar on Maritime Dispute
text: At first blush, Myanmar, hardly a naval power and not exactly a major diplomatic heavyweight, would seem an odd place for China to seek relief from its headaches in the South China Sea.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Key Supreme Court Decisions in 2014
text: In the multimedia piece “Key Supreme Court Decisions in 2014,” The Times summarizes the major Supreme Court decisions from this term. The video above reports on one of those cases, Burwell v. Hobby Lobby.

headline: Short-Selling of Banco Espírito Santo Briefly Banned
text: LONDON – Securities regulators in Portugal and Britain have temporarily banned short-selling in Banco Espírito Santo after the Portuguese lender’s stock fell more than 16 percent on Monday on fears about its corporate parent.

headline: How Would Chuck Norris Vote?
text: “I’ve learned through football that strong leadership can be the difference between winning and losing,” Brett Favre said, leaning on the bed of a dirt-crusted utility vehicle in the middle of some lush green field. Favre, who now sports a Gandalf-style beard, could have been taping a Viagra commercial, or maybe one of his usual spots for Wrangler jeans. Instead, the retired N.F.L. gunslinger had been called into another arena. “When it comes to our state’s future, trust me,” said Favre, the pride of Kiln, Miss., in an ad paid for by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. “Mississippi can win and win big with Thad Cochran as our strong voice in Washington.”

headline: Falling for the Photo in Staten Island
text: “O.K. You sure you want to do this? Can you use this? Let me give you some background. You follow?”

headline: French Ex-Leader Questioned in Graft Inquiry, Imperiling Comeback Hopes
text: PARIS — Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, was detained Tuesday for questioning by French anticorruption investigators, a serious new turn in a blossoming criminal inquiry that threatens his hopes of a political comeback.

headline: BNP Paribas Is Confident It Can Absorb the Blow of a Record Fine
text: PARIS — A day after their bank was handed a record penalty by the United States authorities for violating sanctions laws, officials at BNP Paribas struck a confident note on Tuesday about the bank’s future, insisting it would be able to continue meeting the needs of most customers and had “ample” capital to absorb an $8.9 billion fine.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: U.S.A. and Belgium: A Long-Running Battle for Supremacy Continues
text: Belgium and the United States are preparing to face off Tuesday in Salvador, Brazil, in the World Cup, but few realize just how many battles for supremacy these two nations have already fought, in and out of the sports world. Despite a population gap of more than 290 million, Belgians and Americans have proved to be worthy adversaries.

headline: New York Today: Belgians Among Us
text: Happy Tuesday morning to you on this first of July.

headline: Modest Euro Zone Growth Fails to Dent Unemployment Rate
text: FRANKFURT — The unemployment rate in the euro zone remained close to a high in May, according to official data released on Tuesday, a reminder that despite modest growth, the recession has never ended for millions of Europeans.

headline: Putin Warns Again of Force as Ukraine Fighting Spreads
text: MOSCOW — The simmering standoff in eastern Ukraine exploded into warfare early Tuesday, pushing the conflict to a dangerous new phase and prompting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to warn again that he reserves the right to use force to defend Russian-speaking citizens.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times echoes President Obama in urging legislators to pass comprehensive immigration reform. But on Monday, he said the federal government needed “additional authority to exercise discretion.” The editorial board asks: Does the President intend “to change the law that requires such children be given an adequate chance to have their cases heard in immigration court”? The law, enacted by the Bush administration, “recognizes that many unaccompanied minors are likely to be refugees or victims of human trafficking who need legal and humanitarian help. It also protects them from summary deportation and requires that the Border Patrol turn them over to a refugee resettlement office and, where appropriate, to the care of parents or other relatives living in the United States.” The Times believes “weakening those protections in a misguided effort to discourage new migrants would be a terrible outcome.”

headline: Housing: Small Economic Sector With a Big Impact
text: Housing is a pretty tiny part of the economy. But housing also plays an enormous role in creating economic booms and busts. This is one of the most important paradoxes of how the economy works that policy makers are only now starting to grapple with adequately.

headline: 1969: A Warning on Global Warming
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: When Data Can Do More Harm Than Good
text: At RJMetrics, data is king. We’ve built our business around the belief that data-driven decisions are better decisions, and we’ve made it our mission to inspire and empower data driven people. But having such a deep love affair with data can be a dangerous game. The truth is that, even for companies like ours, using data is not always the best path. In fact, sometimes data can do more harm than good.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Tech Spending Projections
text: Summer is flying by – Gartner has already trimmed its annual projections for worldwide information technology spending.

headline: Obama and Iraq
text: Republicans do not agree with President Obama’s policies in Iraq.

headline: 1939: Joliot Seeks Uranium Advance
text: Frédéric Joliot, co-winner of the 1935 Nobel Prize in chemistry, is trying to find a way to make a $2 pound of uranium give up as much heat or power as is now obtained from burning $10,000 worth of coal. Joliot is working independently of his wife, Irene Joliot Curie, with whom he was given the 1935 Nobel award. She is the daughter of Pierre and Marie Curie, discoverers of radium. If scientists can find practicable means to set up uranium chain reactions, then it is estimated that it may be possible to obtain from one pound of uranium as much energy as is at present obtained from 1,250 tons of coal. — New York Herald Tribune, July 2, 1939.

headline: A Closer Look at Simplifying Financial Aid Applications
text: Sometimes, making something simple raises a lot of fears.

headline: Sparse Turnout at Pro-China Rally in Hong Kong
text: While tens of thousands of people converged on Hong Kong’s Victoria Park for an annual protest march, Ali Hassan, Usman Zahid and their colleagues quietly passed out plastic Chinese and Hong Kong flags at a pro-establishment rally across the harbor.

headline: A Trail of Clues Leading to Victims and Heartbreak
text: JERUSALEM — One suspect took 10 years to complete a college degree in Shariah law, according to relatives, because his studies kept being interrupted by stints in Israeli prison. The other quit school at 13, has been in poor health since a swimming accident put him in a coma in 2007, and has worked as a blacksmith, a porter, and a clothes salesman, several people who know him said.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Road to BNP’s Guilty Plea
text: State and federal authorities announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas on Monday for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. BNP’s agreement to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty ends months of arm-twisting by French officials. It is also the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which began with a bus bombing two decades ago and a grieving New Jersey father’s quest for justice, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook.

headline: Seamy World of the Tabloid, Bared
text: LONDON — Which one is she? Where is the woman we have gathered here to see pilloried? Where is, you know, Rebekah Brooks?

headline: What’s News in Washington: The Politics of Women
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington.

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction Mellon’s Treasures
text: Ever since Rachel Lambert Mellon died in March at the age of 103, the art world has been wondering what would become of the vast treasures of art and objects that she and her husband, Paul Mellon, had collected and lived with.

headline: In Performance: Benjamin Scheuer of ‘The Lion’
text: This week’s video features the composer and musician Benjamin Scheuer singing the number “Cookie-tin Banjo” from “The Lion,” his coming-of-age solo show about his relationship with his father, who died when Benjamin was 13. In the song Mr. Scheuer remembers how his love of music was inspired by a “simple homemade toy” crafted for him by his father. Directed by Sean Daniels for Manhattan Theater Club, “The Lion” continues through July 13 at City Center’s Studio II.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Of White Girls and Privilege
text: Season 2, Episode 8 It’s all about privilege in this episode — who benefits and who doesn’t — and it should surprise none of us at this point in the story (or history?) that our white heroine from Connecticut is the chief recipient. Piper gets her furlough after Healy makes some calls. Harder to judge is whether we’re supposed to be annoyed by her going on about her grandmother. (As I was – am I alone?)

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Here are a few more sound-alike mix-ups, all of which we’ve stumbled over before. Put them on your watch list:

headline: Japan Announces a Military Shift to Thwart China
text: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister announced a reinterpretation of the country’s pacifist Constitution on Tuesday, freeing its military for the first time in over 60 years to play a more assertive role in the increasingly tense region.

headline: In Testimony, Agent Calls Pistorius Caring
text: LONDON — A close associate of Oscar Pistorius said at his murder trial on Tuesday that, even on the night before the athlete killed his girlfriend, he was arranging for them to fly together — in business class — to a track meet in England as part of a series of trips abroad to show her “his world.”

headline: Limping in Solidarity and Leaping for Joy
text: PARIS — There’s never a busier time for dance in France than the end of June and early July, with the Paris Opera Ballet at the Palais Garnier, the Tanztheater Wuppertal (for the past 35 years) at the Théâtre de la Ville, the Montpellier Danse Festival in that city, and numerous other festivals on the horizon. But this year’s cornucopia has been marred by strikes and rumblings over government cuts in unemployment benefits for some performers and technicians working in the arts.

headline: Turkish Premier Runs for President, an Office He Plans to Strengthen
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced Tuesday that he would run for Turkey’s presidency in elections next month, a move that is likely to position him as the country’s dominant political figure for years to come.

headline: European Union Reduces Cellphone Roaming Charges
text: LONDON — The European Union on Tuesday cut cellphone roaming charges across the region by as much as 50 percent in the latest move to revamp how people communicate across the 28-country bloc.

headline: The Biological Grandparent Trap
text: As someone who has never planned on having children, I’ve always counted on my straight brothers to be the ones to provide my parents with grandchildren. Unfortunately, they’ve shown no greater enthusiasm at the prospect of having children than I have. But I figure at least one of them is bound to have a happy accident eventually, right?

headline: French Ban on Face Veils Upheld by European Rights Court
text: LONDON — The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a ban imposed by France on the wearing of face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms and bolstering opponents of strict Islamic dress in other parts of Europe.

headline: Longevity Insurance Joins the Menu of Retirement Plan Options
text: New tax rules will make it possible for workers to buy a type of annuity often called longevity insurance inside their retirement plans. The annuity aims to protect people from exhausting their savings in their later years.

headline: An Art Review in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Cameroon Investigates Match-Fixing Charges
text: BRASÍLIA — The plight of African teams at the World Cup has not subsided even after they all have been eliminated. Cameroon’s soccer federation announced late Monday that it would investigate its team for possible match fixing, paying particular attention to a lopsided loss to Croatia in the opening round.

headline: By Design | Just North of Paris, A New Concept Store Where Everything Is White
text: Just north of Paris, amidst the sprawling antiques bazaar of the Saint-Ouen flea markets, a burgeoning community of contemporary design and fashion outposts is drawing the attention of the weekend shopping crowd. Within the last two years, Rue des Rosiers, the area’s main thoroughfare, has seen the arrivals of Ma Cocotte (a Philippe Starck-designed restaurant), Habitat 1964 (a midcentury-focused spinoff of the Terence Conran-founded housewares chain) and L’Éclaireur (the multibrand men’s and women’s boutique). The latest addition to the street, located within a quiet courtyard in a space that once belonged to one of Jacques Cousteau’s sons, is a minimalist new concept store that looks the way its name suggests: Le White.

headline: Lazy, Hazy Days of Celebration
text: TIMES INSIDER — Welcome to the July 2014 Times Premier Puzzle Pack. It’s the height of summer, and not only are we enjoying the warm weather, but we also celebrate our Independence Day this month. Bring your colored pencils as we pay tribute to a special symbol.

headline: After Aereo
text: When the Supreme Court ruled last week that Aereo violated copyright law by retransmitting over-the-air TV signals and selling the content to its customers, broadcast networks celebrated the decision as a major victory. Meanwhile executives at Aereo lamented the decision as a “massive setback”—not just for its business but also for the entire technology industry.

headline: Are Categories Like Immigrant Fiction and ‘New American’ Fiction Valid or Worthwhile?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Francine Prose discuss whether categories like immigrant fiction are useful or meaningful labels.

headline: Chronicler Recalls a Bridge’s Rising, 50 Years Later
text: On windy days, ironworkers clambered up catwalks, linked the 60 garage-size steel segments that made up the bridge deck, and tiptoed atop the bridge’s 70-story towers at the risk of their lives. Three men were killed in falls during the construction. The workers or their bosses bore names like Hard-Nosed Murphy and Drag-Up Drilling. One crane operator in a steelyard was James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion from 1935 to 1937, when he lost the crown to Joe Louis.

headline: Scenes of Protest in Hong Kong
text: In what may be the biggest demonstration in a decade, hundreds of thousands of people marched in Hong Kong to demand greater democracy.

headline: An Even More Nuanced Breakdown of the Supreme Court
text: Last week, my colleagues Adam Liptak and Hannah Fairfield wrote about the divisions among Supreme Court justices. In showing the justices on a spectrum from more to less liberal, they found “a series of clusters, a few loners and several telling gaps,” not a steady progression from left to right.

headline: Twitter Names Ex-Goldman Banker Anthony Noto as Chief Financial Officer
text: Updated with details on compensation package.

headline: Amanda Knox Co-Defendant Changes Strategy
text: ROME — In the long-running courtroom drama of the Amanda Knox case, her co-defendant and former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, was relegated by the news media to a minor role, eclipsed by the attention focused on Ms. Knox, a pretty 21-year-old American who captured the public spotlight.

headline: Big Bowl With Spicy Brown Bean, Squash and Corn Succotash
text: If you have a problem liking succotash, it’s probably because of the lima beans, which have a mealy consistency that is not to everybody’s taste. What’s not to like, though, if you use another bean? Pintos or borlottis are great, and Good Mother Stallards from Rancho Gordo are luxurious. This succotash has some spice to it, a nice contrast to the sweet corn. Make sure to hold onto the bean broth. I like bulgur with this, but any grain will work.

headline: G.M. Sales Rise as Buyers Ignore Recalls
text: It has been a mystery in the auto industry in recent months: How can General Motors, embroiled in a safety crisis that has led to the recall of about 29 million vehicles worldwide this year, continue to have such strong sales?

headline: Ruling in Cannibal Case Revives Debate Over When a Fantasy Crosses a Criminal Line
text: In his mind and online persona, Gilberto Valle left little doubt about the depths of his depravation: In communications over the Internet, he imagined subjecting women he knew to sex-related torture and, in some cases, murder and cannibalism.

headline: Online, the Lying Is Easy
text: Charles Seife is a pop historian who writes about mathematics and science, but his abiding theme, the topic that makes his heart leap like one of Jules Feiffer’s dancers in the springtime, is human credulity.

headline: Learned Macroeconomic Helplessness
text: One of the oddest, most frustrating things about the six years plus since the Great Recession began is the incessant whining from pundits that it’s all very complicated, and nobody knows what to do. As Dean Baker says, the story of this slump is remarkably simple; I would give more role to household debt than he does, but basically yes, it’s a huge slump in housing. Here’s residential investment as a percentage of GDP:

headline: Two-Bean and Tuna Salad
text: I’ve always had a weakness for tuna and bean salad. This one, because I used luxurious Good Mother Stallard beans from Rancho Gordo, is quite the most amazing version of the salad I’ve ever tasted. If you want to use a more commonly available bean for it, use pintos or borlottis, but cook them yourself instead of using canned. Then you can use some of the broth in the dressing and the beans themselves will taste better because you’re in control of the seasonings. The nutritional values here are based on tuna canned in water, but you could always use tuna in olive oil for a richer version.

headline: 1964: Luebke Is Re-elected in Berlin
text: BONN — Heinrich Luebke, 69, was overwhelmingly elected today [July 1] to a second five-year term as president of West Germany. The outcome was never in doubt because the former cabinet minister had been endorsed by both major parties, the ruling Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats. The election, held in West Berlin despite strong Soviet and East German objections, reaffirmed West Germany’s insistence that the divided city is the real capital of Germany and some day will serve as such for a reunited nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 2, 1964.

headline: Tostadas With Smashed Black Beans or Vaqueros, Salsa Fresca and Avocado
text: I have always had a weakness for black bean tostadas. These are not unlike Oaxacan tlayudas, though this recipe doesn’t call for that dish’s signature extra-large corn tortillas. I used luxurious black and white vaqueros from Rancho Gordo for these, but black beans will also work well. Cook them yourself (don’t use canned), because you’ll need the delicious broth. I don’t refry them for as long as I normally would because I like them moist, and vaqueros are starchier than black beans.

headline: G.O.P. Power Broker in Albany Accused of Lying to F.B.I.
text: State Senator Thomas W. Libous is a natural in Albany’s clubby corridors, a world away from the family grocery store in Binghamton, N.Y., where he worked growing up.

headline: Argentina vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Lionel Messi is tied for the Golden Boot with four goals. The Swiss gave up just six goals in 10 qualifying matches; they have given up six in just three games at the Cup. More Messi goals to come?

headline: Teenager Topples Top-Ranked Nadal in Round of 16
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court on Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a men’s Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open. The winner then was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, days after Nadal’s 19th birthday.

headline: I Am the Real Nick Cave
text: “I went to Graceland once,” Nick Cave said. “The rest of the band went in, but I stayed out on the curb, smoking cigarettes and feeling sorry for myself. Those last Elvis performances — the ones for television, when he was already sick — I must have watched those clips a hundred times. They’re like crucifixions.” He paused for a moment. “I couldn’t bring myself to go inside.”

headline: In Store | A.P.C. Sets Up Shop at the Wythe Hotel
text: The Wythe Hotel has established itself as more than a place to stay in Williamsburg. Last month, it set up a chapel on the roof, where gay couples were married over the weekend during New York’s Pride Week. And of course there’s the location’s shop, whose wares change every several months and are usually curated by a local designer or brand. Beginning today, however, the Brooklyn boutique will open the doors to an assortment curated by its first international retailer: the French brand A.P.C.

headline: Arugula and Corn Salad With Roasted Red Peppers and White Bean
text: Since you don’t need a broth for this composed salad, canned beans will work, though I always prefer the flavor of beans I’ve cooked myself. I like to use a white bean, either a cannellini or a navy bean. I’ve always loved sweet corn with pungent arugula. I combine the two for a salad bed, which I top with the roasted peppers and beans. So the dish is really two salads, one on top of the other.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Getting Out of Town
text: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archive that tell tales of New York City summers past.

headline: Facebook Flunks Its Apology
text: “Ok so,” begins Adam D.I. Kramer’s apology for Facebook’s recent experiment on its users’ feelings. Mr. Kramer, a data scientist at Facebook, went on to explain the experiment in greater detail (Facebook altered some users’ news feeds, then analyzed the emotional content of their later posts) and to say, “my coauthors and I are very sorry for the way the paper described the research and any anxiety it caused.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Penalty Kick Strategy
text: Midfielder Kyle Beckerman demonstrates his penalty kick strategy, which he says is all about trusting yourself. On the other side of the ball, goalkeeper Nick Rimando says he aims to react, not guess.

headline: NASA Delays Launching of Carbon Observatory
text: The launching of NASA’s Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 spacecraft was called off on Tuesday morning, with 46 seconds left in the countdown, when equipment on the launching pad malfunctioned.

headline: Wheelies: The Flying Honda Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: American Homes Acquires Rival in Buy-to-Rent Business
text: In what could be the start of a wave of consolidation in the business of buying single-family homes to rent them out, American Homes 4 Rent, one of the largest institutional investors in foreclosed homes, said on Tuesday that it was buying a smaller competitor.

headline: Saudi Arabia Donates $500 Million to Help Displaced Iraqis
text: Answering criticism with cash, Saudi Arabia on Tuesday swooped in to address the humanitarian crisis caused by the Sunni insurgency in Iraq, providing $500 million to the United Nations to help the more than one million Iraqis whose lives have been uprooted by the mayhem of recent weeks.

headline: The N.S.A. Can Spy on These 193 Foreign Governments
text: The Washington Post has published a 2010 government document indicating that the National Security Agency was authorized, by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, to intercept information “concerning” 193 foreign governments. According to The Post, the N.S.A. can “intercept through U.S. companies not just the communications of its overseas targets but any communications about its targets as well.”

headline: Who’s a ‘Christian’? Avoiding Labels in the Hobby Lobby Coverage
text: I heard from several thoughtful readers who object to The Times’s description of the owners of two companies in the news because of a major Supreme Court decision on Monday. (The companies are Hobby Lobby and Conestoga Wood Specialties.) That decision said that requiring such family-owned corporations to pay for insurance covering birth control was a violation of federal law protecting religious freedom.

headline: Penalties for Companies, but Executives Often Emerge Unscathed
text: Before BNP Paribas pleaded guilty to violating United States economic sanctions laws, the bank’s chief executive, Jean-Laurent Bonnafé, said in a message to employees that “malfunctions have occurred and mistakes were made.” It was much more than that, costing to the bank nearly $9 billion. But even then, the misconduct leading to that kind of penalty did not result in criminal charges against any individuals.

headline: Flame Retardants Are Everywhere
text: Just over 10 years ago, Dr. Arnold Schecter, a public health researcher in Texas, started finding traces of chemical flame retardants in the breast milk of American women. It appeared that the compounds were carried into the milk from fat in the mothers’ bodies.

headline: Maria Sharapova Ousted by Angelique Kerber at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For three grueling sets, Angelique Kerber would not be bullied. In the most exhausting test of her endurance, along with her character, she would not be beaten.

headline: 4 Are Rescued Days After Building Collapse in South India
text: NEW DELHI — Four people were rescued on Tuesday from the rubble of a 12-story building on the outskirts of the southern Indian city of Chennai that collapsed three days before. One of them was a 27-year-old man who got up and walked away from the site on his own once he was freed.

headline: The Illogic of Employer-Sponsored Health Insurance
text: Imagine yourself in a bar where a pickpocket takes money out of your wallet and with it buys you a glass of chardonnay. Although you would have preferred a pinot noir, you decide not to look that gift horse in the mouth and thank the stranger profusely for the kindness, assuming he paid for it. You might feel differently, of course, if you knew that you actually had paid for it yourself.

headline: Orwell Birthplace in India to Become a Museum
text: The ramshackle three-room bungalow in Motihari, India where George Orwell was born in 1903 is being restored and transformed into a museum that will celebrate the life and career of the essayist and author, The Times of India reported. The renovation, which has been under discussion since 2010, when the house was declared a protected site, is being underwritten by the government of Bihar state, which is hoping the museum will become a tourist attraction. Motihari is in northeastern India, near the border of Nepal. Orwell, who was born Eric Arthur Blair, was born there while his father, Richard Blair, was posted in Bihar as an employee of the Indian Civil Service, to supervise the production of opium for export to China.

headline: Q & A: Chocolate Ganache
text: The cookbook author Dorie Greenspan and Julia Moskin of the Dining section discussed making chocolate ganache with you, our readers. (The master recipe for chocolate is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

headline: Former Newspaper Editor to Oversee Pulitzer Prizes
text: The former editor of The Concord Monitor will oversee the Pulitzer Prizes, Columbia University announced on Tuesday.

headline: Noisy Predators Put Plants on Alert, Study Finds
text: It has long been known that some plants can respond to sound. But why would a plant evolve the ability to hear? Now researchers are reporting that one reason may be to defend itself against predators.

headline: American Soccer Fans Dominate FIFA’s Online Audience
text: For many Americans, FIFA has long been a foreign-sounding jumble of letters rather than the organization behind the World Cup, the globe’s biggest sporting event. (Where is the “S” for soccer?)

headline: Your World Cup Ethical Questions, Answered
text: Was Luis Suárez’s bite of an opponent any more unethical than other forms of direct harm, such as a stomp or a professional foul in which the risk of serious injury is more likely? Or does the fact that biting is viewed as “uncivilized” make it uniquely worse? JACK HIGGINS, posted on Facebook

headline: Bonus All-World-Cup Ethicist Column!
text: In his most recent Ethicist column, Chuck Klosterman weighed in on whether it’s wrong to mention the result of a World Cup match in front of a friend who you know has recorded the game to watch later. We realized that this was just one of many fascinating questions raised by all the flopping, biting and cheering that’s been going on since June 12. We asked what other ethical questions you had about the World Cup, and you submitted some great ones via Facebook, Twitter and email. Read Klosterman’s responses in this week’s bonus column.

headline: Post Office to Release a Janis Joplin Stamp
text: Janis Joplin is about to join the small, but growing, pantheon of American musicians honored on postage stamps. On Tuesday, the United States Postal Service unveiled the design for its Joplin stamp, which is to go on sale in August. It is the fifth installment of the postal service’s Music Icons series, which also includes Johnny Cash, the Tejana star Lydia Mendoza and Ray Charles, all issued in 2013, and Jimi Hendrix, whose stamp was issued in March.

headline: Clip: ‘Tammy’
text: Melissa McCarthy and Susan Sarandon in a scene from “Tammy.”

headline: Thousands Beat Path to Queens Cemetery to Remember a Jewish Leader
text: The pilgrims had traveled from Montana and Helsinki, eastern Michigan and western Ukraine, waiting for the sun, hanging stubbornly above the Old Montefiore Cemetery in Queens, to disappear on Monday night.

headline: Atmospheric Tunes from the Spring/Summer 2015 Paris Men’s Shows
text: As is to be expected in Paris, where runway looks tend toward the experimental, most designers sent their clothes down the catwalks this season to the beat of atmospheric music by relatively obscure musicians and bands (the kind of songs you can’t always Shazam). While some tracks, like Tuxedomoon’s “Triumphant Procession” at Comme des Garçons Homme Plus, created a contemplative mood, other presentations showed a sense of humor in the form of lighter, more uplifting fare like “Easy Easy” by King Krule (at Carven) and “L’Eau A La Bouche” by Serge Gainsbourg (at Valentino).

headline: Today in Small Business: Skip the Morning Meeting
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rottapharm, an Italian Drug Maker,  Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
text: LONDON — The Italian drug maker Rottapharm said on Tuesday that it expected an initial public offering of its shares later this month to value the company at up to 1.8 million euros, or about $2.46 billion.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Men’s Spring/Summer 2015 Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.

headline: The Secret of Belgium’s Success
text: No, not about soccer. But since we’re talking about Belgium, a little-known fact is that the Belgian economy has actually done considerably better than its neighbors since the crisis began:

headline: Curtain Call | Paris Men’s Fashion Week
text: To mark the conclusion of Spring/Summer 2014 Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.

headline: Ever True to You, Local Parlor
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Emily Appel, 28, is in charge of spinning the well-regarded burnt caramel ice cream here at Toscanini’s, where both the ice cream and the memories are so thick, they could make even an M.I.T. engineer weep.

headline: U.S.A. vs. Belgium: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Largely outplayed in group competition, the United States still has a shot against Belgium, which is undefeated since World Cup qualifying began.

headline: An Ailing Serena Williams Abandons a Doubles Match
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It was clear Serena Williams was in trouble before the first point of her doubles match Tuesday at Wimbledon.

headline: Fresh Ink for the Human Canvas
text: If you are thinking about getting a tattoo, or adding another one to the half-dozen or so you already have, the options of what are available may have multiplied since the last time you visited your tattoo parlor.

headline: Pershing Square Said to Hire Credit Suisse for Allergan Fight
text: Updated, 3:48 p.m. | Wall Street banks tend to defend companies against activist investors. But at least one bulge-bracket institution has aligned itself with William A. Ackman, one of the biggest dissident shareholders around, as he takes on the Botox maker Allergan.

headline: T.S.A. Fees for Air Trips to Rise
text: While airfares fluctuate constantly with demand, competition and fuel prices, at least one constant in pricing is set to rise: T.S.A. fees.

headline: Nets General Manager Wants to Move Quickly to Replace Jason Kidd
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A day after officially cutting ties with Jason Kidd, Nets General Manager Billy King said that he would not consider Kidd’s actions to be a “personal affront” and that he had already taken steps to move on.

headline: Russell Westbrook Moves Between Oklahoma City and Paris With Ease
text: PARIS — In the last several years, a clutch of National Basketball Association players — like Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler and Dwyane Wade — have emerged as darlings of the fashion world, showing up in the front rows of fashion shows in New York, Paris and Milan, and being featured in photo spreads in magazines such as GQ and Vogue.

headline: In BNP Paribas Case, an Example of How Mighty the Dollar Is
text: Even if you are a bank as gigantic as BNP Paribas, $9 billion is a lot of money. Shareholders of the French bank know that all too well, as that is what they are paying in penalties to the United States for a conspiracy to allow money transfers to Sudan and other blacklisted nations.

headline: Hong Kong Challenges Beijing
text: On Tuesday, hundreds of thousands of people held one of the largest marches in Hong Kong’s history to demand democracy.

headline: Graco Recalls 1.9 Million Rear-Facing Infant Seats
text: Under pressure from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Graco Children’s Products has agreed to recall about 1.9 million rear-facing infant seats with a faulty buckle that can make it difficult to free a child during an emergency.

headline: Messi, as Always Expected, Rescues Argentina
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Lionel Messi is often the smallest player on the field. But it is clear that he possesses his own gravitational pull.

headline: A Straw Purchaser Goes to Jail
text: On Christmas Eve, 2012 — less than two weeks after the gun massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School —  William Spengler, Jr., 62, shot and killed two firefighters and wounded two others, whom he had lured to his home in Webster, N.Y., by starting a fire. He also wounded an off duty police officer who was driving by. In the hours that followed, shots were exchanged with police, seven houses burned down and Mr. Spengler shot and killed himself. In the burnt debris of his home, police later found the remains of his 67-year old sister, Cheryl, whom he also had shot and killed.

headline: The Culture War’s Sore Winners
text: After following some of the more intemperate liberal reactions to the Supreme Court’s Hobby Lobby decision yesterday, I thought of this post from Mother Jones’s Kevin Drum from earlier this year, making the case for a liberalism that owns up to its own culture-war aggressions and success:

headline: Compromise at the Supreme Court Veils Its Rifts
text: WASHINGTON — Two very different group portraits of the Supreme Court emerged this term, one familiar and one unexpected.

headline: Distracted Diva: The Second Screen Goes to the Opera
text: Do two instances mean the start of a trend – or is it still just an experiment? In June, On Site Opera, a small New York company, presented a production of Rameau’s “Pygmalion,” at which operagoers were encouraged to use Google Glass, the eyeglasslike computer, onto which a translation of the libretto was projected. It was by no means an amateur operation or a frivolous stunt: the technology used to project the subtitles to Google Glass was created by Figaro Systems, the company that makes the seat-back title panels used at the Metropolitan Opera, the Santa Fe Opera and other houses.

headline: U.S. Accuses T-Mobile of Overbilling
text: WASHINGTON — T-Mobile, which sees itself as a new kind of carrier, now stands accused of an old-fashioned practice — overbilling its customers.

headline: HSBC Settles Fraud Charges Over Foreclosure Fees Paid by the U.S. Government
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Tuesday announced a $10 million settlement with the British bank HSBC, accusing it of fraud over the way it submitted fees to the government when foreclosing on homeowners.

headline: Funeral Held for Slain Israeli Teenager
text: Shirel Shaar, the sister of one of the Israeli teenagers killed, and Yair Lapid, the Israeli finance minister, spoke at the funeral for Gilad Shaar in Talmon in the West Bank.

headline: Census Considers How to Measure a More Diverse America
text: When Alexa Aviles received her census form in 2010, she was frustrated by the choices. Like all Hispanics, Ms. Aviles, a Puerto Rican who lives in Brooklyn, was first asked to identify her ethnicity and then to answer a question about her race. Ms. Aviles, 41, who works for a nonprofit, thought, “I’m all of these!” In annoyance, she checked Hispanic, and then identified herself as white, black and “some other race.”

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week One | 21st-Century Concentration Camps
text: For the fifth summer in a row we’re posing a simple question to teenagers each Friday: What interested you most in The Times this week?

headline: Barclays Rehires Tim Luke, an Adviser to Britain’s Prime Minister
text: Barclays said on Tuesday that it was rehiring Tim Luke, an adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, as a senior banker for its technology, media and telecommunications group.

headline: Tinder Is Target of Sexual Harassment Lawsuit
text: Whitney Wolfe, a former executive at the popular dating start-up Tinder, has filed a lawsuit against the company, along with its majority owner, IAC/InterActiveCorp, on sexual harassment and discrimination claims.

headline: Prescription Overdose Deaths in Florida Plunge After Tougher Measures, Report Says
text: Prescription drug overdose deaths in Florida fell sharply after the state began strengthening its prescribing laws and stepping up enforcement. Federal researchers said Tuesday that it was one of the first significant documented declines in the nation since the epidemic of prescription drug abuse took hold more than a decade ago.

headline: One Goal, Three Perspectives
text: See Germany’s goal against the United States from the perspectives of the goalkeeper, a defender and the kicker.

headline: Time With Turtles in North Carolina
text: A popular destination on the North Carolina coastline dedicated to rescuing and rehabilitating injured sea turtles has relocated, expanded and reopened to the public.

headline: The Latest Ice Cream Essentials
text: To Anticipate: A Shop Finds a Space To Match Its Name

headline: Rangers Begin Makeover Only Weeks From Stanley Cup Finals
text: A few weeks after reaching the Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers are a changed team. Enter the 15-year veteran defenseman Dan Boyle and forward Tanner Glass. Exit forwards Brian Boyle and Benoit Pouliot, and defenseman Anton Stralman.

headline: Print Matters | In Honor of the World Cup, Three Beautiful Independent Sports Journals
text: Since the World Cup kicked off in Brazil two weeks ago, soccer fever has gripped New Yorkers to a surprising degree. In honor of today’s U.S.-Belgium match, a do-or-die affair for the American squad, we take a look at three beautiful N.Y.C.-based sports journals.

headline: For Singer, Boundaries Are There to Be Ignored
text: Beck ended the main portion of his show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday with the evening’s only true bit of shtick, unspooling a roll of yellow police tape across the length of the stage. He and his band had just rampaged through “E-Pro” — a decade-old tune with a nasty guitar riff, its chorus indistinguishable from a playground taunt — and a residual growl of feedback accompanied him in his task. “Crime Scene Do Not Cross,” advised the tape, inviting a moment’s reflection on the subject of enforced boundaries and willful transgressions, the crossing of lines and purposes.

headline: Grand Banks to Offer Dining and a Raw Bar on a Tall Ship
text: Headliner

headline: U.S. Justice Seems to Fall Harder on Foreign Companies
text: Uncle Sam is cooking up penalties with an anti-foreign flavor. New research suggests that overseas firms like BNP Paribas do in fact pay bigger fines and plead guilty more often than United States companies. One reason may be that prosecutors single out only the most serious cases abroad. But the differences feed suspicions that the United States is playing favorites.

headline: Simona Halep Takes Away Zarina Diyas’s Forehand
text: WIMBLEDON, England — There are many weapons on a tennis court, and the ability to disarm an opponent is as good as it gets.

headline: Festival of New Musicals Announces Its Roster
text: The Tony Award-winning playwright David Henry Hwang, the composer Adam Gwon and the composing duo Michael Kooman and Christopher Dimond are among the names represented in this year’s Festival of New Musicals, produced by the National Alliance for Musical Theater, a national nonprofit organization.

headline: Obama Urges Congress to Fund Infrastructure Projects
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on congressional Republicans on Tuesday to take quick action to fund infrastructure projects throughout the country, arguing that failing to do so could mean huge layoffs for Americans this year.

headline: Interest Rates for Student Loans Just Went Up
text: It’s July 1, and that means you’ll pay higher interest rates on federal student loans for the coming school year.

headline: Stability or Sadomonetarism?
text: Simon Wren-Lewis is harsh about the current tight-money crowd, exemplified by the Bank for International Settlements, who are urging tight money despite weak economies, for fear that investors will take excessive risks. But he’s not harsh enough.

headline: Ice Cream Basics
text: Melissa Clark shows you how to make the only ice cream recipe you’ll ever need.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Charge Against Thomas W. Libous
text: Mr. Libous, the second-highest-ranking Republican in the New York Senate, was charged with lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Bees, Brews and Boutiques in Cape May, N.J.
text: Long known for its Victorian bed-and-breakfasts, this historic seaside resort in recent years has seen its once-faded grande dame hotels and low-slung motels get stylish makeovers. Cabanas with beachside refreshment service can now be found a few steps from old-time arcades. As the area increasingly attracts young, affluent visitors, a new generation of proprietors is bringing tastefully appointed boutiques, organic-food shops and laid-back restaurants to the mix.

headline: Restaurant Report: Masala Library in Mumbai
text: Are ultramodern molecular gastronomy techniques compatible with a culinary tradition steeped in centuries of history? That’s what Jiggs Kalra, the renowned chef from Mumbai, India, set out to discover in October when he opened Masala Library, his temple of new-age Indian cuisine.

headline: Charges Against Matthew Libous
text: The charges against Matthew Libous include that he failed to identify a lobbying firm as the source of payments that he had received through a law firm.

headline: Please Tune Out Those TV Studies
text: You remember eating. If you were hungry, you ate something. If you liked it, you ate some more.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, the West Bank, Kosovo and South Africa.

headline: Obama on Supporting U.S. Infrastructure
text: At the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, the president urged Congress to replenish the Highway Trust Fund, which reimburses states for their infrastructure projects.

headline: New Owners for Some of Canada’s Landmark Railway Hotels
text: OTTAWA — The age when rail travel dominated in Canada has long passed. But the railway-built hotels that era left behind have retained much of the glory and glamour of that period.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: A French Ball Game, the Fashion Way, at the Paris Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Shows
text: Scenes from the photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Fusion Names Jane Spencer Its Editor for Digital Content
text: Fusion, a joint online and television venture between Univision and Disney-ABC Television Group, announced on Tuesday that Jane Spencer, a veteran of The Daily Beast and The Wall Street Journal, would be its editor in chief for digital content.

headline: Hotel Review: The Roundhouse at Beacon Falls in Beacon, N.Y.

headline: Mayor Drives the Remaking of an Indiana City
text: CARMEL, Ind. — In 20 years, this city has undergone a substantial overhaul, and its longtime mayor has presided over every stage of its development.

headline: Cuomo Praises State Senator Libous
text: Highlighted remarks from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on State Senator Thomas W. Libous over the past few years.

headline: Charges Against Gilberto Valle
text: Mr. Valle had been charged with kidnapping conspiracy and illegally gaining access to a law enforcement database. He was convicted in 2013 but had not yet been sentenced.

headline: Single Winner of All Bitcoins in U.S. Auction
text: The United States Marshals Service announced on Tuesday that one bidder had won all of the nearly 30,000 Bitcoins auctioned on Friday.

headline: To Strut (and Leap) on a Stage
text: There is no ballet danced better by American Ballet Theater than Frederick Ashton’s 52-minute “The Dream,” 50 years old this year. This is remarkable for three particular reasons. First: “The Dream” — which on the surface seems a quaint study in Victoriana — is a flawless ballet, deeply witty, intricate and eloquent, full of complex challenges to its dancers, a piece that rewards countless re-viewings.

headline: An Uncoiling of Energy and Urgency, Sans Venom
text: The first thing the Agalloch frontman John Haughm does at the beginning of concerts is light incense at the foot of the stage. On Monday night at Irving Plaza, he did that just as “(serpens caput),” a mesmerizing little goth-folk guitar breather from the band’s new album, “The Serpent & the Sphere” (Profound Lore), was pouring out of the speakers.

headline: Bonnie Stone Sellers
text: Ms. Sellers is the chief executive of Christie’s International Real Estate, the New York-based division of the auction house Christie’s. The company has 138 real estate affiliates in 45 countries, including Brown Harris Stevens.

headline: Popular For a Reason
text: It’s summer blockbuster season, so a popular subject of scorn is upon us: the latest “Transformers” movie. But all the scorn in the world, argues Jeff Nesbit at U.S. News & World Report, will not dissuade us from paying to watch giant robots attack one another. And believe it or not, the large and loud may appeal to something deep within us.

headline: Paul Mazursky Dies at 84; Director Showed ‘Me’ Era’s Strength and Foibles
text: Paul Mazursky, an innovative director and screenwriter who both satirized and sympathized with America’s panorama of social upheavals in the late 1960s and ’70s in films that included “Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice,” “Blume in Love” and “An Unmarried Woman,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: When Life Offers Lemons, Zest Them
text: How do you solve a problem like Melissa McCarthy? That question feels inescapable after watching her try to powerlift “Tammy,” her newest and least funny comedy, all by her lonesome. Ms. McCarthy plays the title bad-luck gal who, shortly after the movie opens, hits a deer and is hit in return, walks away from her broken-down car and into the rest of her tumbledown life. Repeatedly knocked down throughout this knockabout comedy, Tammy takes a licking and keeps on sticking her foot right back in it. She’s a total loser, except in the comedy of misfortune.

headline: China’s Hurdle to Fast Action on Climate Change
text: When the Environmental Protection Agency published in June its new rules to combat carbon emissions from power plants, the American political class lit up in debates over what this meant for the country’s carbon emissions, its coal industry and its economic growth.

headline: The Court’s Ruling on Contraception
The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows in Paris
text: The European tour of the spring/summer 2015 men’s shows came to an end on Sunday when the last of the Paris runway presentations came to an end. In the City of Lights, a range of references — as subtle as boyishness and as culturally specific as India  — inspired the most memorable collections presented there.

headline: Google in Deal for Songza, a Music Playlist Service
text: In a sign of growing consolidation in the digital music business, Google announced on Tuesday that it had bought Songza, a three-year-old app that competes with Pandora and others in making customized playlists of recommended songs.

headline: A Cone to Remember
text: With the summer sun comes summer fun, but after we’ve worked hard at hardly working what do we reach for? Ice cream. We asked readers to share photographs of their favorite memories of ice cream from their youth.

text: PREMATURE

headline: Wild Ride by U.S. Comes to End, but Soccer Is the Winner
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — It felt as if Tim Howard would never go down. As if the United States would never go down, standing there, taking shots like an undersize fighter clinging desperately to a puncher’s chance. Howard saved with his hands. His feet. His legs. His knees. At one point, Howard even had a shot bounce off the crest over his heart.

headline: The Only Ice Cream Recipe You’ll Ever Need
text: When I was 17, I had a summer job making ice cream at Peter’s on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. It was a cinch. You poured the milky contents of a container labeled “base” into the machine, added your flavorings (chocolate, vanilla, kiwi or what have you) and turned the switch.

headline: An Ordinary Setting, Thick With Family Dynamics
text: LOST PERSONS AREA

headline: High Fashion Finds Its Man
text: PARIS — Jocks like Victor Cruz may not seem like the obvious target market for high-end fashion designers. Yet the wide receiver, who last year signed an estimated $46 million contract extension with the Giants, is a banner example of where exactly we find ourselves in the ongoing evolution of men’s wear.

text: EARTH TO ECHO

text: This rich, silky custard base can accommodate nearly any flavor you can imagine.

text: In this animated short, Christoph Niemann uses some birds and a rooftop in Brasilia to explain the term “offside” in soccer.

headline: A New York Cop Walks the Satan Beat
text: DELIVER US FROM EVIL

headline: Quiz: Can You Tell What Makes a Good Tweet?
text: A quiz tests your skill at picking which of two tweets would be shared more.

headline: JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon Has Throat Cancer That He Calls ‘Curable’
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has throat cancer and will begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, he said in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders late Tuesday.

headline: Bacon, and a Bed, Sell Well at Christie’s  London Auction
text: LONDON — It was another buoyant night for postwar and contemporary art at Christie’s auction here on Tuesday night, and it was, in many ways, an echo of Sotheby’s sale the evening before. Both salesrooms were overflowing with collectors, predominately from America and Asia, bidding briskly for classic paintings. Even the two artists who brought the top prices were the same — Francis Bacon and Peter Doig.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Adopting Tools of Protest for a Level Playing Field
text: In the quest for park equity, many residents in poor neighborhoods have seemed to have little recourse for the sorry state of their cracked basketball courts and out-of-service bathrooms.

headline: Advocacy Group Sues 4 Universities in Challenge to Policies It Says Curb Free Speech
text: LOS ANGELES — Arguing that free speech is being stifled at college campuses across the country, a Philadelphia-based advocacy group on Tuesday filed lawsuits against four universities, seeking to force the schools to revise policies that the group says restrict some forms of speech.

headline: Justice for Blacks and Whites
text: WASHINGTON — THE Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned discrimination in public accommodations, employment and federally funded activities like education, would not have passed without the support of House and Senate Republicans who were competing for black votes. And Presidents Kennedy and Johnson would not have advocated for the bill without being pressured to do so by a multiracial grass-roots movement.

headline: The Ukrainian Crisis Reaches a New Level
text: President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine took the fateful step late Monday of ending his unilateral cease-fire in the struggle with separatists in eastern Ukraine, declaring: “We will attack and liberate our land.” The attacks began shortly after, moving the Ukrainian crisis to a highly dangerous but unavoidable level. Dangerous because Ukrainian forces are woefully ill-equipped and ill-trained to fight what is essentially a civil war, in which Ukrainian civilians are bound to be casualties; unavoidable because neither the rebels nor Russia ever took seriously the negotiations with Kiev and Western mediators. In effect, the long-building showdown has begun, and it is essential for the West to shed any illusions about what is at stake.

headline: Give Scotusblog a Seat in Court
text: At a few minutes past 10 a.m. on Monday, as the Supreme Court began to issue the final rulings of the term, 60,000 people — including journalists at major news outlets around the country — were following the live feed of Scotusblog, a website devoted to covering every warp and woof of the court’s complex litigation. Since its inception in 2002, the site has become required reading for Supreme Court news and analysis, winning multiple awards.

headline: Neomonetarist Delusions
text: Danny Vinik notes that “reform conservatives”, who are trying either to rescue the right from its intellectual torpor or to provide cover for its fundamental anti-intellectualism — your choice — have gotten a fair bit of lip service for some of their ideas, but none at all for one key proposal: activist monetary policy to assure full employment.

headline: Many Sharp Turns in Bergdahl’s Path to Army
text: KETCHUM, Idaho — In 2003, the year he turned 17, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl left his mark on the wet cement floor of the Strega Tea Bar Gallery and Cafe, a swirling design signed with a florid “B.” The drawing is a lasting statement that this liberal-tinctured ski resort town, where he took ballet and fencing lessons, met artists and debated philosophy, had become his second home.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Plan to Fight AIDS in New York
text: New York City was ravaged by AIDS after the first cases were reported more than 30 years ago, and the plague soared to about 14,000 new cases in the state and nearly 8,000 deaths a year in the city in the early 1990s. Since then, medication and prevention programs have lowered new infections with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to about 3,000 a year and far fewer deaths. Now Gov. Andrew Cuomo has announced that he wants New York to reduce new infections to 750 by 2020, about the same as the number of new tuberculosis cases each year.

headline: Fair Compensation for G.M.’s Victims
text: Kenneth Feinberg, the lawyer who oversaw the Sept. 11, 2001, victims’ fund, has outlined a pretty good plan to compensate people for the deaths and injuries caused by a defective ignition switch that General Motors used in 2.6 million cars. If implemented properly, the plan could speed payments to victims and their families, some of whom have waited years for G.M. to even acknowledge the defect, without forcing them to sue the company.

headline: Canadian Antispam Law Whips Up a Storm of Last-Minute Messages
text: OTTAWA — The email has all the markings of malicious spam: an overwrought subject line screaming “Urgent Action Required,” a message directing the recipient to click a mysterious link.

headline: Argentine Fans Feel Right at Home
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Tens of thousands of soccer fans came from all parts of Argentina. It does not matter that there were no tickets left for the match. This seemed an irrelevance. The main thing was to have been here, and to have witnessed Argentina take on Switzerland.

headline: People of Influence
text: You can’t make this up. The Guardian reported on Sunday that Ukrainians have crowdfunded the first “people’s drone” to help their army stem infiltration by Russian-supported rebels in Ukraine’s eastern provinces that border Russia. “Last week, Ukraine’s crowdfunding site ‘The People’s Project’ said that it had received enough donations to fund a drone,” The Guardian reported. “The organizers had originally hoped to buy a state-of-the-art Israeli drone — for $165,000 — or a cheaper American one costing $120,000.
