In the end, however, they managed to build the drone for just $35,000. A designer and other volunteers built the airframe, with a Ukrainian military institute chipping in technical equipment.”

headline: Union Dues and the Court
text: Should public employees be required to pay union dues, even if they don't join the union that represents them? If not, what effect would that have on organized labor?

headline: Dov Charney Fights to Regain Control of American Apparel
text: Dov Charney, the ousted chief of American Apparel, is forcing a stunning showdown with the company’s board, full of twists and turns that few could have predicted when he was fired just two weeks ago.

headline: GoDaddy Tries to Move Further From Innuendo
text: TWO years after GoDaddy began moving away from sexually provocative advertising that sharply divided consumers, the company is seeking to help accelerate the shift with a change in creative agencies.

headline: Marion Barry in His Own Words
text: The former Washington mayor reflects on his life and his new memoir.

headline: Hobby Lobby Is Only the Beginning
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — THE United States Constitution speaks of the Supreme Court’s jurisdiction over “cases” and “controversies.” But when social controversies do come before the court, its powers are limited. In Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, which concerned the dispute over the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptive mandate, the court may have decided the case. The larger controversy, however, won’t be settled so easily.

headline: Nutrition Group Lobbies Against Healthier School Meals It Sought, Citing Cost
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration in 2012 announced long-awaited changes to require more fruits and vegetables and less sugar and salt in government-subsidized school meals, no group celebrated more than the School Nutrition Association.

headline: A Vandalism Spree Leaves Behind a Trail of Broken Glass and Frustration
text: Seated at the wheel of his nine-year-old Saturn on Tuesday morning, the engine running, the driver’s side window broken into a million pieces, Aharon Charnov patiently spoke into his cellphone.

headline: Twitter’s Revolving Door Spins Again
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter’s chief executive, Dick Costolo, has replaced virtually every crucial executive at the company in the last few months as he has struggled to figure out how to get more people using the service.

headline: Tourists on Trial in a North Korea Angry at the U.S.
text: North Korea’s decision to put two detained American tourists on trial for unexplained hostile acts may have nothing to do with what they did, and instead could reflect the isolated nation’s frustration that it is no longer viewed as a front-burner issue for the United States, experts on North Korean behavior said on Tuesday.

headline: Limits to Books in Prison Draw Creative Foes
text: LONDON — Jailed for making false expense claims, Denis MacShane, a former British lawmaker, suffered another blow when he arrived last December at Belmarsh prison, a grim penitentiary in southeast London, and staff members confiscated the bag of books he had brought.

headline: In Once-Mighty A.L. East, Everyone Can Dream
text: Tanyon Sturtze had just finished golfing in Florida on Tuesday when he took a call about Derek Jeter. He was happy to talk. Sturtze pitched for 12 seasons in the majors, with seven teams, but people ask him more about Jeter than any other teammate.

headline: Barry, Once Washington’s ‘Mayor for Life,’ Tries to Shape Legacy With Autobiography
text: WASHINGTON — The City Council was considering whether to end a three-day waiting period for marriage licenses when Marion S. Barry Jr., a councilman who set the bar for bad mayoral behavior long before Rob Ford came along in Toronto, wondered if three days would be enough time for people to get blood tests.

headline: BNP Paribas Guilty Plea Is Latest Big Settlement to Bolster New York State’s Fiscal Position
text: The financial crisis came at a huge cost to New York State. Thousands of jobs were lost, billions of dollars in revenue evaporated and the state’s reputation suffered a body blow. Now it seems the state is getting pretty good at recouping money from big financial institutions.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Indebted Power Utility Adds to Island’s Problems
text: Puerto Rico’s electrical utility is running out of money and time to negotiate a deal with its lenders, part of a broad reckoning for an island that relies on Wall Street to finance some of its most basic functions.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 1, 2014
text: July 1 , 2014

headline: I.R.S. Commissioner John Koskinen, on Hot Seat, Has History of Bureaucratic Rescue Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — It was clear from the start that John Koskinen, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, was in for a long night.

headline: Valor if Not Victory
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — The great rush and fevered desperation were spent now. Their bodies and chances at victory exhausted, the Americans bent over, collapsed to the ground on their knees and backs, stared ahead at what might have been.

headline: Public Schools in New York City Are Poorer and More Crowded, Budget Agency Finds
text: Schools in New York are becoming more congested, federal and state aid has dropped, and the number of students in “temporary housing situations,” including homeless shelters, has shot up, according to a report on the state of public education the city’s budget oversight agency issued on Tuesday.

headline: Anatoly Kornukov, Who Led Russian Air Force, Dies at 72
text: Gen. Anatoly Kornukov, a retired commander in chief of the Russian Air Force who in 1983 relayed the order to shoot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 as it strayed into Soviet airspace, killing all 269 aboard, died on Tuesday in Krasnogorsk, near Moscow. He was 72.

headline: As N.B.A. Free Agency Opens, Anthony Is the Star
text: The Chicago Bulls were prepared for Carmelo Anthony’s arrival. Video boards outside the United Center featured “Melo” next to the team’s logo. Huge depictions of Anthony wearing a Bulls uniform festooned the side of the building. It was apparent that with months to plan the festivities, the team’s graphics department had been busy.

headline: Deadlock in Congress Appears to Worsen as Midterms Loom
text: WASHINGTON — With immigration legislation dead for the year, Congress has a very short must-do list as relations between the two parties, already miserable, seem to be getting worse in the buildup to the midterm elections.

headline: Holiday on Friday: Independence Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: My Head’s Exploding
text: WASHINGTON — W. cut off Dick Cheney.

headline: Deeply Divided Israel Unites in Grief and Sees a Larger Purpose
text: SHAALVIM, Israel — For many Israelis, Tuesday was a day when the national became the personal, and the personal became communal. A day after their bodies were found, the three Israeli teenagers who were kidnapped and killed by suspected Palestinian militants in the West Bank were buried side by side, wrapped in Israeli flags, in a joint funeral that was intimate and attended by a multitude.

headline: Printed Points of View
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen are back after Mr. Chen ably assisted Mr. Shlakman in his New York Times debut in February. At the time, Mr. Shlakman modestly admitted that Mr. Chen had done the lion’s share of the work and, indeed, Mr. Chen’s name was first in the byline. This time around, however, Mr. Shlakman’s name is first, and it makes me wonder if that’s a sign that he’s acquiring the constructing skills needed to eventually publish under a solo byline. That would be great, because then I could finally use the headline “Shlak’s Blocks Rock Socks.”

headline: Record-Setting Effort by Howard, but Belgium Ousts U.S.
text: Tim Howard made his first save 43 seconds in and he ended the game with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in the World Cup since 1966.

headline: Eligibility for Health Insurance Was Not Properly Checked, Audit Finds
text: WASHINGTON — An independent audit of insurance exchanges established under the health care law has found that federal and state officials did not properly check the eligibility of people seeking coverage and applying for subsidies, the latest indication of unresolved problems at HealthCare.gov.

headline: Lloyd Garrison, 83, Journalist; Covered Africa for The Times
text: Lloyd Garrison, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered conflicts in Africa during the 1960s, including a secessionist war in Nigeria that resulted in more than a million deaths, died on June 21 at his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 83.

headline: A New Leader for Newark
text: Ras J. Baraka was sworn in as mayor on Tuesday outside the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.

headline: Protesters in California Delay Transfer of Migrants
text: LOS ANGELES — Three buses carrying migrant families caught illegally crossing the Texas border with Mexico were turned away from a Southern California Border Patrol station on Tuesday afternoon when dozens of angry protesters met them with American flags and signs reading, “Illegals out.”

headline: Yankees Could Use Price, but They May Not Be Able to Get Him
text: In the days before the luxury tax, and in an era when the Yankees’ farm system was flush with potential superstars, obtaining a former Cy Young Award winner like David Price seemed almost inevitable. Conceivably, the Yankees in those days could have acquired almost anybody they wanted.

headline: Lillian B. Rubin, 90, Is Dead; Wrote of Crippling Effects of Gender and Class Norms
text: Lillian B. Rubin, a sociologist and psychotherapist who wrote a series of popular books about the crippling effects of gender and class norms on human potential, died June 17 at her home in San Francisco. She was 90.

headline: Benghazi Suspect Said to Corroborate Important Details of Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — The militia leader who has been charged in connection with the 2012 killing of the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, has provided American interrogators with “voluntary statements” that corroborate “key facts” about the attacks, the Justice Department said in a court document filed Tuesday night.

headline: Envoy to Afghanistan and Pakistan Will Leave Post
text: WASHINGTON — James F. Dobbins, the veteran diplomat who has served as the United States special envoy for Afghanistan and Pakistan, is leaving government this month, following a tumultuous year in which the Obama administration settled on a plan for withdrawing American forces from Afghanistan but ran into a roadblock in trying to pursue peace talks with the Taliban.

headline: Protesters in Hong Kong Confront Beijing Over Elections
text: Huge crowds of demonstrators took to the streets of Hong Kong on Tuesday to express their support for democracy and discontent with the Chinese central government’s desire to control how the territory’s chief executive is elected.

headline: Factors Supporting Khattala’s Detention
text: Federal prosecutors argued that Ahmed Abu Khattala should remain in custody until trial because he posed a continued threat to the United States.

headline: France: European Rights Court Upholds French Ban on Veils
text: The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a French ban on wearing face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms and bolstering opponents of strict Islamic dress in other parts of Europe. The ban, which took effect three years ago, set French authorities on a collision course with conservative Muslims who said the wearing of such veils by women was an obligation of their faith. Judges at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, said Tuesday that the ban was a legitimate attempt to preserve the norms of France’s diverse society and that it did not infringe on Europe’s Convention on Human Rights. The court was ruling on a case brought by an unidentified Frenchwoman who said the law was discriminatory and violated her freedom of conscience. The 24-year-old woman, a college graduate, requested anonymity for fear of reprisals if her identity became known. France was the first country in Europe to enact such a ban, followed by Belgium.

headline: After Retreat, Iraqi Soldiers Fault Officers
text: AIN AL-TAMR, Iraq — The forlorn scenes in the ancient Al-Ukhaidir fortress tell of a government force in deep disarray. Flies circle beneath its high ceilings, above dozens of demoralized men who pass the day sleeping on dusty stone floors.

headline: Christian Führer, East German Whose Prayers Inspired Protests, Dies at 71
text: BERLIN — The Rev. Christian Führer, the “pastor in the denim vest” whose prayer meetings for peace grew into mass demonstrations in 1989 that inspired East Germans to take to the streets to demand their right to freedom, died on Monday in Leipzig, Germany. He was 71.

headline: Wimbledon Mixed Doubles Team Takes a Partnership to Heart
text: WIMBLEDON, England — On Sunday, a relentless drizzle peppered the All England Club for a third successive afternoon, but on the practice courts little could dampen the spirits of Martin Emmrich and Michaella Krajicek, the German-Dutch mixed doubles partners who became engaged two weeks ago.

headline: The Light and Luxurious Look for the Fourth of July
text: Dressing for the Fourth of July, it’s easy to get lost in the red-white-and-blue stars and stripes mindset, or wrapped up in the sea of colorful summery prints. But opting for a few simple, neutral pieces with subtle graphic touches will keep things light and luxurious, and make for more of a statement this weekend against the backdrop of star-spangled fireworks. A tame terry cloth cape from Lisa Marie Fernandez adds drama when layered over simple swimsuits, like this maillot from Eres. Calm separates and accessories — two-toned sandals, a basic tote — round out a minimalist look. And an oversize but understated piece of jewelry, like this cuff from Céline, is just enough to pull it all together.

headline: In the Hills of Mexico, Patrón Processes Agave the Old-School Way
text: Patrón Spirits International distills small batches of premium tequila and tequila-based liquors at its rambling hacienda in Atotonilco, a small town in Mexico’s hilly Jalisco region that’s crawling with Weber Blue agave, a key ingredient for the local tequila industry there. Since 1989, the company’s co-founders, Martin Crowly and John Paul DeJoria (of John Paul Mitchell Systems Hair Care Company), and its master distiller, Francisco Alcaraz, have crafted high-end tipples like the amber-tinted Patrón Añejo that today are distributed to 120 countries around the world. Recently, they opened the doors to the Hacienda de Patrón distillery, erected in 2002 and closed to the public ever since, for a behind-the-scenes look at how its small-batch products are made, including a new range of 100 percent agave tequilas being released this month.

headline: BlaBlaCar, a Ride-Sharing Start-Up in Europe, Looks to Expand Its Map
text: LONDON — In France, Charlotte Jurdieu has become part of the millions in the sharing economy.

headline: Can Exercise Reduce Alzheimer’s Risk?
text: Exercise may help to keep the brain robust in people who have an increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease, according to an inspiring new study. The findings suggests that even moderate amounts of physical activity may help to slow the progression of one of the most dreaded diseases of aging.

headline: Word of the Day | stealth
text: stealth •\ˈstelth\• noun

headline: Mets Cling to Glimmers of Hope After Loss to Braves
text: ATLANTA — Terry Collins sat slumped in a chair and looked down. The Mets had just lost to the Braves, 5-4, had fallen a season-worst 10 games below .500 and were now nine games behind the Braves, who were atop the National League East. Collins, the Mets’ manager, had just been asked how the team could save its season before it slipped away for good.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 7 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON (2008) Brad Pitt received an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Benjamin Button, a man born in his 80s in 1918 New Orleans, who ages in reverse into the 21st century, in this adaptation of a short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cate Blanchett, above with Mr. Pitt, is Daisy, the dancer who loves Benjamin at whatever stage he is in. And Taraji P. Henson, who was also nominated, is the nursing home caretaker who raises him when his father abandons him. From Fitzgerald’s “odd, somewhat unpromising kernel, the director David Fincher and the screenwriter Eric Roth have cultivated a lush, romantic hothouse bloom, a film that shares only a title and a basic premise with its literary source,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film “sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist’s condition in a spirit that owes more to Jorge Luis Borges than to Fitzgerald.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 2, 2014
text: “Japan is experiencing a security renaissance. What is remarkable is not that things are changing, but that they are changing with so little fanfare.”

headline: Corrections: July 2, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: After Uproar, European Regulators Question Facebook on Psychological Testing
text: Facebook could be in hot water with Europe’s privacy regulators.

headline: Remembering the Rebbe
text: Pilgrims from around the world gathered at the grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson on the 20th anniversary of his death.

headline: Arab Boy’s Death Escalates Clash Over Abductions
text: JERUSALEM — The abduction and killing of a Palestinian teenager whose burned body was found in a Jerusalem forest on Wednesday further poisoned relations between Israelis and Palestinians and prompted international outrage as the police investigated the death as a possible Israeli revenge killing.

headline: In Hong Kong, a Potent Visual Echo of Tiananmen
text: Cecilia Ng was born seven years after the Goddess of Democracy statue in Tiananmen Square was destroyed during the bloody 1989 suppression of student-led protests. A quarter-century after the crackdown in Beijing, she and 10 of her friends made a smaller replica of the statue that on Tuesday was planted in the middle of one of central Hong Kong’s busiest streets.

headline: Time-Lapse Video Shows Steady Stream of Hong Kong Protesters
text: Just how many people participated in Hong Kong’s pro-democracy march on Tuesday? As often is the case with protests, the number is a matter of dispute. Organizers say 510,000 people participated, while a Hong Kong police spokeswoman said only that a maximum of 98,600 joined the march at any given time, without giving an estimate for the overall total.

headline: Student Crossword | Westward Expansion
text: Test your knowledge of westward expansion by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: U.S. Vessel to Tote Poison Gas From Syria to Sea
text: ROME — A specially equipped United States vessel, the Cape Ray, loaded toxic chemicals at an Italian port on Wednesday for destruction at sea in the latest phase of an operation to remove and destroy about 1,300 tons of Syrian chemical weapons.

headline: Roche to Pay Up to $1.7 Billion for Seragon Pharmaceuticals
text: LONDON – The Swiss drug maker Roche Group said on Wednesday that it would pay up to $1.7 billion to acquire Seragon Pharmaceuticals, a privately held biotechnology firm focused on developing treatments for breast cancer.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | All Jooked Up With Everywhere to Go
text: In “All Jooked Up With Everywhere to Go,” Alastair Macaulay writes about jookin, a street dance born in Memphis.

headline: Accusations ‘Grotesque,’ Nicolas Sarkozy Says of Inquiry
text: PARIS — Hours after being put under formal investigation in a corruption and influence-peddling case, Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, lashed out at the prosecution on Wednesday, saying again that he is innocent and expressing outrage at a case he said was being manipulated for political ends.

headline: War’s Lingering Requiem in Vietnam
text: I was 13 when Saigon fell in 1975. I watched the evening news as the last American helicopter lifted off from the United States Embassy roof. In 1977, in the closet of a rented house, I discovered a pile of dusty Life magazines that pictured the Vietnam War: dust, heat, blood, tanks and helicopters, faces contorted with pain and desperation or just impenetrable. 1966, 1967, 1968. Tet, Hue, Khe Sanh, the Perfume River, Ben Tre, Dak To. Dates and names that grabbed and held.

headline: Can the G.O.P. Be a Party of Ideas?
text: In May, a handful of prominent legislators gathered at a Beltway think tank, along with some writers and policy experts, to discuss, as the event’s organizers somberly put it, “conservative policy options to further the prosperous society President Lyndon Johnson described in his ‘Great Society’ address 50 years ago.” If this seemed strange, the venue and cast were even stranger: the American Enterprise Institute, a bastion of right-leaning ideology, filled with Republicans, speaking in a language most unlike the one we’ve heard in recent years.

headline: Destination Maternity Rebuffed Twice in Bid for British Retailer Mothercare
text: LONDON — Destination Maternity, the operator of A Pea in the Pod and Motherhood Maternity stores in the United States, said on Wednesday that it had been rebuffed twice recently in takeover approaches to Mothercare, a British retailer of maternity and children’s products.

headline: Nestlé to Sell Juicy Juice Brand to Brynwood Partners
text: LONDON – The food giant Nestlé said on Wednesday that it would sell its Juicy Juice brand of fruit drinks to the buyout firm Brynwood Partners, a frequent buyer of the Swiss company’s castoffs.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Wet Weather Ahead
text: Good morning on this steamy Wednesday.

headline: Cybercrime Scheme Uncovered in Brazil
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Security researchers have uncovered what they believe is a significant cybercrime operation in Brazil that took aim at $3.75 billion in transactions by Brazilians.

headline: China Sees Long Road to Cleaning Up Pollution
text: A trickle of statements from Chinese leaders in recent months have given hope to some residents of Beijing and other smog-choked Chinese cities that they might regularly breathe clean air within a few years. Prime Minister Li Keqiang in March declared a “war against pollution,” for instance.

headline: ING Group Raises $2 Billion in I.P.O. of Insurer NN Group
text: LONDON – The Dutch financial services company ING Group raised 1.5 billion euros, or about $2 billion, in the long-anticipated initial public offering for the NN Group, its European and Japanese insurance and investment management arm.

headline: Morning Views
text: “Kenneth Feinberg, the lawyer who oversaw the Sept. 11, 2001, victims’ fund, has outlined a pretty good plan to compensate people for the deaths and injuries caused by a defective ignition switch that General Motors used in 2.6 million cars,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “If implemented properly, the plan could speed payments to victims and their families, some of whom have waited years for G.M. to even acknowledge the defect.” The fund “will not satisfy everybody,” the board writes, and G.M. could do more. “No amount of money is ever going to be sufficient to compensate families for deaths or serious injuries. But that should not stop G.M. from doing all it can to help the people who have been hurt by its mistakes.”

headline: Oscar Pistorius at Increasing Risk of Suicide, Lawyer Says
text: LONDON — A psychologist’s report read by the defense at the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius on Wednesday said the disabled athlete — once a major draw at international track meets, including the Olympics — was at increasing risk of suicide without treatment for post-traumatic stress and depression brought on by the killing of his girlfriend last year.

headline: How I Learned to Build and Appreciate a Good Board
text: When I started Posse, I knew nothing about company boards or their value. The family lawyer who helped establish our companies suggested that I create a board before I raised our first investment round and that I try to find some high profile people to join it. His objective was to make the team slide in my presentation deck look as impressive as possible. Off I went to enlist some big name folks to join my not-yet-established company.

headline: Everyone Expects the Spanish Inquisition
text: LONDON — Something completely different was never going to be on the menu. The record-breaking ticket sales generated by the news that members of the fabled comedy team Monty Python would be reassembling here for a rare onstage reunion were surely not generated by hopes that the old boys had come up with new tricks.

headline: Where the Christian Right Is Strong
text: The religious right remains one of the most potent forces in American politics, but Northeasterners could be forgiven for forgetting. Evangelical Christians and Mormons, the two religious groups who most consistently espouse conservative political and cultural views, are basically absent in the Northeastern corridor.

headline: Assigning a Dollar Value to Being the Incumbent
text: What is an incumbency worth? About half a million dollars, mostly from business political action committees who know cementing ties to established politicians is a top priority.

headline: Daily Report: Management Changes at Twitter Suggest a Company in Turmoil
text: Twitter’s chief executive, Dick Costolo, has replaced virtually every crucial executive at the company in the last few months as he has struggled to figure out how to get more people using the service, Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac report.

headline: Uphill Fight for a Territory’s Democracy Movement
text: HONG KONG — A pro-democracy march held Tuesday by a huge crowd of mostly young demonstrators showed the determination of many of this autonomous Chinese city’s residents to preserve and expand the freedom they inherited from British rule. But it also brought to light more challenges that may lie ahead.

headline: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Chief Has ‘Curable’ Cancer
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was “curable.” Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the “original site” and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as “excellent.”

headline: FinecoBank Shares Rise in Trading Debut in Italy
text: FinecoBank, an online banking and brokerage arm of the Italian lender UniCredit, made its debut on Wednesday on the Borsa Italiana in Milan after its initial public offering last week.

headline: 1939: Americans See Faith on the Rise
text: NEW YORK — Dr. Henry C. Link, secretary and treasurer of the Psychological Corporation, which conducts surveys and advises on personnel, announced today [July 2] that more persons in the United States today thought that religion was gaining in influence than thought that it was losing, according to a nation-wide poll. Two years ago, he said, a survey showed that the situation was the other way around. ‘‘An interesting sidelight which comes out of the study,’’ Dr. Link reported, ‘‘is that more people in the high than in the low income groups believe that religion is gaining, in influence.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, July 3, 1939.

headline: Ira Glass’s ‘This American Life’ Leaves PRI
text: Ira Glass had lost his voice. That gentle, reliably nasal, public radio staple of a voice had been worked hoarse. On any given day, this would be an issue for Mr. Glass, 55, whose award-winning show, “This American Life,” is broadcast on nearly 600 stations and is consistently the top podcast on iTunes.

headline: European Regulators Sign Off on Telefónica’s Deal for E-Plus
text: LONDON – European antitrust regulators on Wednesday signed off on the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica’s long-awaited acquisition of Germany’s smallest mobile operator, E-Plus.

headline: Iraqi Premier Places Unity Second to Fighting ISIS
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi prime minister, in an apparent rebuff to his international critics, said Wednesday that finding a political settlement to the differences among the country’s factions was not as important or urgent as fighting extremist Sunni insurgents.

headline: Crazy Love on the Platform
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Feeling For | A Home Scenter That Design Aesthetes Can Appreciate
text: For those who consider fragrance an invisible form of art, the olfactive medium has suddenly become much more visible these days, with an influx of objets d’art dedicated to perfuming the air. Now on display at Commune Design in Los Angeles: a rather rare trio of wooden “scenters” designed by the natural perfumer Haley Alexander van Oosten, the nose behind L’Oeil Du Vert. Crafted from vintage Douglas fir and redwood sourced from furniture makers and local dealers, each piece is entirely unique (as noted by the organic knots and cracks in the grain) and fastened with bronze and copper hardware. Inside, a handblown glass tube holds a custom aromatic oil, composed of California flora, amber and smoky notes, that transforms into a cold vapor to scent your environs.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Sugar-Free
text: The Challenge: A 53-year-old woman has episodes of confusion caused by big drops in her blood sugar. Can you figure out why?

headline: Tyson Foods Reaches Formal Deal for Hillshire Brands
text: Tyson Foods formally struck a deal on Wednesday to buy Hillshire Brands for $7.7 billion, weeks after winning a quick bidding war for the company, which makes Jimmy Dean sausage.

headline: Fast and Easy Photo Albums for Printing
text: Fast and Easy

headline: Slain by a Samurai Who Covets a Wife
text: A love triangle, one of those timeless romantic woes right up there with unrequited devotion, is at the heart of “Kaidan Chibusa no Enoki” (“The Ghost Tale of the Wet Nurse Tree”), a 19th-century Japanese ghost story that begins a short run at the Lincoln Center Festival this week. It is the third festival visit by Heisei Nakamura-za, a Kabuki company from Tokyo started by Kanzaburo Nakamura XVIII, who was known for his vibrant and often funny influence on this traditional performance style. Mr. Kanzaburo died in 2012, and his two sons now run the company.

headline: Winner of Bitcoin Auction, Tim Draper, Plans to Expand Currency’s Use
text: Updated, 8:28 p.m. | When the government auctioned nearly 30,000 Bitcoins on Friday, many bidders were looking for a bargain, hoping to buy the virtual currency at a discount and flip it later for a short-term profit.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Abu Khattala Appears Before Judge
text: Good Wednesday morning from an overheated Washington, where temperatures today could approach the century mark.

headline: Named for Princess, Young Player May Yet Rule the Court
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Canadian tennis player Eugenie Bouchard was named for a British princess by a mother with a fascination for the royal family. Twenty years later, that fateful decision has helped endear Bouchard to the fans at Wimbledon.

headline: To Hold Senate, Democrats Rely on Single Women
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The decline of marriage over the last generation has helped create an emerging voting bloc of unmarried women that is profoundly reshaping the American electorate to the advantage, recent elections suggest, of the Democratic Party. What is far from clear is whether Democrats will benefit in the midterm contests this fall.

headline: On a Roll
text: If you have the kind of children who like to stop and watch construction vehicles doing their work, the kind fascinated by anything with wheels, then Brian Floca’s “Five Trucks,” and “Food Trucks!,” written and illustrated by Mark Todd, should find a long-term parking spot on their night tables.

headline: Casting Time as a Lead Character
text: Twenty years ago, Ethan Hawke, sporting a ratty red turtleneck and a scraggly goatee, first worked with Richard Linklater on the set of “Before Sunrise,” playing an impulsive romantic who makes a bold pass at a stranger on a train. Over the next two decades, as Hollywood seemed to retrench into critic-proof franchises, that reckless romanticism continued to animate the friends’ idiosyncratic careers. Altogether, the two men, both Texas born, have made eight unpredictable movies together. On Friday, they will release their most audacious gamble yet, “Boyhood,” a film so formally bold that it is without an exact precedent.

headline: Excavation for Railyard Project Reveals a Hidden Piece of New York City
text: If you think the crush is bad around Pennsylvania Station these days, you should have been here 465 million years ago.

headline: Former Heinz Chief Joins Private Equity Firm Advent as Adviser
text: William R. Johnson, a former chief executive of H.J. Heinz, has joined the private equity firm Advent International as an adviser.

headline: Chinese President’s Visit to South Korea Is Seen as Way to Weaken U.S. Alliances
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Xi Jinping of China arrived in South Korea on Thursday for a state visit to a vital American ally, a move that appears to signal his resolve to unsettle America’s alliances in Northeast Asia and fortify his argument for a new security architecture in the region, with China as the dominant player.

headline: Lynne Cheney: By the Book
text: The author of “James Madison: A Life Reconsidered” says the last book to make her cry was Shel Silverstein’s “The Giving Tree”: “I have to steel myself before I read it to my grandchildren.”

headline: Empowering Words
text: “I have never had a feeling politically,” Abraham Lincoln declared in Philadelphia on his way to the White House, “that did not spring from the sentiments embodied in the Declaration of Independence.” This statement cut to the core of Lincoln’s deepest reflections on politics and philosophy. The question is, what precisely are the “sentiments” embedded in the Declaration? This is an issue with which some of our best historical minds — Carl Becker, Garry Wills, Pauline Maier — have grappled.

headline: Orange Decides Not to Pursue Deal in French Mobile Market
text: LONDON – Consolidation in the French telecommunications market looks to be on hold for now.

headline: McAllister and Ford and Cianci: Second-Chance Politicians Out in Force
text: Electoral seasons often feature a penitent candidate practicing the politics of expiation — apologizing, with or without tears, for some suddenly exposed personal flaw while appealing to voters’ mercy for a second chance. This season is particularly rich, with three sack-clothed candidates trying again.

headline: 1964: Klan Recruiting Drive Starts
text: PHILADELPHIA, Miss. — A drive to recruit new members of the Ku Klux Klan was under way here yesterday and appeared to be meeting with some success. Klan posters displayed at the courthouse attracted groups of interested readers. The drive was initiated by Robert Shelton of Tuscaloosa, Ala., Imperial Grand Wizard of the Klan. Posters were thrown in every yard and doorway in this city of 6,000. The posters make the usual Klan claim that ‘‘White America’’ is threatened by Communism and mongrelization. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 3, 1964.

headline: Rightward Bound
text: In July 1977, a law professor and former official in the Nixon and Ford administrations, Antonin Scalia, joined the editorial board of a new magazine called Regulation. It was decidedly not pro-. Its first issue featured an article in which Scalia expressed his contempt for legislation aimed at the “platitudinous goals of pursuing ‘the public interest’ or preventing ‘sex discrimination.’ ” The use of quotation marks was revealing. Here was Nino Scalia, 41 years old and already fully formed: scathing, self-confident and profoundly at odds with the premises of late-20th-­century American law and life.

headline: Stem Cell Research Papers Are Retracted
text: Two scientific papers that initially electrified biologists by describing an easy way to make stem cells were retracted on Wednesday by the journal that published them after they were found to be riddled with “critical errors.”

headline: Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.: A Village With a Changed Image
text: Two decades ago, Dobbs Ferry, then a working-class village in southern Westchester along the Hudson River, was considered by many the poor stepsister of its immediate neighbors — artsy Hastings-on-Hudson on its southern border and upscale Irvington to the north.

headline: Hong Kong’s Democracy Movement
text: A pro-democracy march underlined the determination of residents to preserve and expand the freedoms that they inherited from British rule.

headline: A Cuisine for the Age of Us – the Anthropocene
text: In late spring, Emma Marris, the author of “Rambunctious Garden: Saving Nature in a Post-Wild World,” wrote “Beyond Food and Evil,” a refreshing essay for the Breakthrough Journal on a new generation of chefs celebrating both nature and technology in their cuisine. Ingredients include lichen powder (see the video above). Technology, including devices like the Thermomix, has a Jetsons feel.

headline: A Hong Kong Protest for Democracy, in Pictures
text: The protests in Hong Kong demanding more democracy began Tuesday night and lasted into the next morning, when the police carted off demonstrators from the Central business district.

headline: Escaping, Literally, in Budapest and Beyond
text: It took only a few minutes after the door locked behind us for the atmosphere in the cramped room to turn tense. A hasty note, left behind on a battered table, warned us that we had only an hour to get out, and it soon became clear that our escape route lay behind a second door.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,200,000
text: SEATTLE

headline: By Design | An L.A. Gallery and Shop So Laid Back, It’s at the Curator’s House
text: The unique geography of Los Angeles — both physical and social — tends to encourage the city’s burgeoning art and design communities, especially on the artist-friendly east side, to think outside the white gallery box. Case in point: a rotating monthly pop-up known as Either Way L.A., a 150-square-foot exhibition space nestled in the garden studio beneath the hillside home of Julia Leonard, an artist and curator, in the bohemian enclave (and emerging microscale design hub) of Echo Park. “I wanted to show people in L.A. some things they haven’t seen yet,” she explains, “in an environment that didn’t feel as precious as a four-wall gallery.” Since she began the project a year ago, Leonard has showcased functional objects by exciting young talents from L.A. and beyond, such as the ceramists Jessica Hans and Morgan Peck. Now up is a show by the artist Dane Johnson, “Paintings You Can Wear,” a collection of garments hand-painted with abstract geometric shapes. Leonard devises each show’s theme in collaboration with the artist or designer on view. “Art can be so hard and harsh and it doesn’t need to be,” Leonard says. “I like the idea of running the gallery as if it’s a group effort.”

headline: Walking the Walk
text: “In the Army there are those who walk the walk, and those who just talk the talk.” My drill sergeant at Fort Knox said this to me more than 30 years ago. What he was implying was that there are jobs for soldiers, and jobs for people who just joined the Army for the college plan or to get some skills training.

headline: Second Try Puts Carbon Observatory Into Orbit
text: NASA’s new spacecraft to sniff carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere reached orbit on Wednesday after launching from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

headline: New York Summer Stories: The Ladies and Their Fans
text: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from the archives of The New York Times that tell tales of New York City summers.

headline: Wall Street Journal Said to Have Cut 20 to 40 Jobs
text: The Wall Street Journal has cut between 20 and 40 staff members in recent weeks, according to people with knowledge of the matter, as part of a re-evaluation of its newsroom that came at the end of its financial year.

headline: House Hunting in ... Turkey
text: A DUPLEX APARTMENT IN A HISTORIC BUILDING IN CENTRAL ISTANBUL

headline: Paris Fashion Trade Group Selects New Leader
text: In the fashion industry, the Paris couture shows, which begin this weekend, still reign supreme.

headline: Benghazi Attack Suspect Ordered Held Until Trial
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the Libyan militia leader charged in connection with the 2012 killing of the American ambassador and three others in Benghazi must remain in government custody and be held without bond.

headline: Defending Champion Is Dethroned by Another Young Star
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon is only one tournament, but in many minds it is the biggest, grandest stage in tennis. So let the speculation begin that cracks in the wall of dominance enjoyed by the group known as the Big 4 of the men’s game may have finally appeared during Wimbledon’s second week.

headline: Radical Chic
text: Subcultures have long used visual cues to signal allegiances, both to individuals within a movement and to outsiders. Goths wore corsets and black nail polish; punks sported mohawks and tore up the queen’s tartan plaid. Neo-Nazis were recognizable by their shaved heads, bomber jackets and Doc Martens.

headline: Why More Start-Ups Are Sharing Ideas Without Legal Protection
text: In 2011, Andy Moeck was looking for investors for Moeo, a Los Angeles start-up he was building that makes mobile gaming apps based on real-time sporting events. A friend introduced Mr. Moeck to a partner at the Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, and at their first meeting, Mr. Moeck asked the partner to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

headline: Wheelies: The Corvette Reunion Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: From Humble-Wear, Fashion-Wear
text: HAS THE JUMPSUIT become standard-issue daywear for elite Manhattan women not convicted of securities fraud? How did I miss such a significant historical development?

headline: When Halibut Was Plentiful
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Food News: Fresh Halibut Now in Peak Supply” appeared on June 19 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: A Bright Side to Facebook’s Experiments on Its Users
text: Facebook’s disclosure last week that it had tinkered with about 700,000 users’ news feeds as part of a psychology experiment conducted in 2012 inadvertently laid bare what too few tech firms acknowledge: that they possess vast powers to closely monitor, test and even shape our behavior, often while we’re in the dark about their capabilities.

headline: Letters: ‘The Letters of Robert Frost’
text: ‘The Letters of Robert Frost’

headline: Unarmed Drones Aid U.N. Peacekeeping Missions in Africa
text: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The call came after 8 in the evening, from peacekeepers posted in a remote corner of the country’s restive east. The troops sensed suspicious movement nearby. Venturing out into the forest at that hour was far too risky. Would ground control send a drone to have a look?

headline: Woman Chasing Her Dog Is Killed by Garbage Truck
text: It is a daily ritual for many New Yorkers who share an apartment with a dog: the walk around the block.

headline: Should Start-Ups Share Their Ideas Without Getting an N.D.A.?
text: In 2011, as we explain in an article we just published, Andy Moeck was looking for investors for Moeo, a Los Angeles start-up he was building that makes mobile gaming apps based on real-time sporting events. At a meeting at the Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, Mr. Moeck asked a partner to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

headline: An Alternative World Cup
text: While many soccer fans’ eyes were riveted on Brazil, a group of would-be nation-states met in Sweden last month in the ConIFA World Cup, a tournament for teams not recognized by the sport’s governing body.

headline: Suit Seeks to Block Corcoran Takeover
text: When the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington — one of the nation’s oldest privately supported museums — announced in May that its artwork, landmark building and venerable school would be taken over by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University, the arrangement was presented as a done deal.

headline: Robin Thicke Hears the Vultures Tweet
text: Every now and again — almost every day, really — the Internet demands a head on a platter, and this week, it came for Robin Thicke’s.

headline: More Casting Announced for ‘An American in Paris’ Musical
text: Casting has been announced for the new musical version of George Gershwin’s “An American In Paris,” directed and choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon, that is to open in Paris in December. The New York City Ballet principal Robert Fairchild, and the Royal Ballet dancer Leanne Cope, had already been named for the roles of Jerry Mulligan and Lise Dassin. Joining them will be actors who have worked both on and off Broadway: Veanne Cox as Madame Baurel, Jill Paice as the society heiress Milo Davenport, Brandon Uranowitz as Adam Hochberg and Max von Essen as Henri Baurel.

headline: Subaru to Recall Vehicles With Takata Air Bag Inflators
text: Subaru says it will recall about 8,500 Legacy, Outback and Baja cars from the 2003-4 model years because they are equipped with defective Takata air bag inflators, Michael McHale, a spokesman for the automaker, said on Tuesday.

headline: Corinthian Colleges Is Closing. Its Students May Be Better Off as a Result.
text: Late last month, Corinthian Colleges, a publicly traded for-profit higher education company that enrolls 72,000 students at over 100 campuses nationwide, announced its imminent bankruptcy.

headline: Trick or Tweak
text: Sam Tanenhaus asks, “Can the G.O.P. Be a Party of Ideas?”

headline: The Fleeting Benefits of Overseas Corporate Marriages
text: Tax-arbitrage mergers and acquisitions require a deep discount. American companies seeking to relocate by mergers in a bid to slash how much they pay Uncle Sam were a big part of the $1.8 trillion first-half deal boom. The benefits of such ill-conceived combinations will be fleeting, though. The more so-called inversions there are, the more likely the law is to change.

headline: Russia Demands New Cease-Fire in Ukraine as Foreign Ministers Seek Path to Peace
text: MOSCOW — In a stern warning that cited civilian casualties in war-torn eastern Ukraine, Russia on Wednesday demanded that the Ukrainian government reinstate a cease-fire and halt its military operation aimed at suppressing the pro-Russian separatist insurrection that has destabilized the region for more than three months.

headline: 8 Afghan Air Force Officers Killed in Suicide Bombing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed eight Afghan Air Force officers on Wednesday after boarding a bus carrying them through central Kabul, in one of the first major attacks in the capital in months.

headline: Mourning, And Rioting, Over Death In Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — As police tear gas wafted through his East Jerusalem neighborhood, the father of a slain 16-year-old Arab, the possible victim of a Jewish revenge attack, mourned with friends who had come to console him Wednesday on the enclosed porch of his two-story stone house. He had just spent seven hours with police investigators.

headline: A New York Concert to Honor Mandela, and Stream Online
text: To celebrate Mandela Day on July 18 – which would have been Nelson Mandela’s 96th birthday – the composer and producer Joel A. Martin, and the South African playwright, director and choreographer Welcome Msomi, have assembled “Footsteps of Mandela,” a style-crossing work for choir, percussionists and solo voices from the jazz and opera worlds. Mr. Martin and Mr. Msomi will present the work at Riverside Church, where Mandela spoke on several occasions. Mr. Martin said in a telephone interview that he also hoped the performance would be streamed live on the Internet, in high-definition video, but that he was still seeing to the details.

headline: Paris Court Rejects Guggenheim Descendants’ Claim Over Venice Palazzo
text: PARIS — A court here on Wednesday issued a ruling that permits the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to display art as it sees fit in the Venetian palazzo given to it by the wealthy collector Peggy Guggenheim.

headline: Janet Yellen Signals She Won’t Raise Rates to Fight Bubbles
text: Janet Yellen just delivered the most significant speech yet in her still-young Federal Reserve chairmanship. It doesn’t necessarily send any startling signals about what the Fed will do next month or even next year. But it tells us a great deal about how she will deal with new risks on the horizon from financial bubbles.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Bok Choy
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: U.S. Privacy Panel Backs N.S.A.’s Internet Tapping
text: WASHINGTON — The federal privacy board that sharply criticized the collection of the phone records of Americans by the National Security Agency has come to a starkly different conclusion about the agency’s exploitation of Internet connections in the United States to monitor foreigners communicating with one another abroad.

headline: China Expels 3 Officials in Corruption Inquiry
text: SHANGHAI — The ruling Communist Party in China expelled three government officials on Wednesday who had ties to Zhou Yongkang, a former member of the powerful Politburo Standing Committee. The expulsions were the latest sign that officials were preparing to announce charges against Mr. Zhou himself.

headline: Today in Small Business: Speed-Dating
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: “Harlan County” by Loudon Wainwright
text: An exclusive premiere of a song from the album Haven’t Got The Blues (Yet).

headline: Breezy Looks to Spruce Up Your Summer Wardrobe
text: It’s the Fourth of July, high time to embrace the breezy, lighthearted look of the season. (The young women below have it down.) Here are a few ideas — a flirty new miniskirt, a nervy manicure — to brighten your summer turnout and your outlook.

headline: Reactions to Death of Palestinian Youth
text: Palestinian and Israeli officials and a relative of the slain teenager, whose body was found in a Jerusalem forest early Wednesday, discussed the kidnapping and killing.

headline: Gin, London Style
text: Gin is the quintessential summertime tipple in Britain, but the traditional Wimbledon gin punch Pimm’s No.1 Cup has some fresh competition: the Gin & Tonics Garden, a pop-up bar on a secluded lane within the extensive grounds of the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens in London.

headline: No One Expects the Caliphate
text: The latest issue of the New Republic includes an essay by Mark Lilla, cited in a pessimistic column by my colleague David Brooks, that’s one of the richer takes on our present political-cultural big picture that I’ve read in some time. I’ve been looking for a news peg on which to hang some comments on Lilla’s argument, and I think I’ve found one in the news that the ISIS terrorist organization, a.k.a. the de facto government of eastern Syria and western Iraq, has taken the high-risk step of actually declaring a reborn caliphate in its conquered territory. The connection here is that one of Lilla’s themes is the way our ongoing end-of-history era has constricted the Western political imagination, leaving us unable to reckon with the complexities of a wider world where liberal democracy isn’t obviously spreading anymore:

headline: Weaning Older Patients Off Sleeping Pills
text: “Deprescribe.” It’s a word I hadn’t encountered before, but Dr. Cara Tannenbaum, who holds an endowed chair in geriatric pharmacy at the University of Montreal, told me that “it’s been popping up with exponential frequency” in medical journals and conversations among geriatricians.

headline: At Thom Browne, It’s Not the Plot, It’s the Wardrobe
text: PARIS — Under a gridded neon light fixture, perched on plinths in rows of five, 20 models in plastic face masks and gray tailored suiting sat silently. They waited, as did the guests facing them, for Thom Browne’s show to start.

headline: 9 Worldly Ways to Make a Burger
text: An American staple with cosmopolitan adaptations.

headline: African Leaders Grant Themselves Immunity in Proposed Court
text: DAKAR, Senegal — African leaders have voted to give themselves immunity from prosecution for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide in an African human rights court that does not yet exist, angering rights groups and puzzling activists on the continent.

headline: Ed Sheeran Hits No. 1
text: Ed Sheeran, a 23-year-old British singer-songwriter who has been championed by Taylor Swift, topped the latest Billboard album chart with his second full album, “x” (Atlantic), beating out Phish’s latest release as well as recent hits by Lana Del Rey and Sam Smith.

headline: SEMA Garage Takes Aftermarket Parts From Concept to Reality
text: The Specialty Equipment Manufacturing Association, better known as SEMA, doesn’t hold its annual trade show until November each year. But the organization’s focus on aftermarket parts has found another, full-time outlet: the SEMA Garage.

headline: Early Nick Drake Recording to Be Auctioned
text: The English folksinger and songwriter Nick Drake made three extraordinary albums between 1969 and 1972, and for many years, that was all there was. The discs, “Five Leaves Left,” “Bryter Layter” and “Pink Moon,” barely sold; Drake’s label, Island, dropped him; and in 1974, at age 26, he died of an overdose of antidepressant medicine.

headline: All of Tim Howard’s 16 Saves Against Belgium
text: Howard made his first save 43 seconds into the game. He finished with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in a World Cup game since 1966.

headline: Washington, Roosevelt, Lincoln ... Howard?
text: When United States goalkeeper Tim Howard knocked down shot after shot in Tuesday’s game against Belgium — recording 16 saves, the most in a World Cup match since at least 1966 — the viewing experience wasn’t at all like watching LeBron James score 60 points or Peyton Manning drill a pass through three defenders for a last-second touchdown.

headline: What’s Gained and Lost as The Times Ends Many Blogs
text: Updated, 1:35 p.m., Thursday

headline: He’s Alone on a Stage, With Tough Characters
text: I don’t know for sure what kind of man Joe Assadourian is. After all, he’s served 12 years in prison for attempted murder. But I can say that he’s one terrific actor, and a very good playwright as well. That much is clear throughout his solo show, “The Bullpen,” which takes an extremely funny look at a particularly dreadful situation.

headline: Judge Whittles Down Insider Trading Charges Against Rajaratnam’s Brother
text: Rengan Rajaratnam, the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, the former billionaire hedge fund manager convicted of insider trading in 2011, is winning the war of attrition in his own insider trading trial.

headline: App Smart | Road Trips
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can make your summer road trip smoother and more memorable.

headline: The Delights and Challenges of French Guiana
text: The 15th-century Treaty of Tordesillas famously divided South America, leaving Portugal much of what would become Brazil, and leaving Spain the rest. Somehow, along the way, the French muscled their way in to grab a foothold. Make that a toehold: French Guiana today makes up just 0.5 percent of the continent and 0.06 percent of its population, yet accounts for, in my estimation, 99 percent of its baguette consumption.

headline: Apps to Plan Summer Road Trips, Down to the Pit Stops
text: A SMARTPHONE screen might seem a terrible distraction on a road trip. With the right apps, though, your phone can make any road trip smoother and more memorable.

headline: Designing a Perfect Summer
text: In January 2013, Richard Ross stood outside a drab brick building in Pawtucket, R.I., a fashion pilgrim drawn to an unlikely mecca. Months earlier, Mr. Ross had learned of a designer there named Kiel James Patrick, or KJP for short, who promotes his line of nautical-inspired bracelets and other apparel robustly through social media.

headline: Hobby Lobby, or When Corporations Get Things Both Ways
text: Among the galling aspects of Monday’s Supreme Court ruling in the Hobby Lobby contraception case is that it made a muddle of the longstanding concept of “corporate separateness.”

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Torn Between Soccer and Shakespeare
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Mood-Lifting Additions to the Nail Scene
text: The popularity of look-at-me nails, with brazen tints and fanciful patterns, shows little sign of abating. Here are some mood-lifting additions to the nail scene.

headline: Janet L. Yellen on Monetary Policy
text: In an event at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, the Federal Reserve chairwoman said that monetary policy faces limitations as a tool to promote financial stability.

headline: What to Call the Extremists in Iraq?
text: Among the fast-shifting events in Iraq in recent days, an added source of confusion has been the name of the Sunni extremist group at the center of the fighting.

headline: Nets Quickly Hire Lionel Hollins as Their Coach
text: The interviews came and went for Lionel Hollins. He met last year with the Los Angeles Clippers and the Denver Nuggets, who opted for other candidates. In recent weeks, more teams called, including the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Los Angeles Lakers. Hollins did what he could to prepare, and then was left to hope for the best.

headline: Man Accused of Killing Brooklyn Boy, 6, in Elevator Pleads Not Guilty
text: The man accused of stabbing a 6-year-old boy to death and wounding a 7-year-old girl in an elevator last month told police officers shortly after they took him into custody, “Satan has powers and controls things.”

headline: Aid From Massachusetts in New Hampshire Race
text: STRATHAM, N.H. — It was a bit of an odd tableau: a former Massachusetts governor endorsing a former Massachusetts senator to represent the people of New Hampshire in the United States Senate.

headline: For Bonobos, a Good Fit in Stores as Well as Online
text: Bonobos, the e-commerce business best known for its well-fitted men’s pants, was never supposed to have brick-and-mortar shops. Then, all of a sudden, they opened a few and money came pouring in.

headline: An Alternative World Cup
text: It was a World Cup full of goals, political intrigue and pressure of an expectant home crowd. Amid equal measures of excitement and agony, penalties decided most of the second round games. In the end, an unlikely champion was crowned.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Sues Over a Character in Grand Theft Auto V
text: Have you ever played Grand Theft Auto V and thought that the minor character Lacey Jonas – a young startlet whom players rescue from pursuing paparazzi – seemed oddly like Lindsay Lohan? Jonas is a slinky blonde, like Ms. Lohan, and some players have noted that she sounds like Ms. Lohan, has a line of clothing like Ms. Lohan’s and has a penchant for complaining about the difficulties of being a star. The game also shows the Chateau Marmont, the West Hollywood hotel where Ms. Lohan racked up a bill of $46,000.

headline: The Perfect Drink for Cookouts (or Dugouts)
text: I finally made it to a New York Times Magazine softball game this week. The Central Park evening was like a happy collision between a Hudson River School painting and a Norman Rockwell. Big blue sky, grand old trees — and scrappy journalists, editors and designers in our team’s bright green T-shirts.

headline: Italian Leader Presses His Case for Budget Relief in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — The presidency of the European Union is largely ceremonial, rotating every six months among the bloc’s 28 nations. But Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy means to use its new presidency as a platform from which to seek relief for his country’s debt-saddled economy.

headline: For Spirits That Can Only Be Tied Down by a Sash
text: GLAMOUR IS A SLIPPERY CONCEPT, defined one season by a neoprene minidress, and the next by a gown cut from stiffened brocade. But in one of those pendulum swings as regular as rent hikes, it is encapsulated this summer in the loose, and louche, kimono, the casual uniform of music festival pilgrims traipsing through Coachella, South by Southwest or Bonnaroo. A stand-in for the trusty jeans jacket or cardigan, the look is being embraced this year by self-styled free spirits of every persuasion.

headline: La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels Opens in NoLIta
text: A sliver of the Sixth Arrondissement has landed on the fringes of NoLIta. An offshoot of La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels, a renowned wine bar in Paris, opened in New York this May with an extensive wine list that would make a Michelin-starred restaurant blush.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, South Africa, Afghanistan and Kenya.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Loudon Wainwright Offers Another Reason It’s Tough to Live in Kentucky
text: In a recent It’s the Economy column, Annie Lowrey wrote about the toughest places to live in America, based on research by the Upshot that focuses on six factors: education, household income, jobless rate, disability rate, life expectancy and obesity rate. Harlan, Ky., like many parts of the Bluegrass State, doesn’t fare so well. The median income is about half that of the country over all, the unemployment rate is more than twice as high and the life expectancy is seven years lower — all factors that make it one of the 25 hardest places to live in the country, according to the Upshot’s analysis.

headline: Gin, Miami Beach Style
text: Como Hotels and Resorts, the Singapore-based brand of 12 upscale properties, recently opened its first hotel in the United States, the Metropolitan by Como, Miami Beach, which claims to have the city’s first artisanal gin bar.

headline: Common Back and Leg Pain Treatment May Not Help Much, Study Says
text: A widely used method of treating a common cause of back and leg pain — steroid injections for spinal stenosis — may provide little benefit for many patients, according to a new study that experts said should make doctors and patients think twice about the treatment.

headline: The Deadly Politics of Revenge
The Devil Went to Midtown to Serenade the Lord
text: If the Devil were as endearingly funny as Randy Newman at the piano, a season in hell might not be so painful. Mr. Newman, the singer-songwriter known for his wry, bluesy tunes with lyrics etched in acid, portrayed the Lord’s nemesis on Tuesday night, in a concert performance of his musical-theater adaptation of Goethe’s “Faust” at City Center.

headline: U.S.A.-Belgium World Cup Game Drew 22 Million Viewers in Ratings
text: With just under 16.5 million viewers on ESPN, and 5.1 million more watching on Univision, the World Cup game on Tuesday between the United States and Belgium was the second-most-viewed soccer game ever on American television, trailing only the United States-Portugal game earlier in this tournament.

headline: They Need to Get in the Game
text: SOMETHING ABOUT THE current Wimbledon has me scratching my head — and it’s not both Williams sisters losing in the third round despite their power groundstrokes, or Li Na and Caroline Wozniacki falling to Barbora Zahlavova-Strycova, who is ranked 43rd. It’s not, in fact, anything to do with playing style at all. Rather, it has to do with players’ style.

headline: Bratton Putting Desk Officers on Streets to Fight New York’s Summer Crime
text: As many as 400 veteran New York City officers assigned to desk jobs in the Police Department will return to the streets this summer as part of a broad push by Commissioner William J. Bratton to head off a seasonal spike in crime.

headline: Mixed Predictions About Wearables Like Smartwatches and Google Glass
text: The wearable computing market will be huge. Actually, it’s a passing fad. (Remember the netbook?) Or it will be a modest hit.

headline: Sweating Out Their Differences
text: WASHINGTON — A new muscle-crushing, sweat-inducing workout has infiltrated the inner sanctum of Congress, the members-only gym of the House of Representatives. And it is called, simply, the “Markwayne Mullin.”

headline: Songs of Love and Heartache, Self-Assured and Bittersweet
text: “Here’s the true love song on the album,” Jenny Scheinman said at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday night, holding her fiddle across her midsection like a mandolin. The album in question was “The Littlest Prisoner” (Sony Masterworks), and the song was “Sacrifice,” a dirgelike drift of rhyming couplets with a single-phrase melody kneaded into shape through repetition. Ms. Scheinman sang its lyrics — addressed first to a husband and then to their small child — with a deliberative heaviness, as in certain kinds of prayer.

headline: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
text: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people — with odd or singular looks — who capture his attention on the street.

headline: Edit Your Facebook and Twitter History
text: Molly Wood explains how to download and delete activity on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: The Apps – and Airplane Blankets – That Track Our Lives
text: A new app could help people with mental illness get timely treatment, by logging their behavior and sending the data to their doctors. But it may also become part of a larger conversation around how much we want our devices keeping track of us.

headline: Swear Off Social Media, for Good or Just for Now
text: SOCIAL media can be a harmless and easy way to keep track of friends, family and news.

headline: Yankees Fall Under .500 as Offensive Struggles Continue
text: Joe Girardi conceded recently that there was not much he could do to rouse the Yankees’ often-lifeless offense. Girardi believes he must be patient and hope that his veteran hitters, who have a record of success, will soon start hitting because big changes to the lineup are unlikely to make much difference.

headline: How to Digitally Avoid Taking It to the Grave
text: Planning for control of your personal information after you die used to be as simple as telling someone about the desk drawer or the fireproof box or the safe deposit box at the local bank.

headline: Weinstein Company Is Said to Consider Spinning Off TV Unit
text: LOS ANGELES — Just seven months after declaring an ambitious thrust into television, the Weinstein Company, best known for its Oscar-winning film operation, is exploring plans to spin off its TV division into a separate company that could be sold to a strategic partner or taken public.

headline: The Facts and Figures Behind Jeff Koons’s Massive, Awe-Inspiring Show at the Whitney
text: Like Jeff Koons himself, “Jeff Koons: A Retrospective,” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is larger than life. The biggest show the institution has ever devoted to a single artist, it sprawls across all four floors, occupying 27,000 square feet of exhibition space. Included among the 145 works on display is a pastel Koons created last year specifically for T. The show also serves as the farewell party for the Whitney’s iconic Marcel Breuer building before the museum relocates to its new Renzo Piano-designed space downtown next year. Here, a few more key figures about this one-of-a-kind, once-in-a-lifetime survey.

headline: Jay Nixon Vetoes a Terrible Abortion Bill
text: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri vetoed an extreme measure on Wednesday that would have tripled his state’s existing mandatory waiting period for women seeking an abortion, to 72-hours.

headline: Janet Yellen Says Fed Will Emphasize Stronger Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that the central bank did not plan to raise interest rates or alter its stimulus campaign to address concerns about excesses in the financial system.

headline: Winner in the Amazon War
text: LOS ANGELES — Nobody expected much from Edan Lepucki’s debut novel. Her publisher planned a tiny first printing of 12,000 copies. She was assigned to an editor with almost no experience. Was there a marketing budget? How cute of her to ask.

headline: Thinking Locally, So Fighting Globally
text: Beth Macy, a longtime reporter for The Roanoke Times in Virginia, understood how lucky she was when she accidentally uncovered the great, gripping story told in “Factory Man.” This is Ms. Macy’s first book, but it’s in a class with other runaway debuts like Laura Hillenbrand’s “Seabiscuit” and Katherine Boo’s “Behind the Beautiful Forevers”: These nonfiction narratives are more stirring and dramatic than most novels. And Ms. Macy writes so vigorously that she hooks you instantly. You won’t be putting this book down.

headline: Playing in a Part of Something Bigger
text: The musicians spilled off the stage when Adam Schatz’s rock band Landlady performed on Tuesday night at Rough Trade NYC. By the end of the set, there were a dozen horn players and half a dozen drummers and percussionists along with Mr. Schatz and Landlady’s core musicians, blaring and pounding as Mr. Schatz pushed the audience to sing along. It was an album party through a show of community. “This is such a special way to feel like you’re a part of something bigger,” Mr. Schatz announced as the musicians assembled. Mr. Schatz, who is also a jazz concert promoter, works with many other bands as well as Landlady, playing rock, funk, jazz, Afrobeat and improvisation. Landlady’s more-or-less pop songs hold a little of them all.

headline: Dutch Women Win European Championship
text: The European Team Championships concluded in Opatija, Croatia, on Tuesday. The results in the women’s and open events were unclear until the last boards were finished.

headline: Sales at Ralo, C. Wonder, Grace & Favor and Warp & Weft
text: Ralo carpets will discount all hand-knotted Tibetan rugs and handmade pillows up to 60 percent from July 5 through July 13 (a 5-by-8-foot Lhasa rug, originally $5,290, will be $2,116); 29 Howard Street (Crosby Street); 212-966-7661, tibetcarpet.com.

headline: Ahoy, Birdie!
text: Haptic Lab, the interdisciplinary design studio of Emily Fischer, a Brooklyn architect, specializes in handmade furniture, quilts and fanciful kites that are produced in collaboration with Balinese artisans.

headline: Out of Indonesia, Vintage Teak Furniture
text: Last year, Teak Me Home opened a 2,000-square-foot showroom in Emeryville, Calif., to sell dressers and tables made from old-growth teak salvaged from 100-year-old Indonesian houses. “The beauty of the aged wood is that there’s more grain in the pattern,” said Alexander Elsinga, the founder. He has just introduced four new dining pieces that, like all Teak Me Home products, are made by hand in its Bay Area workshop. Prices range from $1,699 for a 40-inch round table that grows to a 64-inch oblong to $2,299 for an elliptical table that expands from five to nine feet. Famously durable, teak needs little effort to maintain its patina; a monthly wiping with furniture oil or wood polish will keep the wood “looking brilliant,” Mr. Elsinga said. The company ships nationwide. Information: 510-725-7258 or teakmehome.com.

headline: Our Niches, Our Shelves
text: The prospectus for 44 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, a six-story brick apartment building finished in 1940, promised all sorts of modern amenities: Venetian blinds, concealed radiation, radio outlets in every room. But it neglected to herald one of the building’s niftiest architectural features. In one wall of most of the foyers is an arched bookshelf niche, a Moderne version of the china cabinet. Like china cabinets, the niches were intended to be a place for the display of more than just books — where folks could show off their best (and most carefully edited) selves, as an environmental psychologist might say.

headline: The Women of Men’s Fashion Week
text: Increasingly, female models are showing up on the men’s wear runways in Europe.

headline: Faith, Severely Tested, in a German Commune
text: Don’t believe the title: “Nothing Bad Can Happen” is a veritable smorgasbord of bad, at least for Tore (Julius Feldmeier), the newest member of a punk-rock Christian commune in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: A House That Sips Energy
text: With a voluptuous skin of high-performance fabric, Techstyle Haus is one of 25 projects on display through July 14 at the Solar Decathlon Europe 2014 in Versailles, France. The 800-square-foot amoeba-shaped house was created by students from the Rhode Island School of Design, Brown University and the University of Applied Sciences in Germany to combine passive-house elements with a flexible system of solar panels.

headline: State-Shaped Accessories: Form Follows 50
text: Anyone who visits Mary Jo Otsea and Richard Brown’s home on the Upper East Side can’t help but notice that they have a fondness for a certain kind of Americana. On display in a sideboard is an impressive collection of salt-and-pepper shakers, each shaped like one of the 50 states.

headline: The Court and Gay Therapy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Match: U.S. Colleges vs. World
So Small but Already a TV Star
text: Zack Giffin is an extreme, or “free,” skier and tiny-house booster, having made his home for the last three years in a 112-square-foot mobile “ski chalet.” This year, Mr. Giffin, 34, is a host of a new series, “Tiny House Nation,” beginning Wednesday on FYI, an A & E Networks channel that used to be known as Bio. When we caught up with him by phone last week, he was on the road for the show, which chronicles those who live the tiny-house life. The chalet, he said, was sitting on a trailer “in a lovely field in Lummi Island, Washington State, on my parents’ property, which is where it lives when we are not around.” (He shares it with his girlfriend, Molly Baker, 30, who is also a skier and was away working for a ski sponsor in Austria.) The couple have used their tiny house as an assist to their lifestyle, to help them get close to the mountains, mostly in the Northwest. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Obama in the Polls
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tunisia’s Jews Under Strain
text: To the Editor:

headline: Timeless Manipulators
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Clients Cool
text: After a dramatic family crisis, Pat Law of Singapore quit her job to start a new kind of social media agency.

headline: Civil Rights, Human Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shopping Events Starting July 3
text: Fourth of July

headline: Sleeping in the Afterthought
text: Even before Hurricane Sandy swooped in two years ago and wiped out 15 years of her work at the Battery Conservancy, where she was director of horticulture — in charge of what she thought of as her “23-acre roof garden” — Sigrid Gray had already decided to leave the city.

headline: The Garage That Bloomed
text: For five years now, I have been tending a plot — cultivating hostas, lilies and astilbes, gently trying to persuade a hydrangea bush not to depart this earth — in the Lotus Garden, a community garden on West 97th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue.

headline: Israel’s Justice Minister Condemns ‘Incitement’ on Facebook
text: Israel’s justice minister denounced a Facebook campaign in Israel on Wednesday that called for soldiers to take “revenge” on the Palestinian community as tensions spiked in Jerusalem, where an Arab teenager was kidnapped and killed hours after the funerals for three Jewish teenagers abducted last month in the West Bank.

headline: There Goes the Neighborhood Cafe
text: I OPENED my first restaurant, Union Square Cafe, nearly 30 years ago, at a time when Manhattan rents were low, crime rates were high and the future of the city seemed, even for an optimist like me, to be an open question.

headline: The War on Workers
text: UNIONS have never been uncontroversial in American society, but the battles over labor have grown fiercer in recent years: Witness the fight over public-employee unions in Wisconsin, or the 2012 decision by Michigan lawmakers to join the ranks of “right to work” states.

headline: Shrimp’s New Path to the Plate
text: STOUGHTON, Mass. — In a warehouse south of Boston, miles away from the city’s bustling harbor, James Tran, a semiconductor designer, is incubating an unlikely product: shrimp.

headline: The Words, and Works, of Walter Dean Myers
text: The award-winning young adult author Walter Dean Myers, who died on Tuesday at 76, wrote an Op-Ed piece for The New York Times last March in which he bemoaned the paucity of children’s books about black people.

headline: Barack the Bear
text: The president is growing hostile to being held hostage — both by the very insular nature of the presidency itself, and by the more stultifying intransigence of Congress.

headline: Gay, Widowed and Fighting for What They’re Due
text: While gay rights advocates were encouraged by the federal government’s recent announcement that it would extend more benefits to gay married couples, Gerald Passaro, a 49-year-old former hairstylist, was reflecting on a private victory.

headline: A Guide to Changes in Federal Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
text: The Obama administration made regulatory changes last month   that extend more federal benefits to committed same-sex couples. But there are still a few provisions on the books, both at the Social Security Administration and the Department of Veterans Affairs, that prohibit same-sex couples from receiving benefits if they live in states that do not recognize their unions.

headline: Harvard to Bring On Specialists to Examine Sexual Assault Claims
text: Harvard University will hire a team of investigators to deal specifically with sexual harassment and assault complaints, and it will end a fragmented approach that allows various parts of the university to handle such cases differently, it said Wednesday.

headline: American Apparel Deal Gives Power to Hedge Fund, Not Dov Charney
