text: A little-known hedge fund backing Dov Charney, the ousted executive of American Apparel, has emerged as a critical power broker in the battle for control of the struggling retailer.

headline: Journalists at Odds With Union Over Role of Voice of America
text: WASHINGTON — Voice of America journalists who are fighting to maintain what they say is their editorial independence are now at odds not only with Congress, but also with their own union.

headline: South Sudan’s Kickboxing Team
text: The photographer Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin documented the team last year, before civil war erupted in the country.

headline: Kidd Dismisses Intrigue Without Dispelling Mystery
text: MILWAUKEE — A photograph of a smiling Jason Kidd under the phrase “Welcome to Milwaukee” shone on a video screen outside Bradley Center on Wednesday. Hardly anyone noticed. The nearby sidewalks were barren on a cold, drizzly morning as Kidd was introduced as the coach of the Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: I Couldn’t Turn My Abortion Into Art
text: I had just turned 22 and I had the self-esteem of a squashed toad. This may explain why I was having an affair with a married 36-year-old sound mixer whom I’d met on a film shoot a couple of months earlier.

headline: Pakistan Approves Sweeping Antiterror Bill, Prompting Warnings From Rights Groups
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Parliament on Wednesday approved sweeping new powers for the country’s security forces, with an antiterrorism measure that the government says is needed to combat the Taliban, but that rights activists warned could result in state-sponsored human rights violations.

headline: For Banana Boat, Epic Battles Between Men and Sun
text: Banana Boat is introducing what it says is a first in the sun-care aisle, a men’s line, and unlike typical sunscreen advertising filled with sand and surf, commercials for Banana Boat Triple Defense Sunscreen for Men are, in every sense, no day at the beach.

headline: Regulators Criticize Chrysler for Delay in Repairing Recalled Jeeps
text: Federal auto regulators, criticized recently for not acting aggressively enough on safety issues, turned some of their fire on Chrysler on Wednesday, saying in a harshly worded letter that the automaker was taking too long to repair 1.6 million recalled Jeep sport utility vehicles.

headline: Porsches, Potholes and Patriots
text: The anti-tax crusader pulls out of his driveway in his Porsche, hoping that the neighbors are watching. He’s proud that it’s the most expensive car on his block. “That’s the greatness of America” he muses. “That’s what we should celebrate on July 4! I spend money so much more wisely than government.”

headline: Outside Legal Work Proves Fruitful for New York’s Top Legislators
text: The three lawmakers who lead the New York State Legislature earned as much as $1.1 million combined practicing law in their spare time last year, according to disclosure statements released on Wednesday.

headline: Government of Ecuador Can Sue Fugitive Bankers in U.S.
text: The government of Ecuador has the right to sue a pair of fugitive bankers in courts in the United States to recover millions of dollars that the government accuses the men of having embezzled, a Florida appellate court ruled on Wednesday. The bankers, Roberto and William Isaias, brothers who live in Coral Gables, Fla., have been convicted of embezzling $600 million from Filanbanco, a bank they owned in their native Ecuador. The Ecuadorean government sued them in a Miami court to recover a portion of the $200 million the government claims it is still owed. Last year, a state judge in Miami ruled in favor of the brothers, saying that international law did not allow Ecuador to seize properties in Florida. The Third District Court of Appeal overturned that verdict, ruling that the government was trying to recover funds, not seize property.

headline: Dimon’s Cancer and the Fine Line in Revealing Illness of a C.E.O.
text: The diagnosis came out of nowhere: It was leukemia.

headline: 2 Companies Accused of Faking Safety Checks at Building Sites
text: A building inspector visited a scaffolding last summer on East 90th Street in Manhattan, where workers were restoring the exterior of an apartment building. The inspector noticed something amiss in the site’s safety log: The safety manager who had supposedly signed the log that day could not have done so; he had recently died.

headline: Nicolas Sarkozy’s Many Legal Hurdles
text: The former president of France is facing numerous legal challenges as he considers running for the top office again in 2017.

headline: Cheney’s Back, Blitzing Rivals and Drawing Scorn
text: As his heart failed a couple of summers after leaving office, former Vice President Dick Cheney slipped into a coma and, by his later account, spent weeks dreaming that he was in a countryside villa north of Rome, padding down a stone path every morning to pick up a newspaper or coffee.

headline: The Dispute Over Annual Pelvic Exams
text: Two major medical groups have taken opposing positions on whether healthy, low-risk women with no symptoms should have an annual pelvic exam. The American College of Physicians, the largest organization of physicians who practice internal medicine, strongly advised against the exams, which many women find distasteful or painful. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the leading group of specialists providing health care for women, immediately reiterated its support for yearly pelvic exams for asymptomatic adult women.

headline: Another Failure to Regulate Derivatives
text: By the time the Securities and Exchange Commission finalized a rule last month to regulate derivatives under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, the big banks that dominate the multitrillion-dollar market had already figured out how to game it.

headline: Japan and the Limits of Military Power
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has disturbed many in Japan and increased anxiety in Asia by reinterpreting his country’s pacifist postwar Constitution so that the military can play a more assertive role than it has since World War II. While a shift in Japan’s military role was never going to be readily accepted by many, Mr. Abe’s nationalist politics makes this change even harder to swallow in a region that needs to reduce tension.

headline: U.S. Success Will Take Some More Extra Time
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — Underneath the jingoistic backlash that engulfed Jurgen Klinsmann last month when he dared to say that the United States national team was not currently capable of winning the World Cup was an actual question that is genuinely confusing — particularly to casual soccer fans. When it comes to American soccer, what is success?

headline: When the Texas Governor Drops the Official State Footwear
text: HOUSTON — Rocky Carroll was inside his cluttered boot shop here on Tuesday, watching television as the dusty ceiling fan jangled. Dolly Parton’s white boots were behind him. President George W. Bush’s cigar-color alligator boots were by the front door, next to President Ronald Reagan’s Italian calf. A fly swatter was within reach.

headline: The Rise and Fall (and Rise) of Salmon P. Chase
text: On July 4, 1864, four days after President Abraham Lincoln had surprised him by accepting his resignation, Treasury secretary Salmon P. Chase confided to his diary, “I am too earnest, too antislavery … [and] too radical.”

headline: As Deadline Nears for an Iran Nuclear Pact, the Fingers Are Pointing
text: WASHINGTON — With less than three weeks until a deadline for a final agreement between Iran and the West on the future of Iran’s nuclear program, it is not just the country’s 10,000 working centrifuges that are spinning. So are the key negotiators.

headline: Takeover of Kenmore Hotel: Informer Recalls His Complicity
text: It was as if the Fifth Infantry Division had come marching down East 23rd Street.

headline: Baseball Let Rodriguez Use Testosterone in Big Year, Book Says
text: WASHINGTON — When the 2007 baseball season began, Alex Rodriguez was still one of the sport’s untarnished stars, the home-run-hitting antidote to Barry Bonds and other sluggers who had already been linked to the use of performance-enhancing substances.

headline: Flights to U.S. Face Scrutiny After Threats Are Reported
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security has tightened passenger screening on many United States-bound flights from Europe, Africa and the Middle East in response to intelligence reports of an increased threat from Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen, officials said Wednesday.

text: Should schools use the student-centered balanced literacy program to teach reading, or require closer instruction by teachers?

headline: New York City Agrees to New Contract With Chief Municipal Union
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and District Council 37, the largest municipal union in New York City, announced on Wednesday a tentative contract that would raise wages by 10 percent and reduce health care costs, resembling the city’s new contract with the United Federation of Teachers.

headline: Insurers on New York State’s Health Exchange Seek Significant Rate Increases
text: Some New Yorkers are in sticker shock after receiving notices from their insurance companies saying that they have asked for significant rate increases through the state’s health exchange next year.

headline: Immigration Case Ensnares a Get-Tough Sheriff in South Carolina
text: LEXINGTON, S.C. — The weekday lunch rush arrives as a small ritual of suburban pleasure at the San Jose Mexican Restaurant, just across from the tanning salon and the strip-mall multiplex. A mostly white clientele pulls into a parking lot, past a sign with a cartoon peasant tugging on an obstinate donkey. Inside, a mostly Latino work force serves Americanized versions of Mexican classics as a sound system plays syrupy Spanish ballads.

headline: Colorado Clerk Won’t Halt Marriage Licenses for Gays
text: BOULDER, Colo. — County clerks like Hillary Hall tend not to be bomb throwers. “We’re procedural, and we’re cautious,” she said, noting that clerks are duty-bound to follow bureaucratic rules for counting ballots, recording property deeds and registering license plates.

headline: After Its Exit, U.S. Identifies Opportunities for Its Future
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Seeing the United States players pinging the ball around with purpose, making determined runs upfield and generally setting the tempo of play after falling behind Belgium, many fans may have thought or yelled out the same thing.

headline: After Criticism, Investigator Steps Down From the V.A.
text: The head of the Department of Veterans Affairs’ medical investigation unit has stepped down, the department announced Wednesday, just days after a federal watchdog sharply criticized the department for failing to adequately investigate allegations of poor care within its sprawling hospital system.

headline: Stephen Gaskin, Hippie Who Founded an Enduring Commune, Dies at 79
text: Stephen Gaskin, a Marine combat veteran and hippie guru who in 1971 led around 300 followers in a caravan of psychedelically painted school buses from San Francisco to Tennessee to start the Farm, a commune that has outlived most of its countercultural counterparts while spreading good works from Guatemala to the South Bronx, died on Tuesday at his home on the commune, in Summertown, Tenn. He was 79.

headline: Class-Action Suit Can Proceed Against Census
text: A United States magistrate judge in the Southern District of New York certified a class-action lawsuit on Tuesday against the Department of Commerce, which alleges that the Census Bureau’s use of criminal background checks for part-time workers unlawfully screened out 250,000 African-American applicants. The plaintiffs said the bureau gave applicants with criminal records 30 days to provide court records detailing their criminal history, a request they contend is in violation of federal civil-rights protections. Adam Klein, the lead lawyer for the plaintiffs, said that many of them had difficultly providing documentation or had minor charges against them or had been arrested but not convicted of a crime. African Americans and Latinos are also disproportionately arrested compared with whites, Mr. Klein said.

headline: Rain May Spare Fireworks, but Not Other July 4th Plans
text: The grill has been cleaned. The fireworks-spotting spot has been staked out. Reservations and invitations have been made.

headline: It Left Parts of Itself in 11 States
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s not often that we get a history lesson with our crossword puzzles, but today’s debut by Luke Vaughn taught me something that I didn’t know. I consider that a bonus, and it more than makes up for the fact that I am not one of the better rebus recognizers.

headline: Political Pop Quiz

headline: State Board Deals a Setback to Apartments in Chappaqua
text: A New York State review board on Wednesday issued a split decision on eight zoning variances being sought for a low- and moderate-income housing project in Chappaqua, the affluent Westchester County hamlet perhaps best known as the home of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Rockets Use Lin’s No. 7 as Anthony Lure
text: Carmelo Anthony and Jeremy Lin never exactly clicked as teammates on the Knicks. When Linsanity erupted out of nowhere in early 2012, with Lin repeatedly leading the Knicks to victories, Anthony was on the sideline, injured and not looking especially pleased to see someone else becoming the focal point of New York basketball.

headline: Girl, 12, Fatally Struck by Stolen Van in Brooklyn; 2 Are Critically Injured
text: A 12-year-old girl was killed and her mother and sister were critically injured in Brooklyn when a stolen minivan jumped a sidewalk and plowed into them on Wednesday, the police said.

headline: Trade Talk Grows With Murphy’s Value
text: ATLANTA — By rule, at least one player from every major league team must be chosen for the All-Star Game this month. This presumes that every team, even the Mets, who are among the most hapless teams in the National League, has at least one deserving representative.

headline: “It’s a huge financial strain.”
text: Dr. Lindsay Irvin is a pediatrician in San Antonio, Tex., who says providing vaccines is a financial risk and strain for doctors.

headline: The Price of Prevention: Vaccine Costs Are Soaring
text: SAN ANTONIO — There is little that Dr. Lindsay Irvin has not done for the children’s vaccines in her office refrigerator: She remortgaged her home to afford their rising prices. She packed them in ice chests and moved them when her office flooded this year. She pays a company to monitor the fridge in case the temperature rises.

headline: Scorn for ‘Tiger Xu,’ From Official and Unofficial Sources
text: Shock is reverberating in China over the very public expulsion from the Communist Party this week of “Tiger Xu,” as Xu Caihou, once a Politburo member and deputy head of the Central Military Commission, is now being dubbed, in a reference to the allegations of his corruption. On Thursday, the military’s official newspaper held him up as a negative example for soldiers.

headline: A Young Upstart With the Tools to Have Staying Power
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Nick Kyrgios’s month in England has featured the greatest success of his young career, and many people may be wondering if he is a flash in a pan. No, Kyrgios is the real deal.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday

(Cinemax) ABOUT TIME (2013) Richard Curtis (“Love Actually”) plucks the heartstrings once again in this British tale about a young man (Domhnall Gleeson) who uses the time-traveling abilities he shares with his eccentric father (Bill Nighy) to pursue a lovely American (Rachel McAdams, above, with Mr. Gleeson) by revisiting their interactions until he gets them right. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film “a flimsy bit of mildly romantic, putatively comic Anglophile bait.”

headline: A Rogue State Along Two Rivers
text: The victories gained by the militant group calling itself the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria were built on months of maneuvering along the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers.

headline: Where’s the Rest of Me?
text: There is no shortage of spherical pendant lights, but there are few with gaping holes in their structure. Neil Poulton, a Scottish-born designer in Paris, has produced an example with tiny LEDs tucked within the frame. The fixture, named Scopas after the Greek sculptor who lived in the fourth century B.C. and who carved a much-copied personification of desire, is composed of black and white painted aluminum circles and is about 20 inches in diameter.

headline: After Relative Silence on Hong Kong Protests, Mainland Media Outlets Note Arrests
text: After a day of largely ignoring the big turnout for Hong Kong’s pro-democracy march on Tuesday, China’s news outlets have weighed in — to report on the arrests that followed it.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Tension Mounts After Apparent Revenge Killing in Jerusalem
text: Updated July 3, 2014: An earlier version of this post was based on the article “Tension Mounts After Apparent Revenge Killing in Jerusalem” by Isabel Kershner and Jodi Rudoren. The Times has since updated the article, and we have revised our questions to reflect the latest version.

headline: Jay Carney: ‘A Little Perspective Is Useful’
text: The former White House press secretary talks to Jim Rutenberg about what he learned from working both sides of the lectern.

headline: 794 Ways in Which BuzzFeed Reminds Us of Impending Death
text: Sometimes I forget that I’m going to die someday, and then BuzzFeed reminds me. In its frenzied onslaught of yellow “LOL"s and “fail"s and “10 Dogs Who Went as a Different Dog for Halloween” lies an existential evasion so strained that it can’t help inadvertently evoking the specter of death. The site’s effortfully whimsical tone and its compulsion to quantify and classify everything represent the apotheosis of American trivia-focused escapism, served up with an overabundant garnish of “trashy” and “cute” and “yaaass.”

headline: The Animal Whisperer
text: A giraffe overcoming an eating problem. Harbor seals being prepared for an eye exam. And a tegu learning how to go through tunnels. How one behaviorist attends to their needs.

headline: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
text: Jacques Sonck has spent nearly four decades on the streets of Antwerp, Ghent and Brussels in Belgium collecting models for his portraits.

headline: Zoo Animals and Their Discontents
text: Dr. Vint Virga likes to arrive at a zoo several hours before it opens, when the sun is still in the trees and the lanes are quiet and the trash cans empty. Many of the animals haven’t yet slipped into their afternoon ma­laise, when they retreat, appearing to wait out the heat and the visitors and not do much of anything. Virga likes to creep to the edge of their enclosures and watch. He chooses a spot and tries not to vary it, he says, “to give the animals a sense of control.” Sometimes he watches an animal for hours, hardly moving. That’s because what to an average zoo visitor looks like frolicking or restlessness or even boredom looks to Virga like a lot more — looks, in fact, like a veritable Russian novel of truculence, joy, sociability, horniness, ire, protectiveness, deference, melancholy and even humor.

headline: Teenagers’ Deaths Raise Fears of Shift From Political Struggle to Blood Feud
text: SDEROT, Israel — In this resilient town about a mile from Israel’s volatile border with the Gaza Strip, the streets were empty on Thursday but the residents expressed defiance as Israeli troops massed around Gaza after a barrage of rockets including three that hit homes here.

text: After reaching out to the next-generation designer community via the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize, the richest and most ballyhooed fashion award for start-ups, well, ever (Thomas Tait, a British-Canadian, was the surprise winner), LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton is proving itself truly committed to cultivating the youth vote.

headline: The Doctor Gets V.I.P. Treatment
text: I was halfway through my ride on a recent crisp and sunny Sunday morning, gaining speed as the road on which I was traveling descended precipitously: 25 miles per hour … 30 … 35. I eased on the brakes but my bike abruptly lost its traction and, as if pushed by God, wiped out.

headline: Why Polls Can Sometimes Get Things So Wrong
text: In the aftermath of Eric Cantor’s loss and Thad Cochran’s narrow runoff victory, you might be tempted to conclude that political polling is losing its utility.

headline: Moving Day for the Declaration and Other Charters
text: In December 1952, a number of mysterious-looking slender crates were brought out of the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., and placed upon mattresses inside two armored Marine personnel carriers. While the Army Band and the Air Force Drum and Bugle Corps played patriotic music, the procession rolled down Capitol Hill.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times editorial board is critical of the decision of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to reinterpret “his country’s pacifist postwar Constitution so that the military can play a more assertive role than it has since World War II.” The board believes the move will only exacerbate tensions in a region where they are already high. “Japan’s military would still face restrictions on what it could do, but it would be allowed for the first time, for example, to help defend an American ship under attack, destroy a North Korean missile heading toward the United States or play a larger role in United Nations peacekeeping operations.” Still, the Japanese people remain generally opposed to engagement in conflict of any kind, and The Times believes it is fair for citizens to demand its government assure them that Japan will not revert to its militaristic roots.

headline: A Social Media Agency Takes an Edgy Approach
text: Pat Law, who started her social media agency, Goodstuph, in Singapore in 2010, has developed a reputation for being unconventional. She has cropped hair, tattoos and funky glasses, and is openly gay — all of which help her stand out in this prosperous but socially conservative city. “I will piss a person off within the first five minutes of meeting them,” said Ms. Law, with more than a hint of pride.

headline: Tablets in the Workplace: a Corner Office Perk
text: Are tablets taking off in the workplace? Only if you’re the boss.

headline: Hurricane Makes Landfall on Carolina Coast
text: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C. — As darkness fell over the Carolina coast on Thursday, anxiety about Hurricane Arthur rose the nearer the strengthening storm moved toward landfall.

headline: Google Alerts British News Outlets About Deleting Their Links
text: LONDON – A week after Google started to remove links to online content in Europe, some examples of the type of information that is to be taken down have started to emerge.

headline: Morning Agenda: When the C.E.O. Gets Sick
text: Corporate leaders from Steven P. Jobs to Warren E. Buffett and now Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, have wrestled with how ‒ or whether ‒ to go public about health problems, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Julie Creswell write in DealBook. How much to disclose, and when, involves delicate corporate and personal decisions for which there are few hard rules. Executives have no real legal obligation to tell the world they are sick.

headline: Daily Report: Winner of Bitcoin Auction Seeks to Increase Currency’s Use in Emerging Markets
text: When the government auctioned nearly 30,000 Bitcoins on Friday, many bidders were looking for a bargain, hoping to buy the virtual currency at a discount and flip it later for a short-term profit.

headline: European Central Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady
text: PARIS — The European Central Bank left its monetary policy intact on Thursday, choosing to wait for the extraordinary measures it enacted a month ago to work their way through the economy before deciding whether additional action was needed to bolster growth and keep deflation at bay.

headline: 1914: Joseph Chamberlain, Veteran Statesman, Dies
text: LONDON — Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, the veteran statesman, died at his London residence, 40 Prince’s gardens, on Thursday night, on the eve of his seventy-eighth birthday. (He was born on July 8, 1836.) All the members of his family were present. Death was due to heart failure. A short time previously he had announced his intention of retiring from Parliament, in which he had been a representative of Birmingham for thirty-eight years. — From the New York Herald, European Edition, July 4, 1914

headline: Looking at Photos the Master Never Saw
text: The photographer Garry Winogrand was known for imposing an artist’s eye on messy urban life, but when he died in 1984, after a rapidly lethal cancer, he left behind an imposing mess of uncertain artistic value: a third of a million exposed frames of film that he hadn’t edited. More than 2,500 rolls — some 100,000 frames — were undeveloped. He had never seen them.

headline: Tea Party Favorites Find That Losing Only Widens Their Reach
text: WASHINGTON — Mississippi Tea Party dreams were extirpated last week when State Senator Chris McDaniel lost his Republican primary bid to unseat Senator Thad Cochran. Yet if some of Mr. McDaniel’s most outspoken contemporaries are any guide, he may actually have greater political influence as a loser.

headline: London Transport Regulator Says Uber Can Legally Operate
text: LONDON – In the battle between Europe’s taxi drivers and the ride-sharing service Uber, score one for Uber.

headline: Hiring Is Strong and Jobless Rate Declines to 6.1%
text: American companies are finally getting comfortable enough with the economy’s prospects to add new workers at a very healthy pace, after years of saying they lacked the confidence to hire people aggressively during a fitful recovery.

headline: Q. & A. | Maya Lin on Saving the Planet Through Art
text: In 1981, Maya Lin first caught the world’s attention with her design for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Three decades later, she is working on what she calls her “last memorial”: What is Missing?, a nonprofit that blends art and science to raise awareness about the ongoing loss of biodiversity and natural habitats. Man’s precarious relationship to nature is also at the center of Lin’s studio practice, where she uses the tools of a scientist — sonar resonance scans, satellite mapping — to create strikingly minimalist works. Her environmentally-minded site-specific projects, including “Pin River — Sandy,” a ghostly wall-sized installation that maps Hurricane Sandy’s flood plain using straight pins, are the subject of the exhibition “Platform: Maya Lin,” which opens this Friday at the Herzog & De Meuron-designed Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y. As she readied the show, the artist discussed climate change, art’s power to shift perceptions and the place where the land meets the sea.

headline: Divas Ready for Another Stage
text: It’s not unusual in the history of opera for a singer to gaze longingly at the world of performance that exists outside music. Theater, television and film offer fame of a kind that opera, for better or worse, no longer does. And in an era of entertainment multitasking, of the “triple threat” and the “EGOT” (Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, Tony), who wouldn’t want to be a star of stage and screen?

headline: Great Jobs Numbers, but Hold the Fireworks
text: There can be no question that the United States employment data for June, released on a rare “Jobs Thursday” thanks to the Independence Day holiday, is good news.

headline: What About the Jobless Who Aren’t Looking?
text: The labor market remains much weaker than the last time the unemployment rate stood at 6.1 percent, just before Lehman Brothers collapsed in September 2008. The difference is “shadow unemployment,” to borrow a term Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, used at her June press conference.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Uganda Warns of ‘Specific Threat’ to Airport
text: A day after the announcement of heightened security measures on United States-bound flights, the American Embassy in Uganda said Thursday it had been warned of a “specific threat” of attack to the country’s main airport and said travelers “may want to review their plans.”

headline: How to Pierce a Deafening Silence? Maybe an Army Can Help
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Scrubbing the Past, One Link at a Time
text: When the European Court of Justice ruled that individuals had a right to ask search engine companies to remove links to web pages that might cause embarrassment, the editorial board, warned that such a right could be used to limit freedom of the press and deny Europeans access to information. That is exactly what seems to be happening.

headline: China and South Korea Affirm Antinuclear Goals
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The leaders of China and South Korea sent a strong message to North Korea on Thursday, saying they were united in their opposition to the development of nuclear weapons on the Korean Peninsula, though they fell short on how they would pursue that goal.

headline: It's Hard to Claim the Good News Is Really Bad

headline: Iraqi Militants Release 32 Turkish Truck Drivers
text: ISTANBUL — Islamist militants in Iraq released 32 Turkish truck drivers on Thursday after holding them for nearly a month, Turkish officials said.

headline: Only Hours From Napa, but a World Away
text: While Napa Valley and Sonoma are renowned for their world-class wines, tasting trips there generally come attached to luxurious digs, spa treatments, $25 tasting fees, Hummer limos and standstill traffic — and all the “no picnicking” pretension that goes with that.

headline: Set ’Em Up, Joe, With an F Major
text: Giant teddy bears wandering in the woods with Björk. Adults riding stuffed ponies that come to life. Animated versions of the ideas of Noam Chomsky. The director Michel Gondry, the man behind these moments, has always seemed most comfortable in surreal worlds.

headline: In Norway, Seeking Munch’s Brighter Palette
text: Almost from the start, my trip to Oslo last summer became a voyage of discovery into the life and trials of Norway’s greatest 20th-century painter, Edvard Munch.

headline: An Art Scene by the Sea in Uruguay
text: This January, the Uruguayan musician, writer and visual artist Dani Umpi had a solo exhibition in Punta del Este, a resort town on Uruguay’s eastern coast. It was held at Galerie Xippas, a sleek showroom recently opened by the Paris-based dealer Renos Xippas. Hanging on the gallery’s walls were bright collages made of endless tiny scraps of magazine images, and shadow boxes containing bird faces wearing neon wigs, a vivid display of Mr. Umpi’s penchant for bizarreness and sarcasm.

headline: With Focus and Force, Kvitova and Bouchard Reach Wimbledon Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Petra Kvitova and Lucie Safarova stood just inside the door of Wimbledon’s Centre Court clubhouse, waiting to be called to their semifinal match. The two have been friends, training partners and Fed Cup teammates in the Czech Republic for years.

headline: What Did My Mother the Chemist See in Betty Crocker?
text: Growing up, I loved looking at the photos in my mother’s old Betty Crocker cookbook: the chocolate cakes, the cookie house, even the cheese balls and fondues. Then, as an adult, I actually read the text and discovered that woven into the recipes were tidbits of advice for the 1960s homemaker: The man you marry will know the way he likes his eggs. And chances are he’ll be fussy about them. So it behooves a good wife to know how to make an egg behave in six basic ways.

headline: The Rickshaw Drivers of Kolkata, India
text: The rickshaws of Kolkata, India, remnants of British imperialism, are among the last in the world, but phasing them out has been far from simple. In 2005, Chief Minister Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee called them an “inhuman practice” and pushed for their eradication. But the All Bengal Rickshaw Union protested the ban, claiming that without alternative employment, the drivers would lose their livelihood. The photographer Dougie Wallace, who has a book coming out on taxis in Mumbai, “Road Wallah,” shot the drivers on these pages, many of whom told him they’ve been working for more than 20 years for less than 500 rupees ($8) a day. Still, says Shireen Hyrapiet, an instructor at Oregon State University who has interviewed drivers extensively, many young immigrants see pulling a rickshaw “as a means of upward social mobility.” Marnie Hanel

headline: Reply All: The 6.22.14 Issue
text: THE BOOMERANG KIDS WON’T LEAVE

headline: Who Made That Wet Suit?
text: In 1951, a U.C. Berkeley physicist named Hugh Bradner devoted some “weekend time” to improving gear for Navy frogmen. Bradner was a veteran of the Manhattan Project who helped develop the trigger mechanism for the atomic bomb; he was also an avid swimmer and diver. At the time, Navy divers wore constricting rubber “dry suits” over long wool underwear. When they leaked, the wool got wet and lost its warmth.

headline: A Baby Called . . . Well, Not That
text: A writer on the run; picking the perfect pair of jeans.

headline: Clean Water for Members Only
text: Back in May, the Portland Water Bureau issued a boil-water notice for the area because of a temporary bacteria scare. Many received word of the potential contamination while at work. The only clean water available at my workplace was from a water cooler, paid for by some — but not all — employees who contribute to an office “water club” each month. Shortly after the city issued the notice, a member of the club reminded others in the office that the water cooler was only for dues-paying members. Thirsty co-workers could buy bottled water from the lobby or a nearby store. My question: In such a situation, what is the ethical duty to share potable water when clean tap water is unavailable? C.B., PORTLAND, ORE.

headline: Vietnam, Real and Reimagined
text: The Hollywood new wave that broke with “Bonnie and Clyde” receded in the late 1970s, swamped by a surge of feel-good jumbo genre films. Still, a handful of unconventional studio movies swam against the tide for another few years. Walter Hill’s “Southern Comfort” was one.

headline: 1964: CIA Helped Fidel Castro’s Sister
text: WASHINGTON — Cuban Prime Minister Fidel Castro’s sister Juanita, who has defected to Mexico, had been in contact with the United States’ Central Intelligence Agency for nearly four years, the Herald Tribune learned yesterday [July 2]. Mr. Castro’s brother Raul, his trusted No. 2 man, protected Miss Castro from the dictator’s wrath and paved the way for her flight while the prime minister was away from Havana, according to highly placed intelligence sources. Miss Castro informed U.S. officials in 1960 that she was breaking with her brother’s regime. The CIA made it easy for her to enter Mexico on June 20. ‘‘She came out quite openly,’’ said an intelligence source. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 4, 1964

headline: Jobs Numbers Raise Questions About Fall in G.D.P.
text: Today’s strong jobs report forcefully suggests that employment growth is accelerating. Payrolls have expanded by an average 272,000 jobs per month in the last three months compared with 210,000 over the last year.

headline: A ‘Battered’ Mideast Envoy Steps Down, but Keeps a Bag Packed
text: WASHINGTON — Martin S. Indyk announced his departure from Middle East peacemaking last week with a post on Twitter that said he was “battered but unbowed.” When that prompted questions from people curious about why he felt that way, he replied that if they knew anything about the nine months of negotiations between the Israelis and Palestinians, “you wouldn’t have to ask why.”

headline: Back to New York, With Toddlers in Tow
text: Back before they had children, Denise and Jim Burnham spent three years living in New York. They rented a one-bedroom with a balcony for around $3,400 a month in a Midtown West high-rise.

headline: Immigration
text: THE DANGEROUS DIVIDEPeril and Promise on the US-Mexico BorderBy Peter Eichstaedt  Lawrence Hill, $26.95.

headline: The State of the Union’s Books
text: With patriotism and fireworks in the air this weekend, the Book Review turns its attention to American life and thought, looking at new books by or about Hillary Clinton, Franklin Delano Roose­velt and the Supreme Court, among other subjects.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE SOUND OF THINGS FALLING,  by Juan Gabriel Vásquez. Translated by Anne McLean. (Riverhead, $16.) Vásquez’s closely observed novel is built on Colombia’s tragic history with the drug trade. In 1990s Bogotá, a young lawyer named Antonio witnesses the assassination of a reclusive friend just out of prison after 20 years. Antonio’s search for answers leads him back to the 1960s, before Bogotá was engulfed by violence “whose actors are collectives and written with capital letters: the State, the Cartel, the Army, the Front.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE SILKWORM,  by Robert Galbraith. (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $28.) The publishing world is the setting for this endlessly entertaining second novel featuring the detective Cormoran Strike, by J. K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.

headline: Louis Zamperini, Olympian and ‘Unbroken’ War Survivor, Dies at 97
text: Louis Zamperini, an Olympic runner who as an airman during World War II crashed into the Pacific, was listed as dead and then spent 47 days adrift in a life raft before being captured by the Japanese and enduring a harsh imprisonment, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Air-Conditioning’s Start in Brooklyn
text: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Mayhem Hits Myanmar’s No. 2 City
text: BANGKOK — The authorities in Myanmar on Thursday declared a nighttime curfew in Mandalay, the country’s second-largest city, after a resurgence of religious violence left two people dead and more than a dozen injured.

headline: V.I.P. Room
text: “Throw a fit. You’ll get whatever you want.” That’s the advice given to major donors by a senior “fixer” working the high-end hotels reserved for guests of the Obama Victory Fund at the 2012 Democratic convention. The campaign’s prized financial supporters got everything from “S.E.I.U. for Obama” thundersticks to “exclusive” campaign briefings to V.I.P. party-suite passes. Those who complained about lack of access could always “write a check to get a higher package,” according to a manual for volunteers.

headline: Under the Influence
text: If Ken Kesey’s “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” prefigured the Age of Aquarius, then Don Carpenter’s semi-­autobiographical “Fridays at Enrico’s” can be read as the swan song of the entire Love Generation. After Carpenter burst onto the West Coast literary scene in 1966, with his gritty first novel, “Hard Rain Falling” (reissued in 2009 by New York Review Books), he became an unofficial adviser to fellow Bay Area writers trying to ride Jack Kerouac’s coattails. Never a hippie celebrity like Richard Brautigan or a living legend like Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Carpenter was a straight man to the more illustrious neo-Beat and -Dada artists of the era. With his moon face, receding hairline, professional discipline and calm demeanor, he was a steadying antidote to the counterculture bedlam of the tumultuous 1960s and beyond.

headline: Independence Days
text: Reviewing a debut novel titled “The Orchard Keeper,” in 1965, the New York Times critic Orville Prescott chastened its author for nearly submerging “his own talents beneath a flood of imitation.” That young author was Cormac McCarthy, and the influence whose weight Prescott saw him sagging beneath belonged to William Faulkner. Among the hand-me-down characteristics Prescott noted: “the wandering pronouns with no visible antecedents; the recondite vocabulary and coined words; the dense prose packed with elaborate figures of speech; the deliberate ambiguity, the hints and withheld information; the confusion in time and place; and the flashbacks that fail to shed much light into the intermittent gloom.” All of these factors, he concluded, made for an exasperating book. “But the wonder,” he pivoted, “is that in spite of them it is also an impressive book.”

headline: Life Into Art
text: Of all the American artists of the 19th century, James Abbott McNeill Whistler was probably the talkiest. In the 1870s, when he painted his famous portrait of his mother, he was living in London, a high-strung expatriate who saw fit to issue mission statements on what seemed like an hourly basis. “Art should be independent of all claptrap,” he declared, believing he had stripped painting of sentimentality and moral uplift and the other trademarks of Victorian culture.

headline: Escape From L.A.
text: Some dystopian novels, like Cormac ­McCarthy’s “The Road,” explore human relationships in dark, existential post-collapse scenarios, uninterested in either causes or solutions. Others engage with global warming head-on and imagine the possibilities beyond catastrophe, as in Margaret Atwood’s ultimately optimistic Madd­Addam trilogy. But there’s a middle path too — one exemplified by Edan Lepucki’s first novel, “California,” in which characters traverse a cross-section of mid-collapse landscape, framed by the gradual decline of civilization. This approach may seem too optimistic given dire news about melting icecaps and acidic oceans, but it does allow for a reading of the novel as satire, skewering the elements of modern life that have brought us to this tipping point.

headline: Patriarch and Pariah
text: A religion whose followers believe that the Earth was created somewhere in the neighborhood of the planet Kolob, and that the Garden of Eden was created somewhere in the neighborhood of Kansas City, Mo., would seem to have so fortified itself against mockery that there’s no sport in scorning it. In this respect, Mormonism is an honest reflection of its founder, a man who offers such an easy target that providing even a partial list of his myriad and exotic transgressions feels too easy, like a distasteful piling on.

headline: Rural Noir
text: Some stories are so sad, you want them to have the comfort of a gentle storytelling voice. Tom Bouman extends that kindness in DRY BONES IN THE VALLEY (Norton, $24.95), his beautifully written first novel set in the mountainous region of northeastern Pennsylvania that sits atop the Marcellus Shale, a vast geological treasure, prized and exploited for its natural gas resources. With neighbors feuding over whether to lease drilling rights to companies accused of poisoning the environment, it’s no wonder that a crazy old recluse like Aubrey Dunigan would be testy with anyone he finds hanging around his decrepit farm. But these hills are also overrun with meth cookers, dope dealers and Mexican drug cartels. So just because a stranger is found dead on his property doesn’t make poor old Aubrey a murderer.

headline: A People’s History
text: “Where else in the world does one have the freedom to contradict oneself?” Ilan Stavans asks in “A Most Imperfect Union,” a witty alternative history of the United States from the arrival of European settlers to the shooting of Trayvon Martin and the Mars rover landing in 2012. It’s a prequel to “Latino USA” — his previous collaboration with the illustrator Lalo Alcaraz, a cartoon history of Latino culture in America — and even more ambitious. This time the focus is on “the dispossessed and minority groups of all stripes, as well as individuals known and unknown to most students of American history.” What the books have in common, Stavans writes, is “sarcasm.”

headline: Bombers’ Early Light
text: “England’s battles, it used to be said, were won on the playing fields of Eton,” the American labor leader Walter ­Reuther declared in 1940, but “America’s can be won on the assembly lines of Detroit.” Joseph Stalin agreed. Toasting President Roosevelt in 1943, he stated that “the most important things in this war are machines” and that the United States was “the country of machines.”

headline: Americanos
text: If it’s true that — in the long tradition of “Don Quixote” — all novels are about road trips, then perhaps no novels detail the challenges of the journey more than immigrants’ tales. The tradition is long and worldwide. The hearts of the downtrodden, the forgotten and neglected, swell with hope at the prospect of starting over somewhere. They collect their courage along with essential belongings and begin the trek to the unforeseen. No matter if the stories they’ve heard about the new country are exaggerated and acculturation is a frightening hurdle, it will — it must — be better than the present situation. In this spirit, the characters in ­Cristina Henríquez’s new novel, “The Book of Unknown Americans,” have come to the United States.

headline: ‘Harry Hood’ by Phish
text: This recording is from the band’s performance on Tuesday night in Mansfield, Mass.

headline: Pill to Prevent H.I.V. Gets a Prominent Backer: Andrew Cuomo
text: On Sunday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced an ambitious goal: Ending the AIDS epidemic in New York State by 2020.

headline: Exploring the Wild Weather of Mount Washington
text: In a feat of careful coordination between bouts of epic snowfall and freezing fog, work on a new museum at the self-proclaimed “home of the world’s worst weather” is now complete.

headline: Beyoncé: Genius or Terrorist?
text: In her 2011 hit, “Run the World (Girls),” Beyoncé Knowles, the onetime Destiny’s Child frontwoman turned solo megastar, demands, “Who runs the world?” This month, Forbes proffered an answer: she does.

headline: No Fragile Flower in This Fight
text: “I’m fighting hard to keep an equilibrium between the characters,” said the playwright Laura Eason, whose “Sex With Strangers” begins previews on Tuesday at Second Stage Theater .

headline: And Fade Out ... but Not Fade Away
text: “Life Itself,” Steve James’s documentary on the life of Roger Ebert, is in many ways like a wake at which intimate acquaintances warmly recall their departed friend in all his aspects, foibles and quirks along with his talents and triumphs. Deep currents of love and sorrow flow under the succession of often funny recollections of a busy life. But it is a wake where the departed is still present.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Studebaker Drivers Unite
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: A Typewriter’s Sorry Exit
text: David W. Dunlap is a metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

headline: Gehrig vs. Dempsey
text: Rare footage from April 12, 1935, shows Lou Gehrig and Jack Dempsey sparring at McGovern’s gym in Manhattan.

headline: Audio: ‘Seeing’ Phish’s ‘Harry Hood’
text: The music writer Mike Hamad drew this “schematic,” a graphic map of his own invention, during the first performance of Phish’s summer tour.

headline: Obama Mocks Congress on Climate Change
text: At the League of Conservation Voters’ Capital Dinner, President Obama spoke out against members of Congress who say that climate change is “a liberal plot.”

headline: Sheltering in Storm, Family Must Flee as Debris Rains From Brooklyn Bridge
text: With his family taking shelter from a powerful storm under the Brooklyn Bridge on Wednesday evening, Jerome Dilligard darted out into the streets of the Dumbo neighborhood to retrieve their car. When he returned a few moments later, all he could see where his family had stood was a mound of gray rubble.

headline: Leaders of China and South Korea Meet
text: With Chinese President Xi Jinping at her side, South Korean President Park Geun-hye called for reunification of the Korean peninsula and stated their opposition to North Korea’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: If Convicted, Rengan Rajaratnam Faces Light Insider Trading Sentence
text: Rengan Rajaratnam, who is on trial for conspiracy to commit insider trading, would face a much lighter sentence than the 11-year prison term being served by his older brother, Raj Rajaratnam, the former billionaire hedge fund manager, if he were convicted.

headline: Daimler Demonstrates a Self-Driving Truck
text: MAGDEBURG, Germany — For Daimler, the truck driver of the future looks something like this: He is seated in the cab of a semi, eyes on a tablet and hands resting in his lap.

headline: 11 Artists Who Really, Really Love Their Bicycles
text: The photographer Casey Kelbaugh shot KAWS, Tim Barber, Jason Nocito and other artists exhibiting in the bike-themed group art show “Joyride,” on view through Aug. 3 at Marlborough Chelsea, with their beloved two-wheeled transport.

headline: In Case the Fourth’s Not With You
text: If you’re the patriotic sort, this is definitely your weekend to do that most American of things: sit in front of the television. Rousing, flag-waving concerts and other such fare will be readily available on network TV and cable alike.

headline: Quick Stock Sales Toy With Volcker Rule’s Spirit
text: Investment banks are using quick stock sales to toy with the spirit of the Volcker Rule. Wall Street sold some $23 billion in large trading orders, or block trades, for public companies in the first half of the year, according to Thomson Reuters data. That’s almost as much as initial public offerings have raised. These deals are a handy tool for corporations. But at times, investment banks blur the line between capital-raising and banned proprietary trading.

headline: Today in Small Business: Saving the Naked Bean
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Then and Now: Tea Party Also-Rans
text: A sampling of the Tea Party’s most outspoken also-rans who have gone on to great influence after their losses. Will Chris McDaniel do the same?

headline: A Collector’s Dream: 149 Forgotten Dylan Records Found in a Closet
text: Record collectors dream of finding caches of rare discs – collections with music that cannot be found elsewhere, perhaps because the number of known copies is tiny,  and which therefore commands considerable value, in financial as well as artistic terms.

headline: Luna Park Nostalgia (via Futuristic Technology)
text: Classical masters like Michelangelo, Bernini and Rodin fashioned their canonical works from elemental materials like marble, bronze and clay. These days, however, some sculptors have turned to more populist modes.

headline: Filmmakers Face Charges in Death on a Set in Georgia
text: LOS ANGELES — A prosecutor in Georgia said on Thursday that three filmmakers had been charged with involuntary manslaughter and criminal trespass in the death of Sarah Jones, a crew worker who was killed by a freight train on the set of the film “Midnight Rider” in February.

headline: Keeping Track of Hurricane Arthur
text: In the hectic and devastating hurricane seasons of the mid 2000s, a coast-grazing storm like Hurricane Arthur would have been unremarkable. Here’s the storm’s limited coastal surge potential (the maps are helpful but are still listed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration as experimental). But in the news flow ahead of the Fourth of July weekend, there’s continuing coverage on news channels.

headline: Prepaid Mobile Data Plans for International Travel
text: Also, how to get everything from an iPod, even if you didn’t buy it through the same computer.

headline: Subaru Recalls 660,000 Vehicles for Brake Line Corrosion
text: Subaru is recalling about 660,000 of its newer vehicles in the United States because the brake lines might corrode, according to a report the automaker posted Thursday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: The Luckiest Man, on a Playful Day
text: Four days before the Yankees opened their 1935 season, Lou Gehrig stepped into the gym of the celebrity trainer Artie McGovern on Manhattan’s East Side.

headline: Does America (Ever) Need New Ideas?
text: My colleague Paul Krugman, commenting on a generous profile of some of my reform conservative friends by Sam Tanenhaus in this weekend’s Times Magazine, is skeptical that any new or new-ish right-of-center policy ideas could meaningfully reshape America’s political debates:

headline: Former Players File Objection to Proposed N.F.L. Settlement
text: Seven former N.F.L. players accused the N.F.L. and the lawyers representing more than 4,500 retirees of failing to justify how they reached their proposed settlement that includes an uncapped amount of damages for players with severe neurological disorders.

headline: Inside the List
text: By the Numbers: Jordan Ellenberg’s math-based guide to life, “How Not to Be Wrong,” is at No. 15 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Ellenberg is a star mathematician at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where the local alternative weekly recently asked him about his specialty in number theory — “addition and subtraction and multiplication, all the things you can do with numbers,” as Ellenberg put it. “Haven’t we already figured all that stuff out?” the reporter wondered, and Ellenberg laughed. “We know nothing,” he said. “Right now we are standing in a tiny circle of light around our feet, and every 1,000 years, we push that circle out just a little bit. Every time someone sticks his toe out beyond that circle, it opens up whole worlds of inquiry.” Ellenberg is also a published novelist (I met him at a summer fiction workshop almost 20 years ago), but he told the Madison weekly that one of the things he’d learned in his creative writing classes was how much he liked math.

headline: All the Conventional Cohabitation, but No Nuptials
text: When Rebecca Eckler and her boyfriend decided to have a baby and move in together three years ago, she had one condition. It wasn’t the promise of marriage, which Ms. Eckler deemed “so 2003,” but of a legally binding document that would dictate what would happen to the couple’s assets if they ever broke up.

headline: Text, Vent, Repeat
text: I have a close friend who is going through a tough divorce. She often sends me long text messages about her horrific situation. I have asked her, on many occasions, to call me or come over to my place to talk because I find it difficult to be empathetic in a text reply. But she ignores me and continues sending long and repetitive text messages. Sometimes I choose not to respond, and she becomes upset that I am not “there” for her. What should I do?

headline: One of American Apparel’s Biggest Shareholders Sells Most of Stake
text: Unnerved by the recent turmoil at American Apparel and anxious about the company’s uncertain future, American Apparel’s second-largest shareholder has sold a substantial portion of its stake in the company.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’
text: This week, Peter Baker talks about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “Hard Choices”; John Williams discusses the week’s literary news; Jeff Shesol talks about “Uncertain Justice” and “Scalia: A Court of One”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Taking Marriage One Year at a Time
text: On our honeymoon in Paris, my husband and I were served breakfast every morning by the same short-haired woman. The breakfast came free with our hotel room: croissants, a basket of bread with its little trough of butter, fresh-squeezed orange juice and café au laits.

headline: The Surprise in the Hobby Lobby Comments
text: Timothy R. Williams is a community moderator, monitoring comments submitted to the website.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’
text: This week, Peter Baker and Jeff Shesol.

headline: Dow Closes Above 17,000 as Stock Rally Outpaces Economy
text: The stock market, continuing a remarkable ascent that began in the darkness of the last recession, surged past a milestone on Thursday after a strong jobs report indicated that the economy might finally be gaining steam.

headline: Wheelies: The Mexican Bimmer Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Sugar-Free Solved!
text: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a middle-aged woman who suddenly began to have episodes of confusion caused by low blood sugars. Her endocrinologist thought she might have an insulinoma, an insulin-producing tumor of the pancreas, but the testing he did seemed to rule out that diagnosis. Nearly 200 of you took on the challenge of trying to figure out what was causing her life-threatening drops in blood sugar level.

headline: All in This Together
text: Four years ago, a series of circumstances led my husband and me to move back to the town where I grew up, and then to buy my parents’ home of 25 years. The home came with a lot of stuff: my mother’s colorful porcelain egg collection, my father’s dusty musical cassettes, rooms full of frayed chintz and endless silver in need of polish. It also came with my mother and father.

headline: In Paris, the Ultimate Place to Watch a World Cup Match
text: As the World Cup moves into the quarterfinal, semifinal, and final rounds, one Paris establishment is offering the ultimate setting for watching a match: Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris, the grand Philippe Starck-redesigned hotel situated in the Eighth Arondissement. The hotel’s private theater, with seating for 99, will screen the playoff matches in live broadcast, enhanced with a few choice amenities. There will be strawberry and basil caipirinhas (in deference to the host country) and a pop-up Veuve Clicquot Champagne terrace (it’s still France, after all). There will be caramelized popcorn, made by the pastry chef and macaron maestro Pierre Hermé, to snack on, and a three-course dinner option from the hotel’s Michelin-starred restaurant, La Cuisine. And there will be state-of-the-art televisions specially installed by Sony for the occasion. While the setting is opulent (and the dress code specifies “no board shorts or flip-flops”), the mood will be spirited, according to the hotel’s manager, Pierre-Alexandre Francin. “Guests love the fact that they’re allowed to let loose, scream and shout whenever someone scores a goal,” he says.

headline: Dell Expands a Program for Tech Start-Ups
text: Dell has expanded its offerings for entrepreneurs with the Founders Club 50, a two-year acceleration program for 50 start-ups in a variety of industries. Dell had already established its own Entrepreneur in Residence program in 2011, started the Center for Entrepreneurs and created The Dell Innovators Credit Fund, a $100 million financing program.

headline: From a Night at the Roxy to Capitol Hill
text: U.S. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney and Randy Florke were married on June 21 at a church near their home in Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Lime Is of the Essence
text: The origins of the daiquiri are vague and subject to embellishment and apocrypha. This is the case with many classic cocktails. We know for sure that there was a mine in Cuba called Daiquiri, not far from a beach of the same name, but we don’t know with certainty that an engineer there concocted the first daiquiri. And while the drink is bound forever to Ernest Hemingway, its most illustrious consumer — from whom one variant takes its name — he was not its creator.

headline: An Unrevised View of the Declaration of Independence
text: In the days leading up to the Fourth of July, the New York Public Library has drawn crowds with a temporary display of one of its prime treasures — a copy of the Declaration of Independence written out by Thomas Jefferson. By Thursday, more than 10,000 people had lined up to see it, taking selfies in front of the display case, and in some cases quietly reading passages out loud.

headline: A Refreshing Drink for a Complicated Emotional State
text: Two things happened this week that give cause for a drink: In the World Cup, which The Upshot has been following obsessively, the United States lost a valiant game to Belgium and is now out of the contest, and the July 4 holiday is upon us. Rarely has there been a better occasion for a summer cocktail that is at once sorrowful and celebratory.

headline: SunTrust Reaches U.S. Settlement Over Mortgage Modifications
text: Federal prosecutors and SunTrust Banks reached a settlement on Thursday in a criminal investigation into the bank’s tardiness in approving mortgage modifications. The bank will pay as much as $320 million for a combination of consumer relief and housing counseling services.

headline: Clicking Their Way to Outrage
text: You needn’t Google far for recent case studies of Internet outrage. Log in to a social network and you’ll find it directed at celebrities and civilians alike. (See: Woody Allen, Stephen Colbert and Justine Sacco, the former communications director for IAC who posted an insensitive Twitter message about AIDS in Africa.) Politicians are a perennial favorite: Chris Christie, Rob Ford, Anthony Weiner. Then there’s the bigger game: courts of law, social movements, news media outlets, corporations and governments that have rubbed people the wrong way.

headline: A Relationship Where Marriage is Freedom
text: In the close-knit world of New York City’s gay scene, circa 1992, Randy Florke was a somebody: flaxen-haired model, up-and-coming designer, Studio 54 habitué and downtown bon vivant. But on the night he met the man who would become his husband two decades later, he was being treated like a nobody.

headline: No Moral, No Uplift, Just a Restless ‘Click’
text: Garry Winogrand, who has an ample retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was born on the eve of the belt-tightening Great Depression, came of age in the pumped-up postwar 1950s and was photographer laureate — one, anyway — to the long era of morbid cultural and economic obesity that followed, and continues.

headline: Under Cover: The G.O.P. in Boldface Letters
text: ‘‘Sometimes language is the strongest way to convey an idea,’’ says Gail Bichler, the magazine’s art director. That’s her explanation for why Sam Tanenhaus’s article about the Republican Party’s identity crisis was given a typographic treatment on the cover this week.

headline: If You’re Lighting Fourth of July Fireworks, Who’s Holding the Match?
text: We’re about to go buy fireworks.

headline: Privacy Group Complains to F.T.C. About Facebook Emotion Study
text: Update 6:20 p.m.: This post was updated with a comment from the academic journal that published Facebook’s research.

headline: Space Pod Alights at the Serpentine Gallery
text: LONDON — For the 15th year, the Serpentine Gallery has commissioned an architect to design a temporary structure on its front lawn in Kensington Gardens here. Generally, those who are chosen have not built anything in Britain before. Over the years, Frank Gehry, Zaha Hadid, Jean Nouvel, Sou Fujimoto and Rem Koolhaas have each planted a pavilion here, some more bizarre than others. This year’s creation, by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, is a kind of alien space pod resting on 62 tons of giant quarry stones. Fashioned from semi-translucent, glass-reinforced plastic, like the Fiberglas used to build yachts, it arrived in 66 pieces and took six weeks to install. Inside are a cafe and space for events that bring together art, poetry, literature and film by emerging creators.

headline: Initial Wimbledon Run Still Drives a Former Semifinalist
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Alexandra Stevenson is sure she had to wear three pairs of socks to fit into the men’s tennis shoes she borrowed from her coach during qualifying at Wimbledon in 1999, the year she reached the semifinals.

headline: Scores of Militants Reported Killed by Iraqi Army, but Group Seizes Syrian Oil Field
text: BAGHDAD — Almost 200 Sunni militants were killed in battles with the Iraqi Army on Thursday, the Iraqi government said, but the militants’ group gained potentially significant economic ground in their struggle for leverage in the region, taking control of Syria’s largest oil field.

headline: At 75, Still Stepping Out of Line
text: Could anything be more steeped in the order and orders of the Old World than those 12 little girls leaving an old house covered with vines, in two straight lines, in rain or shine? It has been 75 years since they made their appearance in Ludwig Bemelmans’s classic “Madeline” with their hair bows and yellow hats: models of propriety being led through the grandeur of touristic Paris (the Opera, the Place Vendôme, Notre Dame, the Tuileries). Except, of course, for Madeline, who never quite stayed in place.

headline: Making ‘American Ideals’
text: Stephen Doyle shows how he created an American flag and turned it into an open box for the cover of this week’s Book Review.

headline: Lawsuit Claims Katy Perry’s ‘Dark Horse’ Borrows From Christian Rap Song
text: Katy Perry, who will perform at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, may be making an appearance at a courthouse in St. Louis sometime soon. The Christian rapper Flame, who was born Marcus Gray, and three of his associates — Chike Ojukwu, Emanuel Lamber and Lecrae Moore, the co-creators of Flame’s 2008 song “Joyful Noise,” — filed a lawsuit against Ms. Perry and her label, Capitol Records, and others in federal court in St. Louis on Tuesday, charging that Ms. Perry used “Joyful Noise” without permission in her 2013 recording, “Dark Horse,” Courthouse News Service reported.

headline: Reactions to Hurricane Approaching N.C.
text: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina warned people to not “put your stupid hat on” as Hurricane Arthur approached the state. Meanwhile, tourists and visitors prepared for the storm.

headline: A Mondrian for London
text: Amid London’s booming hotel scene, the Mondrian London, opening Sept. 30, is poised to make a splashy debut – on the Thames riverfront in the increasingly trendy South Bank district.

headline: A Few Stories Among Characters
text: The appetizers hadn’t even arrived and Lee Grant was already discussing the juiciest portion of her new memoir, “I Said Yes to Everything.” Did she sleep with Warren Beatty?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Breakfast at Tiffany’s
text: Just when you expect Fourth of July white, women appear all in black.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Holly-Go-Delightfully
text: Just when you expect Fourth of July white, women appear all in black. At 8:30 a.m., 18 women visiting from Australia gathered in front of Tiffany & Company dressed à la Hepburn, with black dresses, long gloves, pearls and exaggerated cigarette holders. Most every morning, you’ll see tourists brown-bagging that famous meal outside Tiffany. One biker accounted for the weather in a two-piece outfit — call it minimalist black.

headline: Three Generations, One Home, One Unavoidable Future
text: When the writer Jennifer Conlin, her husband and her children moved in with her parents, it was a new twist on “till death do us part.”

headline: Racing Canoes in the Hudson
text: New York Outrigger is a paddling club that races using traditional Pacific Island canoes. Each year, it hosts “The Liberty Challenge,” a 12-mile race in the Hudson River.

headline: Couples Taking On ‘I Believe’ After ‘I Do’
text: At the start of “The Religion Thing,” Mo and Brian, a married couple in their 30s living the high-velocity life of Washington lawyers and lobbyists, are having Mo’s best friend since college, Patti, and her latest man, Jeff, over for dinner. It’s been six, maybe eight, months since the women have talked, let alone seen each other, and Patti has a lot to tell.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Castoff Joins a Master’s Canon
text: When the British publisher Chatto & Windus agreed in 1933 to publish Samuel Beckett’s first book of fiction, a collection of 10 interrelated stories titled “More Pricks Than Kicks,” it asked him for one final story, a culminating wallop.

headline: Fighting Summer FOMO
text: Summer, as Americans are amply informed by everyone from Us Weekly to The Wall Street Journal, is supposed to be when you go to the beach, feast on barbecue, watch fireworks, and generally frolic in the sunlight. And if you’re indoors — either because you have to be or because you just don’t like going outside that much — it’s easy to feel like you’re missing out.

headline: Weekend Gas Prices Drop, but Iraq Crisis Is a Threat
text: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices are drifting lower just in time for the Fourth of July weekend, although they remain at the highest levels for this time of year since 2008 mainly because of the crisis in Iraq.

headline: Campfire Girls Grow Up
text: At Campowerment, a group of women enjoyed a long weekend of traditional camp athletics and bonding.

headline: German Parliament Advances a National Minimum Wage
text: BERLIN — The lower house of the German Parliament voted to establish a national minimum wage for the first time on Thursday — 8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour — to take effect next year. Some lawmakers hailed the step as historic.

headline: Varied Sides of One Girl
text: The performance collective Carroll Simmons is obsessed with the “Girls” creator and star Lena Dunham, no doubt about it. But something more complicated than hate-watching fuels its puzzlingly diffuse parody “Too Many Lenas 3: Let Them Eat Cake,” directed by David Bernstein at the New Ohio Theater as part of the Ice Factory Festival.

headline: Giving Uzbekistan Some Beach Flair
text: The air smells of salt and sunscreen, cumin and lamb, the Silk Road and the boardwalk. Out front is a surf rack slapped with stickers for Futures Fins and Mucho Aloha beer; inside are hulking Central Asian meat pastries the recipes for which reach back to the time of the Khans.

headline: A Happy Hunter for a Must-Have Taste
text: At a certain point in life, you’re old enough to stop thinking that other people’s jobs sound like fun. But when I heard about Mark Rosati, who is the culinary director of Shake Shack — meaning all 27 branches in this country and 21 internationally, including ones in Istanbul, Moscow and Dubai — I thought his job might be an exception.

headline: Evening Hours | The Fine Art of Living
text: Tours, shows, benefits and awards fill the calendar.

headline: Social Media’s Vampires: They Text by Night

text: Figuring out how to pay in-state college tuition for a college student who grew up elsewhere is the ultimate money hack.

headline: A Seasonal Staple, Slightly Less Buttoned Down
text: The New York Philharmonic’s Summertime Classics concerts, which began on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall, are an opportunity to see the orchestra “kicking back,” its president and executive director, Matthew VanBesien, writes in the Playbill. The musical selections are “eminently listenable,” an article a few pages later says.

headline: Frank’s Way or the Highway. Or Both.
text: For more than a decade, Bill Loizon has catered Detroit-area events from an old Volkswagen Pickup that he turned into a mobile hot-dog stand.

headline: Shifting Contexts, Psychodrama and Meta-Works
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Abstract painting is on the move in “Amy Sillman: one lump or two,” a spirited midcareer survey at Bard College’s Center for Curatorial Studies. It jumps around from paper to canvas to phone and tablet screens, as if to say, “Catch me if you can.”

headline: ‘Glass Puzzle’
text: Anchored by a magical early work by Joan Jonas, this small group show, organized by the painter Mary Simpson, runs wild with the theme of multiplied and divided selves. It should be seen especially for Ms. Jonas’s “Glass Puzzle,” a video installation from the early 1970s that involves two female performers, two cameras and various ways of distancing the spectator from the action. (Ms. Jonas, who once called the piece a “puzzle in space,” fed a live performance to a television monitor and then aimed a camera at the monitor, so that we ultimately see a fuzzy view of the women that’s further marred by reflections on the screen.)

headline: Ed Paschke
text: Think of Ed Paschke, the great American painter who died in 2004, was a formalist in wolf’s clothing, or the most abstract of Photo Realists. His dystopic photo-based paintings depict the denizens of a lurid dark side, where crime, race, clubs and an eerie glamour mixed with intimations of violence.

headline: Events on Long Island for July 6-12, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Words That Do More Than Signify
text: In 1974 Allen Ruppersberg copied by hand the entire text of Oscar Wilde’s novel “The Picture of Dorian Gray” onto 20 6-by-6-foot canvases. It’s a safe bet that no one has ever read Mr. Ruppersberg’s rendering of the book all the way through. Printed in a pale marker on beige fabric, the words aren’t easy to decipher. But see for yourself: The whole thing is included in “Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions” at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Brice Dellsperger: ‘Body Double: Vous N’en Croirez Pas Vos Yeux’
text: The French artist Brice Dellsperger takes cinephilia to absurdist extremes. He makes ultra-low-budget films in which he and a few other actors — usually in drag — recreate scenes and full-length versions of well-known movies, retaining the original soundtracks. He particularly favors Brian De Palma, the director of “Body Double,” but he’s also created interpretations of movies by David Lynch, Stanley Kubrick, Alfred Hitchcock and numerous others.

headline: ‘Thin Skin’: ‘Six Artists from Beirut’
text: Since opening last year, Taymour Grahne Gallery has been a boon to New York, which has few other outlets for contemporary art from the Middle East. Its current show offers an instant education in new painting from, or about, Beirut, the cosmopolitan but perennially embattled capital of Lebanon.

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Clashes Escalate
text: Clashes between Israeli security forces and Palestinian protesters continued in East Jerusalem as tensions remained high over the deaths of four teenagers.

headline: ‘Some Artists’ Artists’
text: Nobody keeps a closer eye on an artist than other artists. So when Karina Daskalov, a director at Marian Goodman Gallery, was planning the inevitable summer group show, she called on artists she knew best, those already on the Goodman roster, for fresh candidates. Nearly 20 responded, and “Some Artists’ Artists” brings some valuable introductions and re-encounters.

headline: Events in Westchester for July 6-12, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Stroke Lessons (Time Wasted is Brain Lost)
text: I’d like to interrupt this nonstop exploration of paths toward planetary sustainability to recall the importance of sustaining yourself, whatever you do.

headline: Abandoning Control on Coney Island
text: Leslie Jean-Bart makes pictures of reflections on the shore and boardwalk, where the image changes in an instant, and nothing is ever fully under his control.

headline: Many Hands in Creative Frenzy
text: The Museum of Arts and Design is plunging into the deep end of the biennial pool with a big, messy splash. Part swan dive, part belly-flop, its inaugural edition, “NYC Makers: The MAD Biennial,” is an ambitious, inchoate, sometimes dissatisfying sampling of visual culture from across the five boroughs.

headline: Jobs Rebound, Prosperity Lags
text: The spring rebound in employment has come to pass — just a little later than projected. The economy added 288,000 jobs in June, and tallies for April and May were revised upward, bringing job creation over the past year to 2.49 million, the highest level in five years. The unemployment rate also fell to 6.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly six years, and, even better, the decline was unambiguously good news. It resulted from people getting hired and not leaving the work force.

headline: Downloads in Decline as Streamed Music Soars
text: For the music industry, the good news about this year’s sales is not quite enough to make up for all the bad news.

headline: Birth Control Order Deepens Divide Among Justices
text: WASHINGTON — In a decision that drew an unusually fierce dissent from the three female justices, the Supreme Court sided Thursday with religiously affiliated nonprofit groups in a clash between religious freedom and women’s rights.

headline: College Debt and Home Buying
text: Swelling student loan debt is commonly cited as a primary factor in the declining homeownership rate among 25- to 34-year-olds. But are the two really related?

headline: Small Army, Philharmonic in Tow

headline: 36 Hours in the Berkshires
text: The Berkshires, I used to think, were nothing special. Only after I left my childhood home in western Massachusetts did I learn that not every American countryside is crisscrossed by so many lines of music and literature, by crumbling stone walls running like half-forgotten stories through farms and woodlands, by ellipses of deep green hills fading to blue. The Berkshires, of course, have been beloved for centuries. Long before their Gilded Age heyday as the “Inland Newport,” a guillotine-fleeing lady-in-waiting of Marie Antoinette remarked on the region’s fertility and “majestic forests.” A sense of that history is one reason that I keep returning to favorite Berkshire spots. But this summer new attractions and renovations are making their mark on the county’s cultural, natural and culinary landscapes, and the decisions you’ll face every Berkshire morning — old or new? art or the outdoors? — are getting harder than ever to make.

headline: German Student Under N.S.A. Scrutiny, Reports Say
text: BERLIN — A 27-year-old informatics student in southern Germany was identified in news reports on Thursday as the first German citizen known to be under surveillance by the National Security Agency since it was revealed last year that the agency had once tapped the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Supreme Court Order on Challenge to Contraception Rule
text: The Supreme Court’s majority said Wheaton College in Illinois need not fill out forms that groups must submit to insurers and plan administrators as an alternative way to deliver free contraception to female workers under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: What Is Jamaica, Queens, Named After?
