headline: With Detention of Sarkozy, France Laments Presidency’s Faded Grandeur
text: PARIS — The monarchical majesty of the French presidency suffered an undignified blow early this year when paparazzi photographed the head of state, François Hollande, scurrying away on the back of a scooter from an assignation with a secret lover. This week it took an unprecedented new hit: Mr. Hollande’s predecessor in the Élysée Palace, Nicolas Sarkozy, whose phone had been tapped by investigators, was taken into police custody.

headline: The Ethics of Safari Hunting in Africa
Shubert Alley: Star-Gazing, but Maybe Not on Mondays
text: How about ... an Alleyscapes? The Shubert and Booth theaters, built in 1913 west of Broadway on 44th and 45th Streets, created one of the most unusual thoroughfares in New York, the through-block passage known as Shubert Alley. Although an incidental feature at first, it is now one of the most important gathering spaces in the theater district. Maryann Chach, director of the Shubert Archive, has given the odd space its first full treatment in the current issue of the archive’s newsletter, "The Passing Show," but there are still some unanswered questions.

headline: Declaration of Independents

The House, already a graveyard for common sense, will fall further under the control of politicians whose idea of legislating is to stage a hearing for Fox News. The Senate, padlocked by filibusters over everyday business, will be more of the same, with one party in nominal control.

The holiday of July Fourth is the anniversary not only of America’s birth but also of a spiritual rebirth in postwar Germany, and it is also the date of two races that are landmarks in the history of the world’s oldest automaker and in the annals of motorsports.

Another Toyota Camry?”

headline: Vintage VW Is Now a Wiener Wagon With All the Fixings
text: BIRMINGHAM, Mich. — His name is Bill Loizon, but everyone calls him Frank. For more than a decade, he has catered events from an old Volkswagen Pickup he turned into a mobile hot-dog stand — Franks Anatra, he called it. A couple of years ago, the name of the wiener wagon had to be changed, by court order, and the business was grudgingly rechristened Franks Etc.

headline: Bromance Blooms in Wintry Iceland
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Earl Lynn Nelson, 72, is an ocular plastic surgeon, the only such mender of eyeballs within a 200-mile radius of his eastern Kentucky home. He is also a hoot, a one-man party, a lover of all things carnal and delicious. Martha Stephens, 30, an indie filmmaker and his second cousin, was planning a vacation to Iceland when a thought came to her. Why not take Earl Lynn there and film that? He could go to that wild, wintry place and, well, that’s about as fleshed out as the story was when she texted her idea to a fellow filmmaker, Aaron Katz. Maybe they could direct the film together.

headline: A Secret Retreat Morphs Into a Detox Unit
text: With his pimply face, mop of tousled hair and blue-eyed stare that conveys a volatile mixture of fear and hostility, Lorenzo, the bratty 14-year-old protagonist of Bernardo Bertolucci’s “Me and You,” is the quintessence of flailing adolescent angst.

headline: In a Republican’s Ethics Issue, Democrats See an Opening
text: AUSTIN — Sam Houston, the first president of the Republic of Texas, has already staked his claim to the state’s history books. This year, a man by the same name is hoping to make a little Texas history of his own.

headline: Airbnb’s Promise: Every Man and Woman a Hotelier
text: In recent weeks, Airbnb, the online lodging site and popular Silicon Valley emblem of the sharing-loving-trusting-hugging-anyone-can-be-Conrad-Hilton economy, unveiled a promotional campaign in New York aimed at getting doubters to see what a valuable social function the company performs. In a series of ads, visible mostly in subway stations, Airbnb hosts of various races and creeds are depicted in the unpretentious living quarters they rent out — in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, in Astoria, Queens — over text explaining that Airbnb not only provides tens of thousands of New Yorkers with supplemental income, but also “strengthens our communities.”

headline: Going Without Water in Detroit
text: DETROIT — A FAMILY of five with no water for two weeks who were embarrassed to ask friends if they could bathe at their house. A woman excited about purchasing a home who learned she would be held responsible for the previous owner’s delinquent water bill: all $8,000 of it. A 90-year-old woman with bedsores and no water available to clean them.

headline: A G.O.P. Shift Against Toll Roads in Texas
text: The Republican state convention drew national headlines last month with candidates and activists staking out hard-line positions on homosexuality and immigration.

headline: Build We Won’t
text: You often find people talking about our economic difficulties as if they were complicated and mysterious, with no obvious solution. As the economist Dean Baker recently pointed out, nothing could be further from the truth. The basic story of what went wrong is, in fact, almost absurdly simple: We had an immense housing bubble, and, when the bubble burst, it left a huge hole in spending. Everything else is footnotes.

headline: Jin Soon Choi: Sometimes, She’ll Even Do Nails
text: The manicurist Jin Soon Choi, who immigrated from South Korea in 1991, is a regular at New York Fashion Week, with a roster of celebrity clients that includes Taylor Swift and Anne Hathaway. Her nail art has appeared on the cover of Italian Vogue and is featured in advertising campaigns for Prada, Dior and Jimmy Choo. Ms. Choi, 52, is the founder of JINsoon Nail Lacquer and Jin Soon Natural Hand and Foot Spa. In summertime, sandal-clad fans flock to her three Manhattan locations for the Summer Oasis Pedicure, which features cucumber slices and mint leaves, to soothe their tired, blistered feet. Ms. Choi is married to John Coughlan, 53, an architect. The two met in 1999 and live in a loft in SoHo.

headline: At a YMCA Near You, a Course for a Diabetic Nation
text: Oralia Barrios knew she’d gotten heavy, but she didn’t realize how heavy until she went to the doctor last year. At 5-foot-2, she weighed 190 pounds. And her doctor at the Open Door Family Medical Center in Port Chester, N.Y., had bad news: her blood sugar was too high. Her A1c test showed that her hemoglobin level was 5.9, making her pre-diabetic.

headline: States and Painkiller Overdoses
text: There are big differences among the states in the rates at which opioid painkillers are prescribed — differences that can’t be attributed to disparate rates of illness or injury. Unfortunately, in places where prescribing rates are high, so are death rates from overdoses.

text: It was one of the more curious reasons for a flight delay: scores of turtles — diamondback terrapins, to be precise — slowly marching across the tarmac at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Mr. Obama, Go Big on Immigration
text: This week, President Obama finally declared his independence from a suffocating debate over immigration reform that Republicans in Congress had never seriously joined. After waiting too long for the obstructionists to move, Mr. Obama has freed himself to do what he can to fix the broken-down system.

headline: The Labor Picture in June
text: The Labor Department reported that employers added 288,000 jobs in June and the unemployment rate fell 0.2 percentage points to 6.1 percent.

headline: Now Pitchers Have the Power
text: When Mark Teixeira was drafted into professional baseball in 2001, brawny hitters mauled terrified pitchers and ruled the major leagues. Less than a generation later, run producers like Teixeira feel like hunters on the prowl for endangered species.

headline: An Energized Cleveland Takes a Bipartisan Tack to Wooing Conventions
text: CLEVELAND — Attention, Internet wits: Cleveland has heard all your jokes — about “the mistake by the lake,” about its sports teams failing year after year, about its river so polluted that it once caught fire — and it wants you to know that is tired, worn-out stuff.

headline: Social Science Palooza IV
text: A day without social science is like a day without sunshine. Fortunately, every morning Kevin Lewis of National Affairs magazine gathers recent social science findings and emails them out to the masses. You can go to the National Affairs website to see and sign up for his work, but, in the meantime, here are some recent interesting findings:

headline: Brazil Comes Around as the World Cup Plays On
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — When huge protests rocked Brazilian cities a year ago, Raphael Rabelo was among the multitudes in the streets, even joining the thousands of demonstrators enraged with political corruption and spending on lavish World Cup stadiums who danced on the roof of the Congress building in Brasília.

headline: Manhattan’s Illegal Fireworks, a Tradition of Boom and Bust
text: It was a few days before the Fourth of July, and the man known to his friends as Scruff was ticking off his final to-do list. A grocery run for steak and shrimp. A haircut. And more fireworks.

headline: Carol Loomis, Editor for Warren Buffett, Leaves Job After 60 Years
text: In January 1954, a bright-eyed 24-year-old from Cole Camp, Mo., walked into Fortune magazine’s offices at Rockefeller Center. Armed with a college journalism degree and work experience writing for a Maytag company magazine, she took an entry-level job assisting Fortune’s male writers.

headline: Kurdish Officials Seek More Autonomy in Any Deal With a New Government
text: WASHINGTON — Senior Kurdish officials served notice on Thursday that Kurdistan would not participate in a new Iraqi government unless Baghdad grants it expanded autonomy and does not insist on reversing their occupation of Kirkuk.

headline: For Inspiration, the United States Should Probably Look North
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The emails have come at an accelerated pace for the past few days, under a once obscure heading: Tennis Canada. In so many words, they say, Excuse us, but we have more bad news for the fragile American tennis psyche.

headline: The Town Where Immigrants Hit a Human Wall
text: MURRIETA, Calif. — Suddenly, this city in the desert has become the place that turned away the immigrants.

headline: An Author Known for Empathy Has None for His Attacker
text: The Irish-born writer Colum McCann, author of the novels “Let the Great World Spin” and “TransAtlantic,” among others, is known for his faith in what he calls “radical empathy.” He helped found an international organization, Narrative 4, where children who have experienced hardships exchange and retell one another’s stories.

headline: As Carmelo Anthony Makes Rounds, Knicks Hope to Be Final Stop
text: When Phil Jackson spoke before the N.B.A. draft last week, he was asked whether he hoped to have a second meeting with Carmelo Anthony before Anthony decided on his future. Jackson, the Knicks’ president, offered one of his wry smiles. His response was something of a riddle.

headline: A Different Path to Fighting Addiction
text: When their son had to take a medical leave from college, Jack and Wendy knew they — and he — needed help with his binge drinking. Their son’s psychiatrist, along with a few friends, suggested Alcoholics Anonymous. He had a disease, and in order to stay alive, he’d have to attend A.A. meetings and abstain from alcohol for the rest of his life, they said.

headline: Amid Influx of Migrants, Obama Is to Skip Border Visit on Texas Trip
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama travels to Texas next week, he will come as close as he has been in weeks to the rapidly escalating border crisis that has left thousands of unaccompanied children in shelters and spurred angry protests throughout the country.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats France, 1-0

headline: Obama’s Blueprint for Fighting Terrorism Collides With Reality in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — Speaking at West Point in May, President Obama laid out a blueprint for fighting terrorism that relies less on American soldiers, like the cadets in his audience that day, and more on training troops in countries where those threats had taken root.

headline: Emblem on Captain America’s Shield
text: “LET us go then, you and I,When the evening is spread out against the sky…”— “The Love Song of Alfred J. Prufrock,” T.S. ELIOT

headline: Syria Aid Needed, Refugee Agency Says
text: The United Nations refugee agency said Thursday that 70 percent of its $3.74 billion emergency budget for helping Syrian war refugees remained unfunded, and it warned of “dramatic consequences” in the Middle East if donors failed to provide the needed aid. António Guterres, the high commissioner for refugees, also said the total number of Syrian refugees had swelled to nearly three million and was increasing at the rate of 100,000 a month. “The international community simply cannot afford to let this growing and increasingly protracted population of refugees fall through the cracks,” Mr. Guterres, above, said in a statement on the agency’s website. “Nor can we fail to support the countries who generously host them.” The biggest concentrations of Syrian refugees are in Lebanon, Turkey and Jordan, with smaller populations in Iraq and Egypt.

headline: Christie’s Veto of Gun Control Bill Angers Relatives of Newtown Victims
text: Families of children killed in the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School lashed out at Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Wednesday for vetoing a gun control bill that would have banned the sales of ammunition magazines larger than 10 rounds, after he dismissed it as a “trivial approach” to gun violence and “the embodiment of reform in name only.”

headline: U.N. Peacekeepers’ Pay Dispute Is Resolved
text: Diplomats on Thursday resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid. The countries that send troops, mostly from South Asia and Africa, are currently paid an average of $1,210 per soldier per month, a rate that has not changed for about a decade. The payments will increase gradually over the next four years, according to an agreement that is expected to be approved by the United Nations General Assembly, to just over $1,400. The countries contributing troops had wanted a rate of more than $1,700, based on an estimate provided by the United Nations Secretariat. Countries that fund peacekeeping missions — the United States, Japan and France are the largest funders — called that demand unrealistic. The total peacekeeping budget has increased to $8.6 billion, a record, though as the United Nations points out, that is less than 1 percent of total military expenditures worldwide. Each country decides how much of the reimbursement rate goes to individual soldiers.

headline: Celebrating a Diverse Music Scene
text: The Pleasantville Music Festival, scheduled for noon to 8:30 p.m. at Parkway Field on July 12, will be celebrating its 10th anniversary. And just the fact that this volunteer-run festival has been held that many years, said its executive director, Sol Skolnick, “is pretty great.”

headline: Anniversary in Egypt Draws Protests
text: Protesters held rallies in several Egyptian cities on Thursday in opposition to the military’s ouster one year ago of Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first fairly elected president. The protests in the capital, Cairo, were scattered and in some neighborhoods, small and quickly dispersed by riot police officers. At least one protester was killed. Mr. Morsi’s supporters have held regular rallies since his ouster on July 3, 2013, but the protests have dwindled in the face of an increasingly harsh government crackdown against Islamists and other dissidents that has included mass killings by the security forces, the arrests of tens of thousands of people and a ban on demonstrations. Separately on Thursday, an explosion in a Cairo apartment killed two people who the authorities said were militants in the process of preparing a bomb.

headline: 100 Years Later, Scar Remains From a Strike’s Fatal Legacy in Manhattan
text: An infamous explosion of violence a century ago in Colorado, which became known as the Ludlow Massacre, was rock bottom in what has been called the deadliest labor dispute in the nation’s history. But few people recall that just a few months later, on July 4, 1914, the strike reverberated emphatically in Manhattan.

headline: A Beeping Phone That Created a False Alarm
text: Enough time had passed that I felt it was O.K. to approach Elvis Costello last week after a Carnegie Hall concert. “Do you remember being stuck in the Columbus Airport about three years ago?” I asked.

headline: Sabathia’s Knee Swells Again, Threatening to Delay Return to Yankees
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The Yankees expected C. C. Sabathia to rejoin their rotation after the All-Star break, a boost for a team that certainly could use one. Now, that may not happen.

headline: Preschool Intern Accused of Sex Abuse Can Be Kept in Jail, Judge Says
text: A Manhattan judge ruled on Thursday that an intern at a preschool who was accused last month of inappropriately touching 13 children could be kept in jail longer, saying prosecutors had enough evidence to establish “probable cause that the defendant committed a felony.”

headline: A Philosophical Detour From Summer Lazing
text: With his elastic face, and especially that gaping mouth and those peering eyes, Richard Kind is an ideal guide through the labyrinthine, addled memories of a British consular officer recalling his days in Zurich that make up the play “Travesties.” One of Tom Stoppard’s more challenging plays, the show runs through July 20 at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor.

headline: Wheeler’s Home Run in Debut Helps Make Yankees’ Tanaka a Winner
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The home run landed in the Yankees’ bullpen in left-center, so Zelous Wheeler had no trouble retrieving his first major league hit.

headline: The Calm Before the Thud
text: On a recent afternoon in Lower Manhattan, two middle-aged men were grappling on a mat, grunting and breathing heavily as one tried desperately to pin the other down. Five other pairs were likewise entangled in this ever-shifting struggle. They were practicing “osaekomi,” or judo pinning techniques, at the Oishi Judo club.

headline: Paul S. Amos, a Co-Founder of Aflac, Dies at 88
text: Paul S. Amos, one of the three brothers who founded the Aflac insurance company nearly 60 years ago and the man behind its huge success in selling policies at workplaces, died on Wednesday in Columbus, Ga. He was 88.

headline: Hold the Home Fries. Forever.
text: Halfway around the world, my 6-year-old son could feel the pull of the Soup Burg’s eggs and sausage, the meal he would have ordered every time, in every restaurant, if he could. So when we arrived home after more than a year away, we headed straight to East 77th Street and Lexington Avenue, where we were confronted with terrible news: The Soup Burg was closing down.

headline: Adopt a Bean and Cook With It
text: John Ash, the renowned cooking teacher, chef and James Beard Award-winning author, sometimes assigns this wonderful exercise to his students: “adopt a bean” and cook with it.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: July 4, 2014
text: What to watch for in Friday’s World Cup quarterfinals, featuring two European powers and an all-South America clash.

headline: Settlement Is Contested
text: Seven former N.F.L. players accused the league and the lawyers representing 4,500 retirees of failing to justify how they reached their proposed settlement, which includes uncapped damages for players with severe neurological disorders. In a 58-page objection filed in federal court on Wednesday, the seven former players, including Alan Faneca and Robert Royal, said the proposed settlement would fail to compensate many retired players, including those showing signs of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., a degenerative neurological condition. The N.F.L. and lawyers for the plaintiffs declined to comment on the objection.

headline: Lawyers for N.C.A.A. Show Support for Northwestern
text: Lawyers for the N.C.A.A. filed a brief with the National Labor Relations Board on Thursday supporting Northwestern University, which has been trying to fend off a movement by members of its football program to form a union. Northwestern is asking the full board to overturn a regional board official’s ruling this year that the university’s scholarship football players are employees who should be considered eligible to collectively bargain.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) MACY’S 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Nick Cannon hosts this 38th annual pyrotechnic extravaganza, featuring performances by Ariana Grande, Hunter Hayes, Enrique Iglesias, Miranda Lambert, Lionel Richie and the Zac Brown Band. The Brooklyn Bridge will be the backdrop for some 40,000 shells — about 1,500 a minute — fired from barges on the lower East River.

headline: Jim Brosnan, Who Threw Literature a Curve, Dies at 84
text: Jim Brosnan, who achieved modest baseball success as a relief pitcher but gained greater fame and consequence in the game by writing about it, died on June 29 in Park Ridge, Ill. He was 84.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 4, 2014
text: “Those who are bound by our decisions usually believe they can take us at our word. Not so today.”

headline: Corrections: July 4, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Win or Lose, in Britain It’s Where the Game Is Played That Matters
text: LONDON — With Andy Murray knocked out of Wimbledon and Britons bereft about yet another prominent sports defeat, there is at least one small silver lining: the British can once again embrace “Wimbledonization.”

headline: Chinese Tycoon Pays Homage to a Fading Martyr
text: The Chinese Communist Party has not had an easy time reviving interest in Lei Feng, the most famous martyr of the People’s Liberation Army. Most Chinese learn about his ill­-fated but supposedly heroic life while in school: that he donated to the poor while a common soldier in northeastern China, devoted himself to learning the teachings of Mao Zedong and was killed at age 22 by a tumbling telephone pole knocked over by a soldier driving a truck at an army base.

headline: Fuel Cell Developer Intelligent Energy Valued at $1.1 Billion in London I.P.O.
text: LONDON — Intelligent Energy, a British developer of hydrogen fuel cells for automobiles and consumer electronics, said on Friday that its initial public offering in London valued the company at about $1.1 billion.

headline: Dance Troupe Taps Into Anti-Japanese Passions
text: On a humid summer night in Beijing, a group made up mainly of retirees gathered in front of one of Beijing’s gleaming malls to remember the past through song and dance — fake guns in tow.

headline: Richard Mellon Scaife, Influential U.S. Conservative, Dies at 82
text: Richard Mellon Scaife, the Pittsburgh philanthropist and reclusive heir to the Mellon banking fortune, whose support for right-wing causes laid the foundations for America’s modern conservative movement and fueled the 1998 impeachment of President Bill Clinton, died on Friday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 82.

headline: Joint Venture to Take Over Canary Wharf Driverless Train Line
text: LONDON — The commute to Canary Wharf, the home of much of London’s investment banking community, may soon take on a different flavor.

headline: Andy Coulson Gets 18 Months in Tabloid Phone Hacking
text: LONDON — Andy Coulson, a former senior editor in Rupert Murdoch’s news empire and a onetime adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron, was sentenced on Friday to 18 months in prison for his part in the phone hacking scandal that convulsed Britain’s press, police and political elite and inspired calls for tighter regulation of journalists.

headline: Tensions High in Jerusalem as Palestinian Teenager Is Given a Martyr’s Burial
text: JERUSALEM — Before the body arrived, young Palestinian men, some with faces covered by kaffiyehs, filled the main street, chanting about blood and guns, sacrifice and struggle.

headline: Younger Americans Are Less Patriotic. At Least, in Some Ways.
text: Americans are a patriotic bunch. Compared with people in most other countries, Americans express more pride in their nationality, and most say that being an American is an important part of their identity.

headline: Tour de France to Start in Britain, Which Seems Apropos
text: Money often determines where the Tour de France starts, with communities bidding for the right to host the first several days of the race. Exactly how much they pay the organizers is not made public, though the county of Yorkshire, England, has a £10 million, or $17 million, budget for this year’s start.

headline: All-White Is the Style, Whether the Players Appreciate It or Not
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon has long required players to wear outfits that are “predominantly in white” or “almost entirely in white.”

headline: Iris van Herpen Gets the Andam Prize, but She’s Not the Only Winner
text: Iris van Herpen, the Dutch designer who became famous (or notorious, depending on your point of view) last March when she shrink-wrapped the models at her fall show in plastic, was announced Thursday as the winner of the 2014 Andam prize, one of the oldest, most international and most lucrative of the young-fashion awards.

headline: Police Make More Arrests in Huge Hong Kong Protest
text: The police have arrested more protesters for their actions in the huge march on Tuesday in which tens of thousands of people took over the streets of downtown Hong Kong.

headline: 5 Die From Food Poisoning From Southern Chinese Snack
text: At least five people have died and another 17 others were poisoned in China’s southern Yunnan Province after they ate fermented corn flour snacks.

headline: Happy Independence Day
text: Today is the most American of holidays. So we thought we’d republish some of the pieces about the country that have appeared since our launch in April.

headline: Want to Brainstorm New Ideas? Then Limit Your Online Connections
text: The digitally connected life is both invaluable and inevitable.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week Four | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In The Times this week: an issue of the Dining section devoted to the pleasures of ice cream.

headline: Daily Report: Google Begins Deleting Search Links in Europe
text: In May, a European court told Google it must assist people in cleaning up their online reputations by ruling that there is a “right to be forgotten.”

headline: Outer Banks Mops Up and Counts Storm’s Cost
text: MANTEO, N.C. — Even on a relaxed island in the Outer Banks in North Carolina, it is rare for Mayor Jamie Daniels of Manteo to stand barefoot in someone else’s place of business.

headline: In Myanmar, the Euphoria of Reform Loses Its Glow
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Three years after Myanmar’s ruling generals shed their uniforms and propelled the country on an ambitious journey toward democracy, security forces are back on the streets of the former military dictatorship.

headline: Standoff Between Israel and the West Bank
text: After the killings of four young people, tensions between Israelis and Palestinians are high.

headline: Volatile Chemistry in an Underheated Flat
text: LONDON — When acting is this focused, your own vision seems to improve miraculously. Watching Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy in Stephen Daldry’s laser-sharp new production of David Hare’s “Skylight,” at Wyndham’s Theater here, you may feel you’ve been endowed with superhuman insight.

headline: Television That Is More Than Child’s Play
text: Talking trucks. Dinosaur trucks. Builders who use elaborate trucks. Then there are space adventurers, animal and alien, as well as genies and fairies. Television networks and their online streaming equivalents are awash in new characters intended to appeal to preschoolers.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Taystee! How Could You?
text: Season 2, Episode 9 Just when you think you’re not attached to characters, just when you think you’re watching at some remove, they have to do something that makes you want to yell “NO!” at the television, to make you realize how deeply invested you are, how magical the thinking that you might be able to save them from their obvious fate.

headline: China Detains 6 Vietnamese Fishermen
text: Chinese ships detained six Vietnamese fishermen in disputed waters between China and Vietnam on Thursday, a move that could heighten tensions between the two countries.

headline: Which World Cup Team to Root For, Reconsidered
text: At lunch this week in Rio de Janeiro, I asked a Brazilian friend how many times Brazil had won the World Cup in his lifetime. He said, “Once — ummm, no, twice.” His incorrect initial answer nailed one of my concerns with a ranking I devised last week, a World Cup Utilitarian Fan Index, which aimed to measure how much aggregate happiness would be created by a particular team’s victory. Is the second win in one’s recent lifetime really as important as the first? Clearly not to my friend, who forgot about the second one. And he considers himself a pretty avid Brazilian soccer fan.

headline: German Man Arrested as Spy Implicates U.S.
text: BERLIN — In the latest turn in the yearlong tensions with Germany over American spying, a German man was arrested this week on suspicion of passing secret documents to a foreign power, believed to be the United States. The American ambassador, John B. Emerson, was summoned to the Foreign Office here and urged to help with what German officials called a swift clarification of the case.

headline: Merkel Heads to China to Keep Alive ‘Golden Decade’ of Deals
text: BERLIN — With some experts warning that the “golden decade” of rapid growth in German-Chinese trade and dealings may be ending, Chancellor Angela Merkel embarks this weekend on her seventh visit to China, accompanied by top people from German business who, surveys indicate, are still markedly more optimistic about China than are their European counterparts.

headline: Five Recent T Style and Culture Reads for the Fourth of July
text: America’s birthday provides a perfect opportunity to kick back, relax and enjoy the best of fashion, culture and food. Here, a few recent T stories that offer ideas for the weekend — or simply inspire a celebratory summer mood.

headline: Summer Love
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Google Reinstates European Links to Articles From The Guardian
text: LONDON — Google’s efforts to carry out a European court order on the “right to be forgotten” took another twist on Friday as the company restored search-engine links to several newspaper articles from The Guardian whose delinking had stirred a public furor only a day earlier.

headline: Chinese Leader, Underlining Ties to South Korea, Cites Japan as Onetime Mutual Enemy
text: SEOUL, South Korea — China’s visiting president, Xi Jinping, reminded South Koreans on Friday that their two countries had fought “shoulder to shoulder” against Japan more than four centuries ago, highlighting what analysts have called the main goal of his visit: unsettling America’s alliances in Northeast Asia.

headline: New Offices Reflect Growth of Busy Anticorruption Agency
text: The main symbol on the homepage of China’s anticorruption agency shows the unadorned, old-school, gold hammer and sickle of the Communist Party, to which it belongs entirely. But that simplicity belies a harried new reality these days — the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is in a flurry of activity as it carries out instructions from the president, Xi Jinping, to pull down “tigers” as well as “flies,” or high-level corrupt officials as well as low-level ones, according to people who have worked with it or are familiar with its doings.

headline: France vs. Germany: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Germany advanced to its 16th straight quarterfinals, but not before getting an almighty scare from minnows Algeria. Its defense, in particular, looked shaky, which will not do against Karim Benzema, Mathieu Valbuena, Paul Pogba and France’s potent attack, which has 10 goals in four games.

headline: Classical Playlist: Ailyn Pérez and Stephen Costello, Milton Babbitt, Handel and More
text: ‘LOVE DUETS’Ailyn Pérez, soprano, and Stephen Costello, tenorBBC Symphony Orchestra, Patrick Summers, conductor(Warner Classics) The opera world has a new love couple: the soprano Ailyn Pérez and the tenor Stephen Costello, who are married and have been appearing together to acclaim. They have been smart, so far, to carefully maintain individual careers. Their latest husband-wife project, though, is an appealing recording: a program of diverse “Love Duets.” Ms. Pérez’s warm, penetrating voice matches well but also contrasts interestingly with Mr. Costello’s rich, virile sound. They excel in duets from Massenet’s “Manon,” Verdi’s “La Traviata,” Gounod’s “Faust” and, best of all, the tender “Cherry Duet” from Mascagni’s “L’amico Fritz.” “One Hand, One Heart” from Bernstein’s “West Side Story” is disappointing: too somber, slow and self-consciously operatic. But they are charming in “I’ll Know” from “Guys and Dolls.” (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: British TV Entertainer Is Sentenced for Sexual Abuse
text: LONDON — Rolf Harris, once one of Britain’s most popular television entertainers, was sentenced on Friday to five years and nine months in prison for a range of sexual offenses committed decades ago against girls and young women, one of them as young as 8.

headline: Macro Debates and the Relevance of Intellectual History
text: One of the interesting things about the ongoing economic crisis is the way it has demonstrated the importance of historical knowledge. This is only the second global financial crisis serious enough to drive interest rates down to the zero lower bound in most major economies; making sense of it has depended crucially on knowing something about the first.

headline: 2 Jobs at Sugar Factory, and a Lump in the Throat
text: Robert Shelton had never seen the floor of what he always called the sugar house until the day this spring when he returned to the Domino refinery. In the 20 years he worked in its char house, the kilns blasting the temperature up to 140 degrees year round, the mounds of unbleached crystals had never dipped below the seven- or eight-foot mark.

headline: Arthur Ashe, Pathbreaker: From Richmond to Wimbledon, and Back
text: When the 25-year-old Arthur Ashe was cheered as a winner at the first U.S. Open in 1968, he threw an arm around the shoulders of his fiercely proud father, who wept.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Land Ho!’
text: In this video, the directors Aaron Katz and Martha Stephens narrate a scene from their comedy “Land Ho!,” which they shot in Iceland and which features Paul Eenhoorn and Earl Lynn Nelson.

headline: Buildings With a Past
text: New York has always been a place where people could start over, reinvent, try something new.

headline: New York Summer Stories: At the Turn of the Century
text: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times’s archives that tell tales of New York City summers past.

headline: By the Numbers, the Edge Goes to Petra Kvitova
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The women’s final at Wimbledon will feature the surging Canadian Eugenie Bouchard against the former champion Petra Kvitova from the Czech Republic.

headline: 1914: Mercedes Finishes First in Grand Prix
text: The greatest automobile race of the year, the Grand Prix, organized by the Automobile Club de France, ended yesterday on the Lyons circuit in a definite and conclusive German victory. Lautenschlager, driving a Mercedes machine, finished first; Wagner, also driving a Mercedes, was second, and Salzer, another German, in the same make of machine, was third. Never since 1895, when the Automobile Club de France organized its first big competition, the race from Paris to Bordeaux, has an automobile race attracted so huge a crowd. Even the Paris-Vienna and Paris-Madrid contests of 1902 and 1903 were eclipsed. Lyons was hardly recognizable. It was the magnet for hundreds of automobiles and thousands and thousands of spectators. On Friday many of the cafés remained open all night. The streets were lined with automobiles unable to obtain garage, and the pavements were black with a multitude of pedestrians moving, because they could not help it, at a snail’s pace. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 5, 1914

headline: New Delay for F-35 Jets as Defense Department Grounds Fleet After a Fire
text: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department has grounded its fleet of F-35 fighter jets after one of them caught fire as it was preparing to take off at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida.

headline: Protecting Parrotfish on the Path to a Caribbean Reef Revival
text: Coral reefs in much of the Caribbean have been badly degraded in recent decades by die-offs of algae-munching sea urchins, high-temperature bleaching events, overfishing, invasive species and runoff from fast-paced coastal development.

headline: Navigating Sprawling Indonesia
text: When Elizabeth Pisani set out to research her new book, “Indonesia, Etc.: Exploring the Improbable Nation,” she passed up any ambition to pin the vast archipelago nation down in a pithy manner. “We don’t even know how many islands there are,” Ms. Pisani said. Some officials say 17,000; others, 15,000. “It’s an extraordinarily difficult thing for even its own government to get its head around, let alone an outsider like me.”

headline: On the Absinthe Trail
text: Sunbeams shot through the forest, lighting up the wispy fog on the path ahead. For over an hour I’d been walking up the mountain trail without seeing a soul, marching to the off-kilter orchestras of Swiss cowbells ringing their dull symphonies in nearby meadows, to which I added my own contrapuntal exhalations whenever I stopped to catch my breath. For several minutes, I was certain that I had lost my way. But eventually I spotted a sign for the goal I was seeking: La Fontaine Froide, it said, was somewhere up ahead.

headline: Exploring Lanai, Hawaii, Rough Roads to Resorts
text: The first clue that Lanai is not just another Hawaiian island comes as your two-propeller plane banks off the Pacific Ocean, crossing stark cliffs rising out of the churning blue water before lowering over fields rustling with scrappy brown shrub, dry and flat in all directions, and onto the single runway at Lanai Airport. There is barely a swaying palm tree, beach umbrella, sparkling pool, or splash of tropical color in sight.

headline: Banco Itaú of Brazil Sells Insurance Unit to Ace
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Banco Itaú of Brazil, Latin America’s largest private-sector bank, announced Friday that it is selling its high-risk corporate insurance unit, Itaú Seguros Soluções Corporativas, for about $685 million to Ace Limited, an insurance company headquartered in Zurich that trades on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: 1939: Nazi Germany Unprepared for World War II
text: BERLIN — Germany is faced with seemingly insurmountable obstacles to real preparedness for war, according to the semi-annual economic review of the Reichskredit Gesellschaft, which was published here today. Just at a time when the entire world is studying the Reich’s economic position in an effort to determine its war potential, this mid- year report reveals there are still a number of monkey wrenches in the country’s war machinery. Germany apparently is still handicapped by a severe shortage of labor, food products and raw materials. The economic expert, who summarized the report, found that the labor shortage is one of the weakest spots in Germany’s militarized economy. Even with the present size of fine armed forces, there is a shortage of one million workers and the only apparent way to increase the number of industrial and building workers is to import more foreign labor and ‘‘comb out superfluous labor’’ in the retail trades. It is estimated that the country could get 450,000 laborers by the combing-out process. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 5, 1939.

headline: Bank of America Names Co-Heads of Investment Banking in Britain
text: LONDON – Bank of America Merrill Lynch has named Ian Ferguson and Michael Findlay as the new co-heads for its investment banking business in Britain and Ireland.

headline: Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Gets Its Turn
text: Nestled next to Prospect Park and home to the popular Brooklyn Children’s Museum, along with subway stops for four express trains, Crown Heights seems to be having a moment.

headline: Learning Young the Gift of Helping Others
text: THE Moret girls, Zoe, Mia and Sophie, are given a choice when they turn 5: Have a birthday party of their choice with presents from their friends or have the same party but forgo the presents.

headline: Reflections on America
text: This week the Book Review has a themed issue for the Fourth of July holiday weekend, specifically around what we consider, per our issue headline, “American Ideals, American Realities.”

headline: The Men’s Final Remains in Familiar Hands
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For several years now, a trickle of promising young players has bubbled up, threatened to erode the top layer of men’s tennis and receded again. Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal have held firm, allowing room only for Novak Djokovic, then for Andy Murray.

headline: Investors Are Pushing Starter-Home Prices Up
text: WALL STREET is driving up home prices again, but this time it is not by granting mortgages to customers who cannot afford houses. Instead, institutional investors have been buying up relatively inexpensive homes, particularly in areas hard hit by foreclosures during and after the Great Recession.

headline: New Rules Allow Carry-Over of Flexible Health Funds
text: IF your employer offers health care flexible spending accounts, you may have a new option for managing the funds.

headline: Animal House
text: Gregory Speck, a collector of taxidermy, is about to place his apartment on the market for $3.39 million. The animals are negotiable.

headline: Fashionably, the '50s
text: PARIS — Thus far it seems doubtful that 21st century fashion is going to be organized neatly into filing cabinet drawer-like decades, as the 20th century was. Say “the ’70s” and your interlocutor is likely to flash on bell-bottoms or bralessness; the ’60s might produce associations of pillbox hats and miniskirts. And the ’50s?

headline: It’s a Jungle in Here
text: When Gregory Speck opens the door to his Classic 6 apartment at the Beresford, an Emery Roth-designed co-op at 211 Central Park West, he greets guests with a Southern lilt: “Welcome to Animal House.”

headline: Some States Look to Fill a Retirement Savings Gap
text: SAVING for retirement early and often is part of the common financial wisdom. But those nest eggs aren’t always enough.

headline: Two Brothers, and the Blessings of Ballet
text: Christopher and Adam Holms, the brothers behind the roughly three-month-old Norwalk Metropolitan Youth Ballet, take pride in how many of the program’s early enrollees, about one of every four students, have been boys.

headline: After-School Detention Can Be Steamy
text: Some teenage boy must really have displeased Lissa Levin to have inspired such an irreverent comedy.

headline: World War II Tanks Roll Out on Long Island
text: OLD BETHPAGE, N.Y. — The convoy rolled out with Jim Lennon at the wheel of a scout car, the kind of olive-drab machine with a gun above the windshield that Allied soldiers drove in World War II. As he gunned the engine and headed up a dirt road through a pasture, the split-levels of the Long Island suburbs seemed far away.

headline: Metal, Poetry and Satan
text: Ben Ratliff and the poet Michael Robbins discuss the current state of metal and the music’s perhaps surprising similarities with poetry.

headline: Popcast: Metal, Poetry and Satan
text: The poet Michael Robbins, author of “Alien vs. Predator,” has written that poetry and metal share something: they are “arts of accusation and instruction.” They are also both persistent arts in which hundreds of mini-audiences — enacted, in metal, through worldwide substreams like black metal, death metal, melodeath, blackened death, doom, et cetera — do not, at this point, add up to a popular culture. And they are arts that have given us new ways to think about Satan, at least as a metaphor for something else. John Milton, meet Nergal, from the Polish blackened-death metal band Behemoth.

headline: Educated Fools Abound in ‘The Learned Ladies’
text: Their hair is big and their intellectual posturing is even bigger. They are Molière’s “The Learned Ladies,” and their ridiculous pretensions yield many a laugh in the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s current revival of his 1672 comedy.

headline: Big Ticket | $20.87 Million at One57
text: For the fifth time this year, a three-bedroom apartment at One57, the Extell Development Company’s 90-story glassy Midtown tower, was the most expensive sale of the week, selling for $20,877,625, according to city records.

headline: Barclays Suit Sheds Light on Trading in Shadows
text: Dark pools just got a little brighter.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Tammy,’ ‘Life Itself’ and ‘Earth to Echo’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Tammy,” “Life Itself” and “Earth to Echo.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: The Hopes of Central America Rest on a Perpetual Underdog
text: SÃO PAULO — When Costa Rica played Uruguay on June 14 in its first game of the World Cup, it was not so much a case of David versus Goliath as it was David versus David. That time fortune favored the Central Americans: Against all expectations — they had never beaten Uruguay, the two-time Cup winners — the Costa Ricans won, 3-1.

headline: Shut Out of White House, G.O.P. Looks to Democrats of 1992
text: WASHINGTON — It took 24 years for Democrats to end the last period of Republican presidential advantage, in which issues and the makeup of the Electoral College helped Republicans win five of six elections, and to start their own behind Bill Clinton.

headline: Johansson Wins Suit Over a Lookalike Character
text: Scarlett Johansson gainfully posed in underwear and spiked heels for Esquire’s cover last year after the magazine named her the “sexiest woman alive.” But a French novelist’s fictional depiction of a look-alike so angered the film star that she sued the best-selling author for defamation.

headline: Vows | The Wedding Watchers
text: Every summer Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn attracts wedding parties as a backdrop for pictures. For decades Rhoda Hill, 79, and her fellow wedding watchers have enjoyed the spectacle.

headline: All About the Angles
text: Because he is a choreographer, Warren Carlyle tends to think differently from most people about angles and lines and planes.

text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Italy Accuses Germany of Undermining Its Economic Efforts
text: ROME — Italy’s prime minister on Friday accused Germany’s central bank of blocking efforts to stimulate regional growth and putting the interests of financiers before citizens in the European Union.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Peter Baker reviews Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “Hard Choices.” Mr. Baker writes

headline: German Proposal Seeks to Sharply Curtail Fracking
text: BERLIN — Germany’s ministers for energy and the environment are seeking a ban on shale gas and oil drilling over the next seven years because of worries that the practice could pollute drinking water and damage the environment.

headline: College Group Run for Profit Looks to Close or Sell Schools
text: Facing heavy losses and a crackdown by government agencies, Corinthian Colleges, one of the largest for-profit operators of trade schools and colleges, will largely cease operating under an agreement with the federal Education Department.

headline: How Much Will Brazil Miss Neymar?
text: Teams that have relied heavily on one player being involved in its scoring chances have fared much better than teams that have shared those opportunities more evenly.

headline: It’s Tasty and Political: Britain Presses U.S. on Haggis
text: LONDON — The British government is pulling out all the stops for Scotland with a referendum on independence two months away, going so far as to lobby the United States government to allow the importation of that famous Scottish delicacy made from sheep’s innards, haggis.

headline: Paying Employees to Stay, Not to Go
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Ben Nawn, a sophomore at the University of New Hampshire, says his friends who work at McDonald’s are envious of what he earns working for the Boloco burrito restaurant here.

headline: Actors’ Union Reaches a Deal for Movie and TV Contract
text: The union representing performers and others in the media and entertainment industries announced on Friday that it has reached an agreement with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers for a new three-year theatrical and television contract, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Germany Wins a Battle of the Old Guard
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — As appetizers go, it was more of a dessert: a World Cup quarterfinal at Estádio do Maracanã between two European powerhouses featuring 22 starting players who play club soccer in England, Spain, France, Italy or Germany. For much of the world, it was a heavyweight fight contested in one of the sport’s greatest venues.

headline: Aims of Donor Are Shadowed by Past in Coal
text: To environmentalists across Australia, it is a baffling anachronism in an era of climate change: the construction of a 4,000-acre mine in New South Wales that will churn out carbon-laden coal for the next 30 years.

headline: Brazil vs. Colombia: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Host Brazil has not had any favors in the knockout draw. After outlasting a fast, aggressive Chile team on penalties, it must now face Colombia, arguably the most impressive team in the tournament so far. James Rodriguez of Colombia has become a bona fide star, with five goals so far, and Brazil is going to need to find a way to stop him, as well as improve at, well, just about every position that Neymar doesn’t play.

headline: The Secret of Effective Motivation
text: THERE are two kinds of motive for engaging in any activity: internal and instrumental. If a scientist conducts research because she wants to discover important facts about the world, that’s an internal motive, since discovering facts is inherently related to the activity of research. If she conducts research because she wants to achieve scholarly renown, that’s an instrumental motive, since the relation between fame and research is not so inherent. Often, people have both internal and instrumental motives for doing what they do.

headline: Virus Plagues the Pork Industry, and Environmentalists
text: The bodies are piling up fast.

headline: Sailing With a Ghost From Auschwitz
text: An opera begins with a married German couple on a long sea journey in the late 1950s. The two are traveling from Europe to Brazil, where the husband has taken a diplomatic post.

headline: 30 Years Later, a Cosmos Reanimated
text: On a soggy night in April, Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village provided a soothing sanctuary from a downpour. At one side of the club’s stage, the composer and record producer Craig Leon conjured a hypnotic drone from his synthesizer and laptop; on the other, his wife and collaborator, Cassell Webb, commanded another synth. Between them, the American Contemporary Music Ensemble string quartet gently bopped bows against violins and cello, keeping time with the sinuous mechanized pulse.

headline: Bucolic Outpost for Downtown Creativity
text: MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y. — As the artistic director of Mount Tremper Arts, Mathew Pokoik is also, more informally, the head chef. One evening last month at this rural performance center, he could be found hauling pans of smoked brisket and creamed corn from the farmhouse to the lawn, which overlooks an undulating stretch of the Catskills. For that night’s party and performance, a prelude to the center’s seventh annual summer festival, which begins on July 11, he had prepared dinner for 72.

headline: A Fish Out of Water, for Real and on TV
text: Americans would be forgiven for never having heard of Greg Poehler. After all, this legal eagle turned stand-up comedian has been sequestered for the last eight years in that sunlight-challenged, design-superior netherland known as Sweden.

headline: A Dancehall Debut and Love Songs From a Philosopher
text: Popcaan

headline: Iraqi Premier to Run for a Third Term
text: BAGHDAD — Despite sharp criticism from almost every political party in Iraq and pressure from friendly foreign powers to step down, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced Friday that he would seek a third term as prime minister.

headline: When Pupils Are Away, Teachers Play (and Jam)
text: The pianist Geri Allen has been running an educational residency this week for female jazz musicians ages 14 to 25, administered by the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and housed at Montclair State University. Ms. Allen herself is the kind of musician that jazz produces only when its philosophies and systems are working. Her playing keeps getting bigger, showing no contradiction between tradition and risk; it teaches as it challenges.

headline: In Battle of Muscle Shows, Only One Is Having Fun
text: Certain Americans — you know the type — take physical fitness far too seriously. These people probably don’t spend a lot of time on the couch watching television; they’re too busy training for the next Ironman or Spartan Death Race.

headline: Edition Has Alternate Opening of ‘Sun Also Rises’
text: Contestants on “Jeopardy!” this week were asked to identify the book that opens with this line: “Robert Cohn was once middleweight boxing champion of Princeton.” The answer (or rather the question) was: What is “The Sun Also Rises”?

headline: Week in Pictures for July 4
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes a police informer and Police Academy graduates.

headline: Tradition Meets Innovation, Italian-Style
text: Most Italian restaurants in New Jersey either specialize in red sauce and meatballs or focus more on perfecting their veal Francese or pasta and shellfish dishes. Those that embrace fresh ingredients and experimentation are few and far between. Girasole Cucina Italiana in Bound Brook offers a little bit of everything. Since its opening in 1996, one of the owners, Rob Russo, 45, has emphasized an ever-changing specials menu without ignoring the importance of a good Bolognese sauce.

headline: How Netherlands Women’s Team Beat Italy’s
text: The Netherlands won the women’s event at the European Team Championships in Croatia last Tuesday. The Dutch team members were Carla Arnolds, Wietske van Zwol, Marion Michielsen, Meike Wortel, Jet Pasman and Anneke Simons, with Alex van Reenen as the nonplaying captain.

headline: Twinkling Orbs of a Starry Run
text: For many dancegoers, American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which ends on Saturday, is special because of its visiting stars. Where else in the world can you compare the Giselles of Diana Vishneva and Alina Cojocaru in one week?

headline: For This Class, Professors Pass Screen Tests
text: CHANTILLY, Va. — Attention, college professors: If you aspire to film a lecture series for the Great Courses, the extended-learning outfit here, be prepared to check your idiosyncrasies at the door.
