text: To the Editor:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Diving for Treasure in Less Traveled Seas
text: Admit it: These days, nothing says “long holiday weekend” like Netflix. Or Amazon, Hulu, iTunes, Vudu, Google Play or Xbox Video.

headline: Drama Onstage and Off
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Impassioned pleas, angry remonstrations and intrigue marked the first two nights of the Aix-en-Provence Festival. There was opera, too — Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” on Wednesday, and Handel’s “Ariodante” on Thursday — but it was sometimes drowned out by the clamor of demonstrations outside the theaters.

headline: Now on Your Cellphone Bill, Services You Never Wanted
text: For years, phone carriers have wanted to find ways to make it easy for mobile customers to buy things and charge them to their phone bills.

headline: On Construction: Buy American
text: To the Editor:

headline: Take a Seat, Dockside, for Asian Flavors
text: Wide, white and airy, with shiny wood floors and a blue and white décor delivered with nautical flair, Harlow East is the quintessential Hamptons restaurant, offering expansive views of the water both inside and out. The restaurant, which opened on Memorial Day weekend, is the Sag Harbor outpost of the Manhattan restaurant Harlow, on East 56th Street. Neither place has anything to do with the Depression-era actress Jean Harlow, but both are named after the 8-year-old daughter of Richie Notar, the owner. Harlow East is located on Long Wharf in the former home of another New York City success story: B. Smith. If you go, try to snag a table on the wide porch under the crisp, navy blue awning to take in the best bay views. After all, you’ll be paying for it.

headline: The ‘Personhood’ Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tastes From (at Least) Three Countries
text: A spot of bright style in a drab strip mall, Han Asian Cuisine is crowded on a Friday, on a Wednesday, even on a Monday. I’m guessing this popularity reflects the restaurant’s versatility. The big menu created by the chef and primary owner, James Chen, combines three cuisines, Japanese, Chinese and Thai — with a few Korean add-ons — and mixes corner-take-out favorites with more ambitious offerings.

headline: Brazil Takes a Painful Step Forward
text: FORTALEZA, Brazil — It was an enormous win for Brazil, but it came at a gigantic cost.

headline: How to Prevent Summer Blackouts
text: IT’S July, and it’s starting to get hot. This month last year — on Friday, July 19, 2013 — New York City broke its electricity usage record. The demand strained Con Ed’s grid until it broke. Within hours, 5,200 Bronx residents were without power. And as more heat rolled in, the blackouts did too, in Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston — no major metropolitan area on the East Coast was spared. Earlier that summer, California, Texas, Illinois and other states fought the same battle with heat-driven peak demand. Canada, Japan, India, Nepal and virtually the entire world face the same issue.

headline: Friday Night Dancing: Clones
text: From the season finale of Orphan Black, featuring Jordan Gavaris, Tatiana Maslany, Tatiana Maslany, Tatiana Maslany, and Tatiana Maslany:

headline: Introducing the ON? App, the Yo of the Future
text: “BRILLIANT.” “Magical.” “Revolutionary.” These are words no one is using to describe Yo, the new app that lets users send the message “Yo” to other users and does absolutely nothing else. But here are some words they are using: “$1 million has already been staked on its success.”

headline: Two Kinds of Refreshment Near the Water
text: Want to get yourself in a really great mood?

headline: In Messi’s Shadow, Argentine Fans Find a New Hero to Worship
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina has been disjointed at the World Cup, relying heavily on Lionel Messi for its goals and a couple of narrow escapes. Messi’s fellow forwards, Gonzalo Higuaín and Sergio Agüero, have fumbled, and after Agüero was injured, his replacement, Ezequiel Lavezzi, played poorly enough that he was substituted.

headline: Yanks Stop Twins but Get Discouraging News on Sabathia
text: MINNEAPOLIS — C. C. Sabathia appeared briefly, unbilled, on the Jumbotron at Target Field before Friday’s game between the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins. Sabathia was one of several players who were filmed as they read portions of Lou Gehrig’s “luckiest man” speech, on the 75th anniversary of the July 4, 1939, ceremony honoring Gehrig, who died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis two years later.

headline: An Online Shift in China Muffles an Open Forum
text: BEIJING — For the past few years, social media in China has been dominated by the Twitter-like Sina Weibo, a microblogging service that created an online sphere of freewheeling public debate, incubating social change and at times even holding politicians accountable in a country where traditional media outlets are severely constrained.

headline: Taking on Hobby Lobby After Turning Away From a Religious Past
text: There are many ways a high school senior might decide on a college: cost, what majors are offered, a decent football team, a really rocking Greek system. But when Sarah Jones was in high school in rural Bristol, Va., she was moved by other criteria.

headline: About Those Presidential Polls
text: Perhaps you’ve heard that Barack Obama was named the worst president since World War II in a recent poll. It isn’t all that surprising. Given the current mood of the country, it’s likely that if St. Francis of Assisi were in the White House, he would be getting terrible ratings, too.

headline: Not All Will Follow This Star in the East
text: PRAGUE — THE REV. TOMAS HALIK sat in a nest of books in an art-cluttered apartment a few blocks from his parish at the foot of the Charles Bridge. Shelves lined each room and tall stacks tottered on desks, on tables, across every open space.

headline: Who Do We Think We Are?
text: WASHINGTON — AMERICA’S infatuation with the World Cup came at the perfect moment, illuminating the principle that you can lose and still advance.

headline: Still Further to Go on Land Mines
text: Ridding the world of destructive weapons is a slow and often discouraging process. The international treaty outlawing land mines started out that way but has turned into a success story, with 161 countries joining the pact. Nevertheless, the treaty will not reach its full effect if the United States, the most significant holdout, does not also sign on. President Obama took a step in that direction last week, but it is still not enough.

headline: Homicide Charges Likely in Baruch College Fraternity Retreat Case
text: Pennsylvania authorities expect to bring charges against most of the 30 or so Baruch College students who were on a rural fraternity retreat in December when a freshman died after a pledging ritual, a police official said this week.

headline: A Truth Widely Held to Be Self-Evident: It’s a Glorious Fourth, Rain or Shine
text: They huddled under tents and tarps suspended from tree branches on Friday as the wind and rain swept relentlessly downriver off the George Washington Bridge. They were dressed in garbage bags, fearlessly holding umbrellas in one hand, tongs in the other.

headline: Unease in G.O.P. Over Mississippi Tea Party Anger
text: WASHINGTON — The stormy aftermath of Mississippi’s Republican Senate runoff has sent Tea Party conservatives around the country to the ramparts, raising the prospect of a prolonged battle that holds the potential to depress conservative turnout in November in Mississippi — and possibly beyond.

headline: In Reversal of Earlier Strategy, Knicks Ply Anthony With Cash
text: Phil Jackson, the Knicks’ president, had gone out of his way in recent weeks to emphasize the importance of cap space and financial flexibility, buzzwords for his interest in fiscal responsibility. As Carmelo Anthony approached free agency, Jackson continued to preach the virtues of sacrificing cash for the greater good.

headline: Lessons From Argentina’s Bond Battle
text: A long-running legal dispute between Argentina and investors who own some of its bonds could force the country to default on its foreign debt by the end of the month. That would be a crushing blow for the already weak Argentine economy and could make it much harder for other troubled countries to restructure their debt in the future.

headline: Painted by His Classmates: A Portrait of the Con Artist as a Young Man
text: The 17-year-old from Pennsylvania stood out when he showed up for his freshman year at the University of Arizona, and 50-plus years later, his former classmates remembered him well.

headline: House Job, Comes With Free Travel
text: Taxpayers complaining about a do-nothing Congress should take note that free travel junkets by lawmakers and their staffs are on the rise. House members are doing something. Last year, they took more free trips financed by special interests than were taken in any other year since Jack Abramoff, the legendary Republican uber-lobbyist, was sentenced to prison in 2006 for corrupt schemes that gave congressional junketeering a bad name.

headline: A Town Won’t Let Go of a Coin-Drop Line to the Past
text: PRAIRIE GROVE, Ark. — As the driver of an S.U.V. drifted off to sleep one recent afternoon, her vehicle drifted across a momentarily quiet two-lane highway. It came to rest on grass, but not before hitting a utility pole, an ornamental gas lamp and an upright rectangular structure of aluminum and glass.

headline: Another Indictment in Albany
text: It is often said that New York’s state legislators leave office only when they die, retire or get indicted — which comes pretty close to the truth. Since 1999, according to Citizens Union, 26 state legislators have left office either because they have been charged with a crime or they have been shamed into resigning for ethical lapses.

headline: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Gasoline stocks in the Kurdish region are running low, requiring rationing and hourslong waits for a fill-up. Hundreds of thousands of civil servants have gone months without a paycheck after Baghdad cut payments to the regional government in retaliation for its exporting oil without permission.

headline: My American Family
text: On the Fourth of July 1951, my parents were married. Not long ago, I asked my mother, who, at 87, is still going strong, why they chose that date. I thought there might have been some symbolism. She quickly disabused me. It was because that was the only time “the market” would be closed, and my father’s family could attend the wedding.

headline: Man Accused in Brooklyn Hit-and-Run Had Trouble With Drugs
text: The lawyer for a drug addict charged with crashing a stolen minivan into a family in Brooklyn, killing a 12-year-old girl and injuring her sister and mother, detailed on Friday how he brokered his client’s surrender as details about the suspect’s trail of recent arrests came into focus.

headline: Californians Keep Up With Joneses’ Water Use
text: LOS ANGELES — For all the doomsday proclamations about the historic drought that has this state in a chokehold, here is what Californians have done to save water: not much.

headline: How to Redraw the World Map
text: What parts of the world should rethink their maps? Why and how?

headline: As They Invade, Argentines Seek Soccer Conquest
text: BRASÍLIA — There is a new song going around the World Cup, a ditty sung by the Argentines to taunt their Brazilian hosts and longstanding rivals. The gist is simple. It asks the Brazilians how they feel about being bossed around in their own country and tells them to prepare for an Argentine championship on their own soil.

headline: Refugee Camp for Syrians in Jordan Evolves as a Do-It-Yourself City
text: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — A young Syrian salesman stopped into Ahmad Bidawi’s barbershop for a shave the other day. Music wafted on fan-cooled air. Outside, on what has become the main commercial strip here in one of the world’s largest refugee camps, workers steered handcarts packed with lumber and kitchen appliances through sunbaked crowds hanging out in front of shops.

headline: Obama Weighs Steps to Cover Contraception
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, reeling from back-to-back blows from the Supreme Court this week, is weighing options that would provide contraceptive coverage to thousands of women who are about to lose it or never had it because of their employers’ religious objections.

headline: The Emojis We Really Need
text: Last month, some 250 new emojis were rolled out by the Unicode Consortium, which develops software standards. Here are several that they might consider adding to that list.

headline: Bruno Zumino Dies at 91; Sought to Tie Together Laws of Universe
text: Bruno Zumino, a physicist who proposed a theory called supersymmetry that promised to help tie together the fundamental laws of the universe but that has yet to be borne out in experiments, died June 21 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 91.

headline: At Retooled Maracanã, Olympics Are Palpable
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — You come to the Maracanã on a pilgrim’s tiptoes: to see and feel the place where nearly 200,000 fans once watched a World Cup final; where Pelé scored his 1,000th goal; where Zico played his last match for Flamengo.

headline: Young American Qualifier Says She Has Cancer
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Having reached the second round of Wimbledon as a qualifier, the 18-year-old American Victoria Duval will make her debut in the top 100 of the WTA rankings on Monday, the next step in what has been a steady climb up the rankings.

headline: Gerald Robinson, Priest Convicted of Killing Ohio Nun, Dies at 76
text: The Rev. Gerald Robinson, a Catholic priest who was convicted in 2006 of murdering a nun more than 20 years earlier, died on Friday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 76.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 4, 2014
text: July 4, 2014

headline: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Costa Rica in Shootout
text: The Netherlands beat Costa Rica, 4-3, on penalties after 120 scoreless minutes, with substitute goalkeeper Tim Krul making two saves in the shootout. The Dutch advance to play Argentina in the semifinals on Wednesday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Ousts Belgium, 1-0
text: Lionel Messi didn’t score but his teammate, Gonzalo Higuaín, did to help Argentina defeat Belgium and advance to the semifinals.

headline: 11th-Hour Talks Are Key for American Apparel
text: The future of American Apparel hangs in the balance.

headline: World Cup Drama Plays Out Among Drivers in IndyCar
text: The IndyCar driver Helio Castroneves is no stranger to the Brazil-Colombia rivalry. A Brazilian, Castroneves is teammates at Team Penske with the Colombian Juan Pablo Montoya, and he lives with his Colombian girlfriend, Adriana Henao.

headline: What Ruthless People Show
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always nice to have a David Steinberg puzzle on a weekend. Not only do you have to stretch your memory muscles to get the excellent entries that cover many decades, but between Mr. Steinberg and Will Shortz, you have some really entertaining cluing.

headline: New Brooklyn Theater Casts Audience in Crucial Role
text: The four plays speak to a grim period in American history, touching on slavery, lynching and broader issues of racism. Two of the plays are by Harlem Renaissance writers, including Zora Neale Hurston. One was commissioned by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People right after its founding at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side.

headline: Emilio Álvarez Montalván, Nicaragua’s Pro-Democracy Sage, Dies at 94
text: Emilio Álvarez Montalván, a former guerrilla, political prisoner and government official who in the last quarter-century of his life was often called the wisest man in Nicaragua, died on Wednesday in Managua. He was 94.

headline: Frank M. Robinson Dies at 87; Author and Adviser to Harvey Milk
text: Frank M. Robinson, a well-regarded science fiction writer whose credits include a novel adapted for the 1974 blockbuster film “The Towering Inferno,” and who was also a speechwriter and adviser to Harvey Milk, the San Francisco city supervisor assassinated in 1978, died on Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 87.

headline: Obama, at Naturalization Ceremony, Calls for Immigration Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama presided over a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Friday for 25 members of the military and their spouses, the second time he has spent the Fourth of July with new United States citizens.

headline: Both Sides Now
text: The Macy’s Fourth of July fireworks show was over the East River this year; Jersey City set off a display at Liberty State Park.

headline: On a Beautiful Day for Brazilians, an Unexpected Dark Cloud
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Neymar has brought a lot of joy to Brazilians in the last few weeks, but he and they were in a lot of pain Friday night.

headline: Injuries and Uneven Play Take Some Luster Off a Mets Victory
text: The Mets have been vocal in their support of Jon Niese’s bid for an All-Star selection this season, despite his 5-4 record. On Friday, Niese was presented with an opportunity to prove his worth against Yu Darvish, one of the game’s best pitchers and last year’s American League leader in strikeouts.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 5, 2014
text: “You can hear people running their sprinklers when it’s dark because they don’t want to get caught watering when they’re not supposed to be — it’s maddening.”

headline: Corrections: July 5, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: July 5, 2014
text: What to watch for in Saturday’s World Cup quarterfinals:

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE BEST MAN HOLIDAY (2013) In this follow-up to his 1999 debut, “The Best Man,” the writer and director Malcolm D. Lee reassembles his earlier film’s college friends — and reignites old rivalries — during Christmas at the home of the football god Lance (Morris Chestnut, above far left, with, from left, Taye Diggs, Harold Perrineau and Terrence Howard) and his wife, Mia (Monica Calhoun). The author Harper (Mr. Diggs) is now battling writer’s block and financial woes as his pregnant wife (Sanaa Lathan) nears her due date; the educator Julian (Mr. Perrineau) has learned that his wife (Regina Hall) has a past, available for viewing online; the troublemaking Shelby (Melissa De Sousa) is a reality television diva; and the womanizing Quentin (Mr. Howard) is living large amid celebrities. “Mr. Lee’s film is more traditional than its sexually frank humor might indicate, with faith and charity ultimately given pride of place (right alongside human pettiness),” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But even if some of the crudeness and the drama feel forced, it’s hard to hate.”

headline: Pastrami and Partnership, to Go
text: What began in 1982 as a delicatessen in Ann Arbor, Mich., has expanded into a confederation of establishments governed by a management model that other companies line up to study.

headline: When Beliefs and Facts Collide
text: Do Americans understand the scientific consensus about issues like climate change and evolution?

headline: Autopsy Suggests Palestinian Teenager Was Burned to Death After Abduction
text: JERUSALEM — Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, spent his last hours before being abducted, beaten and most likely burned to death in one of his favorite places, doing some of his favorite things.

headline: They Have Seen the Future of the Internet, and It Is Dark
text: Forecasting is tough. The future comes at us fast today, with too many variables to say much with certainty. Predictions are still useful, though: They are an excellent way to examine the passions of the moment.

headline: Driven | 2015 Chrysler 200C
text: An ugly duckling becomes a swan.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, July 6
text: “We’re situated in the finance capital of the world. We just had to know where to look to connect the dots.” Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, after BNP Paribas admitted to doing billions of dollars in deals with Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States and agreed to pay a record $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities. Prosecutors said a charity that owned an office tower on Fifth Avenue was actually a front for the Iranian government.

headline: Donors Give More When They Have a Sense of Belonging
text: With the rise of behavioral economics, my profession is no longer so fixated on the theory that people are relentlessly selfish, striving only to maximize their own pleasure. We know, for example, that work is not just eight daily hours of suffering that people endure to make money for their own benefit. People actually like to work if they see meaning in it, and they can be generous with their money, too.

headline: The Not-So-New Mother, Finding Balance
text: We were all strangers that spring of 1996. Our only connection was that we had all recently given birth at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., and, as recommended by our doctors, had signed up for the New Mother training class. Once a week, we sat in a circle sharing our concerns as a nurse educator led the discussion. It was like those consciousness-raising sessions from the 1960s. But, unlike our mothers who had gathered to secure their place in the world, we gathered to figure out how to be mothers in spite of it.

headline: Shaping a School System, From the Ground Up
text: In the fall of 2011, an eclectic group of people from the San Francisco Bay Area began making regular trips to Lima, Peru. Among them were architects, mechanical engineers, ethnographers, communication designers and education specialists.

headline: Kevin Tracey, on Putting It Together (After Taking It Apart)
text: This interview with  Dr. Kevin J. Tracey, president and C.E.O. of the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research of the North Shore-LIJ Health System, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: When Taxes and Profits Are Oceans Apart
text: Here’s a question for investors in any big United States corporation with foreign operations: Do you know what the company’s tax bill would be if it had to bring its overseas earnings home?

headline: Pro-Russian Fighters Routed From Stronghold, Ukraine Says
text: KIEV, Ukraine — With a fierce onslaught of gunfire and mortar shelling, Ukrainian government forces on Saturday expelled pro-Russian insurgents from Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold, government officials and separatist leaders said.

headline: A Game of Chairs (and Globalization)
text: Oh, if only we had more business writers like Beth Macy, and more business books like her debut, “Factory Man: How One Furniture Maker Battled Offshoring, Stayed Local — and Helped Save an American Town.”

headline: A Four Seasons at Walt Disney World Resort
text: Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts is opening its first Orlando location this August. The 443-room Four Seasons Resort Orlando at Walt Disney World Resort is set on 26 acres in Golden Oak, a Disney-developed residential community rich with palm trees, lakes and protected wetlands and is the biggest resort the luxury brand has opened.

headline: For Bellicose Brazil, Payback Carries Heavy Price: Loss of Neymar
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Colombian defender named Juan Camilo Zúñiga ended the World Cup for the Brazilian star striker Neymar on Friday with a nasty knee into Neymar’s back that fractured one of his vertebrae. It was an ugly play and a bad foul. It deserved, at least, a yellow card.

headline: Petra Kvitova Routs Eugenie Bouchard for Wimbledon Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Eugenie Bouchard arrived at Centre Court with cool confidence and a ruthless tennis game to match. Bouchard, a 20-year-old Canadian, had captured the affection of her country and of the British tabloids, her looks, play and marketability drawing gawking comparisons to Maria Sharapova.

headline: A Mad Scramble for Young Bankers
text: A battle is raging on Wall Street as never before, with powerful factions scrambling for control of a precious resource.

headline: 1964: Anquetil Wins Tour de France for the Fifth Time
text: A French television news report about stage 22 of the Tour de France, won by Jacques Anquetil in 1964. (From the archives of France’s National Audiovisual Institute)

headline: California’s Extreme Drought, Explained
text: The state is experiencing the worst drought in its history. Find out just how bad the situation is getting and what it means for you.

headline: Dealing With Barking Dogs
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Argentina vs. Belgium: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Lionel Messi has lived up to his reputation at this World Cup, at times carrying Argentina despite triple and quadruple coverage. But winning it will require help from Ángel di María, who scored the game-winner in the last round, as well as Gonzalo Higuaín and Ezequiel Lavezzi. Belgium has dispatched Algeria, Russia, South Korea, and the United States. With respect to those teams, its World Cup really begins here.

headline: Egypt Sharply Raises Prices for Fuel, Drawing Protests
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian government sharply raised fuel prices early on Saturday, apparently signaling the resolve of the country’s new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, to forge ahead with a series of austerity measures despite official concerns about a public backlash.

headline: Swedish Sadomonetarist Setback
text: OK, this is fairly amazing. I’ve written often about sadomonetarism among central bankers — the evident urge to find some reason, any reason, to raise interest rates despite high unemployment and low inflation. The most influential hive of this kind of thinking is the Bank for International Settlements, which for some reason commands great respect even though it offers an ever-changing rationale — inflation! Any day now! Or maybe not! Financial stability! — for its never-changing advocacy of tight money. But the place where policy makers most dramatically gave in to this urge is Sweden, where the majority at the Riksbank decided to indulge its rate-hike vice while freezing out one of the world’s leading experts on deflation risks, my friend and former colleague Lars Svensson.

headline: Vacation Snapshots With a Professional Touch
text: Many hotels are offering guests the chance to improve their “point and shoot” game through classes with professional photographers.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — This holiday weekend just keeps getting better and better: a Friday Patrick Berry puzzle, a Saturday David Steinberg puzzle and now a cryptic crossword by Richard Silvestri. That doesn’t even take into account the barbecue and fireworks.

headline: Philadelphia Rowhouse Fire Kills 4 Children
text: PHILADELPHIA — Neighbors gathered outside several fire-ravaged rowhouses here on Saturday, crying and hugging as they mourned the deaths of four children in an early morning fire that ripped through the block.

headline: Georgian Opposition Leader Ordered Jailed Until Trial
text: TBILISI, Georgia — One of Georgia’s most prominent opposition leaders was denied bail and ordered jailed on Friday until his trial on charges of threatening a regional election official, setting off a political firestorm just days before a decisive second round of local elections.

headline: At Zingerman’s, Pastrami and Partnership to Go
text: It was a typical Wednesday morning at Zingerman’s Roadhouse, a restaurant in Ann Arbor, Mich., that offers nine varieties of macaroni and cheese and smokes its own hogs for pulled pork. But on this particular morning, in a colorful back dining room, finance was on the menu.

headline: Free Video Games Say Pay Up or Wait, Testing Players’ Patience
text: In the world of gaming, as in life, you get what you pay for.

headline: At Moment to Shine, Twins Are Light on Stars
text: Sometimes a city hosts an All-Star Game, and the event lines up perfectly with the local team’s fortunes. The Montreal Expos, coming off their only postseason appearance, had four starters in 1982. Pedro Martinez, at the height of his pitching powers for the Boston Red Sox, started for the American League at Fenway Park in 1999. Ichiro Suzuki, in the middle of a spellbinding rookie season for Seattle, led off for the American League at Safeco Field in 2001.

headline: If He Walks and Talks Like a Monk, but Has His Hand Out ...
text: In Times Square, amid the dozens of Elmos, Mickey Mouses and superheroes who work the crowds for loose bills, new costumed characters have come to seek their fortunes.

headline: Two Generations of Tennis Stars Collide in Wimbledon Men’s Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The best of two generations of men’s tennis will collide Sunday when Roger Federer plays Novak Djokovic for the Wimbledon title with Stefan Edberg and Boris Becker looking on as coaches of the finalists.

headline: Fearing Lawsuits, Sheriffs Balk at U.S. Request to Hold Noncitizens for Extra Time
text: LOS ANGELES — Sheriffs around the nation are openly rejecting the Obama administration policy of holding noncitizens who are accused or convicted of crimes for extra time, which for years has enabled the federal government to begin deportation proceedings for thousands of immigrants. The local decisions are limiting the Obama administration’s ability to enforce immigration laws and could significantly decrease the number of immigrants deported each year.

headline: Waiting … and Waiting …
text: A look at the average time to get five kinds of appointments for new patients in 2013, from a survey of 15 metropolitan areas.

headline: Bespoke Bats Are Must-Have Accessories for Picky Hitters
text: NORWALK, Conn. — In his airy new workshop, in a business park less than a mile from the Long Island Sound, Pete Tucci has batting cages, renovated offices, a showroom and a humidor large enough to store more than 13,000 billets of wood.

headline: Museum’s Vast Trove Is Distinctly Offline
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It is fitting that the quietest place at Wimbledon is the library.

headline: Children at Gunplay
text: An estimated one-third of American children live in homes with firearms, according to public health research, and 43 percent of these homes have at least one unlocked firearm lying about as an invitation to accidental mayhem.

headline: A Rotten Mango Crisis
text: AS an apprentice anthropologist, I once had the misfortune of attempting to converse with the Indian critical theorist Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak. Professor Spivak, who translated the work of the French philosopher Jacques Derrida and wrote the famous essay “Can the Subaltern Speak?”, was visiting Dhaka, Bangladesh, and I went to meet her. After patiently listening while I asked a series of dumb questions about discursive practice, she turned and said, cryptically, “I came for the mangoes.”

headline: Rethinking the Wild
text: YOU won’t hear it on your summer hike above the bird song and the soft applause of aspen leaves, but there’s a heresy echoing through America’s woods and wild places. It’s a debate about how we should think about, and treat, our wilderness in the 21st century, one with real implications for the nearly 110 million acres of wild lands that we’ve set aside across the United States.

headline: The Next Act of the Neocons
text: WASHINGTON — AFTER nearly a decade in the political wilderness, the neoconservative movement is back, using the turmoil in Iraq and Ukraine to claim that it is President Obama, not the movement’s interventionist foreign policy that dominated early George W. Bush-era Washington, that bears responsibility for the current round of global crises.

headline: Dan Auerbach
text: Dan Auerbach is half of the raw blues-rock duo the Black Keys, which is on a world tour following the release in May of their eighth album, “Turn Blue.”

headline: The Health Care Waiting Game
text: ONE small consolation of our high-priced health care system — our $2.7 trillion collective medical bill — has been the notion that at least we get medical attention quickly.

headline: Anxiety in Teenagers
text: Readers discuss physiological and cultural factors that may explain adolescent angst.

headline: India’s Role in the Nuclear Race
text: India is seeking membership in the Nuclear Suppliers Group, a 48-nation body established 40 years ago to ensure that civilian trade in nuclear materials is not diverted for military purposes, as was done by India itself. Membership would greatly enhance the acceptance of India as a nuclear weapons state and give it a say in how countries trade in nuclear-related exports.

headline: Less Sexy, Better for Sex
text: IN inventing a self-driving car, Google has in one fell swoop struck a blow at masculinity, female empowerment, romance, sex and action heroes. It may even violate two of our three inalienable rights — liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

headline: Fine Perfumes of the Animal World
text: One of the odder things about perfumes is how much they have depended over the centuries on the scent of other animals — for instance, ambergris, a fatty excretion of the sperm whale, or the musk from the anal sacs of a civet. In concentration, some of these scents are unpleasant, even noxious. One component of civet is skatole, literally the smell of animal feces. Why not just make up a cologne called “Hyraceum — the Ultimate Code of Seduction,” advertised in a suitably libidinous whisper? The fine print would reveal that Hyraceum comes from the petrified excrement of the Cape hyrax. (Oh, but it turns out Hyraceum actually exists, at a very reasonable $60 an ounce.)

headline: Is Joe Riley of Charleston the Most Loved Politician in America?
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — THE custom here is for a mayor’s portrait to be hung in the City Council chamber only after he leaves office. But in 2007, folks got tired of waiting for Joe Riley to make his exit, and he was put on the wall while still on the job. He’d been running Charleston for more than 31 years.

headline: A Company Liberals Could Love
text: FOR a generation now, liberals have bemoaned the disappearance of the socially conscious corporation, the boardroom devoted to the common good. Once, the story goes, America’s C.E.O.s recognized that they shared interests with workers and customers; once wages and working hours reflected more than just a zeal for profits. But then came Reagan, deregulation, hostile takeovers, and an era of solidarity gave way to the age of Gordon Gekko, from which there’s been no subsequent escape.

headline: Do I Have the Right to Be?
text: It’s a disturbing thought: All of us are alive today thanks at least partly to some mass atrocity that was committed in the past. This is because war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and ethnic cleansing invariably affect who is born after them. Who knows how many of us can claim, “Even if the Holocaust had not occurred, I would still have been born”? And if you can, perhaps because you were conceived before 1933 or shortly afterward without having been influenced in some way by the effects of Hitlerism, what about the Crusades or slavery in America? Anyone who reflects on the unjust death of others will be surprised at how much his or her own right to be is put in question, to the point where his or her place on this earth can appear as a usurpation. This might not be obvious at first so let’s slow down a bit.

headline: When They Imprison the Wrong Guy
text: ON the day after his 32nd birthday, Michael Morton returned from work to find his home in Austin, Tex., surrounded by yellow police tape.

headline: The Real Internal Revenue Scandal
text: There is a scandal going on at the Internal Revenue Service, but it has nothing to do with Lois Lerner or her missing emails. House Republicans have not given up on their noisy crusade to tie Ms. Lerner to what they imagine to be widespread political corruption within the Obama administration, but all they have proved is that the I.R.S. is no better at backing up its computer files than most other government agencies.

headline: At Home Abroad, Argentina Shuts Down Belgium
text: BRASÍLIA — As unlikely as it may seem given the résumés of the two nations involved, including the seven combined world championships, Argentina and Brazil had never reached the semifinals in the same World Cup until this year.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 6
text: On this Independence Day weekend, the Sunday talk shows will be focused on illegal immigration as American officials grapple with a surge of undocumented immigrants, especially women and children, crossing the United States border with Mexico. Last week, President Obama said he would use executive actions to make changes to the immigration system without Congress, blaming Republicans for failure to pass legislation to overhaul the system.

headline: How Prophets Get Lonely
text: At Bloomberg View, Leonid Bershinksy weeps over the cruel world that for some reason isn’t listening to Jaime Caruana of the BIS, who warns that we must raise interest rates now now now. Why is this prophet so lonely?

headline: From East to West, Cultivating Change on the Grass Courts
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Change can be upon us at the All-England Lawn Tennis Club as quickly as the rain clouds and five-year-old roof can roll over old Centre Court, which pretty much means before we know it.

headline: Costa Rica vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: On paper, this is the biggest mismatch of the quarterfinals, with the Netherlands a comfortable favorite to stop Costa Rica’s Cinderella run. Robin van Persie’s finishing, Arjen Robben’s flicks and tricks and Wesley Sneijder’s leadership are expected to overwhelm a Costa Rica team that has punched above its weight.

headline: Amid Modi’s Centrist Shift, an Aide With a Turbulent Past Rises
text: MUZAFFARNAGAR, India — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s new junior minister for agriculture, Sanjeev Balyan, is a first-time officeholder famous for precisely one thing: After two Hindu men were killed in an altercation with Muslims in his district last summer, he rallied crowds of angry young men from his caste, urging them to protect their own kind.

headline: After Barrage of Personal Attacks, Indonesian Presidential Election Tightens
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The allegations have been flying thick and fast as Indonesia’s presidential election campaign nears its end.

headline: Looking for Breakout Star, M.L.S. Pins Hopes on a World Cup Standout
text: Shortly after he signed a professional contract with the Seattle Sounders in 2013, DeAndre Yedlin had tattoos put on his calves that joined to read, “Always Remember the Beginning.”

headline: A Legend’s Dress, My Mother’s Memories
text: When a parent’s health deteriorates and you have to move her quickly across state borders, the to-do list swells like an air mattress.

headline: The Amazon’s Floating Fields
text: CATALÃO, Brazil — In this floating village, there is only one way to travel. Students go to school by boat. Pentecostals go to church by boat. Taxis arrive by boat. Even the soccer field is often a boat.

headline: A Century-Old Landmark of the Everglades Confronts the Possible End of the Road
text: CHOKOLOSKEE ISLAND, Fla. — The Seminole medicine man climbed the steep wooden stairs to the Ted Smallwood Store and shuffled past the counter used to measure raccoon hides, past the Jeris Hair Tonic bottles, the Sloan’s Liniment for aches and Dr. Gunn’s mid-19th-century “Home Book of Health.”

headline: When “Justice” Isn’t Just
text: My Sunday column looks at the flaws in our criminal justice system through the remarkable story of Michael Morton, author of a new memoir. Morton was a middle class guy in Austin with no criminal record, and he came home from work one day to find his wife murdered–and himself a key suspect. He spent the next 25 years in prison for murdering her, partly because the authorities suppressed exculpatory evidence. It’s as harrowing a story as you can imagine, and it’s a good starting point for a discussion about what to do to improve the justice system. Three elements of an improvement would be, I think: 1.) an end to the disastrous mass incarceration experiment that began in the 1970’s; 2.) an improved network of mental health services, so that prisons and jails are no longer our default mental health system; 3.) improved treatment programs for addicts, so that a failed war on drugs no longer fills up prisons and jails. That’s all a bit glib, I realize, and there’s no silver bullet solution the problems of drugs, but it’s impossible to read Morton’s memoir without feeling that the present system is an appalling and expensive mess.

headline: Shadow of Brutal ’79 War Darkens Vietnam’s View of China Relations
text: LANG SON, Vietnam — She was 14 when Chinese artillery fire echoed across the hills around her home in northern Vietnam, and hundreds of thousands of Chinese soldiers swarmed across the border. She remembers sprinting with her parents through the peach trees, her waist-length hair flying, as they fled the invaders. They ran straight into the enemy.

headline: Militant Leader in Rare Appearance in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Wearing a black turban and black robes, the leader of the self-proclaimed Islamic state that stretches across eastern Syria and much of northern and western Iraq made a startling public appearance, his first in many years, at a well-known mosque in the Iraqi city of Mosul, according to a video released on Saturday whose contents were confirmed by experts and witnesses.

headline: Q. and A.: Lyle Goldstein on China and the Vietnamese Military
text: As friction increases between China and Vietnam over the South China Sea, an important question is how Vietnam’s military, famed decades ago for its resilience and guerrilla warfare, measures up. For the last two months, Chinese and Vietnamese Coast Guard vessels have been jostling each other around a billion-dollar Chinese oil rig that Vietnam says was unilaterally placed in its waters by Beijing. (Beijing says the waters are Chinese.) Warships from both countries lurk in the distance, and from time to time, the Chinese send air force fighters into the rig’s vicinity to show they mean business.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: One Whistle, One Point
text: The Red Bulls have played 17 games this season in Major League Soccer and eight, nearly half, have ended in ties. Some were deserved, some fortunate, some disappointing, some enraging.

headline: Oakland’s Future Can Wait as Beane Makes Big Bet on the Present
text: Billy Beane is all in.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Life in the City
text: During this holiday weekend, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past.

headline: Coming to U.S. for Baby, and Womb to Carry It
text: At home in Lisbon, a gay couple invited friends over to a birthday celebration, and at the end of the evening shared a surprise — an ultrasound image of their baby, moving around in the belly of a woman in Pennsylvania being paid to carry their child.

headline: Younger Americans Show Promise
text: WIMBLEDON, England — “It’s not pretty at the moment, but the cavalry is coming,” Patrick McEnroe said last month of the state of American men’s tennis.

headline: Aggressive Tactics Help Kvitova Make Quick Work of Bouchard
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Petra Kvitova won the points before they really got started, allowing her to collect her second Wimbledon title.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Life Itself’
text: Geoffrey O’Brien reviews “Life Itself.”

headline: Flying the Old-Fashioned Way
text: Gail Bennett has played Mary Poppins before, but for her reprisal of the role at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts, she had to learn completely new dance routines.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Earth to Echo’
text: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews “Earth to Echo.”

headline: Oh, Say…
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s a really good thing that I am not a professional musician, because my first thoughts when I looked at the words formed by the circled letters in Daniel C. Bryant’s puzzle was, “Those aren’t the first notes of the national anthem.”

headline: Beating of Palestinian-American Boy Caught on Video
text: As my colleague Jodi Rudoren reports, a video posted online appears to show Israeli police officers beating a Palestinian-American boy after his detention on Thursday during protests in East Jerusalem that followed the death of his cousin, a teenager who was kidnapped and killed two days earlier.

headline: Young Hand, Just Out of High School, Guides a City
text: ARCHER CITY — Kelvin Cletus Green sat flanked by City Council members. He was 18 years old but looked much younger, and as Kim Whitsitt — the city secretary who is also Mr. Green’s godmother — whispered to him about the next agenda item, a stranger could be forgiven for assuming he was a student shadowing city officials for his civics class.

headline: State Starts to Have Company in Stand on Academic Standards
text: When Texas refused to sign onto a nationwide effort five years ago to develop common academic standards in reading and math — putting $700 million in federal money at risk — the state found itself in lonely territory.

headline: Phelps Has Strong Outing for Yanks, but Late Error by Cervelli Wastes It
text: MINNEAPOLIS — David Phelps gave the Yankees a quality start on Saturday. He shut out the Minnesota Twins for six innings, allowed a leadoff homer to Josh Willingham in the seventh and left at the end of the inning, providing a badly needed rest for a taxed Yankees bullpen.

headline: Revenue Aside, Legislators See a Need to Cut
text: In one corner, the government’s number nerds are telling us that the state treasury will be taking in more money than anyone could have imagined: Thank you, oil and gas industry.

headline: Texas Isn’t Keeping Up With National Drop in Teenage Births
text: DALLAS — Charmaine Carbs thought that she would be the only senior at her high school to walk across the stage pregnant at graduation. She was wrong.

headline: By Talking, Inmates and Victims Make Things ‘More Right’
text: NORFOLK, Mass. — For many of his 15 years behind the soaring prison walls here, Muhammad Sahin managed to suppress thinking of his victims’ anguish — even that of the one who haunted him most, a toddler who peeked out from beneath her blankets the night he shot and killed her mother in a gang-ordered hit.

headline: An Elite Club May Add Its Second Woman
text: Hou Yifan of China is on the cusp of becoming just the second woman to crack the list of the world’s top 100 players.

headline: Power Struggles in Middle East Exploit Islam’s Ancient Sectarian Rift
text: RIFFA, Bahrain — Black and yellow concrete barricades block the roads entering this wealthy Sunni enclave, where foreign-born Sunni soldiers in armored personnel carriers guard the mansions of the ruling family and the business elite.

headline: Students Joining Battle to Upend Laws on Voter ID
text: WASHINGTON — Civil rights groups have spent a decade fighting requirements that voters show photo identification, arguing that this discriminates against African-Americans, Hispanics and the poor. This week in a North Carolina courtroom, another group will make its case that such laws are discriminatory: college students.

headline: Missing 2-Year-Old Girl Is Found Dead in Prospect Park Lake
text: A 2-year-old girl who wandered away from her family on Saturday at Prospect Park in Brooklyn was found dead after an hourslong search, the police said.

headline: Abandoning Control on Coney Island
text: Like a cooling salve, the Atlantic waves lapping onto the Coney Island shore had a calming effect on Leslie Jean-Bart. About eight years ago he had gone there seeking peace, his photographic career on hold as he dealt with his mother’s dementia.

headline: An Upbeat Wright Returns After an Encouraging Stint by a Rookie Replacement
text: Nine days after aggravating an injury to his left rotator cuff, David Wright stepped into the batter’s box at Citi Field before Saturday’s game against the Texas Rangers.

headline: A Late Entry Helps the Dutch Avert an Exit
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — With a World Cup quarterfinal in the closing moments of extra time on Saturday, Louis van Gaal, the coach of the Netherlands, made a move that was as bold as it was rare.

headline: New York Racing on Display at Belmont Park
text: New York, which has not hosted the Breeders’ Cup World Championships since 2005, took a small step back onto thoroughbred racing’s international stage when Belmont Park held its inaugural Stars and Stripes Day on Saturday.

headline: Injury and a Loss Eclipse Wright’s Return to the Mets
text: Early Saturday, it appeared that luck was turning in the Mets’ favor. The Mets were coming off a victory the night before, and David Wright was set to return to the lineup after missing the last seven games with a bruised rotator cuff. It also appeared as if the Mets would soon have an excess of healthy starting pitchers.
