text: Thea Amanda Cohen and David Scott Yellin were married Saturday at Sequoia, a restaurant in Washington. Judge Thomas F. Hogan of the Federal District Court in Washington officiated, with Judge Paul W. Grimm of the Federal District Court in Greenbelt, Md., taking part.

headline: Elissa Miller-Kay and Warangkana Chomchuen
text: Elissa Pauline Miller-Kay and Warangkana Chomchuen are to be married Sunday at Caffino Ristorante, an Italian restaurant in Toronto. Nathan Cheifetz, a licensed wedding officiant in the province of Ontario, will perform the ceremony.

headline: Love at First Laugh
text: Kasey Marie Wickman and Christopher James Rosen were married Saturday evening at First Presbyterian Church in Portland, Ore. The Rev. Amber Nettleton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Indu Chugani and Sushil Singh
text: Indu Nanik Chugani and Sushil Kumar Singh were married Saturday at Sakonnet Vineyards in Little Compton, R.I. Amrutur V. Srinivasan, a Hindu priest who became a Universal Life minister so he could officiate in Rhode Island, performed the ceremony.

headline: Liza Kaplan, Evan Glucoft
text: Liza Olivia Kaplan and Evan Popik Glucoft were married Saturday evening at Calistoga Ranch, a resort in Calistoga, Calif. Rabbi Stephanie E. Kramer officiated.

headline: Imbibing the Joys of a Lusty Poet
text: Before Allen Ginsberg and the Beats descended on San Francisco, there was James Broughton (1913-99), a poet, experimental filmmaker, pansexual free spirit and proto-hippie who, like Ginsberg, was a spiritual descendant of Walt Whitman. His exuberant life and times are recalled in “Big Joy: The Adventures of James Broughton,” now available on DVD and on demand. Directed by Stephen Silha, Eric Slade and Dawn Logsdon, the documentary captures the euphoric mood of bohemian San Francisco just after World War II and includes many excerpts from his exhortatory poetry. For much of his life, he followed the dictum of his motto, “Follow your weird.”

headline: A Week When Parks Go Pan-American
text: We’re not all polyglots yet, but the Latin Alternative Music Conference keeps on pushing. This is the 15th year of a gathering for music that envisions an ever more multicultural United States listening to pan-American kinds of rock, hip-hop and pop. Conference participants strategize by day while, the music they’re so passionate about is presented around the city.

headline: Down Memory Lane via Tonya and O. J.
text: Every decade apparently must have its day. Back in 2000, NBC had the two-part movie “The ’70s.” CNN is in the midst of a 10-part documentary called “The Sixties.” And on Sunday, the National Geographic Channel begins three nights of a wide-ranging documentary titled “The ’90s: The Last Great Decade?”

headline: In an Exodus Tale, Myriad Subplots
text: At the beginning of Reggie Wilson’s “Moses(es),” the dancers and singers introduce themselves and say how long each has belonged to his Fist and Heel Performance Group. For some, it’s one year, for others, more than 20, but it looks as if they’ve been performing together forever. They make a formidable tribe, equal parts exuberance and introspection, youth and experience.

headline: Corrections: July 6, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Firefighter Dies After Blaze at Brooklyn High-Rise
text: A New York City firefighter died late Saturday after a blaze in a Brooklyn high-rise, authorities said.

headline: 1914: America Sends a Million Dollars of Gold to Mexico
text: EL PASO, Tex. — More than a million dollars of gold from big business sources in the eastern States alone have been poured into the Mexican rebel coffers during the last nine months. This is admitted by Constitutionalists of prominence. It is added that since the split between Generals Carranza and Villa much money has been withheld, and the rebel cause now faces serious embarrassment. The bitterness engendered by the clash of the two leaders has loosened tongues, and the facts are now known for the first time. The money has come here in single drafts for $50,000 at a time on two local banks transferring the funds. It is impossible to get documental proof, but it is believed that most of it has gone to the honest needs of warfare. So acute has become the need of more money that Senor Alberto Madero has hurried to New York to impress the capitalists alleged to be financing the revolution with the necessity of funds. General Villa is trying to raise money by concessions for the sale of dynamite and the exportation of cattle. The Pearson and Guggenheim lumbering and mining interests have been allowed to reopen. Unusual protection is being afforded the latter. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 7, 1914

headline: With Revenue Roaring, Twitter’s Advertising Team Is Untouched by Turmoil
text: Twitter‘s top executive ranks have been transformed in the last year, from its general counsel to, most recently, its chief financial officer.

headline: 6 Israelis Held Over the Killing of Palestinian
text: JERUSALEM — Confronting the possibility of rising retaliatory violence between Jews and Palestinians, the Israeli authorities arrested six Israelis on Sunday in the killing of a Palestinian teenager, found beaten and burned in a Jerusalem forest last week.

headline: Malaysia Is Sending More Ships to Search for Jetliner
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Malaysian government said Sunday that it would step up efforts to search the southern Indian Ocean for Malaysia Airlines’ missing Flight 370, in the latest indication that a broad international effort to find the plane will continue for many months.

headline: Decisions, Management and the Best Day for an Interview
text: PARIS — According to Sidney Toledano, the 63-year-old, long-serving chief executive of Christian Dior Couture, the most important management trait cannot be learned at business school.

headline: Slump Stories and the Inflation Test
text: Noah Smith has another post on John Cochrane’s anti-Keynesian screed, in which he takes on various “structural” stories about the continuing weakness of the economy. As usual, Noah is very mild and eager to give the benefit of the doubt, although even so there’s not much there.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of the Something-Free Diet
text: Whether it’s fat, sugar, gluten or something new, the idea of cutting one item out of our diets seems to maintain its hold on our culture — even if what we’re supposed to cut changes with time. What is it about getting rid of something that makes it so popular, almost independent of what that something is?

headline: Known for Rescues, a Firefighter Dies in a Brooklyn Blaze
text: After the call came in — a fire licking the curtains in a 19th-floor bedroom window, smoke pouring into the night — the fire ladder truck from nearby Hooper Street was the first to arrive on Saturday at the Brooklyn high-rise. Out jumped Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, a 14-year veteran, leading a team of four firefighters into 75 Wilson Street in Williamsburg. It seemed a routine fire, nothing out of the ordinary. Yet minutes after Lieutenant Ambelas, 40, headed into apartment 19B with two other firefighters to look for people who might be trapped, he was carried out unconscious, badly burned and on the verge of death.

headline: Brazil Lobbies for Punishment of the Colombian Player Who Injured Neymar
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s soccer federation is pressing FIFA to punish the Colombian player whose tackle caused the injury that has sidelined Brazil’s top player, Neymar, for the rest of the World Cup.

headline: Crowding the Frame
text: W.M. Hunt has collected hundreds of photos featuring crowds forming everything form panoramas to living mosaics.

headline: With a ‘Charitable Veneer,’ Littering the Streets With Collection Bins
text: Kyiesha Kelly was up late washing dishes one night in December when she heard the rumble of a truck outside. Peering out the kitchen window in her apartment, she spotted several men dragging a huge used-clothing collection bin from a truck across the street to the sidewalk in front of the community garden that she helps run in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: London Auctions Cap a Go-Go Season
text: LONDON — The momentum seems unstoppable. Last week in London, Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips raised an aggregate 200 million pounds, or about $340 million, from their evening sales of postwar and contemporary art, a 26 percent increase on the equivalent series of sales last summer.

headline: Editorial Cartoon
text: The North Korean leader blows his top over the Beijing-Seoul summit.

headline: The Debt to One’s Homeland
text: “I was not a rat who jumped ship at the first sign of trouble,” Leonid Bershidsky, a well-known journalist and media entrepreneur, wrote in mid-June, announcing his intention to leave Russia. “I am more a sailor who, seeing that the captain had changed course toward a port of ill repute — and with loudspeakers blaring his intent — quietly, and without panicking, lowered the lifeboat and began rowing toward the port for which all of us had originally set sail.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 5, 2014
text: July 5, 2014

headline: Djokovic Back on Top After a Chaotic Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic clutched the most coveted award in his sport, the gilded silver, two-handled trophy presented to the winner of the Wimbledon men’s singles title.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) MILEY CYRUS: BANGERZ TOUR This two-hour concert special, filmed last month, captures the antics of Ms. Cyrus, above, onstage and off as she sings and twerks her way through hits including “We Can’t Stop” and “Wrecking Ball” in Barcelona and Lisbon.

headline: Marching Ahead With Nostalgia
text: A little compare-and-contrast chart, inspired by the assonant names of the conservative writer Dinesh D’Souza and the classic march composer John Philip Sousa, appeared over the weekend in The New York Times Magazine. It emphasized their differences. (In the “despises” category: Mr. D’Souza, “lefties”; Sousa, “recorded music.”)

headline: London Theater Journal: Two Wars, With Song and Sentiment
text: LONDON — If war is indeed hell – and I hear no one contradicting that assertion – then I spent the better part of a day here in the netherworld. The afternoon found me in Vietnam in the mid-1970s, courtesy of a gauzy new revival of the Alain Boublil and Claude-Michael Schonberg musical “Miss Saigon.” That night I joined a ragged regiment of Irish soldiers during the First World War, via the National Theater’s startling production of Sean O’Casey’s seldom-seen “The Silver Tassie.”

headline: Gruesome Attacks in Kenyan Villages Heighten Fears of a Nation on Edge
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — More than 20 people were killed in two attacks on Kenya’s coast on Saturday night — with residents saying that many of the victims had their hands bound and their throats slit — in the latest in a string of gruesome assaults with ethnic undercurrents.

headline: Hamilton Wins British Grand Prix
text: SILVERSTONE, England — After a massive accident on the first lap delayed the 50th British Grand Prix at the Silverstone for an hour, British fans were rewarded with an exciting race that ended with a victory for the home favorite, Lewis Hamilton.

headline: 1964: Fans Scream for Beatles at Movie Premiere
text: LONDON — Twelve thousand screaming teen-agers packed Piccadilly Circus tonight [July 6] for a look at the Beatles as they attended the world première of their first film, ‘‘A Hard Day’s Night.’’ Also present for the charity première were Princess Margaret and her husband, Lord Snowdon, but they received a much smaller ovation from the crowd. The Beatles — Paul McCartney, George Harrison, John Lennon and Ringo Starr — were presented to the royal couple in the lobby of the theater. ‘‘What do you think of the film?’’ asked the princess. ‘‘I don’t think we are very good, ma’am,’’ Mr. McCartney said with a smile. ‘‘But the director is very good.’’ As soon as the royal party left, usherettes in dresses printed with the Beatles’ faces rushed up to the quartet and asked them to sign their dresses. Ambulance men carried off about 20 fainting girls including one who screamed from her stretcher: ‘‘Let me up! I want to see them!’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 7, 1964.

headline: Do You Live in Detroit’s North End Neighborhood?
text: Times reporters covering Detroit’s path to recovery are looking to talk to residents of the North End neighborhood about their experiences and what they would like to see improved as the city moves forward.

headline: Netanyahu on Death of Palestinian Youth
text: On Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke out on the killing of the youth and said of the crime, “We do not differentiate between terrorists, and we will respond to all of them.”

headline: Ties Strained, Germans Press U.S. to Answer Spy Allegation
text: BERLIN — With mystery enveloping a German intelligence service employee accused of spying — reportedly for the United States — German officials and commentators on Sunday angrily demanded a response from Washington, warning that an already troubled relationship was at risk of deteriorating to a new low.

headline: Yankees Make Pitching and Hitting Moves Before Dispatching Twins
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Vidal Nuno arrived at Target Field early Sunday morning. Told by Yankees Manager Joe Girardi that he had been traded to Arizona for the veteran starting pitcher Brandon McCarthy and cash considerations, Nuno spent the next 15 minutes going through the clubhouse, shaking hands and saying goodbyes. He seemed upbeat rather than upset.

headline: Afghan Election Dispute Forcing Western Officials to Take a Stand
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A growing number of Western officials are calling for an audit of the ballots cast in the Afghan presidential election, increasing the likelihood that the nation’s electoral commission will have to formally reassess the June 14 runoff vote even as it prepares to announce preliminary results.

headline: Independent Music Labels and Young Artists Offer Streaming, on Their Terms
text: The rise of streaming music services like Pandora, Spotify and Beats Music has been a boon for listeners, serving up songs for a modest monthly fee or, with ads, free. But their effect on artists, especially those with smaller audiences, has been less positive.

headline: Atelier Versace: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 7
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Just Because You’re Paranoid Doesn’t Mean They’re Not Trying to Get You
text: OK, that’s interesting: I got an email from Instagram to confirm that a new account was indeed mine.

headline: Few Fireworks for ‘Tammy’ and Weekend Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — It opened against very light competition, and over the Fourth of July holiday weekend no less. Warner Bros. pumped it with marketing support. Its star, Melissa McCarthy, aggressively trotted the publicity circuit.

headline: The Limits of Practice
text: I started playing the French horn in sixth grade. I was a rule follower, and so I practiced regularly, in addition to performing at concerts and parades and all the other glamorous events to which a teenage French horn player is routinely invited. And yet, six years later, I was only marginally less terrible than when I began.

headline: Detroit: Ruin and Renewal
text: A complete guide to the bankruptcy of Detroit and the city’s journey of rebuilding.

headline: Rethinking a Spurned Landmark
text: As an architect, Gene Kaufman doesn’t typically save buildings; he designs them.

headline: European Team Champions Are Crowned
text: At the European Team Championships in Opatija, Croatia, which ended last week, the teams were competing not only for medals but also to qualify for next year’s world championships in Chennai, India.

headline: Mets Send Niese to D.L. Before Win
text: About a week ago, Mets Manager Terry Collins approached Jon Niese, inquiring about his health. Collins had noticed that Niese had been dropping his elbow during his delivery, a sign that his shoulder was weak. Niese had done the same thing last year, when he was found to have a partially torn rotator cuff. Now his velocity was gradually dropping, too.

headline: From Ballet Theater, Some Goodbyes and a Promise for the Future
text: The dancer Joseph Gorak still has what Jacques in “As You Like It” calls the “shining morning face” of the schoolboy, even though on Aug. 1 he will become a soloist for American Ballet Theater. And his face shone on Saturday afternoon, when he made his debut as Franz, the engaging double-timing scamp at the center of the three-act ballet “Coppélia.” His account promised much for the future: just what was needed amid three performances of “Coppélia” otherwise chiefly notable for farewells.

headline: Sleuthing Her Way to the Top, Cloaked in Many Disguises
text: Pluck, politics and occasional musical interludes collide in “Bobby Jasoos,” a jaunty, likable star vehicle for the Bollywood actress Vidya Balan. Ms. Balan plays the title character, an aspiring detective in Hyderabad who works to build a career from her formidable sleuthing abilities, her traditionalist family notwithstanding.

headline: Marriage With Eyes Wide Shut
text: Amy Sohn’s roman à clef about Tom Cruise’s love life and his marriage to Katie Holmes is being billed as “a big, juicy literary novel” by its publisher, Simon & Schuster. But it’s unclear what “literary” is supposed to mean. Slow? Artistic? Rife with allusions to Henry James? A blurb on the book’s back cover wishfully claims the book is “like Henry James crossbred with the very best of US Weekly.”

headline: Text Games in a New Era of Stories
text: Interactive fiction, which once went by the name “text adventure,” is having a moment.

headline: Thinking on Their Feet
text: For three weeks each summer, Lincoln Center’s Midsummer Night Swing draws thousands of dancers to its outdoor dance floor at Damrosch Park. Now in its 26th season, the series attracts dancers of all stripes: young, old, amateur, professional. They tend to have one thing in common: a fussiness, or a passion, when it comes to shoes. Sometimes footwear choice is a matter of tradition. (Think of cowboy boots for Cajun or lightweight sneakers for acrobatic swing dancing.) In many cases, it’s a matter of comfort, personal style or the material of the dance floor.

headline: A Battered Spirit Seeking Clues Amid a Multimedia Landscape
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — One of the most anticipated premieres at this year’s Aix-en-Provence Festival was “Winterreise,” a multimedia collaboration between the South African artist William Kentridge and the German baritone Matthias Goerne, which opened to stormy applause at the Darius Milhaud Conservatory here on Friday.

headline: The X-Man Next Door, Claws and All
text: As the video begins, a cheerful young man in a rumpled shirt and tie lays down the challenge: “Can I make some fully automatic adamantium claws?”

headline: A Garage Revival, With Two Seasoned D.J.s at the Wheel
text: There’s a funny clip, available on YouTube, of Todd Edwards and DJ EZ in conversation at a British festival last year. Mr. Edwards is a giant of house and garage music, a pioneer from the 1990s in using complex vocal sampling. DJ EZ has been one of the great popularizers of U.K. garage music in its various forms since the late 1990s. They are each, in their own ways, fathers of the recent garage revival that has gripped British dance music, most notably in the form of the duo Disclosure.

headline: Abandoning His Own Skepticism
text: Fans of the PBS documentary series “POV” are used to advocacy and alternative perspectives, but Niko von Glasow’s “My Way to Olympia,” a film on Monday about Paralympic athletes, might be baffling even to experienced “POV” watchers. That is partly because it has its flaws, but also partly because we’re so used to seeing stories about people with disabilities presented in a certain way that Mr. von Glasow’s aggressive flouting of those conventions is a challenge for any viewer.

headline: Lure for Bargain Hunters
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — My, don’t we look stylish today? Lynn Lempel is back and she’s treating us to some fancy hair coiffing.

headline: U.S. Budget News, and Fed Minutes Due
text: U.S. JUNE BUDGET EXPECTED TO RECORD A SURPLUS

headline: Director to Correct Films on Guatemala
text: The director of two documentaries about human rights abuses in Guatemala said that she planned to correct inaccuracies in those films, including blaming the country’s military for a village massacre, The Associated Press reported. The director, Pamela Yates, said in a statement that the decision resulted from investigations into the circumstances surrounding the killing of 17 villagers recounted in her 1984 film, “When the Mountains Tremble.” The scene took place in Batzul, where a local woman told the filmmakers that the men responsible for the murders wore military uniforms. Later reports and a recent visit by Ms. Yates revealed that the men had been members of guerrilla forces dressed as army soldiers. Ms. Yates said that she intended “to make a correction that will clarify what happened in this scene” in both that film and her 2011 documentary, “Granito: How to Nail a Dictator.” “When the Mountains Tremble” won multiple honors upon its release, including the Special Jury Award at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: No More Anthony on ‘Opie & Anthony’
text: The radio shock jock Anthony Cumia has scratched off another of his nine lives: He was fired last week from SiriusXM’s “Opie & Anthony” radio show. The decision came after Mr. Cumia, below, posted what the company described in a news release as “racially charged and hate-filled remarks” on his personal Twitter account over a run-in with a black woman in Times Square. The tweets, as well as expletive-laced reactions toward his firing, have been removed from his account but can be found online. In the news release, Patrick Reilly, a SiriusXM spokesman, called Mr. Cumia’s comments “abhorrent” and “wholly inconsistent” with the company’s values. Fans have taken to social media to express support of Mr. Cumia, some saying they’ve canceled their SiriusXM subscriptions. An online petition to reinstate him had reached nearly 7,000 signatures through early Sunday afternoon. The show’s other host, Greg Hughes, a.k.a. Opie, posted on Twitter that he was devastated and would meet with SiriusXM on Tuesday. The hosts have a history of trouble. In 1998, Mr. Cumia and Mr. Hughes were fired from a Boston radio station for an April Fools’ prank in which they extensively, and falsely, reported that the city’s mayor had died in a traffic accident. In 2002, their syndicated show in New York was canceled after they broadcast a live account of a couple supposedly having sex in St. Patrick’s Cathedral. And in 2007, their XM Radio show was suspended for 30 days because of a bit about violent sex and Condoleezza Rice.

headline: McCartney Returns
text: Paul McCartney resumed performing Saturday in Albany after illness forced him to take a two-month hiatus. Mr. McCartney, 72, was hospitalized in May in Tokyo with a viral infection, prompting him to cancel parts of his “Out There” tour in Japan and South Korea and to reschedule United States dates. He is scheduled to perform on Monday in Pittsburgh and on Wednesday in Chicago, with shows nationwide through October.

headline: A History of the Now, Found in Politically Charged Objects
text: LONDON — A pair of Primark cargo shorts made at a Bangladeshi sweatshop that collapsed last year, killing more than 1,100 people. The first 3-D printed handgun. An “Occupy Sandy” sign made by grass-roots organizers in New York after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: In Reno, Trading One-Armed Bandits for Data Centers
text: The city is trying to branch out from its reliance on gambling by trying to become a home for the growing tech sector.

headline: Sculptural Treats Grace a Reopening
text: The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, which recently completed a 12-year, $145 million expansion project including new buildings by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando and renovations by the German-born architect Annabelle Selldorf, has reopened its doors in Williamstown, Mass., just in time for the great summer exodus of urban art pilgrims. In addition to Clark’s celebrated permanent collection, part of which has been on tour for three years, visitors can take in two new shows celebrating sculpture by artists separated by millenniums.

headline: Sirius XM Radio Fires a Host of ‘Opie & Anthony’ Over Racist Twitter Posts
text: Sirius XM, the satellite radio broadcaster, fired one of its most prominent talk-show hosts last week over a series of comments on Twitter that included racist and sexist language.

headline: Pluses and Minuses of Common Core
Testing for Ovarian Cancer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Targeted Killings
Silence From de Blasio on Expansion of Living Wage Law
text: For the new administration, it was a pivotal moment: Mayor Bill de Blasio was standing before the crowd, announcing the first concrete steps of his progressive agenda. By the end of February, he vowed, he would issue an executive order to expand the city’s living wage law.

headline: Does the Latin Mass Have a Future in New York?
text: To the Editor:

headline: That Fiery Soprano Is Back as Lucretia
text: The conductor Will Crutchfield has carved out an invaluable niche at the Caramoor Festival, about 40 miles north of Manhattan, with Bel Canto at Caramoor. Now in its 18th season, this series of early-19th-century operas has in the past few years found a muse in the rising soprano Angela Meade, who has joined Mr. Crutchfield for star turns in Rossini’s “Semiramide,” Bellini’s “Norma” and Verdi’s “Les Vêpres Siciliennes.”

headline: Help for Troubled Youths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reno Rolls the Dice on High-Tech
text: RENO, Nev. — A street newly nicknamed Startup Row intersects this city’s old strip of casinos touting Money Maker Jackpots and Crazy Cash Slot Tournaments.

headline: Our Mismeasured Economy
text: TODAY’S polarized debates about the role of government often boil down to a single issue: the size of government compared with the size of the overall economy, as measured in gross domestic product.

headline: The Fallacy of ‘Balanced Literacy’
text: THERE was the student who wanted to read Tolstoy, but abandoned “War and Peace” after a bewildering day with the Russian aristocracy. There were the students who had just come from Albania, to whom a Harry Potter novel was as inscrutable as Aramaic. There were the students who needed special attention, which I could barely offer. And then there were the ones who read quietly and would have welcomed a discussion about “The Chocolate War.” I couldn’t offer that, either.

headline: Europeans Fear France Could Threaten Recovery
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — As Europe struggles to move past the worst of its debt crisis, France has increasingly become a worry point in the recovery.

headline: Sarkozy, Plagued by Accusations, Sees Left-Wing Plot to Destroy Him
text: PARIS — Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France who suffered the unprecedented indignity last week of being hauled before an investigative panel for 15 hours of questioning, has angrily denounced the inquiry and cast himself as the victim of a vast left-wing plot to destroy him.

headline: Still-Divided Washington Prepares for Start of Recreational Marijuana Sales
text: VANCOUVER, Wash. — John Larson, a recently retired high school science and math teacher, hopes to be in the first wave of legal recreational marijuana salespeople opening shop here in Washington State this week.

headline: A Deluge of New Summer Programs Has TV Marketers Scrambling
text: FOR the marketing executives whose job it is to round up eyeballs to watch television, the summer is turning out to be hazy, crazy, anything but lazy.

headline: Taking Oil Industry Cue, Environmentalists Drew Emissions Blueprint
text: WASHINGTON — In November 2010, three combatants gathered in a sleek office here to build a carbon emissions policy that they hoped to sell to the Obama administration.

headline: Tight Script of Soccer Isn’t Hostage to Advertisers
text: The World Cup has shown again that soccer is very kind in its brevity. A 90-minute game takes less than two hours to finish. Even one that needed 30 minutes of added time, like the United States’ loss to Belgium, ended in 2 hours 35 minutes — which would get you to the sixth inning of many Major League Baseball games.

headline: Participant Index Seeks to Determine Why One Film Spurs Activism, While Others Falter
text: LOS ANGELES — You watched the wrenching documentary. You posted your outrage on Twitter. But are you good for more than a few easy keystrokes of hashtag activism?

headline: No Storybook Finish at Wimbledon, but Hope for More Chapters
text: WIMBLEDON, England — There was a telltale moment early in the second set of the men’s Wimbledon final when Novak Djokovic, somehow trailing in a match he appeared to be dominating and in disbelief of a net-cord winner by Roger Federer, clasped his hands and looked to the sky for mercy.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Musicians vs. Bugs
text: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times’s archives that tell tales of New York City summers past.

headline: Rescuing an iPod With a Fishing Knife
text: Dear Diary:

headline: New Yorker Wins Boys’ Title at Wimbledon as Final Shows U.S. Promise
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer may have occupied the prime real estate at Centre Court on Sunday, but on a nearby court two young players from the United States were serving notice that they may one day reach the larger stage.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: Before the holiday weekend, Money Talking took a moment to look at the innovative ideas, services and products that might fuel U.S. economic growth in the years ahead. Rana Foroohar and Joe Nocera joined the host, Charlie Herman, to reveal their choices for the innovations they believe will bring about some of the biggest changes. And then, a discussion about the word “disruption.” Does it need to be disrupted?

headline: Brazil’s Other Beautiful Games
text: MANAUS, Brazil — It was a newsroom like any television station newsroom, unless you count the brunette receptionist wearing a crown, sash and leopard print dress and offering friendly advice on how to spice up the World Cup.

headline: Ramparts Against Republicans
text: Republicans believe that they have a chance of taking control of the Senate in November. And they do.

headline: David Truong, Figure in U.S. Wiretap Case, Dies at 68
text: David Truong, a Vietnamese antiwar activist whose conviction on espionage charges in the United States in 1978 raised alarms about the federal government’s use of wiretaps without court orders and spurred passage of the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act prohibiting such practices, died on June 26 in Penang, Malaysia. He was 68.

headline: Beliefs, Facts and Money
text: On Sunday The Times published an article by the political scientist Brendan Nyhan about a troubling aspect of the current American scene — the stark partisan divide over issues that should be simply factual, like whether the planet is warming or evolution happened. It’s common to attribute such divisions to ignorance, but as Mr. Nyhan points out, the divide is actually worse among those who are seemingly better informed about the issues.

headline: Two Approaches to Tidal Politics
text: The politics of climate change are veering in starkly different directions in the neighboring states of North Carolina and Virginia. Foolhardy denial about the severity of rising seas is underway in North Carolina, where the Republican Legislature, prodded by tourism-dependent coastal counties and alarmed homeowners, ordered a state commission of experts to soften its estimate that coastal waters could rise 39 inches by the end of the century. The commission was told to revise its outlook, take into account dissenting views of climate change and produce a forecast of no more than 30 years — in hopes of keeping the estimated sea-level rise to no more than eight inches.

headline: Officials Defend N.S.A. After New Privacy Details Are Reported
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Sunday sought to play down new disclosures that the National Security Agency has swept up innocent and often personal emails from ordinary Internet users as it targets suspected terrorists in its global surveillance for potential threats.

headline: Reining In the Drones
text: For all the slick technology, there are grave moral and legal questions going unanswered in the government’s use of armed drones to kill people considered terrorist threats. The problems involving these secretive executions are ably underlined by a bipartisan panel of military and intelligence veterans who warn in a new report that without adequate controls and public accountability, the United States could be on a “slippery slope” into a form of perpetual warfare that invites other nations to follow suit and never explain themselves.

headline: G.M. OnStar Data Has Potential as Safety Tool
text: As General Motors overhauls its approach to safety, one powerful tool may be a technology that dates back two decades — the OnStar in-car assistance system.

headline: The Risks of Hospital Mergers
text: In retrospect, it looks as if Massachusetts made a serious mistake in 1994 when it let its two most prestigious (and costly) hospitals — Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women’s Hospital, both affiliated with Harvard — merge into a single system known as Partners HealthCare. Investigations by the state attorney general’s office have documented that the merger gave the hospitals enormous market leverage to drive up health care costs in the Boston area by demanding high reimbursements from insurers that were unrelated to the quality or complexity of care delivered.

headline: Principles Are No Match for Europe’s Love of U.S. Web Titans
text: LONDON — On weekends, Guillaume Rosquin browses the shelves of local bookstores in Lyon, France. He enjoys peppering the staff with questions about what he should be reading next. But his visits, he says, are also a protest against the growing power of Amazon. He is bothered by the way the American online retailer treats its warehouse employees.

headline: Festivus Poles. Close-Talker Mascot. Yada, Yada, Yada.
text: Players took batting practice in puffy pirate shirts. A fan reeled in a slice of marble rye bread with a fishing rod from the suite level. George Costanza announced the third inning. And the first 3,000 attendees at the temporarily renamed Vandelay Industries Park received a Keith Hernandez “Magic Loogie” bobblehead.

headline: ‘Seinfeld’ Fans Take Over a Ballpark
text: The Brooklyn Cyclones celebrate the iconic comedy with a theme night 25 years after the show’s television debut.

headline: Ukraine Military Finds Its Footing Against Pro-Russian Rebels
text: KIEV, Ukraine — When pro-Russian rebels first fanned out across eastern Ukraine in April, seizing public buildings, ousting local officials and blockading streets and highways, the government’s security forces — a ragtag lot of poorly equipped and understaffed military and police units — were largely paralyzed by dysfunction and defection. They seemed to remain so for months.

headline: World Cup Players Are Using Hands More Than Ever (to Tweet)
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Zinedine Zidane of France did not apologize on MySpace after his infamous head butt in the 2006 World Cup final. Diego Maradona of Argentina did not address his 1986 knuckle-assisted Hand of God goal on America Online, a digital community that did not become prominent for another five years.

headline: Semifinals Remain an Inner Sanctum Until Further Notice
text: The World Cup, ultimately, is a highly exclusive club.

headline: Challenges Facing Detroit’s North End
text: A map of Detroit’s North End neighborhood.

headline: Immigrants From Latin America and Africa Squeezed as Banks Curtail International Money Transfers
text: As government regulators crack down on the financing of terrorists and drug traffickers, many big banks are abandoning the business of transferring money from the United States to other countries, moves that are expected to reverse years of declines in the cost of immigrants sending money home to their families.

headline: Jeter Adds a 14th All-Star Game to His Farewell Tour Itinerary
text: As Derek Jeter continues his farewell tour, being honored by teams he has tormented throughout his 20-season career, there is an added stop: the All-Star Game at Target Field in Minnesota.

headline: Testing Ground for a New Detroit
text: DETROIT — Inell Byrd’s house has a leaky roof.

headline: Archives From Prisons in New York Are Digitized
text: Salvatore Lucania showed promise. At 8 years old in 1905 he arrived from Palermo, Sicily, and by the time he was a teenager he was earning $6 a week as a shipping clerk for the Goodman Hat Company in Lower Manhattan. Within five years, he had gotten a 33 percent pay increase as a laborer for the Gem Toy Company. The following year, he was supporting himself, making $8 a week, plus tips, as a barber.

headline: The Bottom Line Should Decide
text: With scintillating headlines and compelling story lines, the N.B.A. has continued to keep pace with global events like the World Cup and Wimbledon.

headline: Creating a Safe Harbor for a Village Heritage
text: MORRO BAY, Calif. — Anyone seeking to learn about the fishing heritage of this port city, named for the huge rock that dominates its harbor, need only amble over to the “Liar’s Bench,” a sitting area along the Embarcadero for fishermen prone to telling tall tales. Or one could visit the Morro Bay Hookers, a thriving fraternity of fish-baiters who skewer anchovies and sardines onto hooks for a living, some 400 hooks per line.

headline: Pete Rose Awaits His Return, 25 Years Into Exile
text: Pete Rose has a vision. Someday his career hits record will be tied, and he will respond with one final turn at bat. He will roll a single up the middle and crawl to first base for No. 4,257, reclaiming his title as Hit King.

headline: Sterling Case Will Examine Role of a Doctor Who Evaluated Him
text: LOS ANGELES — There is nothing outwardly extraordinary about the Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel, aside from the bill for a $38 Kobe beef hamburger that is washed down with a $14 bottle of Belgian beer. The room looks much the same as it always has: the low ceiling, the semicircular banquettes along the walls, the small tables in the middle of the room, the piano that is played in the evenings, and the bar that is tended by a man in a white jacket.

headline: Staten Island’s Tough-Guy Congressman Faces Somebody His Own Size
text: Domenic Recchia thinks there’s something for everyone to loathe about the man he wants to unseat in Congress, Michael G. Grimm.

headline: Day After Drowning at Park, Brooklyn Girl, 2, Is Mourned
text: Men took shelter in the shade on one side of 65th Street in the Mapleton section of Brooklyn, smoking and then snuffing out cigarettes. They stared across four lanes of traffic at the beige exterior of the apartment building where a mother mourned her 2-year-old daughter, then dropped their heads toward the concrete. They huddled in two small circles, as if to shield themselves from the wailing that cut through an otherwise tranquil Sunday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 6, 2014
text: July 6, 2014

headline: Louis Brown Jr., Nicole Simpson’s Father, Dies at 90
text: Louis H. Brown Jr., the father of O. J. Simpson’s former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and a public voice against domestic violence, died on Thursday at his home in Dana Point, Calif., a seaside community in southern Orange County. He was 90.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: When Technology Is Your Best Friend
text: Season 1, Episode 6 “You are too screwed up for words,” Cameron tells Joe early in this week’s “Halt and Catch Fire.” It’s the understatement of the series, but also perhaps a signpost for things to come.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Recap: Laws of  Human Nature, Interrupted — or, The Case of the Disappearing Bagel
text: Season 1, Episode 2 What is it about firing revolvers or swinging axes that is just so darn cathartic?

headline: Popular Demand
text: The top sports and outdoors websites in May included Backcountry.com and DicksSportingGoods.com, the site for a national chain with more than 550 stores.

text: Accounts

headline: The Secret Behind Momofuku Milk Bar’s Sweet Strawberry Treats
text: When it comes to strawberries, the strawberry-blond mastermind behind Momofuku Milk Bar, Christina Tosi, is somewhat obsessed. In the months leading up to summer, she dreams about them coming into season. And back when she was still clocking restaurant shifts at Bouley and WD-50, she would count down until the end of each one from late June to early September, the berry’s prime months, to be able to run out and find the best the Union Square Greenmarket had to offer.

headline: Word of the Day | veracity
text: veracity •\və-ˈra-sə-te\• noun

headline: Overweight and Pregnant
text: Pregnancy, or the desire to become pregnant, often inspires women to take better care of themselves — quitting smoking, for example, or eating more nutritiously.

headline: Corrections: July 7, 2014
text: OPINION

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) DANGEROUS ACTS STARRING THE UNSTABLE ELEMENTS OF BELARUS (2014) Since 2005, the Belarus Free Theater, including Yana Rusakevich, above, has addressed social and political issues in performances in and around Minsk, the country’s capital and the troupe’s base, often infuriating the government of President Aleksandr Lukashenko but rallying international supporters like Tom Stoppard and Jude Law. This documentary, directed by Madeleine Sackler, presents some of those works, including “Being Harold Pinter,” in which actors struggle to break free of a plastic sheet, and “Minsk 2011,” which pantomimes a police crackdown on a peaceful protest. “The scenes of protest and police brutality include footage gleaned from hundreds of hours filmed in collaboration with a cinematographer in Belarus (whom Ms. Sackler directed over Skype) and then smuggled out of the country,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The Belarus Free Theater, whose members are as articulate as they are talented, continue to spread the message of determined resistance to oppression.”

headline: ‘True Blood’ Recap: Shot, Without So Much as  a Goodbye
text: Season 7, Episode 3 Sunday night’s episode of “True Blood” was titled “Fire in the Hole,” and to answer the first question of a few obsessives like myself, the simple, haunting version of the Steely Dan song “Fire in the Hole” — with its lyric “Am I myself or just another freak?” — was by the Swedish duo Sara Isaksson and Rebecka Tornquivst, who put out an album of Dan covers in 2006.

headline: Student Crossword | Scientists
text: Test your knowledge of scientists by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Q. and A.: Julia Middleton and Ronald Arculli on Cultural Intelligence in a Global Era
text: China doesn’t seem to lack I.Q. — Chinese students ace examinations in educational establishments around the world. And Chinese increasingly seem to want E.Q., or emotional intelligence, with some educators concerned their students’ lack of emotional insight and ability will hinder them in life. But what about the growing idea of C.Q., or cultural intelligence?

headline: A.D.M. to Buy a Swiss Food-Flavoring Company
text: LONDON — The American agricultural giant Archer Daniels Midland said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Wild Flavors of Switzerland, a flavoring company, for 2.3 billion euros, or about $3.1 billion, in cash and debt.

headline: Lawyer Charged After Trying to Defend June 4 Commemorators
text: A meeting on May 3 in Beijing to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement led to the detentions of several participants and criminal charges against a prominent lawyer, Pu Zhiqiang, in events widely reported abroad and spoken of, quietly, in China.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Students Challenge Voter ID Laws
text: In “Students Joining Battle to Upend Laws on Voter ID,” Matt Apuzzo reports on the claims of age discrimination by young adults who are challenging laws requiring voters to show a photo ID.

headline: Crowding the Frame
text: We highly recommend viewing this slide show in full-screen mode.

headline: Cement Giants Holcim and Lafarge List Potential Asset Sales to Ease Merger
text: LONDON — Holcim and Lafarge, the world’s two largest cement and construction materials companies, outlined on Monday which assets they planned to sell in hopes of easing regulatory approval for their merger.

headline: Xi Condemns Efforts to Play Down Japan’s Wartime Aggression
text: President Xi Jinping spoke Monday at a ceremony in Beijing marking the 77th anniversary of Japan’s war with China, and he condemned efforts to revise views of Japan’s history of military aggression.

headline: SABMiller to Sell Stake in South African Hotel and Casino Group
text: LONDON — SABMiller, the world’s second-largest beer brewer, said on Monday that it would sell its stake in the South African hotel and casino group Tsogo Sun Holdings after a strategic review.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Apple Poaches an LVMH Executive
text: Just as the couture shows really get underway in Paris, an executive from LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, a.k.a. the biggest French luxury group (and, for that matter, the biggest luxury group in the world), has been lured away from the fashion capital to the technology capital of Silicon Valley. Patrick Pruniaux, until last week sales vice president for Tag Heuer, one of LVMH’s most successful watch brands, is this week joining Apple in an unspecified role.

headline: New York Today: Back to Work
text: Good Monday morning to you.

headline: Gingrich’s Correct Prediction About Medicare’s Future
text: On Oct. 24, 1995, Newt Gingrich made an assertion about what would happen to Medicare if its beneficiaries could choose between it and private plans. Medicare is “going to wither on the vine because we think people are voluntarily going to leave it — voluntarily.” Though he later walked this statement back, many observers viewed it as an attack on the program.

headline: Britain to Investigate Allegations of Sexual Abuse Cover-Up Decades Ago
text: LONDON — After days of news media reports potentially heralding a new sexual abuse scandal, British officials announced on Monday an inquiry into claims that the authorities had covered up allegations of organized child abuse in government circles decades ago.

headline: Daily Report: Personal Objections Aside, Europeans Still Hooked on U.S. Tech Titans
text: On weekends, Guillaume Rosquin browses the shelves of local bookstores in Lyon, France. He enjoys peppering the staff with questions about what he should be reading next. But his visits, he says, are also a protest against the growing power of Amazon. He is bothered by the way the American online retailer treats its warehouse employees, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Schiaparelli: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Israel Calls Up 1,500 Troops as Tensions Mount With Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and the militant group Hamas seemed set on a collision course on Tuesday, with an escalation of cross-border clashes around the Gaza Strip, Hamas vowing to avenge the deaths of six of its fighters, and Israeli warplanes attacking dozens of targets in the Palestinian coastal territory.

headline: Morning Views
text: “It looks as if Massachusetts made a serious mistake in 1994 when it let its two most prestigious (and costly) hospitals — Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women’s Hospital, both affiliated with Harvard — merge into a single system known as Partners HealthCare,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Investigations by the state attorney general’s office have documented that the merger gave the hospitals enormous market leverage to drive up health care costs in the Boston area by demanding high reimbursements from insurers that were unrelated to the quality or complexity of care delivered.” The board warns that the situation in Massachusetts “offers a cautionary tale to other states about the risks of big hospital mergers and the limits of antitrust law as a tool to break up a powerful market-dominating system once it is entrenched.”

headline: When Senate Polls Start to Matter
text: This table shows how the accuracy of polling improves as Election Day nears.

headline: Money Is Raised; Now Lessig’s Super PAC Must Win
text: The “super PAC to end all super PACs” reached its fund-raising goal in just over two months, but now comes the hard part: winning elections.

headline: Helvetia Agrees to Buy Rival Swiss Insurer
text: LONDON — The Swiss insurer Helvetia said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Nationale Suisse for about $2 billion in cash and shares in a deal that would create the third-largest insurer in Switzerland.

headline: Iraq: Where the Stories Find You
text: BAGHDAD — My late father-in-law, Peter Webb, a wonderful English grocer from Brighton, used to ask me the same question when I came back from a trip to some difficult or awful place. “How do you get your stories?” He was never quite satisfied with the answer, probably because I never much improved on it.

headline: How Small Businesses Really Use the Export-Import Bank
text: Exports are crucial to Dry Corp, a company that makes waterproof medical cast covers, and its sister company, Dry Case, which makes waterproof cases for smartphones, tablets and other gadgets. Together, the two companies employ 21 people, and each one sells about $1 million in products a year. About 17 percent of those sales come from overseas.

headline: British Hospital Operator Spire Healthcare Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The Spire Healthcare Group, a British operator of hospitals, said on Monday that it expected its initial public offering in London to value the company at about $1.6 billion.

headline: Eduard Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister Under Gorbachev, Dies at 86
text: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who as Mikhail S. Gorbachev’s foreign minister helped hone the “new thinking,” foreign and domestic, that transformed and ultimately rent the Soviet Union, then led his native Georgia through its turbulent start as an independent state, died on Monday. He was 86.

headline: Morning Agenda: Curbing International Money Transfers
text: As regulators crack down on the financing of terrorists and drug traffickers, many big banks are ending or limiting the business of transferring money from the United States and other countries, moves that are expected to lead to higher costs for immigrants sending money home to their families, DealBook’s Michael Corkery writes. While Mexico may be most affected, the banks’ retreat over the last year is also affecting other countries in Latin America and parts of Africa.

headline: 1914: Welsh Beats Ritchie on Points
text: LONDON — The world’s lightweight boxing championship changed hands last night at Olympia, with “Freddy” Welsh, the British champion, winning the premier title from the American holder, “Willie” Ritchie, on points. Approximately eight thousand spectators watched the contest in Olympia. There were many women to lend refinement and beauty to the proceedings, but not so many, I should say, as last week, when “Bombardier” Wells met Colin Bell. This, perhaps, is explained by the fact that the “Bombardier” is an unusually strong drawing card with the feminine boxing enthusiasts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 8, 1914.

headline: A Possible Solution to Toilet Stink in China
text: Using public toilets in China can often be a challenging undertaking, particularly for those not practiced in the art of squatting. But researchers in China have come up with a new technology that they say can help eliminate one of the most noxious of problems to plague China’s public lavatories: the overpowering stench.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Immigration Fireworks
text: Good Monday morning from Washington, where heat and humidity are due to return after a blissful holiday weekend.

headline: Pope Asks Forgiveness From Victims of Sex Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Monday used his first meeting with victims of clerical sexual abuse to offer his strongest condemnation of a crisis that has shaken the Roman Catholic Church, comparing priests who abuse minors to “a sacrilegious cult,” while begging forgiveness from victims and pledging to crack down on bishops who fail to protect children.

headline: A Louis Vuitton Chronograph Timepiece Inspired by Motor Racing
text: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Louis Vuitton.

headline: Setting the Table for Migrating Monarch Butterflies
text: I haven’t heard of any adult monarch butterflies arriving in the lower Hudson River Valley yet, but at least at our home the table is set for these migrants, which have had a very tough time at both ends of their continent-spanning range in recent years, with suburban sprawl in the Northeast, intensified corn production in the Midwest, deforestation in Mexico.

headline: Iraqi Parliament Wobbles Over Forming Government
text: Iraq’s political process appeared near collapse for several hours on Monday after the Parliament said it would be at least five weeks before members would even try to elect a speaker, the first step in the process of forming a government.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': A King’s Gotta Eat
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: European Union Juggles Its Problem Children
text: ROME — NATO’S first secretary general, Gen. Hastings Ismay, once said that the Western defense alliance was created “to keep the Americans in, the Russians out and the Germans down.”

headline: China Denies Entry to an American Scholar Who Spoke Up for a Uighur Colleague
text: BEIJING — When Elliot Sperling, an American professor, landed here in Beijing after a 12-hour flight from the New York area last weekend, he found himself dragged by border officers into a back room in the airport for an interrogation. They then marched him back to the same United Airlines jet that he had flown in on, despite the fact he had arrived with a valid one-year tourist visa.

headline: Egypt’s President Expresses Disappointment Over Conviction of Three Journalists
text: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt expressed disappointment in remarks published Monday at the conviction of three journalists from Al Jazeera’s English-language service, saying that their sentences had “negative consequences” and that he preferred that the journalists be deported rather than put on trial.

headline: Analytics: Boomerang Kids Talk Back
text: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 6 issue of the magazine.

headline: Not Knut
text: Gavyn Davies takes on the de facto debate between the hard-money men at the BIS and the monetary doves, and frames it as a conflict between Keynes and Wicksell. But I don’t think that’s right. The BIS position is in fact just as inconsistent with Wicksell as it is with Keynes. That doesn’t mean that the BIS is wrong (although I believe that it is); it does mean that its view is much stranger and harder to defend than Davies suggests.

headline: Tele2 of Sweden to Sell TeliaSonera Its Norwegian Business
text: LONDON – The Swedish telecommunications company Tele2 said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Norwegian business to its larger rival TeliaSonera in a deal that values the business at about $744 million.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Insider Trading Case
text: The Justice Department’s long run of insider trading convictions may be near an end as the trial of Rengan Rajaratnam comes to a close this week. Prosecutors have had a series of setbacks that whittled down a case that started out with seven charges and now consists of a single count of conspiracy. And that count only covers losing trades.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Factory Man’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Battle Over Reconstruction
text: On the morning of July 4, 1864, as Congress was preparing to adjourn for the summer, Abraham Lincoln was busy in an office at the Capitol signing bills. Senator Charles Sumner hovered nearby “in a state of intense anxiety.” George Boutwell, a representative from Massachusetts, paced nervously. Senator Zachariah Chandler of Michigan kept asking anyone who would listen if one particular bill had been signed. Told no, he spoke with Lincoln who, according to the president’s secretary John Hay, said, “this bill was placed before me a few minutes before Congress adjourns. It is a matter of too much importance to be swallowed in that way.”

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven executives as the 2014 inductees into the Advertising Hall of Achievement, for ad professionals who are age 40 or under. The honorees, to be inducted on Nov. 18, are Lauren Connolly, executive vice president and executive creative director at BBDO New York, part of the BBDO North America division of BBDO Worldwide, which is owned by the Omnicom Group; Sarah Hofstetter, chief executive of 360i, part of Dentsu; Ross Martin, executive vice president of Scratch, part of the Viacom Media Networks unit of Viacom; Erika Nardini, chief marketing officer at AOL; Elias Plishner, executive vice president for worldwide digital marketing at Sony Pictures Entertainment, a division of Sony; Bozoma Saint John, global head of marketing at Beats Music, which was recently acquired by Apple; and Jennifer S. Warren, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at RadioShack. Mr. Plishner will also receive the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, presented to an inductee for public service.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Atelier Versace Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: New Scarlett Work Among Highlights of Ballet Theater Season
text: American Ballet Theater will celebrate its 75th anniversary season with programs that include newly commissioned works and new productions alongside works by choreographers who have been significant in the company’s history – among them Michel Fokine, Frederick Ashton, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins and Antony Tudor. The season will open with a 12-day residency at the David H. Koch Theater, on Oct. 22, 2014, and will run through December 2015.

headline: 1964: Sinatra Shielded From Press
text: PARIS — Frank Sinatra, who more often rasps than croons to the press, arrived here yesterday for what he described as a few days’ “amusement.” Casualties from the running ruckus were reported to be two photographers slightly injured in brawls with the bodyguards, known as “gorillas” in French journals. “Get the so-and-so out of my way,” Sinatra shouted at the photographers. He then reportedly pulled a couple of small firecrackers from his pocket, lit and tossed them into the milling throng. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 8, 1964

headline: Grilled Vanilla-Ginger Pineapple
text: Sherry Yard has a wonderful recipe in her first cookbook, “The Secrets of Baking,” called Roasted Voodoo Vanilla Pineapple. She roasts her pineapple with the dried vanilla pods that you save after you’ve scraped out the seeds, and fresh ginger. She inserts the pods into the flesh of the pineapple, a great idea if you’re roasting the pineapple for a long time.

headline: Grilled Watermelon and Feta Salad
text: I love watermelon and feta salad, whether the watermelon is grilled or not. The sweet, juicy watermelon against the salty, creamy feta and pungent onions is a winning combination. This version introduces heat and char. Throw the watermelon slices, with the rind, onto the grill after or before you’ve grilled your meat or fish or vegetables. Grill them on both sides until just charred, then cut away the rinds and dice up the melon for the salad.

headline: Crêpes With Grilled Peaches and Apricots
text: Heat deepens the flavor of both peaches and apricots, and grilling adds one more seared dimension. The trick here is to grill the fruit just until it colors and softens, but not to let it burn or collapse. I find that 3 minutes on one side is sufficient for peaches, and 2 minutes for apricots, with about 1 minute on the other side.

headline: New York Summer Stories: It’s Too Hot
text: City Room has dug up articles from The New York Times archives during the past week that tell tales of city summers past.

headline: Arugula Salad With Grilled Apricots and Pistachios
text: Pungent arugula contrasts beautifully with fruit of all kinds. Grilling the apricots deepens their flavor and makes them stand out against the arugula even more. You’ll be able to make this beautiful salad only during the summer’s short apricot season, and even then, you should buy the fruits at the farmers’ market so you can sample them to make sure they are juicy and sweet.

headline: The Other Greenhouse Gas, Feeling Lucky in Sports, Animal Madness
text: Scientists argue over the importance of controlling methane emissions; why it’s a good thing that the World Cup is all about luck; what humans can learn from grieving animals.

headline: Grilled Figs With Pomegranate Molasses
text: These are wonderful. First you toss them in a mix of balsamic vinegar and olive oil, then you grill them on both sides just until they soften and grill marks appear (at which point they are warm all the way through and just beginning to become jammy), then you remove from the grill and brush with pomegranate molasses. It’s a match made in heaven. Serve while the figs are still warm, as a first course with goat cheese, or as a dessert with ricotta or yogurt.

headline: Tentative Results in Afghan Presidential Runoff Spark Protests
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s already tumultuous election grew more perilous on Monday after the announcement of preliminary presidential runoff results that were rejected by the candidate Abdullah Abdullah, leading some of his most powerful supporters to call for protests and even the forming of a breakaway government.

headline: Ads for Zoo Exhibit Give New Meaning to ‘Animal House’
text: It is relatively easy these days, thanks to social media, to make monkeys out of stars. A campaign for the Los Angeles Zoo, now underway, is hoping to make stars out of monkeys.

headline: Christian Dior: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Photographing Grief
text: Throughout the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: World Cup 2014: Puzzle 2 of 2
text: This week we continue to celebrate World Cup 2014 (in case you missed it, here is last week’s post) with a challenge featuring a critical component of any soccer match, particularly at the highest levels: the penalty kick. The puzzle was suggested by Marco Moriconi, who lives in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: New Pink Floyd Album Coming in October
text: The news was leaked in what seemed an aside: On Saturday, the author Polly Samson, who is married to David Gilmour, Pink Floyd’s guitarist, went onto Twitter and tweeted, to her 17,100 followers:

headline: Facts & Figures: Healthier With Same-Sex Parents?
text: An Australian survey of same-sex parents found that their children scored higher on measures of health and family cohesion than the general population.

headline: Couture Fashion Week (So Far) in 140 Characters
text: The winter 2014 couture shows in Paris are in full swing and our staff has been reporting from the front rows and behind-the-scenes. See a collection of their tweets so far.From Dior:

headline: British Phenom Charli XCX on Sudden Success, Singing With Iggy Azalea and What Made Madonna Special
text: The British singer-songwriter Charli XCX was just another would-be star trying to make it onto the charts when Icona Pop’s “I Love It,” written by XCX, became one of the biggest hits of 2013. A torrent of success has followed, which has included penning tracks for the hottest names in music and singing the hook for the current hit “Fancy” alongside Iggy Azalea. Here, XCX talks about the origin of “Fancy” and premieres the ASTR remix of her new song, “Boom Clap.”

headline: For Head of New York Tourism, 55 Million Visitors Isn’t Enough
text: Fred Dixon is not replacing Neil Patrick Harris in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” on Broadway, but he still has one of the hardest acts to follow in New York City.

headline: Winning a Battle of the Mind, Not to Mention the Backhands
text: Novak Djokovic went to hell and back to win his second Wimbledon title Sunday.

headline: James Simons Gives $50 Million to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory
text: James H. Simons, a retired hedge fund titan who used mathematical strategies to become a billionaire, is financing a new medical research center that plans to apply similar strategies to investigate serious diseases.

headline: Testimony in Clippers Case Begins, but Sterling Doesn’t Take the Stand
text: LOS ANGELES — A lawyer for Rochelle Sterling turned with a grand gesture and allowed his eyes to sweep over the courtroom as he asked for his first witness.

headline: Hamas Vows Vengeance for Israeli Strike
text: Hundreds of mourners gathered in Gaza on Monday for the funeral of two of the militants killed in an Israeli airstrike earlier the same day, and a Hamas spokesman pledged to avenge their deaths.

headline: Iraq — or Sunnistan, Shiitestan and Kurdistan
text: When the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria launched its 2014 assault on Iraq, the ensuing chaos ignited familiar discussions about the future of the country and the possibility of a “three-state solution.”

headline: Fire Damages Acclaimed Bay Area Restaurant
text: David Kinch, a Northern California chef who has been widely hailed for paying meticulous attention to the seasons and the elements, suffered a setback early Monday morning when a fire roared through Manresa, his restaurant in Los Gatos, Calif. near San Jose.

headline: Ball? Strike? It Depends: Is the Pitcher an All-Star?
text: They would rather not talk about it, but umpires may be just as star-struck as the average baseball fan.

headline: Dangers of Weekend Emergency Surgery
text: A new study suggests that emergency surgery done on children during the weekend results in more complications and deaths than similar surgery done during the week.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Benefits From Rosberg’s Hard Luck
text: Lewis Hamilton, who assumed the lead when his teammate, Nico Rosberg, dropped out on the 47th lap, took the victory Sunday in the British Grand Prix at Silverstone. The win, coupled with Rosberg’s no-points nonfinish, helped Hamilton close to within four points of his teammate in the season’s driving championship. Rosberg, whose Mercedes had a gearbox failure, had been leading by 29 points entering the race; he had finished every previous grand prix this season.

headline: Pope Meets Clergy Sex Abuse Victims
text: Pope Francis spoke after meeting with six victims of clerical sex abuse.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Schiaparelli Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Pope Francis Apologizes to Abuse Victims
text: Pope Francis met over the weekend with six victims of abuse by Catholic clergy, denounced attacks on children in religious terms during a special Mass this morning and warned bishops of the Roman Catholic Church that they will be held accountable for their actions toward the abused and the abusers.

headline: Corner the Market on Summer Squash
text: Suddenly it is summer at the market. Make a wish for a summer vegetable or fruit and most likely it is there. Shaded tents now brim with green beans, tomatoes, eggplant, even corn. More stalls are piled with cherries and red currants and peaches and tiny sweet strawberries.

headline: Watching the World Cup, and Watching Children See Dishonesty Pay Off
text: What do you tell your children when cheaters win?

headline: Spy Scandal Tails Merkel All the Way to Beijing
text: BEIJING — The visit to China by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was supposed to focus on business, but financial matters were overshadowed Monday by a spy scandal at home — reportedly involving the United States — and China’s wartime history with Japan.

headline: Welcome to the Everything Boom, or Maybe the Everything Bubble
text: In Spain, where there was a debt crisis just two years ago, investors are so eager to buy the government’s bonds that they recently accepted the lowest interest rates since  1789.

headline: Glimmerglass to Offer Mozart, Vivaldi, Verdi and Bernstein for 40th Anniversary
text: The Glimmerglass Festival, which presents a summer season of opera at the graceful Alice Busch Opera Theater in Cooperstown, N.Y., will celebrate its 40th anniversary in 2015 with four productions, the company said Monday. As in recent seasons the prospectus includes three operas and a musical – although the musical, Leonard Bernstein’s “Candide,” has a foot in both worlds. It started its life in the theater, while in recent decades it has been presented more regularly in opera houses (it was a staple at the New York City Opera).

headline: Pilot Dies in Plane Crash in Long Island Sound
text: The pilot of a single-engine airplane died on Monday after his craft crashed into the waters of the Long Island Sound, Coast Guard officials said. Investigators have yet to determine the cause of the crash or to release the name of the pilot.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Anthropocene (Age of Us)
text: Nathanael Johnson, Grist’s excellent food and sustainability blogger, offer to mediate a conversation between the ethicist and author Clive Hamilton and me over our differing views of this age of us, known increasingly as the Anthropocene.

headline: Alcohol Remains a Leading Killer
text: Excessive alcohol consumption, including binge drinking, is responsible for 10 percent of deaths among working-age adults in the United States, according to a recent study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Tanenhaus on the G.O.P.’s New Intellectuals
text: Sam Tanenhaus, writer at large for The New York Times, wrote this week’s cover story about an influential group of young intellectuals feeding ideas to the Republican Party. He is the author of, among other books, “The Death of Conservatism.”

headline: Studying May Make You Nearsighted
text: Can too much studying ruin your eyesight? Maybe. A German study has found that the more education a person has, the greater the likelihood that he will be nearsighted.

headline: Officer ‘Separations’ Break More Than Years of Service
text: How does it feel when the country for which you’ve lost youth, relationships and health wants to get rid of you? It feels like betrayal. If the Army is our family, then this is divorce.

headline: Ackman’s Hedge Fund Offers Slate of Directors for Botox Maker Allergan
text: Pershing Square Capital Management unveiled a proposed slate of directors on Monday that it hopes to elect to the Allergan board.

headline: Friend Says Boston Bombing Suspect Spoke of Building Bomb
text: BOSTON — A federal prosecutor told jurors on Monday that a college friend of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, believed that his friend had been involved in the attack and tried to cover up incriminating evidence.

headline: The 10 Books That Made Debut Novelist Will Chancellor Want to Write One of His Own
text: The author Will Chancellor spent a decade working on his debut novel, “A Brave Man Seven Storeys Tall” (out tomorrow from Harper), the tale of a would-be Olympian turned one-eyed wanderer named Owen Burr who goes missing, and his professor father who follows his trail to Athens, Berlin and Iceland. Whenever Chancellor lost his path, he turned to these novels for guidance and inspiration. In each of them, he explains, “I saw more of myself and finally accepted that I had to spend my life writing.”

headline: In Craziness of Free Agency, a Levelheaded Approach
text: LOS ANGELES — If it was not apparent by now that Pau Gasol is cut out a little differently, consider the outside interests of Gasol, the sublimely skilled, ever so polite and supremely conscientious 7-foot center.

headline: In Performance | Jan Maxwell
text: A scene from Anthony Giardina’s play “The City of Conversation,” about three decades in the life of a Washington socialite.

headline: A Departure for A.D.M. in $3.1 Billion Deal
text: Archer Daniels Midland is going merger wild – sort of.

headline: More on American Colleges’ Standing in the World
text: Last week I wrote that, contrary to conventional wisdom, there is no reason to believe that American colleges are, on average, the best in the world. A number of people who responded, including several in letters to The Times, raised issues worth addressing more broadly.

headline: No Need to Demonize High-Frequency Trading
text: Bart Chilton, a former commissioner of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, is a senior policy adviser at DLA Piper and the author of “Ponzimonium: How Scam Artists Are Ripping Off America.”

headline: A Video Debut from Rick Rubin’s New Protégés, Angus and Julia Stone
text: It goes without saying that if the renowned, elusive music producer and Def Jam Records co-founder Rick Rubin gets excited about someone, they’re probably destined for great things. Now the man who turned the Beastie Boys and the Red Hot Chili Peppers into icons has tapped the Australian folk-blues sibling duo Angus and Julia Stone as his new protégés. “It’s few and far between that I hear something that really excites me,” says Rubin, who’s notorious for rarely speaking to the press. “I heard their music and it really moved me. They make the kind of songs that I can listen to over and over again for a long period of time. They have hypnotic, poetic depth.” What Rubin didn’t know when he contacted the pair — who started making music together in 2006 — was that not only did they have no plans to write any further songs at the time, but they flat-out weren’t getting along at all. “It was only when I reached out to them that they decided to get together to make the album we eventually made, and through that process had a family healing and are better friends today than they, I think, have ever been,” Rubin says. “None of this was intentional. It just happened, and it’s a pretty beautiful part of the story.”

headline: Signs of an Afghan Crisis, There on Election Day in June
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With the Afghan election commission releasing preliminary results that seemed too inflated to be trusted, the stage is set for even more conflict over the political process here.

headline: G.M. Resists Recalling Trucks Over Brake Lines
text: Under pressure from federal regulators and legislators, General Motors this year has been reviewing past safety problems. That has resulted in 54 recalls affecting about 25.7 million vehicles in the United States.

headline: Does That Cat Have O.C.D.?
text: It was love at first pet when Laurel Braitman and her husband adopted a 4-year-old Bernese mountain dog, a 120-pound bundle of fur named Oliver.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: A Sound Tour of the World, Accompanied by Birds
text: The sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art is separated from the museum’s lobby by an expansive wall of glass. It speaks to Mozart’s continued reach over the music of today that in little more than a month, I have heard recent reworkings of his melodies on both sides of that wall.

headline: Fiddling While Iraq Burns
text: Iraqi politicians are acting as if their country weren’t under mortal threat from Sunni extremists. Instead of quickly forming a government so leaders can concentrate on rallying the country to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the new parliament on Monday postponed its next session until Aug. 12.

headline: Russia Urges Bulgaria to Resume Building Gas Pipeline
text: Russia’s foreign minister urged the European Union on Monday to allow construction to resume on a natural gas pipeline that Moscow is backing.

headline: Altered N.F.L. Settlement Wins Judge’s Approval
text: A federal judge approved a preliminary settlement between the N.F.L. and lawyers for the more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league, accusing it of hiding the dangers of concussions and repeated hits to the head.

headline: Box Raises $150 Million in New Financing as It Moves Toward an I.P.O.
text: Updated | 7:04 p.m. Box, the online storage provider on its way to going public, has raised $150 million from two investment firms as it bides its time before completing its initial public offering, the company said on Monday.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Christian Dior Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | July 1-7, 2014
text: How well did you follow the news this week? Test yourself to see how you do against others.

headline: Pasta With Burst Cherry Tomatoes
text: Melissa Clark makes a summer pasta salad with burst cherry tomatoes, scallions and mint that has something bright and lively in every bite.

headline: What the Therapist Thinks About You
text: BOSTON — David Baldwin wasn’t sure how he had come across the other day in group therapy at the hospital, near the co-op apartment where he lives with his rescue cat, Zoey. He struggles with bipolar disorder, severe anxiety and depression. Like so many patients, he secretly wondered what his therapist thought of him.

headline: Months Full of Meredith Monk Performances
text: Meredith Monk will spend next season celebrating the 50th anniversary of her first New York concert – a work called “Break,” at the now defunct Washington Square Gallery, in September 1964 – with concerts all over Manhattan and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The timing could not be better: as the current occupant of the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair at Carnegie Hall, Ms. Monk has a spotlight and resources greater than she has had for most of the 50 years since that first show.
