headline: Not Only Pretty, They Pop
text: Long-simmered tomato sauces are just right in winter, when you’re looking to spend hours next to the stove in the company of a steaming, bubbling pot. But summer demands something brighter and fresher, dishes that feature the season’s ripest produce but do so with minimal cooking time.

headline: The Letters That Warren G. Harding’s Family Didn’t Want You to See
text: Warren Harding is not the most beloved of American presidents. Two of the earliest polls to assess presidential popularity, conducted in 1948 and 1962, ranked him last and last among chief executives. Harding served only briefly, from 1921 to 1923, before he died in office, but his administration has been widely regarded as visionless, ineffectual and corrupt. He slashed immigration quotas, appointed his cronies — one of whom, his secretary of the interior, accepted bribes from oil companies in what became known as the Teapot Dome scandal — and brought an end to the famously reform-minded eras of Teddy Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson. Perhaps the best that can be said about Harding is that he seems to have been conscious of his defects. “I am not fit for this office and should never have been here,” he once conceded.

headline: Woman in Custody After Leaving Baby on Subway Platform
text: The subway train doors opened at the Columbus Circle station around noon on Monday, and a woman stepped out onto the platform pushing a stroller with a 6- or 7-month-old girl inside. Moments later, the police said, she stepped back into the train alone.

headline: In Fair Verona, Where Soca Music Now Plays Under Starry Skies
text: Hip-hop music from the nearby baseball diamond wafts into Verona. A stray tabby and a cloud of fireflies crowd its lanes. At “Romeo N Juliet,” a free performance staged in an amphitheater at Marcus Garvey Park by the Classical Theater of Harlem, the distractions of an uptown summer evening compete with a centuries-old tragedy.

headline: The Daily Do | Feathers In Lieu of Bangs at Schiaparelli
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runway.

headline: In Winnipeg, a Museum Honoring Human Rights
text: The Canadian Museum for Human Rights — billed as the first museum dedicated to raising awareness of national and international human rights issues — will open on Sept. 20 in Winnipeg.

headline: The Myth and Magic of Pic de Bugarach
text: This past weekend, Yvette Monahan published a book of photographs about a rural area in south-central France between the Mediterranean Sea and the Pyrenees mountains. At the region’s center is a mountain called Bugarach. Monahan spent a year taking pictures of the mountain and its surroundings, which have a rich mythical history. I was enchanted by the photos in her book, ‘‘The Time of Dreaming the World Awake,’’ when I saw them recently, so I reached out to her and got her to tell me what sparked her interest in this French spot:

headline: Debate Continues on Hazards of Electromagnetic Waves
Théodore Géricault at Jill Newhouse
text: The French Romantic Théodore Géricault will forever be identified with “The Raft of the Medusa,” a wrenching, ripped-from-the-headlines painting of disaster at sea that set off a political controversy in France and has since inspired contemporary artists like Martin Kippenberger and Thomas Hirschhorn. But he was also drawn to quieter subjects, to judge from an intriguing show of drawings, watercolors and small oil paintings.

headline: Ford Recalls 92,000 Vehicles for Driveshaft Problem
text: Ford is recalling about 92,000 sedans and crossovers in North America because of a problem with the front, right half shaft, which means the vehicles can cause drivers to “experience the loss of drive function” suddenly, the automaker said on Monday.

headline: Beehive Air-Conditioning
text: Q. Why are honeybees drinking water from my birdbath?

headline: Couture Fashion Week Street Style
text: Street style looks at Couture fashion week in Paris.

headline: Roger Cabán: ‘Canto Boricua: The Two Islands’
text: Roger Cabán was born in Puerto Rico in 1942, came to New York as a child and has lived here ever since. But like most Nuyoricans of his generation, he has shuttled back and forth, which explains the title of this refined and cordial solo show of his black-and-white photographs from the 1970s.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Bosnia and Washington.

headline: One Way to Solve Private Equity’s Recruiting Problem
text: Hardly anyone on Wall Street is happy about the way private equity firms recruit low-level employees from investment banks. But there are signs that the process may be starting to change.

headline: Meyer Vaisman: ‘In the Vicinity of History, 5774’
text: In his first solo show in New York in over a dozen years, Meyer Vaisman’s paintings home in on the issues of appropriation, authorship and self-reference that he pursued in New York in the early 1980s. Then he was fresh from Caracas, his birthplace, and in his early 20s but already quite prominent as a partner in International With Monument, the hot East Village gallery that gave Jeff Koons his breakthrough exhibition, and as a member of the short-lived Neo-Geo trend, showing at galleries like Sonnabend and Jay Gorney Modern Art.

headline: Former Barclays Chief Robert Diamond Takes to Twitter
text: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former chief executive of Barclays, has joined the Twittersphere.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: For Broadway, a Tepid July 4 Week
text: The big-budget Broadway musicals “Bullets Over Broadway” and “Rocky,” the hit shows “Kinky Boots” and “Once” and the star-studded plays “The Cripple of Inishmaan” (with Daniel Radcliffe) and “Of Mice and Men” (with James Franco) were among several Broadway productions with soft ticket sales during the Fourth of July holiday week, according to box office data released on Monday.

headline: New Field Tests May Curb Kissing Bug Disease
text: Six different rapid diagnostic tests have proved reliable in detecting Chagas disease without having to wait for laboratory confirmation, according to a study by the medical charity Doctors Without Borders and the World Health Organization.

headline: ‘Supports/Surfaces’ at Canada
text: Big, shiny Chelsea galleries are not the only ones that can present missing chunks of recent art history. Canada, working with the Paris-based Galerie Bernard Ceysson, is staging the first American survey of some painters of the relatively unknown French Supports/Surfaces art movement, which was active in the late 1960s, ’70s and early ’80s. With so much of current abstraction in back-to-basics mode, the show is timely, revealing the strengths and pitfalls of its artists’ approach. Some of this stuff looks alive and pertinent; some of it looks ordinary and inert.

headline: Social Anxiety
text: Does social media help shy people open up? Some relish the chance to connect with others without the awkwardness of the face to face. But for others, the Internet is just as bad as the physical world — or even worse. And the question of shyness may open up into bigger questions about how we experience social life online.

headline: Emily Mae Smith: ‘Novelty Court’
text: Bucking the messy abstraction trend, Emily Mae Smith’s Pop-style paintings comment on sex and gender with satirical ingenuity. Two posterlike works on view in this pint-size gallery mimic the cover of The Studio, a late-Victorian art magazine, with the title lettered at the top and the Art Nouveau-style image of a female artist painting in her studio rendered in thin black lines on white grounds. To each of these genteel images, Ms. Smith has added the realistic, semi-transparent color image of a much-enlarged piece of fruit — a banana and a tomato — highlighting the idea of the woman as a desirable commodity.

headline: Hitting the Ceiling, Then Moving Up
text: Sia goes over the top almost immediately on her new album, “1000 Forms of Fear.” When the chorus of “Chandelier” arrives, a simulated orchestra crashes in, and her voice appears in a strenuous high register, belting, “I’m gonna swing from the chandelier, ” with an I-dare-myself upward leap on the last syllable of “chandelier.” Still aloft, she repeats “from the chandelier” and leaps even higher. It’s showy, impulsive, shrewd, gripping and maybe a little unhinged, and so is the rest of the album.

headline: Youth Tsunami in Arab World
text: These days, alarming news continues to spill out of the Middle East. Syria’s continuing civil war has claimed tens of thousands of civilian lives. Iraq — where the prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, has stoked sectarian conflict by refusing to form an inclusive government — is hurtling toward civil war, as Sunni militants, led by the Qaeda splinter group ISIS, have moved close to Baghdad. Farther east, the Taliban are resurgent in Afghanistan.

headline: Back to the Beginning of Elemental Emotions
text: Late one night on Second Avenue, the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker practiced walking and turning in the studios of New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. To the music of Steve Reich and Bach — she couldn’t decide which to use — she played around with permutations of these elemental steps, adding a spiraling torso or swinging arms on top of precisely placed feet.

headline: Russian Arrested in Guam on Array of U.S. Hacking Charges
text: A Russian man accused of being one of the world’s most prolific traffickers of stolen financial information was arrested in Guam on Saturday, according to the Secret Service.

headline: Would Warren G. Harding Have Fared Better in 1971?
text: As Gail Collins teased in her column this weekend, the magazine has obtained access to a trove of letters that Harding wrote to his longtime mistress, Carrie Fulton Phillips, between 1910 and 1920. People have known about these letters for half a century — they were front-page news when they were discovered in 1964 — but they’ve mostly been locked up until now. In 1971, the Harding family agreed to donate the letters to the Library of Congress (also front-page news) on the condition that they remain sealed for 50 years.

headline: Istanbul Deftly Takes Contrasts in Its Stride
text: ISTANBUL — During one particularly eclectic afternoon here at the end of June, I watched the whirling dervishes in their serene ritual at the 15th-century Mevlevi Lodge and then dashed out to observe an exuberant gay pride parade marching down Istiklal Street, the city’s bustling pedestrian shopping boulevard.

headline: Fishermen Hang On to Livelihood in Morro Bay
text: Faced with increased competition from corporate fish processors in bigger ports, fishermen in Morro Bay, Calif., have set up a community quota fund.

headline: The Lag Time for Patients
text: To the Editor:

headline: American Apparel Creditor Calls In $10 Million Loan
text: After weeks of intense wrangling, one of American Apparel’s longtime lenders, Lion Capital, has demanded immediate repayment of a $10 million loan it made to the troubled retailer, after negotiations over new terms failed, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Replaced by an Algorithm
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Dior, Historical References Translated to Modern Style
text: As editors piled in for the Christian Dior fall 2014 couture presentation today, taking in the classic white orchids that lined the walls around the futuristic runway space (shaped a bit like a round U.F.O.), the collection’s theme — a connection between old and new, past and present — began to make itself apparent. The show began, and the house’s artistic director Raf Simons launched his audience into a sort of time travel with his range of references. He embellished archetypal silhouettes like loose, flapperesque dresses; wide-through-the-hips, Marie Antoinette-style gowns; and baggy, one-piece flight suits with anachronistic details like sophisticated embroidery and fresh prints. Among the many knockout looks in the show, it was hard to ignore the ornate justacorps jacket with a matching gilet underneath. Finished off with a simple black top and trousers, it made for a truly modern ensemble that ushered the couture era right into the now.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Ruling on Union Contributions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Proof and Campus Rape
text: To the Editor:

headline: Earthlike Planets May Be Merely an Illusion
text: In 2010, astronomers were stirred by the discovery of Gliese 581g, a distant Earthlike planet that orbited its star just closely enough to allow for surface water, and possibly life.

headline: Stolen From Cradle, Now Back to Rage
text: Young adult television typically cleaves into two camps — it’s either about the absurd comedy of teenage life, or its unending tragedy. The plotlines aren’t that different, but in the first category, characters respond to pain with charm and wit, while in the other, their shoulders droop, and they stew in bad lighting.

headline: An Undead Tale of the Teenage Years
text: LONDON — And just when you thought you’d had your fill of young vampires in love, along comes a ravishing little romance of the undead that’s guaranteed to warm — and break — your heart, even as it chills your blood. “Let the Right One In,” which is bringing limelight to endless night at the Apollo Theater here, turns your emotions inside out in a way you probably haven’t experienced since you were a teenager.

headline: Acropolis Maidens Glow Anew
text: ATHENS — For 2,500 years, the six sisters stood unflinching atop the Acropolis, as the fires of war blazed around them, bullets nicked their robes, and bombs scarred their curvaceous bodies. When one of them was kidnapped in the 19th century, legend had it that the other five could be heard weeping in the night.

headline: An Athlete Who Needs More Than a Ponytail
text: Skylar Diggins, 23, is a point guard for the Tulsa Shock. She was a basketball star at Notre Dame, where she holds the record as the all-time scoring leader. These days, when not in uniform (the Women’s National Basketball Association regular season runs through mid-August), she might be modeling for Nike or appearing at red carpet events with Jay Z and her Roc Nation management agency. A native of South Bend, Ind., Ms. Diggins now lives in Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Ancient Bird Had Some Feathers Just for Show
text: German scientists found a new specimen of Archaeopteryx, the 150-million-year-old winged creature thought to represent the transition from dinosaurs to birds, with well-preserved feather markings. The bird, described in the journal Nature, had feathers on its hind limbs that researchers said were more likely used for display than for flight.

headline: Germany Proposes a Road Tax Aimed Primarily at Foreigners
text: BERLIN — The German government announced plans on Monday to charge a road-use fee on all cars using roads and highways in Germany, a measure aimed at the foreign-registered cars that make an estimated 170 million trips to and through the country each year.

headline: Giving Tofu the New Look It Deserves
text: It’s not likely that tofu will become anyone’s favorite food; this we know. Those who grew up in households where it was well prepared may relish it, but for the rest of us it’s a bit of a requisite, something we think we “should” eat in place of chicken or eggs whenever we can stomach it.

headline: Brad Hintz, Top Bank Analyst, to Retire
text: Brad Hintz, who became known as one of the premier bank analysts after a career at some of Wall Street’s most powerful firms, will retire from Sanford C. Bernstein & Company to teach at New York University’s Stern School of Business.

headline: Picking Lesser of Two Climate Evils
text: Climate scientists long ago settled among themselves the question of whether human emissions of greenhouse gases are a problem, concluding that we are running some grave risks. But the field still features vigorous debate about how bad global warming will get, how quickly, and how to combat it.

headline: Saul Leiter’s Black-and-White World
text: Though he was famed for his color photography, Saul Leiter’s earliest work was in black-and-white, and just as personal and powerful as his later images.

headline: Ash Borers and a Deluge of Data
text: Invasive Species

headline: Forced Out: High Rent Alters a City
Seeker, Doer, Giver, Ponderer
text: James H. Simons likes to play against type. He is a billionaire star of mathematics and private investment who often wins praise for his financial gifts to scientific research and programs to get children hooked on math.

headline: Learning the Secrets of E-Commerce in China
text: There has been much buzz about the initial public offering of Alibaba, China’s e-commerce giant. The company is the top player in an increasingly crowded and diverse Chinese online sales market that features corporations looking to order large quantities of manufactured goods; small business buying items in lots of, say, 25 pieces; and consumers looking for a single product.

headline: A California Oil Field Yields Another Prized Commodity
text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The 115-year-old Kern River oil field unfolds into the horizon, thousands of bobbing pumpjacks seemingly occupying every corner of a desert landscape here in California’s Central Valley. A contributor to the state’s original oil boom, it is still going strong as the nation’s fifth-largest oil field, yielding 70,000 barrels a day.

headline: Soccer, a Beautiful Game of Chance
text: I’ve been watching the World Cup with some frustrated American social scientists. When they see an underdog team triumph with a miraculous rebound or an undeserved penalty kick, they don’t jump up and scream “Goooaaalll!” They just shake their heads and mutter, “Measurement error.”

headline: New T.S.A. Rules for Electronics on Flights Bound for U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — In response to intelligence reports about plots being hatched by Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen, the United States has, for the first time, asked officials at more than a dozen foreign airports to confiscate from passengers any electronic devices that cannot be turned on, American officials said on Monday.

headline: Making Films in Bulgaria Can Bring Pleasures and Frustrations
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — It looks like an authentic corner of Brooklyn, right down to the entrance to an imaginary subway and the “no parking” sign.

headline: Lenders Agree to Give Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority More Time to Repay Debt
text: Puerto Rico’s struggling electric power authority reached a temporary deal with some of its lenders on Monday, buying the agency a little more time as it sorts out its troubled finances.

headline: Flowers Foods PAC Gives to Democrats, First Time in Decades
text: On June 10, the Flowers Foods PAC did something it had not done in 20 years: It gave money to a Democrat. Three, actually.

headline: Should Germans Read ‘Mein Kampf’?
text: WASHINGTON — GERMANY is once again passing through the wringer of its past. At issue this time are not the deeds but the words of Adolf Hitler and the planned republication of his infamous manifesto-as-autobiography, “Mein Kampf,” a book that has been officially suppressed in the country since the end of World War II.

headline: To Camp, or Not to Camp
text: Is summer for planned activities, or a time for kids to wander?

headline: Security Firm Described Simulation as Real Hack
text: BAE Systems Applied Intelligence, a defense, aerospace and security company, recently noted in a report that one of its clients at an unnamed hedge fund lost millions of dollars because of a cyberattack. But the incident was, in fact, a simulation run by the security firm itself.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Is Anyone Trustworthy Around Here?
text: Season 2, Episode 10 I don’t think I’ve ever been so happy to be so wrong: Nicky didn’t do the drugs!

headline: An Activist Investor Helps a Solar Power Company Turn Itself Around
text: Two years ago, the solar power company SunEdison was in a crisis.

headline: Writing Alone, Together
text: For the better part of my writing life, I’ve been alone. By this I mean I have written alone, spending my days in the kind of voluntary solitary confinement that is necessary to the business of getting the right words out of my head in the right order.

headline: No Punishment on Neymar Hit
text: FIFA’s disciplinary committee Monday rejected a request by Brazil’s soccer federation to punish the Colombian player whose tackle knocked Brazil’s top player, Neymar, out of the World Cup.

headline: To Cut Costs, Federal Workers Become Nomads
text: WASHINGTON — The most sumptuous room in the headquarters of the General Services Administration has floor-to-ceiling oak panels, chandeliers and a working fireplace carved of French limestone.

headline: Investors Are Buying Troubled Golf Courses and Giving Them Makeovers
text: When the Gaillardia Golf and Country Club opened in 1998, it was to be the crown jewel of golf in Oklahoma City, complete with an 18-hole P.G.A. championship course and a 55,000-square-foot clubhouse of Norman-style architecture. The Gaylord family, best known as Oklahoma media moguls and owners of the Grand Ole Opry, sank a reported $59 million into the project.

headline: Knutty Asset Prices
text: Neil Irwin has a nice piece about high asset prices that actually ties into my Wicksell discussion from earlier today.

headline: Group Promoting Referendum on Marijuana Submits Signatures
text: Advocates for the legalization of marijuana in Washington announced Monday that they had collected more than twice the signatures required to get a measure on the November ballot. The district’s Board of Elections has up to 30 days to check that the group promoting the measure, the D.C. Cannabis Campaign, had collected valid signatures from at least 22,500 voters. The effort could lead to a confrontation with Congress, which controls the district’s budget and can intervene in local lawmaking.

headline: Fan Sues After Untimely Nap Brings Unwanted Attention
text: The television cameras at baseball games often catch fans in semi-embarrassing moments, and good sports announcers are adept at poking gentle fun at spectators when the action on the diamond slows down.

headline: Clinton Defends Her Handling of a Rape Case in 1975
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton — responding for the first time to new criticism about how she handled the defense of a rape suspect in 1975 — said she had asked to be removed from the case, in which her client was accused of sexually assaulting a 12-year-old girl.

headline: The Creative Climate
text: In the current issue of The Atlantic, Joshua Wolf Shenk has a fascinating description of how Paul McCartney and John Lennon created music together. McCartney was meticulous while Lennon was chaotic. McCartney emerged out of a sunny pop tradition. Lennon emerged out of an angst-ridden rebel tradition.

headline: No Signs of Fabrication in Imprisoned Al Jazeera Crew’s Reports From Egypt
text: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt expressed regret in remarks published Monday over the convictions of three journalists from Al Jazeera’s English-language service, saying that it would have been better to simply deport them than put them in prison.

headline: In Bulgaria, Corruption and Mistrust Turn Promise Into Pain
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The lines of panicked depositors in this threadbare capital evaporated as quickly as they appeared in what may have been the shortest banking crisis in history — or potentially the prelude to something more tumultuous.

headline: A Dwindling Transportation Fund
text: Business advocacy groups say lawmakers’ inaction on infrastructure spending threatens the economic recovery.

headline: Alfredo Di Stéfano, Soccer Great for Real Madrid, Dies at 88
text: Alfredo Di Stéfano, an Argentine soccer star who built a legendary career when he moved to Europe in the 1950s and led Real Madrid to five straight Continental club championships, died on Monday in Madrid. He was 88.

headline: U.S. Scrutiny for Banks Shifts to Commerzbank and Germany
text: A trail of illicit money led the American government on a hunt through the European financial system, generating criminal cases against banks in Britain, Switzerland and most recently, France.

headline: The Messy World of Smart Guns
text: The Andy Raymond rant is a thing to behold.

headline: Coalition Prods Congress on Transportation Fund
text: WASHINGTON — With both the legislative calendar and the Highway Trust Fund nearly exhausted, a broad coalition of business groups and labor unions will push this week to shake Congress from its stasis and approve federal infrastructure spending before transportation projects begin to dry up in August.

headline: New York’s Mapmaking Scandal
text: In his 2010 campaign for governor, Andrew Cuomo promised to end “partisan gerrymandering,” in which lawmakers draw their own districts. He failed to do that, and instead, as governor, signed onto a set of legislative maps in 2012 that were carefully designed to keep legislators safely in their jobs.

headline: The Long Wait to See a Doctor
text: Americans are already experiencing long waits to get doctor’s appointments, and experts say the delays are bound to get worse when millions of previously uninsured Americans get health coverage under the Affordable Care Act. That is the sobering news from a new survey of wait times conducted by Merritt Hawkins, a physician staffing firm, which polled some 1,400 medical offices in 15 large metropolitan areas across the country.

headline: Germany and the Minimum Wage
text: The federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour is obviously too low. So is the Democrats’ proposed increase to $10.10 an hour by 2016. If the minimum wage had merely kept pace over time with inflation, average wages or productivity growth, it would be between $11 an hour and $18 an hour today.

headline: Expensive Internet and Other Hotel Peeves
text: WE all have had serious complaints about the way airline service has deteriorated in the last 15 years or so, so I was interested in a recent list of complaints about the other most important aspect of business travel: hotels.

headline: Alan J. Dixon, 86, Is Dead; U.S. Senator Who Championed Illinois
text: Alan J. Dixon, a two-term United States senator from Illinois in the 1980s and early ’90s who was known for keen attention to constituents’ needs and an old-fashioned glad-handing style that won him the nickname “Al the Pal,” died on Sunday at his home in Fairview Heights, Ill. He was 86.

headline: Four Horrific Killings
text: In the space of a few weeks, the brutal killings of four teenagers — one Palestinian and three Israelis — have inflamed tensions in Israel and the occupied territories, potentially igniting a conflict that could be even more vicious than the intifadas of 1987 and 2000. It is the responsibility of leaders on both sides to try and calm the volatile emotions that once again threaten both peoples.

headline: For Brazil, Winning Trumps Aesthetics
text: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — Brazil’s national soccer team is the embodiment of the beautiful game, an 11-man samba performance that dazzles fans of any country and leaves its opponents both flummoxed and flat-footed.

headline: Appellate Court’s Ruling on Arizona License Rule
text: A three-judge panel said it could find “no legitimate state interest” to justify treating young immigrants in a federal program differently from other noncitizens whose work permits Arizona had traditionally accepted as proof of authorized presence in the United States.

headline: Court Blocks Arizona Policy of Denying Driver’s Licenses to Some Immigrants
text: PHOENIX — A federal appeals court on Monday blocked Arizona’s policy of denying driver’s licenses to young immigrants who have received work permits and avoided deportation under an Obama administration program.

headline: Fliers Facing Fewer Rewards
text: For airline passengers, rewards programs may not seem so rewarding anymore.

headline: When Slow and Steady Doesn’t Help
text: WHEN I was younger I spent a lot of time following the Grateful Dead and Phish around the United States. I was a backpacker so I stayed at a lot of campgrounds and hostels. I really felt that made me a pretty savvy traveler.

headline: How England, Italy and Germany Are Dominating the World Cup
text: Tables showing which professional soccer leagues are most represented in each round of the World Cup

headline: The Immigration Debate’s Twin Issues
text: As tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors cross into the United States this year, immigration reform is stalled. The issues are related but not the same. Here’s why.

headline: N.B.A. Salary Cap Maximizes Free Agents’ Difficulty
text: In recent days, the basketball-watching world has turned its attention from midlevel exceptions to flight-tracking software. (What, exactly, was that plane belonging to the Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert doing in South Florida over the weekend?) Not that there ever was any doubt, but N.B.A. free agency has officially moved into its familiar terrain of thinly veiled chaos.

headline: Opposition Rally in Nairobi
text: Opposition supporters gathered for a rally in Nairobi.

headline: Blink and It’s Gone: A Farewell Column About Chasing the Ever-Changing New York City
text: I came of age in the prewar apartment canyons of the Upper West Side of Manhattan. As we wended our way back from high school, a buddy and I would stop by the 91st Street soda stand and pick up the tabloids. We read as we walked, gorging on Pete Hamill, Murray Kempton, Jimmy Breslin and Jóse Torres, a boxing champion who became a pretty damn good columnist.

headline: Immigrant Surge Rooted in Law to Curb Child Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — It was one of the final pieces of legislation signed into law by President George W. Bush, a measure that passed without controversy, along with a pension bill and another one calling for national parks to be commemorated on quarters.

headline: Before He Leaves, Michael Powell Shares His Favorite Gotham Columns
text: Michael Powell wrote the Gotham column for a little more than three years, covering wayward bishops, egocentric governors, and varieties of suffering and inspiration.

headline: Snack Food for Hikers
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — This one didn’t play like a Tuesday for me, but it’s a cute idea. Your mileage may vary, of course. Bruce Venzke and Gail Grabowski are back, and today they are hanging out in BARS.

headline: Wall Street Offers Clinton a Thorny Embrace
text: As its relationship with Democrats hits a historic low, Wall Street sees a solution on the horizon: Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Samsung Foresees a Decline in Profit
text: The next big thing is here, as Samsung Electronics likes to say in its ads. But fewer people appear to be buying it.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Brazil, 7-1
text: The scoring began in the 11th minute when Thomas Müller tallied his fifth goal of the Cup after being left unmarked in the box. But it was the brief period from Minute 23 to Minute 29 that devastated Brazil.

headline: Opposition Rallies Its Ranks in Kenya, Peacefully
text: NAIROBI — They started streaming in at dawn on Monday, thousands of people, the crowd slowly building as the sun rose. Men in rubber swamp boots. Men in thin suits. Men in raggedy trousers and ripped T-shirts, men from the slums.

headline: Aid Elusive, Crimea Farms Face Hurdles
text: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea — Sergei V. Tur, a significant landowner, scowled beneath his desert camouflage cap as he watched a hulking combine chew through one of his golden barley fields, reaping part of what he predicts will be the best harvest in Crimea in three years.

headline: Not Over Till Overtime’s Due? Met Labor Strife Bares Secrets
text: The operatic drama and larger-than-life passions usually subside at the Metropolitan Opera when its season ends for the summer, but not this year.

headline: Proposed Precinct Plan in North Carolina
text: The Cleveland County Board of Elections proposes combining five precincts into two and reducing the number of polling places in Shelby, N.C.

headline: Q. and A.: John Delury on Chinese-South Korean Ties
text: The visit of President Xi Jinping of China to Seoul last week underscored how Beijing is intent on warmer ties with South Korea, already  a strong economic partner. During the visit, Mr. Xi and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea agreed on the need to keep North Korea’s nuclear ambitions in check but papered over substantial differences on how to reach that goal. Perhaps more important, the visit reflected tensions among Seoul and Tokyo, the United States’ key allies in the region, as China tries to exploit South Korean wariness of Japan stemming from Japan’s colonial dominance of the Korean peninsula in the early 20th century.

headline: Mistrust in North Carolina Over Plan to Reduce Precincts
text: SHELBY, N.C. — When Alan Langley, a Republican member of the local elections board here, explains a new proposal to consolidate five voting precincts into two, it sounds procedural and well-meaning: He speaks of convenient parking and wheelchair access at the proposed polling places, and of saving more than $10,000 per election.

headline: A Power Struggle Across Continents
text: The World Cup’s final four has two classic matchups, with European powerhouses taking on equally dynamic teams from South America. Germany and Brazil go first, on Tuesday afternoon, followed by the Netherlands and Argentina on Wednesday. Here is a look at both games.

headline: Nets’ Low-Key Introduction Reflects New Coach
text: The Nets elected Monday to introduce Lionel Hollins as the 19th coach in franchise history in their standard news conference room at Barclays Center, underground, adjoining the locker rooms, eschewing the pageantry that accompanied last year’s introduction of Jason Kidd.

headline: Indonesian Candidate Masters a System He Is Said to Disdain
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — For a candidate accused of questioning the value of democracy, Prabowo Subianto appears to be a highly efficient campaigner.

headline: Grieving a Firefighter Who Saved a Son’s Life in May, and Died on Saturday
text: A little boy dangled 15 feet in the air, his arm and head in danger of being crushed by a metal roll-up gate that had risen without warning as he and his friends were playing around it.

headline: Training Document From the New York Fire Department
text: A Fire Department document posted to an internal website, and in all firehouses and EMS stations, gives instructions for precautions to take when dealing with Collyers’ mansion conditions during a fire.

headline: Firefighters Have Name for Deathtrap Homes
text: Just this May, the Fire Department of New York posted training materials on its internal website detailing some of the difficulties encountered while battling blazes in homes brimming with hoarded belongings: blocked entryways, deep-seated fires and debris piled so high that, in smoke conditions, a “firefighter crawling atop can accidentally crawl out a window.”

headline: Emergency Starter and Hot Bats Lift Yankees to Satisfying Victory
text: CLEVELAND — There could have been ways that Monday’s game unfolded better for the Yankees. Maybe their emergency pitcher, making his first career start, could have lasted seven innings instead of six. Or their $85 million catcher, mired in a four-month slump, could have laced four hits instead of just three. Or maybe their lineup could have chased the Cleveland Indians’ starter in the second inning and not the third.

headline: Neymar’s Injury Sidelines Effort to End World Cup Racism
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — After an episode in Peru earlier this year in which Peruvian soccer fans subjected a Brazilian player to racial abuse by imitating the sounds of monkeys, President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil swiftly pledged a “World Cup against racism,” declaring, “Sports should be no place for prejudice.”

headline: A Taxi Alternative, UberX, Offers Lower Fares
text: For years, the smartphone apps storming New York City’s professional driving industries presented an implicit trade-off: For a bit more money, passengers could find a ride more efficiently — and, if they chose, travel on a more opulent set of wheels.

headline: Ukraine Rebels Are Retreating for Last Stand
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions in eastern Ukraine, apparently blowing up bridges, and began building barricades in the two largest cities, Donetsk and Luhansk, in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.

headline: Police Fire on Hummer as Suspect Flees on Staten Island
text: Police officers opened fire on a stolen sport utility vehicle early Monday near the Staten Island side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge during a search for a suspected carjacker, officials said.

headline: Jihadis Tug at Edges of a Staunch American Ally
text: MAAN, Jordan — Hanging from the facade of a shuttered bank on a bustling market street in this sunbaked town were two large, white banners emblazoned with black letters.

headline: How Birth Year Influences Political Views
text: People’s political views are particularly shaped by events they experience between 14 and 24.

headline: U.S. Official Ordered Out of Bahrain After Meeting
text: WASHINGTON — Bahrain on Monday ordered the senior United States official on human rights to cut short his visit and leave the country after he met with the nation’s main Shiite opposition group.

headline: Last Ball Rumbles Down a Village Bowling Alley
text: Tom Shannon recalled the first time he stepped inside the old bowling alley on University Place for a friend’s birthday party in 1994.

headline: Intel, Qualcomm and Others Compete for ‘Internet of Things’ Standard
text: If the stakes are big enough, companies will compete even for something that is supposed to be free to all comers. And over the next few years, very little stands to be bigger than the Internet of Things, or IoT.

headline: Word of the Day | diffuse
text: diffuse •\di-ˈfyüs\• adjective and verb

headline: Art of the Deal: A Broker Who Knows When to Go All In
text: Julie Zelman has made a very nice living playing poker over the past decade, though her biggest wins have not come in piles of chips.

headline: Venezuela: Stolen Matisse Painting Returned
text: Venezuelan authorities on Monday welcomed home a painting by the artist Henri Matisse more than a decade after it had disappeared from a Caracas museum. The painting, “Odalisque in Red Pants,” was recovered in 2012 by F.B.I. agents in Miami when they arrested two people and charged them with trying to sell the long-missing artwork. Officials do not know when it was stolen from the Contemporary Art Museum of Caracas, where it was part of the museum’s collection, because the thieves put up a fake version of the painting in its place — a ruse that was discovered in 2002. Photographs showed that the fake, which experts said was crudely executed, was in place at least as early as 2000. News of the painting’s recovery two years ago caused a stir in Venezuela, and officials on Monday made a show of bringing it home, with a live television broadcast from the Caracas airport. When it was recovered, American officials said the painting was worth $3 million.

headline: India: Shariah Courts Rebuffed
text: India’s Supreme Court ruled Monday that Shariah courts, which are run by the dictates of Islamic law, had no legal status and were not legally binding. In the court’s judgment, fatwas, or orders declared by Muslim clerics, were deemed to have “no legal status” though they were not found to be illegal, and individuals may follow the Shariah rulings if they wish. The court said, however, that a religious leader “has no authority or powers to impose his opinion and enforce his fatwa on anyone,” adding that legally sanctioned fatwas have “no place in independent India under our constitutional scheme.”

headline: A Victory for Same-Sex Unions
text: The marriages of gay men and lesbians who work for the United Nations Secretariat will be recognized by the organization if they have been wed in a jurisdiction where same-sex unions are legal, including New York. Previously, the secretariat, the body of employees who work under the secretary general, deferred to the laws of a staff member’s home country in classifying his or her marital status: Same-sex unions were recognized by the United Nations only if the employee’s home country deemed such marriages to be legal. The change, said the organization’s deputy spokesman, Farhan Haq, reflects Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s support for “greater equality for all staff.” The new rule was announced in an internal staff bulletin, Mr. Haq said Monday. It expands the civil rights of gay and lesbian employees, even as many of the United Nations’ member states, including Uganda, whose foreign minister assumes the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly in September, crack down on their own gay and lesbian citizens.

headline: U.N. Report Calls for Public Sanitation Funding
text: Nearly one billion people worldwide defecate in the open, and such bad sanitation practices can endanger the health of children who live and play nearby, the United Nations said in a report released Monday. The report, which calls for greater effort and funding to redress inadequate sanitation, measures the world’s progress on the so-called Millennium Development Goals intended to improve the health and well-being of the global poor. The report notes some advances: A greater number of children are living past their fifth birthday. As many girls as boys are enrolled in primary school. Extreme poverty has been halved since 1990. But about one in five people in the developing world still lives on less than $1.25 a day; about 25 percent of the world’s children suffer from stunted growth, reflecting the effects of chronic hunger; and nearly half of all pregnant women did not see a doctor during their pregnancy.

headline: New York State Pavilion Receives $5.8 Million for Restoration
text: The New York State Pavilion, a 1964 World’s Fair colossus that rests off an expressway in Queens, will receive nearly $6 million for restoration work under the new city budget.

headline: A Graffiti Titan With New York City Cred Is Remembered
text: The mourners, many of them in middle age, came adorned in sprawling tattoos and wearing crisp Air Jordans. They gathered in Queens on Monday to honor Jason Wulf, a titan of New York’s graffiti movement who was found dead last week next to the third rail in a subway station.

headline: Why Teenagers Today May Grow Up Conservative
text: There was a time not so long ago when the young seemed destined to be liberal forever. Americans in their teens and 20s were to the left of their elders on social issues. They worried more about poverty. They voted strongly Democratic.

headline: This Time, Mets Tilt a One-Run Game in Their Favor
text: Before the first game of every series, the Mets meet for 30 minutes to review their scouting report. The bench coach, Bob Geren, runs the meeting; other coaches often speak, and Manager Terry Collins usually sits to the side and listens quietly.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 7, 2014
text: July 7, 2014

headline: Woman Seen With Child Later Abandoned
text: A video from the New York Police Department shows a woman pushing a child in a stroller through an emergency exit gate. The police said she abandoned the child on the subway platform.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (CNBC) RESTAURANT STARTUP Each week two teams will pitch their concepts to the restaurateurs Tim Love and Joe Bastianich (above, from left) and try to persuade the men to invest in them. The chosen team will be given the keys to a restaurant on Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles, where members will have 36 hours and $7,500 to open a pop-up eatery, complete with a branding campaign and a business plan, devised under the tutelage of the consultant Waylynn Lucas. Then they’ll test their idea on the public. Based on diners’ reactions and the quality of the team’s work, Mr. Bastianich and Mr. Love will decide whether to back it. In this premiere episode, the Kraken Congee team, three line cooks from Seattle who have adapted Asian rice porridge for the American palate, and Ramy’s Falafel Fusion team, a businessman, a chef and a promoter from Portland, Ore., who have conjured up a fava bean falafel, try to realize their culinary dreams.

headline: A Sport Embraces Fashion and Flirting, but Breaking a Sweat Isn’t Required
text: Amid the slick sunbathers and bare-chested volleyball players in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on a recent Sunday afternoon, Gabriel Vaughan was an apparition in white: white Converse sneakers, white T-shirt and shorts, and a white boater hat with navy and red ribbon trim. Three bikini-clad women listened to Bob Marley as Mr. Vaughan pushed croquet wickets into a patch of clover and crab grass by the Picnic House near the park’s West Drive.

headline: Corrections: July 8, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 8, 2014
text: “Before God and his people, I express my sorrow for the sins and grave crimes of clerical sexual abuse committed against you.”

headline: Israel and Hamas Trade Attacks as Tension Rises
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas escalated their military confrontation on Tuesday, with Israel carrying out extensive air attacks in response to heavy rocket fire and authorizing a major call-up of army reserves for an extended campaign against militants in Gaza.

headline: Medical Marijuana Coming to New York
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo with Amanda Houser, 10, on Monday in the ceremonial signing of a bill authorizing medical marijuana in New York. Amanda has Dravet syndrome, which causes seizures that may be reduced by marijuana. The program is expected to begin within 18 months.

headline: Christian Pastor Sentenced to 12 Years in Chinese Prison
text: A court in Henan Province has sentenced a Christian pastor, Zhang Shaojie, to 12 years in prison for fraud and “gathering a crowd to disrupt social order,” charges that one of his lawyers called “untenable” and “without foundation.” The lawyer, Zhang Xinyun (the two men are not related), characterized the entire judicial process as “illegal.”

headline: Student Crossword | America’s First Ladies
text: Test your knowledge of America’s first ladies by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: To Curb Prostitution, Guangdong Tries to Clean Up Massage Industry
text: When is a massage just a massage? The southern Chinese province of Guangdong, which in February saw one of the country’s biggest crackdowns on vice, wants to clarify the difference between legitimate establishments that knead tired muscles and brothels that offer massage services as a front for prostitution.

headline: HSBC Draws Fire After Downgrading Hong Kong Stocks
text: HSBC, the London-based bank with roots in Hong Kong and Shanghai, waded into controversy this week when it downgraded Hong Kong stocks out of concern that a swelling pro-democracy movement could sour relations with the mainland.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | California’s Extreme Drought, Explained
text: The video “California’s Extreme Drought, Explained” provides a brief overview of the drought plaguing the nation’s most populous state.

headline: David Brat’s Hand-of-God Economics
text: Even before David Brat’s out-of-nowhere victory against Eric Cantor last month, there was plenty of skepticism about whether he merited the label of academic economist. Brat, a professor at Randolph-Macon College in Virginia, is certainly not in danger of winning a Nobel Prize: He writes discursive papers devoid of math; he has cited Wikipedia as a source; and he has never been published in a significant journal. But his big idea — that Protestantism is good for the economy — has a surprisingly distinguished history.

headline: Saul Leiter’s Black-and-White World
text: Saul Leiter was famed for his richly hued color photographs. Yet when he first came to Howard Greenberg’s attention, it was his black-and-white street photos that stunned the New York gallery owner, who immediately gave him a one-man show.

headline: 2 Leaders Named to NN Group Posts After Spinoff
text: LONDON – The NN Group, the former European and Japanese insurance and investment management arm of the ING Group, named two new members to its management team on Tuesday after its spinoff from ING last week.

headline: Is Christopher Bailey Worth It?
text: According to The Financial Times, some Burberry shareholders are up in arms about what they see as an outsize pay package for Christopher Bailey, their new chief executive and chief creative officer. Apparently, he’s in line for as much as 10 million pounds, or about $17 million, not including the shares he was granted before his promotion, which could be worth £20 million when they vest. Shock! Horror! Unfairness! And all that.

headline: Commerzbank Shares Fall on News of Settlement Talks
text: FRANKFURT — Shares in Commerzbank, Germany’s second-largest lender, fell about 5 percent on Tuesday after news that it could be the latest European institution to settle with the American authorities over suspicions that it violated sanctions.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Defense Rests Case in Oscar Pistorius Murder Trial
text: LONDON — He has sobbed, retched and wailed. His testimony has been punctuated by cries of grief and met with accusations of mendacity. Before the High Court in Pretoria, the South African capital, Oscar Pistorius has been depicted variously as anguished and remorseful, egotistic, enamored of guns and filled with a rage that propelled him to kill his girlfriend last year.

headline: New York Today: The Vanishing High Line
text: Good morning on this tropical Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: Samsung Forecasts a Profit Decline as Smartphone Sales Ease
text: The next big thing is here, as Samsung Electronics likes to say in its ads. But fewer people appear to be buying it.

headline: 10 Headlines That May or May Not Actually Be From BuzzFeed
text: In this past weekend’s Riff column, Heather Havrilesky wrote about BuzzFeed (and how it reminds her that she’s going to die). In the spirit of BuzzFeed, we present a quiz. Can you guess which of these are actual BuzzFeed headlines?

headline: Morning Views
text: “The brutal killings of four teenagers — one Palestinian and three Israelis — have inflamed tensions in Israel and the occupied territories,” The New York Times editorial board writes, “potentially igniting a conflict that could be even more vicious than the intifadas of 1987 and 2000.” Both Israeli and Palestinian leaders must calm emotions in their respective peoples. “In an atmosphere in which each side dehumanizes the other, it shouldn’t be surprising that some people would act on extremist views,” the board reasons, but “these deaths should cause the two communities to think again about the need for a permanent peace.”

headline: Is Obama’s Foreign Policy Too European?
text: BERLIN — I have long been a critic of the German foreign policy debate — of its freeloading on the American security umbrella, coupled with moral grandstanding whenever the Americans did things their way; of too much analysis of past events and not enough thinking about how to get things right in the future; of its tendency to take words as a substitute for deeds. That’s why I have usually given the Americans the benefit of the doubt: At least they took on problems nobody else was willing to tackle.

headline: You Don’t Have to Feel Very Guilty About Using Your Smartphone While Parenting
text: My 3-year-old son was off from preschool last week, and just between you and me, I played partial hooky from work to take care of him.

headline: Why I Ditched My Co-Working Space
text: Last summer I tried the start-up dream. I moved into a trendy co-working space in Manhattan with a few members of my team. We’d just moved to New York, and we wanted to be in the hub of the tech community. A co-working space seemed like a great place to meet other entrepreneurs and investors and it looked like fun.

headline: Trail of Tumult for Mother Charged With Abandoning Her Baby
text: Frankea Dabbs arrived in California last year with a new baby and a promise to get her life in order. Back home in North Carolina, there were conflicts with family, and run-ins with the police. Drugs. Prostitution.

headline: 1964: U.K. Will Act on Freight Rates
text: LONDON — The British government has decided to take legal action to protect British shipping against United States efforts to readjust transatlantic dual freight rates. The government said it will submit a bill to secure British Jurisdiction against “encroachment by certain foreign requirements in … the carriage of goods or passengers by sea.” “It will also protect British shippers with regard to the production of documents and furnishing of information” for foreign officials. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 9, 1964

headline: How the Everything Boom Might End: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
text: Nearly every major asset market on earth is currently expensive by historical standards. You can read more about this phenomenon — the Everything Boom, or possibly the Everything Bubble — here. But what happens now? What does this simple fact, that globally prices are high and expected returns are low, mean for the future?

headline: Chanel: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: France Decapitated
text: LONDON — The Tour de France bicycle race kicked off in England this year, in Yorkshire to be precise, and ended its third stage on the Mall outside Buckingham Palace. Next pigs will fly.

headline: Morning Agenda: Commerzbank Under U.S. Scrutiny
text: State and federal authorities have begun settlement talks with Commerzbank, Germany’s second-largest lender, over the bank’s dealings with Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The bank, which is suspected of transferring money through its American operations on behalf of companies in Iran and Sudan, could reach a settlement as soon as this summer. A potential deal is also expected to pave the way for a separate settlement with Deutsche Bank.

headline: In Performance: Jan Maxwell of ‘The City of Conversation’
text: This week’s video features the Tony Award-nominated actress Jan Maxwell in a scene from Anthony Giardina’s play “The City of Conversation,” a drama about three decades in the life of Hester Ferris, a Washington socialite with a firm belief in traditional liberal values and a flair for hosting dinner parties at her Georgetown home. In this scene, set in 1987 during the fight over the nomination of Robert Bork to the Supreme Court, she excoriates her conservative daughter-in-law over her support of the Reagan administration’s political agenda. The show, directed by Doug Hughes, is at Lincoln Center Theater’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater through July 26.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: If you call a nonfiction book “well-researched,” that’s good. “Authoritative,” “definitive”? Very good indeed.

headline: A Flashback to Croquet’s Heyday in Prospect Park
text: In 1875, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle called croquet “a healthy and harmless pastime.”

headline: Air France-KLM Lowers Its Earnings Forecast
text: PARIS — Air France-KLM warned Tuesday that weaker-than-expected demand during the peak summer travel season was likely to mute earnings growth this year as a rising number of unsold seats on crucial routes to North America and Asia has forced many large European carriers to lower their fares.

headline: Japanese Foreign Minister Speaks Out Against Chinese Newspaper Graphic
text: A Chinese newspaper’s graphic declaring that “Japan wants a war again” and showing mushroom clouds over Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, drew strong criticism from the Japanese foreign minister on Tuesday, adding to the continuing acrimony between the two countries over historical issues.

headline: U.S. Drug Maker AbbVie Increases Bid for Shire, as Cost of Moving Abroad Rises
text: Updated, 7:28 p.m. | The price of moving overseas appears to be rising.

headline: Itinerary | Botanically-Themed Destinations in Paris (and Beyond)
text: France is abloom during the warmer months, when its legendary garden festivals draw flower-philes to the countryside. And while agricultural import restrictions mean you can’t take clematises, irises or pelargoniums on the plane back to the States, Paris offers no shortage of botanically-themed shopping for the home and garden (and pleasures for the palate). Here, on the heels of a recent trip, the author and designer Charlotte Moss curates a flora-focused list of some of her favorite spots in Paris and the surrounding countryside.

headline: Intersection | Southern Boulevard, Bronx
text: Javier Lopez, 34, says he tends to dress like a “normal 20-year-old kid” in his leisure time. Born and raised in the Bronx, he lives in Manhattan now, but stays connected to hip-hop style.

headline: What’s News in Washington: The Heat Is On
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where the summer heat is officially on and temperatures are expected to approach 100.

headline: Iraqi Lawmakers to Reconvene in Effort to Form Government
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi Parliament on Tuesday set its next meeting for Sunday as it tries again to form a new government after a failed attempt last week.

headline: Paramount’s Push Into China Pays Handsomely
text: In the less than two weeks since its premiere in China, Paramount Pictures’ ‘‘Transformers: Age of Extinction’’ has hurtled to the top of the country’s box-office records, surpassing ‘‘Avatar,’’ according to the Chinese movie website Mtime.

headline: Holder Urges Europeans to Step Up Antiterrorism Tactics
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday implored more European countries to adopt American-style counterterrorism laws and tactics, including undercover stings to prevent potential terrorists from traveling to Syria.

headline: Is There Anything You Did as a Writer Starting Out That You Now Regret?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Anna Holmes and Leslie Jamison discuss mistakes they made when starting out.

headline: Sterling Spars With Wife’s Lawyer at Trial That Will Determine Clippers Sale
text: LOS ANGELES — A feisty, audacious and occasionally charming Donald Sterling took the witness stand Tuesday in a trial that will determine whether he can prevent his estranged wife from selling the Los Angeles Clippers, the basketball team he has owned for more than 30 years.

headline: 1939: French Tackle Birthrate Issue
text: Alarmed by the constant and growing decline of France’s birthrate, the French government decided over the weekend to take legislative action to stop a population process which is now more than fifty years old, and which in another fifty threatens to make France by far the least populated country among the great powers. The French Cabinet discussed the birthrate problem in all its aspects at its meeting Friday. It also discussed various proposals for increasing the birthrate suggested by several official and semi-official bodies, but the decrees embodying some of these proposals will not be promulgated for at least another week, after a report on the subject has been presented by the Minister of Labor. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 9, 1939

headline: Sales of Recreational Marijuana Begin in Washington State
text: SEATTLE — Caden Robinson, a 21-year-old college student, said he might not have stood in line for three hours to buy legal recreational marijuana when the first retail sales began here on Tuesday if his parents had not suggested it.

headline: Stéphane Rolland: Winter 2014 Couture

headline: Paris Couture Week: Giambattista Valli Fall/Winter 2014

headline: Why World Cup Final Is Too Close to Call
text: By one measure, the World Cup seems utterly predictable. The semifinals feature four of the world’s great soccer nations: Argentina, Brazil, Germany and the Netherlands. Each has a rich World Cup history, and each was among the favorites before the tournament. As it continued, the chances of each of the potentially exciting giant killers have been extinguished. There’s no more Costa Rica, Mexico or Chile.

headline: Newer, Bigger, Faster Trains
text: Anyone who has tried to book a trip on the Acela recently along the Boston to Washington, D.C. corridor knows that Amtrak’s fastest trains are extremely crowded and often sold out. Ridership is at an all-time high, even with prices rivaling air fare.

headline: Typhoon Hits Japan’s Okinawa Island
text: A powerful storm brought torrential rain and high winds to the Okinawa island chain in Japan.

headline: A White Stripes Live Album for Record Club Subscribers
text: Just a couple of weeks after his new album, “Lazaretto,” had a brief reign at the top of the Billboard album chart – with sales of its elaborate vinyl version outpacing the CD versions of everything else in the Top 5 – Mr. White is reminding fans why they flocked to his music in the first place. On Monday, he announced a limited-edition, subscription-only vinyl release of “Live Under the Lights of the Rising Sun,” a two-LP set containing two shows by the White Stripes, recorded in Japan in October of 2000.

headline: Obama Asks for $3.7 Billion to Aid Border
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged Congress on Tuesday to quickly provide almost $4 billion to confront a surge of young migrants from Central America crossing the border into Texas, calling it “an urgent humanitarian situation.”

headline: Recent Tanker Hijackings Add to Problems in the South China Sea
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Add another problem to the rising tensions in the South China Sea this year: a mysterious spate of tanker hijackings since late April, as armed bands of men have boarded and commandeered the ships, siphoned their cargos of diesel and gasoline onto barges or other tankers, and fled into the night.

headline: Republicans Pick Cleveland Over Dallas for Convention
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans chose Cleveland on Tuesday for their 2016 national convention, with the hope of appealing to Rust Belt voters who eluded them in the last two presidential elections, and an acknowledgment of the political value of ending the party’s nomination process sooner.

headline: Japan Makes an Asian Pivot
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reinterpreted Japan’s pacifist Constitution, freeing its military for the first time in over 60 years to play a more assertive role in the Asia-Pacific region. The move comes as another shakeup in an increasingly tense part of the world, marked by the growing influence and military might of China, President Obama’s pivot to Asia and the perennial saber-rattling of North Korea.

headline: On Creating a Race Beat
text: Six months ago, Tanzina Vega began to report on a newly created beat about race and ethnicity in America for the National desk. Since then, she has written about the high but rarely discussed rates of infertility among black women, as well as the conflicted feelings of minority gun owners. We asked her to talk with us about her experience so far.

headline: Sex and Consequences
text: Because I engaged in a little gentle straw-manning in my post last week on liberalism and the culture war, describing a tendency without citing many specific examples (angry tweets and MSNBC outbursts are tedious to quote), and because my column on Sunday took a higher-altitude view of the religious liberty debate, I think it’s only fair to grapple with a specific liberal commentary on the Hobby Lobby decision. And this one, from New York Magazine’s Ann Friedman, captures where I think a lot of the Supreme Court majority’s critics are coming from, and raises a number of issues that are worth debating. Here’s an excerpt:

headline: Obama to Pick Defense Aide for Energy Post

headline: Afghan Candidate Stops Short of Forming Government
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After hours of pitched political drama that sent President Obama and other officials scrambling to calm a surge of Afghan factional hostility, the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah walked a perilous line on Tuesday, threatening to declare his own government even while urging his frenzied supporters to give him time to negotiate.

headline: Share Your Travel Misadventures
text: The most memorable moments of a trip are often unplanned. Have you encountered a travel misadventure on a recent trip? We invite you to share your story.

headline: 2 Arrested After Drone Flies Close to a New York Police Helicopter

headline: Weekly Quandary: Children With a Single Focus
text: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread, or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: In Dividing Up Extra Tax Spoils, Risks for New Investors
text: Initial public offerings that generate extra tax spoils are in the spotlight. Two private equity firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Silver Lake, are listing the web-hosting company GoDaddy three years after buying it for $2.25 billion. The use of what’s called an Up-C structure means the company will go public with big potential tax deductions on its books. In GoDaddy’s case, investors and sponsors will both benefit. But other I.P.O.s with Up-Cs have more dubious arrangements.

headline: Class and Monetary Policy
text: I’ve been writing a lot lately about the continuing influence of inflation hysterics despite their awesome wrongness over the past five-plus years. One question that naturally arises is whose interests are served by this unjustified influence.

headline: Back in France, Spill Roughs Up Defending Champion
text: LILLE, France — The return of the Tour de France to its homeland Tuesday brought a noticeable reduction in the enormous crowds that characterized its first three days in England. It may also have brought unwanted trouble for the defending champion, Chris Froome of Britain.

text: Did you attend “Così Fan Tutte” at the Metropolitan Opera or an elementary-school performance of  “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown”? Browse a museum store or watch a movie? The New York State Council on the Arts wants to know.

headline: Chinese Leader’s One-Man Show Complicates Diplomacy
text: BEIJING — As Secretary of State John Kerry and Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew, joined by a large group of American officials, met with senior Chinese leaders here on Wednesday, they faced an American-Chinese relationship riven by a strategic rivalry not seen before, a situation that neither side appears in the mood to improve.

headline: Author Held in Beijing After a Spate of Detentions
text: BEIJING — A prominent Chinese writer and frequent critic of the Communist Party who goes by the pen name Murong Xuecun was detained by police officers in Beijing on Tuesday afternoon, his girlfriend said.

headline: Israel Warns Gaza Targets by Phone and Leaflet
text: JERUSALEM — The call came to the cellphone of his brother’s wife, Salah Kaware said Tuesday. Mr. Kaware lives in Khan Younis, in southeast Gaza, and the caller said that everyone in the house must leave within five minutes, because it was going to be bombed.

headline: The No Longer Reluctant Sperm Donor
text: My friends Tori and Kelly have been trying to conceive for many years now. And of the two, Tori had hoped to carry the child with the help of an anonymous sperm donor. But even after multiple advanced fertility treatments, nothing was working.

headline: Microwaved and Messy, Not Stirred
text: The East Village cocktail scene does not lack invention. A bar crawl of limited mileage will bring you face-to-face with draft cocktails, bottled cocktails, drinks heated up with red-hot pokers or cooled down by liquid nitrogen, high-tech Jell-O shots and alcoholic phosphates.

headline: Bespoke Paper Goods Designed by Big-Time Creative Types (With Small-Town Price Tags)
text: For nearly 40 years, culturally influential people and companies — from MoCA to Marc Jacobs — have enlisted the Los Angeles-based, family-run printing house Paper Chase Press to print art books, lookbooks, posters and other custom objects. Now, Paper Chase is drawing on its extensive roster of clients to create a new product for the public: an ongoing series of customizable stationery collaborations called Paper Cuts that are as affordable as they are stylish.

headline: Holder on Extremists Traveling to Syria
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. urged countries in Europe and elsewhere to do more to keep their citizens from traveling to Syria to train and fight with extremists.

headline: Barclays Names New Head of Mergers and Acquisitions
text: LONDON – The British bank Barclays has named Gary Posternack as its new head of mergers and acquisitions in a series of moves as the bank radically reshapes its investment banking business, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Summer Camp: The Debate
text: My colleague Bruce Feiler and I are arguing a new question on Room for Debate today: To Camp, or Not to Camp? His 9-year-old daughters left last week for what he hopes will be their first summer of sleep-away camp; they’ll be gone for seven weeks. My children are home and largely (although far from totally) unscheduled. Apart from some assorted day camps, they’re spending the summer wandering around the house, complaining that “there’s nothing to do” until they disappear and discover that there actually is. Bruce and I found that our family differences might have their roots in tradition (I never went to camp, he did), but that we also saw summer freedom very differently. How will your kids spend the summer, and why? Go read and, please, weigh in.

headline: Benghazi: The Cost of an Obsession
text: The furious, year-and-a-half-old effort to turn the deadly Benghazi attack into a Watergate-level scandal has so far failed. Naturally that hasn’t stopped Republicans from howling at hearings and turning over seat cushions in search of evidence. “Naturally,” because the Republican base has so far embraced these tactics.

headline: Democrats Push Bill to Reverse Supreme Court Ruling on Contraceptives
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress said Tuesday that they had developed legislation to override the Supreme Court decision on contraceptives. The bill would ensure that women had access to insurance coverage for birth control even if they worked for businesses that had religious objections.

headline: Prosecutors’ Winning Streak on Insider Trading Cases Ends
text: The scene that played out over and over again in Lower Manhattan in recent years — federal prosecutors enter the courtroom with an insider trading case and leave with a conviction — all began in 2007 with a tip about a little-known hedge fund trader, Rengan Rajaratnam.

headline: Shire Can Get Higher Bid From AbbVie
text: Shire can get more from AbbVie. Shire, the London-listed drugmaker, is pondering a fresh, $51 billion unsolicited bid from its American rival. AbbVie claims shareholder support and is offering a hefty premium, but Shire’s board can probably extract one more increase in return for its recommendation.

headline: Jeffrey Mayer of Deutsche Bank to Depart for Cerberus
text: Jeffrey Mayer, a senior executive at Deutsche Bank, plans to leave the firm for a position at the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, according to an internal memorandum on Tuesday.

headline: Opening the Vault on YouTube: 13,000 More Performance Clips
text: It’s something close to a music collector’s idea of heaven. Music Vault, a company that was started in April as a division of Wolfgang’s Vault, an online memorabilia shop, opened its expansive YouTube page on Tuesday. The site offers some 13,000 performance clips, which the company estimates to be roughly 2,000 hours of music.

headline: As New York City Expands Pre-K, Private Programs Fear Teacher Drain
text: When Michelle Arvelo returned to her prekindergarten classroom on June 30 after a weeklong vacation in the Dominican Republic, 18 exhilarated 4-year-olds sprinted to the door to greet her, wrapping their arms around her thin frame and inquiring about her tan, her haircut and whether her plane had a co-pilot in the cockpit.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week Two | A ‘Native Generation Z-er’ on ‘Girl Meets World’

headline: Commerzbank Shares Sink on News of U.S. Inquiry
text: FRANKFURT — Investors reacted with dismay Tuesday to news that Commerzbank, Germany’s second-largest lender, could be the latest European financial institution to settle with the United States authorities over suspicions that it violated sanctions on trade with Iran and other countries.

headline: Friendship Underscored With Songs and Winks
text: I know it’s a stretch to imagine a spiritual amalgam of Lena Dunham and the young Joan Baez, but Lindsay Mendez personifies that fusion of witty skepticism and earnest nobility in the show “#Klendez at 54 Below,” which opened on Monday evening. Klendez is the collaborative nickname of Ms. Mendez, 31, and her stage partner, Derek Klena, 22, who teamed up in the well-regarded 2012 musical “Dogfight,” adapted from the Nancy Savocca film starring River Phoenix.

headline: Dead Girls as Objects, or the ‘Ick’ in Lovesick
text: William T. Vollmann is, as often as not, more interesting to read about than to read. His hobbies have included hookers, drugs, large-caliber pistols and tramping through war zones. He’s written a seven-volume treatise on violence. Yet he’s never been a Hunter S. Thompson manqué. There’s no gonzo coil in his DNA.

headline: Yelp Joins Critics of European Union Antitrust Settlement With Google
text: BRUSSELS — Yelp, the online service increasingly popular on both sides of the Atlantic, has joined the critics formally opposing the European Union’s proposed antitrust settlement with Google.

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor Limits When He’ll Target Marijuana
text: After months of resistance from the New York Police Department, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office announced on Tuesday that it would immediately carry out its plan to stop prosecuting most low-level marijuana cases.

headline: At Senate Hearing, Wall Street Executives Share Concerns About the Market
text: Wall Street has no shortage of ideas on how to improve the stock market. The question is whether regulators think those ideas are worth heeding.
