headline: Your Eyes Are Happier Than Your Stomach
text: Not long ago at a restaurant that regularly tweets photos of dishes as lush as one of Monet’s lily ponds, I found myself poking cautiously at perfect circles of glossy black sauce, discs of potato purée that looked like white roses and cylinders of gnocchi so tiny they seemed to have been pushed out of a drinking straw. Tiny, delicate flowers and tender sprigs of leaves gently rested here and there as if a woodland nymph had casually tossed them from a basket before running off to play hide-and-seek with a den of baby field mice. The dish was definitely ready for its close-up. It was also, by and large, very cold — no surprise given how long it must have taken to squeeze and tweeze everything into position.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Judge Dismisses Insane Clown Posse’s Lawsuit Against F.B.I.
text: The rap duo Insane Clown Posse and the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan said on Tuesday that they had appealed a judge’s order dismissing their case against the federal government for characterizing its fans — known as Juggalos — as gang members.

headline: As Chanel Proves, It’s Chic to Match Your Bag to Your Dress
text: The fashion set was eager to see what Karl Lagerfeld would come up with after last season’s suburban supermarket extravaganza of a runway. His fall/winter 2014 couture presentation held today didn’t compete with that infamous show, but instead fell on the other end of the eye-candy spectrum, offering a look that was restrained yet undeniably chic. The collection’s pared-back sensibility was inspired by a now-defunct 1930s Le Corbusier apartment on the Champs Élysées. Like that apartment’s mash-up of design motifs — a gold baroque mirror that sat atop a modern outdoor fireplace, for example — Lagerfeld’s designs married the old and new. Case in point: this modern-silhouetted maxi dress with ornate gold embroidery. Paired with a coordinating messenger bag, it made for a standout look that lent fresh new meaning to the term “matchy-matchy.”

headline: Hirst Work Gets a Fig Leaf
text: The naked lady stays.

headline: East Providence Works to Develop Its Waterfront
text: EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Like the rest of Rhode Island, this city of 49,000 people has experienced its share of ups and downs in the last decade, including a budget deficit of $7.3 million in 2011, which prompted the state to step in to temporarily manage its finances.

headline: Obie Walli
text: Mr. Walli, 36, is a founder and the chief executive of Coldwell Banker Commercial Alliance, one of the largest of Coldwell Banker Commercial’s 200 franchises. CBC Alliance, which is based in New York, is backed by the hedge fund Waterfall Asset Management.

headline: Jake Hoffman (Yes, He’s the Son of Dustin) Makes His Debut as a Director
text: If Jake Hoffman looks familiar, it’s not just because of his striking resemblance to a certain icon of the silver screen with whom he shares a surname. The 33-year-old — who, yes, happens to be the son of Dustin Hoffman — has been acting since the age of 7, when he appeared in his father’s classic film “Rain Man” (he was an extra eating pancakes in a diner). Since then, he has been cast in “I Heart Huckabees,” “Arrested Development” and “The Wolf of Wall Street” (in which he had a small but memorable role as the shoe designer Steve Madden) and he even played his own father’s grandson in HBO’s ill-fated series “Luck.” Since graduating from NYU’s film school in 2003, Hoffman has tried his hand at writing and directing, and completed a trio of short films. Now, with the release of his debut full-length feature, “Asthma” — which he wrote, produced and directed, and which premiered today at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival in the Czech Republic — Hoffman is staking out a film career on his own terms.

headline: Iranian Reporter Faces 2 Years in Prison and 50 Lashes
text: Marzieh Rasouli, an Iranian journalist who writes mainly about literature for reformist newspapers and her popular blog, Three Days Ago, was taken into custody on Tuesday at Evin Prison in Tehran to begin serving a two-year sentence for taking part in street protests in 2009 and publishing what the authorities called antistate propaganda. The verdict, which she learned about in a phone call on Monday, also calls for her to receive 50 lashes.

headline: Bradley Cooper’s Broadway ‘Elephant Man’ Is Delayed
text: The revival of Bernard Pomerance’s “Elephant Man,” with Bradley Cooper in the title role, originally scheduled to begin previews in October, has been delayed a month because of a scheduling conflict, a spokesman for the producers said.

headline: Love Thy Homeless Neighbor
text: On June 30, hundreds of Elmhurst, Queens, residents gathered to protest the sudden transformation of a neighborhood hotel, the Pan American, into an emergency homeless shelter. Families rallied outside a meeting between shelter operators and the city, and they brought their children, who flashed signs in Chinese and in English — “No Homeless Shelter in Elmhurst” and “2, 4, 6, 8, who do we NOT appreciate? Hobos hobos hobos!”

headline: Wheelies: The Next-Generation Toyobaru Edition

headline: Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, and Brazil’s Day Goes Dark
text: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — The fireworks began at dawn. All around this city, loud pops and bangs rang out as men and women and children, so many dressed in yellow, set off flares and beeped car horns. It was supposed to be a magical day. The Brazilian national soccer team, playing at home, was one game away from a World Cup final.

headline: An Odd Couple Returns, Still Bound by a Border
text: When “The Bridge” won a prestigious Peabody Award this year for its first season, the citation made it clear that the FX show’s quality as a crime drama wasn’t the only or even the most important reason. First came, “For raising awareness of border issues,” including the so-called Lost Girls of Juárez, followed by “while creating a compelling murder mystery.”

headline: Younger Rajaratnam Finally Out of His Brother’s Shadow
text: During their heady years as hedge fund managers on Wall Street, one quality divided the Rajaratnam brothers: Raj, the elder brother, was always more successful and better connected than his younger sibling Rengan.

headline: It Takes a Village (and a Composer and a Writer)
text: As Hillary Rodham Clinton contemplates another run for the presidency in 2016, she has written a book (“Hard Choices”), delivered upbeat paid speeches to trade groups (“Leadership is a team sport”) and pitched in at her family’s foundation. Now she can add another line to her résumé: musical theater muse.

headline: Photojournalists Push Project in Spain
text: A group of accomplished documentary photographers is launching a tablet magazine for immersive photo stories and multimedia.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Cloudlike Confections at Couture
text: Couture looks are by definition designed to make a grand entrance. But this week, a handful of houses showed frothy, lavishly tiered ball gowns that proved especially eye-catching in the mix. The first of these cloudlike confections popped up last night during the Giambattista Valli finale, which consisted of a small series of ombré gowns (and evening skirts, which were paired simply with poplin shirts). Then this morning at Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld interrupted his parade of white dresses with a soft, billowing light-blue dress complete with equally full feather sleeves. And finally, at this evening’s Armani Privé show, one of the many red dress options from the designer included a voluminous strapless number topped with an equally dramatic veil.

headline: An Allegory Steeped in Enigmas
text: The solitude of a writer, who has retreated to a seaside villa with his dog and a vaguely defined but pressing project, is disrupted one rainy night by the arrival of unwelcome guests. A man and a woman, on the run from something (the police? a criminal gang?), burst in and demand shelter. Deaf to the writer’s protests, the man leaves the woman — he says she’s his sister — in the other man’s care, promising to come back soon.

headline: Replica
text: Scenes from the band’s show at Acheron in Brooklyn.

headline: So Much Worth Fighting for, Both on the Stage and Off It
text: Dharma Mooney, singer for the Oakland, Calif., hardcore band Replica, started her set at Acheron in Brooklyn on Monday night on the floor, up against the waist-level stage with her back to the audience, looking down as if she were fixing some wiring.

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Netherlands in Shootout, Advancing to Final
text: Argentina beat the Netherlands on penalties, 4-2, after 120 scoreless minutes, and will play Germany in Sunday’s final with the World Cup at stake.

headline: Ryder Ripps: An Artist of the Internet
text: Computer skills do not usually correlate with a strong fashion sense. So when Nicola Formichetti, Lady Gaga’s former stylist and the current artistic director for Diesel, met a whiz kid named Ryder Ripps four years ago, he expected a geek.

headline: Publishing ‘Mein Kampf’ in Germany
text: To the Editor:

headline: School Cafeteria Fight: What’s for Lunch?
Blueprints for Taming the Climate Crisis
text: Here’s what your future will look like if we are to have a shot at preventing devastating climate change.

headline: Germany’s Five First-Half Goals Against Brazil
text: Germany scored five goals in the first half against Brazil.

headline: Cuomo’s Goal on AIDS
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Piece of Pioneer Florida
text: To the Editor:

headline: Honda Expands Takata Air Bag Inflator Recall
text: Honda is expanding its two-million-vehicle air bag recall by as many as one million more vehicles in California, the automaker said Tuesday. Last month, Honda recalled vehicles in eight other states.

headline: World Cup: Germany vs. Brazil
text: Brazil, without its two best players against Germany, was considered a shoe-in for the final, but Germany’s midfield may halt those plans.

headline: Another Digital Move
text: Newsroom management has been focused on strengthening The Times’s digital report. Resources have been added. New positions have been created. Meeting schedules have changed. Even the nature of the meetings has changed. This spring, an internal committee studying innovation urged the newsroom to make digital planning a far greater part of its thinking.

headline: If Tuberculosis Spreads ...
text: ATLANTA — DRUG-RESISTANT tuberculosis is on the rise. The World Health Organization reports around 500,000 new drug-resistant cases each year. Fewer than half of patients with extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis will be cured, even with the best medical care. The disease in all its forms is second only to AIDS as an infectious killer worldwide.

headline: In Deal to Cut Corporate Taxes, Shareholders Pay the Price
text: Medtronic is pursuing a deal to move abroad and save taxes. But few have noticed that the company’s shareholders will be the ones left with a big tax bill as a result.

headline: Textbooks or Not, You Never Outgrow Your Backpack
text: Backpacks, trending over the last few seasons with grown-up styles in luxe leather (think: the Row), are taking a kitschy turn. Give some credit to Jeremy Scott, who, in his Moschino debut for fall, showed bags printed with SpongeBob and McDonald’s golden arches. If the success of his Moschino French fries phone case is any indication, the bags, available for pre-order now, will be a hot commodity. And as the recent men’s-wear shows in Europe revealed, statement-making backpacks are for big kids, too. The young woman (in the slide show) carried a bag from Nasir Mazhar, a London designer known for his logo-heavy brand of club-kid streetwear. Multiple attendees were spotted with Chanel’s graffiti-printed number . Any of the bags here can be a playful accessory for travel or a day at the beach now, or serve as that all-important conversation starter come back-to-school season.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Does Evolution Explain Religious Beliefs?
text: This is the eighth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Michael Ruse, a professor of philosophy at Florida State University and the author of the forthcoming book “Atheism: What Everyone Needs to Know.”

headline: Concord Music Buys Catalog of Vee-Jay Records
text: Concord Music Group, an independent music empire that caters to adult listeners, has acquired the catalog of Vee-Jay Records, a storied blues and soul label of the 1950s and ‘60s that put out records by the Staple Singers, Jimmy Reed, John Lee Hooker and Jerry Butler.

headline: Britain Confronts Not-in-My-Backyard Attitude
text: WESTCOTT, England — When Taylor Wimpey, one of the largest residential construction companies in Britain, proposed building 34 homes in an empty field in Westcott, 30 miles southwest of London, it was doing just what Britain’s leaders were calling for: attempting to alleviate a severe housing shortage, which politicians consider a key factor in the country’s soaring real estate costs.

headline: After Arrest of Accused Hacker, Russia Accuses U.S. of Kidnapping
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On the web, he was known by his hacker handle, “Track2,” a nod to his skill in stealing so-called track data from hundreds of thousands of credit cards and selling it for millions of dollars in the digital underground.

headline: Itinerant Statue of Ex-Mayor Finds a Home at Foley Square
text: Even before Mayor Abraham de Peyster’s heroic 7-foot-tall seated bronze effigy was to be installed in Battery Park in 1895, he was made to feel unwelcome.

headline: Umaru Dikko, Ex-Nigerian Official Who Was Almost Kidnapped, Dies
text: In July 1984, Umaru Dikko, a former Nigerian government official living in exile after a military coup, was kidnapped outside his London estate, packed in a shipping crate and driven to Stansted Airport, to be flown back to Lagos, where he stood accused of embezzlement and other crimes.

headline: Purity Vodka Banks on Some Comic Timing
text: A SMALL brand of Swedish vodka seeking to become better known is turning to an American comedian with a big following for an online video series that will use humor to get noticed and shared.

headline: How to Stop the Surge of Migrant Children
text: What can be done to stem the surge of children illegally crossing into the U.S.? And how does this crisis fit into the larger debate for immigration reform?

headline: Senator Sees Cuban Role in Corruption Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — With a public corruption investigation hanging over him, Senator Robert Menendez suggested Tuesday that Cuban spies had planted the seeds of that inquiry as a way to discredit him and mute his strident opposition to the government in Havana.

headline: Invaluable and Infuriating All in One
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The second period of extra time brought a moment of odd congeniality in Saturday’s taut World Cup quarterfinal between the Netherlands and Costa Rica.

headline: Pharmacist Is Accused of Stealing Oxycodone
text: The former head pharmacist at a major Manhattan hospital was charged on Tuesday with stealing about 200,000 oxycodone pills — with a street value of $5.6 million — by requisitioning them from his own pharmacy for phantom research projects, New York City’s special narcotics prosecutor said.

headline: Profits Vanish in Venezuela After Currency Devaluation
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Brink’s, the armored car company, could see about $400 million in revenue disappear this year from its operations in this country. Procter & Gamble announced a write-down of $275 million on its Venezuela business. American Airlines and Delta Air Lines are slashing their Venezuela flights.

headline: Ex-Governor, Suing Over Book, Is Back in Minnesota’s Spotlight
text: ST. PAUL — Jesse Ventura, the blunt-talking former governor with the outsize reputation, has always been hard to define. The same man who upended Minnesota’s political establishment more than a decade ago with a third-party candidacy was once better known as a professional wrestler who wore a feather boa and went by the nickname “The Body.” He has been an author, a member of a special unit of the Navy and a television host.

headline: House Committee Takes Step Toward Renewing Highway Trust Fund
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ways and Means Committee released a bipartisan plan on Tuesday that would provide federal financing for transportation projects through May 15, 2015, and would be the first step in replenishing the Highway Trust Fund, which will run out of money next month unless Congress acts.

headline: U.S. Adjusts Court Flow to Meet Rise in Migrants
text: As part of the administration’s efforts to deter the current surge of illegal Central American migrants, the nation’s immigration courts will make a major shift in priorities to place unaccompanied minors and families with children first in line to go before immigration judges, Justice Department officials said Tuesday.

headline: For Those in the Digital Dark, Enlightenment Is Borrowed From the Library
text: Joey Cabrera stands for part of most evenings on the doorstep of the Clason’s Point Library, near 172nd Street and Morrison Avenue in the Bronx.

headline: Game That Shocked the World Leads to Joyous Disbelief in Germany
text: BERLIN — Fireworks boomed across the city, and fans in the German capital took up the refrain chanted by the German supporters in Estádio Mineirão in Belo Horizonte, Brazil: “What a day! So beautifully wonderful is today!” Their national team had stunned the world, including Germany itself, with a 7-1 trouncing of Brazil to reach its eighth World Cup final.

headline: Hobby Lobby’s Disturbing Sequel
text: The Supreme Court violated principles of religious liberty and women’s rights in last week’s ruling in the Hobby Lobby case, which allowed owners of closely held, for-profit corporations (most companies in America) to impose their religious beliefs on workers by refusing to provide contraception coverage for employees with no co-pay, as required by the Affordable Care Act. But for the court’s male justices, it didn’t seem to go far enough.

headline: In Arizona, Dreamers Can Drive
text: For a change, Arizonans are getting some good news on immigration. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the state cannot deny driver’s licenses to young unauthorized immigrants whom the federal government has given protection from deportation and permission to work.

headline: Six Vials of Smallpox Discovered in Laboratory Near Washington
text: Scientists said Tuesday that six glass vials found in a storeroom in a government laboratory outside Washington contained the smallpox virus. It was the second incident in a month that revealed government mishandling of potentially deadly infectious agents.

headline: Citigroup Is Said to Be Close to Settling Inquiry Into Mortgage Securities
text: Citigroup and the Justice Department are nearing a deal that could cost the bank roughly $7 billion to settle a civil investigation into the sale of mortgage investments, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Brazilian Fans React to Loss
text: Brazilians watched as their national soccer team lost to Germany, 7-1, in a World Cup semifinal. Many stopped watching after the first half.

headline: Lessons of a For-Profit College Collapse
text: For-profit colleges are lobbying hard to weaken rules proposed by the Obama administration that would deny federal aid to career training programs that burden students with crippling debt and worthless credentials. But a recent spate of state and federal investigations into potentially predatory behavior by the for-profit sector — combined with the collapse of Corinthian Colleges, one of the country’s largest operators of for-profit colleges and trade schools — makes clear that the rules need to be strengthened and that federal oversight generally needs to be broadened.

headline: Nation in Despair
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Daniel Pereira went to work on Tuesday because he could not bear to stay home and watch.

headline: Using M.C.s and M.D.s to Promote Healthy Eating for Youths
text: Adrian Harris, known as Easy A.D. to his fans, has rapped about street life in the South Bronx as a member of the Cold Crush Brothers, a group that is among the pioneers of hip-hop.

headline: Faith Groups Seek Exclusion From Bias Rule
text: WASHINGTON — After a setback in the Supreme Court in the Hobby Lobby case, President Obama is facing mounting pressure from religious groups demanding to be excluded from his long-promised executive order that would bar discrimination against gay men and lesbians by companies that do government work.

headline: The New Yorker Alters Its Online Strategy
text: The New Yorker is overhauling its website and making all the articles it has published since 2007 available free for three months before introducing a paywall for online subscribers.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 8, 2014
text: July 8, 2014

headline: ‘Cutting the Grass’ of Hamas’s Militancy
text: How Israel’s latest airstrikes on Gaza are seen as part of a broader tactic known as “cutting the grass,” or using military incursions to manage conflict.

headline: Queens Woman, 22, Is Arrested in Killing of Infant Son
text: Detectives arrested a 22-year-old Queens woman Tuesday on charges that she intentionally suffocated her 11-month-old baby boy because, the police said, she no longer wanted him.

headline: Stunned Brazilians Try to Move On After Their Exalted Team Falls
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — When Brazil’s national soccer team lost to Germany on Tuesday in a 7-1 rout, it lost something much larger than a game.

headline: The Crumbs Cupcake Boom and Bust
text: Crumbs Bake Shop closed its doors for good on Monday and prepared to file for bankruptcy. A look at how the company followed the cupcake craze and its decline.

headline: Big Holder Gives Up Entire Stake in American Apparel
text: Another one of American Apparel’s major shareholders has sold millions of shares of the company’s stock, even as the retailer continued to battle with one of its longtime lenders.

headline: More Officers at New York Public Housing Amid a Rise in Shootings
text: The Police Department is adding hundreds of officers to units that patrol New York City’s projects to address an increase in shootings at public housing developments, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Tuesday.

headline: For Crumbs, Growth May Have Come Too Fast
text: Word went out swiftly through Midtown Manhattan skyscrapers, downtown coffee shops and clusters of snack-craving children heading home from day camp.

headline: NATO Chief Expresses Support for Ukraine
text: The NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, spoke about the Ukraine crisis after meeting with President Obama.

headline: With Talks Uncertain, Ukrainian Rebels Cling to Hope in Strongholds
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — They are blocking roads and erecting barricades. They are riding around town in columns of cars. They are lounging at bus stops and have taken up residence in university dormitories.

headline: In Effort to Shift Abandoned NASA Craft, a Hiccup (or Burp)
text: A NASA spacecraft launched during the presidency of Jimmy Carter fired its thrusters on Tuesday to change course for the first time since the presidency of Ronald Reagan.

headline: América Móvil to Shed Assets, Loosening Grip
text: América Móvil, the Latin American telecom giant, said Tuesday that it would sell off parts of its Mexican unit, an unexpected capitulation by its controlling shareholder, Carlos Slim Helú, to strong new antimonopoly rules.

headline: Testimony in Boston Bomb Trial Focuses on Backpack
text: BOSTON — An F.B.I. agent told a federal court here on Tuesday that Azamat Tazhayakov, a college friend of the surviving Boston bombing suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, agreed that a backpack found in Mr. Tsarnaev’s dorm room in the days after the bombing should be thrown away.

headline: Silicon Valley Sharknado
text: WASHINGTON — Mostly, this July, I’m worrying about the jumping sharks jumping the shark.

headline: Departure of Official Is Sought by Teachers
text: The long partnership between Democrats and teachers’ unions has frayed in recent years as the Obama administration has pursued policies that many teachers oppose, including performance ratings that link student test scores to evaluations and decisions about promotion or firing.

headline: Study Finds Racial Disparity in Criminal Prosecutions
text: Black and Hispanic defendants are more likely to be held in jail before trial and more likely to be offered plea bargains that include a prison sentence than whites and Asians charged with the same crimes, according to a two-year study of prosecutions handled by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.

headline: Iran Sends 3 Attack Planes to Iraqi Government
text: WASHINGTON — Deepening its involvement in the crisis in Iraq, Iran has sent three Russian-made attack planes to the Maliki government that could be deployed against the Sunni militants who have wreaked havoc on Iraqi military forces, American and Iraqi officials said Tuesday.

headline: Where Anything Can Happen and Usually Does
text: You know that part, right before the show starts, when they tell you where the emergency exits are? Usually, it’s not the most ear-catching information. But should you find yourself in a crowded theater that’s so thickly clouded with pink-lit stage fog that no exit signs are visible, and they skip the part about where to find them, you might feel the tiniest bit alarmed.

headline: Like the Oscars
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — The first time we met Bruce Haight, he had ONE thing on his mind. The second time we met up with him, he asked us to marry him. He’s been around a few times since then and one thing I like about his puzzles is the sense of optimism and good cheer.

headline: Spying Case Left Obama in Dark, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany last Thursday, he had a busy agenda: to consult with a close ally and to mobilize wavering Europeans to put more pressure on Russia to end its covert incursions in Ukraine.

headline: Anne Hollander, Scholar Who Linked Art and Style, Dies at 83
text: Anne Hollander, a historian who helped elevate the study of art and dress by revealing the often striking relationships between the two, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Swiss Banks’ Tradition of Secrecy Clashes With Quests Abroad for Disclosure
text: ZURICH — For a while, it seemed, the tide had turned against the tradition of secrecy in Zurich, the pristine Alpine city that is a hub of global banking.

headline: Tejada Fights His Way Back Into Mets’ Good Graces
text: Ruben Tejada followed the curveball as it dipped, kept his swing short and quick and punched a low line drive into center field. And with that, the Mets walked off victors against the Atlanta Braves on Monday night. As his teammates chased him into the outfield, waving white towels, Tejada pointed toward the dugout, tossed his helmet, and turned to face the mob.

headline: North Korea Fires 2 More Ballistic Missiles
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea test-fired two Scud-type missiles on Wednesday, demonstrating its ballistic missile abilities even as it was taking modest steps to reach out to Japan and South Korea.

headline: Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, Jewish Pioneer, Dies at 89
text: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, who was considered the spiritual father of the Jewish Renewal movement — an influential camp of religious pioneers who reintroduced to synagogue services ancient Judaic traditions of mysticism and meditation, gender equality and ecstatic prayer — died on Thursday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 89.

headline: No Word on Anthony as Knicks Get to Work
text: LAS VEGAS — Phil Jackson needed about 10 seconds Tuesday afternoon to traverse a small patch of real estate that stretched from a gymnasium door to an idling sport utility vehicle. He greeted several members of the news media who were awaiting the end of a summer league practice at a high school before he offered some unsolicited advice.

headline: The First Cannabis Store in Seattle
text: The first stores legally selling recreational marijuana in Washington State opened on Tuesday. Cannabis City was the first in Seattle.

headline: Religious Groups’ Letter to Obama
text: President Obama is planning to sign an executive order barring discrimination against gay men and lesbians by companies that do government work, but major faith organizations asked for exemptions for groups whose religious beliefs oppose homosexuality.

headline: More Charges to Come Against Libyan Over Benghazi
text: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it intended to file additional charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, the man being held in the 2012 attacks that killed the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and three others. At a hearing in Washington, the government said several factors would determine when it would file the charges, but it did not say what those factors were. Judge Christopher R. Cooper of United States District Court said the case would proceed slowly because of its complexity. He scheduled a status hearing for Sept. 9. A week ago, a magistrate judge ruled that Mr. Abu Khattala should remain in government custody and without bond.

headline: Afghanistan: Taliban Strike in Deadly Bombing
text: In one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in recent months, 10 Afghan civilians, two Afghan police officers and four Czech soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber riding a bicycle attacked a village north of Kabul. The attack occurred Tuesday morning, as the soldiers were assessing the security situation in the village of Qalander Khel of Bagram district in Parwan Province. Such attacks have grown increasingly rare as international forces have withdrawn, or stayed within their bases.

headline: At a New Michigan Club, a Touch of Wimbledon at Members’ Feet
text: PONTIAC, Mich. — Eliza Brown looked out at the clean expanse of lawn, precisely dissected into tennis courts by fresh chalk lines, and shrugged.

headline: Fallen Firefighter Is Mourned
text: Firefighters on Tuesday attended the Staten Island wake of Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, 40, who died in a Brooklyn fire Saturday.

headline: Report Says Debt Settlement Companies May Leave Clients Worse Off
text: Using a settlement company to help you dig out from underneath burdensome debt may sound appealing, but it may leave you worse off than when you started, according to new research.

headline: Yankees Ace Tanaka Has a Rare Off Day, and the Score Reflects It
text: CLEVELAND — At his best, Masahiro Tanaka has been dominant. His good starts have been superlative, and even his mediocre outings — rare as they have been — are often better than what the Yankees have received from the other members of their tattered rotation.

headline: NATO Chief Warns of Duplicity by Putin on Ukraine
text: WASHINGTON — The secretary general of the NATO alliance warned on Tuesday that Russia was playing a “double game” in Ukraine, issuing conciliatory public statements while massing its forces along the border and smuggling arms and equipment to separatists inside eastern Ukraine.

headline: European Effort for Computer-Simulated Brain Draws Fire
text: The Human Brain Project is Europe’s flagship contribution to neuroscience. Established last year and funded by the European Commission, the project was meant to rally scientists and computer engineers around developing better tools to study how the brain works.

headline: DeGrom Overpowers the Braves
text: After a road start a few weeks ago, Jacob deGrom was back at the team hotel, flipping through TV channels, when something caught his eye. It was a slow-motion replay of him throwing a changeup. He noticed his front side fly open and his arm drag, the same way it had last season, when he was struggling in the minors.

headline: European Companies See Opportunity in the ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
text: LONDON — Days after Europe’s highest court said people could ask search engines to remove some links about themselves, Andy Donaldson started to receive phone calls.

headline: Preet Bharara’s Key Insider Trading Cases
text: The United States attorney in Manhattan oversaw a sweeping crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry, but a federal appeals court upended the campaign.

headline: How Much Do Our Genes Influence Our Political Beliefs?
text: It’s been a key question of American politics since at least 1968: Why do so many poor, working-class and lower-middle-class whites — many of them dependent for survival on government programs — vote for Republicans?

headline: A Recent History of Chanel’s Couture Show Sets
text: Chanel is known for building over-the-top stage sets whose sense of drama rivals, and in some cases eclipses, the clothes. At the house’s fall/winter 2014 couture presentation yesterday at the Grand Palais, however, the setting was more modest, if no less elegant, than expected. Karl Lagerfeld showed his standout collection in a relaxed setting inspired by a 1930s Le Corbusier apartment. Minimalist, intimate-feeling rooms at either end of the space were each adorned with a gold oval baroque mirror sporting the trademark interlocking-C logo, placed over a digital fireplace.

headline: Probing Brain’s Depth, Trying to Aid Memory
text: PHILADELPHIA — The man in the hospital bed was playing video games on a laptop, absorbed and relaxed despite the bustle of scientists on all sides and the electrodes threaded through his skull and deep into his brain.

headline: Jay Z to Headline Global Citizen Festival in Central Park
text: The Global Citizen Festival will again descend on the Great Lawn in Central Park, on Sept. 27, aiming to raise awareness and inspire action on the issue of extreme poverty worldwide. This year’s lineup will feature Jay Z, Carrie Underwood, No Doubt, Fun, Tiësto and the Roots.

headline: This Is Our Youth
text: America’s young people, as a group, are becoming more out of shape with every passing year, regardless of their family’s economic situation, a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports. The finding raises troubling questions about the future health and longevity of our children and suggests that parents and other authority figures need to find better ways to get our youth moving.

headline: Word of the Day | fallow
text: fallow •\ˈfa-(ˌ)lo\• adjective

headline: Comptroller Aims to Curb Personal-Injury Claims Against New York City
text: New York City two years ago more than doubled its $1.45 million budget for pruning trees, adding $2 million after a spate of injuries and deaths caused by falling tree limbs in parks and along city streets.

headline: Seeking a Lift at the Site of a Career Peak
text: Yani Tseng hopes a return to the Royal Birkdale Golf Club this week for the Women’s British Open will be just what she needs to rekindle some fire in her game.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (FYI) ROWHOUSE SHOWDOWN The Biography channel, now rebranded as FYI, continues to unfurl new programming throughout the month. In this home makeover show, Carter Oosterhouse, above, oversees three design teams as they each renovate a dilapidated home in a distressed neighborhood in Cincinnati while living together in the house in an effort to raise the area’s property values. Each week the teams will transform a different room on limited time and money, with the designer Kathy Kuo and the Cincinnati-based house flipper Jim Bronzie judging the results. The team that most increases the value of its home will receive $50,000 and a feature on the Dwell magazine website, whose editor in chief, Amanda Dameron, will judge the finale. In “Tiny House Nation,” at 10, John Weisbarth and Zack Giffin tour ingenious small spaces — among them, a micro-apartment in New York City, a transformed caboose car in Montana and a mini-mobile home for taking road trips — while helping families construct their dream dwellings in no more than 300 square feet.

headline: Corrections: July 9, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 9, 2014
text: “I think that it was the worst day of my life.”

headline: Brazilians Confront Defeat in World Cup
text: Brazilian fans grieved in the streets after their team’s historic loss to Germany on Tuesday.

headline: Populist Hopeful Says He’s Likely Winner in Indonesia, Defeating Ex-General
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Joko Widodo, the populist governor of Jakarta who burst onto Indonesia’s national political scene less than two years ago, said Wednesday that he appeared to have won the country’s presidential election, with results from several unofficial tallies putting him ahead of his opponent, a former army general. But the ex-general, Prabowo Subianto, said it was too early to declare a winner.

headline: Student Crossword | Bodies of Water
text: Test your knowledge of bodies of water by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: K.K.R. Takes Majority Stake in Scottish Oil Rig Equipment Supplier
text: LONDON – The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has taken a majority stake in the privately held OEG Offshore Group, a provider of equipment to the oil and gas industry.

headline: Tibetan Writer Says Invitation to U.S. Embassy Preceded House Arrest
text: Chinese security officers placed Tsering Woeser, the prominent Tibetan writer and advocate who lives in Beijing, and her husband under house arrest after Ms. Woeser received a call inviting her to the United States Embassy on Wednesday night, according to a Facebook post by Ms. Woeser.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Animal Whisperer
text: The video “The Animal Whisperer” provides a glimpse into the work that one veterinarian and behaviorist does in zoos.

headline: Photojournalists Push Project in Spain
text: Among Spanish photographers, no one is a prophet — or makes a profit — in their own land.

headline: Macau Activists Plan Hong Kong-Style Poll on Greater Democracy
text: Activists in the Chinese territory of Macau say they plan to hold an informal referendum on direct elections after a similar effort in Hong Kong attracted a large turnout and helped publicize residents’ aspirations for democratic change.

headline: Israeli Leader Vows to Intensify Gaza Attacks on Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — As new volleys of rockets whizzed toward Israel’s major cities on Wednesday and Israel pressed its intensive air bombardment of Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to increase “the assault on Hamas and the terrorist organizations in Gaza.”

headline: AbbVie Backtracks on Comments in Shire Bid
text: LONDON – AbbVie on Wednesday retracted statements that shareholders of the Irish drug maker Shire were supportive of AbbVie’s takeover bid.

headline: Britain Pushes Hard on Nuclear Power
text: LONDON — There are few places in the West where companies that build nuclear plants are welcome to construct new ones. That lack of choice probably accounts for a lot of the appeal of a nearly 500-acre stretch of scrubland called Moorside near the Irish Sea in northwest England.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: A Marijuana-Friendly Borough
text: Good morning on this fine Wednesday.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Ground Battles in Afghanistan Contribute to Surge in Civilian Casualties, U.N. Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Driven by increased ground combat between insurgents and government forces, civilian casualties in Afghanistan surged 24 percent through the first half of the year, reaching their highest levels since 2009, according to the United Nations. The findings were released just as a Taliban attack unfolded in the densely populated center of Kandahar, the main city in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Iraqi Premier Blames Kurds for Advances by Militants
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s prime minister made his harshest public criticism of Kurdistan to date on Wednesday, accusing the Kurds of aiding Sunni militants, even as sectarian tensions appeared to be rising with the discovery of 50 bodies, blindfolded, bound and shot about 50 miles south of Baghdad.

headline: Morning Views
text: “For-profit colleges are lobbying hard to weaken rules proposed by the Obama administration that would deny federal aid to career training programs that burden students with crippling debt and worthless credentials,” writes The New York Times editorial board. Citing the example of Corinthian Colleges, one of the country’s largest operators of for-profit colleges and trade schools, the board argues that such “rules need to be strengthened and that federal oversight generally needs to be broadened.” Corinthian Colleges relies so completely on funding from the government to cover its operating budget that a delay in the delivery of federal aid as part of an investigation threatened to shut down the chain entirely. “If Congress required such operations to get more of their revenue from private sources, then more institutions would be forced to produce higher-quality programs that students would be willing to pay for,” the board writes.

headline: The French Do Buy Books. Real Books.
text: PARIS — One of the maddening things about being a foreigner in France is that hardly anyone in the rest of the world knows what’s really happening here. They think Paris is a Socialist museum where people are exceptionally good at eating small bits of chocolate and tying scarves.

headline: What I Learned From Firing My Employee of 20 Years
text: A business owner of no particular distinction, in an unfashionable industry, without a record of success or a vast fortune to substantiate his opinions, is given a chance to write about his company in The New York Times. He tries to tell a long, complicated story with a large cast of characters, a story that started two decades ago but concentrates on events covering the last two years.

headline: Plan to Give Former King Immunity Splits Spain
text: MADRID — When he gave up the Spanish throne recently after nearly four decades, Juan Carlos I forfeited some perks and privileges, not least among them immunity from legal proceedings. And in the weeks since his son Felipe took the crown, Juan Carlos has gotten a glimpse of what it might be like to be treated by the courts like any other citizen, including the threat of two paternity suits.

headline: Does Birth Control Coverage Pay for Itself?
text: The Supreme Court took two actions on contraceptive coverage last week that have, appropriately, received considerable attention. But there’s a health economics question in the background that warrants some attention as well: Does contraceptive coverage pay for itself?

headline: Yea, Oops, Nay: Voting Mistakes in Congress
text: If you make a mistake in the voting booth, chances are good that no one will ever know, unless you say so. Members of the House of Representatives not only make voting errors, but they also own up to them in public to avoid the political fallout for taking an unpopular position.

headline: Not Your Ordinary Bananas Foster
text: A long time ago, when the century was young and the East Village seemed like a land of opportunity, a young cook named Allison Vines-Rushing was the chef at a tiny restaurant called Jack’s Luxury Oyster Bar, on East Fifth Street.

headline: 10-Year Term on Graft Charges for C. Ray Nagin, Former Mayor of New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — C. Ray Nagin, the former New Orleans mayor, was sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in prison on corruption charges, a remarkable fall from grace for a man who came to office pledging to root out cronyism.

headline: Morning Agenda: Prosecutors’ Perfect Streak Ends
text: Since the government’s crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry became public in 2009 with the arrest of Raj Rajaratnam, federal prosecutors under Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, had secured 85 insider trading convictions and guilty pleas without one defeat. But on Tuesday, that perfect streak came to an end, Matthew Goldstein, Rachel Abrams and Ben Protess write in DealBook. After just under four hours of deliberation, a federal jury found Rengan Rajaratnam ‒ the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of insider trading in 2011 ‒ not guilty of conspiracy to commit insider trading with his older brother.

headline: New Case of Spying Is Alleged by Germany
text: BERLIN — Anger at Washington mounted Wednesday with the disclosure that American intelligence agents were suspected of having recruited a second spy in Germany, this time linked to its Defense Ministry, prompting even robust allies of the United States to suggest that a fundamental reset was needed in one of the most important of trans-Atlantic partnerships.

headline: Daily Report: Yelp Joins Opposition to Google’s European Antitrust Settlement
text: Yelp, the online service increasingly popular on both sides of the Atlantic, has joined the critics formally opposing the European Union’s proposed antitrust settlement with Google, James Kanter reports.

headline: 1914: Aviators Attempt London-Paris Return Flight
text: In British and French aviation circles interest now centres in the international race from London to Paris and back, upon which fourteen pilots are expected to start to-morrow morning. Since M. Blériot first astonished the world by flying across the Channel, aviation has advanced so extraordinarily that a cross-Channel flight is now regarded as a mere incident in the day’s work. Aviators have flown from London to Paris and vice versa so frequently that the feat has become a mere commonplace. At the same time the race to-morrow will constitute a severe test both of the machines and their pilots. —The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1914

headline: Revisiting His Arsenal of Misanthropy
text: Morrissey’s “World Peace Is None of Your Business,” his 10th solo album, is not a good record, but, on the other hand, it is almost a perfect one.

headline: Li Chengpeng’s Social Media and Blog Accounts Suspended
text: The social media and blog accounts of the widely followed social and political commentator Li Chengpeng have been suspended in what appears to be part of a continuing effort by the Chinese government to crack down on outspoken voices online.

headline: Disappointed Fireworks Fans in Brooklyn
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Paris Couture Week: Armani Privé Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: American Apparel Deal Gives Retailer a Lifeline
text: After a bruising three-week battle over the future of American Apparel, the struggling retailer reached a deal with its largest shareholders on Wednesday, agreeing to remake its board and to try to shore up the company’s finances.

headline: Finding Ways to Use Big Data to Help Small Shops
text: Brian Janezic, 27, was in the equipment room of one of the two Auto Wash Express self-service locations he owns in Tucson, going through his cleaning supplies and vending machine items to determine what to reorder, when it hit him. “We have machines that automatically size and wash a car, mix chemicals, activate pumps, turn on lights — and here I am still counting inventory by hand.”

headline: Shielding Modems When Lightning Strikes
text: Shielding Modems During Storms

headline: Elie Saab: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: App Smart | Perfect Beach Day
text: Kit Eaton explores three apps to track surf and sun conditions so you can enjoy a summer day at the beach.

headline: As New York Landlords Push Buyouts, Renters Resist
text: The first offer from the landlord’s representative came in April: Take $90,000 to move out, the tenants said they were told, or the landlord would sue and they would lose their apartments anyway.

headline: Before Slapping On the Sunscreen, Check the Phone
text: WE’RE in the middle of summer now and that means one thing: It’s time to head to the beach and have some fun. But before you go, make sure you’ve downloaded the apps you need to make your day at the beach the best it can be.

headline: Snowden Asks Russia to Extend Asylum
text: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency analyst who fled to Russia last year after releasing reams of secret American government documents, has applied to extend his temporary asylum, his lawyer was quoted as telling Russian news agencies on Wednesday.

headline: At 27,000 Feet, an Air Force Plea to Preserve Its Bombers
text: PIEDMONT, S.D. — At 7:29 a.m., the B-1 bomber raced down the runway at Ellsworth Air Force Base, and within two stomach-churning minutes was at 10,000 feet and streaking toward Lake Michigan.

headline: Making Fun
text: Summer vacation offers children unstructured time rich with opportunities for creative projects, and three new crafts books suggest ideas for a range of activities to inspire young artists and their adult assistants. There’s no dearth of crafting books on the market, but as with cookbooks, novelty makes old techniques seem freshly appealing. Parents will recall from their own childhoods the basic skills required: cutting, gluing, taping, tracing, sewing and pom-pom making. But even pom-pom pros can use a refresher course every couple of decades, and the craftiest readers may find a few tricks to be learned from experts who take their projects to new heights.

headline: The Religious Penumbra Revisited
text: Earlier this year, I wrote a column on a crucial sociological distinction between religious affiliation and religious practice in American life — specifically, the way that the strong association between social capital and religious faith only really obtains for people who are active in their faith, and the way that a great deal of social ruin in our nation is concentrated in communities (mostly working class) where religion has half-retreated, leaving a kind of identitarian, Christian-ish residue that either has no real effect on people’s choices or (possibly) shapes them for the worse.

headline: Cockpit Footage of Israeli Airstrikes
text: Israel released video of missile strikes it says are targeting weapons facilities in Gaza.

headline: For Young Bankers, the Job Starts Now
text: For first-year junior bankers, summer is anything but endless. Instead, these young employees, most fresh out of college, are now trading sunglasses for suits as they begin training programs in New York geared to prepare them for work on Wall Street.

headline: Public Opinion Against Russia Hardens After Ukraine Intervention, Poll Finds
text: In the wake of its military intervention in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea, Russia is widely disliked in Europe, the Middle East and the United States, according to a Pew Global Attitudes poll released on Wednesday. The leadership of President Vladimir V. Putin inspires little confidence, the survey found. And while most Russians think Mr. Putin will do the right thing in international affairs, few people in the other countries surveyed have faith in him.

headline: On the Road to Samarra, Glimpses of Iraq’s New Fractured Reality
text: SAMARRA, Iraq — About 20 miles beyond the northern gates of Baghdad, on the way to the embattled city of Samarra, site of one of Shiite Islam’s holiest shrines, the road empties out as if some invisible barrier has been passed.

headline: U.S. Program Can Take Heart in Germany’s Win
text: The stunning performance by Germany on Tuesday was a long time coming. Fourteen years would be the best figure.

headline: Nearly 3,500 Years Old, an Egyptian Monument Gets a Laser Cleaning
text: Thutmose III thought big.

headline: Argentina and the Netherlands: The Confident vs. the Humble
text: The World Cup’s second semifinal, between Argentina and the Netherlands, features two very different groups of fans.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama to Meet With Perry
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington.

headline: Karlie Kloss Shares Her Summertime Fitness Tips
text: “Summer is my favorite time of year,” says Karlie Kloss, the 21-year-old supermodel whose cropped, tousled hair was the coveted cut of the year in 2013, and is again making headlines this season for its new, summery blond hue. “Because of the nice weather, I can spend my free time outside moving and staying active.” Kloss isn’t shy about her healthy habits: a vocal vegetarian, she designed dairy- and gluten-free cookies with Christina Tosi for Momofuku Milk Bar (a portion of the proceeds are donated to hunger relief). She also Instagrams frequent evidence of balanced eating and hours clocked at the gym, like this morning’s posts of her recent workout in New York City with the Nike Training Club master trainer Traci Copeland, during which she test-drove Nike’s upcoming fall 2014 collection.

headline: Bedford-Stuyvesant: Diverse and Changing
text: To sum up Bedford-Stuyvesant as yet another stunning Brooklyn brownstone neighborhood falling victim to gentrification would be to deny the vitality and tenaciousness of a community with deep cultural and historic roots in the area.

headline: Microsoft Taking Steps to Comply With the Right to be Forgotten
text: LONDON — Microsoft has kept its head down since a European court in May ruled that people could ask Internet search services to delink personal information.

headline: FINalternatives Is Sold to Upstart Media Firm
text: FINalternatives, an online publication covering the world of hedge funds and private equity, has been sold to an upstart media company called the Alpha Pages.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Staples vs. Sutures After C-Section
text: Staples are faster, but sutures are safer, researchers have concluded in a new study of how incisions are closed after a cesarean section.

headline: The Next Step for Rengan Rajaratnam
text: The end of a prominent winning streak inspires trivia questions. Which team stopped the U.C.L.A. men’s basketball team at 88 wins in a row? Notre Dame. Which baseball team put an end to Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hitting streak? The Cleveland Indians.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
text: CHICAGO

headline: Following Her Parents’ Lead, Chelsea Clinton Takes Stage as a Paid Speaker
text: There is a new Clinton paid to deliver speeches — Chelsea, the former first daughter — and she is commanding as much as $75,000 per appearance.

headline: Playing Dress-Up, the Musical
text: Beauty pageants have faded away from the mainstream of American culture. Can you name this year’s Miss America? Do we still even have one? But in certain niches, they still carry a sweet mystique. Witness, for example, the success of “RuPaul’s Drag Race,” in which the male contestants swan down a runway in sequins and heels, seeking to be crowned best in show. For fans of the series who are looking for diversion during the off-season, the return of “Pageant,” a musical in which all the contestants in a beauty competition are played by men, will be required viewing.

headline: Aide to India’s New Prime Minister Gets Top Party Post
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s closest aide on Wednesday was named president of the governing Bharatiya Janata Party, further strengthening Mr. Modi’s control over India’s political system.

headline: Reduce Your Monthly Digital Bills
text: Molly Wood audits her digital expenses, from cloud storage to streaming movies, and finds ways to trim her monthly bills.

headline: When a Start-Up Creation Myth Hits Reality
text: Whitney Wolfe, the former vice president of marketing at Tinder, the online-dating app, recently filed suit against her former employers. She claims damages for sexual harassment, discrimination and defamation and also details the story of her contributions to the company’s founding.

headline: Cutting the High Cost of Digital Living
text: SOMETIMES the modern world feels like death by a thousand little subscription payments.

headline: A Familiar Destiny to Photograph the New China
text: Sim Chi Yin walked away form a comfortable reporting job to become a photographer with an interest in social issues. Her gamble paid off.

headline: Show Could Be BBC’s Answer to ‘Game of Thrones’
text: The BBC and Carnival Films – the producers of “Downton Abbey” – have a new historical drama in the works, and this time they are going medieval, with a tale of Saxons and Vikings, set in the kingdom of Wessex in the year 872, during the reign of Alfred the Great.

headline: 1920: The ‘World War’ Gets a Number
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Putting the Con in Reformicon
text: Brad Delong does a chart of the “reform conservative” wonks cited by Sam Tanenhaus in his “party of ideas” piece; basically, it’s all Yuval Levin and Ramesh Ponnuru. So what do we know about these would-be reformers?

headline: Why a Merger of Pet Retailers Would Make Sense
text: PetSmart’s activist shareholders are barking up the right tree. Jana Partners and Longview Asset Management, which together own about a one-fifth stake, are demanding that the  purveyor of dog food and toys sell itself. There are other options to enhance shareholder returns, but a deal with Petco, the smaller rival controlled by TPG and Leonard Green, could be the pick of the litter.

headline: New Hampshire Residents: Did You Sign up for Insurance Through the Affordable Care Act?
text: The Times would like to hear from Americans who are signing up for insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Salix Pharmaceuticals to Buy Irish Company and Reincorporate Overseas
text: LONDON – Salix Pharmaceuticals of North Carolina said late Tuesday that it had struck a deal to acquire the Irish arm of an Italian drug maker, becoming the latest United States company to seek to move its headquarters abroad for tax purposes.

headline: This Year’s Special Guest at Sun Valley? Word Is John Kerry
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho – One of the perennial guessing games of the annual Allen & Company conference is who the big guest will be.

headline: Stir-Fries, Mastered. Next Up, the Easy Vegetarian Gratin
text: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. Last week, Renee did her first stir-fry, based on last week’s advice and a recipe like those found here.)

headline: Obama, on Texas Trip, Will Face Immigration Critics
text: DENVER — President Obama is traveling to Texas on Wednesday and will come face-to-face with liberal and conservative critics of his government’s handling of a humanitarian crisis on the southern border, including Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Defending Champion Quits During a Stage of Chaos and Cobblestones
text: ARENBERG, France — Every three years the square in Ypres, Belgium, which hosted the start of Wednesday’s stage of the Tour de France, holds a Festival of the Cat. For hundreds of years, as part of the festivities, cats were thrown from the bell tower of an imposing guild hall.

headline: Classical Playlist: ‘West Side Story,’ Schubert, Haydn and More
text: BERNSTEIN: ‘West Side Story’Alexandra Silber, Cheyenne Jackson and others.San Francisco Symphony, Michael Tilson Thomas, conductor(SFSmedia; two CDs)Do we need another recording of “West Side Story” performed by a full symphonic orchestra? Absolutely when it’s this one, taken from live performances in 2013 that Michael Tilson Thomas conducted with the San Francisco Symphony at the orchestra’s home hall. The cast, led by Alexandra Silber as Maria and Cheyenne Jackson as Tony, who bring youthful ardor, beguiling voices and dramatic immediacy to their roles, is ideal. This is a nearly complete version of Bernstein’s score, with lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. The symphonic richness of the playing is an asset. But even better is the stylish naturalness and clarity that Mr. Thomas draws from the players, and the inspired cast. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Congress Unlikely to Step In as L.I.R.R. Strike Looms
text: The dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and its unions hurtled into a more urgent phase on Wednesday, less than two weeks before a possible strike, as congressional leaders said they were unlikely to intervene on behalf of either side.

headline: Romance Is in the Air
text: “Just wait till I come.” Those words interjected by the singer and pianist Loston Harris into his rendition of “You’d Be So Nice to Come Home To,” on Tuesday evening at Birdland added a quietly assertive personal touch to this Cole Porter standard. Mr. Harris, who has a pleasantly husky baritone, is offhandedly suave. Cool but winning, he doesn’t go in for seductive wiles or conspicuous emotional display. His pianism, although technically proficient, is relatively impersonal. He swings steadily in phrases that travel long and winding roads to their destination.

headline: Nike and Manchester United Set to End Equipment Partnership
text: LONDON — After 13 years, Nike and Manchester United are calling it quits.

headline: More on Class and Monetary Policy
text: A bit more on the question of whose interests are served by hard-money ideology: One way to identify what you might call the creditor class is to look at who derives a lot of income from interest. The Piketty-Saez tables calculate interest income as a share of total income for various percentiles of the income distribution; I looked at the numbers from 2007, when the crisis had not yet struck and returns were “normal”. It looks like this:

headline: U.S. Open Singles Champions to Earn $3 Million Apiece
text: The prize money at the United States Open will take another leap this year, with the men’s and women’s singles tennis champions taking home $3 million and the early-round winners also receiving a significant bump in pay.

headline: One Step From World Cup Final, Argentina Channels Di Stéfano
text: When Alfredo Di Stéfano died at 88 on Monday, one of the last ties to a golden age of Latin American soccer was cut.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paying Employees After a Fire
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: U.S. Spied on 5 American Muslims, a Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A new report based on documents provided by Edward J. Snowden has identified five American Muslims, including the leader of a civil rights group, as having been subjected to surveillance by the federal government.

headline: 1939: Spinsters Block Tulsa Airport
text: TULSA, Okla. – Two spinster sisters who have an intense dislike for noise have prevented air liners from landing in Tulsa for the last week by the simple expedient of erecting two fifty-one-foot radio masts over their house, which is next to the airport. As soon as the aerials went up, the Civil Aeronautics Authority classified them as a “grave hazard” and forbade the use of the airport. Threats had no effect. For the time being, the sisters are enjoying tranquillity, and the American Airlines, which use the adjacent landing field, admit they are stymied. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1914

headline: James Patterson’s ‘Maximum Ride’ Books to Be a Series on YouTube
text: James Patterson, the novelist whose blockbuster books have sold more than 300 million copies, is setting his sights on another medium: Internet video.

headline: Wheelies: The Future Infiniti Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Air Sirens Puncture Life in Affluent Tel Aviv Suburbs
text: NESS ZIONA, Israel — The sirens wailed about 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday in this orderly suburb south of Tel Aviv. Two rockets were whizzing here from Gaza.

headline: Once in a Blue Moon
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — To paraphrase one of the cartoon characters of my formative years, be vewy, vewy quiet: We’re hunting missing words. And they’re tricky; you won’t hear them sneaking around.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Maison Martin Margiela Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Kenny Kingston, ‘Psychic to the Stars,’ Dies at 87
text: Kenny Kingston, a “psychic to the stars” who communicated with the rich, the famous and the titled — many of them disembodied, he maintained — died on June 30 at his home in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: How Is Your Small Business Making Use of Big Data?
text: We’ve just published an article about how small businesses are finding ways to make use of big data. One example is Brian Janezic, 27, who owns two Auto Wash Express self-service locations in Tucson. Mr Janezic said he was standing in one of his locations when he realized, “We have machines that automatically size and wash a car, mix chemicals, activate pumps, turn on lights — and here I am still counting inventory by hand.”

headline: Mamphela Ramphele, Veteran of Anti-Apartheid Struggle, Quits Politics
text: JOHANNESBURG — Mamphela Ramphele, a prominent veteran of the struggle against apartheid, raised great expectations in early 2013 by entering politics and starting a new party. A black woman who had two children with Steve Biko, the anti-apartheid martyr, and went on to forge a formidable career as a medical doctor, business executive and managing director at the World Bank, she seemed such a compelling candidate that South Africa’s main opposition group even proposed a merger with her fledgling party.

headline: Something Gained, Something Lost
text: “I’ve got to get out of this crowd.”

headline: Urban Legends Told Online
text: In early June, two 12-year-old girls in Waukesha, Wis., were charged with attempted murder in the attack on a third girl, a classmate whom they had invited for a sleepover. Prosecutors say the girls lured their victim into playing a game of hide-and-seek in the woods. When in the woods, the prosecutors say, they attacked her with a knife, stabbing her 19 times. The victim was discovered by a bicyclist and rushed to the hospital; she is said to be recovering from her injuries.

headline: Hope for Frogs in Face of a Deadly Fungus
text: In the 1990s, a disturbing silence began to settle across the world. From mountain lakes to tropical streams, the music of singing frogs began to disappear.

headline: A Familiar Destiny to Photograph the New China
text: Sim Chi Yin had a cushy expat life in Beijing working as a reporter for The Singapore Straits Times, writing long feature stories and sometimes taking photos. The company paid for her education at the London School of Economics in exchange for eight years of employment. She had health insurance, a pension and job security.

headline: Voting Totals Reveal Crucial Boost From Blacks in Thad Cochran’s Victory
text: The precinct level returns in Hinds County bolster the theory that a surge in black, Democratic turnout allowed Senator Thad Cochran to defeat Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, in last month’s Republican primary runoff in Mississippi.

headline: Somali Police and Intelligence Chiefs Fired After Militant Attack
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somalia’s prime minister fired his police and intelligence chiefs on Wednesday following a brazen attack in which Islamist militants blasted their way into the inner sanctum of the presidential compound here.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Paul Ryan
text: In the wake of the Times Magazine’s profile this weekend of les reformocons, both Jonathan Chait and Danny Vinik have noted what Chait calls the “near-total absence” of Paul Ryan’s name from a story that concerns itself with the kind of wonkery that has long defined the House Budget Chairman’s brand. Chait suggests that this reflects a shift away “from Ryan-style apocalypticism” on fiscal issues among right-of-center policy entrepreneurs. Vinik, meanwhile, argues that a split between Ryan and reform conservatives over taxes might be in the offing, since the former veep nominee is more likely to side with a WSJ-style “always cut the top rate” vision than with proponents of something like Mike Lee’s family-friendly approach.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: What to Expect
text: Thursday’s announcement of the Emmy nominations will almost certainly include a face-off between two of the year’s most lavishly praised dramatic series, even though one of them really is not a series.

headline: Senate Confirms Obama's Pick for Housing Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Wednesday to confirm Julián Castro as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, catapulting the young mayor of San Antonio to the national stage and putting him in charge of the agency as it grapples with a sluggish housing recovery and efforts in Congress to overhaul the nation’s housing finance system.

headline: Fed, Confident in Economy, Details End of Bond-Buying Program
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it planned to stop adding to its bond holdings in October, in a sign of its confidence that the economy is gaining strength even as the central bank gradually withdraws its support.

headline: Sultry Univision Ads Help Steer Women From Soaps to Soccer
text: In the months before the World Cup, Univision began to unveil its plan to reach female viewers, many of whom are devoted to its daytime talk shows and telenovelas.

headline: Britain to Review I.P.O. Process After Criticism of Royal Mail Offering
text: LONDON – The British government began an “informal review” on Wednesday of how it pursues initial public offerings of government assets in the wake of questions about whether the Royal Mail offering last year was properly priced.

headline: Parent on a Smartphone, With Almost No Guilt
text: Here’s why my colleague Farhad Manjoo spent last week alternating between his smartphone and his 3-year-old, and why he says You Don’t Have to Feel Very Guilty About Using Your Smartphone While Parenting.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Flat-Footed Boots on Couture Runways
text: Last season’s couture tennis shoe is this season’s modest flat boot. It first appeared in the fall/winter 2014 couture shows at Atelier Versace, an unexpected runway for such tame footwear. (To her credit, Donatella Versace’s suede mid-calf gogo boots were topped with dazzling diamanté buckles.) The trend then began to take shape at Schiaparelli, where perhaps the only toned-down aspect of the designer Marco Zanini’s fanciful and eclectic presentation were the short pointed boots in luxurious monochromatic crocodile and printed leopard. And at Chanel, a single over-the-knee leather boot style, which appeared once in buff and once in black, broke up the onslaught of flat sandals with ribbons that tied around the ankle.

headline: With Eye on LeBron James, Cavaliers Trade Guard to Nets
text: LAS VEGAS — The Nets appeared to solve their problem at backup point guard Wednesday by reaching an agreement to acquire Jarrett Jack from Cleveland in a three-team trade that had everything to do with the Cavaliers’ eagerness to create maximum financial flexibility in their pursuit of LeBron James, a free agent.

headline: ‘Short Film’ by Springsteen and Zimny Unveiled
text: At the end of June, Bruce Springsteen put a teaser on his website, asking his fans to return for the premiere of “Hunter of Invisible Game,” which he described as “a short film by Thom Zimny and Bruce Springsteen.” That raised a few questions: the title is that of one of the more darkly introspective songs on Mr. Springsteen’s most recent album, “High Hopes,” suggesting that he might be simply unveiling a promotional clip.

headline: Adidas Joins Wearable Stampede With Fitness Tracker
text: There are a few things that should give pause to Adidas, the footwear and apparel maker, as it enters the so-called wearables market.

headline: Falcone’s Hedge Fund Files Suit Against Dish Network Over LightSquared
text: A battle between two billionaires over LightSquared, the wireless broadband company, has played out for months in bankruptcy court. Now one of the billionaires, Philip A. Falcone, has picked a fight with his adversary in a new arena.

headline: Pope Francis Names New Leadership for Vatican Bank
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis continued his efforts to modernize and reorganize the Vatican finances on Wednesday, by appointing a new leadership for the scandal-tainted Vatican Bank, streamlining other operations and signaling future changes to the church’s global media operations.

headline: Suits and Sneakers in the Bronx
text: Southern Boulevard in the Bronx is a shopping hub for jeans, gold chains and sneakers, with Jordans being elevated to a wardrobe staple. When the Bronx native Javier Lopez is not working in politics, he stays loyal to his sneakerhead roots, matching his outfits with a pair from his collection of nearly 100. This interview has been edited.

headline: Argentina vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Argentina beat the Netherlands on penalties, 4-2, after 120 scoreless minutes, and will play Germany in Sunday’s final with the World Cup at stake.

headline: A Growing Arsenal of Homegrown Rockets Encounters Israel’s Iron Dome
text: JERUSALEM — For the moment at least, the hostilities between Israel and Gaza are partly a fight between rockets and interceptors — between the varied and improved arsenal of rockets possessed by Hamas and its allies, like Islamic Jihad, and the antimissile systems of Israel.

headline: Draghi Calls for Closer Economic Integration in Europe
text: The president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, said on Wednesday that countries in the euro zone should be compelled to take steps to improve the performance of their economies in the same way that they are already required to observe rules on government spending.

headline: Greece Plans Another Bond Offering
text: ATHENS — Three months after returning to international bond markets following a long exile, Greece said on Wednesday that it was planning to sell bonds again in an effort to capitalize on the growing demand for short-term euro zone debt.

headline: Argentines Sing of Brazil’s Humiliation, Loudly and in Rio
text: As the Brazil team has come spectacularly undone in the World Cup, the pain for the host country has been compounded by the prospect that its hated rival, Argentina, could still lift the championship trophy on Sunday in Rio de Janeiro’s fabled Estádio do Maracanã, after Argentina won a tense semifinal against the Netherlands in a penalty shootout on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: For Vaporizers, Smoke Means Fire
text: Hip-hop artists like Wiz Khalifa rap about them regularly. If you pay attention, you’ll see one tucked into the palm of a passer-by’s hand on the street. Whoopi Goldberg wrote fawningly about hers, and shortly after, The New Yorker posted an article titled, “Vaping for Yuppies.”

headline: Handy Liquor Bar in SoHo
text: SoHo’s night life dwindled last year when several well-liked bars, including subMercer, Ñ and Milady’s, abruptly closed, leaving the neighborhood vulnerable to sticky-fingered Cronut pilgrims and fro-yo fiends. Bringing much-needed adult refreshment to this district is Handy Liquor Bar, a cozy cocktail den opened in April by the night-life swami Matt Levine.

headline: Marriage Gone Sour? Go Home to Ma Bell
text: From the Oz stories to Harry Potter, there have always been books that attracted a crossover following of adults and young readers. Most recently, the runaway popularity of John Green’s “The Fault in Our Stars,” and then anything else John Green has written, more than proved the point. Stephen Colbert defined the phenomenon this way: “As far as I can tell, a young adult novel is a regular novel that people actually read.”

headline: Bieber to Be Charged in Egging of Neighbor’s House
text: The Los Angeles County district attorney’s office took its time: back in February, a spokesman for the sheriff’s department said it had ample evidence that Justin Bieber egged a neighbor’s house, causing what the department estimated at $20,000 of damage. But it took until now for formal charges to be filed. That is expected to happen on Wednesday at Superior Court in Van Nuys, Calif., where Mr. Bieber is to be charged with a single count of misdemeanor vandalism, The Associated Press reported.

headline: An Ad Campaign for Whistleblowers
text: Federal bureaucrats commuting to work in the nation’s capital are finding fresh food for thought as they wait for the bus — glossy six-foot posters with an open invitation to blow the whistle on bad stuff happening at the office. Daniel Ellsberg, the patriarch of whistle-blowers who outraged the Nixon White House with his mega-leak of the Pentagon Papers, is depicted on the posters with a plea to “tell the truth with documents that reveal lies or crimes or internal projections of costs and dangers.”

headline: Armadillo to Açaí: Flavors of a World Cup Journey
text: Language had failed us, so Ruben Dada had resorted to charades to demonstrate which wild animal found in the Surinamese rain forest he was offering to cook up for me.

headline: A Dash of Whimsy, With Leftover Stars
text: The experimental filmmaker Jodie Mack grew up around the family business of posters and merch. From a Florida warehouse her parents supplied music retailers and others with the cultural wallpaper that decorated countless bedrooms in the 1990s — from the bands and celebrities du jour to the dorm-room patron saints Belushi, Marley and Guevara.

headline: In a Buenos Aires Barrio, a Quiet Metamorphosis
text: Just south of the hip Palermo Soho neighborhood, a staunchly working-class Buenos Aires barrio is undergoing a quiet metamorphosis. Long home to the city’s Jewish community, Villa Crespo’s streets are lined with mom-and-pop shops, onetime factories and faded colonial facades that have mostly remained outside the trendsetters’ purview. But given its prime location — enterprising real estate agents are trying to rechristen the enclave Palermo Queens, much to the chagrin of longtime residents — an influx of hip restaurants and boutiques was inevitable. At the moment, the neighborhood still feels removed from the city’s hubbub, but more locals are descending upon its cobbled lanes.

headline: Downtown Las Vegas Jumps Again
text: From its frontier infancy through the mid-20th century, the only Las Vegas was downtown Las Vegas. But the city center known as Glitter Gulch lost the glamour battle post-1960 with the newer Strip, a stretch of Las Vegas Boulevard South with room for massive resorts featuring Egyptian pyramids and dancing water fountains.

headline: The Roar Over the Funds of the Crowd
text: Eight times a week, Zach Braff stands on a Broadway stage and bellows, in a nebbishy kind of way, “No more compromises!”

headline: Prisons of Gender and a Generation
