text: Not only actors but also directors can be typecast, particularly strong stylists like Max Ophuls and Michelangelo Antonioni. Ophuls has been dismissed by some as a froufrou formalist, Antonioni as a poet of the privileged. Neither is noted for his social consciousness, but their complexity is evident in new Blu-ray releases of two relatively obscure films, Ophuls’s “Caught” (1949), made under the name Max Opuls, and Antonioni’s “I Vinti” (1953).

headline: Paris Couture Week: Jean Paul Gaultier Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Bolshoi Arrives With Drama, Some Onstage
text: The overture to Rimsky-Korsakov’s “The Tsar’s Bride” begins with unassuming courtliness and swiftly ramps up to seething passion. It is, in a way, a microcosm of the work as a whole: a historical fantasy that quickly reveals itself as a vibrant blood-and-guts drama.

headline: First-Class Fares, on Sale
text: GiltCity.com, a website that offers local deals on everything from spa services to concerts in 13 major cities, will begin a flash sale Thursday, July 10, encouraging shoppers to get out of town in style, aboard first-class flights on Delta Air Lines.

headline: Trey Songz Is No. 1; Slow Sales for Thicke
text: This week on the music charts, the amorous R&B singer Trey Songz scores his second No. 1 album, Iggy Azalea holds her perch with the top single, and Robin Thicke’s latest album flops after a social-media campaign went bad.

headline: Radio Ad on Possible L.I.R.R. Strike
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is alerting Long Island Rail Road commuters about the potential of a walkout by its workers.

headline: The Birth of a New World Cup Curse
External Drives Bring Data Storage Back Home
text: BUYING digital copies of movies, music and video games can free up shelf space in your entertainment center, but you still have to store those digital files somewhere.

headline: Valentino: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: ‘Big Short’ Case Raises Questions About Finra Arbitration
text: Deeb Salem, the former Goldman Sachs trader who helped devise the firm’s brilliant and highly profitable proprietary bet against the mortgage market, has never been shy about trumpeting his accomplishments. Mr. Salem no longer works at Goldman — he decamped to GoldenTree Asset Management, a New York hedge fund, in 2012 — but his continuing lawsuit, which contends the firm shortchanged him about $21 million in bonus and deferred compensation during the years after the financial crisis, raises fresh questions about the fairness of Wall Street’s compensation practices, its willingness to make scapegoats out of former employees and the arbitration system — run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority — that everyone who deals with Wall Street is forced to use to resolve monetary disputes.

headline: Shopping Events in New York City Starting July 10
text: Sunny Style

headline: Lufthansa to Start Low-Cost, Long-Distance Airline
text: PARIS — Scrambling to find more ways to shave costs and improve profitability, Lufthansa of Germany announced on Wednesday a plan to expand its domestic low-cost operations by creating a new, no-frills airline for long-distance flights, possibly to popular leisure destinations in Southeast Asia.

headline: Viktor & Rolf: Winter 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: A Modern Fairy-Tale Dress at Valentino
text: The mood at today’s Valentino fall/winter 2014 couture show was par-for-the-course romantic. The wood-plank runway bedecked with moss and branches suggested a mythical forest to arriving guests, and what followed was a dance of ethereal, fairy-tale-like fashion moments. Subtle ballet references danced throughout the collection: leather belts on many of the looks mimicked the wraparound leotards worn for warm-ups, while delicate, knee-high lace-up sandals evoked the ties of toe shoes. The muted, wearable collection had its share of standout moments, but it was hard to forget this intricately embroidered pleated wrap minidress that felt at once folkloric and resolutely modern.

headline: A Test Run at 19,000 Feet
text: Before Jeremy Jones could attempt to climb and ride a massive peak in Nepal, he simply needed to get back on his snowboard after weeks without riding. This task led to a test run—at 19,000 feet.

headline: Summer Nights, Late and Spooky
text: It’s amazing what joy good air-conditioning and a midnight movie can bring, and the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s series Freaky Fridays — a delightfully unsettling meeting of horror, kink and 35 millimeter running through August (albeit at 11 p.m.) — offers plenty. Among the perverse pleasures are David Cronenberg’s parricidal nightmare “The Brood” (1979), Kathryn Bigelow’s outlaw vampire movie “Near Dark” (1987), Herk Harvey’s fever dream “Carnival of Souls” (1962) and Liliana Cavani’s lurid “The Night Porter” (1974), each for 10 bucks or less.

headline: In Stormy Year, Yanks Lose Anchor as Tanaka Heads to D.L.
text: CLEVELAND — Their offense has sputtered and their starting pitching has crumbled, and yet three months into the season, the Yankees have remained competitive. It is easy to recognize why: When their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, pitches, the Yankees tend to win.

headline: Deep in Debt, Sarkozy’s Party Might Have to Sit Out Next Election
text: PARIS — France’s main conservative opposition party has disclosed that it is more than $100 million in debt, leaving it financially crippled and further impairing its ability to take on President François Hollande’s governing Socialists and head off the growing strength of the far-right National Front.

headline: The New Business Casual Is Still Uptight
text: Every workplace imposes certain behavioral standards on its workers — dress this way, talk that way, get lunch here and not there. Learning these standards is, we’re told, a big part of being successful. But what do we do if they’re constantly shifting, or if we’re not even sure what they are?

headline: Strategy at the European Team Championships
text: What is the textbook approach to leading against small slams and grand slams? Should you be aggressive or cautious?

headline: Video: Snowboarder Takes a Test Run at 19,000 Feet
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Europe Fines Servier in Pay-for-Delay Crackdown
text: BRUSSELS — Fines totaling 427.7 million euros ($581.8 million) were imposed Wednesday on several European drug makers, including the French company Servier, for keeping more affordable forms of a popular heart treatment off the market.

headline: Kerry Presses China to Abide by Maritime Laws to Ease Tensions
text: BEIJING — In a closed-door session at a high-level gathering of Chinese and American officials here on Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry urged China to follow maritime law in nearby seas to reduce regional tensions, a senior American official said.

headline: The Kids Aren’t All Right, and Neither Is the School
text: Coercive Christianity has been having a rough time on television of late. In May, PBS’s “Independent Lens” broadcast “God Loves Uganda,” a devastating documentary about dubious work being done there by some evangelicals. And now, Showtime offers “Kidnapped for Christ,” an inside look at a school in the Dominican Republic where a certain breed of American parent hoped that God and discipline would straighten out their teenage children.

headline: Tangled Web of Memories Lingers After a Breakup
text: The last thing I remember was the tears running in rivulets down my cheek as I confirmed that, yes, I did want to delete the picture on my Facebook page.

headline: Veteran Diplomat Said to Be Picked as Third Envoy in Syrian Conflict
text: A veteran Italian-Swedish diplomat, Staffan de Mistura, has been tapped to try to achieve what two seasoned envoys could not: craft a peace deal for Syria.

headline: Obama on Economic Progress
text: The president spoke about the country’s post-recession improvements at a campaign event in Denver, and said Republicans were blocking legislation that would help the middle class.

headline: Zynga Changes Board to Comply With Nasdaq Rules
text: Companies naming new members to their boards is normally a routine affair. For the game maker Zynga, the appointment of Regina E. Dugan, a Google executive, to its board has special significance because it moves the company out of the Nasdaq Stock Market’s penalty box.

headline: Brooklyn Bureaucracy: A Reporter’s Journey
text: Andy Newman, a Metro desk reporter, needed a document from the city. Therein lies a tale.

headline: Brooklyn Cantor Is Sentenced to 2 Years for Sexual Abuse
text: A cantor whose sexual abuse case split the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn was sentenced on Wednesday to two years in prison, as expected under a plea deal struck in May.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: IBM Wants to Invent the Chips of the Future, Not Make Them
text: IBM plans to spend $3 billion over the next five years on research and development for computer chips, both to stretch the limits of conventional semiconductors and to hasten the commercialization of exotic new designs.

headline: Nagin Sentenced on Corruption Charges
text: After former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans was sentenced on charges including bribery and fraud, Matthew Coman, an assistant United States attorney, spoke about the effects of Mr. Nagin’s actions.

headline: Democrats Will Vote to Undo the Hobby Lobby Decision
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling last week in the Hobby Lobby case wasn’t based on a fundamental right found in the First Amendment or anywhere else in the Constitution. When the justices said that closely held corporations have religious rights that let them refuse to pay for insurance plans that cover contraceptives, they based their decision on a 1993 law passed by Congress, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

headline: Very Modern Problems Set in a Navajo World
text: A weakness for drink is only one of the problems encountered by the Native American characters in Sydney Freeland’s debut feature, “Drunktown’s Finest.”

headline: This Time, the Main Attraction
text: No one wants to be upstaged by a toilet, especially in his first appearance as a lead actor in a New York production.

headline: The Daily Do | Long Locks Woven with Pearls at Jean-Paul Gaultier
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runway.

headline: A Butcher, a Baker, a Luxury-Handbag Maker
text: There are no crystal balls in fashion, but there are, at least, weather vanes. Some savvy interpreters point the way the wind is blowing. One is Christopher Kane, the young Scottish designer, whose next-big-thing status was, in effect, confirmed by the Kering investment in his label. So when he announced in September that he would open his first London store, the question was where.

headline: U.S. Will Broaden Sanctions to Deter Violence in Congo
text: WASHINGTON — The United States will expand sanctions on groups in the Democratic Republic of Congo, making it easier to target those who are trying to instigate violence and disrupt peacekeeping efforts in that country, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: Scene | ‘Dawn of the Planet of the Apes’
text: Matt Reeves narrates a sequence from “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” featuring Jason Clarke.

headline: About That Photo of the ‘Reformicons’
text: To capture the spirit of the “reformicons” for the July 6 cover story about the emerging band of intellectuals in the Republican Party, Eric Ogden photographed members of the group in Gunston Hall, the historic mansion in Virginia that belonged to George Mason. Ogden’s group portrait, which alluded to paintings of the founding fathers, inspired readers to analyze who was included (“This is the Republican idea of diversity?”) and what they were doing (“Who’s going to sweep up that mess on the floor? The rest of the country?”). Ogden recently discussed how the photo came about — and what’s on those pages on the floor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Bosnia and China.

headline: Beacons of Creativity, Flung From Rooftops
text: The current exhibition about Trisha Brown’s dances on Governors Island occupies just one large room at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s Arts Center. But (despite its unappetizing subtitle “Embodied Practice and Site-Specificity”) it is a room to linger in for more than an hour. It contains memorable objects, rare photographs and four screens; and each screen plays a continuous loop of Ms. Brown’s choreography.

headline: Adrift in a Sea of Good Humor
text: Scandinavians don’t complain. Not even about ethnic stereotyping.

headline: On the Sidelines of the Tour de France
text: Every Tour de France, spectators stake out their spots to catch a glimpse of the peloton as cyclists race past the countryside.

headline: Haunted by History, but Gifted in Sharing It
text: When a satellite of the Ravensbrück concentration camp, in Germany, was liberated in May 1945, a young Polish Roman Catholic named Zofia Posmysz walked out and drew her first free breath since being sent to Auschwitz-Birkenau more than three years earlier. With 20 other women, she walked back to her hometown, Krakow, a distance of nearly 500 miles, and started a new life as a journalist for Polish radio.

headline: In Small Trials, 2 Drugs Go Far in Soothing Symptoms of Eczema and Psoriasis
text: New drugs that block highly specific parts of the immune system are showing remarkable promise in treating two maddening skin diseases, eczema and psoriasis, according to papers published Wednesday in a leading medical journal.

headline: 3 Days of Peace, Music and a Concierge
text: Michael Lang, who helped make rock history as a co-founder of the Woodstock festival, had never forgotten the 800-acre Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y., where the festival was supposed to take place. “We thought it was perfect,” Mr. Lang, 69, said in a recent telephone interview, a wistful note in his voice.

headline: Personal Computing’s Big Three Get a Little Bigger
text: Three companies are pulling away from the pack in the PC business.

headline: New York City Ballet Names Justin Peck as Choreographer
text: Justin Peck, the New York City Ballet soloist, has been appointed resident choreographer at City Ballet just two years after creating his first piece for the company. Mr. Peck’s appointment, announced on Wednesday, makes him the second person to hold this position at City Ballet, after Christopher Wheeldon, who was the company’s resident choreographer from 2001 to 2008.

headline: What You Need to Build a Patio
text: No one said it would be easy, but here are the tools that make it possible.

headline: Go South to Guangzhou, a ‘Home’ Away From Home
text: For decades, Chinese citizens have chafed at the country’s “hukou,” or household registration, system, with its controls over where they can live, study, work, marry and have children.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Viktor & Rolf Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: When Selfies Won’t Do
text: Wearing black leather pants and a cape top, she reclined on a velvet armchair under the frescoed ceiling of a 19th-century Florentine villa, flanked by a hair and makeup artist, as a photographer clicked away.

headline: Going Back to Her Roots, Sometimes in Sync, Sometimes Not
text: “Fase, Four Movements to the Music of Steve Reich,” by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, is a remarkable work, adopting the methods of American Minimalism while swerving away from its ascetic tone. When Ms. De Keersmaeker created it, in the early 1980s, she was barely 20, a student at New York University. And on Tuesday, when “Fase” was performed at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, that amazing precocity was matched by longevity: The choreographer, at 54, dancing her demanding composition with as much electricity as ever.

headline: Religious Exemptions for Contraception Coverage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Children at the Border
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cross-Racial Alliances
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Violence in Israel and Gaza
The Past as Road to Tomorrow
text: PARIS — Fashion can occasionally seem as if it exists in its own bubble. (An allover sequined diaper catsuit? Who would wear that?) But this season, the Paris couture shows played out against a background of almost palpable conflict, from the organized and (mostly) entertaining — Federer vs. Djokovic; Brazil vs. Germany — to the unexpected and dismaying: Israel vs. Hamas, the civil war in Ukraine. Escapism was not on the agenda.

headline: What Kind of Kitchen Backsplash Will Appeal to Buyers?
text: Q. I’ve decided to install marble countertops in my kitchen. What kind of backsplash would appeal to buyers?

headline: Reading Hobby Lobby in Context
text: To grasp the full implications of the Supreme Court’s Hobby Lobby decision, it helps to read it not in isolation but alongside the court’s other major religion case of the term, Town of Greece v. Galloway. Issued eight weeks before Hobby Lobby and decided by the same 5 to 4 division, Town of Greece rejected a challenge to a town board’s practice of beginning its public sessions with a Christian prayer. A federal appeals court found the practice unconstitutional, concluding that it violated the First Amendment’s Establishment Clause by conveying an official endorsement of one particular religion.

headline: Playing to the Paleo Crowd
text: An elimination diet inspires Kimberly Dobbins to create an allergy-friendly snack bar company.

headline: From Bruce LaBruce, a Perfume All About Obscenity
text: The Canadian art filmmaker Bruce LaBruce is no stranger to transgression. His work has depicted pornographic bloodbaths, zombie necrophilia and amputee fetishism. By those standards, his latest project, “Obscenity,” the subject of a new show at the New York gallery the Hole, might seem rather tame. Like the artist Francesco Vezzoli’s notorious “Greed,” a mock advertisement that starred Natalie Portman and Michelle Williams having a cat fight over a perfume bottle, it’s a critique of fragrance campaigns, but it bears LaBruce’s unmistakable stamp.

headline: What You Need to Build a Patio
text: No one said it would be easy, but here are the tools that make it possible.

headline: Richard Meier’s High and Mighty Beach House
text: The story of how Richard Meier, one of the world’s most-celebrated architects, came to design a small, one-bedroom house on a barrier island likely destined for extinction goes back nearly a half-century.

headline: Where the Curtains Were Made of Iron
text: Some 350 Cold War-era artifacts, including teacups, tables and surveillance equipment used by the East German secret police, have replaced most of the furnishings in the Neutra VDL Studio and Residences in Los Angeles for “Competing Utopias: An Experimental Installation of Cold War Modern Design From East and West in One Context,” opening to the public on Sunday. It takes a disorienting look at the parallel universes on either side of the Iron Curtain, a “Twilight Zone”-like scenario where everything is the same — except that it’s different. “The similarity of objects from the East and West are pretty remarkable,” said Bill Ferehawk, who organized the show with Justinian Jampol, founder of the Wende Museum and Archive of the Cold War, and Sarah Lorenzen, the VDL House’s director. They use no labels, so unless visitors consult the iPads in the room, only clues like German phrases on coffee cans will hint at the décor’s origins. As Ms. Lorenzen said: “We want people to wonder: ‘How is history manufactured? How do stories get told? How different are we really?’ ” Through Sept. 13; neutra-vdl.org.

headline: Ode on a Spanish Urn, Filled With a City’s Tap Water
text: Bilbao, the northern Spanish city, has a new contribution from a design superstar: not a museum or a bridge this time, but a ceramic water pitcher. Patricia Urquiola, the Spanish-born Milanese designer, has created H2O Bilbao, a pitcher based on the kaiku, an ancient Basque wooden milking and cooking vessel. Ms. Urquiola said she borrowed the classic form to pay tribute to Bilbao’s excellent tap water.

headline: Putting the ‘Oh!’ in Patio
text: There’s a fine line between pragmatism and masochism, and I just crossed it.

headline: Sales at Michele Varian, Jensen-Lewis, Yves Delorme and Marimekko
text: Michele Varian is discounting some furniture and decorative pillows by up to 70 percent through Sunday (a metal postal desk, usually $2,956, is about $1,774); 27 Howard Street (Crosby Street); 212-343-0033, michelevarian.com.

headline: Plants With Roots Attached
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — It is through Allen Bush, the seedsman and raconteur, that I lay claim to the 400-year-old legacy of the Dutch engraver and floriculturist Emanuel Sweert. On a cloudless Saturday morning not long ago, Mr. Bush rummaged in his backyard and cut me a clump of a purplish iris. It was an ordinary looking plant, not yet in bloom — hardly noticeable in his oversize city lot.

headline: The Flora and Fauna Chronicles
text: There’s a lot of talk about habitat gardens, but how many gardeners have watched a zebra swallowtail butterfly laying its eggs on a pawpaw leaf and then noticed the fuzzy larvae feeding on the leaves, which contain compounds that make the swallowtails unpalatable to birds? Two giants of the natural gardening world, Rick Darke and Doug Tallamy, have collaborated on their best work yet, “The Living Landscape: Designing for Beauty and Biodiversity in the Home Garden” (Timber Press, $39.95). It documents the layers and creatures of a healthy landscape, like ants carrying seeds of bloodroot and trillium back to their nests, and the blue-gray gnatcatcher nesting in a beech. Mr. Darke, a photographer as well as a plantsman and designer, took most of the gorgeous images, though Mr. Tallamy, an ecologist, offers inspiring close-ups of bugs and birds.

headline: London Theater Journal: Mind Games
text: LONDON – “Here’s to certainty,” says Queen Elizabeth II, raising a glass of gin and it (just a small one) to Margaret Thatcher. The words produce a hollow echo in “Handbagged,” Moira Buffini’s lively stretched-out sketch at the Vaudeville Theater here, because it is far from certain that the reigning monarch of Britain ever made such a toast to such a drinking partner.

headline: Smiljan Radic: A Rock Star Among Architects
text: Two weeks ago, a translucent pod of glass-reinforced plastic, poised atop enormous sandstone boulders, appeared on a curve of lawn in Kensington Gardens in London. The folly, which one reviewer called “a collision between an extraterrestrial egg and a Neolithic burial site,” is by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, whom the nearby Serpentine Galleries chose to create a temporary structure in its front yard. It is the 14th year that the museum has commissioned a Serpentine Pavilion, always turning to an architect who has not previously built in Britain, and the unveiling of the park installation has become a closely watched summer ritual.

headline: Office High Jinks
text: A cozy art-filled living room, a sleek white kitchen, a Yorkshire terrier padding about: Artspace’s new office at 75 Broad Street in the financial district feels more like home than work. The three-year-old company, an online marketplace for contemporary fine art, moved from the Flatiron district last year to a loft that Catherine Levene, a founder and the chief executive, called “a large white box.” She hired the New York designer Maria Gabriela Brito to help personalize the space with art that is sometimes sold off the walls and features like Eurostyle’s Farid chairs, upholstered in a newspaper pattern, for the conference room, below. She nixed a few of Ms. Brito’s wilder ideas, like a bright red pendant lamp in the entry, and insisted on retaining some dull but ergonomic desk chairs. “Catherine is afraid of color,” Ms. Brito said with a smile.

headline: Summer Bedding: Cover Artistry
text: “There are two things that I’m obsessed with,” said Richard Mishaan, an interior designer in Manhattan. “Linens and china: they can elevate your life.”

headline: After Long Stalemate, Argentina Breaks Through in Shootout
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Regulation and extra time brought 120 minutes of scoreless exasperation in a World Cup semifinal on Wednesday that was by turns tense, cautious, clumsy, gripping and stubbornly unyielding.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Start-Ups Make Political Organizing Mobile-Ready
text: With Congress nearly frozen in place and big donors taking on growing influence, start-ups are moving into the political breach.

headline: Man Sentenced to 17 Years for Beating Roommate to Death at Queens Nursing Home
text: A former resident of a nursing home in Rockaway Park, Queens, was sentenced on Wednesday to 17 years in prison after pleading guilty to bludgeoning his roommate to death last year with the metal footrest of a wheelchair.

headline: World Cup Despair in Brazil
text: Brazilians explain what it feels like to lose really, really badly.

headline: Obama Presses Perry to Rally Support for Border Funds
text: DALLAS — President Obama on Wednesday directly challenged Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to rally Republicans in support of a $3.7 billion emergency measure aimed at solving the humanitarian crisis caused as thousands of Central American children have crossed the Mexican border.

headline: The Crisis of Children at the Border
text: The humanitarian crisis of unaccompanied minors from Central America arriving at our Southwest border has brought out the worst in some of our politicians.

headline: A Threat to Internet Freedom
text: New rules proposed by the F.C.C. could divide the Internet into fast lanes and slow lanes, violating the central concept of “net neutrality.”

headline: Co-Author of Bull-Running Guide Is Gored in Pamplona
text: My own final introductory words of advice are simple: if you want to guarantee you’ll survive running the bulls, stay off the street and watch it from a balcony.

headline: On Losing Interest
text: No, it’s not about boredom. Instead, a further thought on the question of who might be upset about low-interest-rate policies. Low policy rates plus quantitative easing have indeed meant much lower interest earnings across the board, and this is a serious hit to the incomes of those who own interest-bearing assets. So who are we talking about?

headline: Detroit’s Art May Be Worth Billions, Report Says
text: A new expert appraisal of the Detroit Institute of Arts’ collection, which some creditors are demanding be sold to help pay municipal debts in the city’s bankruptcy case, has found that the works could be worth $2.7 billion to $4.6 billion.

headline: ‘A Threat to Internet Freedom’
text: The last few months have been critically important for the future of Internet freedom and access.

headline: A Palestinian Mother’s Fear in East Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — THERE was a huge crash, and I felt the ground shake under my family’s home. We heard the first explosion just as we had finished our iftar meal ending the daily Ramadan fast and settled down in front of the television. Out the window, I could see people running in the streets of Beit Hanina, my Palestinian neighborhood. Then came a second crash, and a third.

headline: How Coffee Fueled the Civil War
text: It was the greatest coffee run in American history. The Ohio boys had been fighting since morning, trapped in the raging battle of Antietam, in September 1862. Suddenly, a 19-year-old William McKinley appeared, under heavy fire, hauling vats of hot coffee. The men held out tin cups, gulped the brew and started firing again. “It was like putting a new regiment in the fight,” their officer recalled. Three decades later, McKinley ran for president in part on this singular act of caffeinated heroism.

headline: Deal Allows University of Texas President to Keep Job for Now
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The University of Texas has been engulfed in recent days in a long-simmering clash over turf, personality and ideology that has roiled the state’s political establishment, highlighted questions about the direction of public universities and brought the president of the flagship campus here close to being fired.

headline: Green Eggs and Politics
text: Should children's books deal with issues like politics, race and sexual orientation, or just keep it light?

headline: 3 Rikers Officials Charged in Brutal Beating of Inmate
text: Two New York City correction officers and a captain were arrested Wednesday on charges that they handcuffed and beat an inmate unconscious with a baton at Rikers Island and then falsified documents to cover it up, the authorities said.

headline: The Tennis Pro’s Daughter
text: For 13 summers, my father worked as the tennis pro at a yacht club on Nantucket.

headline: Sizing Up Black Markets and Red-Light Districts for G.D.P.
text: PARIS — As the spokesman for the National Association of Sex Clubs in Spain, José Roca has fielded all sorts of offbeat inquiries. But rarely has he been more flummoxed than when he received a call late last year from the government statistics agency.

headline: Space Probe Might Lack Nitrogen to Push It Home
text: A do-it-yourself team of engineers trying to lasso an aged but operational NASA space probe may have run into an insurmountable obstacle: Tanks on the spacecraft that were once full of nitrogen gas, needed to fire the thrusters, appear to be empty.

headline: Taxi Commission Blocks Lyft’s Entry Into New York City
text: Looks like those pink mustaches won’t be growing in Brooklyn anytime soon.

headline: Migrants and the Middlemen
text: The largest and arguably most effective antipoverty effort in the world is financed by the poor themselves. Last year alone, migrants in rich countries sent an estimated $404 billion to their families in developing countries. The money pays for daily needs, as well as for health, education and emergencies.

headline: 29 Minutes That Shook Brazil
text: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — It started, innocently enough, in the 11th minute.

headline: Health Insurers Are Trying New Payment Models, Study Shows
text: Health insurers are experimenting with new formulas for reimbursing doctors and hospitals, slowly moving away from the traditional approach of basing payments on the numbers of tests and procedures performed, according to a survey of Blue Cross insurers, among the most dominant plans in the country.

headline: Fleeing Gangs, Children Head to U.S. Border
text: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — Anthony O. Castellanos disappeared from his gang-ridden neighborhood on the eastern edge of Honduras’s most dangerous city, so his younger brother, Kenneth, hopped on his green bicycle to search for him, starting his hunt at a notorious gang hangout known as the “crazy house.”

headline: Campaign Atmosphere Amid Detroit Vote on Debt Plan
text: DETROIT — Until now, this city’s journey through bankruptcy has been a drama played out mostly by lawyers and mediators in courtrooms and conference rooms. But as thousands of city workers and retirees approach a Friday deadline to cast votes on the city’s plan to emerge from debt — a plan that depends in part on cutting their benefits — Detroit has taken on the feel of an all-out election campaign.

headline: An Error Puts a Church on George Carlin Way
text: It took three years for comedians and Catholics to find a mutually agreeable way to rename part of a Manhattan street after George Carlin, the merrily vulgar comic who made religion a frequent target of his acerbic monologues.

headline: LeBron James’s Latest Feat: Bringing a Frenzied League to a Freeze
text: LAS VEGAS — He is the most powerful force in the N.B.A., his imprint extending beyond the four Most Valuable Player awards and the two championships, the endorsement deals and the merchandise sales. In recent days, LeBron James even proved capable of slowing the frenzy of N.B.A. free agency to little more than a crawl, his options spread before him like an all-you-can-eat buffet at the Bellagio.

headline: Race Is On to Profit From Rise of Urgent Care
text: NORWALK, Conn. — Start in Room 4, just beyond the reception area: A man is having blood drained from a bruised finger. Over in Room 1, a woman is being treated for eye trouble. Next door, in Room 2, a boy is having his throat swabbed.

headline: U.S. Naming a Monitor for the Police in Newark
text: NEWARK — The federal government will appoint a monitor to oversee this city’s Police Department as it moves to address longstanding allegations of brutality, discrimination and neglect of civilian complaints, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: A Harsh Climate Calls for Banishment of the Needy
text: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway — As governor of Norway’s northernmost territory, Odd Olsen Ingero commands a police force with just six officers and a single detention cell for an area twice the size of New Jersey. Even that is overkill: Nobody has been locked up here in the capital of Svalbard since last summer. And that was for just two days.

headline: Afghanistan’s Dilemma
text: Abdullah Abdullah, one of two candidates for president of Afghanistan, and his supporters are pushing the country toward a dangerous point by calling the election a coup and threatening to establish a parallel government. He is correct in demanding that charges of rampant electoral fraud be thoroughly investigated. But stoking outrage among his supporters with incendiary language does nothing to ensure a credible and peaceful outcome. The better course is to join his opponent, Ashraf Ghani, in ensuring an outcome that Afghans can believe in.

headline: Saving Water in California
text: California is in the third year of its worst drought in decades. But you wouldn’t know it by looking at how much water the state’s residents and businesses are using. According to a recent state survey, Californians cut the amount of water they used in the first five months of the year by just 5 percent, far short of the 20 percent reduction Gov. Jerry Brown called for in January. In some parts of the state, like the San Diego area, water use has actually increased from 2013.

headline: Donald Sterling Shouts at Wife in Courtroom
text: LOS ANGELES — As the third day of the trial that will determine the fate of the Los Angeles Clippers drew to a close, Rochelle Sterling, the estranged wife of the team’s embattled owner, left the stand and approached her husband, who sat in an aisle seat in the first row.

headline: Reputation for Zeal Precedes Republican Leading New Benghazi Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Trey Gowdy was cutting the grass in the front yard of his Spartanburg, S.C., house when Speaker John A. Boehner called with a special assignment.

headline: Religious Freedom in Peril
text: A Sudanese court in May sentences a Christian woman married to an American to be hanged, after first being lashed 100 times, after she refuses to renounce her Christian faith.

headline: Defense Lawyer Ends Preet Bharara’s Streak in Insider Trading Cases
text: The defense lawyer who spoiled Preet Bharara’s perfect record in hedge fund insider trading cases has finally gotten a haircut.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 9, 2014
text: July 9, 2014

headline: The Rant Agenda
text: So little time, so much bad behavior to complain about.

headline: Chinese Hackers Pursue Key Data on U.S. Workers
text: WASHINGTON — Chinese hackers in March broke into the computer networks of the United States government agency that houses the personal information of all federal employees, according to senior American officials. They appeared to be targeting the files on tens of thousands of employees who have applied for top-secret security clearances.

headline: Senate Committee Presses N.C.A.A., Signaling Interest in Direction of College Sports
text: WASHINGTON — Members of a United States Senate committee on Wednesday took their turn demanding answers from the N.C.A.A., signaling that Capitol Hill has a growing interest in weighing in on the future of college athletics.

headline: Brazilians Grumble and Take Stock After Crushing World Cup Loss
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — As Brazil tried to absorb the shock of its 7-1 loss to Germany in the World Cup, the rout offered a vivid reminder of how the fortunes of the national soccer team can mirror how Brazilians view their society even as other traumas recede into history.

headline: Former Cuomo Aide Hired as Executive at Airport Business
text: ALBANY — Less than two weeks after leaving the public sector, a former top aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has been hired by a travel restaurant and boutique operator doing business at both of New York City’s major airports.

headline: Republicans Say Ex-I.R.S. Official May Have Circumvented Email
text: WASHINGTON — Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official at the center of an investigation into the agency’s treatment of conservative political groups, may have used an internal instant-messaging system instead of email so that her communications could not be retrieved by investigators, Republican lawmakers said Wednesday.

headline: A Not-So-Subtle Meditation on Sugar
text: As people streamed out of the Kara Walker installation “A Subtlety” on a recent Sunday afternoon to buy an ice cream cone from one of the trucks idling outside the old Domino Sugar Factory on the Williamsburg waterfront, I wondered how many thought about the jarring contradiction: paying homage to the bodily harms involved in the harsh industrial process inherent in refining sugar, then consuming the industrial concoction that is a Mister Softee-type ice cream cone.

headline: Reebok Founder Proposes 95-Story Tower With Casino for Jersey City
text: Real estate brokers have long described New Jersey’s gold coast, stretching from Jersey City to Weehawken, as the sixth borough of New York City, where apartments offer the best views of the Empire State Building.

headline: Patchwork Makeup of Rebels Fighting Ukraine Makes Peace Talks Elusive
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — One rebel group, Oplot, comes from the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv. Another, the Russian Orthodox Army, is composed of Russians and Ukrainians. A third, named for a river, Kalmius, is made up mainly of coal miners.

headline: Polls Slow Japan’s Plan to Revise Constitution
text: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, appears to have slowed efforts to expand the role of the military just days after announcing a reinterpretation of the country’s pacifist Constitution, a historic and controversial change.

headline: Obama Administration Defends Israeli Airstrikes but Cautions Against Ground War
text: WASHINGTON — As the fighting between Hamas and Israel intensified, the Obama administration publicly defended Israel’s right to carry out airstrikes to stop Hamas’s rockets while privately cautioning it against ordering a ground attack into Gaza.

headline: Roberto Medina, Founder of Rock in Rio Festival, Takes it to Las Vegas
text: ROBERTO MEDINA, the Brazilian music impresario behind the huge Rock in Rio festival franchise, gazed through the floor-to-ceiling windows of his luxury Manhattan apartment one afternoon recently, looking west over the Hudson River in the direction of his next frontier: Las Vegas.

headline: Prescription Fraud Charges for Prominent Manhattan Dermatologist
text: A Manhattan dermatologist often quoted in magazines and on television was arrested on Wednesday at her Park Avenue office on charges she wrote fake prescriptions for painkillers, using the names of her patients, filled them at pharmacies and kept the pills for her own benefit.

headline: Dish Asks F.C.C. to Block Comcast-Time Warner Cable Merger
text: Dish Network, a satellite television provider, has urged regulators to reject a deal between its rivals that it said would reshape the country’s television and broadband markets.

headline: Staten Island Carjacking Suspect Is Questioned in 2 Killings
text: Detectives on Wednesday were questioning a Staten Island man who was arrested on charges of carjacking a Hummer and trying to ram it into police officers near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, seeking to determine whether he had any connection with two killings in the borough over the weekend, a police official said.

headline: Knicks Continue to Court Him, but Anthony’s Future Is Unclear
text: Carmelo Anthony has offered few clues about his future, and it was more of the same Wednesday when his tenure as a free agent reached eight days.

headline: Ex-Inmate Threatens Columbia’s Paper, Police Say
text: The year was 1972 and the crime was front-page news: a 65-year-old Columbia law professor on his way home was stabbed to death during a mugging. The Columbia Daily Spectator, a student newspaper, published a series of articles on the investigation. Mayor John V. Lindsay called for a citywide manhunt. One of those arrested was Daniel Mingues, a 16-year-old nearby resident, who eventually pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of robbery and was sentenced to up to seven years in prison.

headline: Budget Is Key Test for India’s New Government
text: MUMBAI — As India’s newly elected government prepares its first national budget, the business community is watching whether Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s development-focused campaign promises translate into tangible economic reform.

headline: France Aims to Curb Potential Jihadis From Leaving Country
text: PARIS — Amid international concern over the threat posed by Western jihadis returning from training or combat in Syria, the French government will soon propose legislation authorizing it to block suspected proponents of Islamic terrorism from leaving France, top officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Closing Arguments in Case of Doctor Accused of Overprescribing Drugs
text: Joseph Haeg only saw Dr. Stan Xuhui Li for less than a year, but during that time he transformed from a robust outdoorsman with an old back injury into an unkempt derelict, his speech slurred, his skin pallid, his eyes glassy, a man so addicted to painkillers his sister said she hardly recognized him.

headline: Gee Handcuffs Braves in Return to Help Mets Win Fourth Straight
text: Around mid-May, when Dillon Gee first began rehabilitating his strained back muscle, he decided to grow a beard. Through the rest, the treatment and a setback, and as he worked his way back, he did not shave for two months.

headline: 6 Are Killed in Shooting in Houston Suburb
text: Two adults and four children were killed at a home in a Houston suburb on Wednesday, in a shooting that appeared to have stemmed from a domestic dispute, the authorities said.

headline: Egypt Silent as Neighbors Wage Battles
text: CAIRO — Again and again over decades, Egypt has leapt in to play the role of mediator during hostilities between the Palestinians and the Israelis, including the time two years ago when Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi, helped broker a cease-fire after eight days of bloodshed in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Counterterrorism Chief Stepping Down
text: Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years, a time during which the threat from Al Qaeda shifted from its headquarters in Pakistan to its affiliates in places like Syria, Iraq and Yemen. “Most Americans may not know Matt Olsen’s name, but every American is safer because of his service,” President Obama said in a statement released by the White House. Mr. Olsen has not set a date to leave the job, but it is expected to be in the next few months, after a successor is selected, a spokesman said. The National Counterterrorism Center is the nation’s terrorism information clearinghouse.

headline: U.S. Counterterrorism Chief to Step Down
text: WASHINGTON — Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years, a time during which the threat from Al Qaeda shifted from its headquarters in Pakistan to its affiliates in places like Syria, Iraq and Yemen.

headline: A Natural Beauty Emporium Opens on Nantucket (and Online)
text: In Gaelic, the word follain means “healthy, wholesome and sound.” Follain, a beauty storefront in Boston’s historic South End, lives up to its moniker, stocking all-natural, made-in-the-U.S. products ($10-175) that are both safe and effective. Now, just in time for vacation season, the local favorite has spawned a new seasonal outpost on Nantucket — and, for those who can’t make it to the island this summer, a new e-commerce site.

headline: A Summer Clam Feast at the Long Island Home of the Chef Anita Lo
text: At around 4:30 in the afternoon, when the tide is low on the south shore of Long Island, April Bloomfield, Elizabeth Falkner and Anita Lo carry kayaks down to the water. There’s no path, so they make their own as they go, clearing tall, wild sea grass with the viciously sharp blade of a scythe that Lo picked up in Hong Kong. Then they climb into their boats and glide away. A school of mirrored shiners moves past. Plovers hop around the frothy shore and small, see-through jellyfish float by, but the chefs are not distracted. They came to dig clams for dinner. “This looks good,” Lo says, when they reach a grassy island in the middle of the cove. “Let’s drop our anchors.”

headline: Striking Portraits From Pre-Civil-War Lebanon
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: The Physical Exam as Refuge
text: There are few situations where we expect to disrobe and have our bodies touched by relative strangers. The physical exam is one of the unique characteristics of the doctor-patient encounter; a visit to a doctor doesn’t seem the same without one. Yet, increasingly, there’s less and less of it. Visits are shorter and doctors have to spend most of their time at the computer filling out the endless electronic medical records that have come to define the modern medical transaction.

headline: Word of the Day | disgorge
text: disgorge •\(ˌ)dis-ˈgȯrj\• verb

headline: Dick Jones, Who Gave Voice to Disney’s Pinocchio, Dies at 87
text: Dick Jones, an actor whose face should be more familiar than it is, given the dozens of movie and television roles he played from the time he was a child, but whose boyhood voice — the voice of Pinocchio in the original animated Disney film — remains indelibly memorable, died on Monday at his home in the Northridge section of Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Newest Health Insurance Customers Are Generally Happy
text: We’ve known for a few months now that lots of people signed up for health insurance this year in new marketplaces. A new survey shows that the people who did so are also pretty happy with their purchases.

headline: In Yankee Debut, McCarthy Provides a Needed Lift
text: CLEVELAND — The Yankees’ rotation lost a member on Wednesday, but it officially gained one, too. The newest starter, Brandon McCarthy, debuting hours after the team learned that its ace, Masahiro Tanaka, would be out indefinitely with elbow inflammation, was acquired to complement him — not to replace him.

headline: How to Read the Polls in This Year’s Midterms
text: With four months to go until this year’s midterm elections, perhaps the only thing clear about the fight for the Senate is that it will pose challenges to public polling.

headline: Paul Horn, a Founding Father of New Age Music, Dies at 84
text: Paul Horn, a flutist and saxophonist whose mellow, meditative recordings helped lay the groundwork for New Age music, died on June 29 at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 84.

headline: Rosemary Murphy, 89, Emmy Winner Familiar to Broadway, Dies
text: Rosemary Murphy, an Emmy Award-winning actress long ubiquitous on television, stage and screen, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Three Men Die in Car Crash in East Orange, N.J.
text: Three men were killed in a car crash in East Orange, N.J., on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Seymour Barab, 93, Composer of Playful Operas, Dies
text: Seymour Barab, a composer known for his whimsical chamber operas on such stirring subjects as passion, poison and pizza, died on June 28 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (TLC) LEAH REMINI: IT’S ALL RELATIVE Ms. Remini, above, the former “King of Queens” star who last year left the Church of Scientology after more than 30 years, invites cameras into her home, where she; her husband, Angelo; and their daughter, Sofia, interact — sometimes loudly — with an extended cast of characters including Ms. Remini’s mother and stepfather, her sister and brother-in-law, a nanny, a security guard and a personal assistant. The series begins as an argument leads Ms. Remini and her sister to agree to hold a living funeral for their mother, the better for her to find out what her daughters really think of her.

headline: Corrections: July 10, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 10, 2014
text: “When prosecutors wanted to discuss the case, they asked us to meet at their office, because they were afraid to come here. If they were afraid, imagine us.”

headline: Can American Apparel Be Saved?
text: The struggling clothing brand has reached a deal with New York investment firm Standard General. But will it provide rejuvenation or just short-term stability?

headline: Obama on Immigration
text: After meeting with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, President Obama spoke about the political challenges of resolving the immigration situation.

headline: Cloud Computing Giants Add to Open Source Credentials With Kubernetes
text: A modest and geeky announcement by Google and a couple other big tech names on Thursday may be the summer’s biggest development in a continuing fight over the future of huge global computing.

headline: Student Crossword | The 50 States
text: Test your knowledge of the 50 states by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | This Is Our Youth
text: In “This Is Our Youth,” Gretchen Reynolds writes about a new study about young Americans’ physical fitness.

headline: India Unveils Budget to Lift Economic Growth
text: NEW DELHI — Burdened with extraordinary expectations after a campaign that promised “good days are coming,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s center-right government presented a budget on Thursday aimed at increasing investment, improving infrastructure and reviving manufacturing, though it fell short of the drastic overhauls necessary to rein in spending.

headline: SSP Group, an Airport Food Retailer, Raises About $826 Million in London I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The SSP Group, a food and beverage retailer at airports and train stations, saw its shares climb on Thursday after it raised about $826 million in its initial public offering in London.

headline: On the Sidelines of the Tour de France
text: Covering the Tour de France is not easy. Over three weeks and more than 2,000 miles, photographers have to play a game of high-speed leap the frog with the competitors, racing ahead of the pack as road conditions allow and hoping for a decent shot as the cyclists sweep past them. And then they do it all over again.

headline: A Headbanger’s Headache
text: Dancing at a heavy-metal concert could be bad for your health.

headline: ‘Low-Grade’ Nuclear Material Is Seized by Rebels in Iraq, U.N. Says
text: LONDON — Iraq has notified the United Nations that Sunni militants seized nuclear material from a university in the northern city of Mosul last month as they advanced toward Baghdad, the nuclear regulatory body of the United Nations said Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: L.I.R.R. Strike Primer
text: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: Gaza Deaths Spike in 3rd Day of Air Assaults While Rockets Hit Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Palestinian deaths from Israel’s aerial attacks in Gaza rose sharply on Thursday, while militants there fired more than 180 rockets into Israel, reaching new targets spread across a vast area of the country.

headline: Daily Report: Europe’s ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Ruling Offers Some Companies an Opportunity
text: Days after Europe’s highest court said people could ask search engines to remove some links about themselves, Andy Donaldson started to receive phone calls, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The largest and arguably most effective antipoverty effort in the world is financed by the poor themselves,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Last year alone, migrants in rich countries sent an estimated $404 billion to their families in developing countries.” Known as remittances, these transfers could see a rise in transfer fees as big banks like Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are leaving the money-transfer business. Bankers claim “regulation has become too onerous in the wake of recent settlements over money laundering” connected to remittance transfers. But The Times believes “banks want out because they face dwindling profits from cash transfers. Over the last five years, there has been a successful global effort to lower remittance costs through greater transparency, better technology and other innovations.” If banks can’t profitably transmit remittances, “then other secure, low-cost options must be found.”

headline: How the Rise of Cellphones Affects Surveys
text: Do you know anyone who doesn’t own a cellphone? Just a few years ago, you probably would have said yes, but today, those folks are a small minority. As of December, 7 percent of Americans did not have a wireless phone. And 4 in 10 adults have eliminated their landline and use a cellphone exclusively, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Health Interview Survey. The rise of cellphones has forced a transformation in the polling field.

headline: The Long Journey to Market for an All-Natural Snack Bar
text: In 2007, Kimberly Dobbins was working as director of global recruiting for Morningstar, the investment research company, when she took a paid six-week sabbatical – a perk the company offers its employees – to do some soul-searching. “While I was happy at work, I needed something more in my personal life,” said Ms. Dobbins, who had previously worked in human resources at Goldman Sachs. “I didn’t know if it was volunteering or a hobby.”

headline: Bank of England Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
text: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low as policy makers seek to balance Britain’s robust economic recovery with the need to cool an overheating housing market.

headline: Malwarebytes, an Antivirus Start-Up, Raises $30 Million
text: Marcin Kleczynski didn’t want the money.

headline: Chinese Journalists Warned Not to Work With Foreign Media
text: The Chinese government, which already maintains tight restrictions on the country’s media, has issued new warnings to local journalists not to cooperate with foreign news agencies.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Defender Who Ended Prosecutors’ Streak
text: Daniel M. Gitner, the 43-year-old defense lawyer who finally spoiled Preet Bharara’s perfect record in hedge fund insider trading cases, is nothing if not thorough, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. The insider trading trial of Mr. Gitner’s client, the hedge fund trader Rengan Rajaratnam, which lasted about three weeks, required him and his team to sift through 2.5 terabytes of data, enough to store “War and Peace” about 330,000 times. It was that thoroughness that helped Mr. Gitner rattle the office of Mr. Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.

headline: Eat Your Heart Out, MGM Kitty
text: LOS ANGELES — In the beginning, the logos were little more than pencil sketches, bits of Hollywood heraldry that identify film companies.

headline: Neighbors Who Need Good Fences
text: A quick montage at the beginning of “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” fills us in on what has happened since “Rise of the Planet of the Apes.” Three years have gone by for us in the audience, and about a decade for the assorted primates on the screen. James Franco and millions of other people are dead, victims of a lethal virus and the usual apocalypse-causing disease of hubris. After a period of violence and chaos, the survivors have cobbled together a reasonably stable society in the ruins of San Francisco, with Gary Oldman in charge.

headline: 1964: New Premier Takes Office
text: LEOPOLDVILLE, Congo — Moise Tshombe was sworn in today [July 10] as the Congo’s Premier and immediately ordered the release of an estimated 600 Congolese political prisoners. He also abolished the seven-week-old midnight curfew in Leopoldville. These were the first official acts of the ten-member cabinet after the 44-year-old Mr. Tshombe presented the ministers formally to President Joseph Kasavubu. Removal of the curfew on Leopoldville, imposed seven weeks ago after a rash of bombings, was expected to spark wild celebrations. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 11, 1964

headline: Battle Between 2 State Giants, CCTV and Bank of China, Unravels
text: Morale is low at the state broadcaster China Central Television, after about half a dozen senior personnel there were detained on suspicion of corruption or involvement in major political scandals. Other staffers are said to be too worried about the investigations to work properly or are hampered by a lack of direction from the top, according to employees who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Security Is Tight at Sun Valley Conference
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho – Security has always been tight during the Allen & Company conference in this mountain resort. But this year, the cordon became that much tighter.

headline: Police Detain Party Critic for Role in Tiananmen Commemoration
text: In the end, the Beijing police did exactly what Murong Xuecun publicly requested of them: They detained him for his role in a small commemoration of the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989.

headline: House and Senate Committees Offer Competing Rescue Plans for Highway Fund
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate tax-writing committees on Thursday drafted competing plans to refill a highway trust fund running on empty, setting up a confrontation that could stop work on tens of thousands of infrastructure projects.

headline: From Neophyte to Pit Bull, in a Fun House Mirror of Hip-Hop Mannerisms
text: In the last 18 months, the Swedish rapper Yung Lean — a child of the Internet made real — has evolved from suburban ennui to performance art to straight-up commodity.

headline: Henry Hudson Parkway, 1983
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Kurdish Government Calls on Maliki to Quit as Iraqi Premier
text: BAGHDAD — The Kurdish regional government responded Thursday to harsh criticism from Iraq’s prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, announcing that its ministers would boycott cabinet meetings, demanding an apology to the Iraqi people and calling on Mr. Maliki to step down.

headline: Italian Drug Maker Rottapharm Pulls Planned I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The Italian drug maker Rottapharm said on Thursday that it had decided not to proceed with its initial public offering, citing in part “unfavorable Italian and international market conditions.”

headline: Suspension of a Portuguese Bank’s Shares Shakes the Markets
text: The European markets have been exuberant for months. Propelled by an improving economic climate, investors have been eager to make bold bets on risky assets like Portuguese bonds, Spanish construction companies and Greek banks.

headline: Emmy Nominations Cross a Few Lines
text: IT’S not just network and cable television. It’s everything that’s good on video, as far as the Emmys are concerned.

headline: JPMorgan Hires New Chief for Its Operations in China
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired a top investment banker from UBS to head its China operations, which have been shaken by an anti-bribery investigation into the American bank’s hiring practices in Asia.

headline: New Venture Capital Fund Gives Entrepreneurs a Cut of the Profit
text: Venture capitalists tend to promise lots of advantages when they court technology entrepreneurs, saying they can offer expert advice and a network of contacts.

headline: Final Salute for Firefighter: ‘He Was a Lesson to the Rest of Us’
text: The patches on the mourners’ left shoulders announced a common allegiance: Fire Department, City of New York. But the right shoulders of the thousands of firefighters in dress blues and white gloves who gathered on Staten Island on Thursday morning spoke of their places within this vast city.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Immigration Crisis Continues
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: The Tatiana Maslany Clone Theory
text: Updated, 11:43 a.m. | For the second season in a row, Emmy voters have overlooked Tatiana Maslany of “Orphan Black.” In that sci-fi BBC America series, she plays multiple clones, ranging from a Canadian soccer mom to a German punk, in a performance that seemed tailor-made for at least a nomination. When she was snubbed last summer, the Twitterati were outraged. This year, they’re taking a new tack: pretending she — or one of her clones — was nominated after all:

headline: Possible Asbestos Risk at U.S. Capitol Building
text: WASHINGTON — The House pushed back the start of its session on Thursday over concerns that there was a possible asbetos exposure risk in part of the Capitol Building.

headline: Artists Look Beyond the Arab Spring
text: Egypt’s street artists, with their in-your-face approach, aim for an immediate public response. Other Arab artists are more conceptual about their art projects, referring to current events obliquely. “Here and Elsewhere,” on view at the New Museum, at 235 Bowery, Lower East Side, from July 16 through Sept. 28, features 45 artists from Amman, Beirut, Cairo, Dubai, Ramallah and Sharjah, among other cities. “There are artists looking at conflict and wars, but we did not want to restrict this to the Arab Spring,” said Massimiliano Gioni, the museum’s associate director, who worked with a team of curators. “This is not a show in which the artists are forced to illustrate historic changes.”

headline: The Suddenly Ambitious Co-Worker
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Larry McMurtry: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The Last Kind Words Saloon” says that meth-heads are the worst part of being a bookseller. “Anyone can walk into our bookstore in the age of meth — it’s a constant worry.”

headline: Hieroglyphics That Won’t Be Silenced
text: When the people of Cairo took to Tahrir Square in January 2011 to oust Egypt’s longtime ruler, Hosni Mubarak, the streets exploded with murals and graffiti that both mirrored the revolutionary spirit of the movement and propelled it forward.

headline: In Time-Lapse Videos, the Magic Unfolds
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Robert J. Lang is one of the world’s foremost masters of origami. A former laser physicist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Mr. Lang ditched his day job at a fiber-optics company 13 years ago to devote his life to folding paper. Dozens of his featherweight creations are on display here at the Art Center College of Design: a peregrine falcon and an emperor scorpion, a stag beetle and a bull moose, all fashioned with such skill and lifelike detail, they appear ready to leap off their pristine white pedestals. The complex pieces require days of work and hundreds to thousands of folds. Viewers spend as much time enjoying their beauty as they do marveling at just how these animal figures were made, without cuts or glue, from a single sheet of paper.

headline: Pew Study Finds a Sharp Drop in Reporters at Statehouses
text: The nation’s statehouses have lost more than one-third of the newspaper journalists devoted to covering legislative matters full time, according to a study released on Thursday morning by the Journalism Project at the Pew Research Center.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Natasha Lyonne of ‘Orange Is the New Black’
text: The freshman Netflix series “Orange Is the New Black” racked up 12 Emmy nominations on Thursday, with voters recognizing several cast members of the prison-set show.

headline: Germany Demands Top U.S. Intelligence Officer Be Expelled
text: BERLIN — The German government on Thursday demanded the removal of the top American spy in the country, the strongest evidence yet that mounting revelations about widespread American intelligence operations in Germany have gravely damaged relations between once close allies.

headline: Silent for 50 Games, a Slugger’s Bat Is Booming Again
text: BALTIMORE — To find Nelson Cruz’s locker at Camden Yards, in the far corner of the Baltimore Orioles’ clubhouse, it is best to use caution. On your way there, you will pass an artificial turf putting green, an orange-and-black pool table beneath a Tiffany lamp, a card table with a noisy automatic shuffler and a Ping-Pong table. Paddles and clubs and billiard balls are everywhere.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Jon Hamm of ‘Mad Men’
text: Updated, 10:57 a.m. | With Thursday morning’s nod for best actor in a drama series, Jon Hamm, the star of “Mad Men,” is up to 12 career nominations (some of those were for guest appearances in other shows). But this year was a little different, as the 43-year-old actor  explained by phone after the Emmy announcement was made this morning. He also spoke about the show’s final season,  the last days of his character, Don Draper, and what comes next for him. Hint: he’s not looking very far ahead.

headline: 5 Ways to Teach Kids About Money at the Grocery Store
text: One of the most important lessons for children to learn about money is the difference between wants and needs, but it’s not the kind of thing that you can just impart over the dinner table.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Lizzy Caplan of ‘Masters of Sex’
text: The Emmys usually revisit favorite shows from year to year, but the nominations unveiled Thursday showed there was room for newcomers like the Showtime series “Masters of Sex,” about the pioneering sex researchers Virginia Johnson and William H. Masters in the 1950s and ’60s. Lizzy Caplan is known for comedies like “Mean Girls,” but her first Emmy nomination is for best actress in a drama, for her performance as  Johnson (opposted Michael Sheen as Masters). From her sick bed, Ms.  Caplan spoke by phone about how she didn’t expect to be nominated and why it shouldn’t be a surprise that she should get a nod for drama.

headline: The Sound of Waves Gives Way to Horns
text: Before he moved to New York in the spring for his final two years of medical school, Isaac Boyack had never set foot in the city.

headline: Routing All Travel Through the Cloud
text: Cloud computing and mobile technologies change more things than you think. Besides connecting people and devices, or making software operate together more efficiently, they give companies new ways to seek dominance.

headline: Wheels of Justice Turn Quickly In Bieber Egg Case
text: Justin Bieber’s misdemeanor vandalism case for egging a neighbor’s house has been disposed of swiftly. When Mr. Bieber was charged in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Wednesday he pleaded no contest, and the court handed down its sentence: Mr. Bieber, who was not present at the hearing, will be on probation for two years, The Los Angeles Times reported. He will pay $89,000 in restitution and undergo 12 weeks of anger management therapy. He will also be required to do five days of community service, and must stay away from Jeffrey Schwartz and his family (the former neighbor; Mr. Bieber has since moved) for two years.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Josh Charles of ‘The Good Wife’
text: “This is what time I meant to get up,” said Josh Charles, his voice thick with grogginess, as he fumbled to turn off the alarm on his iPhone. When he’s working, Mr. Charles, ever paranoid that he won’t wake up on time, sets four or five alarms in sequence. This morning, however, he set his alarm for a rather leisurely 10 a.m., New York time, even though he knew the Emmy nominations would be announced 90 minutes before that.

headline: The FTSE 100
text: The FTSE 100

headline: Critic’s Notebook: Who Was Snubbed by the Emmy Nominations?
text: Updated, 1:17 p.m. | You know that the Emmy nominations have gone very much as predicted when the biggest surprise among the major categories is “Downton Abbey.”

headline: A Sangria Study Session in London
text: Sangria recipes are hardly in short supply, but the summer master classes at the Michelin-starred Spanish restaurant Ametsa, located in the London hotel the Halkin by Como, are meant to teach guests how to make three of the best renditions.

headline: The State of Obamacare
text: The Commonwealth Fund has a new study out on Obamacare enrollment, estimating that about 9.5 million people gained coverage through Medicaid and the exchanges; this is roughly in line with some previous estimates but perhaps slightly more encouraging for the law’s supporters. Jonathan Cohn uses the estimate to declare that the law is meeting expectations in covering the uninsured:

headline: Matt Reeves Narrates a Scene From ‘Dawn of the Planet of the Apes’
text: In this video, the director Matt Reeves discusses a tense sequence from “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.”

headline: Steven Cohen Writes a Big Check to the U.S. Government
text: Steven A. Cohen proved to be a stickler for the letter of the law when it came to paying the criminal penalty imposed on his former hedge fund as part of its guilty plea on insider trading charges.

headline: Kerry Assures China That the U.S. Can Have Many Allies in Asia
text: BEIJING — Seeking to put the best face on a difficult relationship with Beijing, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the United States and China could find ways to manage their differences and had more in common than not.

headline: EMR Streaming in Go
text: On our platform teams, we use Amazon’s Elastic MapReduce (EMR) service to help us gather useful metrics from log files. We have processes that capture log files, then compress and push them to Amazon S3 for archiving. This pattern builds up massive amounts of information going back several years and, thanks to EMR, it’s all available to us for data crunching. Initially, we used Python for a lot of the heavy lifting, but over time we came to rely on Go.

headline: South Africa Delays Decision on Parole for Apartheid-Era Killer
text: In one of the most charged cases in South Africa’s struggle to overcome its apartheid past, the authorities on Thursday postponed a decision on whether to parole Eugene de Kock, a convicted death-squad leader widely known as “Prime Evil.”

headline: Sampling Sweet Slices of Memphis Pies
text: Last October, after a quick and gluttonous lunch at Hog & Hominy restaurant in Memphis, I swore I had just eaten the best pie of my life: the Beauregarde, named for Roald Dahl’s gum-chewing brat, a certain Violet whose nasty habit led to her expanding into a giant piece of fruit. It updates the traditionally chunky blueberry pie filling by transforming it into a smooth curd. Supported by a hazelnut-graham cracker crust, the deep purple wedge was topped with a zesty bitter orange marmalade and a scoop of Parmesan ice cream on the side.

headline: A Second Canal for Central America — or a Pipe Dream
text: The Panama Canal may have competition. The Central American isthmus will be home to yet another transoceanic conduit slated for completion by 2019, according to a news brief from the PanAm Post.

headline: Wheelies: The Ciao Bella Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Times Critics’ Guide to ‘Planet of the Apes’
text: In the 46 years since the first “Planet of the Apes” film hit theaters, eight critics for The New York Times have weighed in. Highlights below:

headline: 1939: Finnish Fascists Lose Election
text: HELSINGFORS — Finland’s Fascists suffered the most spectacular defeat in their history in the general election concluded in Finland recently. They lost seven of the fourteen seats they had previously held in the Finnish Parliament. The defeat came on the heels of a ban in 1938 against the patriotic national movement, the Fascists’ organization in Finland, by the Finnish Minister of the Interior, M. Kekkonen. The general election brought new adherence to the democratic government coalition, comprising Socialists, Farmers and Liberals, who will constitute three-fourths of the new Diet. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 11, 1939

headline: It Takes a Team to Make a Company Grow
text: This interview with David Ossip, chief executive of Ceridian, a human resources and payroll company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: We Tell Kids to ‘Go to Sleep!’ We Need to Teach Them Why.
text: We tell children why it’s important to eat their vegetables. We tell them why they need to get outside and run around. But how often do we parents tell children why it’s important to sleep? “Time for bed!” is usually the end of it, or maybe “You’ll be tired tomorrow.” No wonder children regard sleep as vaguely punitive, an enforced period of dull isolation in a darkened room. But of course sleep is so much more, and maybe we ought to try telling children that.

headline: Hollywood Box Office, Then and Now
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Entertainment Business Is Now on an Upbeat” appeared on July 5 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Man Being Held in Killing of Six in Houston
text: A 33-year-old man was being held Thursday on six counts of murder after the police said he shot four children and two adults inside a house in a Houston suburb as part of a domestic dispute.

headline: Emmys 2014: The Nominees and Winners
text: Winners are in bold. (The full list of nominees and winners is available at the Emmys website.)

headline: Screwball Tragedy
text: Today most pitchers don’t throw the screwball because of the widespread belief that they are going to get hurt. We wanted to find out if that fear is justified.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pizza for Everyone!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Mystery of the Vanishing Screwball
text: Hector Santiago of the Los Angeles Angels was sitting at a restaurant table in Glendale, Ariz., in March, holding an orange in his left hand. He formed a circle with his thumb and forefinger, then spread his remaining fingers around the fruit with half an inch between each one. He was demonstrating how he throws his screwball, which is the best in baseball mostly because nobody else has one.

headline: Wrongfully Convicted Man Takes $3 Million Settlement
text: A man who spent 15 years in prison for a Brooklyn murder he did not commit agreed to a $3 million settlement approved on Thursday with New York State, one of the largest such settlements in recent history.

headline: Where Older People Are Gloomy About Their Health
text: Older Americans’ perceptions of their health and their quality of life vary significantly from region to region, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: It’s Up, and It’s ... Five Feet Taller
text: BALTIMORE — Football fields are 360 feet long and 160 feet wide, but when it comes to the goal posts, every inch counts.

headline: U.S. Penalizes Firm It Calls a Front for Hezbollah
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration leveled sanctions on Thursday against a Lebanon-based company it called a front for the Shiite militant group Hezbollah. It said the firm was used to buy equipment for surveillance drones flown over Syria and Israel.

headline: A Villa Near the Mediterranean in Caesarea, Israel
text: The seven-bedroom house, on the market for $4,396,377, is in a village between Haifa and Tel Aviv.

headline: Weinshall to Become New York Public Library’s Chief Operating Officer
text: Iris Weinshall, a former transportation commissioner and university vice chancellor, has been named the chief operating officer of the New York Public Library, the library is to announce Thursday.

headline: Germany on Allegations of U.S. Spying
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel and Clemens Binninger, a member of Merkel’s party, discussed the investigation of suspected spying by the United States in Germany.

headline: House Hunting in ... the Czech Republic
text: A MODERN APARTMENT IN A MEDIEVAL BUILDING IN PRAGUE

headline: In Urbanization Update, U.N. Sees Tokyo Atop Megacities List Until 2030
text: The United Nations Population Division has completed the 2014 revision of its continuing survey of urbanization, “World Urbanization Prospects.” Interestingly, despite Japan’s shrinking population, Tokyo not only remains atop the list of biggest cities, with close to 38 million people in its metropolitan region, but is expected to stay there through 2030, with Delhi close behind by then, according to the new analysis. There’s a useful set of country profiles to explore.

headline: House Republicans Resume Efforts to Reduce Fed’s Power
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans frustrated by the Federal Reserve’s expansive economic stimulus campaign and its growing role as a financial regulator are renewing their efforts to constrain the central bank.

headline: The Women of the 1 Percent
text: With the incomes of the wealthy elite rising rapidly in recent decades, three economists looked at income data from Canada and the United Kingdom to see if women were sharing in these gains.  Their new analysis, published today, reveals that the proportion of women in the top 1 percent has been increasing but that they have made few gains at the very top of the income distribution.

headline: Living With Cancer: Parting Gifts
text: Being in a cancer support group eventually means losing a friend. On the first day of November, Leslie informed the six of us that she would not attend our next meeting: “I am so tired and I think all the tricks and treats are done.”

headline: ‘Side Show’ Producers Discussing a Move to Broadway
text: Broadway producers and theater owners are in talks about a possible transfer of the musical “Side Show” to New York as early as this fall, following its critically acclaimed run at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, according to three theater executives involved with the production.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Couture Shows
