text: A peek at what some of the gals in Paris were wearing.

headline: What to Do About Banco Espirito Santo of Portugal
text: Lisbon needs to sort out Banco  Espírito Santo – fast. Despite a recent successful rights issue, Portugal’s second-largest bank by value has a troubled major shareholder and a large exposure to shaky Angolan loans. With Portuguese bond yields up 40 basis points since July 7 and domestic bank shares tanking, a speedy restructuring is needed.

headline: Satya Nadella Says Changes Are Coming to Microsoft
text: Updated, July 17 | Microsoft announced that it would cut up to 18,000 jobs, which accounts for almost 15 percent of its work force.

headline: Crumbs Cupcakes May Live Another Day
text: It’s not over for the Crumbs cupcake yet.

headline: France Is Not an Anti-Semitic Nation
text: PARIS — FEW democratic societies are as rich in populations of diverse origins as France’s. This is one of the many traits France shares with the United States. Both are countries of immigrants where citizenship is universal and does not depend on one’s ethnic or religious origins.

headline: FIFA Rejects Suárez’s Appeal of 4-Month Ban
text: A FIFA appeals committee on Thursday rejected motions filed by Luis Suárez and Uruguay’s soccer federation that had sought to overturn or reduce his four-month suspension from soccer for biting another player.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Allison Tolman of ‘Fargo’
text: “That whole sort of fatgate thing” is how Allison Tolman refers to the tempest in an online teapot that erupted on Twitter last month, after she called out weight-shamers for describing her as fat. Happily for her, the spotlight is back on her acting prowess, with an Emmy nomination for her performance as Molly Solverson, the plainspoken deputy in the FX series “Fargo.”

headline: Myanmar Court Sentences Journalists to Prison and Hard Labor
text: MANDALAY, Myanmar — A provincial court in Myanmar on Thursday sentenced the head of a weekly newspaper and four of its journalists to 10 years in prison and hard labor for publishing a report that said a vast and secretive government factory was designed to produce chemical weapons.

headline: Seven Die, Including 3 Children, in Massachusetts Fire
text: BOSTON — Officials in Lowell, Mass., said Thursday that seven people — three of whom were children — died in an early morning fire that sent nine others to hospitals and left dozens homeless.

headline: TRW Automotive Gets Preliminary Takeover Offer
text: Updated, 2:30 p.m. |

headline: Obscure Rule Restricts Health Law’s Expansion of Care for Addicts
text: EAST HAZEL CREST, Ill. — On its surface, the Affordable Care Act seems like a boon for addiction treatment centers like the South Suburban Council on Alcoholism and Substance Abuse, housed in a no-frills former hotel outside Chicago.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell to Rejoin ‘The View’ on ABC
text: “The View” will reach back to its higher-rated, but more contentious, past with the addition of its former host Rosie O’Donnell to a reconstructed cast next fall.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Trove of Hebrew Books From Centuries Past
text: The Chabad-Lubavitch movement, a Hasidic group known for its outreach to Jewish communities around the world, has amassed one of the largest collections of rare Jewish manuscripts and books anywhere – on the order of 250,000 items, including some that go back to the 11th century or earlier.

headline: The Secret Life of a Soccer Star
text: Britain has James Bond. Gotham City has Batman. Who would the Hispanic market’s hero be? “We’d have an L.A.-based soccer player who’s a spy by night, that’s who,” Roberto Orci, the Mexican-born writer and executive producer of “The Amazing Spider-Man 2,” said recently.

headline: The Calculus Behind Imagery
text: “I use systems in order to provoke the issues around representation,” the Los Angeles artist Charles Gaines has said. His early drawings, the focus of “Charles Gaines: Gridwork 1974-1989” at the Studio Museum in Harlem, resemble math-based artworks by Sol LeWitt and other pioneering conceptualists.

headline: The Bolshoi, Packing Heat
text: This season’s programming may not be the most progressive, but in the spirit of feverishly passionate ballet, the Bolshoi brings its big guns to the David H. Koch Theater. As part of the Lincoln Center Festival, the company presents “Swan Lake” on Tuesday with David Hallberg — the first American to become a permanent member of the Bolshoi — and the gloriously willowy Svetlana Zakharova. After “Swan Lake,” which runs through next Sunday, are “Don Quixote” (July 22 and 23) and “Spartacus” (July 25 to 27). Since the productions lean toward the musty side — Yuri Grigorovich, the company’s former artistic director, choreographed both “Swan Lake” and “Spartacus” — it might be best to focus on the dancers. Along with Mr. Hallberg and Ms. Zakharova, there is the young Olga Smirnova, who performs “Swan Lake” opposite Semyon Chudin  next Saturday and next Sunday, and the boldly enticing Maria Alexandrova as Kitri in “Don Quixote” on July 22. As for “Spartacus”? It pretty much rains men. Leave your umbrella at home. (Tuesday through July 27; 212-721-6500, lincolncenterfestival.org.

headline: The Greening of Verdi’s Jester
text: Will Crutchfield’s Bel Canto at Caramoor series, held each summer at a genteel Westchester County estate, has proved a recurring highlight of the season. Next Saturday, Mr. Crutchfield, again leading the excellent Orchestra of St. Luke’s, offers Verdi’s “Rigoletto,” starring Steven Powell in the tragic role, the tenor John Osborn as the Duke of Mantua and Georgia Jarman as Gilda. Before each performance, there is a rewarding afternoon lineup of recitals by young artists and lectures by visiting scholars.

headline: Stepping In, Out in Front
text: It used to be called the Sammy Hagar Conundrum and lately has been rebranded as the Arnel Pineda Provocation: What to do when your favorite band takes to the road, and the recording studio, with a new person out front singing? This is an especially perplexing circumstance for fans of Queen, whose frontman, Freddie Mercury, died in 1991, and left a long shadow — in voice and attitude — that few would even try to fill.

headline: Unraveling a Dark Family Secret
text: I was 21 years old and sitting with my grandmother in her parlor as she knitted a heavy winter blanket. It was the middle of the summer in Israel, and that blanket made me sweat just looking at it. I was pretending to read, but really my head was on fire.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Anna Chlumsky of ‘Veep’
text: Anna Chlumsky is in Williamstown, Mass., rehearsing for the world premiere of “Living on Love,” a play about an opera diva (Renée Fleming), her maestro husband, and the ghostwriter who comes between them (Ms. Chlumsky), at the Williamstown Theater Festival. “I’m on a 10-minute break,” Ms. Chlumsky said by phone. Plenty of time to discuss her Emmy nod as a supporting actress in the HBO comedy series “Veep,” in which she plays Amy, the sharp but set-upon assistant to the vice president (Julia Louis-Dreyfus, also an Emmy nominee). It’s her second nomination in two years.

headline: Justice Dept. Declines to Investigate C.I.A. Review
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has declined to pursue dueling claims by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee, which had accused each other of criminal behavior related to the committee’s investigation of the agency’s interrogation practices, the department said on Thursday.

headline: Marching Bands, Kierkegaard and Other Musical Influences
text: My Brightest Diamond

headline: Dropping the Mask, With Egos in Check
text: The creators of the British electro-soul collective Jungle may have many self-taught skills, but dancing on roller skates is not one of them. When the duo released their celebrated EP “The Heat” last fall in their native Britain, they took an enigmatic route, keeping their faces and names under wraps. The video for the title track featured a pair of synchronized skaters in tracksuits. Confusion ensued.

headline: False Starts Before Cable’s Golden Age
text: In the golden age of the high-class cable drama, it’s easy to forget that no cable channel started its life with such fare. HBO and Showtime? Movies. AMC? Old movies. USA? Sports. ABC Family? Pat Robertson.

headline: In U.S. Data, a Baffling Contradiction
text: The first quarter of this year was the worst for the United States economy since the depths of the Great Recession in early 2009.

headline: Guiding and Gliding, the Urban Bush Women
text: From their debut in a Manhattan loft 30 years ago this month, in a dance performance that Jennifer Dunning called “deeply affecting and stylishly produced” in The New York Times, the Urban Bush Women have gone on to win awards, tour internationally and take part in cultural diplomacy for the State Department.

headline: From Baby Fat to Stubble: Growing Up in Real Time
text: The first shot in “Boyhood,” Richard Linklater’s tender, profound film, is of a cloudy sky. The second is of a boy staring up at that sky, one arm bent under his head, the other flung out straight on the ground. He’s a pretty child with calm eyes, a snub nose and a full mouth. It’s a face that you get to know and love because, even as this child is watching the world, you’re watching him grow. From scene to scene, you see the curve of his jaw change, notice his thickening brows and witness his slender arms opening to embrace the world and its clear and darkening skies.

headline: Feet Planted on a Choreographic Riddle
text: At the beginning of every project, the choreographer Tere O’Connor asks himself a basic question. As he said recently over coffee near his West Village apartment: “What am I doing? What is dance trying to do?”

headline: Look East, West and Inward
text: ISTANBUL — On a recent evening here, young people tossed Frisbees on the grassy lawns of an American-style college campus, while elegantly clad patrons sipped wine before a concert featuring the soprano Diana Damrau and the harpist Xavier de Maistre.

headline: Homesick Strangers Among Us
text: “We’re the unknown Americans,” says a character in Cristina Henríquez’s second novel, “the ones no one even wants to know, because they’ve been told they’re supposed to be scared of us and because maybe if they did take the time to get to know us, they might realize that we’re not that bad, maybe even that we’re a lot like them.”

headline: Unlikely Warriors
text: I have to confess — my love of elephants made me apprehensive to review a book about their role in World War II. But as soon as I began to read “Elephant Company,” I realized that not only was my heart safe, but that this book is about far more than just the war, or even elephants. This is the story of friendship, loyalty and breathtaking bravery that transcends species.

headline: The Fault in Our DNA
text: In his 2007 book “A Farewell to Alms,” the economic historian Gregory Clark argued that the English came to rule the world largely because their rich outbred their poor, and thus embedded their superior genes and values throughout the nation. In her comprehensive takedown, the historian Deirdre N. McCloskey noted that Clark’s idea was a “bold hypothesis, and was bold when first articulated by social Darwinists such as Charles Davenport and Francis Galton in the century before last.” Indeed, over the past 150 years, various white Western scientists and writers have repeatedly offered biological explanations for Caucasian superiority. They have repeatedly failed because, as Mc­Closkey noted, none ever mounted a credible quantitative argument.

headline: The Settlers
text: On a trip to Lusaka, Zambia, last year, I kept chasing an energetic and jittery Chinese man, the only staff member of a Chinese mining company willing to talk to me after his firm had been involved in several scandals in which both Chinese and Zambian employees were either killed or injured on the job. Zambia, with its abundant copper ore deposits, is one of the most important investment destinations for China. His English was excellent, and he liked to talk — and talk. After telling me about how much he loved the country and its people, he sometimes went into a rant about how Zambian miners liked drinking and money too much, and did not like to work hard. It was that mentality, he continued, that had caused his company all its troubles (not the workplace-safety and low-pay grievances of which it was accused). But even though the Zambian government had repossessed his company’s mines, this man wasn’t leaving. He was now working as an interpreter for the government.

headline: Wedding Q. & A.
text: Invitation to an Etiquette Disaster

headline: André Greipel Wins a Sprint at the Tour de France
text: REIMS, France — Just when it looked as if Marcel Kittel might win all of the sprint finishes at this year’s Tour de France, another German sprinter, André Greipel, was first across the line at the end of the 194-kilometer (120-mile) stage form Arras to Reims on Thursday.

headline: As Gold and Gambling Lose Their Luster, Deadwood Seeks a Spark
text: DEADWOOD, S.D. — This old Western town of gunfights and gambling is going through an identity crisis.

headline: Direct From the Acme Animation Co.
text: He wasn’t famous for chomping on carrots, outsmarting hunters or painting realistic tunnels on the sides of mountains, but Chuck Jones was as important to the history of animation as Bugs Bunny or Wile E. Coyote. Jones spent the 1930s through the 1960s directing many of the most manic and inventive Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts featuring those beloved Warner Bros. characters; he went on to direct and produce more ambitious animation before his death in 2002.

headline: Betting on Diesel Cars, Exxon Is Set to Expand Belgium Refinery
text: LONDON — At Dimitris Poliviou’s car repair shop, customers are increasingly turning up with diesel-powered vehicles.

headline: Google Launches European Venture Fund
text: LONDON — In a sign that Europe’s tech scene is coming into its own, Google announced that its venture capital unit had started a $100 million fund to invest in the region’s start-ups.

headline: In China, Four Seasons of Design
text: Isabelle Pascale, founder of the boutique Wuhao in a preserved corner of Beijing, showcases the work of contemporary Chinese and Western designers.

headline: Obama’s FunnyorDie.com Video Nominated for Emmy
text: President Obama may have a future in Hollywood. The FunnyorDie.com video starring Mr. Obama and Zach Galifianakis was nominated for an Emmy on Thursday in the category of short-format live-action entertainment programs.

headline: Brazil’s BTG Pactual to Acquire Reinsurer
text: SÃO PAULO —  BTG Pactual of Brazil announced on Thursday that it was buying Ariel Re, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda and London, from the Global Atlantic Financial Group, a privately held insurance company that was spun off from Goldman Sachs in 2013.

headline: Rowin’, Rowin’, Rowin’ on the River
text: IF you want a workout that’s strenuous, frightening, frustrating, thrilling, exhausting, challenging and serene all at the same time, try rowing in an eight-oared boat on the Harlem River.

headline: A Fugitive Who Stops to Smell the Flowers
text: “Road to Paloma,” a leisurely drama about family, brotherhood and Native American rights, plays out on the dusty highways and barren landscapes of an American West that seems frozen in time. Using that quality to powerful effect, the director, Jason Momoa, and his cinematographer, Brian Andrew Mendoza, shore up a simple plot with a richly atmospheric palette of coppery light and caramel sunsets that makes even urgent events seem almost soothing.

headline: Cancer Sidelines Japanese Composer
text: The Japanese composer and keyboardist (and, occasionally, actor) Ryuichi Sakamoto posted a note on his website on Thursday saying that he has throat cancer, and has decided to cancel his performances at the Sapporo International Art Festival of which he is the guest director.

headline: In Rubble of Gaza Seaside Cafe, Hunt for Victims Who Had Come for Soccer
text: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip — About a dozen local Palestinians gathered Wednesday evening at the Fun Time Beach cafe, a beachside eatery of plastic chairs, umbrellas, walls of cloth and palm leaves, a container for a kitchen and a small bathroom, to watch the World Cup match between Argentina and the Netherlands.

headline: A Spectacle of Pop Idol Proportions
text: There’s a moment of giddy self-declaration (O.K., one of many) in the splatter canvas of pop pageantry that is Katy Perry’s “Prismatic World Tour.” It comes during “This Is How We Do,” a flippant anthem of consumption featured in one of Ms. Perry’s recent commercials for a major cosmetics brand. On Wednesday night, in her sold-out show at Madison Square Garden, its staging involved an inflatable car, a riot of neon Lycra and a flotilla of parade balloons, including one for the emoji pictograph widely known as “smiling pile of poo.”

headline: Hidden Pleasures Lie Within
text: If you ask, the patient people at Khao Kang will identify the dozen unlabeled dishes on the steam table for you, but this will not necessarily help. Their one-word descriptions (“shrimp,” “chicken” and, repeatedly, “pork”) tell nothing of the layers of flavor, surprises and comforts to be found here, in one of the sincerest Thai restaurants in New York City.

headline: For One Team, It’s Sink or Swim
text: Four teenagers winning an academic contest might not seem to merit a documentary. Happens all the time, right? But in “Underwater Dreams,” the teenagers are Latinos — and illegal immigrants, four of the many who could gain citizenship through the Dream Act — from a low-income high school in Arizona. They win against many colleges, including M.I.T., in a robotics challenge. And their unlikely achievement, in 2004, reverberates a decade later, helping the students who followed them at Carl Hayden Community High School to have more confidence and even, in some cases, propelling them to work as engineers and as leaders in Dreamer groups.

headline: Reform Conservatism and the Culture War
text: After my foray yesterday into the specific case of Paul Ryan, let me return to broader critiques of reform conservatism, picking up threads from E.J. Dionne’s long essay on our little movement and some of Andrew Sullivan’s comments this week. I first read Dionne’s essay some time ago and intended a long point-by-point rejoinder; I’ve read so many (far harsher, less thoughtful) critiques since, however, that upon re-reading the essay seemed marvelously fair-minded, and worth recommending even if I obviously have disagreements with its substance. But here’s a prescriptive passage that’s worth commenting on:

headline: Don’t Bring That Boyfriend Home
text: Folding social realism into a woman-in-peril thriller, “Honour” confronts the problem of so-called honor killings among British Muslims with brash economy and first-feature zeal.

headline: Field of Misfits
text: The story of the Portland Mavericks could slip easily into the same lineup as “Bull Durham” or “Major League”: A baseball outsider starts an independent team in Oregon, holds open tryouts that draw castoffs and rejects, then watches his wild bunch beat more talented clubs.

headline: The Car That Witnessed the Spark of World War I
text: A century ago, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir apparent to the Austro-Hungarian throne, and his wife, Sophie, the duchess of Hohenberg, were killed in Sarajevo while riding in a Gräf & Stift open-topped touring car. It was the event that ignited World War I.

headline: Backsliding Into Brutality to Avenge a Daughter
text: Those expecting Nicolas Cage theatrics in “Rage” — and why not, with a title that practically cries out for a rhyming tagline — may be disappointed. Mr. Cage underplays in his latest role, as a father out for justice after his daughter’s violent death, and it’s at least an attempt at a change-up. But the hand-me-down showiness and sluggish storytelling by the director, Paco Cabezas, underline the monotony in this ordinary revenge thriller.

headline: A Smitten Boy Senses an Opening and Seizes It
text: Washed in the colors of surf and sand, and moving to the languid rhythms of swaying palm trees, “The Empty Hours” is like a mental vacation from the noise and bombast of the summer blockbuster. No convoluted plot or high-wattage star distracts from its meandering observations and mellow performances; no crass jokes or car chases disrupt its delicate, yearning mood. In other words, this second feature by the Mexican director Aarón Fernández is a delight.

headline: Sarah Palin’s Impeachment Plan, Rejected
text: Sarah Palin’s argument—if one can call it that—in Breitbart a few days ago that it’s “time to impeach” President Obama isn’t gaining much traction among Republicans with actual power. Andrew Kaczynski of BuzzFeed has pulled together quotes from elected officials with no interest in trying to add Mr. Obama to that exclusive club composed of Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton (Richard Nixon was not actually impeached). What’s notable is that their lack of interest is entirely practical—i.e. they won’t say the president doesn’t deserve impeachment, only that it’s not going to happen.

headline: Guys With Lots of Mileage, on the Road
text: The road movie, that asphalt playground of fast cars, masculine prerogative, gangland sprees and occasional feminist cri de coeur, is such a durable American genre that you can fly the idea halfway around the world, drop it on Iceland, rev up a car the size of a military tank and still make it work. This pretty much describes what happens in “Land Ho!,” a delightful tale of two longtime friends of a certain age, Colin (Paul Eenhoorn) and Mitch (Earl Lynn Nelson), who embark on a classic journey of self-discovery generously embellished with laughter, otherworldly beauty and philosophical inquiries into the nature of existence perfumed by the aroma of cheerfully smoked joints.

headline: Collecting Books That Are Just Covers
text: Anything that looks like a book but is not one interests Mindell Dubansky, a preservation librarian at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For 20 years, she has been buying antiques with simulations of covers, spines and pages.

headline: With the End of Days Near, a Sect Is Torn
text: “As It Is in Heaven” opens quietly yet with unmistakable joy as the camera tracks a white-robed young woman through gracious rooms and lush gardens to the banks of a sparkling river. Joining the other members of her small religious sect, she watches their prophet (John Lina) baptize a new recruit (Chris Nelson) and give him the name David.

headline: Britain’s Schindler, a Reluctant Hero
text: In 1988, the BBC program “That’s Life!” aired an episode dedicated to Sir Nicholas Winton, a British stockbroker who rescued 669 mostly Jewish children from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia in 1939. In the wake of Sir Nicholas’s 105th birthday last May, a segment from that episode went viral.

headline: Candidates Raise Specter of Cheating in Indonesian Presidential Election
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Political tensions in Indonesia rose on Thursday, a day after the country’s hotly contested presidential election, as the supporters of the two candidates raised fears about possible cheating during days of vote tallying.

headline: If You Read This, You Might Never Drink a Latte Again
text: Lattes have a lot to answer for. To some, drinking one makes you a snob. To others, it makes you a spendthrift. But neither of these perceptions may be particularly accurate — and in fact, the latte can tell us a lot about how America thinks about food, work and money.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Evidence of H.I.V. Found in a Child Said to Be Cured
text: A child in Mississippi who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. with aggressive drug treatment immediately after birth is now showing signs of infection with the virus, federal health officials announced Thursday — a serious setback to hopes for a cure for AIDS.

headline: That First Step Is a Doozy
text: On New Year’s Eve, four despondent Londoners determined to end it all simultaneously converge at a favorite suicide destination atop a tall building. After jockeying for position (who goes first?), followed by some perky commiseration, they agree not to hurl themselves into oblivion but to postpone their rendezvous with death until Valentine’s Day, at which point they will return and make the leap. In the meantime, they form a cheery mutual support group, meeting here and there around London and even traveling together to Spain.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Yemen, Gaza City, India and Spain.

headline: Fighting Trash and Noise at Park’s Weekly Revelry
text: Responding to complaints from residents tired of the raucous behavior and piles of trash left behind in northern Riverside Park, the New York City parks department on Thursday announced a plan to deal with the problem through stepped-up enforcement and additional cleanup crews.

headline: In Spanish Language, With Women’s Voices
text: Across Latin America, girls celebrate their 15th birthday as their quinceañera, the beginning of young womanhood. So it was appropriate that intrepid, idealistic women — Ana Tijoux, from Chile, and Danay Suárez, from Cuba — were the standouts at the first concerts of the 15th annual Latin Alternative Music Conference, which continues through Saturday. It presents rock, pop and hip-hop, often bilingual, from across the Americas at free concerts and club events.

headline: Sex-Role Reversals in Sondheim
text: “Our Time,” the opening number of KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnar’s iconoclastic Stephen Sondheim show at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesday evening, is the optimistic dawn-of-a-new-age anthem from “Merrily We Roll Along.” It’s the 1950s, and there are nothing but blue skies and bright futures ahead in the lives of its naïve musical-theater hopefuls gazing forward with starry-eyed confidence.

headline: Funeral Held for New York Firefighter
text: Thousands of uniformed firefighters gathered for the funeral of Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, who died Saturday searching for victims in a burning high-rise apartment building in Brooklyn.

headline: Birth of a Career
text: I am 11 years old. Practically every adult I meet asks me, “What do you want to be when you grow up?” This would be really cute if I was 4 and could say, “Fireman.” But I’m in the fifth grade and have no idea what I want to do for work 10 years from now. How can I respond that won’t get me in trouble with my parents?

headline: Unlikely Tenants Filling a Neighborhood Vacancy
text: In 2009, when a bad economy left commercial spaces vacant across New York City, an itinerant nonprofit art group called No Longer Empty started filling some of them — a storefront on West 23rd Street, the closed-up Tower Records on lower Broadway — with art. This summer, the organization adds a twist to its mission by working on premises that have yet to be occupied, an in-progress 13-story affordable-housing complex called the Sugar Hill Building located on West 155th Street in Washington Heights.

headline: Scant Interest in F.H.A. Program
text: A government program aimed at helping “underwater” homeowners refinance into more-affordable, reduced-principal loans has captured only a sliver of the borrowers thought to be eligible in the four years since its introduction.

headline: Devil Swipes a Violin, but the Band Plays On
text: “Feather Gatherers,” part of the Ice Factory festival, a wellspring of singular drama, unfurls in some fantastical Serbia of the mind, a Slivovitz-soaked realm of peasant blouses and folk superstitions. Produced by the Drunkard’s Wife, an experimental theatrical troupe, and loosely adapted from Stravinsky’s dance-theater piece “L’Histoire du Soldat,” this bleary, madcap musical tells the story, more or less, of a naïve soldier (Jess Barbagallo) who falls prey to the wily Devil (Juliana Francis Kelly).

headline: Daniel Heidkamp
text: The three main shows at White Columns form a meditation on current painting tactics. In one small gallery, Patrick Berran very capably meets the demand for Minimalist paintings made by largely hands-off methods — in his case, layers of photocopy transfers dominated by a pattern that reads as leopard skin or moisture condensation, depending on its size. Nearby, Jennifer Nichols works with thin, bright acrylic, creating abstract tumults of transparent brushwork and, more recently, calmer arrangements of letterlike shapes. Both artists show promise, but so far they are operating within fashionable styles rather than making the work that only they can make.

headline: Long Days, Extra Innings
text: New art books include textured dreamscapes by Lee Bontecou and full-size reproductions of Charles M. Schulz’s “Peanuts.”

headline: Knud Lonberg-Holm: ‘The Invisible Architect’
text: The Danish-American architect Knud Lonberg-Holm, the first European to teach the Bauhaus curriculum in America, belonged to that white-hot, manifesto-propelled moment in the 1920s when de Stijl principles were being translated into three-dimensional space. A dozen of his limpid gouache renderings of Michigan houses, all masterly compositions of point, line and plane, show buildings broken into constituent walls, roofs, floors and columns. With a palette of photographic black, white and gray, accented in blues and reds, he created weightless abstractions; solids and voids intersect in optical puzzles. He brushed calligraphic proposals for the new streamlined building types of the Machine Age — gas and radio stations — with a fierce graphic energy. His radically angled photographs of America’s traffic jams, skyscrapers, fire escapes and power lines found their way into “Amerika,” the German architect Erich Mendelsohn’s photographic essay of American cityscapes. Letters from Theo van Doesburg, Walter Gropius and Mies van der Rohe authenticate his position as a peer. Buckminster Fuller wanted to write a book about him.

headline: Eileen Ford, Grande Dame of the Modeling Industry, Dies at 92
text: Eileen Ford, the grande dame of the modeling industry who influenced standards of beauty for more than four decades while heading one of the most recognizable brands in the trade of gorgeous faces, died on Wednesday in Morristown, N.J. She was 92.

headline: Amy Poehler Explains What’s Funny About Sweden
text: Will Ferrell’s wife is Swedish. Aubrey Plaza once dated a Swedish exchange student. Patrick Duffy is a big star in Sweden because of “Dallas.” Illeana Douglas appears in “Easy to Assemble,” a web series for Ikea, the Swedish home-furnishings company. Gene Simmons likes Swedish women.

headline: A Pilot’s 1938 Flight of Doom and Memory
text: PHILADELPHIA — The choreographer Matthew Neenan has created ballets across the United States. In 2009, he was the grand-prize winner in Sacramento Ballet’s Capital Choreography Competition; I’ve seen premieres by him in Vail, Colo., and Memphis.

headline: This Weekend | What to Watch on TV
text: Alessandra Stanley, a television critic for The Times, previews three new series.

headline: Questions and Answers About India’s New Budget
text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s new government in India has unveiled its first economic road map aimed at increasing investment, improving infrastructure and reviving manufacturing, even while curbing borrowing. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the economy would expand at an annual rate of 7 to 8 percent within three years, but warned that the global slowdown had created a difficult environment for growth. The plan received a mixed reception.

headline: A Place of Serene Excitement, Inside and Out
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — In a time of hubristic museum expansionism, the beloved if rather fusty Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute here has managed something distinctly surprising: It has gotten bigger and better.

headline: Savory Lanes That Are So Not Food Courts
text: REAL New Yorkers don’t do malls. Or amusement parks, unless they’re a little decrepit and dangerous. Or food courts, unless they’re crowded and ethnic. Or street fairs, unless they’re right outside and can’t be avoided.

headline: A River Runs Through It: The Amazon as Inspiration
text: “Waterweavers: The River in Contemporary Colombian Visual Arts and Material Culture” at the Bard Graduate Center is the most unassumingly beautiful show I’ve seen in New York this summer. And with its glades of abstract patterning, eddying pools of woven fiber, and projected images of water sluicing through galleries, it’s visually the coolest.

headline: Harps vs. the Usual Hubbub
text: Members of the New York Philharmonic departing in a bus after a concert Wednesday evening in Prospect Park’s Long Meadow were saluted with cheers and waves, like a triumphant soccer team leaving a stadium. The event, conducted by Alan Gilbert, was the opener in the orchestra’s free parks concerts series, and the police estimated that it drew 15,000 people.

headline: If Gatsby Were Coming of Age Today ...
text: “Affluenza” begins in September 2008, as an investment banker (Roger Rees) blathers to the protagonist, Fisher (Ben Rosenfield), about a “going-out-of-business sale” for the baby boomers. He quotes Rudyard Kipling on the law of the jungle and tells Fisher, an aspiring photographer, that his pictures capture the decline of a generation of overindulged kids.

headline: Ashes to Ashes, Dust to Powder
text: At the grassy summit of a low hill outside the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., the metal cargo containers of two 14-foot box trucks rise vertically like twin towers, their cabs buried underground. It’s a sculpture called “At Least They Died Together (After Dash)” (2013-14), by Dan Colen, and it’s a memorial to his friend Dash Snow, who died of a drug overdose in 2009. It appears as an incongruous eyesore against the backdrop of its bucolic surroundings. Visitors may notice that the thin skins of the truck boxes have holes in them. During the exhibition’s opening, Mr. Colen threw rocks and hammers at them, while drummers of the two-person band I.U.D. — one atop each of the truck ends — played thunderously.

headline: Many Sacrifices, but Few Perks for Event’s Volunteers
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The day after Brazil lost to Germany in the host country’s worst World Cup loss ever, thousands of volunteers slipped on their official teal blue shirts, slid on their official dark pants and perhaps pulled the brim of their official hats down low to head to another day of working at this event, which began last month as the nation’s pride but is now its raw humiliation.

headline: The Talk of Sun Valley (It’s Not Just About Deals)
text: Updated, 6:47 p.m. | SUN VALLEY, Idaho — It may be hard to believe, but the Allen & Company conference isn’t just about hushed merger talks in side rooms or on the golf course.

headline: Good News in High Places
text: President Obama may have a future in Hollywood.

headline: Obama and Immigration
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Top 10 Moments of Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Couture Week
text: The fall 2014 women’s couture shows, which began Sunday, wrapped up yesterday in Paris. From the fashion to the haute joaillerie to the off-the-runway star sightings, these were some of the season’s most memorable moments.

headline: Stanley Fischer Urges Congress to Expand Fed’s Mandate
text: Stanley Fischer, the Federal Reserve’s new vice chairman, said on Thursday in his first public remarks that regulators had made “significant progress” in improving the resilience of the financial system.

headline: Soccer in Brazil, and Outside the World’s Glare
text: Mauricio Lima went to remote villages, up the river and even to a prison, to document his countrymen’s passion for the sport, and their lives, during the World Cup.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, show times and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: An Illustrated Guide to Eccentric Baseball Pitches
text: Bruce Schoenfeld’s article on the all-but-extinct screwball piqued my curiosity: Are there any other marginalized pitches out there on the brink of falling off the table, as they say of a particularly nasty split-fingered fastball? As it turns out, there are. And the gyro-ball and the Trekkie, to name two, could borrow a bit of the limelight being cast on the screwball in this weekend’s magazine. So I asked Jason Polan, an illustrator with experience drawing a screwballer, to interpret some of these pitches for us. Catch, in no particular order:

headline: Movie Listings for July 11-17
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Cleveland Hopes LeBron James Does Not Break Its Heart Again
text: CLEVELAND — The city that leads with its chin has jutted it out there one more time. In a sort-of, maybe, please-don’t-hit-me-again fashion.

headline: Despite a Pledge by Samsung, Child Labor Proves Resilient
text: DONGGUAN, China — After work, the three teenage girls giggle and pull at one another’s hair. But when questioned, they admit their common secret: They use false papers to work illegally here at the factory that makes mobile phone components for one of the world’s biggest brands, Samsung.

headline: Break the Immigration Impasse
text: AMERICAN citizens are paying 535 people to take care of the legislative needs of the country. We are getting shortchanged. Here’s an example: On June 10, an incumbent congressman in Virginia lost a primary election in which his opponent garnered only 36,105 votes. Immediately, many Washington legislators threw up their hands and declared that this one event would produce paralysis in the United States Congress for at least five months. In particular, they are telling us that immigration reform — long overdue — is now hopeless.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Urg. Glug. Mmph. My head feels like it’s stuffed with oatmeal.

headline: Despite Exposure of Madoff Fraud, New Ponzi Schemes Emerge
text: When the money was rolling in from investors, Scott W. Rothstein, a lawyer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., bought his wife, Kimberly, more than $1 million in jewelry, including an opulent 12-carat yellow diamond ring. He lived in a multimillion-dollar waterfront mansion and regularly wrote big checks to charities and politicians.

text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Questcor Reveals Adverse Events Data for Acthar for First Time
text: For years, Questcor Pharmaceuticals has highlighted the potential benefits of Acthar, its immune-system drug, while saying little about its ill effects.

headline: Barcelona’s Cannabis Culture
text: In Barcelona, government officials worry that Barcelona’s members-only cannabis clubs are becoming a magnet for marijuana tourism.

headline: Marijuana Clubs Rise Out of Decades-Old Spanish Laws
text: BARCELONA, Spain — On a recent evening, two vacationing German college students, armed with addresses they had gotten off the Internet, were trying to get into one of Barcelona’s new marijuana clubs.

headline: Tracking Sun Valley’s Most Wanted Guest: Marissa Mayer
text: Updated, 8:20 p.m. | SUN VALLEY, Idaho — Ask many attendees — and certainly everyone in the press corps — assembled at the Allen & Company conference here who was the guest with the most buzz, and the list of potential answers will almost certainly include Marissa Mayer.

headline: Let ’Em Eat Dirt
text: In the tardy twilight of a Puget Sound evening, we caught a glimpse of a boy, maybe 6 or 7, playing in mud exposed by low tide. Ankle-deep in vibrant muck, he called out a discovery to his father.

headline: U.N. Finds Most People Now Live in Cities
text: UNITED NATIONS — More than half of humanity now lives in cities, and even more will soon. The world will have to confront how to make cities more fit for human habitation.

text: ‘The Greek Monsters’

headline: Suit Against Obama to Focus on Health Law, Boehner Says
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s lawsuit against President Obama will focus on changes to the health care law that Mr. Boehner says should have been left to Congress, according to a statement issued Thursday by the speaker’s office.

headline: Crack Down on Scientific Fraudsters
text: DONG-PYOU HAN needed impressive lab results to help his team at Iowa State University move forward with its work on an AIDS vaccine — and to continue receiving millions of dollars in federal grants. So Dr. Han did what many scientists are probably tempted to do, but don’t: He faked the tests, spiking rabbit blood with human proteins to make it appear that the animals were responding to the vaccine to fight H.I.V.

headline: Why Congress Keeps Ignoring Its Own Budget Law
text: WITH all the crazy things that have happened with the federal budget in recent years — the fiscal cliff, government shutdowns and sequesters — it’s hard to imagine that in some ways the situation was worse 40 years ago.

text: To the Editor:

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: World Cup, en Español
text: Soccer is a universal language during the World Cup. But increasing numbers of non-Spanish-speakers say they watch the games on Spanish-language television for the colorful commentary.

headline: Tanaka Has Small Tear in Elbow and Will Rehabilitate It, for Now
text: CLEVELAND — The Yankees put their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, on a plane to Seattle on Thursday to have his ailing right elbow examined, and then there was nothing else they could do but hope.

headline: How to Answer the Fears of a Palestinian Mother
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shadowy Rebel Wields Iron Fist in Ukraine Fight
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Late one afternoon last month, as separatist militia fighters and Ukrainian forces exchanged fire, a small-time thief by the name of Aleksei B. Pichko left his home on the southern edge of Slovyansk and headed for an abandoned residence at 17 Sadovaya Street. He had been drinking, and wanted to “see what could be stolen from there,” according to documents recovered at the rebel headquarters after their retreat over the weekend.

headline: Form, Function and Beauty Span Eons in Met Acquisitions
text: Objects have long been considered a poor cousin to paintings, but not at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where two recent acquisitions spanning centuries and civilizations were as functional as they were decorative. One is an early Roman vessel used as a cinerary urn; another, a group of 20th-century Venetian glass designs by the Italian architect Carlo Scarpa, was on view last winter.

headline: The Art of Water Recovery
text: Imagine that you run a company that sells bottled water. You spend lots of money, and use lots of energy, pumping the water out of the ground, purifying it and transporting it for sale. Then, one day, you discover that a large number of bottles never make it to the stores. They are falling through holes in the trucks.

headline: Q. and A.: Rana Mitter on the Legacy of World War II in Asia
text: When Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke at an event in Beijing on Monday commemorating the 77th anniversary of the start of full-scale war with Japan, he warned against efforts to downplay Japan’s brutal occupation of China. It was a stark reminder of how the events of that era continue to shape the geopolitics of Asia today, as China and Japan square off over territorial disputes and Beijing voices concern about Japan’s moves to lift  longstanding restrictions on its military forces.

headline: Grim Search on a Gaza Beach
text: Two brothers were among at least eight people killed by an Israeli airstrike while gathered on a Gaza beach to watch the World Cup. A third brother was missing.

headline: Texas’ No. 1 Democrat May Be No. 2 on Ballot
text: It is easy to find people inside and outside the Texas Democratic Party who think State Senator Leticia Van de Putte of San Antonio, the party’s nominee for lieutenant governor, will outperform Wendy Davis, who’s running for governor, in November.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Amazon Sued Over Billing for App Store Purchases
text: Settling isn’t the Amazon way, whether the dispute is with book publishers or the federal government.

headline: Sheep Power at a San Antonio Solar Farm
text: SAN ANTONIO — The landscapers at a 45-acre solar farm northeast of downtown do not complain that they are paid only in shrubbery. After about three months, the bleating crew has kept the grounds well maintained.

headline: Whether Wretched or Inspired, Title Match Often Provides a Jolt
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Apart from Germany, the Champagne fizz has suddenly gone flat at a World Cup that was being hailed earlier as the best in recent memory.

headline: U.N. Proposal Fails to Ease Crisis Over Disputed Afghan Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With the viability of the Afghan government at stake, a new plan by the United Nations to ease the deepening presidential election crisis here appeared to falter nearly as quickly as it was proposed, posing a new obstacle to resolving the dispute just hours before Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here early Friday.

headline: Natural Gas Pipeline Plan Creates Rift in Massachusetts
text: NORTHFIELD, Mass. — Standing on a dirt road outside his aging barn, Walter Jaworski, a former veterinarian turned cattle rancher in this rural part of north-central Massachusetts, points south across his 200 acres of forest and pasture to a nearby tree line. If things don’t go his way, he says, that’s about where a new natural gas pipeline will slice through his land on a 180-mile journey from central New York to a transmission hub north of Boston.

headline: Homeland Security Secretary Testifies
text: Jeh Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, spoke before the Senate Appropriations Committee on President Obama’s emergency appropriations request to deal with the border crisis.

headline: G.O.P. Pushes Back on Approving Border Funds
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans pushed back Thursday at President Obama’s request for nearly $4 billion to help stem the surge of young migrants from Central America to Texas and to deal with the humanitarian crisis there, signaling that they expected concessions for their legislative approval.

headline: Google to Tour Europe to Discuss Privacy
text: LONDON — Google is about to start a grand tour of Europe.

headline: Federal Trade Commission Complaint Against Amazon
text: Amazon’s mobile store, the suit states, introduced the ability to bill customers within an application — so-called in-app charges — in November 2011, and did so without parental notifications or password requirements in children’s games.

headline: Posing a Problem at the Tour
text: REIMS, France — Seeing the Tour de France in person usually involves waiting around, sometimes for hours, to catch a glimpse of riders that often lasts for seconds. Now some people are going through all that trouble to turn their backs on the race.

headline: Who Wants a Depression?
text: One unhappy lesson we’ve learned in recent years is that economics is a far more political subject than we liked to imagine. Well, duh, you may say. But, before the financial crisis, many economists — even, to some extent, yours truly — believed that there was a fairly broad professional consensus on some important issues.

headline: Commitment in Texas to Fiscal Restraint Adds Burden for Education
text: Stacked up against other states, Texas public schools have consistently ranked among the bottom five nationally in per-student spending. And even with a growing population of economically disadvantaged and English-language learning students, some performance measures are on the upswing.

headline: New Envoy for Syria Appointed
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Thursday that he had appointed Staffan de Mistura, a veteran diplomat of Italian-Swedish heritage who has led United Nations missions in Iraq and Afghanistan, to be the new special envoy responsible for seeking an end to the conflict in Syria. Mr. Ban said Mr. de Mistura, whose appointment had been expected by other diplomats, would be working to stop “all violence and human rights violations, and promoting a peaceful solution to the Syrian crisis.” Mr. de Mistura’s predecessor, Lakhdar Brahimi, resigned two months ago in frustration. He had replaced Kofi Annan, the former secretary general who called the Syria job “mission impossible.” Mr. Ban also said that he had appointed Ramzy Ezzeldin Ramzy, an Egyptian diplomat, as Mr. de Mistura’s deputy.

headline: Events in Connecticut for July 13-19, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Baseball or Soccer?
text: Is life more like baseball, or is it more like soccer?

headline: Bahrain: Opposition Under Fire
text: The government on Thursday charged two leaders of Bahrain’s largest opposition group with illegally meeting an American official, escalating a feud with the United States that began after the official, Tom Malinowski, was expelled from Bahrain this week. Mr. Malinowski, the assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights and labor, was ordered to leave after Bahrain’s government, an ally of the United States, accused him of interfering in the country’s affairs by meeting with members of the opposition group, al-Wefaq. Khalil al-Marzooq, one of the leaders, said he and Sheikh Ali Salman, the group’s secretary general, were questioned by prosecutors on Thursday about their talks with Mr. Malinowski.

headline: Despite Silence From Anthony, Jackson Is Confident in Knicks’ Chances
text: LAS VEGAS — Phil Jackson emerged Thursday afternoon from the cocoon of silence known as the N.B.A.’s free agency moratorium with an announcement: He had no news.

headline: Early Returns on Health Care Reform
text: It will take a while to understand fully how the Affordable Care Act affects the quality of health care and access to doctors in this country. But a new survey offers encouraging reviews from people who signed up for private plans or Medicaid during the first enrollment period from October 2013 through March 2014.

headline: Spree of Violence Ends With Murder Charges
text: The violent crimes piled up with a rapidity rarely seen in the bedroom communities of Staten Island: a gunpoint robbery ending in a killing; a second killing several miles away; and a carjacking of a Hummer sport utility vehicle nearby.

headline: Lawsuit Contends Surveillance Database Is Too Lax on Reporting Criteria
text: WASHINGTON — Intent on not overlooking clues about any terrorist plots after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the government spread a now-familiar slogan: “If you see something, say something.” Less visibly, it built a national database to better harness reports of suspicious activity in the hunt for terrorists.

headline: Once Again, Art in Russia Carries Moral and Political Overtones
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The “white nights” are an enchanting time in “Piter,” when darkness never falls and a carnival atmosphere settles over the grand palaces, canals and broad Neva. Between the rock concerts, sailing regattas, river cruises and palatial museums bursting with brilliant exhibitions, a visitor longs to forget the struggle in Ukraine and all the jingoism and repressive politics that increasingly shape the image of Russia in the West.

headline: Bahrain’s Bad Decision
text: Bahrain would seem an unlikely country to expel a senior American diplomat on a trumped-up complaint, since the Persian Gulf state is home to the United States Navy’s Fifth Fleet and depends on America for its defense, especially against Iran. Yet the government did just that, forcing Tom Malinowski, the State Department’s assistant secretary for human rights, to cut short an official visit on Tuesday because he met with members of an opposition party. Then on Thursday, it compounded the error by charging the leader of Bahrain’s biggest opposition group with holding an illegal meeting with Mr. Malinowski.

headline: Kerry to Join Talks on Iran as Deadline Draws Near
text: VIENNA — With the Vienna negotiations over Iran’s nuclear activities making halting progress at best and a deadline looming, the Obama administration announced Thursday that Secretary of State John Kerry would fly here this weekend to assess whether a deal is possible — and perhaps to begin negotiating an extension in the talks that both sides said they had wanted to avoid.

headline: Lockheed in Deal to Cut Costs of F-35s
text: Lockheed Martin and two of its biggest suppliers agreed on Thursday to invest up to $170 million of their own money to help lower the high cost of the new F-35 fighter jets.

headline: The Internet for All
text: Do Internet providers need to be more closely regulated to assure wider access to lower-income people?

headline: Agencies Set Sights on Marketing for a Cause
text: COMPANIES that hope to do well by doing good are getting another option as the largest division of the world’s largest agency holding group forms a practice devoted to advertising efforts that include cause-related marketing, sustainability and corporate social responsibility, which are aimed not only at consumers but also at employees, policy makers, thought leaders and Wall Street.

headline: Cancer Survivors Apply Tenacious Spirit to Bay Cleanup
text: The waters of Flushing Bay, within view of La Guardia Airport, are some of the more polluted around New York City. The bay has poor circulation, and during heavy rainfalls sewers spew raw waste into the water from nearby homes and businesses.

headline: Killing of Palestinian Youth Puts an Israeli Focus on Extremism
text: JERUSALEM — Even as the Israeli public offers strong support for airstrikes on Hamas fighters and their weapons stocks in Gaza, there is a good deal of reflection over the coldblooded killing of a Palestinian teenager that helped lead to the latest increase in violence.

headline: A History of the Jackson, Miss., F.B.I. Office in Documents
text: Documents from J. Edgar Hoover, then the director of the F.B.I., and other top bureau officials show the speed and haste given to setting up the Jackson, Miss., field office in 1964.

headline: A Provocateur’s Book on Hillary Clinton Overtakes Her Memoir in Sales
text: Of all the headaches of her current book tour — the declining sales, the constant travel, the interviews that generated unkind headlines about her family’s wealth — this one may sting Hillary Rodham Clinton the most: Her memoir, “Hard Choices,” has just been toppled from its spot on the best-seller list by a sensational Clinton account by her longtime antagonist Edward Klein.

headline: Despite Earlier Loss, U.A.W. Creates Union at VW Plant
text: In an unorthodox move, the United Automobile Workers announced on Thursday that it was forming a union local in Chattanooga, Tenn., to represent workers at the Volkswagen plant there even though a majority of the plant’s workers voted in February against joining the union.

headline: Pakistan Claims Win Against Militants Along Afghan Border, but Enemy Slips Away
text: MIRAM SHAH, Pakistan — A solitary donkey wandered through the deserted streets of this once-bustling tribal town of 100,000, but no other inhabitants were to be found 10 days after Pakistani troops backed by tanks and helicopter gunships seized control.

headline: Scary Little Sucker
text: Administrivial Cruciverbal Magic Update! Hey, remember that David Kwong puzzle from March 18 that flummoxed us so? The one that turned out to be connected to Mr. Kwong’s TEDx talk? With an interview with Will Shortz that wound up on the TEDBlog? Well, the entire performance is online now at the TED website, and you can enjoy it here.

headline: Sony Threatens to Bypass Licensers in Royalties Battle
text: A month after the Justice Department said it would review the decades-old regulatory agreements governing the music licensing agencies Ascap and BMI, the world’s biggest song publisher has threatened to end its relationship with those groups if the changes it wants are not made.

headline: Rumor and Leaks Fill a Void as Israel Silences Press Over Killings
text: Israeli intelligence officials used gag orders in recent weeks to stifle reporting on the initial investigations into both the abduction and the killing of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank, and the apparent revenge killing of a Palestinian teenager in East Jerusalem.

headline: Science Journal Pulls 60 Papers in Peer-Review Fraud
text: A scientific journal has retracted 60 papers linked to a researcher in Taiwan, accusing him of “perverting the peer-review process” by creating fraudulent online accounts to judge the papers favorably and help get them published.

headline: Available Soon for People Needing ID: City-Issued Cards
text: If a police officer asks him for identification, Juan Carlos Gomez, an undocumented immigrant from Colombia, has nothing to show. He often cannot rent an apartment for lack of documentation; a friend has to do it for him.

headline: Judge Gives I.R.S. a Month to Explain Lost Emails
text: A judge on Thursday gave the Internal Revenue Service until Aug. 10 to explain under oath how it lost emails that Republicans are seeking as part of their investigation into accusations that the agency targeted conservative groups.

headline: F.B.I. Honors Office Opened Amid Struggle for Civil Rights
text: JACKSON, Miss. — After President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act in July 1964, civil rights was the last thing he wanted to talk about. He feared that being associated too closely with the issue would make him appear too liberal for voters coming into that fall’s presidential election.

headline: Phone Call Between Lyndon B. Johnson and J. Edgar Hoover
text: Listen to a phone conversation between J. Edgar Hoover and President Lyndon B. Johnson regarding the death of the civil rights workers in Mississippi and the need to reopen the Jackson, Miss., F.B.I. office.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: No Charges in Killing of Driver After Chase
text: A Secret Service officer and Capitol Police officer will not be charged in the shooting death of Miriam Carey, who last October led officers on a car chase from the White House to the Capitol before crashing, the United States attorney’s office for the District of Columbia said Thursday. A statement said that federal prosecutors found insufficient evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the officers used excessive force. Ms. Carey, 34, of Stamford, Conn., drove into a White House checkpoint and then hit a Secret Service officer. After a chase, two officers opened fire on her vehicle. Her child, who was also in the car, was uninjured.

headline: Massachusetts: Decision on Health Site Expected
text: Officials will know by early August whether the state can move forward with its own retooled health exchange or join the federal marketplace. The state’s Health Connector sputtered last fall when it was updated to meet the requirements of the Affordable Care Act. In May, officials said they would simultaneously improve the state’s exchange with new software and prepare to join HealthCare.gov if they could not get the Connector working properly. The leadership at a Thursday board meeting of the Connector said that, after a successful demonstration of the new software, federal officials told them to continue the dual-track approach until early August, when a decision will be made.

headline: Season-High Winning Streak Ends as Mets Fall to the Braves
text: Terry Collins clearly had something to say. For months, he had subtly danced around the subject. On Thursday, finally, he had some ground to stand on. The Mets had run off their longest winning streak of the season and their bats had come alive, against the rival Atlanta Braves no less.

headline: In the Language of Romance, Romeo Santos Is a True Superstar
text: Pink Floyd’s “The Wall” couldn’t do it, Jay Z got help from Justin Timberlake and Eminem, and Metallica didn’t try. Selling out consecutive shows at Yankee Stadium, with its capacity of roughly 50,000, is nearly impossible for any pop music artist not named Paul McCartney. But Romeo Santos, who will perform there Friday and Saturday nights, is about to achieve that feat.

headline: Yankees’ Future Hinges on a Troubled Elbow
text: This is not about 2014 anymore. The Yankees will not and cannot say that, but it is the truth. Masahiro Tanaka was the only player keeping this season from sinking, and now he has a partial tear in his ulnar collateral ligament.

headline: Judge Rules G.O.P. Illegally Redrew Florida Districts
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In a sharply worded decision, a Florida judge ruled late Thursday that Republicans illegally redrew the state’s congressional districts, saying they “made a mockery” of an amendment meant to inject fairness into a process that has long been politically tainted.

headline: A Preview of the World Cup Final
text: Germany and Argentina are set to meet in the final match of the 2014 World Cup on Sunday. Here’s what to look for.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 10, 2014
Immigrants Who Speak Indigenous Languages Encounter Isolation
text: Laura is a Mexican immigrant who lives in East Harlem, a neighborhood with one of the largest Latino populations in New York City. Yet she understands so little of what others are saying around her that she might just as well be living in Siberia.

headline: Hasidic Williamsburg, as Seen by One Who Left Sect
text: On a recent sunny Monday, a bespectacled young woman stood at Broadway and Marcy Avenue, a Brooklyn crossing where hipsters, Hispanics and Hasidim mingle in a way that defines Williamsburg in 2014: a chic coffee shop near a Caribbean restaurant near a group of bearded men wearing black hats.

headline: Through the Haze at the Carnegie Club, It Sounds Like Sinatra
text: If Mark Twain could not smoke in heaven, he promised he wouldn’t go. A more companionable afterlife might have been spent at the Carnegie Club Cocktail and Smoking Lounge in Manhattan, where at least he could linger in peace as he pondered the 40 cigars listed on the menu.

headline: Top Dining Destinations in Paris During Couture Week (or Any Week)
text: Couture week in Paris offers an ideal excuse to indulge in the city’s food, which is at times as extravagant as the confections on the runways. Here, a few of T’s senior market editor Malina Joseph Gilchrist’s most memorable recent meals from the last several days in the City of Light.

headline: These Fruits Were Made for Grilling
text: On the Fourth of July, before the meat and fish hit the grill, I decided to throw on some fruit. I’ve always loved the way roasting summer stone fruit like peaches and apricots deepens their flavors, and I thought a sizzle on the grill might do the same. It did. Just a few minutes on each side – enough to create griddle marks on a peach or an apricot and soften it, but not so long that the fruit collapses, brought out the juices and warmed the fruit through. When I removed the peaches and apricots from the grill I tossed them with a little honey and lemon zest.

text: retrograde •\ˈre-trə-ˌgrad\• adjective and verb

headline: Brooklyn Officer Shoots Man Who Fled Traffic Stop, Police Say
text: A police officer reassigned to Brooklyn as part of the city’s Summer All Out campaign shot a man who drove his S.U.V. through a red light and who ran over another officer in the middle of a busy road, the police said.

headline: Errie Ball, Welshman Who Played in First Masters, Dies at 103
text: It was late March 1934, a spring Sunday in Augusta, Ga., the last round of the first Masters golf tournament. Errie Ball stood on the edge of the third green. He had traveled farther than most to get there.

headline: Ted Steeg, Who Found Big Audience With Jury Duty Films, Dies at 84
text: Ted Steeg, a documentarian whose best-known films have been seen by millions of cursing, carping, cranky, choleric and incontrovertibly captive audience members, died on July 7 in Manhattan. Mr. Steeg, who produced the informational movies long shown to prospective jurors throughout New York State, was 84.

headline: Letter from Amazon to the F.T.C.
text: In a letter dated July 1 and addressed to Edith Ramirez, the F.T.C. chairwoman, Andrew DeVore, associate general counsel of Amazon, criticized the agency’s “unwillingness to depart from the precedent it set with Apple.”

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords. This Disney 3-D animated movie musical produced “Let It Go,” the Oscar-winning power anthem, written by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez, on seemingly every child’s (and quite a few adults’) lips since its release in November. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a handsome prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace atop a mountain, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. “Allegorically, ‘Frozen’ lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like ‘Beauty and the Beast,’ but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.” “There are moments when you may feel that you are inside a giant crystal chandelier frosted with diamonds.” Josh Gad plays Olaf, the snowman sidekick (above, with Anna and Kristoff, voiced by Jonathan Groff) who would rather be a beach bunny, in this Oscar winner for best animated feature.

headline: In China, Super Boys Learn to Say, ‘I Am Myself’
text: The young men are in the throes of early adulthood. Most are single children, the products of state family-planning policies. Some are from broken homes, or were treated harshly as children, others spoiled. Battling each other for the No. 1 spot in “Super Boy,” an “American Idol”-style TV talent show, they discover who they are and learn to love others in a process recorded in a new documentary by Fan Lixin, who was named by The New York Times last year as one of “20 Directors to Watch.”

text: Brazil lost its World Cup semifinal match to Germany by a devastating 7-1 score. The Netherlands lost its game against Argentina in a penalty shootout after 120 minutes of tense scoreless play.

text: Updated, 10:17 p.m. | Hoping to combat a decades-long slump in smoking, two of the biggest American tobacco companies said on Friday that they were in talks to merge and create a $56 billion cigarette colossus.

headline: China’s Central Bank Investigates Report of a Bank’s Money Laundering
text: BEIJING — China’s central bank is investigating a report by state television that a major Chinese bank is helping clients transfer large amounts of money overseas in a program that violates currency controls, Xinhua, the state-run news agency, said Friday.

headline: The Post-Post-Apocalyptic Detroit
text: In downtown Detroit, at the headquarters of the online-mortgage company Quicken Loans, there stands another downtown Detroit in miniature. The diorama, made of laser-cut acrylic and stretching out over 19 feet in length, is a riot of color and light: Every structure belonging to Quicken’s billionaire owner, Dan Gilbert, is topped in orange and illuminated from within, and Gilbert currently owns 60 of them, a lordly nine million square feet of real estate in all. He began picking up skyscrapers just three and a half years ago, one after another, paying as little as $8 a square foot. He bought five buildings surrounding Capitol Park, the seat of government when Michigan became a state in 1837. He snapped up the site of the old Hudson’s department store, where 12,000 employees catered to 100,000 customers daily in the 1950s. Many of Gilbert’s purchases are 20th-century architectural treasures, built when Detroit served as a hub of world industry. He bought a Daniel Burnham, a few Albert Kahns, a Minoru Yamasaki masterwork with a soaring glass atrium. “They’re like old-school sports cars,” said Dan Mullen, one of the executives who took over Quicken’s newly formed real estate arm. “These were buildings with so much character, so much history. They don’t exist anywhere else. And it was like, ‘Buy this parking garage, and we’ll throw in a skyscraper with it.’ ”

headline: Soccer in Brazil, and Outside the World’s Glare
text: Mauricio Lima has been in Brazil for the World Cup. Not exactly at the games, mind you, but going deep into the hearts — and jungles — where love of the game sustains and thrills (at least until the Brazilian team’s loss this week to Germany). He has ventured to a floating village where children kick improvised soccer balls along narrow docks, to a prison where inmates make balls, to an amateur tournament where teams and beauty queens compete together and to indigenous villages that are an overnight boat ride away from the nearest World Cup match.

headline: Mota-Engil Africa Pulls London I.P.O. Amid European Market Jitters
text: LONDON — Market jitters have claimed another initial public offering in Europe.

headline: Guangxi Officials Told to Stay Sober (on the Job, at Least)
text: The rules read like something imposed on a fraternity under double-secret probation. But as People’s Daily, the mouthpiece of China’s Communist Party, explained on Friday, they are meant for officials in the southern region of Guangxi. Officials there now face a list of restrictions on consuming alcohol that are meant to prevent them from reaching embarrassing and even dangerous levels of intoxication.

headline: Voting in China, a Distant Dream
text: BEIJING — I am 54, but have never in my life seen an election ballot.

headline: Israeli Leader Calls for ‘Full Force’ in Effort to Quell Hamas Rocket Attacks
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that his forces were fighting Hamas with “increasing intensity” to quell its rocket barrages from Gaza, ignoring outside criticism and calls for restraint in the increasingly deadly Israeli aerial assaults. Even as he spoke, Palestinian militants fired salvos into central and southern Israel and said their arsenal had barely been dented.

headline: Morning Views
text: “Bahrain would seem an unlikely country to expel a senior American diplomat on a trumped-up complaint,” writes The New York Times Editorial Board. “Yet the government did just that, forcing Tom Malinowski, the State Department’s assistant secretary for human rights, to cut short an official visit on Tuesday because he met with members of an opposition party.” The Board clarifies that the expulsion as well as a subsequent charge against the opposition group “raise doubts about the willingness of the ruling al-Khalifa family, members of the Sunni minority, to find a compromise with the Shiite majority, which is demanding democratic reforms and a bigger role in governing.” The Board calls Bahrain’s moves “outrageous” and, should Bahrain and the United States fail to resolve its differences, predicts “disastrous consequences for Bahrain, its neighbors and the United States since the last thing the volatile region needs is more sectarian divisions and instability. So far, the Obama administration, which has worked to maintain ties with the monarchy despite human rights concerns, has responded weakly. It must go further to show that such behavior is unacceptable.”

headline: From Twitter, a Growing Collection of Communicative Conservationists
text: A Facebook post by the environmental journalist John Platt directed me to an excellent Twitter list of — at last count — 89 conservation biologists, journalists, educators and other people focused on using new communication tools to foster wildlife conservation and animal welfare. The list was assembled by the editors of The Dodo, a website tracking biological wonders (the sea turned black by shoals of anchovies) and issues (the use of bullhooks on circus elephants) that arise when Homo sapiens interacts, for good or ill, with other animals.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: ‘Go Ahead, Girls, Take a Break From Your Values’
text: Season 2, Episode 11 We’re pushing toward the apocalypse here – or at least, the season finale – so it feels appropriate that we’ve got a crusading nun leading the charge. After resisting the hunger strike, Sister Ingalls has finally reignited her passion for protest and become its most ardent participant. She would seem to lend gravitas to this fledgling movement, especially as the other new recruits can’t decide on their demands. Soso and Yoga Jones want the black bathrooms fixed, restrictions on segregation, and an end to the “compassionate release” policy that dumped poor demented Jimmy on the street. Leanne and Angie want more dessert, field trips and visits from musical acts like Johnny Cash.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week Five | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In The Times this week: news about the crisis caused by the tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors who have crossed into the United States this year.

headline: Don’t Laugh: Berkeley Plans to Give Free Marijuana to the Poor
text: Earlier this month, Berkeley’s City Council voted unanimously for an ordinance that would provide free medical marijuana to patients with low incomes. If the ordinance passes its second reading in August, marijuana dispensaries will have to set aside 2 percent of their product — which must be of equivalent quality to the marijuana they’re selling at market prices — and give it free to city residents with incomes below $32,000.

headline: Morning Agenda: Global Stock Markets Shaken
text: GLOBAL STOCK MARKETS SHAKEN | The European markets have been exuberant for months, with investors eager to make bold bets on risky assets like Portuguese bonds, Spanish construction companies and Greek banks. But investors received a jolt on Thursday when shares of Portugal’s second-largest bank, Banco Espírito Santo, were suspended from trading, prompting fears that the bank might need to be rescued, Landon Thomas Jr. and Peter Eavis write in DealBook. The move sent highflying stocks and bonds in Portugal plummeting, forced two Spanish companies to suspend bond offerings and brought concerns over the health of Europe’s banking system.

headline: Uber, Lyft and a Road Map for Reinventing the Ride
text: When the hail-by-smartphone car service Uber and its competitors make news, it is usually for something like the raucous protests against them by cabdrivers across Europe, or for bizarre incidents like the (now-former) Uber driver who reportedly took a passenger on a high-speed chase this week in Washington.

headline: 1964: Dance Marathon in Paris
text: PARIS — The huge doors of firehouses throughout the city swung open this afternoon and thousands of Parisians invaded gaily decorated courtyards to start off the annual dance marathon coinciding with the anniversary of the fall of the Bastille. By tomorrow evening, scores of competing “bals” will have sprung up at most of the major intersections and squares, and seemingly nearly all of Paris will be kicking high in a polka or weaving in a conga line. With a frenzy matching the revolutionary fervor in the streets on July 14, 1789, many will pursue the dancing until dawn on Tuesday. The hardiest then will rest briefly before hustling over to the Champs-Élysées for the annual military parade. Officially, July 14 has been celebrated as a national holiday only since 1880. The parliament then, it has been said, wanted to endow the Third Republic with a fête day comparable to those established under previous regimes. Although nearly a century had passed since the Revolution, strong but futile protests were delivered in parliament against the official glorification of a day associated with the parading of decapitated heads on spikes in the streets. Some of the rites marking that first official commemoration continue to be observed today. Others have been modified or have disappeared. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 13, 1964

headline: Obama’s Humanitarian Immigration Crisis
text: On July 8, President Obama requested $3.7 billion dollars from Congress to address the growing “humanitarian crisis” on the border between the United States and Mexico. Since October, more than 52,000 children traveling from Central America have already been apprehended and the U.S. government now faces the question of how to handle processing them. In the meantime, the children keep coming: Estimates of how many children will cross the border this year now surpass ninety thousand.

headline: Anticipating a Showdown, Ukraine City Empties Out
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Train tickets are sold out in all directions. Shipping companies are booked weeks in advance. For rent and for sale signs are plastered on stores and apartments like political posters during campaign season.
