headline: Seeing Cost of Saber Rattling in Ukraine, Putin Alters Course
text: MOSCOW — When he speaks about Ukraine at all these days, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia focuses on worthy subjects like humanitarian aid, distinctly turning down the flame underneath the political speech that erupted with the annexation of Crimea in March.

headline: Bowlmor’s Beloved Greeter
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Vacation Experiences That Only Money Can Buy
text: JAMES BARBER yearned to travel to exotic places when he was a boy reading National Geographic. Now 71 and a successful business owner, he is able to indulge that love in far-flung destinations during trips created exclusively for him and his family.

headline: More City Hall Change: A Mayor Taking a Break
text: New York is a city of workaholics, and its mayors are no exception. In three terms, Michael R. Bloomberg did not take a week off — ever. Rudolph W. Giuliani ignored weekends and spent holidays corralling officials on the phone.

headline: Looking for a Housemate, Not a Mate, in Later Life
text: WHEN Marianne Kilkenny was in her mid-50s, she decided she’d had enough of living and working in Silicon Valley but was not sure what to do next.

headline: Rift With Kurds Widens as Iraqi Leader Replaces the Foreign Minister
text: BAGHDAD — The dangerous struggle between the leadership of Iraq and the country’s Kurdish minority intensified Friday as the Kurds seized two oil production facilities in Kirkuk Province and the prime minister appointed a temporary replacement for the foreign minister.

headline: A Storied Ceramics Workshop Where Visiting Artists Can Get to Work
text: You won’t find Umbertide, Italy, in most guidebooks. This town in northeast Umbria has little to recommend it: no churches with vibrant frescoes, no hilltop vistas, no Michelin-starred restaurants, not even a first-rate pizzeria. Umbertide is so ordinary, in fact, that “The Companion Guide to Umbria,” the 1969 classic armchair reader on the province, singles it out as the only second-tier town in the region that is not worth even a short visit.

headline: Kerry Pushes for Solution to Afghanistan Election Crisis
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Obama administration had hoped that after years of frustration with President Hamid Karzai, a successful election in Afghanistan would finally produce a leader who could stabilize the country while working with the United States to allow an orderly withdrawal of American troops and end its longest war.

headline: Imperial Tobacco’s Ambitions Challenge Its Balance Sheet
text: Investors think Imperial Tobacco has much to gain from a possible $56 billion merger of its United States peers, Reynolds American and Lorillard. The combination would require a large sale of assets to assuage antitrust regulators, and these forced sales could present bargains for Imperial. The snag is that Imperial is short of cash – and the assets available may not be that attractive.

headline: For Biggest Cities of 2030, Look Toward the Tropics
text: REALLY big cities used to be primarily in rich countries. But as the world has urbanized, that has changed.

headline: Spice Boys To Men
text: Transgressive Yiddish; regional profiles.

headline: The Future Sure Looks Better From the Past
text: On July 5, 2010, the 25th anniversary of the release of “Back to the Future,” Total Film magazine tweeted an exciting image to its 30,000 followers. The image showed the dashboard clock of Doc Brown’s famous time-traveling DeLorean, from the second “Back to the Future” film, in which Doc, Marty and Jennifer travel to the future — and the date displayed was July 5, 2010! Countless fans — along with everyone from The Guardian to the film’s producer, Frank Marshall — retweeted, favorited and emailed the DeLorean dashboard in euphoric celebration. The future had finally arrived.

headline: 12 Food Orders and the People Who Delivered Them
text: For thousands of delivery people in New York, work is hectic, usually anonymous and often perilous when it involves bicycles. Young Jang, a photographer, orchestrated rare moments of sustained contact between customer and employee when she ordered food several times a day from her apartment and asked the deliverymen to pose for pictures. One of them, Muhammed Bella, works at Westside Brewhouse, where he waits on tables most days and pitches in as a deliveryman on Mondays. He says the customers are curt and rude much of the time. “They treat you bad,” says Bella, a native of Nigeria who lives in the Bronx. “Not everybody. But when you try to deliver to them, some people are drunk. They act up. I say nothing. I just say, ‘Thank you, have a good day, bye.’ ” ﻿Julie Bosman

headline: Accounting Principles
text: My spouse and I earn too much to contribute to a Roth I.R.A. Recently, we learned that it is legal to contribute to a traditional I.R.A. and then convert it into a Roth. My understanding of the Roth is that people who make over a certain income shouldn’t benefit from its advantages. My spouse says that because it is legal to roll a traditional I.R.A. into a Roth, there is nothing unethical about doing so. Is this a case in which the law and the ethical standard conflict? S.R., TENNESSEE

headline: Will Arnett: ‘I’m Rooting for the Refs’
text: The actor talks to Dave Itzkoff about taking a break from playing jerks and striking a delicate balance between work, family and watching hockey.

headline: Reply All: The 6.29.14 Issue
text: THE BRAVE NEW WORLD OF THREE-PARENT I.V.F.

headline: Who Made That Ice Pack?
text: Physicians have long made use of the medicinal powers of cooling. Hippocrates wrote that cold water is to be applied “when there is a hemorrhage, or when it is expected.” During the French Army’s ghastly retreat from Moscow in 1812, Napoleon’s surgeon in chief, Dominique Jean Larrey, used ice and snow to numb soldiers before field amputations.

headline: My Mother’s Miracle-Water Cure
text: When my mother pulled up in front of our house in a flatbed truck, my stomach dropped. It was summer, and she’d been away for two weeks. Her boyfriend was carrying a large plastic container. I knew there would be trouble. My younger brother, Dan, who was not quite a teenager yet and used a wheelchair to get around, rushed to the front door to lock it.

headline: ‘All My Friends Are White’
text: My son is 6. Last week, I found him sitting on the floor, hugging his knees. “What’s wrong?” I said.

headline: Liverpool Will Let Luis Suárez Go to Barcelona
text: Luis Suárez, who was suspended from all soccer activities for four months after biting an opposing player during the World Cup, will return from his ban with a new club: Barcelona.

headline: Population by the Numbers: Unplanned Pregnancies
text: To mark World Population Day, the Population Institute has posted an informative set of two-sided informational graphics on encouraging and troubling demographic trends and issues: “Population By the Numbers.”

headline: Stop Making Sense
text: Her blood sugar was dangerously low, and her words were incoherent.

headline: 1939: ‘Peace’ Raid Made Over France
text: LONDON — More than 120 of the finest heavy and medium bombers of the British Royal Air Force participated today [July 11] in the most impressive and significant sham air raid yet staged in air-conscious Europe. Taking off in succession this morning from their aerodrome in the English Midlands, the British planes pointed southward and “spread their wings” out over France. Never before had so many military planes of one country carried out an expedition of this character over the territory of another. The only information given the squadron commanders before they left the ground was that their destinations were “somewhere in France.” Sealed orders, when broken in the air, instructed the heavy bombers, totaling about eighty units, to make a round- trip, non-stop flight to Bordeaux, the French port on the Bay of Biscay, a two- way distance of nearly 1,200 miles. Similar orders provided a shorter flight for about forty medium bombers passing above the French cities of Le Treport, Orleans, and Le Mans, near Cherbourg. Their cruising radius is more restricted. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 12, 1939

headline: Letters: Whose Argument?
text: Whose Argument?

headline: In Connecticut, Breaking a Barrier Between a Suburb and Public Housing
text: NEW HAVEN — Dillard Bennett has lived for most of his life in the shadow of a 12-foot-tall chain-link fence that divides his public housing project from an adjacent suburb. He had to go the long way around to make a trip to a shopping center or to visit his pastor’s home.

headline: A Rare Bond
text: Your dog may love you, but does your dog jump onto your shoulder every morning and nuzzle you as you shave? Your cat may purr with pleasure when you feed it, but does your cat try to coax tempting morsels into your mouth, to please you? Anyone who thinks the bond between man and dog or cat is the supreme human-house pet attachment will have to reconsider after reading Martin Windrow’s touching account of the bird who changed his life, a possessive and characterful tawny owl named Mumble who was his domestic companion for 15 action-packed years. In the wild, a tawny owl is lucky to reach the age of 5; Mumble, living with the author in South London and later in rural Sussex, enjoyed three times that life span.

headline: A Supremely Cool Friend
text: Memoirs about cats and dogs are nearly as common as cats and dogs. Rarer animal companions have to wait longer for their literary turn, like Margaret Stanger’s “That Quail, Robert” (1966) or, more recently, Brian McGrory’s “Buddy: How a Rooster Made Me a Family Man” and Matt Whyman’s “Oink: My Life With Mini-Pigs.”

headline: Bookshelf: Great Outdoors
text: New picture books include John Burningham’s “Picnic.”

headline: Foodies
text: HARVEST  Field Notes From a Far-Flung Pursuit of Real Food  By Max Watman  Norton, $24.95.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A HOUSE IN THE SKY: A Memoir,  by Amanda Lindhout and Sara Corbett. (Scribner, $16.) In August 2008, Lindhout — a 27-year-old Canadian traveler and fledgling television reporter — was kidnapped in Somalia along with a photojournalist named Nigel Brennan. This account of Lindhout’s 460 days in captivity is more than a gonzo adventure tale gone awry; it’s a powerful coming-of-age story and a narrative of forgiveness and spiritual triumph.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FOURTH OF JULY CREEK,  by Smith Henderson. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) In Henderson’s deeply impressive novel, an overburdened social worker becomes involved with a near-feral boy and his survivalist father in 1980 Montana.

headline: Teenagers Rule
text: Chris Weitz’s “The Young World” tells of a Manhattan dominated by tribes of swaggering, self-possessed adolescents, some buzzed on attention-deficit medication, cruising through the city while adults cringe in the shadows, fearing for their lives. Oh, no, that was my teenage daughter’s diary of her life in eighth grade last year. (Sorry for the joke, darling; I would never read your journal, really.) But in Weitz’s novel, those things do happen — save that the adults are all dead. Indeed, Weitz takes that familiar, real-world theme of precocious autonomy and carries it to its logical end: What if Manhattan was not just dominated by adolescents but actually ruled by them in a Hobbesian world of violence and ­savagery?

headline: Health Official on Child’s H.I.V. Return
text: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director, discussed the case of a child who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. and is now showing signs of infection.

headline: On the Move
text: As America’s postwar baby boomers grew up, dipped a toe or more in child psychology studies at college and started families of their own, children’s book publishers took note of a new, pop cultural sensitivity to a wide array of ­developmentally-based childhood trials and tribulations. Picture books about ­potty training, tantrum throwing, the death of a pet and other emotionally charged topics proliferated, and were often shelved together at the library under the catchall heading of “bibliotherapy.” Some authors explored these concerns more artfully than others. Judith Viorst (“Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day”) and the late Charlotte Zolotow (“The Hating Book,” “William’s Doll”) proved to be masters of the genre, their dry-eyed wit, empathic touch and storytelling prowess easily a match for their good intentions.

headline: Avatar
text: Steve Brezenoff’s third young adult novel, “Guy in Real Life,” begins when two teenagers literally collide one night in St. Paul, Minn. Lesh Tungsten, a metal-head with a heart of gold, steps in front of a bicycle ridden by Svetlana Allegheny, an artsy-craftsy dungeon master given to talking to herself in French, and the encounter leaves a deep impression on them both. Svetlana, because she is furious with Lesh for causing her sketchbook to fall into a puddle; Lesh, because Svetlana looks “like an angel. ”

headline: Romeo and Juliet in Crown Heights
text: Even before Devorah Blum meets the lanky West Indian nerd who will derail her plans to remain an “unfailingly obedient” Hasidic girl, there are signs she’s wavering. “Like No Other,” Una LaMarche’s second young adult novel, begins as a hurricane bears down on New York City. Devorah’s 18-year-old big sister, Rose, is about to give birth to her first baby prematurely. In the sweltering hospital waiting room, Devorah, dressed in a long wool skirt and tights for modesty’s sake, envies other girls sitting near by who are wearing shorts and tapping on cellphones, despite a sign forbidding their use. Devorah, 16, isn’t allowed a phone, because her family is part of the strict Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement. She used to admire how Rose, who had a “wild side,” read fashion magazines on the sly. Now, she laments how her sister has grown meek in marriage. Devorah’s own imminent future as a doting wife and teenage mother doesn’t look so bright to her anymore.

headline: Into the Deep
text: In October 1873, 12-year-old Tommy Picco knocked on the door of the Rev. Moses Harvey’s house in Newfoundland, holding something enormous and strange. While out fishing, Picco and his companions had been attacked by a “devil-fish,” or giant squid. He’d finally beaten back the monster by hacking off its tentacles. One of the tentacles was 19 feet long. Picco thought Harvey might like to buy it.

headline: Out of Step
text: The ballet world is incestuous — insular and intensely intimate, full of young, beautiful people who work grueling hours and share in one another’s triumphs, setbacks and neuroses. No wonder, then, that dancers’ professional and social lives become inescapably entwined, and that fictional works revolving around ballet so often default to melodrama.

headline: Adaptation
text: At the heart of Kathryn Ma’s haunting first novel, “The Year She Left Us,” is a young woman who loses her way. Ari is 18 and home from a summer in China, where she worked for a company that takes Western families with adopted Chinese girls on “heritage tours.” They visit the orphanages and, sometimes, the places where the abandoned babies were first found: police stations, department stores and random patches of dirt by the side of the road. For these orphans, their “Finding Day” may be the closest approximation to the simple commonplace most of us take for granted — a birthday.

headline: The Indiscreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie
text: Published in English last year, “The Dinner,” by the Dutch writer Herman Koch, became an international best seller in part by occupying that slender intersection between literary and commercial fiction. Its prose has the direct, undemanding quality of an airport novel, its story the momentum of a page turner. Yet its more literary devices — an elegant structure, with each section titled by course, “Aperitif,” “Appetizer” and so on, as a single restaurant dinner progresses; a narrator who seems increasingly unreliable — suggest a greater complexity, an ambition to achieve Higher Things.

headline: School for a Scoundrel
text: The name Seneca brings a particular image to mind: a gaunt, half-naked old man, glaring wildly, his veins open, his lifeblood seeping into the small bath beneath him after he was forced to commit suicide. Painted by Rubens, memorialized by Dante in his first circle of hell, gilded into medieval manuscripts alongside Plato and Aristotle, Seneca has come to represent the perils of proximity to absolute power. The central question of James Romm’s “Dying Every Day” is this: When we confront this tragic Roman wordsmith, tutor to the emperor Nero (and, some argue, the power behind that terrible throne), who stares back at us? Is it a tyrannodidaskalos, a tyrant-teacher? Is he the ultimate exemplar of Stoicism, a would-be philosopher king? Or is Seneca simply an accretion of history, a phantom constructed to fit our ravening for heroes, for antiheroes and for the sensational in the stories of antiquity?

headline: Rage Runs Through It
text: Jim Stegner — the narrator of Peter Heller’s second novel, “The Painter” — burns hot. When rage finds him, “everything goes dark at the edges. Kind of tunnels down to the target.” This temper drove him, years ago, to pull a .41 Magnum and shoot a known sex offender point blank.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Fur Flies: Comedy is like sex, or subatomic particles: The more you try to analyze it, the more elusive it becomes. So it’s probably futile to look too closely at Joan Rivers’s latest book, “Diary of a Mad Diva,” new at No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list. But what the heck. As its title suggests, the book is structured as a conventional diary that happens to be filled with the author’s brand of rapid-fire politically incorrect jokes — in the second entry, Rivers contrasts herself favorably with Anne Frank: “I’ve written six books, and Anne? She didn’t even complete her one.” Rivers is unavoidably outré — racist, sexist, raunchy, crass — which isn’t to everybody’s taste. (Another way comedy resembles sex, and maybe subatomic particles — I’m no scientist — is that different folks like different strokes.) But readers seem divided as to whether Rivers is truly meanspirited or whether it’s all a provocation, a persona she slips into as easily as the fur coat she’s wearing on her book’s cover. When the CNN anchor Fredricka Whitfield suggested as much in a recent interview, noting that Rivers is a well-known animal rights advocate and wondering whether the fur was there just for its shock value, Rivers went ballistic. “Are you wearing leather shoes? Then shut up,” she said, before storming off the set. “I don’t want to hear this nonsense.” She didn’t seem to be joking.

headline: Asian Families Travel a Long Way for Summer Camp
text: After hours spent performing cartwheels, American show tunes and a series of jazzy dance routines in a cramped studio on West 28th Street in Manhattan, 8-year-old Futaba Kawakami left  TADA Youth Theater  camp earlier this week, clammy and slightly hoarse. She pulled off her new camp T-shirt, the one with the slogan Sing! Dance! Act! emblazoned on the back, and marshaled enough energy to ask her mother for ice cream. Then they headed off to 16 Handles in Chelsea.

headline: Video Reviews: ‘Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,’ ‘Boyhood’ and ‘Land Ho!’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” “Boyhood” and “Land Ho!” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Affordable Day Camps Help Working Parents Enjoy the Summer, Too
text: IT’S July, prime time for swimming, hiking and slurping watermelon. But if both you and your spouse work and you have school-age children, you may have another perspective on summer: as the season when you must juggle your schedule and scrounge up affordable child care until school reopens.

headline: All-Star Smashup in Cincinnati
text: On Tuesday evening, July 14, 1970, 51,838 fans jammed into the spanking-new poured-concrete paradise of Cincinnati’s spare-tire-shaped Riverfront Stadium for Major League Baseball’s 41st All-Star Game. While the spectators waited for the game to start, transistor radios blared out that week’s top hit, a version of “Mama Told Me (Not to Come)” by Three Dog Night.

headline: My Buddy the Super
text: When it’s dinnertime and Michele W. Miller’s husband, Jerome, has gone AWOL, Ms. Miller reflexively checks in with her co-op’s superintendent, Carlos Muñoz.

headline: Unusual Album Offerings From Beck and Rabbit Rabbit
text: As album sales plummet in the age of file sharing and Spotify, musicians are finding increasingly idiosyncratic ways of getting their music out there and persuading listeners to pay for it. Here are two installments from the Annals of Peculiar Record Release Formats of the Early 21st Century:

headline: Saving for Bucket List That’s Likely to Evolve in Years Before Retirement
text: When most of us imagine retirement, our minds wander to what we’ll get to do then that we don’t have enough time for now. If we’re lucky, we can push the uncertainty of our investment performance and future health out of our minds and picture all the fun we’ll have. That’s what will make the decades of saving worthwhile, after all.

headline: Why You Should Tip More Than You Do Now
text: For most of my life, I’m ashamed to admit, I didn’t leave a tip for the housekeeper in the hotels in which I stayed. My wife always did, but I somehow didn’t pay attention. Only recently did I wake up to just how little these folks earn and how exhausting their jobs typically are.

headline: Covering the Israeli-Palestinian Battle
text: Michael Slackman, deputy international editor, is overseeing coverage of the conflict between the Israelis and the Palestinians. We asked him about the desk’s plans for coverage.

headline: Sia’s Path from Victim to Victory
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Sia Furler, the Australian singer-songwriter, and her new album, “1000 Forms of Fear.”

headline: The Best Wardrobe Investments, Courtesy of the Museum That Knows
text: The haute couture shows closed this week with that rare thing: a black-tie bash in Paris, at the Palais Galliera, a.k.a. the city’s recently renovated fashion museum. Hosted by Olivier Saillard, chief curator, and French Vogue, and held in honor of both the museum’s new show — “Les Années 1950s” — and its new acquisitions, made possible by a special 100,000-euro annual fund created by French Vogue this year, the evening was notable for three things:

headline: Chrysler Recalls 895,000 S.U.V.s for Fire Risk in Vanity Mirrors
text: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Chrysler is recalling almost 895,000 sport utility vehicles because a wiring problem in the vanity mirror can cause a fire, the automaker said in a report posted Friday on the safety agency’s website.

text: Besides every word published on reform conservatism …

text: New York City is always shifting, as new people arrive with suitcases stuffed with hope and ambition, replacing others who have packed up and moved on.

headline: Abortion Buffer Zones After McCullen: How Big Is Too Big?
text: According to the Supreme Court, the length of two parking spots  is too far for “gentle sidewalk counselors” like Eleanor McCullen to try to convince women not to get abortions.

headline: Popcast: Sia’s Path from Victim to Victory
text: Sia Furler, the Australian singer-songwriter, is 38. “1000 Forms of Fear” is her sixth album, and her first since 2010: that all sounds like mid-career time, when maintaining a sufficient audience becomes the job.

text: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke talks about “Elephant Company”; Alexandra Alter has notes from the field; David Dobbs discusses two new books about genes; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Parliament Committee Criticizes Handling of Royal Mail I.P.O. in Britain
text: LONDON – A Parliament committee sharply criticized the British government on Friday for its handling of the initial public offering of the Royal Mail, saying officials failed to maximize “value for money for the taxpayer.”

text: Secretary of State John Kerry and an Afghan presidential candidate, Ashraf Ghani, discussed the contested election during a meeting in Kabul.

headline: Let Them Eat … a Gender-Neutral Confection
text: The fall of the cupcake, allegedly heralded by the closing of Crumbs this week, has reopened a debate about the gendering of desserts. And since forecasting the cupcake’s replacement has already become a popular pastime, it’s worth asking what the future holds for food trends and their gender implications.

headline: A Hotel With Its Art on the Outside
text: The London-based restaurateurs Chris Corbin and Jeremy King have a reputation for developing buzz-generating places that draw glitterati as well as gapers, especially at their grand cafe the Wolseley.

text: Spinning the wheels of The Upshot’s Senate forecaster is one of our favorite tools for understanding the uncertainty around this November’s election. In today’s spin, the Republicans ride a “wave” to a decisive, nine-seat gain in the Senate.

text: Four years after he bolted to Miami from Cleveland in pursuit of the N.B.A. championships that had eluded him, LeBron James is returning home.

headline: In San Francisco, Artists Take Over Outdoor Advertising Spaces
text: In San Francisco, where tensions between established artist communities and Silicon Valley continue to rise, Luke Groesbeck, a former tech worker and the founder of the fledgling public art organization Art City, wants to help his hometown reinvest in the former. “This is a city with a major arts and cultural legacy,” he says. “How do we honor that? Then an idea came up and I got fixated on it: What happens when you turn an entire city into a gallery? Is it possible?”

headline: A Brief History of Pro-Immigrant Conservatism
text: Warren Buffett and Bill Gates don’t seem like such an unlikely pair. Both are extremely wealthy, both have made sizable contributions to the American economic and innovative spheres, and both are staunch progressives who have worked together on many initiative in the past, such as Mr. Gates’s foundation, and Mr. Buffett’s Giving Pledge. But, add the famously conservative casino-magnate Sheldon Adelson into the mix, and you’ve got an unlikely partnership, indeed.

headline: Expectations vs. Reality at the World Cup
text: Everyone always expects the worst from big sporting events before they begin, and this World Cup was no different.

headline: Big Tobacco Getting Bigger: A Brief History of Deal Making
text: The merger talks announced on Friday between Reynolds American and Lorillard could create a new tobacco giant in the United States. But the history of consolidation in the cigarette business goes back decades.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Elephant Company’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Sara Gruen reviews Vicki Constantine Croke’s “Elephant Company,” about a man known as Elephant Bill who trained the animals to help build bridges and evacuate refugees during World War II. Ms. Gruen writes:

headline: A Move to Extend Visiting Hours at Hospitals
text: I recently had to leave a hospital, where I was keeping a friend company after his cardiac procedure, when visiting hours ended at 8 p.m. I wasn’t worried, because my friend was otherwise healthy, mobile and alert. He wasn’t taking drugs that might have caused confusion or dizziness. And he was only 60, which in my world is practically adolescent.

text: Updated, 2:06 p.m. |

headline: ‘The Escape Artist': Thomas Beller Talks About J. D. Salinger
text: Thomas Beller’s “J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist” is partly a look at Salinger’s early life and career, and partly a memoir about the New York that Beller grew up in and sees reflected in his subject’s work. In a recent email interview, Mr. Beller discussed Salinger’s reclusion, the development of his style, how “The Catcher in the Rye” holds up today and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Vintage Motorcycles in the Garden State
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Because Stuff Is Not Nonsense
text: There was a moment in the 1980s when many fashionable Manhattanites decorated their apartments like country houses, furnishing them with patchwork quilts, dried flowers and weathered pie safes. The look was second nature to Mary Randolph Carter, the Ralph Lauren executive who codified it in her 1988 design and entertaining book, “American Family Style,” which was photographed at her Upper East Side apartment as well as at Muskettoe Pointe Farm, her parents’ home in Virginia, and elsewhere.

headline: Country Music History in Motion
text: The singer Marty Stuart has been documenting legendary figures in country music from an intimate, personal perspective on stage and on the road.

headline: Buick Sheds Its Old Fogy Image and Lifts G.M.
text: As General Motors teetered on bankruptcy just a few years ago, its venerable Buick division seemed on the brink of extinction. The oldest active automobile brand in North America and a car once known as the “moving couch” for its plush interiors, Buick catered to a population of people over 65. Sales had fallen to just 102,000 vehicles in 2009.

headline: The Words of the World Cup
text: Which team will win the World Cup on Sunday: the one that’s perceived as “powerful,” “focused” and “committed”? Or, its rival, described mostly as “confident” and full of “flair,” but “unconvincing”?

headline: C.D.C. Closes Anthrax and Flu Labs After Accidents
text: After potentially serious back-to-back laboratory accidents, federal health officials announced Friday that they had temporarily closed the flu and anthrax laboratories at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and halted shipments of all infectious agents from the agency’s highest-security labs.

text: Compared to “The Decision” four years ago, LeBron James quietly dropped his latest franchise shift into the social media sea Friday. As his story hit the Internet via an essay he co-wrote for Sports Illustrated, he posted this unremarkable link to it on Twitter:

headline: My Brooklyn, Then and Now
text: The floor-to-ceiling windows provided a panoramic view of Manhattan. But I was more interested in the foreground, below me — Brooklyn.

headline: Lawrence of Sardinia
text: “I don’t care for islands,” D. H. Lawrence once wrote, an attitude I happen to share, though my wife doesn’t, which is how we found ourselves in Sardinia last spring.

headline: 36 Hours in Graz, Austria
text: Ask most travelers about Austrian cities beyond Vienna, and you’ll probably hear suggestions to go to Salzburg or Innsbruck. Austrians, however, might tell you that Graz — their country’s second-largest city, with a population of just over 300,000 — is a better choice for many tourists, thanks to its rich design, art and culinary scenes, and wine and produce from the surrounding south Austrian state of Styria. Built around the Schlossberg, an ancient hilltop castle, Styria’s regional capital is home to scores of boutiques, shops, restaurants and museums, many housed in restored Baroque-era buildings in the city’s well-preserved Old Town. You might not expect to find such a cultivated metropolis two hours down the road from Vienna toward Ljubljana, but Graz has a palpable joie de vivre, thanks in part to the presence of its six universities and over 40,000 students.

headline: Restaurant Report: Peumayen in Santiago, Chile
text: A quick visit to Santiago may leave the impression that typical Chilean food is limited to steak sandwiches and completos, the ever-present hot dogs smeared with avocado. In an effort to change that, the restaurant Peumayen attempts to reawaken the ancestral cuisine of some of the country’s native peoples: the Mapuche, Aymará and Rapa Nui.

headline: Hotel Review: Waldorf Astoria Panama in Panama City
text: Rates

headline: Summer School for Anchovies
text: This week, scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif., noticed an enormous school of anchovies gathering near the coast. Pressed into a huge swarm, an estimated one billion of the tiny fish are taking cues from their neighbors, carefully coordinating their every move.

headline: The German 71 Cocktail
text: Few people are more worthy of a toast this week than members of the German national soccer team. They defied the modest expectations of their fans and produced one of the most incredible displays in World Cup history by thrashing Brazil — the favorite and host — 7-1. So in honor of the Nationalmannschaft, as they’re known, we bring you this week’s Upshot cocktail: the German 71.

headline: Seeing Johannesburg Through Artists’ Eyes
text: In the Ferreirasdorp section of Johannesburg, I passed a group of young men who had set up an informal carwash business with buckets of soapy water arranged by a curb, and as I turned a corner, there was Nelson Mandela.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Blooper Reel: Cleveland Fans Aren’t Used to Such Good News
text: Johnny Football. The Republican Convention. Now the second coming of the disgraced hometown hero LeBron James. Could — gasp — things finally be working in Cleveland’s favor?

headline: Teenagers in The Times | June 2014
text: This slide show taken from “Richard Linklater’s Leading Boy” features images from the new film “Boyhood,” which details the journey from childhood to adolescence of one Mason Jr., played by Ellar Coltrane.

headline: Digital Humanists to Catalog Notes Scrawled in Books
text: The Wall Street Journal recently made a tongue-in-cheek attempt to determine the “most unread” book of the summer using Amazon’s “Popular Highlights” feature, which tracks the passages in any given book that have been most frequently highlighted by Kindle users, taken as an indirect measure of which books were barely read past the introduction. (Here’s looking at you, Thomas Piketty.)

headline: Garth Brooks Planning First New Studio Album Since 2001
text: The country music superstar Garth Brooks released his last album of new studio material, “Scarecrow,” in November 2001, roughly a year after he announced that he intended to retire from performing and recording to spend time with his family. Since then he has made occasional appearances on the concert stage and on television, and since 2009 he has been inching toward a full comeback.

headline: A Damaging Distance
text: DAYS after Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was gunned down in 1995 by an Israeli Jew who opposed compromise with the Palestinians, Shimon Peres, the acting prime minister, held a news conference. He was asked why more had not been done to protect Mr. Rabin from people like his assassin, Yigal Amir. Mr. Peres replied that it had never occurred to the authorities that a Jew could do such a thing.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Keeps the Knicks Waiting on His Decision
text: LAS VEGAS — Phil Jackson, clad in a red plaid shirt, watched the Knicks’ summer league team take on the Dallas Mavericks on Friday afternoon from a spot in the bleachers at Cox Pavilion. With General Manager Steve Mills sitting to his right and members of the front office assembled around him, Jackson looked at ease. He hardly fiddled with his phone.

headline: A Dance Battle Begins
text: A crew prepares itself for a dance battle at the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival in Goma.

headline: Robert Wilson’s Video Portraits of Lady Gaga to Have First American Showing
text: Although Robert Wilson is best known for his experimental theater works, including several genre-redefining opera collaborations with Philip Glass (most famously, “Einstein on the Beach”), he has created an expansive series of visual art works. Among them is a series of what Mr. Wilson calls “Video Portraits” of artists and performers including Mikhail Baryshnikov, Winona Ryder, Brad Pitt and Isabella Rossellini. He uses high-definition video as the canvas, and costumes, lighting, makeup, gesture and narrative to put his subjects in perspective, usually with references to other art works.

headline: The Directors of “Land Ho!” On Their Icelandic Adventure
text: “Land Ho!,” Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz’s sweet and often hilarious road film about a pair of older men who travel to Iceland to reclaim their youth, began as something far less ambitious. “I wanted to go on a vacation to Iceland,” says Stephens, whose first two films, “Passenger Pigeons” and “Pilgrim Song,” were well-received indie outings. As she researched her trip, however, Stephens saw the opportunity to use the country’s breathtaking landscapes for a more creative purpose. She enlisted Katz, the director of the mumblecore favorites “Dance Party USA” and “Quiet City,” whom she knew from the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, to help write the script and co-direct, and the pair cast Stephens’s second cousin, Earl Lynn Nelson, an oculoplastic surgeon, and the indie actor Paul Eenhoorn (“This Is Martin Bonner”), as the film’s jocular leads, Mitch and Colin.

headline: As Reynolds Looks Ahead, a Familiar Leader, Susan Cameron, Guides the Way
text: When the tobacco company Reynolds American confirmed on Friday that it was in discussions with Lorillard about a multibillion-dollar merger, the news hardly came as a surprise.

headline: Best of the World Cup, From The Upshot
text: The World Cup has proved to be a hit not only around the world — as usual — but also in the United States. Television ratings are up, and online discussion has flourished. Here at The Upshot, we too have had a great time watching and analyzing the tournament. Below is a collection of our greatest hits from the last month, many of which can shed light on the final two matches in the tournament.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: All About the Terraces
text: A one-of-a-kind duplex penthouse, one of just four residences carved in 2005 from the 1913 Amory S. Carhart Mansion at 3 East 95th Street and an elegant, newer adjoining limestone structure that replaced a former school at No. 5, is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: The Rings, the Cake, the Rice ... the Insurance?
text: Picture a rustic wedding in a verdant California park, the nervous couple about to walk the aisle. Now, picture a firefighter rushing in and telling everyone to immediately evacuate because of a wildfire.

headline: Unity in a Strange Land
text: Philip Montgomery calls his photographs of New York City’s various Islamic communities an unfinished project, one driven by changing perspectives and questions. He began in 2009 as a new arrival from California and fresh from photographing Sufi Muslims in Kashmir. In an unfamiliar city, Mr. Montgomery, now 26, said he felt a yearning to “work my way back to the kind of connected communities I saw in Kashmir.”

headline: Real Data on Illegal Gun Sales
text: A recent survey of gun dealers on illegal transactions yields new information on how criminals obtain guns.

headline: Chronicling the Monumental
text: Five years ago in “Mannahatta,” Eric W. Sanderson imaginatively envisioned the natural landscape that Henry Hudson would have witnessed when he sailed into New York Harbor. Now Ted Steinberg, a Brooklyn-born history professor at Case Western Reserve University, engagingly explores what happened to that natural environment in the four centuries since in “Gotham Unbound: The Ecological History of Greater New York” (Simon & Schuster).

headline: Arts Sanctuary in a War-Torn City
text: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — When Petna Ndaliko was a boy, he would head downtown to watch kung fu movies at the Cine Virunga here. On Saturday and Sunday evenings, his parents would take him to the theater. When he got older, Mr. Ndaliko became an actor himself, performing for the first time in a show at the auditorium next to this city’s Roman Catholic cathedral.

headline: Big Ticket | Rupert Murdoch’s Trophy Pad, Expanded
text: The glassy 57th-floor getaway that doubles as the bottom level of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch’s four-tier vertical compound at the pinnacle of One Madison, the slender 60-story tower on the southeast side of Madison Square Park, sold for $14.927 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: In Gaza, Airstrikes and Economic Stress Make for an Anxious Ramadan
text: GAZA CITY — War during Ramadan has a particular tension. It is not just the normal anxiety of airstrikes in a crowded city, no matter how carefully Israel tries to target them. But the holy month of Ramadan falls this year in a particularly hot and humid Gaza July, and observant Muslims are fasting, not even drinking water, until sunset and iftar, the evening meal.

headline: Matt Long: Trading Surf for Turf
text: The professional sand sculptor Matt Long spends most of the summer carving castles along the Jersey Shore and Coney Island, but he saves spaghetti omelets, guitar playing and gardening for Sunday. The 59-year-old has been featured on the Travel Channel’s “Sand Masters,” is the founder of the online shop Can You Dig It Sand Tools, competes in international sand sculpturing events, and has been hired by companies to erect elaborate designs, most recently a plane in Wildwood Crest, N.J., to promote the new Disney movie “Planes: Fire and Rescue.” “Unless someone requests the Taj Mahal or something, I just make sand castles up as I go,” he said. Mr. Long lives in West Brighton, Staten Island, with his wife, Nina, 59, and his daughters, Katrina, 34; Madeline, 26; and Emily, 21.

headline: How Good Are Cavaliers Now? And Four Other Questions
text: LeBron James’s decision to return to Cleveland makes the Cavaliers an instant contender and a favorite to win the N.B.A. title, according to manyoddsmakers, even though James himself acknowledged that it will take time to build a winner. The decision also raised many questions, which may not be answered any time soon.

headline: Dead in the Water: A Long Island Ferry
text: It is now clear that before the end of the month, should various labor disputes fail to resolve themselves, workers for the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike, an outcome that would jeopardize the commute of 300,000 working people each weekday. But it is not the fate of this population that ought to concern us, not during the peak of summer, when the genuinely endangered are the 26-year-olds with juice bottles full of vodka who depend on the train to get them to the Jennifer Convertibles sofas at their weekend quarter-shares in Westhampton. Millennials, it would seem, have already endured enough.

headline: As Senate Spotlight Is Given to Vulnerable Democrats, G.O.P. Finds a Dimmer
text: WASHINGTON — Very little is happening in the Senate these days, but what passes for action has a lot to do with re-electing Democrats — or blocking their re-election.

headline: A Ride Across America | Campfire Cooking in the Rockies
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: A Prophetic Dream Come True
text: Broadway actress Patina Miller and David Mars were married on June 14, at the Foundry in Long Island City, N.Y.

headline: The 2015 GMC Yukon SLT and Yukon XL Denali
text: GMC’s big boys get a slightly new look for 2015. Above, the new GMC Yukon XL Denali.

headline: Driven | 2015 Chevrolet Suburban LTZ
text: An 80-year-old still does the chores in a big way.

headline: Room for the Family. Bodyguards, Too.
text: They line up a dozen deep behind the Capitol in Washington, mostly black General Motors S.U.V.s — Chevrolet Tahoes and Suburbans or their GMC equivalents — waiting to shuttle important people to important places. Or to lunch at Chipotle.

headline: A Fig Tree Dies in Brooklyn, and in Other Boroughs
text: By late spring, Nelson Ryland knew that something was wrong. Normally, the fig trees in his backyard in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, would be plush with verdant leaves and sending up sprays of new branches. This year, though, while the Bronx seedless grape vine, the hydrangea bushes and the black-eyed Susans in his garden flourished, his eight fig trees stood stark and lifeless.

headline: Uber's Travis Kalanick Explains His Pricing Experiment
text: Of the several entrepreneurs who are trying to shake up urban transportation, Travis Kalanick of the smartphone-summoned car service Uber has made some of the boldest moves. In my article about the strategic battle between Uber and its rivals, Mr. Kalanick explains that he sees the 20 to 25 percent sharp price cuts announced this week for its UberX service as a way to increase ridership. Here is more from the conversation, lightly edited for length and clarity.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Despot Behind a Desk
text: LONDON — The “hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death,” as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most fearsome psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you don’t really need.

headline: On Stage and in His Life, the Leading Player
text: When Patina Miller performed “Magic to Do” in the opening number of “Pippin,” she wore a top hat and swung from a trapeze, over a stage full of contortionists, tumblers, dancers and acrobats.

headline: Photographers of the Inadvertent
text: Although the tunneling for the Second Avenue subway is going on far below the street, on the surface whole blocks are in chaos, strewn with barriers, fences, ventilators and huge elevated construction sheds. It was just as much an obstacle course in the early 20th century, when our first subways were built, as we can see from hundreds of thousands of photographs, now divided like a broken Greek vase among various institutions, at least two dealers, several collectors and, on occasion, sale tables at flea markets.

headline: Citroen’s Adjustable Suspension
text: Citroën’s suspensions use a hydropneumatic system instead of steel springs. The result is a smooth ride with excellent road-holding. The system also provides adjustable ride height and self-leveling.

headline: Shoe Prints, Dripping Blood and Groping
text: John Walsh can’t seem to stop trying to catch criminals, and who can blame him? But his latest series, “The Hunt With John Walsh,” is a schlocky disappointment.

headline: Doubts on Fasting Before Cholesterol Tests
text: The National Institutes of Health and other groups recommend fasting for nine to 12 hours before taking a blood lipid test, but a large new study provides further evidence that fasting is probably unnecessary.

headline: Measuring Ramadan
text: WE are in the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. During this time, as prescribed by one of the five “pillars,” or obligations, that make up the foundation of Muslim life, hundreds of millions of followers are abstaining from eating and drinking (and a host of other activities, like smoking and sex) between dawn and sunset.

headline: Silver Lake to Pay $29.5 Million to Settle Suit on Collusion
text: The private equity firm Silver Lake has agreed to pay $29.5 million to settle accusations that it colluded with its rivals to drive down the prices of corporate takeovers before the financial crisis, according to a court filing on Thursday.

headline: With Merger, Tobacco Takes On Technology
text: Disruptive technology can spur takeovers as companies, fearing for their business, race to bulk up and acquire innovators.

headline: Work Out, Then the Wok
text: Perhaps you have seen him, the Zen master of Zen Palate, doing his daily exercise routine in the middle of Midtown Manhattan’s morning rush.

headline: Man Charged in Staten Island Crime Spree Pleads Not Guilty
text: A man accused in a crime spree that included two unrelated murders only 15 minutes apart was ordered held without bail on Friday after he entered a plea of not guilty in State Supreme Court on Staten Island.

headline: Examining a Father’s Role in a Toddler’s Death
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — On a Friday morning in March 2012, Leanna Harris entered a medical office here and underwent an ultrasound to get a glimpse of the baby she and her husband would name Cooper. The grainy, black-and-white footage was uploaded three days later to the YouTube account belonging to her husband, Justin Ross Harris, with a gleeful caption: “First video known as Cooper!”

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Weekend Reading: Have You Even Tried the Potato Salad in Sun Valley?
text: Zack “Danger” Brown can raise more than $43,000 on Kickstarter to pay for his potato salad. Surely there is someone at the Sun Valley conference who can make use of his talents. Or technology and media titans could make use of these delicious potato salad recipes from The New York Times. DealBook recommends Sam Sifton’s grilled fingerling-potato salad with chipotle bacon vinaigrette. Mmm, bacon.

headline: Summer Car Safety: Look Before You Lock, and More
text: The terrible accusations against Justin Ross Harris, the father accused of intentionally leaving his 22-month-old son, Cooper, to die in a hot car because he wished to be free of the burdens of parenting, make it easy to mentally file Cooper’s tragic death under the category “things that will never happen to my family.” People in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Mr. Harris’s deeply conservative hometown, are having a hard time believing what happened, as Richard Faussett and Alan Blinder write in The New York Times, even as prosecutors and the Georgia police and prosecutors have provided details of the actions of of Mr. Harris and his wife on June 18, the day the boy died.

headline: The Body of Salem, Its Nerves Frayed
text: LONDON — The Puritan torturers who try to break the spirit of John Proctor, the honor-bound hero of Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” have nothing on the devastating revival of that play that recently opened at the Old Vic. As directed by Yael Farber, this three-and-a-half-hour production applies unrelieved pressure to your nerves — and, it would seem, muscles that include the heart — until you’re a submissive puddle of pity and terror.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: What gives with C.E.O./founders recently? Some have been behaving badly, facing allegations of sexual harassment or making inappropriate comments. It’s even led to a few getting fired. But when they lose their jobs—if we needed another reminder that C.E.O.’s aren’t like the rest of us—they fight to get them back. Case in point: Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel.

headline: The Children of the Drug Wars
text: CRISTIAN OMAR REYES, an 11-year-old sixth grader in the neighborhood of Nueva Suyapa, on the outskirts of Tegucigalpa, tells me he has to get out of Honduras soon — “no matter what.”

headline: This Tour de France Never Leaves New York
text: On Sunday, French expatriates, Francophiles and fans of old French cars and motorized bicycles will gather to celebrate Bastille Day — a day early — with a rally through the streets of Manhattan.

headline: Citroën’s Last American Gasp: French, Futuristic and Desired by Few
text: One Thursday last fall, Brian Brandt got a phone call from “The Americans,” the FX Networks’ period drama about Cold War-era Soviet spies living in a Washington suburb. An anxious member of the production staff explained that the show, filmed in a Brooklyn studio and at locations around Long Island, needed a car repaired — and back on the set the following Tuesday.

headline: The 1973 Citroën SM
text: Brian Brandt of New York City fell in love with Citroëns as a teenager and now owns three of the cars. He drives his 1973 SM about 6,000 miles a year.

headline: Wheelies: The Classic Gas Prices Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: An Argentine and a German, but No Sign at the Vatican of a World Cup Rivalry
text: ROME — They have prayed together and embraced each other as brothers, but Pope Francis and his predecessor, Benedict XVI, now pope emeritus, find themselves confronting an odd sort of schism: their two countries are competing in the finals of the World Cup on Sunday.

headline: The 1911 Mercer Type 35R Raceabout
text: A racing legend made in New Jersey heads to auction.

headline: In Their Ardor and Sweep, Hints of an Emerging Gold Standard
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — To watch New York City Ballet at its open-air summer home at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center on Thursday afternoon was to be made forcefully aware not just how well the company is currently dancing but with what exuberance. Next week, when Moscow’s legendary Bolshoi Ballet opens at the David H. Koch Theater in Manhattan — and two weeks later, when it arrives here — it will be judged by two standards: memories and films of its own past achievements, and the highest standards of today’s foremost American companies.

headline: Jersey-Born, Racetrack-Bred and Headed to the Monterey Auctions
text: BLENHEIM, Ontario — Wind-in-the-face fun: That’s what it is like to ride in the passenger’s seat of a bright yellow 1911 Mercer Raceabout driven swiftly down a road here in the Canadian countryside an hour east of Detroit. At the wheel, Don McLellan, an owner and manager of the restoration arm of RM Auctions, is all smiles as he steers and shift gears, thoroughly enjoying the response of the light but powerful car.

headline: Fixes for Pistons and Driveshafts
text: BMWs needing new driveshafts and Honda CR-Vs with balky windows are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: A Summer Trip Quashed, but Not the Whining
text: I’ve just had to cancel a vacation I was looking forward to for months, and this has left a gaping hole in my world: the need to find the right people to complain to about it.

headline: Cool Noodle Dishes That Defy the Season
text: When the weather is sweltering, pasta served at cool room temperature can be wonderful. I’m not talking about last night’s congealed lasagna straight from the fridge, although I won’t discount any food choice on a really hot day.

headline: Week in Pictures for July 11
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes the funeral of a fallen firefighter, the Obelisk in Central Park and Fourth of July celebrations.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: They’re Dropping Like Middle Initials
text: In 1991, I was preparing to publish my first book, about a year I spent teaching junior high school in Japan. Stephen Birmingham, the author of “Our Crowd” and an acquaintance of my parents, offered to give me a blurb but recommended one change: that I drop the middle initial from my name on the cover. As a 26-year-old, baby-faced writer, I was eager to appear older and more sophisticated, so I ignored him.

headline: Like a Beach Bro, Nestled in a Mellow Reggae Groove
text: Are there five more worrisome words in the world than “You guys like reggae music?”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Tricolor
text: Dressed for the Fourth of July.

headline: After the Titillation, a Series Gets Sexy
text: It’s not about sex.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Tricolor
text: Visitors to the city celebrated the Fourth of July weekend wearing red, white and blue T-shirts at Rockefeller Center, with its 200 flags; at Battery Park, for their trip to the Statue of Liberty; and in Times Square. Sapphire blue is a summer hit, as seen in the mosaic aquarium in the 57th Street windows of Bergdorf Goodman, recycled from holiday windows.

headline: A Long, Quiet Tour Stage Ends in a Tight Finish
text: NANCY, France — The crashes that have marked most of the first week of the Tour de France continued as the peloton rode through World War I battlefields on Friday.

headline: Laughter Amid Melancholy
text: Joe DiPietro’s “Clever Little Lies” is scheduled to run at Guild Hall from July 16 to Aug. 3 with the same cast and director as its world premiere at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., last year. Information: guildhall.org or (631) 324-4050. Following are excerpts from Ken Jaworowski’s review that was published online in The New York Times on Dec. 5, 2013; the full text is here.

headline: Fleeting Artworks, Melting Like Sugar
text: One of the most substantial works of art to hit New York in years was with us for only two months. This week, the final vestiges of Kara Walker’s “A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby” were removed from the old sugar shed of the Domino factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which will make way for apartments.

headline: Russian Farewells, Quartet by Quartet
text: LENOX, Mass. — Far from shirking challenges, the Emerson String Quartet has, in its 37 seasons, tended to seek them out. It is not enough, for example, merely to scatter the six Bartok quartets (which the group recorded for Deutsche Grammophon, winning a Grammy Award in 1990) among mixed programs; the Emerson has repeatedly performed all six works in a single long evening.

headline: A Forgiving Spirit, Despite Those Sharp Red Nails
text: Charles Busch, the playwright and sometime drag performer, has the gift of comic gab like few other entertainers. Innately funny, endearing and acutely intelligent, he also has claws. For an audience, the possibility of being scratched, although remote, lends his humor a bracing edge.

headline: A Voice in Her Head Comes Into Her Home
text: CHICAGO — Sandra Oh, who spent 10 seasons playing a good doctor on television’s “Grey’s Anatomy,” is now portraying a woman confronting a potentially very bad one in the Victory Gardens Theater production of Ariel Dorfman’s “Death and the Maiden” here. Raúl Castillo, of the HBO young-gays-in-San-Francisco series “Looking,” stars alongside Ms. Oh as her husband, with the veteran Chicago actor John Judd playing the third role of the nefarious (or is he?) doctor.

headline: Eni Chief Angers Unions With Plan to Close Refineries
text: LONDON — The new chief executive of Eni, the Italian energy giant, has put himself on a collision course with workers and possibly the Italian government with a plan to close much of the company’s unprofitable refinery network in Italy.

headline: A Multibillion-Dollar Question for Airbus and Its A330
text: TOULOUSE, France — Inside a 185-acre assembly hall in this quiet corner of southwestern France, a dozen of Airbus’s best-selling wide-body jets stand in various stages of construction.

headline: Digitizing the Family History
text: Q. What is the easiest way to convert an old typed manuscript of our family history into an electronic format so everyone in the family can get it by email?

headline: The World Awaits the F-35, the Latest in Flying Firepower
text: The business battle between Boeing and Airbus traditionally dominates the Farnborough International Airshow. But this weeklong event, which starts on Monday in Hampshire, England, is also a showcase for some of the world’s most sophisticated flying weaponry, which perform dazzling displays in the hope of luring prospective government clients.

headline: Undead Plane Passengers in a Medical Whodunit
text: The Centers for Disease Control don’t always get a good rap. In “The Walking Dead” they were an empty shell that almost got the cast killed before self-destructing in a fireball. So in the new FX series “The Strain,” beginning on Sunday, it’s nice to see the agency getting some respect. You could make a drinking game out of the times it’s mentioned in tones usually reserved for superheroes or counterintelligence outfits. “This crime scene is now under C.D.C. authority!” the hero declares, and no one on screen laughs.

headline: They Pay a High Price Amid the Cash Registers
text: Imagine that you’ve died and gone to hell, and damnation turns out to be a job at Walmart with a psychotic boss and a “No Exit” directive from corporate headquarters.

headline: The Hudson Project Begins
text: Campers began arriving at the Hudson Project, a three-day music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., on Thursday night, bringing their face paint, sequins and fluorescent bikinis.

headline: Fertility Clinics Scan for the Strongest Embryo
text: Annika Levitt initially resisted the fertility clinic’s suggestion that only one embryo — rather than the usual two or more — be transferred to her uterus because she was too small to risk carrying more than one baby.

headline: Impressions of Brooklyn
text: A selection of images, from moments to meals.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: At Sun Valley, Deal Speculation if No Deal Talks
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — Sure, the media and technology moguls who fly to the Allen & Company conference here come for the panels, the sunshine and the many activities that this resort town offers.

headline: Bridge Match at the July 4th Regional in Florida
text: The July Fourth Regional in Jacksonville, Fla., ran from June 30 to July 6.

headline: Luna Moth: Green, Glowy and in Vogue
text: At best, moths are often regarded as country-mouse cousins of butterflies. At worst, they are night-flying pests that tangle in our hair and eat holes in our clothing. Their relatives, the butterflies, steal all the glory, flying through the flowery fields of our imaginations, playing in the sunlight and delicately sipping nectar from colorful flowers.

headline: Sale of Egyptian Statue By English Museum Draws Criticism
text: A British museum’s decision to sell a 4,400-year old-Egyptian statue for a surprising $27 million at auction in London on Thursday has ignited an uproar in England over the propriety of the sale.

headline: Our Love Affair With Predicting Divorce
text: One of the great love stories of our era is not a celebrity coupling or an on-screen romance but a series of psychological experiments. These experiments aim to predict which couples will divorce, based on how they act while married. And while some have questioned their findings, the idea that marital discord is predictable (and, perhaps, preventable) retains its hold on our hearts.

headline: When Does Graffiti Become Art?
text: When does graffiti become art? Does the market for street art create a difference between vandalism and graffiti?

headline: Curtain Call | Paris Couture Fall 2014
text: To mark the conclusion of Paris Couture Week, we catalog the bows of 10 fashion visionaries.

headline: Messi vs. Maradona
text: On Sunday, Lionel Messi will have the opportunity to match the one feat that separates him from Diego Maradona in the hearts of Argentine soccer fans.

headline: What Lies Beneath: A Haunting Nazi Past
text: The strongest quality of “The Passenger,” the harrowing and powerful, if problematic, 1968 opera by the composer Mieczyslaw Weinberg and the librettist Alexander Medvedev, is the visceral way the work exposes the tension between the present and the past of its two main characters.

headline: Mothers Find a Helping Hand in Sobriety Coaches
text: Tamara Mellon, a founder of Jimmy Choo shoes and mother of Minty, 12, was sitting on a cream leather sofa in her airy Madison Avenue office, recounting her arduous climb from hard-partying cocaine addict to fashion goddess.

headline: Turning ‘Likes’ Into a Career
text: On a Monday evening in late June, Darren Lachtman surveyed the sun-dappled patio of Southern Pacific Brewing, a bar and restaurant in a cavernous warehouse in San Francisco’s Mission District. Beer in hand, he nodded toward Robby Ayala, a comedian and employee of Niche, the social media management agency Mr. Lachtman, 32, founded with a partner last July. Mr. Ayala was one of more than a dozen Niche members invited to the company-sponsored happy hour.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Jordan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Jordan, Bosnia, Ireland and China.

headline: Evening Hours | Flowers in the Garden
text: Parties alfresco, at sea level or overlooking the big city.

headline: U.S. Targets South Korea Over Steel
text: WASHINGTON — The Commerce Department declared Friday that South Korean steel companies and those in seven other countries were illegally dumping low-cost steel pipes and tubing into the American construction market and would be subject to additional duties.

headline: From the Age of Dinosaurs, Hard Clues
text: Of all the plants that can be found at David Blersch’s 22-acre farm on Horse Fence Hill Road in Southbury, the one that has drawn the most attention is as hard as a rock.

headline: Among Justices, Considering a Divide Not of Gender or Politics, but of Beliefs
text: During its last term, the Supreme Court narrowly decided two cases bearing extensively on the separation of church and state. Both of them broke along familiar 5-4 lines, and both of them implicitly raised a question hardly anyone has asked about a court that is entirely composed, for the first time in American history, of Roman Catholic and Jewish justices.

headline: John Seigenthaler, Editor and Aide to Politicians, Dies at 86
text: In October 1954, a man called The Nashville Tennessean and said he was going to jump to his death from a bridge high above the Cumberland River. “Send a reporter and a photographer if you want a story,” he said.

headline: After a Wild Ride, a Penny Stock, Cynk, Runs Into a Trading Halt
text: To any rational investor, the stock of Cynk Technology looked like a loser. The company had no assets and no revenue. Regulatory filings listed a succession of chief executives and no other employees. The shares, which barely traded and were not listed on any exchange, were each worth less than a dime.

headline: With Older Parents, Stepping Gingerly Through Life’s Daily Minefield
text: One of my friends has come up with a great verb to describe what it is like taking care of her 90-something mother: curling. Just as the players in that enigmatic Olympic sport incessantly brush the ice to help the stone move forward unobstructed, my husband and I feel like gold medalists at the end of each day if my father, 83, and my mother, 80, simply go to bed uninjured. It means we cleared the paths adequately that day.

headline: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: ‘Somewhere With You’
text: “Somewhere With You,” a Frankenstein’s monster of a musical created from songs written or co-written by JT Harding — some new and some well-known — isn’t quite a jukebox musical, but it’s certainly as simplistic as one.

headline: Race-Fixing Let Musician Reach Sochi, Ski Group Says
text: The pop violinist Vanessa-Mae was perhaps the most unlikely athlete at the Sochi Olympics. A former child star in Britain, she competed in the giant slalom ski race for Thailand, her father’s home country.

headline: Netanyahu Vows Military Attacks in Gaza
text: The Israeli prime minister said international pressure would not prevent him from pressing forward with a broad military offensive in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Federal Judge Rules That Detroit Is Entitled to Revenue From Casinos
text: A federal judge ruled on Friday that Detroit was entitled to casino revenue worth about $15 million a month and could use the money to settle its debts in bankruptcy, rejecting arguments from a bond insurer that the money was beyond the city’s reach.

headline: With Rotation Depleted, Yankees Slide Further Behind
text: BALTIMORE — In a season of mediocrity, Yankees fans might consider themselves justified in demanding apologies from any number of people, from the very top of the organization on down to the bus driver who got stuck in traffic here Friday.

headline: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: ‘Cloned!’
text: “Avenue Q” has Gary Coleman. “Cloned!” has Sharon Stone.

headline: In St. Andrews, a Heavy Knock on a Neighbor’s Door
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — On the last day of finals before the summer break, Louise Richardson, the principal of the University of St. Andrews, sat in her wood-paneled, book-lined corner office and washed down a vegetarian roll with bottled water. Down the road, a long par-5 from the 15th-century campus, a university donor was dining at the Royal and Ancient Golf Club.

headline: Satirizing Patriotism and Piety
text: Anyone who thinks that George Bernard Shaw wrote plays that are long on talk and deficient in action will be agreeably surprised by the dramatic goings-on of “The Devil’s Disciple.” In 1896, early in his career as a dramatist, Shaw wrote a dark comedy that exploited the elements of Victorian blood-and-thunder melodramas to his own purposes.

headline: Vietnam’s Overdue Alliance With America
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — OURS is a small country. We Vietnamese cannot and must not entrust our future to anyone, but we urgently need strategic allies at a moment in history when our priority is to defeat our present-day enemy: China.

headline: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: ‘Searching for Romeo’
text: The night he crashed the Capulets’ little bash, Romeo was smitten with Rosaline, and Paris wanted Juliet for his bride. Then the star-crossed lovers spied each other. “It’s not like people fall in love at first sight. Unless they’re totally shallow,” Paris says in the playful, retropoppy “Searching for Romeo.”

headline: Playing Word Games With Sacred Texts
text: The artist Nina Yankowitz is known for projecting words in glass houses, and oh how they can shatter the place. For “Criss-Crossing the Divine,” her current exhibition at Guild Hall in East Hampton, she takes on sacred texts. “I’ve always been disturbed by the way religion is so often used to incite people towards divisive behavior,” she said of the interactive show, which is scheduled to run through July 27. “It prompted me to think of ways to motivate individuals to re-examine their personal value judgments.”

headline: Guiding Germany’s Young Muslims Off the Road to Jihad
text: BERLIN — BARELY five feet tall, Claudia Dantschke was dwarfed by the lectern when she spoke at a recent gathering of German experts on Islam, its challenges to democracy and especially the luring of teenagers from Europe to join the war in Syria.

headline: Legal Woes Pose Hurdles for Attorney General Tom Horne of Arizona in Campaign
text: PHOENIX — He has been caught by F.B.I. agents leaving the scene of a parking-garage fender-bender after a lunchtime tryst, a mishap that exposed not only the affair, but also a federal investigation into alleged campaign finance violations, which ended unceremoniously and without any charges.

headline: The Political Leanings of the Young
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Jackpot of Kitsch, Burgers and Beers
text: To reach Pinch, the “innovative restaurant concept” at the Empire City Casino in Yonkers, patrons arriving at the valet parking station under a bubble-shaped canopy must step through the looking-glass facade, ascend an escalator to the mezzanine — music throbbing, lights pulsing — and then hang a U-turn at the top, walking between chiming slot machines and a clamorous, chandeliered bowling alley. By the time you get to your table, you’re more than ready to sink into one of the padded armchairs and order a drink.

headline: Turkey: Prime Minister Looks Ahead
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday outlined his vision for his presidential campaign, promising to expand rights and liberties, improve welfare programs and build up Turkey’s economy. On Aug. 10, for the first time, Turkey’s president will be chosen directly by the voters, rather than by Parliament. The presidency has been largely a ceremonial post, but if Mr. Erdogan wins, as is widely expected, he is likely to try to expand the powers of the office. Mr. Erdogan has been the most powerful figure in Turkish politics for a decade. His opponents fear that if he is elected president, he will face no checks on the autocratic tendencies he has displayed in recent months while confronting challenges from street protests and a corruption inquiry. Speaking to more than two thousand supporters in Istanbul on Friday, Mr. Erdogan offered few details but vowed to expand democracy in Turkey if elected and to expand its role in international affairs.

headline: South Sudan: Refugee Crisis Worsens
text: The United Nations refugee agency said Friday that the number of South Sudanese fleeing for neighboring nations is expected to reach as many as 715,000 by year’s end, more than double the number envisioned when the agency began a funding appeal four months ago for refugees from South Sudan, which has been ravaged by a civil war and is on the verge of famine. “The ongoing conflict and worsening humanitarian situation inside the world’s youngest nation is fueling a refugee exodus into Ethiopia, Kenya, Sudan and Uganda at a much higher rate than initially anticipated,” an agency spokeswoman, Melissa Fleming, said in a statement on the crisis in South Sudan. The agency revised its funding appeal to $658 million from the original $371 million and warned that without urgent contributions, “the consequences could be drastic.” In another barometer of the worsening crisis, the charity Save the Children warned that a cholera outbreak that first appeared two months ago had spread, infecting more than 2,600 people and killing more than 60. Pete Walsh, Save the Children’s director in South Sudan, said in a statement that the country’s overstretched health service was plagued by widespread shortages of lifesaving supplies, as “desperate parents are coming to clinics with children who are already considerably weakened by the disease.”

headline: Should We Leave Our Wilderness to Its Fate?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Sunsets and Seafood Are Visions
text: On a recent Saturday night, the place was mobbed. Every table was taken and it was standing room only in the bar and lounge. It made perfect sense; there’s a lot to like at Bay Kitchen Bar in East Hampton.

headline: ‘A Cleaner Tomorrow’: 4 Environmentalists Speak Out
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Four-Star Female Admiral Makes History for the Navy
text: WASHINGTON — Adm. Michelle J. Howard was looking for new insignia for her white Navy dress uniform when she ran into an unusual problem.

headline: A Man Who Was More Than His Feet
text: When Patricia Ward Kelly met her future husband, Gene, in 1985, she had never heard of him. Somehow she — a “nerdy Melville scholar” who had been hired as a writer on a television documentary for which he was narrator — had missed all the films. Writer and narrator bonded over poetry and etymology. She fell in love with the man before she had ever seen the on-screen image beloved by millions.

headline: A Pizzeria’s Simple Pursuit of the Sublime
text: It’s no mean feat for a pizza restaurant to distinguish itself in Guilford — a town just 15 minutes north of such venerable New Haven institutions as Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana and Sally’s Apizza. But since it first opened for business in 2011, Bufalina has done just that. And it has largely set itself apart by keeping things small.
