headline: Chinese Businessman Is Charged in Plot to Steal U.S. Military Data
text: WASHINGTON — A Chinese businessman in Canada hacked into Boeing’s computers and stole information about United States military aircraft and weapons, the Justice Department said on Friday, describing a corporate espionage case that is unusual for the huge amount of data involved.

headline: Creativity 101
text: To the Editor:

headline: Star Reconnects With a Special Place in His Heart
text: CLEVELAND — Stumbling across introspection in a star pro athlete is like discovering a string of diamonds in the back of your closet.

headline: Seeking Revival, Cadillac Goes Outside for a Chief
text: Even as General Motors has rebounded from its bankruptcy in 2009, its Cadillac division has been a work in progress with the introduction of new models during a rotating cast of executives.

headline: Republican Jews Alarmed at the Prospect of a Void in the House and Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Jewish Republicans know they are not many in number. But at a recent gathering at the St. Regis Hotel in downtown Washington, they pondered the meaning of an especially alarming figure: zilch. As in zip, bupkis, zero.

headline: A Tarantula Isn’t Lost and Isn’t Real
text: It certainly sounded like a joke, one of those hoaxes far too good to be true. But there was the sign, taped to a utility pole in South Slope, Brooklyn:

headline: A Resurgence, With Bold Flavors
text: Coastal New Jersey has its share of Hurricane Sandy comeback stories. One of the more impressive ones concerns Daniel’s Bistro by the Sea.

headline: Does Johnny Depp Even Wear Jil Sander?
text: Peeking into some of those chic, expensive boutiques in SoHo on a slow day, it can be tough to tell which one is the clerk and which one is the mannequin. The only break in monotony is the occasional customer or the ringing of the telephone.

headline: Bury My Heart on West End Avenue
text: As an extremely small boy, when the question “What does Dickie want to be when he grows up?” was posed by doting adults, I was ready with the answer.

headline: U.S. Knew Britain Planned to Erase Data at The Guardian
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration knew in advance that the British government was planning in July 2013 to force the newspaper The Guardian to destroy hard drives containing copies of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden, and a high-ranking National Security Agency official celebrated the event as “good news,” newly disclosed emails show.

headline: Contingency Plans Issued in Event of an L.I.R.R. Strike
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Friday outlined its contingency plans for a Long Island Rail Road strike — a hodgepodge of shuttle buses, ferries, adjusted highway rules and other measures — declaring itself ready if workers walk off the job in a little over a week.

headline: American Apparel Is a Lesson in How Not to Run a Company
text: In the same week that a hedge fund, Standard General, essentially took over American Apparel, Bloomberg Businessweek published an eye-opening story about the company and its founder and former chief executive, Dov Charney. Eye-opening not in the usual manner when it comes to Charney: The magazine didn’t uncover any new allegations of sexual harassment, nor did the reporter watch him engaging in oral sex, as a writer from Jane magazine once famously witnessed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 11, 2014
Mideast Rockets and Airstrikes Continue
text: Gazans and Israelis braced for further conflict as Hamas fired more rockets into Israel and Israel continued its aerial assaults on Gaza.

headline: Ex-Governor, Jesse Ventura, Matches Outsize Image in Court
text: ST. PAUL — Jesse Ventura, the wrestler-turned-politician, looked slighter than he once had and more buttoned down, in pinstripes and glasses. Yet as Mr. Ventura, the former Minnesota governor, testified Friday in a defamation suit he has brought against an author, he was every bit the enormous, sometimes contradictory personality the public remembers: boisterous, boastful, even emotional.

headline: Heard the News on George Clooney? This Much Is True: He’s Livid

headline: Getting the Scoop, but Not Necessarily the Story
text: By being the first to report on Friday that LeBron James is returning to the Cleveland Cavaliers, Sports Illustrated beat a journalistic pack that included 15 on-air people at ESPN.

headline: Remains Thought to Be Those of American Missing in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Harry Devert left his job as a financial trader in New York for adventure on the road. He planned to ride his motorcycle to the World Cup in Brazil — only to vanish six months ago while heading through a dangerous part of Mexico on his way to the Pacific Coast.

headline: The Trouble With Brain Science
text: ARE we ever going to figure out how the brain works?

headline: Study of Organic Crops Finds Fewer Pesticides and More Antioxidants
text: Adding fuel to the debates over the merits of organic food, a comprehensive review of earlier studies found substantially higher levels of antioxidants and lower levels of pesticides in organic fruits, vegetables and grains compared with conventionally grown produce.

text: The 2014 election year is just kicking into gear, but we’ve learned so much already. Among the political pointers for candidates of the future:

headline: World Cup 2014: Executive Is Called Fugitive in Ticket-Selling Case
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A police investigation into an illegal ticket-selling scheme at the World Cup took a cinematic turn as one of the suspects slipped out of an employee entrance of the luxurious Copacabana Hotel in Rio de Janeiro just minutes before the police arrived to arrest him.

headline: Impermanent Art
text: Kara Walker’s “A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby,” at the Domino factory in Williamsburg, was disassembled this week, making part of the tradition of ephemeral art.

headline: It’s Summer. Let’s Bounce.
text: Children attending the Police Athletic League’s summer day camps played on Friday during a carnival at a Staten Island park.

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Railroad
text: Riders on the Long Island Rail Road received alarming notices this week about a possible strike starting July 20. Negotiations between union workers and officials from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the railway, are slow, at best. It will be up to Gov. Andrew Cuomo to prevent disruption for the riders who take 300,000 trips on the line every weekday. Earlier this week, Mr. Cuomo suggested that the labor talks were a federal issue under the Railway Labor Act, and Congress’s problem, not his. But that idea was rejected by New York’s congressional delegation.

headline: Amazon Asks Permission From F.A.A. to Test Drone Delivery System
text: In some ways, this was not the best week for Amazon. The Federal Trade Commission  sued it for improperly billing customers for games used by their children. And it continues to be enmeshed in a nasty public relations battle with the publisher Hachette.

headline: Watching Rockets, Feeling Sparks
text: Of all the metaphors deployed to describe the experience of love, fireworks are not only among the most explosive but also among the most ephemeral. Like some passions, they erupt in incendiary bursts, only to dissolve once they reach their apogee. The following poems about the romantic aspect of fireworks were recently “found” in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are reprinted verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

headline: An Inadequate Response to Concussions
text: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which is currently embroiled in a lawsuit over its ostrichlike response to concussions, released new voluntary guidelines on Monday for concussion safety. But these won’t necessarily fix the problem.

headline: Car-Hailing Service, Lyft, Postpones Its Debut in New York
text: Hours before it was to begin operating in Brooklyn and Queens on Friday, a car-hailing company that relies on drivers to use their own vehicles to carry passengers said it was delaying its New York debut, capping a day of legal tussles with city and state officials.

headline: Taxpayer-Financed Bigotry
text: President Obama should resist a pressure campaign by some religious groups to weaken a promised executive order that would prohibit federal contractors from discriminating against gay men, lesbians and transgender people in their hiring practices.

headline: Ruling That Rejects 2 Florida Districts’ Borders Casts Haze Over Coming Elections
text: TAMPA, Fla. — After political operatives helped redraw the boundaries of Florida’s Fifth Congressional District, now held by Representative Corrine Brown, a Democrat, it snaked all the way from Jacksonville to Orlando, packing in more Democrats, but also benefiting Republicans in nearby districts. In a similar process in the 10th District, in the Orlando suburb of Winter Garden, an “appendage” was tacked on benefiting the incumbent, Representative Daniel Webster, a Republican.

headline: Keeping Track: Unlocking Cellphones, H.I.V. Setback, Campus Assaults
text: A Bill to Unlock Cellphones

headline: The 14 Holy Helpers
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! In the Sunday, July 13 print puzzle and some versions of the electronic puzzle, there will be a note that reads: “The circled letters, when read clockwise, will reveal a quote from Gertrude Stein.”

headline: Charlie Haden, Influential Jazz Bassist, Is Dead at 76
text: Charlie Haden, one of the most influential bassists in the history of jazz, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 76.

headline: Bombs, Spies and Brazil’s Humiliation
text: A rain of rockets and bombs over Israel and the Gaza Strip in the past week demonstrated anew the power of extremists on each side to stoke yet another round of violence, adding to the list of victims and hatreds and pushing any possibility of a peace settlement further into the distance.

headline: P. N. Furbank, Biographer of E. M. Forster, Dies at 94
text: P. N. Furbank, a British critic and scholar whose life of E. M. Forster was widely viewed as one of the 20th century’s leading achievements in literary biography, died on June 27 in London. He was 94.

headline: The Mets, and Boras, Are Looking Ahead With a New Draftee
text: As the Mets took batting practice, Keith Hernandez and Michael Conforto, the team’s first-round draft pick, approached Scott Boras to chat near the dugout. Soon, Matt Harvey joined them. Of course, neither Harvey nor Conforto played in the Mets’ 7-1 win over the Miami Marlins on Friday at Citi Field, but the scene was symbolic of how Boras, one of the most influential and powerful agents in baseball, could affect the Mets’ future. He had needled the organization in the past for its tight spending, but, as he discussed Conforto and Harvey, he indicated all was well between him and the team.

headline: After Soccer Loss, Dilma Rousseff Soothes Brazil With a Song
text: BRASÍLIA — As her country recovers from its humiliating loss to Germany in the World Cup, President Dilma Rousseff sang a samba to express Brazil’s resilience and gave no quarter to opponents who suggest that the soccer disaster may haunt her in the election this fall.

headline: Last Votes Cast Over Plan to Lift Detroit From Bankruptcy
text: CHICAGO — Final votes on Detroit’s plan to emerge from bankruptcy this fall were submitted on Friday by its creditors, including Detroit workers and retirees, and the city is expected to file a formal tally of those votes in federal court by July 21.

headline: One Team, Two Cities, and None Are Happy
text: HARTFORD — Two years after a car tore through the St. Benedict playground in this city’s North End, the children’s steel climbing structure is twisted and buckled like a clumsy batter’s legs after he misses a curveball.

headline: An Internal Review of the Navy Yard Shooting
text: Investigators interviewed hundreds of witnesses and law officers, and reviewed radio communications and 911 calls to produce “a narrative of the multiagency response” to the shooting in September.

headline: Report Details Hindrances Police Faced in Navy Yard Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia police were hampered at the Washington Navy Yard shooting in September because a security guard had locked a video surveillance room, preventing officers from immediately making a clear assessment of the situation, according to a department report released Friday.

headline: Zohra Sehgal, Beloved and Prolific Indian Actress, Dies at 102
text: Zohra Sehgal, a beloved Indian actress and dancer who continued making movies into her 90s, died on Thursday in New Delhi. She was 102.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 12, 2014
text: “These events revealed totally unacceptable behavior. They should never have happened. I’m upset, I’m angry, I’ve lost sleep over this, and I’m working on it until the issue is resolved.”

headline: Corrections: July 12, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) GRAVITY (2013) A medical engineer (Sandra Bullock, above) and an astronaut (George Clooney) become stranded high above Earth when debris from a satellite destroys their space shuttle in this intense spectacle, directed by Alfonso Cuarón. “You have to see it to believe it,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Nothing in the movie — not hand tools or chess pieces, human bodies or cruise-ship-size space stations — rests within a stable vertical or horizontal plane. Neither does the movie itself, which in a little more than 90 minutes rewrites the rules of cinema as we have known them.” The film was nominated for 10 Oscars and won seven, including best director and best cinematography.

headline: As Israel Hits Mosque and Clinic, Air Campaign’s Risks Come Home
text: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip — As Israel’s air war against Hamas and Islamic Jihad fighters in Gaza entered its sixth day on Saturday, a pair of bombings threw the difficulties of the campaign into painful relief: Israel bombed a mosque, which its aerial photos indicated was harboring a weapons cache, and a center for the disabled, killing two residents and wounding three, as well as a caretaker.

headline: Analytics: Mark Sanford’s Reboot
text: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 13 issue of the magazine.

headline: This Road Work Made Possible by Underfunding Pensions
text: The Federal Highway Trust Fund is expected to run out of money in August. So, naturally, Congress is debating a temporary fix that involves letting corporations underfund their pension systems.

headline: LeBron’s Supporting Cast in Cleveland
text: LeBron James announced that he was returning to the Cleveland Cavaliers. A look at the rebuilding process that will be needed to secure an N.B.A. championship.

headline: Manuel Neuer’s Wanderlust
text: During his six World Cup matches, Manuel Neuer has covered about a third of the soccer field. This graphic compares Neuer’s Wanderlust to the other goalkeepers in the World Cup.

headline: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Brazil in Third-Place Match
text: The Netherlands beat Brazil, 3-0, to finish in third place in the World Cup, capping a horrendous final two games for Brazil in which it was outscored by 10-1.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Argentina, 1-0, in Extra Time to Win Final
text: Germany won the World Cup for the fourth time after Mario Götze scored in the 113th minute to give the Germans a 1-0 victory over Argentina.

headline: The D.J. Next Door
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Variety: A Fragrant Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Ah, do you smell that? That’s the enticing aroma of another wonderful acrostic puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

headline: Lie Back and Enjoy Your Flight
text: While service and perks have steadily eroded over the years on domestic flights, transcontinental service remains the arena of one-upmanship among competing airlines — especially those vying for forward-class fliers.

headline: Kerry Brokers a Deal to Audit All Afghan Votes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After nearly 12 hours of often tense negotiations, Secretary of State John Kerry announced Saturday that Afghanistan would audit all eight million votes cast in a runoff presidential election last month as part of a deal to end a tense power struggle between the top two candidates.

headline: Biggest Scorer in World Cup? Maybe Univision
text: Months before the first whistle of the World Cup, Juan Carlos Rodriguez, the president of the sports division of Univision Communications, presented his engineers with a challenge: Could they figure out how to beam its soccer broadcasts into American homes faster than its English-language competitors?

headline: Days of $2 Home Run Derby Are Long Gone
text: The All-Star Game Home Run Derby returns to its roots in Minnesota on Monday. But the 29th edition, at Target Field, will hardly resemble the first, at the Metrodome in 1985.

headline: Iraqi Militants Kill 26 in Raid on Baghdad Building
text: BAGHDAD — Gunmen stormed an apartment complex in Baghdad on Saturday night and killed at least 20 women and six men, according to the Interior Ministry.

headline: Adept? Yes. Adored? Not Yet.
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentine fans unfurled a banner at a World Cup semifinal match in São Paulo depicting Diego Maradona on one side, Lionel Messi on the other and Pope Francis in the middle.

headline: Scots Play Through Political Tumult
text: ABERDEEN, Scotland — Alex Salmond, the first minister of Scotland, was not sure where his drives were going during his outward nine in the Scottish Open pro-am, which he played as a member of Phil Mickelson’s group. His natural fade was exacerbated by a left-to-right wind blowing in his face. Taking his wayward shots in stride, Salmond stopped to sign autographs and pose for photographs, forging connections with his constituents to the far right of the fairway, if not of the political center.

headline: Tommy Ramone Dies at 65; He Gave Punk Rock Its Pulse
text: Tom Erdelyi, better known as Tommy Ramone, the founding drummer and last surviving original member of the Ramones, the New York City band whose dizzying, short blasts of melody codified the sound of punk rock, died on Friday at his home in Ridgewood, Queens. He was 65.

headline: Fund Investors, Basking Under Many Clouds
text: STOCKS rallied through the second quarter, as investors displayed a growing appetite for risk and a striking lack of concern about any reversal of fortune. Although they are still taking it mostly on faith, they remain confident that the Federal Reserve eventually will engineer a solid economic revival.

headline: Sticking to Their Guns, Fund Managers Reaped Big Returns
text: MANAGERS of three of the better-performing mutual funds of the second quarter toted up their returns by hewing to the old-time virtue of patience.

headline: Women to Wall Street: Are You Listening?
text: IMAGINE that you work for a financial company. You’ve plowed through stacks of research showing that women — who are increasingly educated and affluent — could be a big source of revenue for you. Now what?

headline: Jockeying for Position in the Bond-Fund Sweepstakes
text: AS he came to early prominence in the 1980s, Bill Gross was sometimes called the Peter Lynch of bonds, after the better-known manager of the Fidelity Magellan stock mutual fund.

headline: Choices Abound in an E.T.F. Boom
text: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds seem to be where all the action is in the asset management business lately. These funds trade throughout the day like stocks, and they have surged in number — by 78 percent from the end of 2008 through 2013.

headline: The Face of Unfortunate Fashion
text: MY pals and I have had flashes of inspiration — blinding insights that promised to be million-dollar ideas. Back when print journalism wasn’t such a dark and wintry boneyard, my friend Jay had the idea for a magazine of modern parenting called, simply, Fret. My buddy Bill wanted to put together a publication for short people like the two of us. He called it Small Man.

headline: In Going Home, James May Be Ending an Exile From Himself
text: Forgiveness is not one of my strong suits, so the idea that LeBron James would go back to Cleveland was unfathomable, even with Miami’s limitations.

headline: Civilians Pay a Price for Gains of Ukraine Forces

headline: Why Europe May Gain the Edge for Investors

headline: The Pendulum Takes a Swing Toward Value Stocks

Lipper, which tracks mutual funds, named it the best small-capitalization growth fund over the previous three and five years, and investors stormed in. It began 2013 with just $66 million in assets and attracted $380 million in new money for the year.

headline: U.S. and Iraqis Try to Fragment Extremist Group

headline: The Hudson Project: Humans and Machines, With the Flaming Lips, STS9, Keys N Krates, Yacht
text: In a headlining set on the first day of the Hudson Music Project, Wayne Coyne of the Flaming Lips sang one of the band’s chestnuts: “Yoshimi Battles The Pink Robots Pt. 1,” with lines like “It’s demanding to defeat those evil machines.” But this was the day of the festival where humans and machines were more cooperative than contentious. As if to prove that “electronic” is still an optional modifier for “dance music,” Friday’s lineup was sprinkled with acts that relied on human physicality, beyond clicks and key presses, in music that’s intended, after all, to get people moving.

headline: Pastor Led Son’s Gay Wedding, Revealing Fault Line in Church
text: Father and son had always been close, from the moment Tim Schaefer was born, six weeks premature, with blood poisoning, a weak heart and lungs, and a doctor who thought he would not make it through the night.

headline: Beleaguered Blue Helmets
text: UNITED NATIONS

headline: Es Devlin
text: Es Devlin is the stage and costume designer who transformed London’s Olympic Stadium into a giant Union Jack and made it possible for Miley Cyrus to cavort on a candy-pink model of her own tongue. Her work spans continents and genres including theater, opera, dance, rock concerts, film and television.

headline: Still at Odds With China
text: For more than a decade, the United States has been watching nervously to see how China would choose to wield its formidable and growing economic, political and military powers. The hope, as Robert Zoellick said in 2005 when he was a deputy secretary of state, was that Beijing would become a “responsible stakeholder” in the international system, working cooperatively to foster economic integration and the peaceful resolution of global tensions.

headline: The World According to Maxwell Smart, Part 1
text: IN the 1960s, there was a popular sitcom  — “Get Smart” — about a hapless secret agent named Maxwell Smart, played by Don Adams. Smart went by the code name “Agent 86.” “Get Smart” famously introduced the shoe phone to American audiences, but the show also introduced something else: its own version of the bipolar world. Do you remember the name of the intelligence agency Maxwell Smart worked for? It was called “Control.” And do you remember the name of Control’s global opponent? It was called “Kaos” — “an international organization of evil.”

headline: A Pipeline Threatens Our Family Land
text: LANCASTER, Pa. — MOUNTAIN LAUREL, tufted with pink blooms each spring, and leathery emerald rhododendron line the Tucquan Glen, a steep hollow in southern Lancaster County, Pa. The Tucquan Creek, home to towering tulip poplar and oak trees and the occasional red fox, rushes over natural rock dams and plunges into secluded swimming holes before it meets the Susquehanna River and continues to the Chesapeake Bay.

headline: The Afterlife
text: BOSTON — “WHEN was the last time you shopped for car insurance?” asks the letter, which arrived the day before Father’s Day. “If your answer is ‘I haven’t done that in years,’ you may be missing an opportunity to save money and get great service from GEICO.” The letter is addressed to our son, David.

headline: Don’t Like Your Neighbors’ House? Sue Them.
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — In October, Louis Cherry, an architect here, received a building permit and had the necessary approvals to begin constructing a house for himself and his wife, Marsha Gordon, on an empty lot in Oakwood, a historic district in Raleigh. The neighborhood features a variety of architectural styles, from postwar bungalows to Greek Revivals, shotguns to Queen Annes. Construction began that month and the home, modern but modestly so, is nearly complete.

headline: How to Talk About Pain
text: LONDON — IN 1926, Virginia Woolf published an essay on pain, “On Being Ill.” Isn’t it extraordinary, she observed, that pain does not rank with “love, battle and jealousy” among the most important themes in literature. She lamented the “poverty of the language of pain.” Every schoolgirl who falls in love “has Shakespeare, Donne, Keats to speak her mind for her; but let a sufferer try to describe a pain in his head to a doctor and language at once runs dry.”

headline: Look Homeward, LeBron
text: ONE of the more significant migrations in recent American history doesn’t involve pioneers heading West, refugees seeking sanctuary, or Joad-like families rambling in search of work. It involves the trajectory of our nation’s most talented citizens, who since the 1970s have been clustering ever more densely in certain favored cities, and gradually abandoning the places in between.

headline: Fighting Climate Change With Trade
text: The United States, the European Union, China and 11 other governments began trade negotiations this week to eliminate tariffs on solar panels, wind turbines, water-treatment equipment and other environmental goods. If they are able to reach an agreement, it could reduce the cost of equipment needed to address climate change and help increase American exports.

headline: Isn’t It Rich?
text: WASHINGTON — CHELSEA CLINTON never acted out during the eight years she came of age as America’s first daughter.

headline: All Children Should Be Delinquents
text: IN the late 1970s, in the Mississippi River town of Dubuque, Iowa, the threat of summer boredom was real. The nearest theme parks were hours away, and the best video games (Space Invaders, Asteroids) were coin guzzlers, fueled by hard-earned lawn-mowing or paper-route funds. While we had the requisite tennis courts and public swimming pools, which we used to exhaustion, our best resources were our rawest ones — hilly streets, undeveloped woods, local streams and hours of unstructured, unsupervised playtime.

She was impressed when the dialect quiz in The New York Times correctly identified where she was from: Tacoma and Spokane, Wash. “Completely spot on,” she wrote, followed by a smiling green emoji.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 13
text: Violence intensified between Israel and the Palestinians this week after three Israeli teenagers, were kidnapped and killed last month and one Palestinian youth was abducted and killed, sparking a surge of retaliatory attacks. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel promised to increase attacks on Hamas in the Gaza Strip. Israeli bombs struck a mosque on Saturday, and a center for the handicapped, killing two patients and wounding three.

headline: Flunking Out, at a Price
text: In the years before the mortgage crisis, financial regulators often looked the other way as banks and other lenders pursued reckless activities that cost investors, taxpayers and borrowers billions of dollars. When trouble hit, these regulators had to scramble to fix the mess that their inertia had helped create.

headline: Envisioning Profit in Environmental Good Works
text: ABOARD THE DREDGE BUTCHER, OFF THE LOUISIANA COAST — All day and all night, this ship off a knob of Louisiana at Alligator Bend sucks up silt from the floor of Lake Borgne and pumps it through a half-mile of fat steel pipe. At the other end, a slurry gushes noisily out into what was until recently a stretch of open water. New land is rising here, forming mud flats that will soon be covered with waving spartina grass.

headline: How Fan Loyalty Changed During the World Cup

headline: Speedy Pitches, Not Recoveries, in a League of Rising Scars
text: You don’t even feel it, this lightning bolt from the pitching gods, this great separator between ordinary and special, between a healthy arm and a vulnerable one. At least that is how it was for Jarrod Parker, as a teenager in Indiana, the first time he threw a baseball 98 miles an hour. He did not know then what he had done, or what it really meant.

headline: Alabama Ruling Hobbles Ban on Guns in the Open at Polls

headline: Carmelo Anthony Said to Agree to Re-Sign With the Knicks

headline: Mandalay’s Chinese Muslims Chilled by Riots
text: MANDALAY, Myanmar — When hundreds of Buddhist men carrying clubs and swords marauded through the streets of this old royal capital earlier this month, the owner of a Muslim-Chinese restaurant took down the Koranic scriptures and the image of Mecca hanging above the cashier and removed the Arabic writing from signs on the street.

headline: When Will We #BringBackOurGirls!
text: My Sunday column is about those kidnapped Nigerian girls, still missing after nearly three months. More broadly it’s about what we can do for all those other girls and boys out there who are missing an education. We may or may not be able to get the Nigerian girls back, but we can definitely do more to get other kids in school among the 58 million who should be in primary school but aren’t. And we can do more to see that the kids who are in school but aren’t learning anything actually get an education.

headline: French Rider Leads Way on Wet Ride in Mountains; Contador Is Sixth Over All
text: GÉRARDMER, France — Blel Kadri, a French rider who is frequently assigned by his team to join early and generally unsuccessful breakaways, was rewarded for his efforts Saturday when the Tour de France made its way to the Vosges mountains.

headline: Republicans Replay 2010 Strategy at State Level

headline: Germany’s Haunting Emptiness in Goal
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Manuel Neuer is the latest in a line of German goalkeepers regarded by many as the best in the world. German soccer fans often reminisce about the greatness of Sepp Maier and Harald Schumacher and Oliver Kahn, and if Neuer helps Germany win the World Cup final on Sunday, his place in history — even in the middle of his career — will be secure.

headline: U.S. Warns Iran Over ‘Unworkable’ Plans for Nuclear Power Program
text: VIENNA — A senior Obama administration official said Saturday that Iran continues to take “inadequate and unworkable” positions on the future of its nuclear program, and warned that the country would have to live with sharp limits on its ability to produce nuclear fuel for at least a decade, and perhaps longer.

headline: World Cup Revelry Overwhelms Beloved Neighborhood in São Paulo
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The World Cup has brought hordes of first-time visitors to Vila Madalena, a hilly, low-slung neighborhood of winding roads, countless bars and world-renowned street art in the middle of Brazil’s biggest, most vertical city. Revelers described the scene on game days along the district’s main drag as Carnival in Salvador: in other words, as packed, wild and carnal as Brazil’s rowdiest street bacchanal, 900 miles to the northeast.

headline: On-Field Identity, Often Lost Amid Victory, Becomes Easier to Spot in Defeat
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Soccer tournaments, and the World Cup in particular, tend to adhere to the law of diminishing returns. The exuberance and fanfare of the opening matches usually give way to stalemates in the later rounds. Even a World Cup final is not exempt from deadlock (as the Italians have demonstrated on two occasions). No country can afford to lose. The price of defeat remains far too high. Despite its inherent tension, the penalty kick shootout remains a cowardly way to engineer a result, albeit a positive one.

headline: Arthur J. Walker, Part of Family Espionage Ring, Dies at 79

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 13, 2014
text: “It’s so obvious you did not choose this for yourself. This is who you are, and this is who God created you to be.”

headline: 1914: Brady Climbs The Mönch in Just Ten Hours
text: LITTLE SCHEIDEGG, Switzerland – The ascent of the Mönch made on Saturday by Mr. J. H. Brady, of Baltimore, was accomplished in face of the most unfavorable conditions, and the route chosen on the northern side of the peak was one of the most difficult. The progress of Mr. Brady and the two Grindelwald guides, Christian and Peter Kaufmann, who accompanied him, could be observed nearly all the time through glasses from the Seiler Hotel, at Little Scheidegg. The party took ten hours to reach the summit. The ascent of the Mönch peak, although its altitude is not quite as great as that of the Jungfrau, is one of the most difficult climbs in the Bernese Oberland. From Little Scheidegg, at the foot of the Eiger — which with the Mönch and the Jungfrau forms the Interlaken group of peaks, of which the Mönch is the central one — the journey requires at least thirteen hours, with a stop for rest and sleep at the Guggi Hut, where climbers for the Mönch and the Jungfrau part company. The Mönch was first scaled by Dr. Porges, of Vienna, in 1857. Its altitude is 13,465 feet, and the climb from the Guggi requires between nine and ten hours. It cannot be undertaken by anyone but a most experienced climber, as the difficulties to be overcome are innumerable. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 14, 1914

headline: Certain Mobile Apps Covet New Real Estate: The Lock Screen
text: App makers have long vied for prime real estate on smartphones, coveting in particular a spot on the home screen, the front page where many people place their most frequently used apps.

headline: The Emotional Whiplash of Parenting a Teenager
text: Being a teenager is hard – being the parent of a teenager may be even harder. Any parent of an adolescent knows the pain of being rejected, neglected, or artfully critiqued by their teenager. But being pushed away is only the half of it. Raising teenagers becomes that much more stressful and confounding when teenagers interrupt weeks of frostiness with moments of intense warmth and intimacy.

headline: Palestinians Flee Northern Gaza as a Cease-Fire Appears Elusive
text: GAZA CITY — Several thousand Palestinians, defying the urging of Hamas to remain in their homes, fled areas in northern Gaza early Sunday after Israel warned them through fliers and phone calls of major attacks to come.

headline: From Benghazi to the Boardroom: The Road to the $7 Billion Citigroup Settlement
text: Updated, 8:23 p.m. | The stage was set for another public shaming of a Wall Street bank.

headline: Stretching Yoga Into a Social-Justice Pose
text: Should yoga be taxed? Washington, D.C., has decided that it should — and the question of whether that policy should expand is part of a larger debate about yoga, its customers and its labor force.

headline: Jersey City Officer Is Fatally Shot While Responding to Robbery Report
text: JERSEY CITY — When he was a teenager, Melvin Santiago was held up at gunpoint by a robber outside a gas station on the city’s west side. The experience made him want to become a police officer so that he could help make the neighborhood safer for his younger brother and the cousins he would go bowling with every other weekend.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: The Thierry Henry Show
text: HARRISON, N.J. — According to the conventional wisdom, what is missing from the Red Bulls’ roster is the proverbial No. 10, soccer’s on-field quarterback who leads the attack and is a towering figure in the midfield.

headline: 1939: England Bans Revengeful Wills
text: LONDON – One of the foundations of English law — that a person of sound mind may will his property to whom he likes — was set aside today [July 13] by the inheritance family provision act which came into operation in the British Isles. The act provides for nullification by court order of revengeful wills in which husbands or wives cut off their widow or widowers and children with a contemptuous shilling or nothing at all, leaving them destitute while the money goes to charity, to persons outside the family or to some freakish cause. Testators are given self-defense, however, in a clause permitting them to append a side statement to their wills setting forth the reason for ignoring the dependants. The courts will take such a statement into consideration when dealing with a contested will. Those who may benefit under the act are limited to a widow or widower, unmarried daughters of any age, sons under twenty-one and sons or daughters who cannot earn their living because of mental or physical incapacity. If any such persons contest a will, a court will decide whether ‘‘reasonable provision’’ has been made. If not, the court may ‘‘tear up’’ the will and redistribute the assets of an estate. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 14, 1939

headline: Bookstore Owner Takes On a Union, Shocking a Liberal Bastion
text: He hung photographs of Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr. above the cash registers, and filled the nooks and crannies with scholarly books. He threw open his doors to local authors, provided a home for the Queer Book Club and created a weekly story time program for children (in English, Spanish and Mandarin).

headline: New ‘Planet of the Apes’ Rules the Weekend Box Office
text: “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” the latest entry in the simian-power film series from 20th Century Fox, took in an estimated $73 million at the domestic box office, as Hollywood shook off its dreary performance over the Fourth of July holiday and fierce competition from a World Cup final match on Sunday. The film topped the weekend box office, placing ahead of Paramount’s “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” which ranked second, with $16.5 million in sales, and about $209 million since its release on June 27. “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” handily beat the performance of its predecessor, “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” which took in $54.8 million on its first weekend in August 2011 and went on to sell $176.7 million in tickets at the domestic box office.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 10:30 P.M. (Ovation) SERENITY (2005) A small crew aboard a spaceship led by Capt. Malcolm Reynolds (Nathan Fillion) tries to scrape together a living smuggling cargo from one fringe of the universe to the next in this film written and directed by Joss Whedon. But the crew members’ off-the-radar existence is threatened when an agent (Chiwetel Ejiofor) of an oppressive government tracks them down, intent on killing a teenager aboard the ship (Summer Glau, above). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis compared this science-fiction adventure with the “Star Wars” movies by George Lucas. “Scene for scene, ‘Serenity’ is more engaging and certainly better written and acted than any of Mr. Lucas’s recent screen entertainments,” she wrote. “Mr. Whedon isn’t aiming to conquer the pop-culture universe with a branded mythology; he just wants us to hitch a ride to a galaxy far, far away and have a good time.”

headline: Americans and Iranians See Constraints at Home in Nuclear Negotiations
text: VIENNA — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here early Sunday in an attempt to rescue negotiations with Iran that have stalled on the question of how large a nuclear infrastructure that nation will be permitted to have over the next decade or two. But he quickly confronted the fact that the problem might be less at the negotiating table here than with mullahs in Tehran and members of Congress in Washington.

headline: Deadlock Blocks Iraqi Leadership Vote as ISIS Makes Gains Toward Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — As Iraq’s deadlocked Parliament was again unable to reach a deal to name a new speaker on Sunday, Sunni militants carried out a raid near Baghdad, a symbolically significant attack signaling their intent to move closer, even if only by a few miles, toward the Iraqi capital.

headline: Lorin Maazel, an Intense and Enigmatic Conductor, Dies at 84
text: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to become the music director of the New York Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra, the Vienna State Opera and several other ensembles and companies around the world, and who was known for his incisive and sometimes extreme interpretations, died on Sunday at his home in Castleton, Va. He was 84.

headline: Germany vs. Argentina: World Cup 2014 Final Live Blog
text: Germany and Argentina meet in a showdown for the World Cup title.

headline: Ukrainian Forces Close In on Rebel-Held Luhansk
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces battered the outer suburbs of the rebel stronghold of Luhansk on Sunday, pushing deeper than ever but falling short of retaking the city.

headline: Nepal Retracts Permission for Tibet Monk’s Cremation
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Under scrutiny from China, Nepal’s government announced on Sunday that it had retracted its permission to allow the cremation of a prominent spiritual figure in Tibetan Buddhism to be held on its territory.

headline: Statement by Player Erases the Last Doubt
text: LAS VEGAS — Nothing about the process happened swiftly or easily. Even an expected announcement that Carmelo Anthony was re-signing with the Knicks took more than a day to be publicly delivered. But after months of uncertainty about whether Anthony would return to New York, what were a few more hours of waiting?

headline: Paul Pierce, Leaving Nets, Is Said to Reach Deal With Wizards
text: The Nets shocked the basketball world at the 2013 N.B.A. draft by snapping up Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce of the Boston Celtics in a trade.

headline: The Hudson Project: Kendrick Lamar, Griz, !!!, Z. Z. Ward
text: I had expected a big influx of weekend festival-goers on Saturday, the second day of the Hudson Project, but I didn’t see one. It was still a relatively cozy event, with sightlines for everyone at outdoor stages and room inside the tents for all who wanted to be there. On Saturday, only one tent set had a big spillover outside, probably by choice; it was hotter and muddier inside. That was the set by Griz — ­­a whomping, quick­-changing barrage of hip­-hop, funk, reggae and ska, including shamelessly crowd-pleasing oldies like “Shout!” and Wild Cherry’s “Play That Funky Music.”

headline: Holder Voices ‘Extreme Concern’ About Terrorist Bomb Makers
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. expressed “extreme, extreme concern” on Sunday over reports that bomb makers from Yemen responsible for the 2009 underwear-bomb plot are now in Syria cooperating with foreign militants there, possibly to develop new, nearly undetectable explosive devices.

headline: The World Cup Is Nearly Over — but Not the Spirit of Soccer
text: Coming off its sound defeat of Brazil in a World Cup semifinal, the German national soccer team will face off against Argentina this afternoon in the final match of the tournament.

headline: It’s Not the Economy, Stupid
text: One thing about the Obamacare denialists: they don’t give up. First nobody but the sick would sign up, so we’d have a death spiral. Then it was “OK, a lot of people have signed up, but they won’t pay — and anyway, even more people have lost coverage.” Now they face evidence like this:

headline: French Rider Gains the Yellow Jersey on the Eve of Bastille Day
text: MULHOUSE, France — In time for Bastille Day, Tony Gallopin, a French rider, took the Tour de France lead on Sunday.

headline: Neil Young Cancels a Concert in Israel
text: Neil Young has canceled a concert scheduled for Tel Aviv this week because of hostilities between Israel and Hamas. The concert, with Mr. Young’s band Crazy Horse, was scheduled for Thursday at Hayarkon Park in Tel Aviv.

headline: Peak Performances to Offer 14 Premieres
text: The Peak Performance series is celebrating its 10th anniversary – and that of the opening of its home, the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, in Montclair, N.J. – with a season that includes 14 music, dance and theater premieres.

headline: A Woman at the Center, Drifting to the Fringe
text: “Price of Fame” completes Sylvia Jukes Morris’s two-volume character study of Clare Boothe Luce, one of the 20th century’s most ambitious, unstoppable and undeniably ingenious characters. The whole project weighs in at a mere 1,296 pages, so it does not even set the Morris house record. This author is married to Edmund Morris, whose splendid, three-volume Theodore Roosevelt totaled almost twice that page count.

headline: A Life on the Podium
text: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to hold the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic and several other ensembles around the world, was 84.

headline: Mechanical and Sensual, Still Baring Shoulders Decades Later
text: The Lincoln Center Festival’s retrospective of four early works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker offers the opportunity, rare in contemporary dance, to track the development of a major artist piece by piece. And development is not synonymous with improvement.

headline: Mrs. Terrible, Before She Met Her Czar Ivan
text: Making a rare appearance in New York, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet have arrived from Moscow for, in effect, a jam-packed two-week residency courtesy of the Lincoln Center Festival. Opera fans might feel shortchanged: Starting Tuesday, the company is presenting elaborate productions of three ballets: “Swan Lake,” “Don Quixote” and “Spartacus.” But the only operatic offering? A pair of concert performances of Rimsky-Korsakov’s “The Tsar’s Bride.”

headline: Hall of Famers at the Summer North American Championships
text: The American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North American Championships begin on Thursday in Las Vegas. The Hall of Fame ceremonies and dinner take place late that afternoon.

headline: Walken as Captain Hook in NBC’s ‘Peter Pan’
text: Christopher Walken, below, will grab the hammy role of Captain Hook in NBC’s new live version of “Peter Pan,” the network’s follow-up to its hugely successful live musical for this past holiday season, “The Sound of Music.” Robert Greenblatt, NBC’s top entertainment executive, announced the casting of Mr. Walken on Sunday in Los Angeles at an annual gathering of television critics. Mr. Greenblatt cited Mr. Walken’s early experience as a song-and-dance man as well as his numerous well-received appearances as a guest host of “Saturday Night Live.” NBC plans to mount the production, “Peter Pan Live!,” in December. The network still needs to find a Peter. Mr. Greenblatt had no announcement on that front, although he did confirm that the network had pursued Kristen Bell (“Frozen”), but could not work out a schedule for her because of her commitment to the Showtime series “House of Lies.” Mr. Greenblatt did say that NBC would stick to the tradition of hiring a female star for Peter, after originally thinking that a man might be considered for the part.

headline: Germans End Long Wait: 24 Years and a Bit Extra
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — For years, Brazilians had a phrase they would inevitably utter when things went wrong. “Imagina na Copa,” they said after an endless traffic jam or a construction accident or an ugly rash of violence dominated the news — imagine if this happened during the World Cup. It became a foreboding warning, a pre-emptive sigh at the presumed disasters that lay ahead.

headline: A Political Comedy for Off Broadway
text: Mario Correa’s political comedy “Tail! Spin!” is to open Off Broadway at the Lynn Redgrave Theater just as this fall’s midterm elections are heating up, the show’s producers announced on Sunday. The play was warmly received at the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Dan Knechtges will return as director, and Rachel Dratch (“Saturday Night Live”) will reprise her roles as “Wives, Tails, Beards & Barbara Walters.” Other roles are expected to be cast this month, Billy Zavelson, one of the show’s producers, said by phone. “Tail! Spin!” uses texts, emails, tweets and remarks from four politicians disgraced by sex scandals: Anthony Weiner, Mark Foley, Larry Craig and Mark Sanford. It has been updated to include material from Mr. Weiner’s unsuccessful run for mayor of New York and Mr. Sanford’s election to Congress, Mr. Zavelson said. “And if another scandal of this ilk happens, we’ll add that to the show, too,” he said. “Tail! Spin!” is to begin previews on Sept. 18 and will open on Oct. 1.

headline: The House That Romeo Built
text: You know the routines by now: Romeo Santos has been doing this for too long. There will be a woman of ample proportions, and Mr. Santos will sing “Un Beso” to her, then kiss her, then encourage her to let her hands roam free on his body. There will be admonishments to the men in the audience about how they aren’t satisfying their women. There will be a microphone stand, parts of the stage and even the air itself that spend long stretches of time on the receiving end of Mr. Santos’s gyrating pelvis.

headline: A Game as Literary Tutorial
text: When he was an immigrant boy growing up in New Jersey, the writer Junot Díaz said he felt marginalized. But that feeling was dispelled somewhat in 1981 when he was in sixth grade. He and his buddies, adventuring pals with roots in distant realms — Egypt, Ireland, Cuba and the Dominican Republic — became “totally sucked in,” he said, by a “completely radical concept: role-playing,” in the form of Dungeons & Dragons.

headline: Battle for the 2014 World Cup Trophy
text: Germany, just off a stunning victory against Brazil, faced off with Argentina, whose star player Lionel Messi faced the biggest test of his international career. Germany won in extra time.

headline: Mets Surge Into the All-Star Break on a Wave of Confidence
text: The Mets celebrated the last win of their best homestand in four years by shaking hands and patting one another on the back. They had just won their eighth of 10 games against Texas, Atlanta and Miami, a 9-1 victory over the Marlins on Sunday at Citi Field.

headline: An Original Tough Career Woman
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — The most famous aria of Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia” is the title character’s last. In “Era desso il figlio mio,” the power-hungry femme fatale of the title laments the loss of her son, whom she has unwittingly poisoned, in an explosion of vocal fireworks. It’s also an aria that Donizetti cut when he revised the opera in 1840, seven years after its Milan premiere, in an attempt to focus the drama more sharply.

headline: An Incoming Conductor Brings a Sunny Outlook
text: LENOX, Mass. — The weather here at Tanglewood, the beautiful summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, often seems to reflect the mood of the institution. How frequent were those terrifying thunderstorms and winds during and after the last years of James Levine’s tenure as music director, rife with illnesses and cancellations?

headline: A Bride Finds Her Gown, and a Groom
text: The official English title of the Bollywood confection “Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania” is “Humpty Sharma’s Bride.” Yet, at the start, Kavya (Alia Bhatt), the heroine, is weeks away from an arranged marriage to someone else. Insisting that if she can’t choose her groom, she should at least wear a designer gown, Kavya travels to New Delhi to earn money and buy one.

headline: Using Speech and Instruments, but Mostly Singing Feet
text: As the American Tap Dance Foundation wisely realizes, feet get hot in the summer. But at Tap City, its friendly weeklong festival that wrapped up on Saturday, little makes them bleed. (The vibe here is more summer camp.) On Thursday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, the gaiety continued with “Tap and Song,” an eclectic program, directed by Tony Waag, intent on highlighting the breadth of the art form — from vaudeville and comedy to contemporary styles — by showing how tap dance is a form of music.

headline: Q. and A.: Cathy Giangrande on China’s Museum Boom
text: Whether celebrating fine art or ancient artifacts, salt or signboards, China increasingly has a museum for most tastes — and a few that can be found nowhere else, such as one devoted to whistling kites. As money has piled up in recent decades, Chinese are turning to culture and the country is in a museum-building boom.

headline: Eerie Encounter
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We last saw MaryEllen Uthlaut back in 2010, when she made her debut in The New York Times crossword puzzle and she returns today to remind us that everything is not always as it seems when we look up into the night sky.

headline: Zine Makers Grab Their MetroCards and Go to Work
text: One woman drew cartoons in an artist’s notebook. Another snipped off pieces from a subway map, then pasted them onto a white paper. Yellow fliers that read “Service Changes” along with “Zine Residency!” were taped to subway car walls. And a black banner with the words “Zinesters in Residence” hung from a railing.

headline: Poor Sanitation in India May Afflict Well-Fed Children With Malnutrition
text: SHEOHAR DISTRICT, India — He wore thick black eyeliner to ward off the evil eye, but Vivek, a tiny 1-year-old living in a village of mud huts and diminutive people, had nonetheless fallen victim to India’s great scourge of malnutrition.

headline: The Hudson Project: A Storm Stops the Music
text: With a torrential thunderstorm moving on Sunday afternoon, the Hudson Project music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., was shut down and the site evacuated. Organizers hoped to resume the event if they could fit more music in before another band of storms.

headline: Boeing Optimistic That Export-Import Bank Will Get Funding
text: LONDON — The head of Boeing’s commercial aircraft division said on Sunday that he was optimistic that the United States Congress would ultimately agree to reauthorize funding to the Export-Import Bank, which guarantees billions of dollars in loans to foreign buyers of its airplanes.

headline: Spies Like Us
text: HAMBURG, Germany — Is it because they know us so little — or because they know us too well — that the Americans can’t stop spying on us Germans?

headline: Editorial Cartoon
text: Uncle Sam has a rat problem.

headline: Even on Nantucket, a Funeral Home Is a Luxury
text: NANTUCKET, Mass. — The hole at the cemetery was dug. The flowers had arrived, family and friends had gathered, food was ready for the reception. All that was missing was the deceased. Doris Davis could not make her own funeral.

headline: Discrimination Is Un-Christian, Too
text: Much to the chagrin of women’s rights advocates, Hobby Lobby has won its legal battle — but claims of “victory” for religious freedom must be emended. Make no mistake: This is no victory for the freedom to exercise Christian principles. Though employers like Hobby Lobby are now free to deny women access to contraceptives through their employer-subsidized health plans on the basis of religious objection, they will be violating their own purported Christian principles if they do. While Christians are not compelled by their faith to engage in religious practices that impose upon the freedoms of others, they are compelled — by their belief that all persons, men and women, are created in the image of God — to oppose discrimination.

headline: In a First Since the 1990s, a Large Bulgarian Bank Goes Bankrupt
text: After a tumultuous month for the Bulgarian financial sector during which thousands of fearful depositors lined up to pull their savings out of two banks, the country’s central bank has said it will start bankruptcy proceedings against one of the lenders.

headline: ‘No One Is Rooting for Him Harder Out There’
text: ABERDEEN, Scotland — The golfer and the caddie were on a bucket-list course thousands of miles from home, two friends bonding over their shared affinity for the game and for competition.

headline: Samsung Considers Its Counterattack as Rivals Erode Cellphone Profit
text: What goes up must come down. That principle seems to be coming true for Samsung Electronics, the world’s top cellphone maker, whose profit is falling in part because of pressure from its price-cutting rivals in China.

headline: Lindt Nears a Deal to Buy Russell Stover Candies
text: The Swiss maker of Lindt chocolate is closing in on a deal to acquire Russell Stover Candies, the storied American boxed-chocolate maker, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Caddie Who Mastered the Game
text: Near the end of the film “The Greatest Game Ever Played,” the story of the 20-year-old amateur Francis Ouimet’s upset of the celebrated British golfers Harry Vardon and Ted Ray in the 1913 United States Open, Vardon, played by the actor Stephen Dillane, congratulates Ouimet in the locker room.

headline: Rivalry Begins for Sisters With Ambition
text: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — Shortly after she was selected in April as the No. 1 overall pick in the W.N.B.A. draft by the Connecticut Sun, Chiney Ogwumike moved into her own apartment. During her first visit, Ify Ogwumike, Chiney’s mother, presented her second-oldest daughter with a housewarming gift that carried a not-so-subtle message, a study guide for the Graduate Record Examination.

headline: Can a Jury Believe What It Sees?
text: LOS ANGELES — LAST week the F.B.I., the Drug Enforcement Administration and other federal law enforcement agencies instituted a policy of recording interrogations of criminal suspects held in custody. Only a minority of states and local governments have a similar requirement, but the new rule, which applies to nearly every federal interrogation, will most likely spur more jurisdictions to follow suit. It’s not far-fetched to think that such recordings may soon become standard police practice nationwide.

headline: Whiting Petroleum to Buy Kodiak Oil & Gas
text: Whiting Petroleum Corporation on Sunday said it would buy Kodiak Oil & Gas Corporation for $3.8 billion in stock, and assume $2.2 billion of Kodiak’s debt.

headline: The View From the Handlebars Makes Its Debut
text: NANCY, France — Television production of the Tour de France is a technological and logistical marvel involving fleets of motorcycles, helicopters and airplanes. But it lacks one element that has long been a part of motorsports broadcasting: onboard live cameras.

headline: Marijuana Is at Center of Feud in Capital
text: WASHINGTON — A law to make marijuana possession in the District of Columbia punishable by only a $25 ticket, one of the laxest drug laws in the nation, has ignited a feud between Washington’s mayor and a Republican House member days before it is to take effect.

headline: The Skeleton Garden of Paris
text: I am at the Jardin des Plantes, in the Fifth Arrondissement on the Left Bank of the Seine. Here we find one of the world’s oldest zoos, still officially called a “menagerie,” various greenhouses and rows of brilliant dahlias book-ended by statues of Jean-Baptiste Lamarck and Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon. We also find the various galleries composing the National Museum of Natural History. These include, not least, the Gallery of Paleontology and Comparative Anatomy, a two-floor exhibition hall built in preparation for the 1900 World Fair, where the skeletons and preserved tissues of thousands of animal species are on display: the massive jaws of sperm whales, cross-sections of elephant molars like great petrified mille-feuilles, countless miniature bat skulls under tiny glass domes.

headline: After a Mejia Save, Improvisation Beats Premeditation
text: Jenrry Mejia of the Mets was one strike away from ending the game, and the fans at Citi Field were on their feet. Mejia composed himself, unleashed a nasty slider and broke into an elaborate celebration. He slapped his glove twice, lifted his arms and his right knee, then slammed them down. It looked like a dance inspired by Ray Lewis.

headline: Tech Scene in Myanmar Hinges on Cellphone Grid
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Images of Steven P. Jobs and Mark Zuckerberg adorn the walls of Myo Myint Kyaw’s creative digital agency. He says they inspire him. But he imagines neither man ever worked in an environment where Internet connections were so unreliable that a “file transfer” often involved delivering electronic documents across town by taxi.

headline: Prospects Show Promise in Their Pop
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Chiseled into a limestone wall on the Legends Club level of Target Field is the number 573, several feet high, representing the career home run total of the Hall of Famer Harmon Killebrew.

headline: For a Weekend, Ukraine Rebels Make Love, Not War
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — It was a weekend of love in this city of war.

headline: Obamacare Fails to Fail
text: How many Americans know how health reform is going? For that matter, how many people in the news media are following the positive developments?

headline: ‘The Buck Stops With Me’
text: In trying to lay the blame for the border crisis on the White House’s doorstep, House Speaker John Boehner exploded at a press conference on Thursday, saying of the president:

headline: With Return of Anthony, Knicks Quietly Edge Ahead
text: Ah, Carmelo, you coquette, it’s good to have you back.

headline: Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say
text: Student loan debt hovers at more than $1 trillion, a threefold surge from a decade ago, and a record number of college students who graduated as the financial system nearly imploded have an average debt load of more than $20,000.

headline: How to Teach Reading and Writing
Vaccines May Be Costly, but They Save Lives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Doctors Run Late
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Security Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gambling on Casinos in New York
text: The timing is worthy of note. As trucks in Albany were unloading reams of documents describing 17 proposals for four new casinos in New York, Moody’s Investors Service was issuing its latest report on gambling — downgrading the national gambling business from “stable” to “negative.” In other words, just when New York is proposing to ramp up its gambling business, the financial community is souring on the idea that casinos are an easy answer to state and local financial problems.

headline: Dirty Tricks, Tea Party Suicide and Rising Mississippi Anger
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Mark Mayfield, one of the founders of the Mississippi Tea Party, had lost his political appetite.

headline: Poison Shot From Guns
text: Sometimes the gross ineffectiveness of Congress is a boon to the nation by heading off a plainly regressive result. This was the case last week when a partisan Senate dispute over election-year gun politics had the unintended effect of killing off a pernicious proposal to bar environmental controls over lead ammunition and fishing sinkers that increasingly threaten fish and wildlife. The poisonous effects of ingesting lead fragments have been documented in numerous studies — the latest counting more than 120 species of birds in North America suffering from the thousands of tons of lead scattered annually by sportsmen.

headline: Success for Brazil, Just Not on the Field
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — When Mario Götze settled a crossing pass with his chest and volleyed a goal that won the World Cup, German fans roared in ecstatic release. Those from Brazil were nearly as delirious, even if it was out of relief as much as celebration.

headline: How Race Skews Prosecutions
text: In the legal stratosphere where Supreme Court justices sit, racism may appear to be largely a thing of the past. But down on the ground, where citizens and law enforcement encounter each other daily, race still matters. That is the key finding of an extensive report issued last week on the prosecutorial practices of the Manhattan district attorney’s office, one of the biggest and busiest in the country.

headline: As Strike Threat Looms, Stalled L.I.R.R. Talks Carry Hint of the Past
text: As the Long Island Rail Road lurches toward a possible strike that could shut it down as soon as Sunday, the long-running dispute between the railroad and its unions carries echoes of the last time workers walked out. But in the final week before the strike deadline, the gap between the two sides is actually much smaller this time around.

headline: Kansas’ Ruinous Tax Cuts
text: There was a windstorm of hasty excuses in recent weeks after Kansas reported that it took in $338 million less than expected in the 2014 fiscal year and would have to dip heavily into a reserve fund. Spending wasn’t cut enough, said conservatives. Too many rich people sold off stock in the previous year, state officials said. It’s the price of creating jobs, said Gov. Sam Brownback.

headline: In a Latino Enclave, the World Cup Puts Everything on Pause
text: Something unusual happened on Sunday afternoon on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens: Quiet.

headline: Brazilians Go Back to Real Life
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil suffered mightily with its national team’s 7-1 rout at the hands of Germany in the World Cup semifinals last week, but the authorities here breathed sighs of relief as the tournament came to a close on Sunday with Germany’s victory over Argentina, amid muted street protests and a display of Brazil’s ability to successfully organize sporting megaevents.

headline: Jerusalem’s Damaged Link
text: A light rail line connecting Arab and Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem was damaged during riots. Some Arab residents would rather not see the line re-opened.

headline: After Lapses, C.D.C. Admits a Lax Culture at Labs
text: ATLANTA — Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, spent much of Wednesday completing a report that would let the public see, in embarrassing detail, how the sloppy handling of anthrax by scientists at its headquarters here had potentially exposed dozens of employees to the deadly bacteria.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 13, 2014
Germany Outlasts Argentina for the World Cup
text: Both Germany and Argentina had solid chances throughout the game, but Germany finally scored in the 113th minute, lifting the country to its fourth World Cup title.

headline: Grief and Evacuation in Gaza
text: As 18 victims of an airstrike in Gaza City were buried, Palestinians fled the north after Israel warned of major attacks.

headline: Yankees’ Exclamation Point Twists Into Question Mark
text: BALTIMORE — The full effects of the loss of Masahiro Tanaka could not begin to actually be felt until Sunday night, when his turn in the rotation arrived and his loss to an elbow injury sustained Wednesday became all too real for the treading-water Yankees.

headline: Frederick I. Ordway III Dies at 87; NASA Official Helped Shape ‘Space Odyssey’
text: Frederick I. Ordway III, whose expertise in science fiction and real space exploration helped shape the groundbreaking imagery and feel of the film “2001: A Space Odyssey,” died on July 1 at his home in Huntsville, Ala. He was 87.

headline: USA Today Goes Viral
text: TYSONS CORNER, Va. — “Today is a good day to be here because we are starting Social Media Tuesdays,” exclaims Larry Kramer, the publisher of USA Today.

headline: U.S. Sees Risks in Assisting a Compromised Iraqi Force
text: WASHINGTON — A classified military assessment of Iraq’s security forces concludes that many units are so deeply infiltrated by either Sunni extremist informants or Shiite personnel backed by Iran that any Americans assigned to advise Baghdad’s forces could face risks to their safety, according to United States officials.

headline: In Divided Jerusalem, Rail Line for Arabs and Jews Is Among the Fractures
text: JERUSALEM — So much here seems so broken right now: the peace process, the moral compass.

headline: Shutting the Door on His Past to Settle Into His Present
text: When Robert Boswell’s “The Long Shrift” opens, 18-year-old Richie Singer has been imprisoned for the rape of a classmate. His parents, Henry (Brian Lally) and Sarah (Ally Sheedy), have sold their home to pay his lawyer’s fees and have washed up in the sort of prefab dump that gives hovels a bad name. “The walls are made of cardboard,” Sarah complains. “The front door won’t even shut.” (Credit the designer Andromache Chalfant with the impeccably slapdash set.)

headline: Sing the Song Before You Drop That Bomb
text: Summer in the city is a time for musical experimentation, with the New York Musical Theater Festival and the New York International Fringe Festival among industry showcases for developing works. Given their aim to allow creative teams to assess the strengths and weakness of their babies while they eye a commercial future, those forums invite a spirit of forgiveness from the audience as the teething troubles and conceptual kinks are worked out.

headline: Capitol’s Partisanship Is Taking Hold in Governors’ Ranks
text: NASHVILLE — When the country’s governors gather twice each year, they delight in excoriating Washington’s political gridlock, holding themselves up as champions of a brand of can-do bipartisanship that is far too scarce in the nation’s capital.

headline: James Rollins Receives a $15 Million Multibook Deal
text: The thriller writer James Rollins has stuck with the same editor and publisher for 15 years — the kind of devotion rarely seen in today’s fluid and fickle publishing business. Now, he is being richly rewarded for his loyalty.

headline: Germans See World Cup Win as a Symbol of Global Might
text: BERLIN — Even normally quiet streets were electrified early Monday by Germany’s dramatic 1-0 win of the World Cup in extra time, a victory that symbolized, at least to fans, not just the country’s dominance of Europe, but its global prominence. Car horns and vuvuzelas honked, and fireworks and firecrackers exploded.

headline: BitTorrent to Try a Paywall and Crowdfunding
text: LOS ANGELES — This might be the latest twist on crowdfunding — or the web equivalent of seeking a ransom.

headline: ‘True Blood’ Recap: Hey, Things Are Looking Less Ghastly, at Least for a Moment
text: Season 7, Episode 4 Eric’s back, and that was the big news in Sunday night’s episode of “True Blood.” Mr. Northman, a pretty tendril of hepatitis-infected vein peeking out above his T-shirt, and his Sancho Panza, Pam, made an understated arrival as Bill Compton was preparing to lead what was left of the Bon Temps irregulars — Sookie and Jason, Sam Merlotte and the vampires Violet, Jessica, James and a couple of newbies — in a seeming suicidal attempt to rescue Arlene and the others from the basement of Fangtasia. The addition of Eric, Pam and Eric’s reluctant spawn Willa tipped the balance in their favor.

headline: Go Where the Money Is, AARP Tells Marketers
text: THE organization that serves as an advocate for Americans who are ages 50 and up is hoping the progress that has been made in changing minds on Madison Avenue about the value of marketing to older consumers will not be reversed by a growing ardor for the younger generation known as millennials.

headline: Treasury Auctions and Bond Issues Set for the Week of July 14
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Afghans to Alter the Government
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The deal that Secretary of State John Kerry brokered to ease the Afghan election crisis with a sweeping audit of the vote was quietly built on an even more profound reshaping of the entire government system, American and Afghan officials confirmed Sunday: The sides have agreed to gradually create an empowered prime minister post after years of an all-encompassing presidency.

headline: Bergdahl Is Set to Resume Life on Active Duty
text: WASHINGTON — Six weeks after being released from five years in Taliban captivity, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is expected to return to life as a regular Army soldier as early as Monday, Defense Department officials said late Sunday.

headline: A Longtime Devotee Examines His Evolving Game
text: Paul O’Neill has flashbacks of his childhood when it is time for baseball’s All-Star Game.

headline: Rival Factions in Libyan Capital Battle for Control of Main Airport
text: CAIRO — Rival militias in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, fought for control of the city’s main airport on Sunday, leaving at least six people dead and causing the cancellation of international flights, officials said.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Album sales are down 15 percent this year, according to Nielsen, compared with the first six months of 2013. Audio streaming, however, is up 50 percent for the same period, and video streaming is up 35 percent.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Recap: Into the Dark, With a Cliché or Two
text: Season 1, Episode 3 It is no fault for a story to interrogate the ways we struggle with calamity, or even to present a vision of that struggle so bleak it can drive a viewership to despair. Loss is universal. Artists, have at it.

headline: Bid to Deliver Aid to Syria May Set Stage for a U.N. Clash
text: The United Nations Security Council was potentially headed for a showdown on Monday over getting food and medicine to millions of needy Syrians.

headline: Three Cheers for Germany
text: In an East Village beer garden, cheers erupted as Germany won the World Cup.

headline: In Buenos Aires, Applause and Cheers Despite Argentina’s Loss
text: BUENOS AIRES — Before the World Cup final, many Argentines had confidently predicted victory. They trusted in Coach Alejandro Sabella’s switch from an offensive style to a more cautious approach to overcome Germany. After the match, they cut forlorn figures, but their sadness was eclipsed by a feeling of pride in the players’ efforts.

headline: Second Thoughts on Lighter Sentences for Drug Smugglers
text: There was the grandmother who hid heroin in the rails of her wheelchair. The pair of women who sewed cocaine packets into their hair extensions. And the Trinidadian man who stuffed cocaine in frozen goat meat.

headline: A Fashionable Sugar-Coated Cookie, Made for Summertime Afternoon Tea
text: This past Saturday, the Steven Alan Home Shop in TriBeCa served up a sweet deal: complimentary cold-brew green tea blends from the Brooklyn- and Japan-based purveyor Tea Wing, and cookies and tea cakes from Burrow bakery for anyone browsing the store’s wares.

headline: A Coveted Candle Line Branches Out into Personal Perfumes
text: The tastefully designed, subtly scented candles of Maison Louis Marie continue to draw distinguished noses to the doorsteps of fashionable outposts like Fred Segal in Los Angeles and Assembly in New York, and all the Steven Alan stores across the country in between. And today, the Belgian behind the brand, Marie du Petit Thouars, introduces her first collection of personal fragrance oils, four of which borrow the delicate bouquet of some of her most coveted candles, and one of which is being introduced for the first time. “Each scent from my collection represents a person, place or memory of my family and childhood that is created through blends of notes that utilize vast arrays of the botanical world,” she says. Another of her dearest childhood memories inspired her to create the oils, four of which are unisex, in the first place. “I remember when I was a child, I went on a fishing trip in the Mauritius Islands with a master perfumer from the Guerlain family,” she says. “He had created a perfume inspired by a woman with whom he had fallen in love with and wanted to reveal her sensuality through a perfume. I was absolutely charmed by this — what a beautiful gift to be able to give someone.”

headline: Le Grand Aioli: a Culinary Ode to Bastille Day
text: On this, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, there may not be a more appropriate, or at least delicious, way to celebrate the values of liberté, égalité and fraternité than with the traditional Provençal feast, le grand aioli. The pungent emulsion referred to as “the butter of Provence” is predictably the hero of the meal; however, it is arguably its accompaniments that make it truly grand. Served in bowls or the heavy mortars in which it is made, the aioli becomes a centerpiece flanked by an array of whatever is best from the market that day. Languid, unstructured and designed for sharing, at its best le grand aioli is a celebration of summer’s bounty andesprit.
