text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Bees, Ourselves
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — AROUND the world, honeybee colonies are dying in huge numbers: About one-third of hives collapse each year, a pattern going back a decade. For bees and the plants they pollinate — as well as for beekeepers, farmers, honey lovers and everyone else who appreciates this marvelous social insect — this is a catastrophe.

headline: The End of the ‘Mormon Moment’
text: LAST month, Kate Kelly, a feminist Mormon lawyer who had called on the Mormon Church to open the priesthood to women, was excommunicated on the charge of apostasy. John P. Dehlin, who runs a popular podcast on hot-button church issues and has loudly advocated for the church to welcome gay men and lesbians, also was threatened with expulsion. Other Mormons have faced sanctions for participating in online forums questioning the church’s positions on these and other matters.

headline: Once a British Open Fan From the Neighborhood, Now a Participant
text: HOYLAKE, England — In a break from his routine, John Singleton took his fiancée’s 6-year-old son to school Monday morning. It was his best drive of the day, at least until he arrived at Royal Liverpool Golf Club, a few miles from his home, and split the fairway with his first tee shot as one of his playing competitors, Darren Clarke, looked on.

headline: In a City Mired in Losing, James’s Return Offers a Glimmer of Hope
text: CLEVELAND — He’s back. And suddenly, we are talking about time and home.

headline: A Municipal ID Card That’s Worth the Wait
text: New York City is creating its own official identification card, which is excellent news for immigrants without papers and other New Yorkers who hope to make their city a more secure and navigable place. Mayor Bill de Blasio signed the bill on Thursday. The cards are supposed to be available early next year, at which point New York will surely leapfrog New Haven and San Francisco in having the largest municipal ID program in the country.

headline: A Defense of Reproductive Rights
text: Facing a torrent of state laws restricting access to safe and legal abortions, supporters of a woman’s right to make her own childbearing decisions have been forced to play a defensive game — trying to block enactment of the laws, and, when that doesn’t work, challenging them in court. An important hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday could begin to move the dynamics of the fight in a positive direction.

headline: Cleaning Up After the World Cup
text: Brazil can be proud of the World Cup it held — except, of course, the shocking breakdown of its national team in the 7-1 semifinal loss to Germany. The crowds were colorful, loud and behaved, and the play ranged from entertaining to utterly brilliant, all devoured by record-breaking audiences on television and social media.

headline: Back From the Brink in Afghanistan
text: The compromise deal over Afghanistan’s bitterly contested presidential election is a big relief and a credit to all involved, especially Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, the two candidates, and Secretary of State John Kerry, who brokered the agreement in 12 hours of intense negotiations. It pulled the country back from the risk of civil war and offers a chance for a peaceful political transition after 13 years of Hamid Karzai’s leadership.

headline: Equal Opportunity Employment Officials Take New Aim at Pregnancy Bias
text: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on Monday issued new enforcement guidelines on pregnancy discrimination for the first time since 1983 in an effort to underscore that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.

headline: Ukrainian Military Plane Is Shot Down as Russia Adds to Presence at Border
text: LUHANSK, Ukraine — A military transport plane was shot down over eastern Ukraine on Monday, Ukrainian officials said, while new reports emerged that Russia was building up forces along its border with Ukraine.

headline: Ex-Governor, Suing Over Book, Faces His Own Words
text: ST. PAUL — Jesse Ventura, the flamboyant wrestler-turned-governor, once told reporters that this nation had turned into “the Fascist States of America,” and said he would no longer rise for the national anthem.

headline: All-Stars Tip Caps to a Finale for Jeter
text: MINNEAPOLIS — At 6 feet 8 inches and 260 pounds, Yankees reliever Dellin Betances could easily be mistaken for Derek Jeter’s bodyguard. That is how tightly Betances clung to Jeter on Monday afternoon, the day before his first All-Star Game, and Jeter’s last.

headline: Yahoo Seeks to Bring the Concert to Your Couch
text: The Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Fla., where the Dave Matthews Band is playing Tuesday night, can hold up to 15,000 people. But as Yahoo and Live Nation see it, the potential audience is limitless.

headline: British Foreign Secretary Quits for Lower Position in the Cabinet
text: LONDON — In a surprise announcement, William Hague, Britain’s foreign secretary, said late Monday that he would quit his job to take a lower-profile cabinet position as part of a wider shuffle of the government.

headline: Helping Big Companies Compete
text: Last week, Standard & Poor’s issued a short report about Boeing. “Boeing Co. Faces Long-Term Credit Risks If The U.S. Export-Import Bank Isn’t Reauthorized,” read the alarming heading.

headline: Abortion Clinic Protections Proposed in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — Massachusetts lawmakers expressed support for a bill filed on Monday that they say would address safety concerns that arose when the United States Supreme Court last month struck down 35-foot buffer zones for demonstrators standing near entrances to abortion clinics.

headline: Toward a New U.S. Defense Model
text: What would the American military look like if we could start from scratch?

headline: Reluctantly, Patriot Flees Homeland for Greener Tax Pastures
text: Heather Bresch grew up around politics. Her father is Joe Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia and a former governor. She has heard him say repeatedly, “We live in the greatest country on Earth,” as he did in countless political advertisements. And it appeared to rub off on her: Ms. Bresch was named a “Patriot of the Year” in 2011 by Esquire magazine for helping to push through the F.D.A. Safety Innovation Act.

headline: Gaza Families Near Israeli Border Struggle to Build a Life in the Heart of a Conflict
text: GAZA CITY — In 2008, Umm Samer Marouf fled the northern Gaza Strip under Israeli bombardments that destroyed her family’s house and strawberry fields and left her deep in debt. Now, she and her seven children have fled again, from their half-built replacement home, and wonder if it, too, will be demolished.

headline: Baseball All-Stars Take Field, but Fewer People Tune In
text: The trend is clear and perhaps irreversible: Baseball’s All-Star Game is doomed to be seen by fewer people with each passing July.

headline: A Federal Appeals Court Sidesteps How to Prosecute Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — In a long-awaited decision about military commissions that was more confusing than clarifying, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Monday reinstated the 2008 conspiracy conviction of a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Ford Foundation Executive to Lead Consumer Reports
text: Consumer Reports has hired an executive from the Ford Foundation with an interest in social media and advocacy as its new chief executive.

headline: A’s Creative Mining Floods A.L. Roster With Hidden Gems
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The Oakland Athletics traded for Jeff Samardzija after the National League players had voted him to their All-Star team. On Monday at Target Field, Samardzija dressed in the N.L. clubhouse and wore an N.L. warm-up jersey with a generic All-Star cap. Then he watched the Home Run Derby from the American League side.

headline: Anxious Moments for an Afghanistan on the Brink
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was the Germans who uttered the first alarm that a potentially deadly power struggle might be brewing, after weeks of Western officials’ staying on the sidelines as the Afghan election crisis deepened. Just over a week ago, they threatened to withdraw funding and training troops from Afghanistan if a powerful regional governor declared a breakaway government led by the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah.

headline: Here They Come, Big-Boned Beauties All Dolled Up
text: I have fond but vague memories of the original Off Broadway production of “Pageant,” a musical spoof of beauty contests featuring an all-male cast of competitors dolled up in shiny gowns, bathing suits and heels. Having seen the sparkly and serviceable revival of the show that opened at the Davenport Theater on Monday night, I am inclined to wonder if the vagueness might have something to do with the fondness.

headline: Founders’ Day
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you know any entrepreneurs, you have probably heard about or seen firsthand how starting a business and making it successful can be all-consuming. In fact, it is sometimes hard, when you are trying to get a business off the ground, to tell where the business ends and you begin. At least, that’s what Zhouqin “C.C.” Burknikel is trying to tell us in today’s puzzle.

headline: Iran Outlines Nuclear Deal; Accepts Limit
text: VIENNA — Iran’s chief nuclear negotiator, faced with an imminent deadline for an agreement with the West on the future of the country’s nuclear program, said in an interview on Monday that Iran could accept a deal that essentially freezes its capacity to produce nuclear fuel at current levels for several years, provided it is then treated like any other nation with a peaceful nuclear program.

headline: Group of Law Professors Urges Obama to Deny Religious Exemption in Order
text: More than 50 constitutional law professors urged President Obama on Monday not to include a religious exemption in an expected order barring federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. Conservative religious leaders want the rule, still being drafted, to exempt religious groups that object to homosexual behavior. But legal experts, organized by Katherine M. Franke of the Columbia University Law School, said in an open letter that church groups are already allowed to favor members of their faith in hiring, and that a new exception would allow employers to discriminate using taxpayer dollars and enshrine a second-class legal status for gay, lesbian and transgender workers.

headline: A Conductor Whose Exuberance Matched New York City’s
text: There was so much to see at the 1939 World’s Fair in New York: its icons, the Trylon and Perisphere. The Futurama, with its promise of automated highways. The giant statue of George Washington. The giant cash register atop one building. And little Lorin Maazel, making his New York conducting debut. He was 9 years old.

headline: Indian Rape Victim to Be Enrolled in Boarding School
text: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the northeastern Indian state of Jharkhand said Monday that a 13-year-old girl who was raped in her village last week, apparently in retaliation for something her brother did, would be immediately enrolled in a government boarding school.

headline: Egypt: Opening for the Old Guard
text: An Egyptian court on Monday lifted a ban that prevented members of the political party of former President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in 2011, from standing in parliamentary and local elections, state media reported. The court’s decision, which said that party members who had not been convicted of crimes should not be excluded from public life, appeared to pave the way for the rehabilitation of members of Egypt’s once-disgraced old guard. Mr. Mubarak’s National Democratic Party, which dominated politics for decades, was dissolved after his ouster. The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that won successive elections after Mr. Mubarak’s fall, was swept from power during a military takeover of the government last year and banned as part of a crackdown on political opposition. Experts say a new election law is likely to further constrict Egypt’s political life, producing a legislature subservient to the new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, while reviving some of the patronage networks that thrived under Mr. Mubarak.

headline: India: Court Stays Executions for 2 Convicted in Gang-Rape Case
text: The Supreme Court of India on Monday temporarily stayed the execution of two men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman on a bus in New Delhi in 2012, said their lawyer, A. P. Singh, in a case that drew international attention, prompted an outcry in India and led to the strengthening of sexual assault laws. The court on Monday stayed the executions of Vinay Sharma and Akshay Kumar Singh; the executions of two other defendants were also stayed by the Supreme Court in March after appeals were filed. All four were convicted of the crimes and sentenced to death last September. The district court that convicted the men categorized the case, in which the victim was repeatedly assaulted with iron rods on a moving bus, as the “rarest of the rare,” a designation that allowed the application of the death penalty. The four defendants plan to continue their appeals, and a final hearing is scheduled for August, said Manohar Lal Sharma, a lawyer for two of the defendants. Another accused, a juvenile at the time of the crime, was sentenced to three years in prison, and a sixth hanged himself in his prison cell.

headline: Haiti: A U.N. Cholera ‘Pilgrimage’
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations visited Haiti on Monday and sought to assure Haitians that he was committed to ending a cholera epidemic “as quickly as possible,” but he did not acknowledge his organization’s possible complicity in causing it, the subject of at least two lawsuits filed in the United States. In a speech in Los Palmas, a village ravaged by the disease, Mr. Ban called the visit “a necessary pilgrimage” that was aimed at expressing solidarity with the cholera victims. He has been seeking to raise $2.2 billion to eradicate cholera, which has killed more than 8,000 people in Haiti since 2010. It was absent from the country for nearly 100 years until after the January 2010 earthquake. Forensic studies have identified the cholera bacteria as an Asian strain carried by Nepalese members of a United Nations peacekeeping force in Haiti. Stanley N. Alpert, a lawyer representing Haitian victims in a lawsuit, called the secretary general’s speech “devoid of any sense of responsibility for the fact that the U.N. brought the cholera to Haiti and it should have gone into overdrive to shut it down.”

headline: Beyond Looking Out for No. 1, Always Putting the Team First
text: Carmelo Anthony declared himself a “Knick at heart” a day after LeBron James said, “I’m coming home.” It was a copycat narrative only in programmed exclamation, not so much in practical execution.

headline: Lobbying Group Adopts de Blasio’s Agenda
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has had his hands full in his first six months in office, with labor contracts, budgets and day-to-day crises to negotiate. But he made time last month to headline a fund-raiser for a new lobbying group: one seeking to promote his political agenda.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 14, 2014
Red Klotz, Beloved Foil for the Harlem Globetrotters, Dies at 93
text: Red Klotz was a 5-foot-7-inch guard on the 1948 Baltimore Bullets team that won the championship of the Basketball Association of America, the forerunner of the N.B.A. But for the next seven decades, his teams could be counted on to lose — and that they did, more than 14,000 times — to waves of laughter.

headline: Alice Coachman, 90, Dies; First Black Woman to Win Olympic Gold
text: Alice Coachman, who became the first black woman to win an Olympic gold medal when she captured the high jump for the United States at the 1948 London Games, died on Monday in Albany, Ga. She was 90.

headline: Peace, Music and the All-Too-Familiar Mud
text: The 800-acre Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y., has long been known as the place that was supposed to host the Woodstock festival.

headline: A Pastry Chef Masters the Veggie Burger
text: Just before the rush of dinner service, the pastry chef Brooks Headley agreed to serve me a veggie burger at Del Posto’s gleaming marble bar in Chelsea. In the mid-’90s, when Headley played drums with the Young Pioneers, he loved veggie burgers so much that he planned the punk band’s tours around stops at Faque Burger in San Diego for the vegetarian diner’s soy-based patty. He’s still obsessed. He has served his own veggie burger to David Chang, who posted a close-up to Instagram (1.8K likes), declaring it the best he’s ever tried. Questlove asked Headley to serve the burger at his food salon. And this Sunday, the guy who turned the most profoundly uncool snack on the planet into something sought after will serve his patties to the public at his first pop-up, Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side.

headline: Data Breaches in New York Hit Record High in 2013, State Attorney General Says
text: Last year was a record-setting one for the state of New York — and not in a good way.

headline: Groups Under Health Act Are Said to Aid Millions
text: WASHINGTON — More than 4,400 consumer assistance programs created under the Affordable Care Act helped an estimated 10.6 million people explore their new health insurance options and apply for coverage during the initial six-month enrollment period, according to a new Kaiser Family Foundation survey.

headline: Word of the Day | mercurial
text: mercurial •\(ˌ)mər-ˈkyu̇r-e-əl\• adjective

headline: The Quiet Movement to Make Government Fail Less Often
text: If you wanted to bestow the grandiose title of “most successful organization in modern history,” you would struggle to find a more obviously worthy nominee than the federal government of the United States.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (Travel) UNDERGROUND BBQ CHALLENGE In this new cook-off series, two rival neighborhoods grill for barbecue bragging rights and a $10,000 prize. It starts in Brooklyn, where a team from Williamsburg will take on a group from Gowanus, with prime rib as the main entree. In future episodes, the show will travel to Austin, Tex. and Kansas City, Mo.

headline: First Israeli Killed Near Gaza Border
text: JERUSALEM — Egypt’s proposal for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas collapsed Tuesday only a few hours after the Israelis had accepted it, as Palestinian militants in Gaza launched a barrage of rockets and Israel resumed its airstrikes. The Israeli authorities said a Palestinian attack caused the first Israeli fatality in the eight-day-old military confrontation, in which Israeli bombings have killed nearly 200 Palestinians.

headline: Tibetan Activist on Her Latest House Arrest
text: Tsering Woeser, a Tibetan writer who often criticizes policies of the Chinese Communist Party, said she was surprised when she heard a United States Embassy official offering her a dinner invitation over her cellphone, since she knew her phone conversations were constantly being monitored by Chinese security officers.

headline: Corrections: July 15, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 15, 2014
text: “This is a watershed moment for the Church of England and a huge step forward in making our society fairer.”

headline: Student Crossword | World Capitals
text: Test your knowledge of world capitals by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say
text: In “Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say,” Rachel Abrams and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report on questionable practices by the debt settlement industry.

headline: A Photographic Muse Beyond the Ruins
text: To visit Pine Bluff, Ark., for the first time is to know it suffers from a broken heart.

headline: LeBron and Melo Have Nothing on Eric Cantor
text: “You know, people are hurting,” Eric Cantor admitted last month, shortly after his humiliating defeat in a Virginia Republican primary. But Cantor, it went without saying, was not one of them. While LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony shopped their talents around the N.B.A. this summer, Cantor was preparing for his own free agency. Fortunately for the former House majority leader, one truth remains self-evident in Washington: No matter how soundly you’ve been walloped by voters, “opportunities in the private sector” await.

headline: Britain Plans to Cap Charges on Payday Loans
text: LONDON — British regulators said on Tuesday that they planned to cap the fees and interest that so-called payday lenders can charge for short-term loans.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Scoring the Fountain
text: Good morning on this wet Tuesday.

headline: Iraqi Parliament Elects Speaker in Effort to Form New Government
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi lawmakers elected a new speaker on Tuesday, taking a small but crucial step toward ending the political deadlock that has frozen decision making as military victories by Sunni militants threaten the country’s existence.

headline: Albemarle to Acquire Specialty Chemical Rival in $6.2 Billion Deal
text: The specialty chemical maker Albemarle said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire its rival Rockwood Holdings in a cash-and-stock deal worth about $6.2 billion.

headline: Hong Kong Leader Says ‘Mainstream’ Opposes Direct Nominations
text: HONG KONG — Presenting a major report on revamping the electoral system, Hong Kong’s top leader, Leung Chun-ying, said on Tuesday that “mainstream opinion” in the city opposed a key proposal of many pro-democracy groups: that voters win the power to directly nominate candidates for his job.

headline: More Evidence That Thad Cochran Owes Runoff Win to Black Voters
text: The precinct-level results for the entire state of Mississippi are now public, and they all but prove that Senator Thad Cochran defeated Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, through a surge in black, Democratic turnout in last month’s Republican primary runoff.

headline: Uncovering Brutality at a City Jail
text: “How can I be resisting when I’m cuffed to the gurney?” said Andre Lane, an inmate who, witnesses say, was beaten by guards in a cellblock on Rikers Island.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The compromise deal over Afghanistan’s bitterly contested presidential election is a big relief and a credit to all involved,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Especially Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, the two candidates, and Secretary of State John Kerry, who brokered the agreement in 12 hours of intense negotiations.” The deal diverts the possibility of civil war and “offers a chance for a peaceful transition” of power after more than a decade of presidential rule by Hamid Karzai. “But it would not have been possible without President Obama’s threat to withhold aid, the billions of dollars that have propped up Afghanistan’s economy and underwritten its security forces, and without which it could well go the way of Iraq.” The board is cautiously optimistic: “Mr. Obama must be prepared, if necessary, to use that leverage again to ensure the deal is carried out.”

headline: Up for Discussion: the Value of a College Education
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about the value of a college education and how well their own schooling prepared them for entrepreneurship.

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo Promotes Its YouTube Competitor With a Year of Free Concerts
text: The Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Fla., where the Dave Matthews Band is playing Tuesday night, can hold up to 15,000 people. But as Yahoo and Live Nation see it, Ben Sisario reports, the potential audience is limitless.

headline: What’s an Overseas Study Tour Without the Studying?
text: Summer study trips have become a popular way for Chinese students to get a taste of life abroad, but the Ministry of Education has put out a call for more studying and less sightseeing.

headline: JPMorgan’s Second-Quarter Numbers a Hopeful Sign for Economic Growth
text: It has worked before: When big banks loosen the lending spigot, the economy tends to grow faster, creating more jobs and higher incomes.

headline: 1914: President of Mexico Resigns
text: NEW YORK — General Huerta resigned office as President of Mexico this afternoon [July 15]. Congress was immediately convoked to discuss the dictator’s resignation. It is stated that the entire Cabinet and the Military Commission will resign if General Huerta’s resignation is accepted. President Huerta’s family and other relatives and close friends left Vera Cruz on a special train at ten o’clock last night. Rebel troops fired on the train on the outskirts of Orozaba, where the train arrived to-day, but no one was injured. It is believed that the passengers’ destination is Salina Cruz, where a Japanese cruiser is lying at anchor. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 16, 1914

headline: To Compete With Altria, Reynolds American Is Buying Lorillard
text: Updated, 8:34 p.m. | With its $27.4 billion deal to buy its smaller tobacco rival Lorillard, Reynolds American is betting that the acquisition is the best way to combat not only its bigger rival, the Altria Group, but also the steady decline of smokers that has been weighing down the industry.

headline: Goldman Earnings Rise 5% in Quarter
text: Updated, 6:51 p.m. | As a result of the financial crisis, a familiar narrative emerged for Goldman Sachs: Declines in trading, once the firm’s cash cow, weighed heavily on profits.

headline: Whom Goes There?
text: “Who,” not “whom,” is used for the subject of a relative clause.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: The Water Is Rising, Rising, Rising
text: Maybe it’s too obvious — or obscure – but as the storm stopped, the floods receded, and daylight returned to the greenhouse near the end of this episode, my immediate thought was, “No more water, but fire next time.”

headline: Subway Train in Moscow Derails, Killing at Least 20 During Morning Commute
text: MOSCOW — A morning commute ended in darkness, smoke and mayhem for passengers on the Moscow Metro on Tuesday when a train derailed underground, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 100 others.

headline: Liberals and Libertarians Find Common Ground in House
text: WASHINGTON — From abortion to electronic privacy to background checks for gun purchases, a strange thing has been happening on the floor of the House as it debates its spending bills for the coming fiscal year: the stirrings of liberalism.

headline: Intersection | Mexico City’s Spirited Style
text: In the Roma Norte neighborhood, Camila Sarasola Montiel, a real estate agent, wears a tattoo that says “love yourself” to remind herself to feel beautiful and embrace being plus-size.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Tobacco Industry Shake-Up
text: Reynolds American agreed on Tuesday to buy its smaller rival, Lorillard, for $27.4 billion, uniting two of the country’s largest tobacco producers in a bet that bigger is safer in a declining industry, Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray write in DealBook. Under the terms of the deal, Reynolds will pay $68.88 for every Lorillard share.

headline: HP Chairman Ralph Whitworth Exits to Focus on Health
text: Ralph V. Whitworth, a longtime activist investor with a large stake in Hewlett-Packard, has resigned as interim chairman of the computer company’s board and will take a leave of absence from his investment firm, Relational Investors, HP announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Ringing Cellphone, and a Good Excuse
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The New Museum Surveys Art From the Arab World
text: The Western media’s obsession with Middle Eastern conflict has made it easy for American audiences to mistake war and crisis as components of Arab identity. But if there’s anything that the New Museum’s newest exhibition, “Here and Elsewhere,” works to dispel, it’s the fallacy that any single portrayal can summarize the many cultural landscapes around and within the Arabian peninsula.

headline: China Requiring Secrecy Pledge for Press Credentials
text: In the latest in a series of measures tightening state control over the media, the Chinese government is requiring journalists to sign a secrecy agreement with their employers as a condition for obtaining press credentials.

headline: European Commission Elects a New Leader
text: BRUSSELS — Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg was elected Tuesday to lead the most powerful agency of the European Union after overcoming fierce opposition from Britain and some lawmakers in the European Parliament.

headline: Latham & Watkins Elects New Leader
text: William H. Voge has been elected global chairman and managing partner of Latham & Watkins, the first change of leadership for the law firm in 20 years.

headline: Novartis Joins With Google to Develop Contact Lens That Monitors Blood Sugar
text: LONDON — Google announced on Tuesday a partnership with the European drug maker Novartis to develop a smart contact lens with the potential to monitor the wearer’s blood sugar levels.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Pushes Fix for Highway Funding
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. More thunderstorms are on the way, but President Obama is hitting the road in hopes of patching a financial pothole in the Highway Trust Fund.

headline: Kerry Cites ‘Progress’ in Iran Talks but Says ‘Very Real Gaps’ Remain
text: VIENNA — After three days of intensive talks with his Iranian counterpart, Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday that “tangible progress” had been made in negotiations on Iran’s nuclear program, and that he would return to Washington to consult with President Obama over whether to extend a Sunday deadline for a final agreement.

headline: Scores Killed in Car Bombing at Busy Market in Eastern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A sport utility vehicle packed with explosives detonated in a market in eastern Afghanistan on Tuesday, bringing down shops and leaving the bloodied remains of men, women and children in the rubble. By late afternoon, at least 89 people were known to have been killed, the Defense Ministry said.

headline: What Are the Last Literary Taboos?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and James Parker discuss what is still forbidden in literature.

headline: Conflict in Senate Creates a Logjam of Ambassador Confirmations
text: WASHINGTON — Next month, President Obama will host African leaders at what the White House describes as “the largest single engagement by any U.S. president with Africa.” But for the State Department, engaging those leaders has been more difficult.

headline: Corner Media Expands Its Network of Brooklyn Blogs
text: By now, the neighbors know exactly where an associate publisher of one of Brooklyn’s biggest media conglomerates works (about three feet from his bed, most days) and what he looks like. That is the way he likes it.

headline: Yellen Tells Congress That Fed Will Continue to Prop Up the Economy
text: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Tuesday that the financial markets remained in reasonable health despite signs of bubbles in some areas, including the stocks of social media and technology companies.

headline: James MacGregor Burns, Scholar of Presidents and Leadership, Dies at 95
text: James MacGregor Burns, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer and political scientist who wrote voluminously about the nature of leadership in general and the presidency in particular, died on Tuesday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 95.

headline: With Woolmark, Public School Becomes the Winningest Brand of the Year. There’s a Lesson Here.
text: Public School, the men’s wear brand designed by Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow, has just added yet another feather to its cap, winning the men’s half of the American regional leg of the Woolmark prize. This follows being named men’s wear designers of the year at the CFDA awards in June, which followed winning the 2013 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards, which followed the 2013 CFDA Swarovski Awards for men’s wear. Oomph. Them’s a lot of trophies in a year.

headline: Review Board Examining Extending Currency Benchmark Window
text: LONDON – The Financial Stability Board said on Tuesday that it was preparing to recommend that the window for determining currency benchmark rates be widened as part of a series of proposals to potentially reshape foreign exchange markets.

headline: F-35 Fighter Jet Cleared to Resume Flights
text: The Pentagon on Tuesday lifted an order grounding all of its new F-35 fighter jets, but said they would operate under restrictions that would keep the plane from appearing at the Farnborough International Airshow in England this week.

headline: On the Neo-paleo-Keynesian Phillips Curve (Wonkish)
text: In a previous post I mentioned, sort of in passing, that recent data actually look like an old-fashioned pre-accelerationist Phillips curve — that is, unemployment determines the inflation rate, not the rate of change of the inflation rate.

headline: Corn, Squash, Red Onion and Tomatoes Stir-Fried in Coconut Oil
text: With a big bunch of Thai basil in hand, I wanted a sweet stir-fry with Thai flavors. I stir-fried the vegetables in coconut oil, and I loved the results. The medley has that coconut fragrance without the heaviness it would have with coconut milk. I served the vegetables with black rice, which was beautiful, but any other rice, noodles or grains like quinoa would work. Make sure that your corn is sweet and your tomatoes are juicy. You can also use the lower-priced tomatoes “for sauce” that may be at your farmers’ market.

headline: China Clarifies its Plans on Setting a CO2 Emissions Peak
text: Updated, 11:28 a.m. | With climate treaty negotiations expected to intensify next year, China is signaling that it may soon set the timetable for hitting an eventual peak in its emissions of carbon dioxide, the most important human-generated greenhouse gas. The signals came on Monday from Xie Zhenhua, China’s lead climate treaty negotiator, speaking at a German climate conference. Here’s coverage by Xinhua, China’s government-echoing “news” agency:

headline: With Eye on Election, British Premier Shuffles Cabinet
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain shook up his government on Tuesday in an effort to present a fresher, less abrasive and more diverse face to voters with the next general election just 10 months away.

headline: Immigration Advocate, Detained on Texas Border, Is Released in Visa Case
text: McALLEN, Tex. — Jose Antonio Vargas, who has chronicled in minute detail the twists and turns of his life as a Filipino living illegally for years in the United States, was detained by the Border Patrol for most of the day on Tuesday and then released with a notice to appear before an immigration judge.

headline: Qatari Soccer Empire Buys a Foothold in Europe
text: EUPEN, Belgium — In the southeast corner of Belgium, there is a town of about 20,000 that is known, to the extent it is known at all, as a key battleground during the Battle of the Bulge and, more recently, as the center of the tiny slice of this country that speaks German instead of French.

headline: Belafonte and Collins to Join Expanded Seeger Festival
text: Seeger Fest, the five-day tribute to the folksinger Pete Seeger and his wife, Toshi Seeger, assembled by one of his grandsons, opens on Thursday evening with a screening of he 2007 documentary,“Pete Seeger: The Power of Song,” at Pier 46 on the Hudson River, and includes events in the  Bronx and in several towns in the Hudson Valley before winding up with two Manhattan concerts – at Damrosch Park, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors, on Sunday; and at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, part of SummerFest, on Monday – with performances by friends, colleagues and musicians inspired by Mr. Seeger, who died in January. The events are all free.

headline: Dispute Is Settled Over Broadcast Rights to Golden Globes
text: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood Foreign Press Association settled its longstanding legal dispute with Dick Clark Productions over rights to produce the annual Golden Globes awards show, The Hollywood Reporter said on Monday. The association had sued the production company in 2010, claiming that it improperly renewed broadcast rights to the show with NBC, without permission of the association.

headline: Budget Office Lowers Its Estimate on Federal Spending for Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The growth of federal spending on health care will continue to decline as a proportion of the overall economy in the coming decades, in part because of cost controls mandated by President Obama’s health care law, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said on Tuesday.

headline: Remembering Nadine Gordimer, a Lioness of Literary Activism
text: At 90 years of age, the South African writer Nadine Gordimer died Sunday, leaving behind a global legacy of both art and activism. “By the time she won the Nobel Prize in 1991, at age 68,” her obituary in The Mail and Guardian (South Africa) recalls, she had “10 novels, nearly 20 collections of stories or essays and innumerable pieces of journalism to her name.”

headline: Chinese Hackers Extending Reach to Smaller U.S. Agencies, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — After years of cyberattacks on the networks of high-profile government targets like the Pentagon, Chinese hackers appear to have turned their attention to far more obscure federal agencies.

headline: Courtly Meals From Buvette’s Queen
text: Brussels sprouts are not in season. They are available at the supermarket, though, small containers full of green California golf balls shipped great distances to satisfy the tastes of people who want such things year-round. We know we should shun them in favor of what the farmers’ market has now: young cabbages from the field across from the sheep; rhubarb from along the stone fence; “real” strawberries; “local” radishes. It is smart to shop and cook and eat seasonally. It tastes better. It is better.

headline: What Happened When Martha Stewart Got a Drone
text: If you have lingering questions about drones — particularly about whether they can take nice pictures of a farm — allow Martha Stewart to reassure you. She recently posted the following on her blog:

headline: MoMA Names New Architecture and Design Curator
text: Martino Stierli, a Swiss art history professor, has been appointed chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, Glenn D. Lowry, the museum’s director announced Tuesday.

headline: Cardinal Reliever’s Tumultuous Road Leads to an All-Star Ending
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Those who know Pat Neshek understood the significance of it all. A St. Louis Cardinals relief pitcher, he entered a Hyatt Regency ballroom a few minutes late for the National League All-Stars’ media session Monday afternoon. Something else had required his attention.

headline: Casualties in Moscow Subway Derailment
text: Witnesses described the morning rush hour crash that killed 20 people on Tuesday, as officials opened an investigation into the cause.

headline: Border Tensions Rise Between Ukraine and Russia
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine and Russia traded increasingly bitter accusations of cross-border hostilities on Tuesday, deepening a shadowy war of real attacks or orchestrated sabotage that increasingly threatens to draw the two countries into direct conflict.

headline: A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk
text: Each year, about 10,000 people contact poison centers in the United States, afraid that they gave too strong a dose of medicine or were confused by measurement directions, according to the American Association of Poison Control Centers. About three-quarters of the callers are parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12, often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers.

headline: For Proof Wall Street Is Changing, Look at Citigroup's Numbers
text: It’s easy to be cynical about Wall Street reform. Nothing ever changes. The big banks get bigger and more powerful than ever. Too Big to Fail is worse than ever.

headline: Kerry on Nuclear Negotiations
text: Secretary of State John Kerry announced that intense nuclear negotiations with Iran have yielded “tangible progress,” but that significant gaps remain.

headline: 1964: Brezhnev As Successor?
text: MOSCOW — Leonid I. Brezhnev emerged today [July 15] as the man most likely to succeed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. Mr. Brezhnev, Soviet president since May, 1960, gave up the largely ceremonial post to devote himself fully to Communist party affairs. His place as president was taken by First Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan, 68. Western diplomats said the change in party assignments, unquestionably made with Mr. Khrushchev’s  personal approval, represent a marked promotion for 58-year-old Mr. Brezhnev. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 16, 1964

headline: The Shadow Universe Revealed
text: Recently astronomers have used a cosmic web imager to visualize simulations of dark matter, showing how the large scale structure of the universe grows and the nests in which galaxies are hatched.

headline: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Recovery
text: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress that an ailing job market and stagnant wages justify keeping interest rates low.

headline: Mulford Farm Prepares for the East Hampton Antiques Show
text: Once again, Mulford Farm in East Hampton, N.Y., a 3.5-acre property with a restored 17th-century farmhouse, is the backdrop for the annual East Hampton Antiques Show, Saturday and Sunday. The show, a benefit for the East Hampton Historical Society, offers furnishings from more than 55 antiques dealers from around the United States.

headline: A Feminist in the Forest
text: Germaine Greer, the Australian author of “The Female Eunuch” (1970), that garrulous classic of second-wave feminism, has been a lifelong agitation artist. In her heyday she tangled with William F. Buckley and Norman Mailer, her skeptical blue-gray eyes boring holes through to the backs of their heads. Her sound bites, lanky good looks and proclivity for posing nude prompted Life magazine to call her, on its cover, the “saucy feminist that even men like.”

headline: The Gay Mormon Known Sperm Donor From Utah
text: Whenever I find myself in a social situation that could use the aid of an icebreaker, some of my friends are a bit quicker than I would like to offer me up as conversational fodder.

headline: Walking Through History in Ireland
text: Travelers can explore the archaeological riches of Ireland’s northwest coast through new walking trips from the Toronto-based active adventure company Butterfield & Robinson.

headline: ‘Hedwig’ Recoups on Broadway
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” has turned a quick profit in just 15 weeks, with robust tickets sales driven in large part by the popularity of its star, Neil Patrick Harris.

headline: Investors See Pricing Power in Tobacco Deal
text: American trustbusters deciding whether to approve Reynolds American’s deal with Lorillard will want to heed the market’s message. The combined market value of the No. 2 and No. 3 cigarette makers in the United States has jumped more than $10 billion since merger talk surfaced. Those gains can’t be justified by the cost savings on offer. Expectations of an increase in pricing power, through the creation of an effective tobacco duopoly, may best explain investors’ enthusiasm.

headline: Janet Yellen on the Everything Bubble
text: Last week we wrote here about how virtually all major asset classes on earth are relatively expensive compared with their historical values. We called it the Everything Boom, with a worrying asterisk that it could be, or become, the Everything Bubble.

headline: Filings Aimed at Challengers to Corcoran Takeover
text: Lawyers for the Corcoran Gallery of Art and its art school filed papers in Washington on Monday challenging an attempt by a group to block a takeover of the Corcoran by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University.

headline: After Reynolds Buys Lorillard, Few Big Tobacco Deals Remain
text: Reynolds American’s acquisition of its smaller rival, Lorillard, is sure to face antitrust scrutiny in Washington. In the United States market, the deal will create a virtual duopoly, with Altria remaining the largest cigarette seller.

headline: No Comment Necessary: ‘Down to a Woman’s Level’
text: At a Friday meeting of conservative women, Representative Renee Ellmers of North Carolina said her male colleagues could improve their messaging by bringing policy discussions “down to a woman’s level.”

headline: Obama Presses Congress for Long-Term Transportation Bill
text: McLEAN, Va. — President Obama on Tuesday pressed Congress to break a deadlock over a long-term transportation spending bill, arguing that Republicans were more interested in trying to “score points on cable TV” than in fixing the country’s roads and bridges.

headline: ‘Litmus Test’ for Regulators Over Money Market Funds
text: Soon after the financial crisis, Congress created an elite group to hunt down risks that might cause another global collapse.

headline: Though Scorned by Colleagues, a Climate-Change Skeptic Is Unbowed
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — John Christy, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, says he remembers the morning he spotted a well-known colleague at a gathering of climate experts.

headline: Still Walking on Air, Germans Touch Down for World Cup Party
text: BERLIN — Germany paraded its pride and its festive side on Tuesday when hundreds of thousands of fans gathered on a joyous, sun-kissed day to welcome home their victorious World Cup soccer squad.

headline: Garth Brooks Sets a Single Tour Date After Canceling Irish Shows
text: When Garth Brooks announced the decisive end of his retirement, last week, he left his fans with news of a new recording contract, a forthcoming album and the availability of music in downloadable form, and promised that the details of a world tour would be forthcoming. On Monday evening, he announced the first stop, a concert at the Allstate Arena in Rosemont, Ill., on Sept. 4. And so far, that’s it: it was unclear on Tuesday whether Mr. Brooks planned to announce the tour one date at a time – a tip of the hat, perhaps, to the British author David Mitchell, who is spending this week publishing a short story on Twitter, 140 characters at a time – or would announce the full tour shortly.

headline: A ‘Stampede’ for Freedom
text: In early 1864, the Union Army began enlisting black soldiers in Kentucky, but Capt. J. Bates Dickson, an enlistment officer in the state, didn’t expect much – they might come “singly and in squads,” but not waves. Indeed, despite tens of thousands of fighting-age black men in the state, turnout was paltry – after all, Kentucky was still a slave state, and enlistment was restricted to free blacks and to slaves whose owners permitted them to go. Most slaveholders and their allies resisted black enlistment by any means possible, often with cruelty and violence.

headline: The Latest News That Isn’t
text: At this point, we all have heard that print media is dying and that online journalism rests upon shaky business models. But at least fake news is thriving, right? Not so fast.

headline: Immigration Activist Detained in Texas
text: Jose Antonio Vargas, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and an activist for immigrants, like him, who do not have legal status, was detained at McAllen-Miller International Airport on Tuesday.

headline: In Performance | Tine Thing Helseth
text: The Norwegian trumpeter performs “I ensomme Stunde” composed by Ole Bull.

headline: Okwiri Oduor Wins Caine Prize for African Writing
text: Okwiri Oduor, a 25-year-old Kenyan who studied law but switched to writing, has won the 2014 Caine Prize for African Writing. The award was announced Monday at the Bodleian Library in Oxford, England. This annual prize, for a short story by an African writer published in English, was first awarded in 2000 to highlight literary talent from the continent.

headline: Beware John Cornyn’s ‘Humane’ Immigration Act
text: Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican, has offered a bill that he says will solve the crisis of unaccompanied migrant children at the southern border.

headline: Pebble Beach Concours to Feature Grand Prix Centennial Cars
text: An exhibition celebrating the centennial of the 1914 Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France, which will include the winning Mercedes, the race trophy and five other cars of the era, will be on display at the Aug. 17 Pebble Beach Concours d'Élégance in California, it was announced by Sandra Button, head of the concours.

headline: It’s Woods and It’s Royal Liverpool, but It’s Not 2006
text: HOYLAKE, England — On his way to the British Open, Tiger Woods stopped in Geneva and spent the day touring a Rolex factory. He has reason to be preoccupied with time.

headline: At Stella 34, Fresh Pasta to Go
text: To Take: A Parade of Pasta in Herald Square

headline: Extremists Make Inroads in Pakistan’s Diverse South
text: MIRPURKHAS, Pakistan — In a country roiled by violent strife, the southern province of Sindh, celebrated as the “land of Sufis,” has long prized its reputation as a Pakistani bastion of tolerance and diversity.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 3 | A Teenage Waitress on ‘Unblinking Eyes Track Employees’
text: Another week, another wonderful set of student entries in our Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Eugene Kadomskiy Is Thinking Big With Urbo
text: Headliner

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Internet Behemoths
Race of Attrition Continues, Even on a Rest Day
text: BESANÇON, France — Short of its halfway point, this year’s unusually cruel Tour de France has raised several questions. Did the organizers go too far in their attempt to liven up the first week of the race with difficult routes? Are riders taking excessive risks? And, above all, with Chris Froome and Alberto Contador removed by crashes, can anyone beat Vincenzo Nibali?

headline: When Climate Change Floods Your Heart
text: In 2100, I will live in Florida.

headline: A Brooklynized Take on the Populist Musical, Courtesy of Yeasayer’s Front Man
text: What happens when two Brooklyn guys dream up a musical about the ravages of industry on a small town in contemporary gilded-age America and cast it full of indie-rock intelligentsia? Something like what would have happened if the Byrds’ Gene Clark restaged “Jesus Christ Superstar” as a series of Dorothea Lange tableaux. “Break Line: the Musical” (Secretly Canadian), a new project written by the Yeasayer front man Anand Wilder and his longtime friend, the pianist Maxwell Kardon, features a cast of musicians from Vampire Weekend, Man Man, Dirty Projectors, MGMT, Suckers, Kishi Bashi and Sinkane, among others, in telling the tale of a coal-mining Pennsylvania town called Greenbelt. The result mixes earnest politics, open-throated Broadway belting and sly psychedelic instrumentation.

headline: In Illinois, a Challenge to Services Like Uber
text: The ride-sharing services UberX, Sidecar and Lyft may soon find it almost impossible to operate in Illinois.

headline: Away From Home but Not the Kitchen
text: GIRONA, Spain — El Celler de Can Roca has climbed to the summit of world gastronomy without ruffling the simple routines of the family that runs it. The restaurant, in this city about an hour’s drive northeast of Barcelona, is owned and operated by three brothers who still lunch on their mom’s food every day in the nearby restaurant where they grew up, learning about cooking while playing soccer among the tables and chairs.

headline: In London, You Can Join the Show
text: Almost 30 years after “Back to the Future” first hit theaters, time travel is about as realistic as Doc Brown’s flux capacitor. But as of July 24, you can visit  California’s Hill Valley between 1955 and 1985 — as in the movie, but in the flesh — via London.

headline: Eating Across Texas, Puffy Tacos to Frito Pie
text: Lisa Fain’s blog, “Homesick Texan,” is predicated on food nostalgia. From her New York kitchen, she conjures recipes of the kind of comfort food and Tex-Mex dishes she knew growing up in the Lone Star State, often updated with fresh ingredients.

headline: Restaurant Report: Hog Island Oyster Bar in San Francisco
text: In 1983, when two young marine biologists planted oyster seed on a Tomales Bay intertidal tract about 50 miles north of San Francisco, little did they know their Hog Island Oyster Co. would grow into a bay-to-bar juggernaut with nearly $12 million in annual sales and a trio of retail locations.

headline: Arbitration Clauses Let American Apparel Hide Misconduct
text: The real lesson from the ouster of Dov Charney at American Apparel is the danger of arbitration clauses.

headline: Stroke Rates Are Declining
text: The incidence of stroke in the United States has declined significantly over the past two decades, a new analysis has found.

headline: Harper Lee Says New Book Not Authorized
text: For an author who is as famous for her reclusiveness as for her work – a single but extraordinarily influential novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” – Harper Lee has been awfully public lately. An on-again, off-again lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum, in Monroeville, Ala., Ms. Lee’s hometown, over what she said was the unauthorized use of her book brought her into the spotlight several times from October 2012 to this May.

headline: Philharmonic Cancels Tuesday’s Park Concert
text: The New York Philharmonic’s second attempt to pay tribute to Lorin Maazel, its former music director, who died on Sunday, has come to grief. The orchestra was to have performed a concert at Central Park on Monday evening, part of its annual series of free outdoor concerts, and had announced that in memory of Mr. Maazel, Alan Gilbert would conduct Samuel Barber’s “Adagio for Strings.” But when dire weather predictions led to the orchestra to cancel the concert on Monday afternoon, the tribute was moved to the Tuesday evening concert in Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx.

headline: Big City Book Club Discusses ‘Lush Life’
text: This concludes our live discussion of “Lush Life.” Thanks to all who participated. Anyone who missed the conversation should feel free to post comments here throughout the week. We will soon announce the next selection of the Big City Book Club.

headline: Chilled Corn Soup
text: Melissa Clark shows how to make a delicious cool corn soup with garlic, buttermilk and basil.

headline: Suit Seeks to Establish Right to Record New York Police Officers
text: A federal lawsuit, which cites arrests of people who recorded police confrontations or activity, was filed on Tuesday asking a judge to declare that people have a right under the First Amendment to film or record officers working in public places.

headline: Motivating Corporations to Do Good
text: Is it naïve to expect corporations to assist in addressing the social, economic and environmental challenges of the day?

headline: Corporate Medicis to the Rescue
text: ROME — Since early July, workers have been carefully unscrewing the steel scaffolding that for months has obscured much of the ancient facade of the Colosseum. Slowly, this monolithic symbol of Rome is coming into view again after the first portion of a 25 million euro ($34 million) refurbishment that underscores how Italy is coming to rely on private aid to preserve national treasures.

headline: Germany’s Defense Against the N.S.A.: Typewriters
text: In the television series “Battlestar Galactica,” by which I mean the most recent version, the human race is essentially saved from extinction because there are no fancy computer networks or other interconnected devices aboard the Galactica, an old spacecraft designed to resist infiltration by angry robots.

headline: London Theater Journal:  A ‘Carousel’ That Really Moves
text: LONDON – When June starts bustin’ out all over in the exuberant production of “Carousel” at the Arcola Theater here, you might wish you had been equipped with riot gear. Flying arms, legs and torsos look as if they’re in imminent danger of colliding with one another and with the audience, too. Hormones, with which the rowdy young things onstage are abundantly equipped, suddenly seem like dangerous weapons.

headline: Hauser & Wirth’s Newest Outpost in English Farm Country Is Now Open
text: In Somerset, an English county marked by rolling farmland, the new and much-anticipated Hauser & Wirth outpost finally opened its doors today. T first profiled the project in April, in the Spring Design 2014 issue, with a first look at the arts center being carved out of a working farm there. The story focused on the farmhouse at Durslade Farm, a property that had been abandoned for 10 years and then left untouched for 50 before being restored and renovated by the Paris-based architect Luis Laplace. Its six guest bedrooms were then filled with pieces by Hauser & Wirth’s impressive lineup of artists, including Pipilotti Rist and Paul McCarthy, and the grounds were landscaped by none other than Piet Oudolf, the Dutch garden designer behind home-like public gardens such as the High Line in Manhattan.

headline: Controlling the Home, Google Style
text: When Google goes after the home, it goes big. And maybe it goes after control, too.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Building the Front Page
text: Tom Bodkin is design director, chief creative officer and a deputy managing editor. Each day, after the best stories and photos are selected by top editors, he sketches the layout of the front page, which will determine the rest of the news sections’ design. We asked him about the process.

headline: The Risks of Hillary Clinton’s Quasi-Campaign
text: Hillary Clinton is not running for president — at least not by her own admission. But it’s been a month since the start of her “Hard Choices” book tour, and nearly all the elements of a presidential campaign have emerged. There are boisterous crowds, speeches, interviews, an appearance tonight on “The Daily Show,” lists with names and email addresses, attacks from the opposition, and gaffes.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pregnancy Discrimination
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Apple Joins With IBM on Business Software
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple is moving up to business class. And its seatmate will be IBM.

headline: The Road Ahead
text: After suffering a catastrophic brain hemorrhage in 2009, Brian Nice’s career as a commercial photographer took an unexpected turn.

headline: Crystal Bridges Lines Up Emerging Artists for American Show
text: After a restless cross-country search in which two curators logged more than 100,000 miles in airplanes and rental cars, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art – founded by the Walmart heiress Alice Walton – announced Tuesday that it had finalized its artist list for an ambitious fall show that will present a snapshot of unheralded 21st century American art.

headline: Life Without Cars
text: I’ve been following some of the discussion about Uber, Lyft, and all that, and I have a few unoriginal thoughts. Well, strictly speaking they are original, in the sense that I haven’t read them anywhere else — but surely they’re out there. So this post is partly a bleg for references.

headline: Would-Be Rescuers of Wayward Spacecraft Previously Solved a NASA Mystery
text: Before reviving a zombie spacecraft, Dennis Wingo and Keith Cowing traveled to the past to rescue a trove of early moon photographs that otherwise would have been destined for oblivion.

headline: Children at the Border
text: The number of children crossing the U.S. border alone has doubled since last year. Answers to key questions on the crisis.

headline: Intel Exceeds Estimates on Improving Demand for PCs
text: Intel has returned to the good old days, at least for a quarter. Longer term, it wants to enter a new and more complex world.

headline: The Intersection of Rough and Refined
text: On April Fools’ Day 2008, a former music publicist and retired dominatrix named Erin Norris signed the lease on a derelict Brooklyn storefront where she intended to open a sausage restaurant called Grindhaus. Almost immediately, the universe began sending her a message: don’t.

headline: This Age of Infallibility
text: The estimable Sarah Kliff tabulates all the predictions of Obamacare disaster that didn’t come true; she puts it at seven major themes, ranging from “the website will never work” to “nobody will sign up”. We can presume, then, that people like John Boehner — who declared that it would never work and that more people would lose insurance than gain it — are spending some time now trying to understand how they could have been so wrong.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Gaza City, Somalia and Afghanistan.

headline: Margaret Low Smith to Leave NPR for The Atlantic
text: The senior vice president for NPR’s news operations said Tuesday that she is leaving public radio to run a division at The Atlantic that creates conversation-driven events around topical issues.

headline: Your Summer Cooking Tool Kit
text: The simple techniques and flavor combinations you can turn to all season long.

headline: Expected Health Spending Declines (Again)
text: The last few years have seen a puzzling and welcome new trend in health care spending: Instead of going up and up, increases have slowed way down.

headline: Biennial’s Bright Young Things, Ages 77 and 84
text: LOS ANGELES — Prominent artists like Cindy Sherman and Mark Grotjahn have bought the work. Galleries on both coasts are beginning to promote it. Now the expressive, comics-inspired pottery of the husband-and-wife team Michael Frimkess and Magdalena Suarez Frimkess (he’s 77 and she’s 84) has become a sleeper hit of the Hammer Museum’s biennial, thanks to a younger generation of local artists who have been bringing it to light.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Money-Spending Decisions, Made Once and for All
text: For more than a decade, my family and I have gone to Jackson Lake in Wyoming for what’s become our favorite summer vacation. Because the trip includes a boat, we make arrangements to rent a mooring for the boat so we don’t have to take it in and out of the water each day.

headline: Teetering on the Line Between Good and Evil
text: “The Divide,” a legal drama that begins on Wednesday, is surprisingly good. But what’s most surprising is that it’s on WE, a cable channel best known for shows like “L.A. Hair” and “Marriage Boot Camp.”

headline: Doomed by Quality, but Not Concept
text: Sad to say, the only surprise about the closing of “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” the new musical featuring the songs of the rapper Tupac Shakur, was that it didn’t come earlier. When the show opened to downbeat reviews on June 19, many expected it would close within a week.

headline: Slump in Advertising Sales Dragged Quarterly Revenue Down at Yahoo
text: Nearly two years to the day that Marissa Mayer took the helm at Yahoo, the company’s turnaround is still a work in progress. And its fortunes are still very much tied to its stake in Alibaba, the private Chinese Internet company expected to go public next month.

headline: Playing the Waiting Game, Quixotically
text: One of the paradoxes of MTV’s “16 and Pregnant” and “Teen Mom” franchise is how small a role sex plays. They’re shows premised on sex that include barely any talk of it, as if its protagonists, once they become parents, don’t crave the thing that got them there. (Until they become parents again, that is.)

headline: Small Changes, and Hopes, for Preventing Dementia
text: What we really want, if we’re honest, is a pill or a shot that would allow us to stop worrying about ever sinking into dementia.

headline: Introducing a Poet Who Works in 3-D
text: The writer Alex Butler may live in brownstone Brooklyn, but that’s about the extent of her similarities to the young literary set. A licensed social worker, she has also worked for the designer Jane Mayle, served as a production assistant on the set of “Sex and the City” and recorded a series of humorous performance videos. It was the loss, in quick succession, of both her parents — and Butler’s experience as her mother’s caretaker during a harrowing illness — that spurred her to turn what had been a secret hobby into a career. But rather than sit down at a laptop and type about the experience, she began speaking words and dialogue into a Dictaphone — and later her computer’s camera — which led to not one, but two books: her debut memoir, “Walking the Night Road,” due out next year from Columbia University Press, and “Circling the Same,” a 41-poem meditation on loss. The latter — newly available online through its publisher, the Los Angeles–based gallery and art-book press Ohwow — is as much art object as literature: Butler’s words are printed alongside photographs from the artists Mirabelle Marden and Andrea Longacre-White. “Both of these artists’ work, and what I imagined were their intentions, reminded me of a world altered by grief,” she explains.

headline: Relief for Chronic Pain
text: To the Editor:

headline: Saving a Steamship
text: Efforts are underway to redevelop the steamship United States and prevent it from being sold for scrap.

headline: Keeping a Historic Ship Afloat
text: PHILADELPHIA — Once upon a time, it carried princes and potentates across the Atlantic in high style and at great speed.

headline: Not All Community Colleges Offer Federal Student Loans
text: Roughly one million community college students lack access to federal student loans, which may limit their options for financing their education, a new report finds.

headline: Mutual Conquest, No Matter Who Perishes
text: A battle of the sexes doesn’t often involve broadswords. But in John Banville’s “Love in the Wars,” an adaptation of Heinrich von Kleist’s “Penthesilea” at Bard’s SummerScape Festival, men and women clash with arrows, spears and daggers. Desire? Well, that might just be the deadliest weapon of all.

headline: ‘Rocky’ to Close in August
text: “Rocky” will go down for the count, giving its last performance at the Winter Garden Theater on Aug. 17, the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion During Wartime
text: Last Tuesday, as most of the fashion flock was filing into the Palais de Chaillot to watch the Armani Privé haute couture show — idly musing, perhaps, on whether or not Caviar Kaspia might have a free table one evening or whether Emma Watson would appear in yet another front row — Leah Perez, the head of the fashion program at Shenkar College of Engineering and Design, the pre-eminent fashion college in Israel, was attending a different kind of show, wondering about very different kinds of questions. The kinds of questions that would probably never occur to her peers at the Istituto Marangoni or Central Saint Martins or the Fashion Institute of Technology.

headline: The True Cost of a Burger
text: In 2005, the House of Representatives passed an act that forbade consumers to sue fast-food operators over weight gain. “The Cheeseburger Bill” (formally, “The Personal Responsibility in Food Consumption Act”) attempted to legislate the message that the costs of fast food are personal, not social, and certainly not a consequence of selling harmful food at addictively low prices.

headline: The Benefits of Failing at French
text: I USED to joke that I spoke French like a 3-year-old. Until I met a French 3-year-old and couldn’t hold up my end of the conversation. This was after a year of intense study, including at least two hours a day with Rosetta Stone, Fluenz and other self-instruction software, Meetup groups, an intensive weekend class and a steady diet of French movies, television and radio, followed by what I’d hoped would be the coup de grâce: two weeks of immersion at one of the top language schools in France.

headline: Florida G.O.P. Seeks Delay on New Districts
text: MIAMI — Two top Republican leaders in Florida announced Tuesday that the Legislature would redraw the boundaries for the two congressional seats that a judge ruled unconstitutional, but they said they did not want the map to take effect until the 2016 elections.

headline: Young Israelis Fight Hashtag Battle to Defend #IsraelUnderFire
text: Confronted with an outpouring of sympathy on social networks for Palestinians killed or wounded in Gaza in an eight-day military confrontation, a group of young Israelis is pushing back, using the hashtag #IsraelUnderFire to rally support for what they say is an unavoidable, defensive war provoked by rocket fire from Islamist militants.

headline: The Original Long, Hot Summer
text: DELAWARE, Ohio — ON the morning of July 16, 1964, an off-duty white police officer, Lt. Thomas Gilligan, shot and killed a black student, James Powell, outside an apartment building on Manhattan’s Upper East Side. Hundreds of his classmates took to the streets in protest.

headline: House Effort to Scale Down Federal Terrorism Insurance Divides Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans’ efforts to pare federal terrorism insurance have ignited a battle between some Republicans from big metropolitan areas and much of the rest of their conference, while giving Democrats a new wedge into a business community increasingly flustered by its traditional allies.

headline: Pakistanis Detail Gains Against Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — One month into a military offensive to seize control of the tribal district of North Waziristan, the Pakistani military said Tuesday that it had extended its operation to the militant stronghold of Mir Ali, resulting in gunfights between soldiers and Islamist fighters that left casualties on both sides.

headline: Bank of America Hires More Junior Bankers
text: Bank of America has been on a hiring spree.

headline: Death Toll From Ebola Surges in West Africa, Prompting Alarm
text: New cases and deaths from the Ebola virus outbreak in the West African countries of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, already the worst ever recorded for the disease, have surged by double-digit percentages in the past week, the World Health Organization reported Tuesday, with no sign of a slowdown. Alarmed Ivory Coast border authorities blocked hundreds of Ivorian refugees in Liberia from returning, news agencies reported.

headline: Why Not Rent the American Dream?
text: Should housing policy be more balanced, supporting rental housing and homeownership on a more equal footing?

headline: A Sensible Marijuana Policy in Brooklyn
text: Kenneth Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, served both justice and common sense this week when he announced that he would no longer prosecute most cases in which people are arrested or ticketed for small amounts of marijuana. Such cases are usually dismissed. But by keeping thousands of them from going to court at all, Mr. Thompson will have more resources to devote to fighting serious crime. The new policy will also prevent the young minority men who are most of those arrested from getting criminal records that deny them jobs, housing or entry into armed services.

headline: Emerging Nations Bloc to Open Development Bank
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — At a meeting in Brazil, the leaders of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa announced on Tuesday that they were establishing a development bank to challenge the influence of venerable institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Pfizer to Inject Youth Into the Aging Process
text: Acronyms seem to be growing more prevalent in the vernacular, among them BOGO, for buy one, get one; YOLO, you only live once; and FOMO, fear of missing out. To that list, the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer hopes to add FOGO, a.k.a. fear of getting old.

headline: Robert W. Barone
text: Mr. Barone, 51, is the president of IVI International, a company based in White Plains, N.Y., that provides construction and risk-management services for lenders, developers and investors of commercial real estate. The company, founded in 1973, is involved in several high-profile projects, among them, the Hudson Yards and the Atlantic Yards developments.

headline: Kite Fight

headline: ‘Kite Fight’
text: After futebol, kite fighting is one of Brazil’s most popular sports. In the crowded urban favelas, flying a kite (or pipa) is more than a leisurely escape from harsh living conditions; it’s also a form of battle, with the sky an arena. This Op-Doc video takes us into Rocinha, Rio de Janeiro’s largest favela, to meet its young pipa warriors and elder statesman.

headline: F.C.C. Is Deluged With Comments on Net Neutrality Rules
text: From legal briefs to pithy one-liners, the public is having its say on the proposed rules that guide how digital bits flow across the Internet.

headline: A Push to Give Steadier Shifts to Part-Timers
text: As more workers find their lives upended and their paychecks reduced by ever-changing, on-call schedules, government officials are trying to put limits on the harshest of those scheduling practices.

headline: Lapses in the C.D.C.’s Labs
text: The crucial question raised by the appallingly careless way in which dangerous pathogens were handled at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is how to prevent future lapses at any of the laboratories, governmental or private, that conduct research on the most dangerous pathogens. If sloppiness and accidents could happen at the C.D.C., supposedly the most expert site in the nation for handling these dangerous materials, they could presumably happen anywhere.

headline: Highways Need a Higher Gas Tax
text: About 10,000 motorists die each year because of inadequate road conditions, and millions of other Americans waste large portions of their lives stuck in traffic or stalled trains. The enormous cost to society of poor infrastructure grows every year, and most of the blame can be placed directly on a Congress that refuses to collect and spend enough money to fix it.

headline: On Kawara, Artist Who Found Elegance in Every Day, Dies at 81
text: On Kawara, a Conceptual artist who devoted his career to recording the passage of time as factually and self-effacingly as art would allow, died in late June in New York City, where he had worked for 50 years. He was 81.

text: LUHANSK, Ukraine — The pro-Russian rebel with bad teeth and aviator sunglasses was trying to help me.

headline: Order vs. Disorder, Part 2
text: I’ve argued for a while now that it is always useful to study the Israeli-Arab conflict because it is to the wider war of civilizations what Off Broadway is to Broadway. A lot of stuff starts there and then goes to Broadway. So what’s playing Off Broadway these days? The Israeli-Arab conflict has become a miniature of the most relevant divide in the world today: the divide between the “world of order” and the “world of disorder.”

headline: L.I.R.R. Workers, on Brink of Strike, Prepare for Life on the Picket Line
text: The workers navigate trains and test signals, repair aging cars and scan moldering stretches of track on the nation’s oldest rail system still operating under its original name: the Long Island Rail Road, chartered in 1834.

headline: Documents Show General Motors Kept Silent on Fatal Crashes
text: The car crash that killed Gene Erickson caught the attention of federal regulators. Why did the Saturn Ion he was traveling in, along a rural Texas road, suddenly swerve into a tree? Why did the air bags fail? General Motors told federal authorities that it could not provide answers.

text: When Dr. Herbert Pardes retired as president and chief executive of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in 2011, the institution honored him at its annual “Cabaret” fund-raiser. More than 1,000 guests dined on wild mushroom soup catered by the restaurateur Danny Meyer and listened to Kelli O’Hara, a star of “South Pacific,” serenade them with Rodgers and Hammerstein, Sondheim and Berlin.

headline: FIFA’s Dazed and Dated Attitude
text: Of all the lasting images from the 2014 World Cup, the officials who run FIFA, soccer’s governing body, should be forced to remember one, above all: Germany’s Christoph Kramer staggering around the field in the final, glassy-eyed and dazed, like a sleepwalker.

headline: Appeals Panel Upholds Race in Admissions for University

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 15, 2014
Medicaid Home Care Cuts Are Unjust, Lawsuit Says
text: A federal class action lawsuit filed late Tuesday accuses New York State health officials of denying or slashing Medicaid home care services to chronically ill and disabled people without proper notice, the chance to appeal or even an explanation, protections required by law.

headline: After Brief Lull in Gaza Crisis, Airstrikes Resume
text: JERUSALEM — After a brief, one-sided cease-fire, Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip resumed on Tuesday the all-too-familiar rhythm of their latest battle: Over 100 rockets sent Israelis scrambling for shelter, Israeli airstrikes pounded tunnels and rocket launchers, and diplomats wrung their hands.

headline: Cuomo’s Campaign Holds a Wide Lead in Fund-Raising
text: ALBANY — Already riding an enviable lead in the polls and with his Republican opponent still struggling to introduce himself to voters, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has entered the final four months of his re-election campaign with an enormous monetary advantage, according to state financial disclosures released on Tuesday.

headline: Leaving a Sport in Better Shape
text: MINNEAPOLIS — They came to their current positions 22 years ago, one as a member of the Yankees’ organization, the other as the baseball commissioner. Derek Jeter was drafted in June 1992, three months before Bud Selig rose to the top of the sport’s hierarchy. Now they are retiring, with just the final lines remaining for their weighty legacies.

headline: Group Aiding de Blasio Spent $1.7 Million in First Half of ’14
text: A lobbying group set up by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign strategists spent close to $1.7 million in his first six months in office to promote his agenda and accomplishments, according to records filed with the state on Tuesday.

headline: Selig Hopes to Award Two Future Games Before His Retirement
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Beyond next year’s game in Cincinnati, Major League Baseball has not announced future sites for the All-Star Game.
