Commissioner Bud Selig said Tuesday that he hoped to award the 2016 and 2017 games before his scheduled retirement in January, but that Yankee Stadium would not be one of the sites.

headline: Gazans, Desiring Deep Change, Are Ambivalent on Egypt Cease-Fire Plan
text: GAZA CITY — Maher al-Jarba, 2, one of the first casualties in the Gaza Strip when Israel resumed airstrikes after a six-hour pause on Tuesday, writhed in terror in an emergency-room bed as a nurse poked a needle into his hand. A blast had knocked the curly haired boy down 11 stone steps, fracturing his skull.

headline: Like the Figure Formed
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Do not adjust your settings; this is not Numberplay, the weekly math blog. We are getting a geometry lesson from Daniel Raymon right here in our daily crossword puzzle.

headline: Calls for Resignation Mount for Minnesota Archbishop in Scandals
text: Just two years ago, the Roman Catholic archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis was making headlines as a leader in the battle against same-sex marriage. But for the last year and a half, the archbishop, John C. Nienstedt, has been battling to hold onto his post in the face of a series of scandals, which further deepened on Tuesday with the filing of an explosive affidavit by the former chancellor of the archdiocese.

headline: The Best Selling Sports Books
text: The 10 best selling sports books in June 2014, according to The New York Times Best Sellers List.

headline: Christie to Test Presidential Hopes in Iowa Trip
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will make his most significant and elaborate return to the presidential arena this week amid indications that, despite his tribulations, his political standing has stabilized and his advisers see a possible path to the Republican nomination in 2016.

headline: Grindhaus
text: At Grindhaus, a halting start reveals a rock ’n’ roll soul.

headline: House Passes Interim Fix for Highway Trust Fund
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday easily approved a short-term fix to the nearly depleted federal highway trust fund, as the prospects of hundreds of thousands of job losses and stalled road construction in August overwhelmed the protests of conservative groups that opposed the bill.

headline: The Umbrella as a Useless Accessory
text: A heavy downpour caught Mahamat Adams as he was making a delivery for a coffee shop on the Upper West Side on Tuesday.

headline: What Is Your Neighborhood’s Summertime Ritual?
text: Around New York City, locals are carrying on their summer traditions — the ritual of the questua, or handing out loaves of bread in exchange for small church donations in Williamsburg and Greenpoint; the Hoops in the Sun basketball tournament at Orchard Beach in the Bronx; croquet in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

headline: Libya Airport Is Crippled in Fighting by Militias
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The halls of this city’s international airport have been emptied of passengers and converted into a barracks for fighters, with a kitchen and a field hospital. Smoke rose from the building on Tuesday, while beyond it, on the airfield, mortar shells crashed into the tarmac.

headline: Robert Roe, New Jersey Congressman Called ‘Mr. Jobs,’ Dies at 90
text: Robert A. Roe, who as a congressman from New Jersey for 23 years played a key role in financing projects to expand the nation’s highway and mass transit systems and to combat water and ground pollution, died on Tuesday at his home in Green Pond, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Witnesses Testify Against Ex-Blackwater Colleagues in Case of 2007 Iraq Killings
text: WASHINGTON — As a line of Blackwater armored trucks pushed through heavy traffic away from the smoking wreckage of Nisour Square in Baghdad one day in 2007, a turret gunner waved his arms, telling nearby Iraqis to get down. He was warning them about the threat of his own American convoy.

headline: Chinese Oil Rig Near Vietnam to Be Moved
text: BEIJING — A Chinese energy company announced Wednesday that a giant oil rig that was deployed in disputed waters off the coast of Vietnam two months ago had completed its exploration work and would be moved.

headline: The Coming Democratic Schism
text: There is a striking generational split in the Democratic electorate.

headline: Looking to the Fall, Democrats in Senate Races Lead Fund-Raising
text: Democratic candidates in most of the races that will decide control of the United States Senate raised more than their Republican opponents during the three months ending in June and entered the summer with bulging bank accounts, according to campaign finance reports filed Tuesday.

headline: Two Former Attorneys General in Utah Are Charged With Corruption
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Two former Utah attorneys general were arrested on Tuesday in a sweeping corruption scandal, accused of trading favors and access to rich businessmen and improperly accepting money, golf getaways, and rides on private planes and a luxury houseboat.

headline: Qatar’s Soccer Move Into Europe
text: In 2012, Aspire, bankrolled by Qatar’s royal family, acquired K.A.S. Eupen, a lower-division team in Belgium, as a place for its top players.

headline: In Call, Obama and Merkel Discuss ‘Cooperation’ on Intelligence
text: WASHINGTON — In their first telephone conversation since revelations of American spying activities jarred relations between the United States and Germany, President Obama and Chancellor Angela Merkel on Tuesday discussed what White House officials described as “ways to improve cooperation” in the wake of the scandal.

headline: California Approves Forceful Steps Amid Drought
text: LOS ANGELES — With rainfall this year at historically low levels and reservoirs quickly dwindling, California officials on Tuesday approved the most drastic measures yet to reduce water consumption during the state’s increasingly serious drought, including fines of up to $500 per day under some circumstances for watering a garden, washing a car or hosing down a sidewalk.

headline: Democrat Is Governor Pick of G.O.P. Group in Kansas
text: In a stark challenge to the re-election prospects of Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, more than 100 Republican politicians and former elected officials on Tuesday endorsed Paul Davis, his Democratic challenger.

headline: Goal Remains to Remove Sterling, but Timetable Shifts
text: LAS VEGAS — The N.B.A. had hoped to approve a transfer of ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers on Tuesday. That was the plan, anyway.

headline: Obama Official Won’t Testify to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — The White House said Tuesday night that it would refuse to allow its director of political strategy to testify Wednesday before a Republican-led House committee investigating whether the administration had illegally conducted political activity in the West Wing.

headline: China Says Lending Put Growth Rate at 7.5 Percent
text: HONG KONG — China announced on Wednesday morning that its economy grew 7.5 percent in the second quarter, marginally better than expected, as a wave of lending unleashed by the central bank helped local governments continue investment projects even as housing construction remained very weak.

headline: TV Reporter Suspended for Comments About Antipolice Sentiment in Black Community
text: A local television reporter covering the killing of a police officer in New Jersey said Tuesday that he was suspended for two days after expressing his opinion on-air about antipolice sentiment in the African-American community.

headline: The Making of Five Aesthetic Flights of Fancy in Michel Gondry’s New Film ‘Mood Indigo’
text: In his new feature starring Romain Duris and Audrey Tautou, the French director has returned to the audacious visual trickery that distinguished his music videos for The White Stripes and Björk and features like “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.”

headline: An Unpretentious Upstate Eatery With Brooklyn-Pedigreed Pizza
text: When the New York City real estate developers Dick Berry and Tony Zunino bought a seven-story grain elevator in Wassaic, N.Y., eight years ago, narrowly saving the landmark from demolition, they thought they might turn it into a brewery or a restaurant. Instead, the structure became home to the Wassaic Project, an arts organization that runs a year-round residency program and an annual summer festival founded by Zunino’s daughter, Bowie Barnett-Zunino, her husband, Jeff Barnett-Winsby, Eve Biddle and Elan Bogarin. (This year’s edition, which will showcase the work of more than 100 artists alongside dance and music performances and film screenings, takes place Aug. 1-3.)

headline: Train Like a German Soccer Star
text: In the stirring World Cup final on Sunday between the national men’s soccer teams from Germany and Argentina, an American played a role on the field in Rio de Janeiro despite the United States team’s having been eliminated. Sitting and occasionally pacing tensely along the German sideline was Mark Verstegen, the team’s trainer.

headline: Word of the Day | muddle
text: muddle •\ˈmə-dəl\• verb and noun

headline: Teenagers’ Cars Are Older, Smaller and Less Safe, Study Finds
text: Many teenagers are driving vehicles that do not offer good crash protection or lack important safety technology, according to research released Wednesday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a group financed by the insurance industry.

headline: Philippines: A Deadly Typhoon
text: A powerful storm cut through the Philippines on Wednesday morning, killing at least one person and sending more than 150,000 people into shelters, disaster response officials said. Typhoon Rammasun caused landslides and flooding along its path from the central Philippines to the northern peninsula of Bataan, passing just south of the capital city, Manila. Government rescue teams were trying to reach remote areas south of Manila affected by the storm, which packed winds of 90 miles per hour and gusts to 115 miles an hour. The one confirmed fatality as of Wednesday morning involved a woman being hit by a falling electric pole, officials said. Last November, Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms on record, devastated the islands of Leyte and Samar on the east coast and killed more than 6,300 people.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (VH1) MAKE OR BREAK: THE LINDA PERRY PROJECT In this new reality competition series, Ms. Perry, above left — who broke into the music business as the lead singer and songwriter for the rock band 4 Non Blondes and has written and produced music for Christina Aguilera, Gwen Stefani and Pink, among others — will welcome a handful of young artists into her recording studio with the goal of finding the next big thing. At the end of the season, Ms. Perry will choose a winner to sign to her record label.

headline: Jeter Takes Advantage, and So Does the American League
text: MINNEAPOLIS — In the final act of his final All-Star Game, Derek Jeter did something that was quintessentially him. Asked about his first at-bat here on Tuesday, and Adam Wainwright’s in-game acknowledgment that he had deliberately given him a good pitch to hit, Jeter tried humor to defuse a bubbling controversy.

headline: Obama on Transportation and the Economy
text: The president spoke Tuesday about the importance of federal highway funding after touring the Turner-Fairbank Highway Research Center in McLean, Va.

headline: No Cornering Clinton on ‘Daily Show’
text: WASHINGTON — When Hillary Rodham Clinton sat down Tuesday night for a “Daily Show” grilling, Jon Stewart was ready with what he called a career-aptitude test. “This can you help you decide if you even want this job”:

headline: Chinatown’s Renegade Sport
text: Since the late 1930s, men of Chinatown have been playing nine-man, their own intense variation of volleyball, which is featured in the forthcoming film “9-Man.”

headline: Rogue Sport Lacks Sand but Has Style and Speed
text: On the eastern edge of Manhattan’s Chinatown on a recent Saturday morning, Mike Fan waited as a group of women with gray-tinged hair maneuvered through their tai chi poses on an asphalt volleyball court with a thick yellow outline. Mr. Fan, 31, kept one eye on the slow-moving choreography over the rough ground as he adjusted his knee-high black socks.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 16, 2014
text: “There was no financial reward for providing good care; there was financial reward for getting people through the doors and filling up the beds.”

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Toll in Gaza and Israel, Day by Day
text: The daily tally of rocket attacks, airstrikes and deaths in the conflict between Israel and Hamas.

headline: Book Editor Says His Firing Was Linked to Tiananmen Gathering
text: Li Xuewen, an essayist and playwright in Beijing, has been fired from his job as a book editor in what he said was retribution for attending a private event in May marking the 25th anniversary of the military suppression of the Tiananmen Square protests.

headline: China Sees a Recovery, on Paper
text: HONG KONG — Ou Chengbi, a butcher at a sweltering open-air market on the outskirts of Guangzhou in southeastern China, can scarcely see signs of recovery in her country’s economy. Dripping with perspiration near unrefrigerated slabs of beef in her stall, she described how as recently as last winter she could still chop up an entire cow each day and sell it all.

headline: Student Crossword | Geometry
text: Test your knowledge of geometry by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Ticking Viral Bombs, Left in Boxes
text: In “Ticking Viral Bombs, Left in Boxes,” Lawrence K. Altman, M.D. writes about recent safety breaches at United States government health and research laboratories.

headline: Military Official Says Israel Invasion of Gaza Is Likely
text: TEL AVIV — Even as Israel and Hamas agreed to suspend hostilities briefly on Thursday at the request of the United Nations, a senior Israeli military official said that his government was increasingly likely to order a ground invasion of the Gaza Strip that it had hoped to avoid.

headline: 7 Sauces That Taste Better Homemade
text: Keep your condiments pure and simple.

headline: Fishing in South India’s Troubled Waters
text: Selvaprakash Lakshmanan thought he had embarked on a human rights project when he visited coastal communities in South India, where traditional Indian fishermen had clashed with the Sri Lankan Navy. Hundreds of fishermen had been killed in the contested waters of the narrow straits separating the two nations. Thousands more had been attacked, and scores were missing.

headline: Steven Holl and Athol Fugard among Winners of Praemium Imperiale Awards
text: Steven Holl has won the 2014 Praemium Imperiale International Arts Award for architecture. The awards, in various fields, are presented annually by the Japan Art Association and recognize lifetime achievement in the arts.

headline: Storm Leaves Trail of Destruction in Philippines
text: MANILA — A powerful typhoon ripped across the Philippines on Wednesday, sending hundreds of thousands of coastal residents fleeing to evacuation centers and leaving several people dead, although officials said the toll could rise.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: A Chinese-Language Lesson Ripped From the Headlines
text: The English-language edition of Global Times, the populist newspaper published by People’s Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece, is now mining corruption investigations for teaching material in its daily “Learning Chinese” column. On Wednesday, the newspaper published a lesson based on the plight of Rui Chenggang, the 36-year-old state television anchor who was detained Friday. The lesson appeared in the lower right corner of page 21 (and can be seen at the end of this post).

headline: White House Announces Climate Change Initiatives
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — President Obama announced a series of climate change initiatives on Wednesday aimed at guarding the electricity supply; improving local planning for flooding, coastal erosion and storm surges; and better predicting landslide risks as sea levels rise and storms and droughts intensify.

headline: New York Today: Weather People
text: Good morning on this still wet Wednesday.

headline: Daily Report: Apple and IBM Form ‘Landmark Partnership’ on Business Software
text: In a deal that could deepen Apple’s sales to corporations and strengthen IBM’s position in business software, the two companies announced a wide-ranging partnership on Tuesday intended to spread advanced mobile and data analysis technology in the corporate world, Brian X. Chen and Steve Lohr report.

headline: Israelis Tells Palestinians to Leave Their Homes
text: Palestinians in Gaza City neighborhoods were warned by leaflet, text messages and automated phone calls.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The enormous cost to society of poor infrastructure grows every year, and most of the blame can be placed directly on a Congress that refuses to collect and spend enough money to fix it,” writes The New York Times editorial board. The passage on Tuesday of a highway funding bill will do little to alleviate the systemic underfunding of infrastructure projects: The 10-month measure “keeps spending at an inadequate level and does not address the dwindling revenues that keep producing all-too-familiar cliffhanging crises.” Road projects are typically funded by the gasoline tax, but it “has been stuck at 18.4 cents a gallon since 1993” and Republicans refuse to raise it. “Without an increase, the trust fund will continually run out of money, jeopardizing one of the most basic functions of government.”

headline: The Invasion of Britain
text: TORQUAY, England — It’s that time of year again. Every July and August, an army of teenagers, several hundred thousand strong, marches, flies, sails, drives and rides trains across Europe toward Britain. The invasion is peaceful, and meets no resistance. In fact, the British welcome it.

headline: How I’m Trying to Manage My Online Brand
text: I met recently with a large Silicon Valley venture fund. My company is not raising money at the moment, but the fund had heard about Posse and reached out to me online. Since I was in town anyway, I decided to meet with the fund’s investors and build a relationship. I showed them some slides and talked about our vision for Posse.

headline: Murdoch Puts Time Warner on His Wish List
text: Updated, 10:13 p.m. | If content is still king in a media business challenged by new technologies and nimble upstarts, Rupert Murdoch hungers to wear the crown.

headline: Messaging App Line Files for I.P.O. in Tokyo
text: LONDON — The owner of the Japanese Internet messaging service Line said on Wednesday that it had filed for a potential initial public offering in Tokyo for the popular smartphone application.

headline: Partisanship Infuses Hearings on Health Law and Executive Power
text: WASHINGTON — Efforts by congressional Republicans to rein in what they say are the legislative and political excesses of the Obama administration played out in simultaneous hearings on Wednesday, further highlighting how election-year politics are overtaking business on Capitol Hill.

headline: Bank of America’s Settlement Negotiations Hit a Snag
text: Once again, Bank of America’s troubled past is clouding its present and future.

headline: 1939: Sculptor Epstein to Carve ‘Eve’
text: LONDON — Jacob Epstein has agreed to carve a mate, “Eve” — for “Adam,” his lonely three-ton version of primitive man — for a glimpse of whom rollicking holiday crowds at Blackpool, Lancashire, lined up during the week end and paid an admission fee of a shilling a time. Laurence Wright, who brought “Adam” to Blackpool, said today that Epstein had accepted his offer to sculpt “Eve” for £15,000. Epstein said Wright will use six tons of pink Derbyshire alabaster for the companion piece, double the quantity from which “Adam” emerged. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 17, 1939

headline: Netherlands Held Liable for 300 Deaths in Srebrenica Massacre
text: PARIS — A Dutch court ruled on Wednesday that the government was liable for the deaths of about 300 victims of the 1995 Srebrenica massacre in Bosnia, Europe’s worst ethnically motivated mass murder since World War II, saying that a United Nations team of Dutch peacekeepers had failed to prevent those deaths.

headline: Gtech of Italy to Acquire Slot Machine Maker for $4.7 Billion
text: Gtech, the operator of the Italian lottery, has agreed to acquire the slot machine maker International Game Technology of Las Vegas for $4.7 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Stalking the Shadow Universe
text: For centuries people have found meaning — or thought they did — in what they could see in the sky, the shapes of the constellations echoing old myths, the sudden feathery intrusion of comets, the regular dances of the planets, the chains of galaxies, spanning unfathomable distances of time and space.

headline: A Master of Illusion Endures
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The cafe here on Westminster Street that was the location for a future Woody Allen movie looked like an elaborate stage illusion, surrounded by large screens that focused light into the restaurant, while also concealing any action within from onlookers outside.

headline: Kimpton Now Rewards How You Act, Not Just How Long You Stay
text: Hotel loyalty programs generally measure guests’ commitment by the frequency of their stays. But Kimpton Hotels aims to discern – and reward — true passion with its new Kimpton Karma Rewards program, beginning Wednesday.

headline: A Tiny Wire, and a Big Train Wreck
text: MOSCOW — The snapping of one small, improperly installed wire caused a Moscow subway crash this week that killed 22 people, investigators said on Wednesday. The police arrested a senior track foreman and his assistant.

headline: Note to Cadres: Hands Off the Black Audi and Chauffeur
text: You can take away a Chinese official’s dignity, as frolicsome videos on the Internet show. You can take away, at least for a while, gluttony on the public purse, chandeliered offices and vacations abroad in the guise of inspection tours. But can you take away that ultimate perk of the respectable cadre — the black car with intimidatingly tinted windows, an equally intimidating medley of official insignia, passes and a faithful driver?

headline: Greek Fugitive Is Arrested in Athens Shootout
text: ATHENS — Greece’s most wanted terrorist, Nikos Maziotis, the self-professed leader of the leftist guerrilla group Revolutionary Struggle, was arrested on Wednesday after a shootout with the police in the middle of a busy shopping district and popular tourist spot in Athens.

headline: BlackRock Results Show a Shift Away From Stocks
text: With stock market indexes near record highs, investors committed more money to BlackRock in the second quarter, helping increase profit for the giant asset management firm.

headline: Morning Agenda: Murdoch Pursues Time Warner
text: The media giant 21st Century Fox, the empire run by Rupert Murdoch, made an $80 billion takeover bid in recent weeks for Time Warner but was rebuffed, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. The bold approach could put Time Warner in play and might again ignite a reshaping of the media industry, prompting a new spate of mega-mergers among the nation’s largest entertainment companies.

headline: Portugal Telecom and Brazil Phone Giant Revise Merger Terms
text: LISBON — Portugal Telecom and Oi of Brazil said on Wednesday that they had renegotiated the terms of their planned merger to salvage a deal threatened by the financing problems of the Espírito Santo group, which is controlled by Portugal’s most powerful family.

headline: Oldies on the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Tomas Maier Seeks an Entirely New Fashion Niche
text: Recently, I was talking to the designer Tomas Maier, a.k.a. the creative director of Bottega Veneta, one of Kering’s brands, and the eponymous designer of a line that last winter got a cash infusion thanks to a joint venture with said big luxury group. We got onto the subject of “What happens next?” with his own brand. The topic isn’t so surprising, but part of the answer was.

headline: A Robot With a Little Humanity
text: As a graduate student at M.I.T. in the 1990s, Cynthia Breazeal studied with the roboticist Rodney Brooks and explored the idea of “social” robots that were designed to interact and collaborate with humans.

headline: A Spare, Americana-Influenced Video From the Indie Supergroup Hiss Golden Messenger
text: [Watch the official video for “Lucia” by Hiss Golden Messenger.]

headline: Assad Begins a Third Term in Syria, Vowing to Look After Its People
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Feted by supporters, whom he hailed as the victors of his country’s brutal civil war, a triumphant President Bashar al-Assad was sworn in on Wednesday for a third seven-year term after an election that was widely seen as a gesture of calculated defiance toward the United States and others in the West and in the Arab world seeking his ouster.

headline: Pakistani Airstrikes Target Haven for Qaeda and Taliban Fighters
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistani fighter jets killed at least 35 people in attacks on militant bases in a remote part of the North Waziristan tribal district, the military said Wednesday, hours after local residents reported that an American drone strike in the same area had killed 20 people.

headline: Treasury Urges End to Foreign Tax Flights, but Quick Action Is Unlikely
text: Updated, 9:40 p.m. |

headline: South Korea Begins Naval Drills With the U.S.
text: ABOARD THE U.S.S. GEORGE WASHINGTON — Fighter jets roared off an American aircraft carrier into a gray sky on Wednesday as the United States kicked off a joint naval exercise off the west coast of the Korean Peninsula, with the South Korean president, Park Geun-hye, calling for strong punishment if North Korea initiated a military provocation.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Boehner Moves Ahead With Plan to Sue Obama
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington. Heat and humidity are taking a brief hiatus, but there will be no such relief for relations between President Obama and House Republicans.

headline: Behind Subway’s Phantom Hotel Entrance, Neither Arias Nor Opulence Linger
text: The management of the Astor family’s Hotel Knickerbocker was baffled.

headline: Gun Deaths Versus Car Deaths
text: A report out on Tuesday from the Violence Policy Center confirms yet again the lunacy of America’s loose gun policies.

headline: Miami’s Coastal Climate Calamity – in Super Slo-Mo
text: I’ve differed with Time Magazine’s fine correspondent Michael Grunwald on the importance of the Keystone pipeline (Grunwald, me), but cheered him on earlier this week on Twitter after climate campaigners attacked him (Grunwald a “denier” and “polyanna”?) for challenging an overheated Guardian account of the impacts of rising sea levels on Miami (Grunwald’s home turf). (The Guardian story was an echo of a May feature in The Times.)

headline: L.I.R.R. Negotiations Resume With Different Tone
text: Four days before a possible strike, the Long Island Rail Road and its unions resumed talks on Wednesday and pledged to continue informal discussions throughout the night — a conspicuous shift in tone after negotiations broke down earlier in the week.

headline: Ya Gotta Have Faith
text: Jared Bernstein sends me to Congressional testimony on the state of the economy – his and Larry Kudlow’s (pdf). Jared’s remarks are, of course, sensible. Kudlow’s are … well, kind of amazing.

headline: Deadly Typhoon in the Philippines
text: Typhoon Rammasun has killed at least 10 people in the Philippines, and forced tens of thousands to evacuate.

headline: Fantasies of Personal Destruction
text: A correspondent directs me to a piece in Forbes about yours truly that is both funny and scary.

headline: Briarwood, Queens: A Quiet Refuge Bounded by Traffic
text: The neighborhood of Briarwood in central Queens borders the Kew Gardens interchange, one of the city’s most congested traffic hubs, but is home to residents who value a quiet, low-key way of life. With its single- and multifamily homes and large co-op and rental complexes, it is an affordable refuge for a diverse mix of middle-class New Yorkers.

headline: Roche Reports Mixed Results in Trial of an Alzheimer’s Drug
text: Roche, the pharmaceutical company, on Wednesday reported mixed results in its latest trial of an Alzheimer’s drug. It said that while the drug did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it did seem to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild cases of Alzheimer’s.

headline: For Friends in the Know
text: OPENING A STORE is easy, right? You pick a bustling neighborhood thick with people, put your space near other businesses likely to attract the sort of people you think will appreciate your wares, fling open your doors and — voilà — retail Valhalla. You’ll be fighting them off at the door.

headline: Fauna, Flora and Freighters in the Danube Delta
text: I once heard an unusual tale about an Indian investment broker working in Bucharest, Romania, who had become enchanted by the Danube River Delta region, with its lonely canals, floating reed beds and silver onion-domed monasteries alongside quaint blue cottages in fishing villages one could only reach by boat.

headline: 57,000 Reasons Immigration Overhaul May Be Stalled for Now
text: WASHINGTON — The crisis on the border with Mexico is rapidly overtaking President Obama’s plans to use executive action to reshape the nation’s immigration system, forcing him to confront a new set of legal, administrative and political complications.

headline: The Rise of Cafe Culture in New York
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Need for a Sidewalk Cafe Society” appeared on July 5 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Simplifying Measuring Medication for Children
text: Parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12 are often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers. In A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk Jan Hoffman describes new efforts by professional associations to persuade manufacturers and pharmacists to adopt a uniform unit for liquid medicines: the milliliter. She describes the mistakes in dosing made by parents grabbing kitchen spoons, confusing teaspoons and tablespoons, and misreading instructions. Of 287 parents interviewed shortly after they had finished giving medication to their children that had been prescribed at the emergency departments at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan and Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, more than 40 percent of the parents had not measured correctly.

headline: Family Behind Hobby Lobby Has New Project: Bible Museum
text: WASHINGTON — The evangelical Christian family that owns Hobby Lobby, the chain of craft stores, made history two weeks ago when the Supreme Court overturned the Obama administration’s mandate that family-owned companies must provide contraceptive coverage to their employees.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,100,000
text: ROSWELL, GA.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Hellish Vacation
text: LONDON – What a pristine room, all sparkling white from floor to ceiling, with not a speck of dust in sight.

headline: Indian Club’s Ban on Dhotis in Favor of Western Attire Draws Protests
text: NEW DELHI — A regional leader in southern India on Wednesday condemned “sartorial despotism” after a posh English-style cricket club denied entry to several men wearing traditional Indian wraparound garments, telling them they could enter only in “full trousers, shirts or T-shirts with collars,” as rules posted outside the club say.

headline: Ron Howard to Direct Documentary on Beatles’ Performing History
text: Having presented a sweeping autobiography of sorts in “The Beatles Anthology,” nearly 20 years ago, Apple, the Beatles’ company, is returning to its archives. The company announced Wednesday that it will produce a new documentary focused on the band’s touring years. The film, which is as yet untitled, will be a collaboration between Apple, White Horse Pictures and Imagine Entertainment, and will be directed by Ron Howard.

headline: Reflecting on a Decade of Murdoch Deals
text: Bold deals are nothing new for Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Wheelies: The Heavy Chevy Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Why You Are So Stressed About Stress
text: NPR conducted a study about how stressed out we are as a country, and the results, released last week, show that one in four Americans reported feeling stressed in the last month and one in two has experienced a major stressful event in the last year.

headline: House Hunting in ...Newfoundland
text: A WATERFRONT CHALET-STYLE LOG CABIN IN NEWFOUNDLAND

headline: BMW Recalls 1.6 Million Cars Over Defective Takata Air Bag Part
text: BMW is recalling about 1.6 million 3 Series cars from the 2000-6 model years, including about 574,000 in the United States, over a concern that the front-seat passenger could be injured by metal shards from a deploying air bag in a crash, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Board Book Roundup: Babies’ Delight
text: New books include “Little Pear Tree” by Rachel Williams.

headline: In Expansion, BMW to Make China-Only Models
text: FRANKFURT — The German automaker BMW said Wednesday that it would significantly expand its operations in the fast-growing Chinese market, doubling the number of models it produces there and extending its alliance with a local partner, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings.

headline: Say Yes to Undress, Then Things Get Complicated
text: In case you missed the news that traditional courtship is dead, naked people on VH1 stand ready to enlighten you. And in case you thought that television networks had evolved beyond trying to attract viewers with cheesy titillation — ditto.

headline: Focus on Asset Managers Highlights Bad Behavior by S.E.C.
text: When a financial titan like Laurence D. Fink lobbies Washington, the natural instinct is to make sure the citizenry pats itself down to check that everyone still has their wallets, watches and belts.

headline: 1964: Hostility Shown to Goldwater
text: PARIS — The world reacted emphatically to Barry Goldwater today and most of the reaction was hostile. From London to Paris to Bonn to Moscow, commentators denounced the Arizona senator as a reactionary and a cold-warmonger. Only in Madrid and Johannesburg and a few other cities were voices of approval raised as the news flashed around the world of the senator’s nomination as the Republican presidential candidate. In London, the pro-Labor mass-circulation “Daily Mirror” said: “The corpse of much that is decent and wise and tolerant in American society is in the coffin, although the lid has not yet finally been screwed down.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 17, 1964

headline: Brazilian Private Equity Firm Near Closing on $1 Billion Fund
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The investment firm Gávea Investments, founded by the former Brazilian Central Bank president Arminio Fraga and Luiz Henrique Fraga in 2003, is near final closing on a new private equity fund that could exceed $1 billion, two people familiar with its plans said.

headline: Small Businesses Are Finding Bank Loans Easier to Come By
text: Jake Fitzsimmons opened his first Stuft Burger Bar in Fort Collins, Colo., in 2010, after the worst recession in decades. It turned out to be an excellent time to open a burger joint — Coloradans were downsizing their dinners out — but a terrible time to apply for a loan.

headline: A New History in the Making for Hoylake
text: HOYLAKE, England — Bernard Darwin, Charles Darwin’s grandson and a Hall of Fame golf correspondent, wrote long ago, “Hoylake, blown upon by mighty winds, breeder of mighty champions.”

headline: Stir-fried Rice With Amaranth or Red Chard and Thai Basil
text: Amaranth is a beautiful green with small red and green leaves that grow, bush-like, off medium-thick stems. I get it from Asian vendors at the farmers’ market, where I can also find Thai basil. I cut away the very tough ends but use the more tender parts of the stalks. A good substitute here would be red chard, whose stems can be diced and included in the stir-fry. You could also use beet greens, but I’d omit the stringy stems. I spiced this Thai-influenced stir-fry with sriracha, but that spicy chili sauce is optional.

headline: Stir-Fried Turkey Breast With Snap or Snow Peas and Chard
text: Shopping for ingredients for this week’s recipes in my farmers’ market, I found young, tender snap peas that were almost as delicate as snow peas. I had part of a bunch of Swiss chard and used both vegetables. I like using turkey breast cutlets in stir-fries; they’ve already been cut to a uniform thickness, so all you need to do is slice them across the grain to get even pieces that cook in minutes.

headline: Paul Gibson Jr., New York City’s First Black Deputy Mayor, Is Dead at 86
text: Paul Gibson Jr., a lawyer and an airline executive who in 1974 became New York City’s first black deputy mayor, died on July 11 at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 86.

headline: Money Alone Won’t Secure Time Warner for Murdoch
text: Rupert Murdoch has one last big takeover left in him. Time Warner makes the perfect swan song for the 83-year-old media mogul. The HBO-to-Looney Tunes conglomerate sits at the top of a pyramid where content is king, has no controlling shareholder and poses few insurmountable antitrust hurdles for 21st Century Fox. But winning will not just be a matter of price.

headline: Changyuraptor, Large Species of Flying Dinosaur, Is Discovered
text: Scientists have discovered a large species of flying “four-winged” dinosaur that may have relied on a long, feathery tail to prevent crash landings.

headline: Randall Stout, Architect Tied to Nature, Dies at 56
text: Randall Stout, an environmentally sensitive architect who earned a national reputation for designing dynamically shaped regional museums, mostly in his native South, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 56.

headline: Analyzing Next Steps, Airbus Chief Is Closely Watching Google and Facebook
text: LONDON — Thomas Enders, the chief executive of the Airbus Group, has not been shy in his public admiration for the speed and scale of innovation that has been achieved by American high-technology giants like Google, Facebook and SpaceX. But it is only recently that he has begun to consider such companies potential future aerospace partners.

headline: Marvel Will Introduce a Female Thor This Fall
text: Marvel Comics revealed on Tuesday that Thor, the God of Thunder and the son of the Norse god Odin, will be replaced by a woman. The character, who Marvel has revealed few details about, will star in “Thor, God of Thunder,” a new series that begins in October, written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Russell Dauterman.

headline: An Apartment as Co-Star
text: Of course, “Between Riverside and Crazy” is by Stephen Adly Guirgis, a playwright whose distinctive style extends to his titles. Longtime admirers of this wistfully poetic writer know that he favors references to places in New York or New Jersey (“Our Lady of 121st Street,” “The Little Flower of East Orange”), hard consonant sounds (“The _______ With the Hat”) and a sense of careening movement (“Jesus Hopped the ‘A’ Train”).

headline: Vintage French Cars Turn Heads
text: Owners of old French cars paraded through New York City to showcase their classics.

headline: Francophiles Celebrate Bastille Day With French Cars and Bikes
text: For the last 15 years, the Greater New York Citroën and Velosolex Touring Club has lent its charms to the annual French Institute Alliance Française Bastille Day street fair on 60th Street and 5th Avenue. The fair celebrates French culture and food, but the collection of classic French cars and motorized bicycles has always added a splash of style and color.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Plan to Send 6 Detainees to Uruguay
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has secretly notified Congress that the military intends to transfer six low-level Guantánamo Bay detainees to Uruguay as early as next month, according to people with knowledge of the communication. All six have been approved for transfer for more than four years.

headline: With DC59 Motorhead, Dyson Looks to Create the iPad of Vacuums
text: More than a decade ago, Dyson, the British company known for its line of powerful and expensive vacuum cleaners, quietly began working on an ambitious project to displace its own best invention.

headline: Nine in Egypt Are Convicted in Sex Assaults
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian judge on Wednesday sentenced nine men accused of sexual assault to terms of 20 years to life, handing down the lengthy penalties weeks after the government pledged that sexual violence against women would be more severely punished.

headline: For a Parting Gift, Do You Want a Grapefruit or a Meatball?
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Denny McLain was the original Adam Wainwright, and Mickey Mantle the original Derek Jeter.

headline: Whisky, Summer Style
text: Scotch whisky might not seem like a natural fit for lighter summer cocktails. The adjectives you hear applied to these whiskies — peaty, earthy, even mediciney — may not immediately suggest beach-ready drinks. But in fact the smokiness or salinity of Scotch whiskies is the very reason they can do so well in citrus-infused drinks with a bit of sugar: they stand up to the sweetness. And just as the complex layers of flavors and aromas of straight whisky open up when you add water, they also sing when combined with the ingredients in these three warm-weather Scotch drinks, created by bartenders from Glasgow, New York City and Los Angeles.

headline: A Westerner’s Inside View of Alibaba Successes and Failures
text: After studying Chinese in the early 1990s and hosting a travel show on state-run television in China, Porter Erisman went to work for a public relations firm. Then, during the dot-com boom in 2000, he joined a tiny, Chinese Internet start-up called Alibaba.

headline: Should Janet Yellen Be Giving Us Stock Picks?
text: Eighteen years ago, when Alan Greenspan wanted to send a message that he worried the stock market was getting a little bubbly, he did it with a typically inscrutable phrasing buried in an otherwise unremarkable speech.

headline: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Mozart, Brahms and More
text: WORKS BY SCHUMANN AND JANACEKMarc-André Hamelin, pianist(Hyperion)The pianist Marc-André Hamelin brings commanding technique, elegant musicianship and imagination to a program of suites about, variously, rural life, nature and children. Janacek’s “On the Overgrown Path,” Book I is a 30-minute compilation of mood pieces, character pieces and short works inspired by folk music. Mr. Hamelin searches out the strangeness in the music while conveying the character. He gives a beguiling, lively account of Schumann’s overlooked “Waldszenen” (“Forest Scenes”) and brings freshness and distinction to his familiar “Kinderszenen” (“Scenes of Childhood”). (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Today in Small Business: Same-Day Delivery
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Is Truvada, the Pill to Prevent H.I.V., 99 Percent Effective? Don’t Be So Sure
text: Truvada, the once-a-day pill to help keep people from contracting H.I.V., is on the cover of this week’s New York magazine, and Tim Murphy’s cover story focuses on how the pill is changing sex by drastically reducing gay men’s fear of infection.

headline: The Moderate Revolution in Kansas
text: A surprising political revolt is now brewing in Kansas, one that could provide a model for breaking the stranglehold of the hard right on the Republican Party — if enough people join in.

headline: Are Banks Fighting Over Your Business?
text: In an article we just published, Jake Fitzsimmons describes how last fall he and his partner induced four banks to compete for the opportunity to loan them money. Mr. Fitzsimmons co-owns Stuft Burger Bar, which was making plans to open its third restaurant in northern Colorado. “We went into it at the front and said we’re going to take the best initial opportunity,” Mr. Fitzsimmons said. “Our hope with that was that they would give us their best offer originally, knowing that we were looking at other banks.” In the end, three of the four banks came back with bids.

headline: Weather May Not Affect Back Pain
text: Many people think the weather affects their back pain, but a new study shows they are probably wrong.

headline: Yellen Says Restraining the Fed’s Oversight Would Be a ‘Grave Mistake’
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that it would be a “grave mistake” for Congress to adopt legislation proposed by House Republicans constraining the Fed’s management of monetary policy.

headline: Witness Accounts of Gaza Attack That Killed 4 Boys
text: Foreign correspondents reporting from Gaza on Wednesday offered visceral accounts of a deadly attack that killed four children on the beach outside a hotel in which the journalists were staying. Tyler Hicks, a New York Times photographer, was among those who rushed from the hotel to the beach as a desperate scramble unfolded to save the lives of other children wounded in the shelling.

headline: Easy Ways to Get More Vegetables on the Table, More Often
text: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. Last week, Renee did her first stir-fry, based on last week’s advice and a recipe like those found here.Hello Martha,

headline: Sweet and Sour Stir-Fried Radishes With Their Greens
text: We always toss out radish greens, but we shouldn’t. They are as nutritious as any green, and they have a pleasantly bitter flavor that is very much like that of turnip greens, which are a close relative. The bitterness works very well against a sweet and sour stir-fry sauce. The radishes should be barely cooked. This is a great dish for large, colorful breakfast radishes. The big bunches I get at my farmers’ market weigh a pound, sometimes a little more. Use 2 bunches if yours are smaller.

headline: Some Top Money Managers Push for Fed to Start Raising Interest Rates
text: The Fed is out of step with Wall Street, say some of the country’s wealthiest investors.

headline: Pelosi, in Reversal, Says She Opposes Speeding Child Deportations
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, reversed course on Wednesday and said she would not back changes to a 2008 law that gave certain undocumented immigrant children broader legal rights to enter the United States.

headline: App Smart | Avoiding Sunburns
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you avoid too much sun exposure, as well as give you tanning advice and hydration tips.

headline: Your Time in the Sun, Measured to the Minute
text: I WOULD bet that more than once over the last several weeks you have forgotten to put sunscreen on before you went outside, even though we all know the dangers of getting too much sun. As in so many situations, your smartphone can come to the rescue, with sunshine prediction and advice apps.

headline: To Reassure Time Warner Employees, Bewkes Takes to the Small Screen
text: Jeffrey L. Bewkes has gone digital.

headline: Noriega Sues Video Game Maker Over Portrayal in Call of Duty
text: Manuel Noriega, the former dictator of Panama, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the maker of the popular Call of Duty: Black Ops II video game, saying his image was used in the game without his permission.

headline: Gene Therapy Is Used to Adjust Pigs’ Heartbeat
text: By injecting a gene into a pig’s heart, scientists have created a “biological pacemaker” that can regulate heartbeats, an achievement that eventually may lead to an alternative to electronic pacemakers in some people.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Loses 4 Performers
text: Updated, 3:44 p.m. | Not many comedians will know what it is like to be a cast member of “Saturday Night Live”; at least Brooks Wheelan, John Milhiser and Noël Wells can say they were part of that NBC late-night comedy franchise for one year. But all three of those featured performers who joined “SNL” in last fall – a season that began with Tina Fey poking fun at the dispensability of the show’s rookie players – are now gone.

headline: Boys Drawn to Gaza Beach, and Into Center of Mideast Strife
text: GAZA CITY — The four Bakr boys were young cousins, the children of Gaza fishermen who had ordered them to stay indoors — and especially away from the beach. But cooped up for nine days during Israeli bombardments, the children defied their parents and went out Wednesday afternoon, the eldest shooing away his little brother, telling him it was too dangerous.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Foreign Policy
text: The recent dust-up between Rand Paul and Rick Perry (among other Paul critics) makes for a good occasion to add another entry to my series on critiques of reform conservatism — this time, responding to the suggestion that our movement either doesn’t offer any foreign policy ideas, or else is shackled to the carcass of Bush-era neoconservatism. The former critique is, in a way, complimentary, a testament to our tendency’s newfound influence (“first they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they demand that you supply a foreign policy agenda as well …”); the latter strikes me as mostly ill-founded but somewhat understandable. Here’s Andrew Sullivan making both at once:

headline: Did a Headline on Germany’s ‘Global Might’ Go Too Far?
text: When Germany won the World Cup earlier this week, not just the sports pages of The Times took note. The news pages featured a story on the joyful mood in Germany, but the headline bothered some German readers, who said it played into offensive stereotypes. It read: “Germans See World Cup Win as Symbol of Global Might.”

headline: Mystery Solved on Names and Money Behind Thad Cochran Ads
text: One of the oddities of the oddity-filled Mississippi runoff between Thad Cochran and Chris McDaniel was the newspaper ads aimed at turning out black voters for Mr. Cochran, the Republican senator who narrowly won the June 24 election.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Receives Nearly $27 Million From Businesses
text: More companies are digging into their pockets to help save the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts from being sold off to help pay municipal debts in the city’s federal bankruptcy.

headline: Lena Dunham’s Book Tour Is a Hot Ticket
text: Lena Dunham’s coming tour to promote her book “Not That Kind of Girl,” is already partly sold out, nearly three months before it kicks off in New York City on Sept. 30, and only a day after Ms. Dunham announced her itinerary on Twitter.

headline: The Trials of Graham Spanier, Penn State’s Ousted President
text: On the day the police arrived at the home of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach, to arrest him on multiple counts of child sexual abuse, Graham Spanier was beginning his 17th year as Penn State’s president. It was an extraordinary tenure, and one that had seemed most likely to continue for many more years. A man of ceaseless energy and considerable ego, Spanier led the university as it grew from a remote outpost of American higher education into a top-tier public university.

headline: Euro Comes Back Into Investor Favor
text: FRANKFURT — The euro appears to be regaining favor with international investors.

headline: Apple Could Pay $400 Million in E-Books Price-Fixing Case
text: The number is in for how much Apple might have to pay to consumers to settle charges of conspiring with publishers to raise e-book prices: $400 million.

headline: Russia Plans to Reopen Post in Cuba for Spying
text: MOSCOW — Russia has decided to reopen an electronic eavesdropping post in Cuba that it closed more than a decade ago, reaching out for a onetime symbol of its global superpower status, Russian officials and newspaper reports said on Wednesday.

headline: The Big Electoral Consequences of Splitting California Six Ways
text: The supporters of a proposal to split California into six states say they have enough signatures to place their proposal on the ballot in 2016.

headline: Bank of America Still Struggles to Churn Out Solid Earnings
text: Bank of America is stuck in a low-profitability trap. Several businesses at the bank actually put in a good showing for the second quarter. The trouble is, Bank of America as a whole is still struggling to churn out solid earnings – even after aggressive cost-cutting.

headline: South Africa Cycling, With Cultural Side Trips
text: VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations’ new tour, Cycling South Africa: Cape Town and the Garden Route, includes more than sightseeing.

headline: Dusting Off the 2-Iron and Bracing for the Links
text: HOYLAKE, England — Players take great care setting the table for the British Open, a formal — and for many, foreign — event. For this one week, many will take out and polish off a club that, like a salad fork, is reserved for special occasions. It is the 2-iron, the nearest thing the golfers have in their bag to a repellent for the British links courses’ biggest pest, the pothole bunker.

headline: Game of Thorns
text: In 2011, when Jasmin Larian was 21 and a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, she started making silk floral crowns in her spare time for herself and her friends to wear out on the town. Her designs were modest — white and pink roses on a simple wire frame — but they sparked immediate reactions from strangers.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Agree, the C.D.C. Was Incredibly Sloppy
text: Republicans and Democrats in the strife-ridden House of Representatives miraculously found common ground at a hearing today. The subject: the sloppiness of researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in mishandling dangerous pathogens and sending them out to other laboratories without completely inactivating them. The universal response: dismay and incredulity.

headline: Refugee From Sitcom Land, Guzzling a Bile Cocktail
text: For seven seasons, the writer Mark Roberts served as an executive producer on “Two and a Half Men.” Apparently, this has made him angry. Dangerously angry. Batten-down-the-hatches, threat-level-red, oh-God-I-think-he-might-actually-stroke-out angry.

headline: Raising Stakes on Russia, U.S. Adds Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama imposed a new round of sanctions against Russia on Wednesday, targeting some of the crown jewels of the country’s financial, energy and defense industries in what officials described as the most punishing measures taken to date by the United States in retaliation for Moscow’s intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Sia Scores Her First No. 1 Album
text: Sia Furler, the Australian-born musician who writes monster hits for Rihanna and Beyoncé yet has had an uneasy relationship with fame in her solo career, has scored her first No. 1 album.

headline: And You Thought Your Teenage Years Were Tough
text: What a difference four years make. The summer of 2010 brought Michael Koryta’s “So Cold the River,” a long, spooky, overplotted book that featured haunted mineral water and a hotel that brought “The Shining” to mind. The summer of 2014 brings “Those Who Wish Me Dead,” a lean, propulsive action-adventure thriller with a raging forest fire as its backdrop and with much more finesse than that description might suggest. The ingenious tricks and conversational wit of “Those Who Wish Me Dead” don’t usually come with this territory.

headline: S.U.V.s and Crossovers Eclipse Sedans in Popularity
text: Americans don’t seem to like station wagons much, but their slightly trucklike counterparts — sport utility vehicles and crossovers — have swelled in popularity over the last few years.

headline: E.U. Meets to Consider More Sanctions on Russia
text: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders met here on Wednesday under pressure to strengthen their response to Russia after the latest spasm of violence in Ukraine and to overcome divisions about who should become the bloc’s next foreign policy chief.

headline: California Death Penalty System Is Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules
text: LA QUINTA, Calif. — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that California’s death penalty system is so arbitrary and plagued with delay that it is unconstitutional, a decision that is expected to inspire similar arguments in death penalty appeals around the country.

headline: Refusing to Quit, American Is Surrounded by Cheers After a Lonely Finish
text: OYONNAX, France — The American rider Andrew Talansky’s hopes of winning the Tour de France effectively vanished after two crashes last week. But he became another kind of cycling hero Wednesday: the rider who would not quit when he probably should have.

headline: Emergency Routine in Israel: 30 Seconds to Run for Cover
text: ASHKELON, Israel — The usual crowd had gathered behind the police cordons after a rocket struck the yard of a house in this seaside town in southern Israel on Wednesday: police officers, a bomb disposal squad, neighbors, municipal social workers, reporters and television crews.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Piece of My Heart’
text: A scene from the number “I Want Candy” from the musical “Piece of My Heart,” about the songwriter Bert Berns.

headline: Many-Hit Wonder, Out of Obscurity
text: Even in his mid-1960s heyday, Bert Berns was barely known beyond the obsessives who studied songwriters’ and producers’ credits on 45 r.p.m. records and LP album jackets. And then, after his death in 1967 at the age of 38, something truly odd happened: Though the songs he wrote and produced, like “Twist and Shout” and “Hang On Sloopy,” proved to have durability, growing in stature and popularity as the years passed, Berns’s own reputation receded even further into obscurity.

headline: The Lake Is Frozen in Time
text: Returning to New York after nine years, the Bolshoi Ballet — the most heroically warm-blooded of ballet companies — seems keen to prove that it has reverted to the ghastly artistic torpor it enjoyed in the last two decades of the Soviet era. For a short time this century (thanks principally to the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, who was for a few years its artistic director), this flagship company became an important center of new choreography and home to major revivals that changed Russia’s and the world’s view of dance history. But the three productions that it’s showing as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, all deriving from an earlier era, have been seen here before — a lot — and none of them are good.

headline: My Gigolo Is Waiting (He’s Much More Fun)
text: Looking at someone else’s marriage is a bit like hearing about someone else’s dream — unless something truly awful happened, it’s kind of a bore.

headline: Making Discreet House Calls for the Rich and Mortified
text: College students eager to study something that could actually secure them a job after graduation might consider majoring in fixing. Fixers — people who make the mistakes of rich and famous idiots go away — are popping up regularly on scripted television these days, which presumably means they’re in demand in real life as well.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: 3 Things to Know About Niacin and Heart Health
text: Recent studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine are adding to concerns about the safety and effectiveness of niacin, a popular drug for the prevention of cardiovascular disease. The studies reveal that although this B vitamin can reduce triglyceride levels, raise “good” cholesterol levels (HDL) and reduce “bad” cholesterol levels (LDL), it does not produce the benefits that patients and their doctors might expect. And the studies are revealing serious harms. Here are three things you need to know about niacin.

headline: Clad in Shorter Skirts, the Better to Let Loose
text: The final installment of the Lincoln Center Festival’s retrospective of early works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker began with something conspicuously absent from the preceding three pieces: a man.

headline: World Cup Withdrawal
text: WASHINGTON — If you are like me, you are suffering from post-World Cup depression.

headline: On the Trail of ‘True Grit’: A Tale Comes to Life
text: On a January night in Fort Smith, Ark., on a desolate block off the main drag of Garrison Avenue, I was having a nightcap of Knob Creek on the rocks at Doe’s Eat Place, after consuming two tamales with chili, a three-inch-thick eight-ounce filet and a couple of glasses of cabernet sauvignon. The motley collection of sports and historical memorabilia hanging on the walls cultivated a divey atmosphere consistent across Doe’s eight Southern locations.

headline: Easily Encrypt Your Email
text: Molly Wood explains how you can use several tools to encrypt your email and lock down your communications.

headline: Easier Ways to Protect Email From Unwanted Prying Eyes
text: IT’S time to face reality: Pursuing digital security should be as much of a no-brainer as locking your door before you leave the house.

headline: House Committee Debates Suing Obama
text: Members of the House Rules Committee discussed the merits of a lawsuit against President Obama over his use of executive powers.

headline: Bombs and Blood: Photographing Gaza
text: What has it been like to photograph the conflict in the Gaza Strip this past week? Tyler Hicks, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, has been there for The Times. On Wednesday he photographed the aftermath of the killing of four boys on a beach. We asked him about his experience since he arrived.

headline: Despite Security Breach, eBay Posts Profit and Sees Steady Growth
text: EBay on Wednesday showed slow but steady growth in the latest quarter despite a wide-ranging security breach.

headline: This Is the Best Anti-Superhero Movie of the Summer
text: Bong Joon-ho’s “Snowpiercer” takes place on a train carrying the survivors of a human-engineered disaster that has frozen the earth. While the poor are forced to cram into tight quarters and eat disgusting “protein blocks,” the rich eat sushi or sit knitting in an orange orchard. The setup has inspired comparisons to our pre-apocalyptic world — but just what “Snowpiercer” says about that world is a matter of some debate. (Be warned: Spoilers follow.)

headline: A Smartphone for Consumers Who Want Privacy
text: IF there’s a symbol for the idea that privacy is on people’s minds, it’s the Blackphone.

headline: Exit Roils Supporters of Women’s Theater
text: Julie Crosby’s abrupt departure as the producing artistic director of Women’s Project Theater has led most of its advisory board and several members of the board of directors to quit, saying that her exit endangers the 36-year-old theater.

headline: Hounded by Reality, Staging a Fairy Tale
text: The cast of “The Snow Queen” was rehearsing in a cramped Midtown studio, the floor littered with costume pieces, props and musical instruments, as staff members watched and took notes. “Oh, the journey is the end, and the end is the beginning,” the actors sang, ahead of their own beginning: the opening of their production, which runs through Sunday in the annual New York Musical Theater Festival.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Syria and Japan.

headline: Bessies Dance Prize Nominees Announced; Choreographers Honored
text: Nominations for one of the dance world’s most prestigious annual prizes, known formally as the New York Dance and Performance Awards, but better known as the Bessies (after the influential teacher Bessie Schonberg), were announced on Wednesday by the Bessies selection committee.

headline: Star Anchor’s Real Sin May Have Been Hypocrisy
text: The Chinese term for schadenfreude is xingzai lehuo (幸灾乐祸), and it does not take long for the sentiment to surface at the mention of Rui Chenggang, the smooth-talking state television anchor who was handed to prosecutors last Friday.

headline: A Different Aging in Place
text: I have a confession. I’m 47 years old, and I still live at home. Sort of; I do have my own apartment. But I still live in the house I was born into, a five-story Brooklyn Heights townhouse.

headline: Burt Shavitz, the World’s Most Famous Retired Beekeeper
text: In the new documentary “Burt’s Buzz,” Burt Shavitz, a founder of the cosmetics company Burt’s Bees, reveals himself to be the ultimate homebody.

headline: From Sow’s Ear to Silk Purse
text: Nathan Devine, the founder of Retrash.com, likes to point out that his new book, also called “Retrash,” is printed on 100-percent recycled paper. This is fitting: The illustrated, self-published book, which was financed through a crowdfunding site, celebrates the work of 82 artists and designers who use recycled materials. Like Jason Podlaski, who makes furniture from broken skateboard decks, and Gilles Eichenbaum, who turns teakettles into stunningly delicate lamps.

headline: Debt Shall Have No Dominion
text: Update: Douglas Elmendorf, director of the CBO, emails me to point out that there is (and it says so in the report) a tilt to nominal growth and interest rates, so that growth exceeds interest for the first decade but falls below it thereafter. This means that there is a bit of a debt spiral post 2025 or so. But it’s still nothing like the rhetoric.

headline: Old Friend, New Collections
text: No question, Buddy Warren’s first Manhattan antiques store, Cranberry Hole Road, was an original. It had a coffee bar downstairs and a place for Mr. Warren to conduct family therapy sessions upstairs. That boutique closed in 2004, but the psychologist-turned-interior-decorator-and-licensed-contractor is back with another retail adventure. His new self-named shop (left photo) sits in a 19th-century building on the Lower East Side that began life as a barn. About a third of the items are Mr. Warren’s own concoctions, like an iron cage table with a base sliced from an 18th-century marble column and a glass top ($950, seen in right photo). The rest ranges from cleansing bars made by a New Hampshire beekeeper ($6) to authentic Windsor chairs ($14,000 for a set of eight). Coffee is still served, but upstairs is now for workshops on themes like organization. 171 Chrystie Street (Rivington Street). Information: 212-727-8400 or buddywarren.com.

headline: Should I Replace My Mustard Toilet, Sink and Tub Before Listing the Apartment?
text: Q. The toilet, sink and tub in my bathroom are all a very retro shade of mustard. Should I replace them before putting my apartment on the market?

headline: All You Need Is Love and $189 a Night
text: For those who want to relive the Age of Aquarius, there is the Hotel Dylan, which opened last month in Woodstock, N.Y.

headline: Divide and Conquer
text: For apartment-bound New Yorkers who dream of discovering new rooms, Joel Klein, a builder in Brooklyn, offers them not by addition but by subtraction. His Tudelu wall, which glides up and down on motorized rollers, provides visual separation along with soundproofing “as good as any Sheetrock,” he said. The coated-vinyl surface is decorative, too, and can be customized with any motif: an ersatz library, say, or rural scene, portrait, supergraphic or solid color.

headline: The Internet of Things
text: David Rose, the author of ‘Enchanted Objects,’ sees a future where we can all live like wizards.

headline: Large Round of Layoffs Expected at Microsoft
text: Updated, 8:35 a.m. | Microsoft on Thursday announced it would cut up to 18,000 jobs, which amounts to almost 15 percent of its work force.

headline: Discounts at Kim Seybert, Ameico, Lalique and Patch NYC
text: Kim Seybert accessories are up to 65 percent off through Sunday (a set of four Indian Summer beaded place mats, originally $512, is about $282); 212-564-7850, kimseybert.com.

headline: Criminal Software, Government-Grade Protection
text: The arms race between criminal hackers and targeted companies just became a little more military, with serious implications for business.

headline: Working All the Angles
text: “How does this space become an event?” was the question Scott Bruckner posed to the architects he hired to remodel the 3,800-square-foot apartment he bought in a new building in TriBeCa in 2007, for $6.5 million. Mr. Bruckner, a financier who had spent much of his career working overseas and had returned to New York to join Perella Weinberg Partners, an international asset management firm, had been in the apartment for about a year. And while “it was big and airy and I liked the location,” he said, it was little more than a static white space.

headline: Putting Magic in the Mundane
text: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — David Rose was taking this reporter’s photo. Every 30 seconds, with a cracker-size plastic clip he wore on the placket of his short-sleeved blue plaid shirt.

headline: When Scientists Commit Fraud
For-Profit Colleges, Supported by Taxpayer Dollars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Life Lessons From Sports
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chip Martel Enters the Hall of Fame
text: LAS VEGAS — Two players were voted into the Hall of Fame this year by their peers: Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif. (Meyers was featured in Monday’s column.)

headline: A Father’s Grief
text: To the Editor:

headline: Buyouts for Tenants
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Role of University Trustees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stunts, Tricks and Effects (Boredom Not Allowed)
text: Pilobolus knows how to pack a lot into two hours. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, opening night of that company’s annual monthlong run there, the bang-for-your-buck variety included magic tricks, gymnastic stunts, large-scale shadow puppetry, stripteases and, just when you thought things couldn’t get more explosive, a short film of stuff blowing up (household items mostly, in slow motion, courtesy of the Danish TV show “Dumt & Farligt”). To ensure our sustained overstimulation — lest we feel bored (not allowed) — video interludes like that one filled the transitions between the five works on Program A.

headline: Rescuing a Landmark
text: To the Editor:

headline: And Then the Singer Dances in a Hooded Leopard Suit
text: The Cuban percussionist and singer Román Díaz spreads a strong, cool presence evenly through a room. When he’s a sideman, he makes the side fold into the center; when he’s the center, he radiates power without anxiety, letting the focus shift.

headline: The Dangers of Private Planes
text: SUMMER is the season when the pilots of private planes like to take to the skies. But summer flying often means thunderstorms and extreme changes in weather that can lead to accidents. It’s also a time to think about a system that doesn’t do all it can to protect those pilots and passengers. Flying in small private planes is far riskier than flying in commercial aircraft.

headline: Time Warner Chief on Murdoch’s Bid
text: Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief of Time Warner, confirms the rejection of 21st Century Fox’s $80 billion bid in a video sent to employees and posted online.

headline: On the Nice Internet, Caring Is Sharing
text: On a bright afternoon, Alex Magnin, chief revenue officer of the website Thought Catalog, strolled through Dolores Park in San Francisco, sipping a cup of green tea. Mr. Magnin, 29 and clad in a rumpled plaid shirt, was visiting from Brooklyn, where Thought Catalog is loosely based (most contributors work out of their homes), to connect with some of the site’s West Coast staff members.

headline: She Wears Her Feelings
text: Lining both sides of the Avenida Álvaro Obregón, a main artery in the Roma Norte neighborhood of Mexico City, are the remnants of a strong European influence — so strong that many of the old buildings survived the 1985 earthquake, while more-modern structures crumbled. Today, converted pastel-colored houses dating from the early 1900s contain restaurants, boutiques and popular mezcal bars. Camila Sarasola Montiel often wanders through the sculpture garden that divides the main avenue, drawing style inspiration from the mix of old and new. This interview has been edited. FRITZIE ANDRADE

headline: Funding Circle, a Peer-to-Peer Lender, Raises $65 Million
text: Silicon Valley has been working on new ways to bolster the flow of capital to small businesses, one of the nation’s main engines of economic growth. Those efforts took another step forward on Wednesday, when Funding Circle, a so-called peer-to-peer lending network, announced that it had raised $65 million in new funding and appointed Robert K. Steel, the chief executive of Perella Weinberg, to its board.

headline: The Mystery in the Machine
text: LOS ANGELES — During the six years I begged my husband to get me pregnant, I kept certain images locked away in a mental hope chest. The first was the moment of conception — one of those lazy Sunday afternoons, post-brunch and newspaper, pre-dinner and a compelling HBO lineup, the two of us resting atop rumpled sheets.

headline: Icahn and Ackman Publicly End Feud With an Embrace
text: A dispute between two billionaire investors, Carl C. Icahn and William A. Ackman, ended with a phone call a few weeks ago and, on Wednesday, a public embrace.

headline: The Scrunchie Grows Up
text: Last summer, Katalina Sharkey de Solis was watching the 1988 film “Heathers” with her friend Ruthie Friedlander when she had a fashion epiphany. In the movie, the scrunchie, so ubiquitous in the ’80s and early ’90s, was a sign of power. Ms. Sharkey de Solis, who is a managing director at an ad agency, was ready for the comeback.

headline: Sheltering Sky in Williamsburg
text: Yes, they exist: die-hard Manhattanites who still regard Brooklyn as a wasteland roamed by wolves. Their outpost could be Sheltering Sky, a month-old rooftop bar in Williamsburg named after Paul Bowles’s novel about a weary New Yorker who flees civilization for the Saharan wilderness.

headline: Obama Hints at Extension for Iran Nuclear Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Wednesday that there had been “real progress in several areas” in negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program, and he hinted that he might extend the talks beyond the deadline on Sunday in order to reach a final agreement.

headline: Music Holdings Are Noticeably Absent in Proposed Fox-Time Warner Merger
text: If the takeover of Time Warner by 21st Century Fox goes through, one company would hold sway over a vast array of media assets, including two Hollywood studios, multiple broadcast and cable television channels and properties like HBO. Yet should a merger happen, it would also be defined by what assets are under one umbrella.

headline: Lightly Worn, Heavily Shared
text: After Brenda Edmondson lost 50 pounds over the course of a year, she wanted to buy a new wardrobe. But first, she needed to get rid of her old clothes. “I decided I needed to purge my closet,” said Ms. Edmondson, 47, who lives in Brentwood, Tenn.

headline: Father and Son; Making Photos While Breaking the Rules
text: Jeff and Henry Jacobson, father and son who are both photographers, discuss their visual influences and making pictures on film and on Instagram.

headline: Reclaiming Our (Real) Lives From Social Media
text: One day in the early 1920s, a young Ernest Hemingway rushed along the streets of Paris seeking shelter from a downpour. He soon came upon a warm cafe on the Place St.-Michel and ducked inside.

headline: Sales and New Products in New York City
text: Sales

headline: Data Delayed Is Democracy Denied
text: WASHINGTON — BILLIONS of dollars are being spent in the run-up to this November’s midterm elections. The Supreme Court has struck down limits on campaign spending by corporations and unions, as well as overall caps on individual donations to candidates for federal office. More and more money is also being spent through ostensibly independent “super PACs” and nonprofit entities.

headline: Effort to Avoid Vote on Fracking Falters in Colorado
text: Efforts by leading Colorado Democrats to head off a costly and divisive election-year fight over oil and gas drilling appeared to crumble on Wednesday as Gov. John W. Hickenlooper announced that he did not have enough support to pass a compromise law giving local towns more control over fracking in their backyards.

headline: Tunisian Whom U.S. Accused of Plotting Terrorist Acts Is Sentenced to Time Served
text: A Tunisian man whom prosecutors had accused of seeking to “engage in terrorist acts against targets in the United States and other countries” was sentenced on Wednesday to the time he had served in prison since his arrest 15 months ago.

headline: Tears for the Border Children
text: The fight over how to process and care for masses of children from Central America who have crossed into this country is quickly becoming a spectacle of the obscene.

headline: The Cultures Along the Waterfront
text: A different crowd gravitates to each of three coastal spots in New York.

headline: President Obama on Russian Sanctions
text: At the White House, the president discussed his administration’s escalated sanctions against Russia.

headline: No Place Like Home
text: Summer in the city used to mean open fire hydrants, barbecues on fire escapes and those dreaded street fairs. Lounging by the water? You were lucky if you made it to the freak show called Coney Island once.

headline: New York City Summer Pop-Up Events
text: Whether it’s a temporary store or limited-run art, New York is awash in pop-up events. Here are our suggestions for the rest of the summer, but you can pick and choose as you like.

headline: Three Tips To Finding Social Media Balance
text: Social media starts out as something you check occasionally, but before long, it takes over your life. You stop reading books or sitting with yourself quietly. Instead, you check Facebook. Then check it again. And again.

headline: Casting the Catwalk, Saint Laurent Style
text: PAT CLEVELAND SKIPPED off to Paris in the early 1970s, intending to ditch her career. “I thought, I’m going to stop modeling,” Ms. Cleveland reminisced the other day. Her plans were derailed when, wearing a poncho and jeans, she encountered the designer Fernando Sanchez, who directed her glance toward a second-story window where his friend Yves Saint Laurent stood gazing at her avidly.

headline: Light Therapy for Home Use Catches On
