text: In January, Jill Addeo, 49, visited the Park Avenue office of Dr. Z. Paul Lorenc, a plastic surgeon, seeking to reduce her hyper-pigmentation and wrinkles from sun damage and aging.

headline: Jamie Biden: A D.J. Related to a V.P.
text: AGE 32

headline: Senate Expected to Focus on G.M. Lawyers’ Role
text: DETROIT — A Senate panel on Thursday will zero in on how General Motors hid a deadly vehicle defect for years, and what can be done to prevent corporations from keeping safety issues secret from consumers and regulators.

headline: Heineken Hopes Star Power Will Do the Trick
text: NEIL Patrick Harris is, as the saying goes, a man of many talents: actor, singer, comedian, awards show host and star of television, film and Broadway. For a campaign that is to begin on Thursday, it is his skills as a magician that may come in handy.

headline: What Standards of Child Labor Should Apply Overseas?
text: Should Western child labor standards apply in developing countries?

headline: Months After Washington Landslide, Hopeful Steps Forward
text: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The Miller family’s bluegrass band, Blueberry Hill, has deep roots in this little mountain town on the edge of the Oso landslide, which killed more than 40 people in late March in a few shattering seconds of geological upheaval. Aida Miller, 19, who sings and plays the mandolin, and her brother, Forrest, 17, a banjo player, were both born here.

headline: A Potential Combination of Two of Hollywood’s Most Successful Studios
text: LOS ANGELES — What for years has been a whisper in Hollywood — the possible consolidation of major studios in the face of tough industry economics — has become a starkly real option with the disclosure on Wednesday that Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox made an $80 billion bid to acquire Time Warner Inc.

headline: President Obama on Middle East Fighting
text: At an appearance at the White House, the president discussed the ongoing conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: C.D.C. Director Admits to Pattern of Unsafe Practices
text: Under sharp questioning from members of Congress on Wednesday, Dr. Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, admitted that recent laboratory accidents involving flu viruses and anthrax were not isolated mistakes, but rather part of a broader problem of unsafe practices at the agency.

headline: De Blasio Takes a Vacation, and a Calculated Risk
text: Vacations are not so simple when you happen to be the mayor of New York.

headline: In Pursuit of Bluefish on Venerable Party Boat
text: Plumb Beach, Brooklyn: Brawny and brutish, with teeth like stilettos, a bluefish on the line is bound to wake you from the lassitude brought on by even the most dolorous winter. This season, I looked on with mounting interest as the Internet ignited with reports of bluefish action.

headline: For Iraq, Debacle in Tikrit as Forces Walk Into Trap Set by Militants
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi troops and their militia and volunteer allies were on the verge of declaring victory over Sunni militants holding the strategic town of Tikrit and were about to hoist the Iraqi flag over key government buildings, when, a survivor recalled Wednesday, “the doors of hell opened.”

headline: Texas: Actress Gets 18-Year Sentence in Ricin Case
text: An actress was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for mailing ricin-laced letters in May 2013 to President Obama and former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York. The actress, Shannon Guess Richardson, 35, pleaded guilty to possession of a toxin for use as a weapon. Prosecutors said Ms. Richardson placed ricin onto letters sent to Mr. Obama, Mr. Bloomberg and Mark Glaze, at the time the director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns. Ms. Richardson, who played a zombie on “The Walking Dead,” among other small roles, had falsely accused her husband of mailing the letters.

headline: Through Lens, 4 Boys Dead by Gaza Shore
text: GAZA CITY — My day here began at 6 a.m. Photographing something as unpredictable as war still has a routine.

headline: Jeter’s Farewell Helps Reverse All-Star Game’s Ratings Slide
text: Derek Jeter’s mission on Tuesday night, whether he knew it or not, was to increase the audience for the All-Star Game, the last one he will play in.

headline: V.A. Official Says Fixing Issues at Root of Waiting-List Scandal Will Cost Billions
text: Fixing the problems that led to the waiting-list scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs will cost $17.6 billion over the next three years, the agency’s acting secretary told lawmakers Wednesday, requiring the hiring of about 1,500 doctors and 8,500 nurses and other clinicians.

headline: Obama Likely to Seek Additional Time for Nuclear Negotiations With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Wednesday that he believed the United States had “a credible way forward” in its nuclear negotiations with Iran, and strongly suggested that after consultations with Congress, which has been threatening additional sanctions, he would seek an extension of the talks beyond Sunday’s deadline.

headline: In Modern Media Realm, Big Mergers Are a Bulwark Against Rivals
text: When the news broke on Wednesday that 21st Century Fox, Rupert Murdoch’s huge media and entertainment company, made an $80 billion offer to buy Time Warner Inc., another big media conglomerate, it seemed like a seismic jolt in the business landscape. If the deal is ever consummated, 21st Century Fox, a public company in name only that the Murdoch family essentially controls, would oversee much of the content consumed by Americans.

headline: Leading Through Great Loss
text: In the carnage of Gaza and the Middle East, the most unlikely people have stepped forward from their grief to offer moral leadership.

headline: In a Potential Merger, Numerous Pieces
text: From sports and movies, to news and prime-time entertainment, there’s little a combined Time Warner and 21st Century Fox wouldn’t touch. Here, a look at what the divisions of each company contain.

headline: Shunting the Homeless From Sight
text: Is homelessness a crime? The question was answered forthrightly in the negative last month by a federal appeals court ruling that struck down a Los Angeles ban on citizens’ living out of their automobiles as a desperate necessity in hard times. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit pronounced the ban — an important part of the city’s anti-homelessness campaign — to be a “broad and cryptic” law that “criminalizes innocent behavior.”

headline: Affirmative Action Survives in Texas
text: For the second time since 2011, a federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the policy at the University of Texas at Austin to consider race as a factor in some of its admissions decisions. The ruling could well put the affirmative action issue back before the Supreme Court as soon as the coming term.

headline: Keep Negotiating on Iran’s Nukes
text: Despite six months of negotiations, it seems unlikely that Iran and the major powers will complete an agreement limiting Iran’s nuclear program by a self-imposed July 20 deadline. But they have left open the possibility of extending talks for up to six more months.

headline: A Symbol of City Hoops, and Now Globalization
text: The rain is tossing down monsoonal outside, but inside the gym in the South Bronx, I’m about to watch a glorious basketball heist.

headline: Bergdahl’s Lawyer Sees a Rare Case With Myriad Legal Options
text: SEATTLE — The legal road ahead for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, whose capture by the Taliban in Afghanistan in 2009 is under investigation by the Army, is both narrowly constrained by Army procedures and at the same time open to almost complete discretion in what course the Army might take, from exoneration to court-martial, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: International Coach Prepares for N.B.A. Debut
text: LAS VEGAS — J. R. Holden was furious with himself as he headed to the bench for a timeout. Here he was, late in the finals of EuroBasket 2007 — the tournament to determine the champion of Europe — and Holden, a naturalized Russian, was wondering if his citizenship might be revoked.

headline: Time Warner Chief’s Turnaround Effort Opened the Door to Fox’s Bid
text: On a Saturday in early June, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief executive of Time Warner, got an email from Chase Carey, the president of 21st Century Fox, proposing lunch.

headline: Political Duel for California Governor Spans Nation
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Gov. Jerry Brown has a little-known Republican challenger campaigning against him across California, taunting him on issues from taxes to transit. But his most formidable Republican adversary is turning out to be a fellow Californian who wields his power from an office 2,700 miles away: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the incoming House majority leader.

headline: Questions of Justice in Tunisia as Ousted Leaders Are Freed
text: TUNIS — Quietly, but with increasing confidence, some of the most powerful and hated figures of the government of ousted President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali have been returning home from prison, greeting friends and family in their large villas. Imprisoned in the months after the Arab Spring uprising, the former officials have been the beneficiaries of a shift in the balance of power in Tunisia since last summer and a growing leniency by the military tribunals trying them.

headline: Towns Fight to Avoid Taking In Migrant Minors
text: OYSTER CREEK, Tex. — A shelter for Central American children who crossed the border illegally opened behind Gregg Griffith’s house here a few months ago. The children are quiet. No one has hopped over the fence that separates his backyard from the shelter, a once-vacant youth home. But when Mr. Griffith looks at the brightly painted brick buildings, he is mostly resentful.

headline: For Sale, English Mountain and Title of Lord, $3 Million. (There’s a Catch.)
text: THRELKELD, England — There were none of the familiar real estate placards when Hugh Clayton Lowther, the eighth Earl of Lonsdale, resolved to sell a part of his family’s vast estate, one of England’s most distinctive and much clambered mountains, and offered to throw in the title that goes with it: Lord of the Manor of Threlkeld.

headline: Literal Clues, Literally
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Did this feel like a typical Thursday puzzle to you? I thought I would just throw that out there, because it didn’t to me, but then again “typical” might not be what we want in our New York Times crossword puzzle. One of the things we can expect is that we never know what to expect from the minds of Will Shortz and our constructors.

headline: Why Everyone Wants Time Warner
text: The media columnist David Carr on how the company pared down, grew profitable and could be primed for a major takeover.

headline: Justice Department Investigating Lost I.R.S. Emails
text: The Justice Department, which has been investigating the Internal Revenue Service’s scrutiny of conservative groups, said Wednesday it was also looking into how thousands of emails vanished. As part of that inquiry, F.B.I. forensic investigators will try to recover the emails, which belonged to Lois Lerner, the former I.R.S. official at the center of the investigation. The I.R.S. has said a computer crash in mid-2011 wiped out two years of Ms. Lerner’s emails. Law enforcement officials have said the F.B.I. does not believe that amounted to a crime, but Republicans in Congress have pressed for answers.

headline: Where Cockroach Legs and Snow White Have Something in Common
text: When Jon Cruz was 8, he flaunted a “Ross Perot for President” pin nearly every day at school. It was 1992, and Mr. Perot was running as an independent candidate.

headline: Consumers Appear Uncertain About Connected Cars
text: LONDON – Many of the world’s largest tech companies are pursuing the automotive sector as new area for growth.

headline: New York Inquiry on Boy, 14, in Stabbing Is Released
text: The mother of a 14-year-old boy accused of fatally stabbing a classmate last month may have sought to transfer him to another school to get away from students she said had been bullying him, according to a report released on Wednesday by the independent investigator for the New York City school system.

headline: High-Stakes L.I.R.R. Threat That Works Both Ways
text: Whenever labor unions threaten a strike, they are playing a game of chicken. And with the Long Island Rail Road’s unions threatening to walk off the job this Sunday, the game has unusually high stakes, potentially creating havoc for tens of thousands of commuters.

headline: What’s Worse Than the L.I.R.R.? Not Having It
text: The signature gesture of a Long Island Rail Road commuter is a shrug. It stands for crankiness, vexation and fatigue; it answers unannounced rain delays and torn seats. The shrug is often followed by a sigh, and inevitable submission to the vagaries of the twice-daily convoy.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 16, 2014
New Jersey Apartment Complex Is Sold, but a Dispute Continues
text: A court-ordered sale of an apartment complex in a middle-class New Jersey suburb that brought $136 million at auction late last week has done little to quell a two-decade battle between one of the state’s most prominent real estate families and its erstwhile partners.

headline: The Global Slowdown in Medical Costs
text: We tend to think of health care as a local good. Most people use the doctor or hospital in their neighborhood. China does not export medical care. Health and life spans differ from country to country, even county to county.

headline: New York State Board Approves Reduced $256 Million Loan for Tappan Zee Project
text: After a last-minute deal that cut the money requested in half, a key state board on Wednesday approved a $256 million loan from federal clean-water funds to the New York State Thruway Authority to help finance the building of a $3.9 billion twin-span replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: A Photo Travel Diary of Architectural Grids and Patterns
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: A Family Plot
text: As a gift one year, an eminently practical cousin presented my family with five funeral plots in a Cape Cod cemetery — sufficient for Mom and Dad, my two siblings and me. As Cousin Nina told my father, “they were cheaper by the dozen,” so she had purchased not five but 12, giving the rest to other cousins. I was 11 at the time.

headline: A Vasectomy May Increase Prostate Cancer Risk
text: Men with vasectomies may be at an increased risk for the most lethal form of prostate cancer, researchers have found. But aggressive cancer nonetheless remains rare in these patients.

headline: Let’s Cool It in the Bedroom
text: Sleep is essential for good health, as we all know. But a new study hints that there may be an easy but unrealized way to augment its virtues: lower the thermostat. Cooler bedrooms could subtly transform a person’s stores of brown fat — what has lately come to be thought of as “good fat” — and consequently alter energy expenditure and metabolic health, even into daylight hours.

headline: Word of the Day | comestible
text: comestible •\kə-ˈmes-tə-bəl\• adjective and noun

headline: Australia Scraps Tax on Carbon
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government on Thursday repealed laws requiring large companies to pay for carbon emissions, fulfilling a key election promise of Prime Minister Tony Abbott.

headline: A Treasure House of Yiddish Prepares to Close
text: Inside a small, one-room office on Broadway and 26th Street in Manhattan that is the headquarters of the 65-year-old Congress for Jewish Culture, the contents run from a unique collection of Yiddish secular writings to a goofy-looking plywood cannon.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 17, 2014
text: “I don’t feel like we have to solve the border crisis for a terrified child to be shown some compassion.”

headline: Corrections: July 17, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) KIDS’ CHOICE SPORTS 2014 Michael Strahan hosts this first-time awards ceremony, broadcast from Pauley Pavilion at the University of California, Los Angeles, and honoring young viewers’ favorite sports stars in categories including best male and female athletes, clutch player of the year, the don’t-try-this-at-home award, king and queen of swag, biggest cannon and superstar siblings. The tennis player Serena Williams, above, and Skylar Diggins of the W.N.B.A. lead the pack of nominees, which were determined by players’ Q scores (a ranking of those athletes most recognizable and well-liked by children) and by a Kids’ Choice Sports Council made up of sports experts. Carmelo Anthony, Tom Brady, Gabby Douglas, Dale Earnhardt Jr., LeBron James, Derek Jeter, Peyton Manning, David Ortiz, Danica Patrick and Tiger Woods are among the other nominees. Larry Fitzgerald of the Arizona Cardinals and Earl Thomas of the Seattle Seahawks will face off to see who can first hit a target that will dunk the other into a tank of goo — the show’s version of the Kids’ Choice Awards slime.

headline: Terror Group Back on the Offensive in Afghanistan
text: URGUN, Afghanistan — With two high-profile attacks in the past three days — first on Tuesday, when a huge truck bomb killed at least 72 at a market in this remote eastern district, then on Thursday, when suicide attackers fired volleys of grenades on the Kabul airport — the feared Haqqani militant network has gone back on the offensive, Afghan intelligence and security officials said Thursday.

headline: SherpaVentures Raises $154 Million for Debut Venture Capital Fund
text: Shervin Pishevar and Scott Stanford, two veteran financiers in Silicon Valley, have raised $154 million for the first fund of their new venture capital firm, with plans to back start-ups focused on consumer technology.

headline: Student Crossword | College Knowledge
text: Updated, 2:06 p.m. | An earlier edition of this puzzle was uploaded in error; the links below now lead to the correct PDF.

headline: Copter Crashes After Search for Korean Ferry Victims
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A fire department helicopter returning from a search for victims from the April ferry sinking that left hundreds of South Koreans dead crashed Thursday morning in the city of Gwangju, killing all five people on board.

headline: Putin Criticizes U.S. Over New Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — Responding to a new round of economic sanctions by the United States, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia lashed out late Wednesday against what he called America’s “aggressive foreign policy,” which he said had caused havoc in the Middle East, and accused the United States of pushing the Ukrainian government to continue fighting rather than encouraging peace.

headline: Israeli Military Invades Gaza, With Sights Set on Hamas Operations
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli tanks rolled into the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday night and naval gunboats pounded targets in the south as Israel began a ground invasion after 10 days of aerial bombardment failed to stop Palestinian militants from showering Israeli cities with rockets.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Rogue Sport Lacks Sand but Has Style and Speed
text: The questions below refer to the video “Chinatown’s Renegade Sport” and the related article “Rogue Sport Lacks Sand but Has Style and Speed.”

headline: Undermining China, One Knockout at a Time
text: Tensions between the United States and China over cybersecurity have risen as the two countries continue to trade barbs over hacking. But according to an essay on the website of a state newspaper that was widely republished this week, there is, in fact, a longer-running cyberwar underway between the United States and China. And the weapons employed, the essay argues, are far more sophisticated than hacking.

headline: Is Your Relationship With Fido on the Rocks?
text: Dr. Joel Gavriele-Gold is not a cat person. The walls of the 73-year-old psychologist’s Upper West Side office are decorated with paintings of dogs, including one of Rin Tin Tin. On the day of my visit, Gavriele-Gold’s enormous black herding dog, Dova, snored on a sofa by the garden-level window. Gavriele-Gold had encouraged me to bring along my Lab-mix, Casey, who lounged at my feet on the carpeted floor, occasionally getting up to sniff a bag of treats stashed behind a chair.

headline: Maria Bamford on Becoming Her Mother
text: The comedian jokes about O.C.D., psych wards, even suicide. Here, she discusses what’s so funny about her personal life — in particular, her mom.

headline: The Weird, Scary and Ingenious Brain of Maria Bamford
text: Maria Bamford has a mantra of sorts, and here it is: Do the work. Three words, three syllables. An easy, orderly thing. She tells it to herself when she wakes up in the morning, whether it’s at her bungalow in a middle-class neighborhood on the outskirts of Los Angeles or at a Holiday Inn in Boston or a Marriott in Bloomington, or any of the other highway-side hotels she hits for one night before moving on. Do the work. It’s a stay against paralysis, against the descent of dread. It’s less dramatic than “seize the day!” more affirming than “stop overthinking everything!” It is functional, and that’s what she’s trying to be. Do the work. She repeats it on airplanes, in taxis, on the long walks she takes to calm her nerves before a show. Sometimes she amends it to: Just do the work, the “just” a reminder that she’s not, after all, performing surgery on babies. There’s another, more refined version, too. Do your bits, she’ll tell herself, resigned to the idea that this may always be a struggle. Just do your bits.

headline: Father and Son; Making Photos While Breaking the Rules
text: Henry Jacobson is known for his impressionistic smartphone photographs collected in his recent book, “Postcards Home.” His father, Jeff Jacobson, has been pushing the visual boundaries of photojournalism in international magazines since the late 1970s. He was featured on Lens in 2010. His most recent book is “Jeff Jacobson: The Last Roll”.

headline: New York Today: A New Home for Very Old Things
text: Good morning on this strangely rainless Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: On the Road With Maria Bamford
text: I confess that, at first, I was a little nervous about interviewing the comedian Maria Bamford. She is a shy person, and so am I. On stage, she jokes about how hard it is for her to talk to strangers, how making eye contact or saying hello to someone in the grocery store can stress her out. She doesn’t generally court the media, either. After decades of struggling with depression and anxiety, and in particular after a period a few years ago during which she was hospitalized in psychiatric units three times, Bamford is careful about what she takes on.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy Stake in British Broadcaster ITV
text: LONDON — John C. Malone’s Liberty Global agreed on Thursday to buy a minority stake in the British broadcaster ITV, further expanding the international cable company’s reach into Europe.

headline: Germany Is Weltmeister
text: LONDON — A new nation won the World Cup. It was the first victory for a unified Germany, or a reunified Germany if you prefer. That country was more than a generation in the making. Germans do not believe in quick fixes.

headline: Our Dogs, Ourselves: Common Complaints From Dog Owners
text: As I traveled around the country in an R.V. with my dog, Casey, to research a book about dogs in contemporary American life, I learned that I wasn’t the only human with “dog issues.” According to therapists, trainers and pet psychics (or “animal communicators,” as they prefer to be called), we humans have a plethora of insecurities about our dogs. Here are three common complaints from dog owners, with comments:

headline: 1914: Decayed Teeth a Menace
text: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — That decayed teeth may be the cause of inflammatory rheumatism and heart, kidney and other diseases is a conclusion of the Scientific Foundation and Research Commission, presented to-night [July 8] in its report to the National Dental Association, which is in convention here. Experimentation with rabbits has shown that when injections of the virus of a tooth abscess are made they die within a few days, or upon being killed show heart muscles badly deteriorated, serious kidney troubles, joint diseases and arteries broken down. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 18, 1914

headline: Injured U.S. Rider Out as Race Nears the Alps
text: ST.-ÉTIENNE, France — The 115.5-mile stage through the vineyards of Beaujolais on Thursday was supposed to be an easy day before the Tour de France made its way to the Alps. But the rising and falling route on narrow and twisting roads, coupled with temperatures over 90 degrees, made it anything but a parade for many riders.

headline: Morning Views
text: “It seems unlikely that Iran and the major powers will complete an agreement limiting Iran’s nuclear program by a self-imposed July 20 deadline,” writes The New York Times editorial board. But all parties should extend the talks: “The whole point of this exercise is to ensure that Iran cannot produce a nuclear weapon. That goal is within reach.” In recent talks, Iran has shown flexibility on the main issue, “its future ability to enrich uranium that can be used to fuel nuclear power plants or, at higher levels of purity, nuclear bombs.” Its history of hiding its nuclear program has caused legitimate suspicions, and there are risks in any deal. “But there are many more if there is no deal — Iran’s program resumes unchecked and an opportunity to work with Iran on other regional challenges slips away.”

headline: Daily Report: Growth at PayPal Helps Lift eBay’s Profit
text: On Wednesday, eBay showed slow but steady growth in the latest quarter despite a wide-ranging security breach, Mike Isaac reports.

headline: Environmentalists Denounce Repeal of Australia’s Carbon Tax
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Opposition politicians and environmentalists in Australia reacted with dismay Thursday to the country’s repeal of laws requiring large companies to pay for carbon emissions, saying that it made Australia the first country to reverse progress on fighting climate change.

headline: Some Universities Crack Code in Drawing Women to Computer Science
text: One of the reasons so few women work in tech is that few choose to study computer science or engineering. Only 18 percent of computer science graduates in the United States are women, down from 37 percent in 1985.

headline: E.C.B. Sets Tight Deadline for Troubled Eurozone Banks
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank gave more details Thursday on what is shaping up as by far the most rigorous review of the health of eurozone banks. The bank will disclose the results in late October, and then troubled lenders will have only two weeks to come up with a plan to raise new capital.

headline: Morning Agenda: Murdoch Sets Sights on Time Warner
text: “If content is still king in a media business challenged by new technologies and nimble upstarts, Rupert Murdoch hungers to wear the crown,” Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. On Wednesday, Mr. Murdoch’s boldest bid yet emerged: an $80 billion takeover offer for Time Warner Inc., which would be the biggest media deal in more than a decade. Time Warner has rebuffed his offer and no talks are underway. But Mr. Murdoch is known for getting what he wants ‒ even when companies have first said no ‒ and people briefed on the matter said he is unlikely to walk away anytime soon.

headline: Blackstone Profit Soars on Performance Fees
text: Updated, 1:34 p.m. | At a heady time for the private equity industry, the Blackstone Group is raking in profit.

headline: Britain Urged to Live Up to Responsibilities in Hong Kong
text: “Time of Uncertainty Begins: Will Beijing Honor Vows?” read the headline on the front page of The New York Times on July 1, 1997, the day Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule. “Vows” refers to the terms China and Britain agreed to in 1984 on Hong Kong’s transfer, including a promise that Hong Kong would retain its civil liberties and capitalist way of life for 50 years after becoming “an inalienable part” of Communist-ruled China.

headline: Oops! Pushed the Wrong Button
text: The Internet, it has been said, is a series of tubes. So is the human body. The intersection of these two systems — each one sticky, nasty and fascinating in its own special way — is a fact of daily life and also the subject of “Sex Tape,” a new R-rated comedy starring Jason Segel and Cameron Diaz.

headline: Morgan Stanley Bolstered by Growth in Wealth Management
text: Updated, 7:55 p.m. | Since the financial crisis, Morgan Stanley has wrestled with erratic results in its powerful trading business, once its most lucrative unit, a situation familiar to its peers.

headline: Microsoft to Lay Off Thousands, Most From Nokia Unit
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft is trying to shake the effects of middle age.

headline: Public Problems, Private Dollars: Obama Seeks Infrastructure Repair Money
text: WASHINGTON — How can a president fix more roads and bridges without any new money to spend?

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Says It Will Cut Up to 18,000 Jobs
text: Microsoft announced today that it would eliminate up to 18,000 jobs over the next year as part of a major restructuring.

headline: The Strange, Revealing Case of Gerard Butler, Fragrance Model
text: Can we talk, for a moment, about Gerard Butler? You know, that beefy aging Scottish he-guy actor who tends to play boors who turn out to have hearts of gold in movies such as “The Bounty Hunter” (What? You didn’t see that one?) or super-bloody warriors in films like “300”? Well, he is the new face of Boss, the Hugo Boss men’s fragrance.

headline: Living Out of a Subway Locker
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Glamorous New Furniture Collaboration from Two L.A. Design Luminaries
text: President Obama sits behind a custom walnut desk of their design in his private study, and François-Henri Pinault and Salma Hayek’s Paris apartment is illuminated by their light boxes, but until now, the design partnership of Daniele Albright and Stefan Lawrence fell under the auspices of Twentieth, Lawrence’s contemporary furniture showroom in Los Angeles. Now, the longtime collaborators have launched Videre Licet (Latin for “to be able to see”), a new line of furniture and lighting, in conjunction with Twentieth’s sweeping new space on Beverly Boulevard. Designed using contemporary technologies but crafted entirely by hand — and priced accordingly, in the $20,000 range — the collection is daring, glamorous and a touch tongue-in-cheek, with sly references to Hollywood, modernism and the ’70s.

headline: Beard Foundation Presents Leadership Awards
text: Ben Burkett is still farming a parcel of land in Mississippi that his great-grandfather homesteaded in 1889, about two decades after slavery ended. He grows 16 vegetables, including okra and soybeans, on 320 acres, but he is also active in several organizations that promote local food production for local consumption.

headline: Report of Volkswagen-Fiat Merger Talks Is Denied
text: Updated, 10:13 a.m. | FRANKFURT – Fiat denied a report on Thursday that it was in merger talks with its German rival Volkswagen, deflating speculation that caused a brief furor on stock markets even though analysts dismissed a deal as implausible.

headline: Studies Say Obesity in China Is Second Only to the U.S.
text: For overweight middle class children, that means going to camp to get in better shape.

headline: What Recovery? Home Building Took a Dive in June
text: Remember when 2014 was going to be the year home building finally got out of the doldrums and accelerated back toward health — or at least to filling something closer to its usual role supporting growth? Yeah, never mind.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Strengthens Sanctions Against Russia
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington.

headline: L.I.R.R. Strike Is Averted After Cuomo Intervenes in Labor Talks
text: Travelers on the Long Island Rail Road were spared a debilitating midsummer strike on Thursday, when the railroad and its unions reached an agreement three days before a planned walkout.

headline: ‘Gone Girl’ to Open New York Film Festival
text: “Gone Girl,” David Fincher’s highly anticipated thriller starring Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike, will have its world premiere at this year’s New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced Thursday.

headline: Robert Stein, Who Led McCall’s and Redbook for Decades, Dies at 90
text: Robert Stein, who helped expand the scope of women’s magazines as editor in chief of McCall’s and Redbook in the early stages of the modern women’s movement, publishing articles about race and politics and introducing readers to the nascent writings of feminist leaders like Betty Friedan and Gloria Steinem, died on July 9 in Westport, Conn. He was 90.

headline: For a Struggling Actor, New Roles
text: Until you partly surrender to its underlying good will and sincerity, watching “Wish I Was Here” is like observing an experiment in a cinematic test kitchen. The perky chefs are seeking an ideal blend of familiar flavors and textures as they devise what they hope will turn out to be a new, improved recipe for that old standby, Thoughtful Comic Entertainment.

headline: Bill Hader: By the Book
text: The actor and comedian, a star of the forthcoming “The Skeleton Twins,” likes reading Dostoyevsky: “I didn’t really go to college, which is probably why I enjoy reading the classics.”

headline: At Hearing on G.M. Recall, Mary Barra Gives Little Ground
text: WASHINGTON — Only three months ago, Mary T. Barra arrived for the first time on Capitol Hill to apologize — publicly, profusely and personally — for General Motors’ long failure to recall millions of small cars.

headline: Understanding the Crank Epidemic
text: James Pethokoukis and Ramesh Ponnuru are frustrated. They’ve been trying to convert Republicans to market monetarism, but the right’s favorite intellectuals keep turning to cranks peddling conspiracy theories about inflation. Three years ago it was Niall Ferguson, citing a bogus source. Ferguson was widely ridiculed, by moderate conservatives as well as liberals — but here comes Amity Shlaes, making the same argument and citing the same source. The “reform conservatives” have made no headway at all.

headline: In Battered City, an All-Too-Brief Taste of Normal Life
text: GAZA CITY — Having piled his grocery cart with tuna cans, Kellogg’s Corn Flakes and Jell-O, Dr. Ayman Abdullah turned to the toy aisle and invited each of his three children to pick something – a reward, he said, for the nine days they spent indoors during the Israeli bombardment.

headline: U.S. Slips in FIFA Rankings Despite Its World Cup Effort
text: The exciting performance of the United States national men’s soccer team at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil failed to translate into gains in the latest world rankings released by FIFA on Thursday.

headline: Ukraine Says Russian Plane Shot Down Its Fighter Jet
text: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian government said on Thursday that a Russian military plane had shot down a Ukrainian fighter jet in Ukrainian airspace the previous evening, a serious allegation of direct intervention by Russia’s armed forces.

headline: Alibaba Said to Have Pushed Its I.P.O. Back to September
text: Updated, 7:39 p.m. | Since it first filed to go public two months ago, the Alibaba Group appeared to face few obstacles in its quest to go public.

headline: Wedded, but Not to Any Particular Place
text: In his eight years in New York, Mike Lee has moved a great deal — sharing rentals throughout Brooklyn and Queens with friends, roommates and siblings.

headline: The CPR We Don’t See on TV
text: The first time I saw a patient who had received CPR, the experience wasn’t what I expected.

headline: Today in Small Business: an App for Google AdWords Express
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Media Center Plans Mary Rodgers Tribute
text: What had been planned simply as the Paley Center for Media’s contribution to the New York Musical Theater Festival has become a tribute to the composer and author Mary Rodgers, who died at 83 on June 26. Ms. Rodgers was the daughter of one Broadway composer, Richard Rodgers, and the mother of another, Adam Guettel, but she wrote several musicals of her own, most notably “Once Upon a Mattress,” which was a hit when it opened on Broadway in 1959 and helped establish the young Carol Burnett as a star.

headline: Yes, I’m Direct. But You Should Be, Too.
text: This interview with Phil Fernandez, chief executive of Marketo, a maker of marketing automation software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: 10-Hour Clash in Pakistan Leaves 3 Dead
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A gunfight between members of the Pakistani security forces and two suspected militants erupted early Thursday about a mile away from the country estate of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, killing a policeman and the suspects, Pakistani officials said.

headline: Cruise Lines to End Smoking on Balconies
text: Cabin balconies are now off limits to smokers on two more cruise lines.

headline: Why Doesn’t the United States Have an Ambassador in Russia?
text: Even as Senate Republicans complain that President Obama doesn’t have a grip on foreign affairs, they are deliberately impeding basic diplomatic business by holding up ambassadorial appointments to several key countries, including Guatemala, Turkey, Russia and Niger.

headline: ‘An American in Paris’ Will Open on Broadway
text: “An American in Paris,” the new musical adaptation of the 1951 Gene Kelly film that wove a plot around George Gershwin’s orchestral work of the same name, will come to Broadway in the spring, the show’s producers announced on Thursday. Directed and choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon, the musical will begin previews at the Palace Theater on March 13, 2015, and will open on April 12.

headline: Two Fledgling L.A. Labels Share a Factory, and a Mission to Reinvent Casual Wear
text: Left coasters may have long since ceased to worry about being underdressed, but from a factory nestled under the 10 freeway in Los Angeles, two labels are reinventing what it can look like to be comfortable in your own clothes. “California is about the idea of adventure and freedom,” says the designer Kyle Ng, who grew up near Berkeley with a rock-climbing father who planted flags all over Yosemite. Ng’s men’s wear line AXS Folk Technology, which debuted two seasons ago, draws on the state’s pioneer spirit as well as the practical demands of communing with nature: “For me, the idea of quality comes from the sense that you can do anything in it,” Ng says, “that your clothes won’t break.”

headline: Murdoch May Be Heading for a Pyrrhic Victory
text: Rupert Murdoch may yet buy Time Warner, but it may be a Pyrrhic victory.

headline: How Environmentalism Can Help Stop Ebola
text: A relentless Ebola virus is sweeping through the West African countries of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, killing nearly 470 people to date, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Jetliner Explodes Over Ukraine; Struck by Missile, Officials Say
text: GRABOVO, Ukraine — A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 with 298 people aboard exploded, crashed and burned on a flowered wheat field Thursday in a part of eastern Ukraine controlled by pro-Russia separatists, blown out of the sky at 33,000 feet by what Ukrainian and American officials described as a Russian-made antiaircraft missile.

headline: Attack at the Kabul Airport
text: Taliban fighters attacked the Kabul international airport from a building that was under construction nearby. Afghan soldiers said that they shot two gunmen and that two others killed themselves.

headline: The Warming State of the Climate in 2013
text: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has released State of the Climate, 2013 — a useful compendium of trends and climate events last year. Visit climate.gov to click for the data on Arctic conditions, sea level change, severe storms and more. The report is also being published as a supplement to the July issue of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society.

headline: 1939: Actor Dies, but His Voice Lives On
text: Georges Dorival, oldest pensionnaire of the Théâtre Français and discoverer of Maurice Utrillo, the modernist painter, died yesterday [July 17] in his Boulevard Clichy home at the age of sixty-eight. But the voice of Georges Dorival will be heard by many hundreds of Parisians each day for many years. For he dictated phonograph records, which automatically announce the time of the day to the subscriber on dialing the Observatory. His voice also replies to the caller when there is change of number, announcing in measured tones, ‘‘Le numéro de votre correspondant est changée.’’— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 18, 1939

headline: A Fast Start and a Strong Comeback
text: HOYLAKE, England — Tiger Woods abruptly stopped during his downswing on his second shot, from the tall grass, at Royal Liverpool’s 18th hole. After it took him 10 holes to gain momentum, why did Woods violently brake on his swing with the end of his first round at a major in 11 months clearly in sight?

headline: Chrysler Accelerates Its Repairs of Jeeps
text: Responding to criticism from federal regulators that it is acting too slowly, Chrysler says it is accelerating production of a trailer hitch needed for the remedy of an already year-old recall of an estimated 1.6 million Jeeps for a fire hazard in rear-impact crashes.

headline: Inquiry Faults Assurances to Potential Terror Suspects in Ireland
text: LONDON — A government program to inform some potential terror suspects that they did not face arrest was “flawed” but was not an amnesty, according to a report published Thursday that highlighted some of the continuing dilemmas thrown up by Northern Ireland’s peace process.

headline: Ask Well | Is Your Sunscreen Safe?
text: Ask Well provides answers to the question of whether nanoparticles of titanium dioxide are safe in sunscreen.

headline: Unpublished Elmore Leonard Stories Coming in 2015
text: Elmore Leonard may have died last August, but readers now have a book of new stories by the wisecracking, adverb-murdering grand old man of crime fiction to look forward to.

headline: A Playwright’s Well-Traveled Valentine to Broadway
text: How could a musical collaboration between the beloved playwright Wendy Wasserstein and the “Sweet Charity” composer Cy Coleman simply sit in a drawer, yellowing with age? Could it finally have its premiere, 10 years after their deaths?

headline: A Cup of Tea Steeps Into a Movie Role
text: Wallace Shawn had dinner with André Gregory. Lisa Joyce had tea.

headline: 10 Questions for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey
text: Chris Christie has returned to the national spotlight in recent weeks, attending the National Governors Association meeting in Nashville, a media and technology gathering in Idaho, and making a campaign trip to Iowa. Mr. Christie, a New Jersey Republican and potential presidential candidate in 2016 who is recovering from political wounds caused by a lane-closure scandal, sat down with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC on Wednesday at CNBC’s Delivering Alpha conference in New York to discuss his party, his state’s pension shortfall, the bridge-closure controversy and his presidential prospects. What follows is a condensed, edited transcript of the conversation.

headline: A Tenacious Show Finds a New Stage
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, MASS. — Even by the standards of the long and winding development process for your average Broadway musical — in which books get overhauled, songwriting teams are replaced, and directors are given the ax — the journey of the Kander and Ebb show “The Visit,” adapted from Friedrich Dürrenmatt’s 1956 satire of greed and revenge, has seemed particularly tortuous and misfortune plagued.

headline: Aftermath of Deadly Gunfight in Pakistan
text: The attack outside of Lahore was about a mile from the country estate of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and lasted for several hours.

headline: Are More Companies Offering Health Insurance? For an Answer, Look to Massachusetts
text: For years, The Agenda has reported dueling predictions from economists and other pundits about whether businesses, especially small businesses, will stop offering health insurance rather than comply with the requirements of the Affordable Care Act. For an example, see Ezekiel J. Emanuel’s claim that by 2020, more than 80 percent of private-sector workers will buy their own insurance.

headline: New Guidelines Proposed
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo offers the first of several new proposals to strengthen ethics laws.

headline: Goodbye to Cloth Diapers, and Ideal Motherhood
text: I cloth diapered my daughter until she was 2, and she began using the toilet. And when I had my son, I was determined to continue. After all, I loved cloth diapering. I loved talking diapers with moms at the park and in forums online. I learned about washing strategies and making my own detergent and became fluent in diaper speak: soaker pads, Kushies, liners, Flips. And do you like AIOs or prefolds?

headline: ‘Not Open to Compromising’
text: Governor Cuomo says he will not accept a watered-down agreement on ethics.

headline: The Challenges of Empire
text: As a supplement to my last post, which ended by discussing some of the difficulties inherent in devising a point-by-point foreign policy agenda – difficulties that the horrific news from Ukraine throw into sharp relief – let me quote from a new essay from The American Conservative’s editor, Daniel McCarthy, on the subject of “liberalism and empire” and (he argues) the dependence of the former on the latter. The essay as a whole is an extended discussion of our current end-of-history era, engaged with some of the same questions as Mark Lilla, Steven Pinker, and other writers frequently discussed in this space. But its conclusion speaks directly to the moment’s foreign policy debates, offering critiques of both the anti-imperial left and the interventionist right, qualified sympathy for what McCarthy calls “anti-liberal anti-imperialists” (like his magazine’s founder, Pat Buchanan, and the late George Kennan, who are “among our greatest critics” but “preach what a liberal nation will not hear”), before coming around to a qualified endorsement of a “conservative realism” in the service of a liberal empire:

headline: Elaine Stritch, Broadway’s Enduring Dame, Dies at 89
text: Elaine Stritch, the brassy, tart-tongued Broadway actress and singer who became a living emblem of show business durability and perhaps the leading interpreter of Stephen Sondheim’s wryly acrid musings on aging, died on Thursday at her home in Birmingham, Mich. She was 89.

headline: The Red Carpet at the ESPYs
text: Cameron Diaz and Jessica Alba were among the best dressed at the award show.

headline: Shubert Organization Set To Add New World Stages
text: The Shubert Organization, a major Broadway player that owns 17 of the 40 theaters there, is positioning itself to move into the commercial Off Broadway sector in a significant way with the acquisition of the New World Stages complex, according to three theater executives with knowledge of the expected deal.

headline: Ask Well: Nanoparticles in Sunscreens
text: Question:

headline: An Edification Vacation
text: Before I turned left in Manhattan and drove some 420 miles to the Chautauqua Institution in the southwest corner of New York State, I asked a worldly and cultured New York City friend what she knew about the place. “It’s in Westchester,” she advised me, “but I think it’s pronounced Chappaqua.”

headline: Officials’ Security Details Bring Neighbors Peace of Mind and Headaches
text: WASHINGTON — Outside Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s Northwest Washington colonial and Secretary of State John Kerry’s historic Georgetown Federal, armed security guards wait with car engines humming.

headline: Small Packages Hold Great Pleasure
text: They sounded cute, brisket tots, and looked it, dark checkers of meat breaded and crisped, faintly ridiculous in their mini casserole dish. They made me laugh, and then I tasted one. It had the flavor of meat, rich and deep, but the near weightlessness of a doll’s pillow or a dandelion puff.

headline: July 17 Updates on Malaysia Airlines Plane Crash in Ukraine
text: The New York Times was tracking developments in the crash of a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 with 298 people aboard in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border on Thursday. Correspondents in Washington, Moscow and in eastern Ukraineprovided updates. Sabrina Tavernise (@stavernise on Twitter) reported from the crash site and Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) reported information gleaned from social media.

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for January 26, 2014

headline: Afghanistan Begins Audit of Presidential Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan election workers on Thursday began auditing the votes cast in last month’s presidential election runoff, monitored by American and United Nations observers.

headline: Remembering the Life and Work of Elaine Stritch
text: When health problems forced Elaine Stritch to leave New York in 2013 and head for her home state of Michigan, James Barron, writing in The New York Times, explained in one sentence what generations of fans loved about an actress who was as comfortable singing “Ladies Who Lunch” at the Cafe Carlyle as she was delivering a zinger in “A Delicate Balance.” “After a hard-driving, hard-drinking life,” wrote Mr. Barron, “Ms. Stritch is irascible and indomitable and, to theatergoers or cabaret devotees of a certain age or mind-set, irresistible.”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Pump Boys and Dinettes’
text: A scene from the number “Highway 57” from the Encores! Off Center production of “Pump Boys and Dinettes.”

headline: Young’uns With a Yen for Wisdom
text: A little strip of lonesome highway has plopped down at City Center, where a flavorsome revival of the chicken-fried musical revue “Pump Boys and Dinettes” plays through Saturday as part of the Encores! Off-Center series. Should you pull off the road for a fill-up, a Coke and a piece of pie, you’ll find amiable company in the show’s beaming cast members, who make like a big old human jukebox as they sing of the daily grind in a gas station (the pump boys) and the roadside coffee shop nearby (the dinettes).

headline: For-Profit Colleges Under Investigation
text: It seemed until recently that regulators and law enforcement agencies would never rein in the predatory for-profit colleges that enrich themselves and their shareholders by misrepresenting their programs, saddling students with high-cost loans and then shoving them out the door with useless degrees or no degrees at all. The situation began to change in 2011, when a group of state attorneys general led by Jack Conway of Kentucky joined forces to investigate a growing number of complaints from students who had been exploited. With so much happening at the state level — 36 attorneys general are now involved — federal agencies had no choice but to take notice.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks Delay in Case Against Rengan Rajaratnam
text: Acquitted of insider trading, the former hedge fund manager Rengan Rajaratnam may now avoid a separate court battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Oh, Mama! That Queen of Denmark Takes Over
text: Hamlet is indecisive. His mother, however, is a lot more resolute. In the first scene of Howard Barker’s “Gertrude: The Cry,” the American premiere of this 2002 play by PTP/NYC at Atlantic Stage 2, she orders Claudius to “kill my husband.” Then she strips naked and demands sex from him astride her husband’s corpse.

headline: Playgrounds for Kids Who Can’t Run and Jump
text: The first time I buckled Ruth in a swing she was 18 months old, but looked younger from the emaciating effects of cerebral palsy. Born in Uganda and quickly abandoned, she had spent much of her first year in an orphanage, which sent her to Maine for six months of physical therapy. Friends signed up to host her.

headline: Amateur Video of Malaysia Airlines Crash
text: After a Malaysia Airlines jet crashed in Ukraine on Thursday, several amateur videos were posted online.

headline: Markets of the Once ‘Fragile Five’ Countries Are Now Soaring
text: The Fragile Five have become the Fantastic Five.

headline: Russian Reliance on Chinese Loans May Blunt the Impact of U.S. Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — With the latest round of sanctions against Russia, the United States Treasury Department said it had “increased the cost of economic isolation for key Russian firms,” like the state oil company Rosneft and the banking arm of the natural gas giant Gazprom.

headline: M.T.A. Chairman on the Averted Strike
text: Thomas F. Prendergast, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, on the agreement reached with Long Island Rail Road labor unions to avert a potential strike.

headline: Flaws in How Mississippi Reports Elections Add to Its Problems
text: Amid the allegations of fraud and the legal wranglings over the Mississippi Republican primary and runoff elections last month, one thing is clear: The lack of timely, useful election results has not helped assure citizens the election was fair.

headline: With Surge in Child Migrants, New York Forms Task Force on Aiding Them
text: New York City officials have formed a task force in response to the surging population of unaccompanied migrant children from Central America who have arrived in the city in recent months and swamped community-based groups in search of help for their deportation cases, health issues, school enrollment and other urgent needs.

headline: President Obama on the Crash in Ukraine
text: At an event in Delaware, President Obama discussed the crash of a Malaysia Airlines jet, calling it a “terrible tragedy.”

headline: At a Football Powerhouse, Her Teams Rolled, Too
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The women’s gymnastics coach at Alabama, Sarah Patterson, used to run into Pat Summitt, the storied former women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, at Southeastern Conference events.

headline: New York Proposes First State Regulations for Bitcoin
text: New York State’s top financial regulator has taken a big step to bring Bitcoin and other virtual currencies under its purview.

headline: Finnish Pride Takes Another Blow From Microsoft Job Cuts
text: Finland has staked much of its national pride on the worldwide growth of Nokia, based on the outskirts of Helsinki. And many Finns still hold a lot of affection for the company’s handsets.

headline: Regulators Come Up With Own Plan to Coordinate Bank Supervision
text: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Maps of the Crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17
text: A Malaysia Airlines flight with nearly 300 people aboard crashed in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border on July 17.

headline: The Woman
text: Clare Boothe Luce has a lot to answer for.

headline: Should Republicans Do Anything About the Border Crisis?
text: I haven’t commented on the border situation since my column a few weeks ago, mostly because it’s the kind of situation (there are so many these days) where it’s easier to say what should have been done in the past than to figure out what the correct policy course is right now. But as House Republicans debate what kind of legislative response they intend to support, I want to say something briefly about the argument that they shouldn’t back any response at all, on the theory that since the president has already claimed sweeping, dubiously-legal powers over spending flows and immigration enforcement, fixing the mess should be his responsibility alone.

headline: The String of ‘Safest Airline Years’ Is Over
text: The year 2012 was the safest since World War II for air travel, and 2013 was even better. Because of the two Malaysian Airlines crashes — including the airline that went down Thursday over Ukraine — this year will not be the safest on record. But it is less of an outlier than many might expect.

headline: James Franco, Poet
text: If you were alive in 1985 and happened to buy Eddie Murphy’s album “How Could It Be” (featuring the hit single “Party All the Time”), then you may have asked yourself — in addition to wondering what shape of Band-Aid is best suited to the human ear — why it is that artists who are vastly successful in one genre feel the need to dabble in another. Because they do, a lot. Sometimes it’s just the case that they happen to be very good at more than one thing (by all accounts, Steve Martin is a genuinely excellent banjo player). But often there seems to be something else going on.

headline: Scientists Name a Newly Discovered Water Mite After Jennifer Lopez
text: Scientists who discover new things – from microorganisms to galaxies – get to name them, and often they name them after public figures, usually ones they admire. Arnold Schwarzenegger has a muscular-looking beetle named after him; there are trilobites (an extinct, prehistoric arthropod) named for Mick Jagger and each of the Sex Pistols; and Frank Zappa has at least five animals named for him, including a jellyfish and a spider.

headline: Malaysia Airlines Flight: History's Lessons in Crisis Management
text: On Oct. 27, 1962, at the zenith of the Cuban missile crisis, President Kennedy learned that an American U-2 spy plane had unintentionally penetrated Soviet air space near Alaska, drawing a complaint from the Soviets. He was concerned that the Soviet leader, Nikita Khrushchev, or those around him, might view the incursion as the deliberate forerunner of a full-scale United States invasion of his territory, which could lead quickly to nuclear war. He persuaded them that it was an accident. Of the American pilot, Kennedy bitterly said, “There is always some son of a bitch who doesn’t get the word.”

headline: AbbVie-Shire Deal Is Expected, in a Flight to a Lower-Tax Locale
text: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | The biggest deal of the year is set to be announced on Friday morning, as the pharmaceutical giant AbbVie plans to announce a $53 billion acquisition of Shire, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Four Way Books
text: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Martha Rhodes, the director of Four Way Books.

headline: By the Bees on My Chinny Chin Chin
text: Beauty is in the eye of the bee-holder. At least, that’s the case in Aylmer, Ontario, on July 25, when Clovermead Apiaries hosts its 10th annual Worldwide Bee Beard Competition. The event brings together teams of insect aficionados who strut their stuff on a catwalk — while covered in thousands of confused bees — in a contest for charity to crown the queen (or king) of bee beards.

headline: At Berl’s Brooklyn Poetry Shop, Balm for the Borrower
text: Poetry may be a noble vocation, but poets are generally an impecunious lot. Resigned to significantly less than blockbuster sales and often saddled with student loans, they’re on intimate terms with arrears. A handful of them will gather Friday night at Berl’s Brooklyn Poetry Shop for “Write Off Debt,” a reading that revolves around the concept. Organized by Ashleigh Lambert and featuring her fellow poets Max Cohen, Dustin Luke Nelson, Allyson Paty, Niina Pollari, Christopher Salerno and Emily Toder, the evening aims to imagine fresh approaches to debt.

headline: 7 Indicted in $50 Million Pump-and-Dump Scheme
text: The former husband of “The Sopranos” actress Jamie-Lynn Sigler was indicted on Thursday along with six other defendants in a pump-and-dump stock scheme.

headline: D.C. Decriminalizes Marijuana: Pot Politics Buds Along the Potomac
text: A marijuana decriminalization law took effect in the District of Columbia at 12:01 Thursday morning, but House Republicans are trying to turn back the clock.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Disneyland Opens in 1955
text: We’re experimenting with a new weekly feature we’re calling “Throwback Thursday” (or #tbt, as it is known on social media).

headline: Glorious Views, Fancy Steps and Painful Memories
text: Like all performers at the Fire Island Dance Festival, Marcelo Gomes was awed by his surroundings when he participated for the first time in 2010. The sun, looking like a burning tangerine, descended behind him as he danced, before extinguishing itself in the bay.

headline: For a Smooth Ride, Look Someplace Else
text: WAITING in line to see the Kara Walker exhibition in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, not long ago, I noticed an off-road cycling course across the street, where numerous children in helmets were zipping around. It looked like fun, so I returned on a recent sunny afternoon for what I thought would be a light two-wheeled frolic.

headline: A Duke’s Gilded Haven, Recreated in Paris
text: PARIS — Sections of 18th-century gilded walls and paintings of deities are sprawled across the floor of a warehouse on this city’s outskirts. After nine decades in limbo, this architectural salvage is being reorganized  into period rooms that will rival Versailles’s for inventiveness and visual impact.

headline: A New Book Explores the Art of Plants
text: From Monet’s “Water Lilies” to Andy Warhol’s “Flowers,” plants have been a perennial subject of interest for artists. “Strange Plants,” the first title from the new L.A.-based art book publisher Zioxla, is a celebration of this ongoing relationship. A mix of in-depth interviews with photography, paintings and sculpture from established and emerging artists, the tome ($30, available online today) explores the roles that plants play both in the creative process and in artists’ personal lives.

headline: Fallen Bodies, Jet Parts and a Child’s Pink Book
text: GRABOVO, Ukraine — Incongruously, given that the plane fell from more than 30,000 feet, many of the bodies strewn about in the smoldering wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 were largely intact. A woman in a black sweater lay on her back, blood streaming from her face, her left arm raised as if signaling someone. Another victim, naked except for a black bra, lay on the field, her gray hair mixing with the green grass, one leg broken and her body torn.

headline: Using a Camera to Make More Than Memories
text: When an art show reaches the end of its run, it usually goes gently into the archives. Lately, however, a number of exhibitions from the 1960s and ’70s have been coming back to haunt us.

headline: To Kill a Friendship
text: “Why does the writing make us chase the writer?” Julian Barnes asked in “Flaubert’s Parrot.” “Why can’t we leave well enough alone? Why aren’t the books enough?”

headline: Cuomo on Avoiding Rail Strike
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York discusses an agreement that averted a Long Island Rail Road strike.

headline: Warming Times in a Cold Land
text: Attention, moviegoers interested in aging who thought “The Iron Lady” was too depressing, “Nebraska” was too depressing, and “Amour” was off-the-charts depressing. I’ve got a tip for you: “Land Ho!”

headline: Wheelies: The Mustang Numbers Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Call to Fight Malaria One Mosquito at a Time by Altering DNA
text: Every year, malaria-carrying mosquitoes kill more than 600,000 people, most of them children. Over the centuries, people have battled those mosquitoes in numerous ways, like draining swamps, spraying insecticides and distributing millions of bed nets. And yet malaria remains a menace across much of the world.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: This Weekend: Bolshoi’s ‘Swan Lake’
text: This weekend the Bolshoi Ballet brings “Swan Lake” to Lincoln Center; “The Long Shrift,” directed by James Franco, plays Off Broadway; and WE’s new legal drama, “The Divide,” is on TV.

headline: Hito Steyerl: ‘How Not to Be Seen’
text: Beginning with an unprintable adjective, the subtitle of Hito Steyerl’s latest New York show identifies it as a “Didactic Educational Installation.” But don’t be misled. The show confirms that Ms. Steyerl (pronounced STYE-rill) is among the most rigorous yet playful artist-filmmakers today, and unusually skilled at working her mediums and messages into an experience of form that is anything but didactic.

headline: IBM in Tug of War Between Legacy and the Leading Edge
text: For IBM, the challenge is to convert the future of technology into an opportunity rather than a threat.

headline: The Morgan Gets a Gift: A Lichtenstein Trove
text: Scholars tend to seek out the Morgan Library & Museum’s archives as a place to research old masters and 19th-century drawings, or to peek at the letters that modern masters like Chagall and Dubuffet wrote to the art dealer Pierre Matisse. But a recent gift from the Roy Lichtenstein estate will now make the Morgan a destination for classic contemporary artists, too.

headline: Events on Long Island for July 20-26, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Justice Department Indicts FedEx in a Drug-Shipping Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — FedEx, the world’s second-largest package-delivery company, was indicted Thursday in connection with a Justice Department investigation into illegal pharmaceutical shipments, according to a person with knowledge of the government’s long-running investigation.

headline: The Two Faces of Soave
text: It’s no longer news that Italy makes great white wines. In the bad old days, the Italian whites available in the United States tended to be insipid mass-marketed brands or campy contrived bottles. But since then, a revival has introduced the world to wonderful selections from the Valle d’Aoste at the farthest reaches of Italy’s northwest, from Alto Adige and Friuli-Venezia Giulia in the extreme northeast, from Sicily at the southernmost end, and from just about everywhere in between.

headline: What to Eat With Italian Soave
text: When I was quite small, I remember my mother telling me that if you put salt on your watermelon, it would taste sweeter. I never quite bought that theory — the salt made it weird to me. I still do not salt my watermelon. But I do like something that comes close: a savory, salty component that I have found does complement melon quite nicely. This was brought home to me on many occasions, traveling in Greece, Jordan, Israel and elsewhere in the Middle East, where watermelon and feta or a similar salty white cheese is often on the breakfast buffet.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Gaza City, Ukraine and Afghanistan.

headline: ‘A Machinery for Living’
text: A good artist-organized show functions a bit like a master class, an artwork and a tour of the artist’s library or record collection. This exhibition, organized by the photographer Walead Beshty, does all of these well.

headline: Mickalene Thomas: ‘Tête de Femme’
text: With their asymmetrical eyes, sequin-adorned cheekbones and swipes of bright lipstick, the subjects of Mickalene Thomas’s new collage-paintings could be Picasso’s “Demoiselles” glammed up for a night at Studio 54.

headline: Robert De Niro Sr.: ‘Paintings and Drawings, 1948-1989’
text: Thanks to the promotional efforts of his son, the actor Robert De Niro, the painter Robert De Niro Sr. (1922-93) is getting some well-deserved posthumous attention. A documentary in which the son talks movingly about his father was on HBO recently. This beautiful exhibition presents works from five decades.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: The Writers’ Retreat
text: A tour of the aspiration tower, the brainstorm rotunda and other hot spots.

headline: Google’s Quarterly Results Show Its Continuing Struggle With Mobile Advertising
text: In the court of Internet advertising, sometimes it’s hard to be the king.

headline: Letters: The Confederate Dead
text: The Confederate Dead

headline: Behind the Escalations in Gaza
text: A look at why Israel and Hamas have repeatedly chosen to intensify the violence at every stage of the continuing conflict.

headline: Pay Your Taxes, Kill the Neighbors
text: Kill or be killed isn’t the official tag line of “The Purge: Anarchy,” but it fits. It would also make a more suitable title for this satisfyingly creepy, blunt, down-and-dirty thriller, one of those follow-ups that improves on the original. Once again, it’s a new morning in future America, and crime is still down, as is unemployment. The only thing that appears to be keeping the peace and assuring prosperity is the government-sanctioned annual bloodletting, that one night a year in which the citizenry can run amok without punishment. The word anarchy is purely superfluous.

headline: Back to the Future: Another High-Tech Twist on Tap-Dancing
text: BECKET, Mass. — In the 1989 film “Tap,” the old-timer character played by Sammy Davis Jr. has an idea for how to save tap-dancing, how to make it contemporary and popular again. The idea is to hook up tap-dancers to synthesizers. As realized in the film, the great dancer Gregory Hines taps, and in place of the nuanced music of his feet come 1980s video game noises. It’s ridiculous, especially since the real future of tap was present in the film, in the form of the teenage Savion Glover.

headline: Palestinian Youth Who Was Abducted and Killed Struggled to Stay Alive, Indictment Says
text: JERUSALEM — In the moments before he was kidnapped at dawn on July 2, Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, suddenly sensed that there was something suspicious about the two casually dressed Jewish teenagers who were asking him directions. He tried to move away and call a friend, then shouted and struggled as the two youths forced him into a waiting car driven by an adult relative, according to court documents released on Thursday.

headline: Single-Family Homes as Rentals
text: Bulk purchases of single-family homes by hedge funds and private-equity firms have been the focus of media attention over the last few years, but individual investors are also showing interest in the market, albeit with less vigor as home prices rise.

headline: Concussions in Sports: The N.C.A.A.’s View
Drunk Self-Indulgence as the Stuff of Drama
text: Good luck trying to criticize Derek Ahonen’s “The Qualification of Douglas Evans,” produced by the Amoralists. Mr. Ahonen, who stars as the titular Douglas, has already beaten you to the punch, and it’s a killer combination. Here’s a character reviewing Douglas’s first play: “You wrote a masturbatory play about your stupid relationship with some stupid girl and then you stupidly starred in it and were equally as bad at playing yourself as you were at writing about yourself.”

headline: This Procedure May Improve Your Brain — and Uncover the Real You
text: People are fascinated by the idea of enhancing themselves — by, say, 10,000 hours of practice or drugs to improve cognitive performance. Now a noninvasive, 20-minute procedure called transcranial direct-current stimulation, or tDCS, may be able to help us learn a language faster, increase our alertness and curb food cravings. It has been shown to help hasten stroke rehabilitation, ameliorate chronic pain and treat even major depressive disorders.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Clare Boothe Luce
text: This week, Sylvia Jukes Morris talks about “Price of Fame”; John Williams and Parul Sehgal talk about the week’s literary news; David Lehman discusses the state of poetry in the age of Twitter; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Far From Home, an Arab Summer
text: Most of our New York museums give us gussied-up versions of what we already know. The New Museum was created almost 35 years ago to do the opposite, to give us art we barely knew existed. With “Here and Elsewhere,” it thrillingly fulfills that mandate.

headline: Daimler Announces Details for 2016 Smart Fortwo and the Forfour
text: Daimler released details in Berlin on Wednesday about its redesigned Smart Fortwo and Smart Forfour city cars. The automaker says the next-generation models, while still diminutive, include a number of improvements. The two models were developed in partnership with Renault.

headline: Where Fancy Took Flight
text: The Four Horsemen of the Glass Tower Apocalypse have passed judgment on West 57th Street, and that is that the little buildings shall be scythed to the ground, and in their places shall rise magnificent glass temples. The street’s quirky little shops have all but disappeared.

text: Amid the hundreds of tips on illegal guns that flow into the New York Police Department each year, there was something wrong with Tip No. 7590.

headline: Now It’s Really Meg Whitman’s H.P.
text: Meg Whitman has added chairwoman to her business card.

headline: Q. and A.: Bill Porter on Journeys, Poets and Best-Sellerdom in China
text: For more than 30 years, Bill Porter has been one of the most prolific translators of Chinese texts, while also developing into a travel writer with a cult following. Under the pen name Red Pine, the 70-year-old resident of Port Townsend, Wash., has translated over a dozen books of poetry and religious texts, including collections of poems by Hanshan and Song Boren, the Daoist classic Dao De Jing and numerous Buddhist sutras. Under his own name, he has also published travel works like “Zen Baggage: A Pilgrimage to China” and “Road to Heaven: Encounters With Chinese Hermits.”

headline: Inventive, Cheaper Tools for Learning a Language
text: To learn a new language travelers often turn to time-tested solutions like Rosetta Stone, Pimsleur or actual classes with native speakers. Yet a number of new, creative and often more affordable tools are aiming to help you rattle off “table for two” and “how much does this cost?” in no time.

headline: On the Road, Finding Savings on Your Phone
text: Let’s assume you’re already a savvy user of travel apps that save you money on the road. You know Gas Buddy can tell you whether the gas station just up the road is cheaper than the one you’re currently passing, and you would never exchange currency without checking the current market exchange rate on Oanda’s Currency app. You don’t pay for text messages to new friends abroad or family back home in the States, thanks to WhatsApp, Heywire and their kin. (For more guidance to travel apps, read past New York Times coverage here, here, here and here.)

headline: A Garden Divine: Beware of Snake
text: It’s one of the greatest stories ever told, the Bible’s tale of God, Adam, Eve and the Serpent in the Garden of Eden, as related in Genesis 2:4 to 3:24. Derived from Babylonian mythology, it circulated in Jewish oral tradition before being written down in the 10th century B.C. It’s not long: In English translation, it amounts to fewer than 1,300 words. Despite its brevity and antiquity, it remains as resonant today as ever.

headline: Mike Cahill Narrates a Scene From ‘I Origins’
text: In this video, the writer and director Mike Cahill narrates a sequence from his film “I Origins,” featuring Michael Pitt as a molecular biologist. Here, Mr. Cahill discusses how he uses the camera to build the tension of the sequence, including what he calls a “double vertigo” shot, similar to a shot Alfred Hitchcock used in “Vertigo,” but with a twist.

headline: Recitals That Linger, a Festival That May Not
text: On most days of the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, a popular annual venture sponsored by Mannes College the New School for Music, there are two piano recitals each evening. So it was on Wednesday, the third full day of the festival. For the early-evening Prestige series, which mostly presents exceptional younger artists, the award-winning 32-year-old German pianist Alexander Schimpf played a varied program culminating with Beethoven’s mighty “Hammerklavier” Sonata. Later that evening, the Israeli pianist Alon Goldstein, admired for the refinement and imaginativeness of his performances, played a formidable program on the Masters series. The recitals were presented at the intimate concert hall of the Mannes College building on the Upper West Side, which seats just 275.

text: For Twitter and Facebook, the two principal combatants in the world of social media, e-commerce is emerging as the newest battleground.

headline: The Consummate Performer, With Love Songs to the Audience
text: It’s common to describe a talent as singular, one of a kind or larger than life. And yet those words seem strictly accurate, albeit a bit flimsy, when applied to Elaine Stritch.

headline: Apple Adds Susan Wagner of BlackRock to Board
text: Apple announced Thursday that it had elected Susan L. Wagner, a founder of the investment firm BlackRock, to its board. The longest-serving board member, Bill Campbell, is retiring, the company said.
