text: Workshops at the Morris-Jumel Mansion

headline: Staring at the Flame
text: I reckon I spent five hours at most in Philip Seymour Hoffman’s close company, six at a pinch. Otherwise it was standing around with other people on the set of “A Most Wanted Man,” watching him on the monitor and afterward telling him he was great, or deciding better to keep your thoughts to yourself. I didn’t even do a lot of that: a couple of visits to the set, one silly walk-on part that required me to grow a disgusting beard, took all day and delivered a smudgy picture of somebody I was grateful not to recognize. There’s probably nobody more redundant in the film world than a writer of origin hanging around the set of his movie, as I’ve learned to my cost. Alec Guinness actually did me the favor of having me shown off the set of the BBC’s TV adaptation of “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy.” All I was wanting to do was radiate my admiration, but Alec said my glare was too intense.

headline: Spare Times for July 18-24
text: Museums and Sites

headline: As Boy Woos Girl, Whimsy Is in the Picture
text: Does Michel Gondry dream of being a toymaker, a watchmaker or the master of his own private circus? That certainly seems likely, given the ingenious contraptions, live-action and animated, that motor and hum through his latest, “Mood Indigo.” Nominally a romance about a boy and a girl, the movie is more rightly a feature-length expression of Mr. Gondry’s love of whirring, purring creations, including the doorbell that scuttles like a large ring-a-ding insect and the upright piano that whips up cocktails and the mouse that makes mischief and the mechanical cloud that sails over Paris and, and, and. ...

headline: Airline Will Not Escape Liability if Act of War Caused Crash
text: Although money cannot replace a lost life, wrongful death law requires Malaysia Airlines to pay compensation for any passenger who is killed in a crash of one of its flights, even if caused by an act of war.

headline: How the West Chose War in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — AS Hamas fires rockets at Israeli cities and Israel follows up its extensive airstrikes with a ground operation in the Gaza Strip, the most immediate cause of this latest war has been ignored: Israel and much of the international community placed a prohibitive set of obstacles in the way of the Palestinian “national consensus” government that was formed in early June.

headline: Making the Spiritually Skeptical Believe, and the Blind Worms See
text: The eyes are windows to the soul. That fuzzy bit of wisdom is repeated several times, with both reverence and skepticism, in “I Origins,” Mike Cahill’s new film. Whatever that may mean, there’s no doubt that eyes are also the portals through which movies, good and bad, enter our consciousness. Considered strictly as a visual experience, this one, which might be described as a faith-based emo-science romance-thriller, is often quite beguiling.

headline: U.S. Raises Threat of Quake but Lowers Risk for Towers
text: Here is another reason to buy a mega-million-dollar apartment in a Manhattan high-rise: Earthquake forecast maps for New York City that a federal agency issued on Thursday indicate “a slightly lower hazard for tall buildings than previously thought.”

headline: Australia Tax Repeal Is Big Blow to Fight Against Emissions
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s repeal of laws requiring large companies to pay for carbon emissions is among the starkest expressions worldwide of how economic concerns have complicated efforts to combat climate change.

headline: Far From Scandal at Home, Christie Basks in Limelight on Iowa Trip
text: MARION, Iowa — The unspoken rules of prepresidential politics, not to mention the diplomacy of navigating a scandal, required Chris Christie to avoid any suggestion that his swing through Iowa on Thursday involved his own White House ambitions.

headline: The Agony of Israel and Gaza
Stand by Your Man
text: My boyfriend’s weight fluctuates. He is now down 30 pounds after cutting out certain foods from his diet. The problem is, I get comments from friends like, “Wow, he looks so much better than when you met him!” The worst was from my sister, on seeing his new Facebook photo: “It’s like he’s actually hot now!” These people are not hurling blatant insults, but their backhanded comments sting. How do I respond?

headline: Loudie App Uses Video to List Concerts
text: Loudie, a concert-discovery app developed and based in New York, allows users to quickly check in on coming shows in the city. But unlike the listings page in The Village Voice (for which I sometimes review concerts), or email blasts sent out by promoters like Live Nation, Loudie doesn’t get bogged down with names and dates. Instead, it uses video aggregated from Instagram to provide a look at artists’ recent performances.

headline: A Family Gathers, and So Does the Dysfunction
text: AMONG RAVENS

headline: Intercepted Audio of Ukraine Separatists
text: Ukraine released what it said was audio from phone calls between rebels and Russian officers after the downing of Malaysia Airlines 17. In one call, a rebel says, “We have just shot down a plane.”

headline: Replaying the Past, to a New Soundtrack
text: One of the things old people do is visit other old people in hospitals. It sounds dreary, and it is dreary, but it has its benefits. If you can learn to read the gauges and dials, you will, next time you are a patient, be able to find out how close to death you are (nobody else will tell you) by keeping an eye on your vitals: blood pressure, ejection fraction. And you can secretly rejoice that it’s not you in the bed. Not yet.

headline: Citigroup’s Settlement, Pro and Con
text: The punishment did not fit the crime, or at least it did not fit the crime that was charged.

headline: Clean Power, Off the Grid
text: STANFORD, Calif. — AFTER years of hype, renewable energy has gone mainstream in much of the United States and, increasingly, around the world.

headline: Vladimir Putin Can Stop This War
text: Growing casualties on the ground, a major escalation of American sanctions against Russia, a military plane shot down and now the appalling destruction of a Malaysian jetliner with 298 people on board, shot by a surface-to-air missile. The Ukrainian conflict has gone on far too long, and it has become far too dangerous.

headline: Mercedes Looks for Up-and-Comers on LinkedIn
text: WHAT defines native advertising, a trendy marketing term for paid content, is that it does not look like advertising because it adopts the appearance of online editorial content. Native advertising in article form — usually labeled advertisements, but still confusing to some readers — is common in publications like The Atlantic and The New Yorker, while on BuzzFeed such ads take the form of sponsored posts.

headline: Duet for Directors, in a Conversational Key
text: DOUBLE PLAY

headline: With a Retirement, an Institution of Higher Education Is Ending
text: When Sam Monroe steps down next month as president of Lamar State College-Port Arthur, a two-year school in Southeast Texas, he will conclude the state’s longest tenure for a president of a higher education institution.

headline: Austin’s Black Population Leaving City, Report Says
text: When Natalie Madeira Cofield walks among the local boutiques and cafes in her South Congress Avenue neighborhood in Austin, she likes to take note of the other African-Americans she sees.

headline: Scenes From the Malaysia Jet Crash Site
text: A Malaysia Airlines plane carrying 298 passengers and crew members crashed in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, and American officials said it was most likely shot down by an antiaircraft missile.

text: The New York Times film critics review “Sex Tape,” “Wish I Was Here” and “Mood Indigo.”

headline: At the RoadHouse, the Clam Pie Draws the A-List
text: Staten Island has its share of famous pizzerias — the kind that Manhattan foodies will visit on weekends, the type that are regular stops on tourist bus tours. The RoadHouse isn’t one of them.

headline: India Aims to Make Forlorn City a Model for Revival
text: VARANASI, India — The big question on many minds here is: How long will the electricity last?

headline: A Fruity Italian Blend, Redolent of Fresh Air and Rehabilitation
text: GORGONA, Italy — The inmates of the penal colony on Gorgona, the northernmost island in the Tuscan archipelago, are not normally allowed to drink alcohol. But prison officials made an exception on a recent sultry summer day, when detainees and guards clinked glasses to celebrate the 2013 vintage of a wine named in its honor.

headline: Lost in a Pressing Crisis: Perpetual Immigration Issues
text: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — After reports in March of three undocumented Honduran migrants being assaulted by a Border Patrol agent, who was later found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot, immigration activists decided to form a group to determine whether migrants were being routinely abused.

headline: Fire Flight
text: PLANES

headline: Addicted to Inflation
text: The first step toward recovery is admitting that you have a problem. That goes for political movements as well as individuals. So I have some advice for so-called reform conservatives trying to rebuild the intellectual vitality of the right: You need to start by facing up to the fact that your movement is in the grip of some uncontrollable urges. In particular, it’s addicted to inflation — not the thing itself, but the claim that runaway inflation is either happening or about to happen.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: After All-Star Break, Nearly Everything (and Every Team) Is in Play
text: Before now, the last time baseball paused at midseason for a trip to Minneapolis was 1985. Summer rolled along, and when the American League regular-season schedule ended, the Toronto Blue Jays and the Kansas City Royals were on top.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Protester Is Out of Jail, but Back in Court
text: She was a cause célèbre of the Occupy Wall Street movement, first when she was arrested for striking a police officer during a protest at Zuccotti Park in Manhattan in 2012, and then for her conviction on a felony assault charge as a result of that incident.

headline: It’s All Over, but the Dying
text: AFTERMATH

headline: After Two-Year Fight, Consumer Agency Orders Recall of Buckyballs
text: After a two-year fight to get Buckyballs off the market, the Consumer Product Safety Commission put a formal recall of the toy into effect.

headline: Abramson Discusses Exit From the Times With Media
text: Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, gave a series of interviews to the news media this week, the first time she has answered direct questions about her abrupt dismissal in May.

headline: TerraForm Power, Operator of Solar Plants, Prices I.P.O. at Top of Range
text: TerraForm Power, an arm of the solar power company SunEdison that operates over 200 solar power projects in the Americas, said on Thursday that it had priced its initial public offering at $25 a share, the top end of an already raised price range.

headline: From Gaza, an Array of Makeshift Rockets Packs a Counterpunch
text: JERUSALEM — The rockets are smuggled via ship and tunnel from Iran, Libya, Sudan and Syria and, increasingly, manufactured from water pipes and household items in what a senior Israeli intelligence officer called Gaza’s “high-tech” sector — about 70 makeshift factories staffed by 250 men and overseen by a few dozen engineers and chemists.

headline: Long on Travel, but Short on Satisfaction
text: A FIVE STAR LIFE

headline: 2 in Florida Said to Catch Fever Found in Tropics
text: Doctors have been warning that Chikungunya fever, a tropical disease that causes severe joint pain, would soon reach the continental United States. Now it has done so, federal and state officials said Thursday.

headline: Egypt Cuts Tax Breaks for Fuel; Few Protest
text: CAIRO — When President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said he intended to raise the price of flour, rice and other subsidized goods in 1977, he ignited days of riots that left more than 70 people dead and stood as a lasting warning to his successors about the perils of forcing impoverished Egyptians to make do with even less.

headline: Three Fathers Make an Impression
text: FANNY

headline: Holding Peacekeepers Responsible
text: Does making peacekeepers liable for the murder of citizens in their care set a tough standard of conduct, or undermine cooperation?

headline: Hitting the Ground Running
text: Sarah Johnson is the director of Weill Music Institute, Carnegie Hall’s education and community engagement enterprise, which has a staff of 25, a budget of $10 million and a reach of 450,000 people in New York and around the world. Among other duties, she oversees the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America, for musicians ages 16 to 19 who come to Purchase, N.Y., from all over the country for a two-week training residency. The ensemble’s eight-city 2014 tour opens at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College on July 20 and at Carnegie Hall on July 22. Ms. Johnson, 38, lives in a Park Slope brownstone with her cat, Caterina, and spends Sundays catching up with her boyfriend, Danyon Davis, 39, an actor, director and teacher, who lives nearby.

headline: A Long and Winding History of Gaming
text: VIDEO GAMES

headline: Air Disaster Strains Moscow’s Competing Strategy on Ukrainian Rebels
text: MOSCOW — The double game that the Kremlin has been accused of playing in eastern Ukraine for weeks — publicly endorsing peace talks while surreptitiously supporting the separatists with arms and men — suddenly appeared less crafty than possibly disastrous on Thursday after the crash of a civilian jetliner in a Ukrainian field.

headline: Germany: American Spy Chief Leaves
text: The United States’ top spy in Germany has left the country, the American Embassy in Berlin said Thursday, a week after the German government demanded that the C.I.A.’s Berlin station chief leave. Two recent spy cases have strained German relations with the United States: one relating to the arrest of a German intelligence officer who claimed to have passed intelligence documents to the United States, and the other to a report that the United States had recruited a spy in the Defense Ministry. Chancellor Angela Merkel has stressed the “far-reaching differences of opinion” between the countries over the extent to which intelligence gathering is acceptable.

headline: Color Wars Tinged by Surreal Hysteria
text: K MISSING KINGS

headline: Amid All the Diamonds, a Bed Would Be Nice
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — It is the shoes that first strike visitors to Lynden Restrepo and Bob Aspenleiter’s home here. They cover the sizable front porch, foreshadowing the chaos inside.

headline: They’re Out to Get Him, Whoever They Are
text: PERSECUTED

headline: Shot Strikes Fan, and Els Staggers to a 79
text: HOYLAKE, England — Ernie Els’s 24th British Open got off to a nightmarish start when his opening tee shot struck a spectator in the jaw. The shot, which Els described as a bullet, veered far left of the fairway and opened a gash in the man’s face that left Els visibly shakened.

headline: Brutality in New York City Jails
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new correction commissioner, Joseph Ponte, inherited a city jail system that has a long and bloody history of allowing corrections officers to batter and brutalize inmates. Mr. Ponte, who took over in April, has promised to curtail the use of excessive force and improve care for the mentally ill, who make up about 40 percent of the jail population and who are disproportionately singled out for abuse. But it will not be easy to fulfill those promises, given a culture that encourages corrections officers to commit acts of violence and that makes it easy for them to cover up those deeds.

headline: At Nursing Homes, Medicine That’s Heard
text: ALIVE INSIDE

headline: Senate Approves Insurance Extension
text: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a seven-year extension of the federal insurance program first approved after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, when developers suddenly found their projects uninsurable. The legislation is especially important in large cities like New York, where many sites are considered terrorist targets, and even in small cities with large-scale developments like stadiums. Republicans in the House, which has not yet voted on the measure, have demanded changes that would scale back the Senate bill.

headline: Fox Challenges ESPN With Pursuit of Time Warner
text: Rupert Murdoch loves nothing more than taking on an entrenched powerhouse, and with his audacious $80 billion bid to purchase Time Warner, he showed a willingness to go up against one of the industry’s most powerful players — ESPN.

headline: Lawmakers Press Christie Aide on Her Texting About Lane Closings in Bridge Scandal
text: TRENTON — Four hours in, an offhand statement on Thursday woke up what had been a sleepy legislative hearing into the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge. Gov. Chris Christie’s designated future chief of staff, Regina Egea, testified that she texted the governor about the lane closings in December, after testimony in a hearing that day disputed his administration’s assertion that the closings were part of a traffic study. But she said she deleted the texts.

headline: Girl With the Boombox Tattoo
text: To look at the Raiders of Concrete, a mostly male street dance crew, one might not figure Carolynn Clarke to be the group’s leader.

headline: $25 Penalties for Marijuana Go Into Effect in the Capital
text: WASHINGTON — One of the least restrictive marijuana laws in the country went into effect in the shadow of the White House on Thursday, eliciting stern warnings from the local police but good cheer from many Washingtonians.

headline: Holding Church Shepherds Accountable
text: When Pope Francis met earlier this month with victims of rape and sexual abuse by priests, he vowed to hold bishops accountable for covering up the scandal instead of confronting it.

headline: Tragedy on Top of Crisis May Strengthen Stand Against Russia in U.S. and Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The downing of a commercial Boeing 777 in the Ukrainian war zone on Thursday inflamed an already volatile international crisis and may bolster President Obama’s efforts to isolate Russia if evidence points to complicity by Moscow’s separatist allies.

headline: Without Much Straining, Minnesota Reins In Its Utilities’ Carbon Emissions
text: MINNEAPOLIS — When city leaders and state legislators agreed last year to fund roughly half the $1 billion cost of a new stadium for the Minnesota Vikings, they attached the usual strings for such projects: It had to be architecturally iconic, employ steel made from Minnesota iron ore and offer at least a few cheap seats.

headline: And They’re Off, to Horse Racing’s Version of Summer Camp
text: Not many text messages bring a smile in the dog days of summer, but one I received a few weeks ago not only prompted a grin, but a shiver as well: “The MALICE left Belmont for summer camp today, when do you go?”

headline: A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Burst
text: David Cronenberg’s “Scanners” was designed to blow minds. It did so, literally, when one telekinetic telepath used his powers to make another telepath’s head explode — in close-up. That shot, notable in an era of gross-out special effects marked by eruptive alien parasites and dramatic lycanthropic transformations (and originally placed in the movie’s opening scene), made the reputation of Mr. Cronenberg, the Canadian director, who was then 37. “Scanners” opened at the top of Variety’s box-office chart in January 1981.

headline: When Poverty Makes You Sick, a Lawyer Can Be the Cure
text: By early summer 2010, the temperature had already reached 100 degrees in Cincinnati. At Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, doctors were urging the families of children with asthma to use air-conditioning. One mother handed a piece of paper to her doctor: The child’s room did have a window unit, and she was using it. But then the landlord responded — he apparently didn’t want to pay the electric bills. Use that air-conditioner, the letter said, and you will be evicted.

headline: Raining? There Is a Gimlet for That at Claudette
text: The rains last week imposed their own rhythms on the city, especially during that fungible slice of time known as the dinner hour. Hungry foragers rushed out en masse during breaks in the weather, then loitered over checks when the rain picked up again. It was too tropical to eat anything substantial, too raw and wet to graze on sprouts. So what to do?

headline: In Close-Knit South Dakota, Mudslinging Carries Political Risk
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. — There is a game that politicians like to play with voters in this sparsely populated state. It starts with a question — What town are you from? — and ends when they find a mutual friend.

headline: The Hudson River Runs Through Them
text: Even in his cursory shipboard log, Henry Hudson’s first mate marveled in 1609 at the mountains and abundant flora and fauna nourished by the river that would eventually be named for his captain. Nearly four centuries later, Congress would call the Hudson River Valley “the landscape that defined America,” a landscape captured by 19th-century painters of the Hudson River School with what Vernon Benjamin, in his newly published history  of the region, describes as “the sense of fear and awe of the sublime.”

Commissioner Roger Goodell said Thursday that the league was considering moving the draft to Chicago or Los Angeles in 2015. Radio City Music Hall, the site of the draft for many years, is booked April 22-25 and April 29-May 2, the two windows the N.F.L. has for hosting the event, which may be expanded to include a fourth day next year.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Showtime) LEE DANIELS’ THE BUTLER (2013) Inspired by the real story of Eugene Allen, Mr. Daniels follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (Forest Whitaker, above), and his wife, Gloria (Oprah Winfrey), as history — particularly the civil rights movement — unfolds over seven presidential administrations in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called “a brilliantly truthful movie on a subject that is usually shrouded in wishful thinking, mythmongering and outright denial.” Robin Williams portrays Dwight D. Eisenhower; Liev Schreiber is Lyndon B. Johnson; and Alan Rickman is Ronald Reagan, with Jane Fonda as his wife, Nancy; Cuba Gooding Jr. and Lenny Kravitz are the fellow butlers who become Cecil’s close friends; and David Oyelowo is the older son whose politics Cecil eschews. “In part, their story is a chronicle of the generational misunderstanding that has occurred in upwardly mobile families of every background, especially in the baby boom era, when educated and restless young people turned against the parents who had sacrificed so much on their behalf,” Mr. Scott wrote. “ ‘The Butler’ has the historical insight and the generosity of spirit to honor the father and the son equally, and to look with skepticism at each’s point of view.” He added: “We remember those who marched and who stood up for themselves in the face of injustice. It is good to remember that, to paraphrase Milton, they also stand who only wait and serve.”

headline: In a Musical Pairing, Old Hands Guide a New Face

It was an acrobatic move; once on his knees, Mr. Lambert bent back until he was nearly horizontal. It was also, as a show of fealty, a preview of the rest of the concert.

headline: 1939: London and Warsaw Skeptical
text: LONDON — There were ample indications today [July 18] that both British and Polish official quarters continue to be highly skeptical of Berlin reports that Adolf Hitler is now prepared to seek a peaceful solution of the Danzig issue on the basis of terms which could be considered by Warsaw. Almost as if these reports had not been broadcast Poland issued today a new warning to the Fuehrer. A semiofficial communiqué issued in Warsaw read: ‘‘Quite apart from the manner in which Germany may desire to incorporate Danzig in the Reich, Polish political quarters declare that the very fact of such an incorporation would constitute an inadmissible violation of the present political and juridical state of affairs and would evoke the appropriate response.’’ This response, if previous Polish declarations are to be trusted, would be in the form of the use of force by Warsaw to restore the status quo ante in the Free City. In a declaration in the House of Commons at the beginning of last week Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain made it clear that should Warsaw determine to resist an attempted change from within or without in the status of Danzig, Britain, backed by France, would come to its aid. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1939

headline: Morning Agenda: AbbVie Wins Deal for Shire
text: ABBVIE CLINCHES $54 BILLION DEAL FOR SHIRE | The pharmaceutical giant AbbVie agreed on Friday to buy the Irish drug maker Shire for around $54 billion, the biggest takeover deal so far this year, Mark Scott writes in DealBook. The deal will allow AbbVie, based outside Chicago, to reincorporate in Britain and reduce its tax bill, representing the largest ever inversion as United States companies rush to pursue the financial advantages of moving overseas, even as lawmakers move to crack down on the increasingly popular maneuver.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The Ukrainian conflict has gone on far too long, and it has become far too dangerous,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “There is one man who can stop it — President Vladimir Putin of Russia, by telling the Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine to end their insurgency and by stopping the flow of money and heavy weaponry to those groups.” It will take some time to establish who shot down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, but “however it happened, it is the worst catastrophe of an increasingly costly and brutal conflict that could and should have ended long ago.”

headline: A Fresh Look at Iron, Plankton, Carbon, Salmon and Ocean Engineering
text: Two years ago this month, an edge-pushing environmental entrepreneur and a company formed by a Native Canadian village set off a wave of international protest by dispersing a pink slurry of 100 tons of iron-rich dust over one of the 60-mile-wide ocean eddies that routinely drift across the salmon feeding grounds of the Gulf of Alaska.

headline: A Palace of Wonders
text: VARESE, Italy — The Lombardy region of northern Italy is known for its many “villas of delight” — the “ville di delizia” that aristocratic Milanese families built in the 17th and 18th centuries as summer escapes and settings for lavish entertainments. Varese, in the foothills of the Alps, was a magnet for these estates, several of which are clustered on the parklike hill of Biumo Superiore. At its crest sits the Villa Menafoglio Litta Panza, the most storied, thanks to its longtime owner, Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, the Milanese businessman whose adventurous tastes and ardent appetites made him one of the most important art collectors of the last century.

headline: G.E. Results Reflect Shift Away From Finance Unit
text: General Electric reported second-quarter results on Friday that reflected its steady return to its industrial roots, as the giant conglomerate looks to accelerate the shift.

He will replace Bertrand Stalla-Bourdillon, who will be “reassigned” within the group. In turn, Mr. Suhl’s job at Givenchy will be taken by Philippe Fortunato, latterly of Louis Vuitton. Oh, the tangled webs these executives weave!

headline: A Japanese Artist Launches Plants Into Space
text: “Flowers aren’t just beautiful to show on tables,” said Makoto Azuma, a 38-year-old artist based in Tokyo. His latest installation piece, if you could call it that, takes this statement to the extreme. Two botanical objects — “Shiki 1,” a Japanese white pine bonsai suspended from a metal frame, and an untitled arrangement of orchids, hydrangeas, lilies and irises, among other blossoms — were launched into the stratosphere on Tuesday in Black Rock Desert outside Gerlach, Nevada, a site made famous for its hosting of the annual Burning Man festival. “I wanted to see the movement and beauty of plants and flowers suspended in space,” Azuma explained that morning.

headline: Stir-Fries With a Touch of Thai
text: I love my summer stir-fry weeks. The list of ingredients sometimes looks daunting, but think of the effort required to put a stir-fry together as family time. Start the rice, pour yourself a glass of wine, put others to work measuring and chopping, and visit while you prep. Once your mise en place is ready, have the others set the table while you make the stir-fry in under 10 minutes. You barely heat up the kitchen.

text: Onstage at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, Ally Sheedy listened from a cheap wooden chair as her director, James Franco, leaned against the set’s kitchen counter and gave her some feedback. It was a Tuesday afternoon, and the cast of Robert Boswell’s “The Long Shrift” had just finished its second preview: an unusual time for a performance at this scruffy walk-up theater in Greenwich Village, but so it goes when the movie-star director is also acting on Broadway in “Of Mice and Men.”

headline: Who Made That Scotch Tape?
text: The particulars are hard to pin down, but everyone seems to agree that Scotch tape, the now-famous brand, originated as a slur. Back in the ’20s, Scotch was a synonym for “cheap.” Richard Drew, a 23-year-old research assistant at Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, was trying to create a sticky-but-not-too-sticky adhesive tape for auto painters to use on two-tone paint jobs. When he erred on the not-too-sticky side, one of the car-painters asked, “Why so Scotch with the adhesive?” and a brand name was born.

headline: Forbes Media to Sell Majority Stake to Hong Kong Investors
text: Updated, 7:36 p.m. | Forbes Media, publisher of the magazine that is perhaps the most famous chronicler and evangelist for American-style capitalism, agreed on Friday to sell a majority stake in itself to a consortium of Asian investors, concluding a protracted sales process in which a number of prospective bidders dropped out.

headline: The Limits of the Law in Insider Trading
text: The remarkable winning streak of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, came to an end a little over a week ago when Rengan Rajaratnam, the younger brother of the convicted hedge fund operator Raj Rajaratnam, was acquitted of one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud. That leaves Mr. Bharara with a still-remarkable 85-1 record in insider trading cases. But that one loss deserves an asterisk.

headline: 1964: Anti-Negro White Is Shot
text: ATLANTA — Restaurant owner Redell Crosby last night shot and critically wounded a 22-year-old white man who entered his integrated restaurant with other whites shouting that Negroes should leave. The shooting coincided with racial outbursts in other Southern cities, including St. Augustine, Fla., and Philadelphia, Miss. Police said five white men who entered Mr. Crosby’s drive-in restaurant were arrested and charged with assault in a scuffle that preceded the shooting. The victim of the shooting was identified as Maurice Lawson of Atlanta. Mr. Crosby was arrested and charged with wounding Mr. Lawson. He was released on $1,500 bond. Detective Tony Quave said Mr. Lawson and the five told the Negroes in the restaurant, “You just have to go.” Mr. Quave said the white men attacked two of the Negroes, punching one in the nose, before Mr. Crosby pulled his pistol. Mr. Crosby held his fire and ordered the white men to leave. All left except Mr. Lawson, who advanced on the restaurant owner with a beer bottle. Mr. Crosby then began shooting. A few blocks from Mr. Crosby’s restaurant, a white man and his son were wounded by blasts from a shotgun fired by Negroes from a passing car. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1964

headline: As Officer Is Mourned, Jersey City’s Tension Is Exposed
text: JERSEY CITY — Friends came to mourn the boy who made good, the one who was robbed on the streets of this city as a teenager and decided he would try to keep them safe for others. Colleagues from near and far came to pay respects to a fellow police officer, a 23-year-old rookie who was gunned down while on duty. And strangers came to send a message that they were tired of the violence.

headline: 36 Hours in Dakar, Senegal
text: West Africa’s hub for nongovernmental organizations and international agencies, Dakar draws a cosmopolitan mix of travelers to its dusty downtown streets and surf-pounded coastline. It’s a city of hustlers and traders, bargainers and touts, eager to show you something or sell you something and not always dissuaded by a polite “non, merci.” Keep saying it. Daytime streets are crowded with men in sharp suits and women rustling in the hand-dyed polished cottons called bazins. At night, intimate restaurants offer Lebanese and French-influenced dishes or simple but fresh grilled fish with Creole sauce. Much later, the dance clubs in Plateau and Almadies, along with the calls to prayer, resound into the early morning.

headline: Eisenhower’s Baseball Secret
text: About a century ago, a young baseball player from Abilene, Kan., struggled with the distinction between professional and amateur sports. This was Dwight D. Eisenhower, the future World War II Allied supreme commander in Europe and two-term president of the United States.

headline: The Data-Driven Home Search
text: When Eugenia Spektor and her husband decided it was time to leave Long Island City for the suburbs, they knew the kind of community they wanted to live in, but weren’t sure they could find it. Their list of wants was straightforward: good public schools for their two children, a train commute of no more than an hour, walking distance to town, an easygoing atmosphere. The characteristics they hoped to avoid were harder to divine: success-crazed moms, high-pressure schools and, since they work full time, a predominance of stay-at-home parents.

headline: A Ride Across America | In Wyoming, a World-Class Burger and an Honest Butcher
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Mickelson Considers Two-Under-Par Round an Encouraging Sign
text: HOYLAKE, England — Phil Mickelson posted his first below-par score in a major since his spectacular finishing round at last year’s British Open, but his two-under 70 at Royal Liverpool on Friday was anything but easy.

headline: A Century of Verse
text: This week, we review several new collections of poetry. Will the work of today’s bards age as well as the last century’s best?

headline: A Former Prodigy Continues to Break Ground in Collaborations
text: There’s a disarming spirit of generosity in the musicianship of Julian Lage, and a keener sense of judicious withholding. A guitarist with roots tangled up in jazz, folk, classical and country music, he has spent most of his life bathed in a bright, expectant light.

headline: Man’s Death After Chokehold Raises Old Issue for the Police
text: The 350-pound man, about to be arrested on charges of illegally selling cigarettes, was arguing with the police. When an officer tried to handcuff him, the man pulled free. The officer immediately threw his arm around the man’s neck and pulled him to the ground, holding him in what appears, in a video, to be a chokehold. The man can be heard saying “I can’t breathe” over and over again as other officers swarm about.

headline: Charlie Rangel's Charitable Giving Shrinks Along With Fund-Raising Clout
text: When Charlie Rangel was riding high as Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, one way Mr. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, helped his profile was by giving hundreds of thousands of dollars to charitable organizations. Those days are long gone.

headline: Library to Host ‘Sesame Street’ Exhibition in New York
text: Devoted fans of “Sesame Street” may remember an episode in 1978, the show’s ninth season, when Big Bird got a library card, followed by several more episodes devoted to finding and reading library books. Other characters have spent time at the library over the years as well. At the New York Public Library, the efforts made by the show’s writers, producers and Muppet stars to help children think of libraries as fun places to visit have not gone unnoticed. So when “Sesame Street” begins its 45th season in September, the library will give it a party, with some help from Sesame Workshop, in the form of an exhibition, “‘Somebody Come and Play’: 45 Years of Learning on ‘Sesame Street’.”

headline: Obama Says Plane Was Shot Down From Rebel-Held Ukraine Area
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that the United States believed that a Malaysian jetliner was shot down by surface-to-air missiles from an area inside Ukraine that is controlled by Russian-backed separatists.

headline: Republicans Respond to the Ukraine Crash by…Blaming President Obama
text: The Gaza Strip is in flames, Israeli troops and tanks rolling in for what is certain to be a bloody military operation in which the region’s battered civilians will once again absorb most of the pain. Meanwhile governments around the world are scrambling to find out who shot down a Malaysian airliner in eastern Ukraine (probably Kremlin-backed secessionists) and why (probably by accident). There are thousands of questions to answer about this nightmare, which is a direct result of the fact that there are gangs of armed men fighting with powerful and dangerous weapons in one of the most volatile places in the world, where Russia bumps up against Western Europe.

headline: Fork Over Those Eggshells!
text: They aren’t what you might think of as typical sanitation workers, but Haley Rogers and Lisa Brunie-McDermott, two Sanitation Department employees, are women with a mission: to persuade New Yorkers to separate orange peels, eggshells and other organic waste from the rest of their trash.

headline: The Immodest Scope of Reform Conservatism
text: This will hopefully be the last post for a while with the word “reform conservatism” in the title (sex, pop culture and religion all deserve more attention), and by the standards of the series it will be relatively brief. Since so many of the criticisms of the reformist tendency have focused on issues where there either isn’t a definite “reform” position or where our ideas are more modest and incremental than the received wisdom about what American conservatism “must” do, I’m concerned that my responses — whether on immigration, foreign policy, the culture war, or climate change — have contributed to the sense that reform conservatism somehow has an ambition problem … that it’s a plausible first step toward a new right-of-center agenda, but lacks (or hasn’t yet been gutsy enough to advance) the Big Ideas that conservatism really needs to matter in American policy debates again. (See David Frum, Kevin Drum, Bill Galston and others for variations on this theme.)

headline: Kia Recalls 52,000 Souls for Steering Problem
text: Kia Motors is recalling nearly 52,000 Soul hatchbacks from the 2014 model year because the steering system may fail, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Russia Lays Blame for Malaysia Airlines Crash on Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin and its military on Friday called the downing of a passenger jet over Ukraine the Ukrainians’s responsibility and rejected accusations that Russia was involved, with senior officials demanding a thorough, impartial international investigation.

text: The comedian and actor talks to Dave Itzkoff about returning to television and good health — and letting his daughters in on his past.

headline: But I Didn’t Know Filming Fights Was Wrong!
text: At my high school, two students were expelled for getting into a fight wherein a teacher was injured. In addition, two students who filmed the fight — and later circulated the video among students — were also threatened with expulsion. Expelling students for filming fights is unheard-of in my district. The school said it had grounds to expel the two who took the video, as outlined by the handbook given to all students: “Students may be disciplined for any other misconduct which is deemed by school authorities to be disruptive or to interfere with the educational process.” There seems to be no rule, however, explicitly banning filming and circulating a fight. How much does students’ ignorance of a rule matter when determining a punishment? Is it ethical for a school to expel students for something they reasonably don’t know to be wrong? NAME WITHHELD, CLEVELAND

headline: Destination: Tokyo
text: After what’s known as “the lost decades” of economic stagnation in Japan, metropolitan Tokyo exudes fresh vitality: A recent TripAdvisor survey ranked it the best tourism city in the world, home to more Michelin three-starred restaurants than any other city. (And a museum devoted to Cup Noodles in nearby Yokohama.) Visiting Tokyo, where preparations for the 2020 Summer Olympics are underway, requires a certain shift of perspective, according to Matthew Pillsbury, whose photographs from Japan appear on these pages and will be shown at New York’s Bonni Benrubi Gallery in September. Pillsbury describes Tokyo as full of slightly weird but engaging sights — like all the Mickey Mouse paraphernalia on teenage boys or the jagged arrangement of mirrors above an escalator in a downtown store. “You’re walking into this shopping mall, and your world is suddenly fragmented,” Pillsbury says. “There’s something really beautiful about it.” Julie Bosman

headline: Inside the List
text: Enemy Territory: The Southern novelist Anne Rivers Siddons is a fixture on the best-seller list — “The Girls of August,” new this week at No. 13, is her 13th book to land on the hardcover fiction list. So is 13 a lucky number for Siddons? Maybe not, judging from the largely disappointed comments readers are posting online about “The Girls of August.” But Siddons has overcome negative reviews before. As a student at Auburn University in the late 1950s, she was fired from the campus newspaper for defying the administration with a scorching column in support of integration (an incident that later found its way into her novel “Heartbreak Hotel”). “Never write a column when you’re mad or sick or disgusted, or all three,” she proclaimed early in the offending essay. “These are the things that make bad little columnists get reprimanding letters from the intelligentsia. Only the greenest, foolhardiest, most naïve amateur would broach a forbidden subject in Enemy Territory. . . . Meet an amateur par excellence.” Later in the same column she mulled the word “tolerance” — “It’s a grown-up word. Children and mobs do much better with four-letter ones” — and criticized people who were content to let their “moral petticoats” drag in the “good old Southern mud.” Auburn finally did integrate in 1964, seven years after that column, and the school eventually forgave Siddons for her justified dudgeon. It awarded her an honorary doctorate of humane letters in 1997, and organized a tribute to her last fall on the anniversary of the column’s publication date.

headline: Stop the Clocks
text: The emblematic Man, any man, every man — dazed, heartsick, utterly bewildered — suddenly pushes away his dinner and gets up from the kitchen table. He can’t take it any longer — the overwhelming, claustrophobic grief, which has hollowed him out — and so he decides to go “there.” But where is there? That’s what the emblematic Woman, any woman, every woman, can’t figure out. That’s what she wants to know. She understands, this woman who is also a mother, a wife, that there is no place to go when you’ve lost a child. You are already wounded by disaster, forever bereft. “In an instant we were cast out / to a land of exile,” she remembers. But this man can’t sit still any longer. The trouble has taken him over again. And so he sets out to go “there” anyway. It has been five years, and he is determined to see his dead son one more time, though no one has ever made the journey and come back alive. Like a figure in a myth, he is going to walk across a divide, leaving the living behind, the innocent ones, who still exist inside of ordinary time.

headline: Picture Everyone Naked
text: It’s always wrong to judge a poem by its retweets, but when a literary work, by a poet not world famous for something else, gets hundreds of thousands of “shares,” “likes” and other such notices online, within weeks of publication, it’s time to ask why. That is what happened, in 2013, to Patricia Lockwood’s “Rape Joke.” Like rape itself, “Rape Joke” was no joke: “The rape joke is that you were 19 years old,” it began. “The rape joke is that he was your boyfriend. . . . The rape joke is that you had been drinking wine coolers. Wine coolers! Who drinks wine coolers? People who get raped, according to the rape joke.” To readers who had suffered similar outrages, Lockwood offered wit and a fed-up solidarity; to others, the poem brought news.

headline: Sing to Me, O Muse (But Keep It Brief)
text: Maybe I dreamed it. Don Draper sips Canadian Club from a coffee mug on Craig Ferguson’s late-night talk show. “Are you on Twitter?” the host asks. “No,” Draper says. “I don’t” — he pauses before pronouncing the distasteful verb — “tweet.” Next question. “Do you read a lot of poetry?” Though the hero of “Mad Men” is seen reading Dante’s “Inferno” in one season of the show and heard reciting Frank O’Hara in another, the question seems to come from left field. “Poetry isn’t really celebrated anymore in our culture,” Draper says, to which Ferguson retorts, “It can be — if you can write in units of 140 keystrokes.” Commercial break.

headline: In Real Life
text: “Friendship,” the first novel by Emily Gould, is about, well, friendship: It chronicles the several-years-long platonic love between two just-barely-30 New York City strivers, Bev and Amy. Bev is a classic ne’er-do-well, an inelegant Midwestern transplant who can’t seem to earn any real money or avoid getting trampled by various cads, one of whom she disastrously follows to Madison, Wis., and another of whom gets her pregnant on their first date. (She accepted the invitation only for the free meal, poor thing.) She exists in sharp contrast to the charming, affable Amy, the more stable, interesting and well dressed of the pair, who was once — remember this next part — a blogger on a prominent gossip site, but who now works at another blog, if the term “work” can be stretched to encompass countless hours of “online window-shopping and Wikipedia rabbit holes and . . . Gchatting with Bev.”

headline: Harm’s Ways
text: In the era before cheap air travel, those in the English-speaking world who wanted to taste authentic French village life read Gabriel Chevallier’s gently satirical novels, published between the mid-1930s and the early 1960s. “Clochemerle” and “Clochemerle-Babylon” were deft, wise and celebratory in what people thought of as the French style. On the town of Cloche­merle, in the Beaujolais region, the issues of French politics, class difference and coming or past collaboration with fascism lay more lightly than did eccentricity, pride in local wine, cooking and love.

headline: I’ve Ruined My Boys
text: “Anyone want pasta for lunch?” I asked, and my 6-, 9- and 11-year-­old boys stared at their little screens in front of the big screen and ignored me. Incredulous, I glared at them. And then I repeated the question, the pitch of my voice notably higher.

headline: World Leaders on Malaysia Airlines Crash
text: Reaction from world leaders to Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash.

headline: Content and Its Discontents
text: Astra Taylor is a documentary filmmaker who has described her work as the “steamed broccoli” in our cultural diet. Her last film, “Examined Life,” depicted philosophers walking around and talking about their ideas. She’s the kind of creative person who was supposed to benefit when the Internet revolution collapsed old media hierarchies. But two decades since that revolution began, she’s not impressed: “We are at risk of starving in the midst of plenty,” Taylor writes. “Free culture, like cheap food, incurs hidden costs.” Instead of serving as the great equalizer, the web has created an abhorrent cultural feudalism. The creative masses connect, create and labor, while Google, Facebook and Amazon collect the cash.

headline: Viva la República
text: There’s a certain sense of fatedness that emerges in the 13 espionage novels Alan Furst has written about Europe before and during World War II, even if it’s never quite enunciated in their wry, reticent storytelling. It has to do with the nature of the genre. Furst’s makeshift spies act with courage, but their choices are shaded with a brutal irony, darkened by what we readers, a few paces further along in history, know will be coming for them and the people they care about: the battlefields, the camps. The consolation Furst offers for this knowledge is present in a careful hedonism, which insists on the heightened beauty of the evanescent during wartime — the unexpected pleasure of a meal or a glass of wine, a night in bed with a stranger as it snows outside, anything human.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: Big changes could be coming to the media world after Rupert Murdoch made an $80 billion bid to buy Time Warner. The offer was rejected, but that doesn’t mean it’s the end of the story. If Murdoch succeeds, he would wind up with movie and TV studios like Warner Brothers and HBO. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar consider what would happen if Rupert Murdoch succeeds in purchasing Time Warner.

headline: A ’70s Childhood
text: In his fourth book of poems, “Bicentennial,” Dan Chiasson is after beauty of a kind, so his poems are often beautiful, odd and quite moving. He seldom resorts to lilting cadences or glow-in-the-dark imagery to achieve this, and complicates any move toward traditional lyric warmth; his poetry is genially brainy, jokey, casually formal, sometimes essayistic and humorously oracular. Yet “Bicentennial” is no mere intellectual pleasure. It’s also a journey into a 1970s New England childhood haunted by a father Chiasson never knew.

headline: Why Myers-Briggs Is Totally Useless — but Wildly Popular
text: If you’ve ever filled out a Myers-Briggs personality test only to feel the results didn’t describe you at all, take heart. According to Vox’s Joseph Stromberg, “The test is completely meaningless.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: MY LUNCHES WITH ORSON: Conversations Between Henry Jaglom and Orson Welles,  edited by Peter Biskind. (Picador, $16.) From 1983 until his death in 1985, Orson Welles met the director Henry Jaglom regularly for lunch at the Hollywood restaurant Ma Maison. Their recorded conversations capture Welles at his most provocative: reflecting on the highs and lows of his career and sharing acerbic observations on politics, literature and Hollywood.

text: An exemplar of the classic, shingle-style Hamptons cottage, built as a 1910 summer home on 5.2 acres on a bayside bluff in Amagansett, is poised to enter the market at $13 million. It is the least imposing of the original five houses in the Devon Colony.

headline: Elaine Stritch Didn’t Have Outbursts, She Said in an Outburst (Get the Joke? She Didn’t)
text: Usually when someone dies, there are encomiums about how kind, generous and loving the person was. This is not going to be like that.

headline: One Rises, One Falls
text: In 1866, the poet Fyodor Tyutchev wrote a piece of wisdom about Russia that used to be quoted incessantly in books, articles, speeches and children’s anthologies, but never quite made it to the West:

headline: A Rose by Other Names
text: I know a songwriter who hates nature poetry. Just about every other style of verse speaks to this guy, whether it’s traditional or avant-garde, unabashedly romantic or abstractedly cerebral, but as soon as my friend hears about silvery, moonlit branches swooshing in some mountain breeze, or raindrops mystically anointing a spray of spring wildflowers, he wants to gag.

headline: Grave Business
text: A tornado tore through the town of Jericho, Miss., in the most recent of Ace Atkins’s deeply rooted regional novels set in a gritty pocket of the rural South. In THE FORSAKEN (Putnam, $26.95), a resident who survived that last book reflects on “the ugliness of what we’ve done to this place, all the logging, busted-up trailers, and stripping of anything that can make a buck” and decides that “we didn’t need a tornado to rip this town apart, we just needed a few more good years.”

text: DETROIT — Even before Senator Elizabeth Warren entered the grand ballroom of the Cobo Center here on Friday for a much-anticipated speech to hundreds of liberal activists, her admirers were handing out plastic boater hats, bumper stickers and lawn signs declaring, “Elizabeth Warren for President.”

text: ELEPHANT COMPANY: The Inspiring Story of an Unlikely Hero and the Animals Who Helped Him Save Lives in World War II,  by Vicki Constantine Croke. (Random House, $28.) A rich portrait of a fascinating Englishman in extraordinary times.

text: Time moves very quickly in the tech industry. Just as a start-up can go from being a glimmer in a founder’s eye to a multibillion dollar company in a few short years, so can companies die or become inconsequential almost overnight.

headline: In Concert on the Home Front
text: If they were so inclined, the cellist David Finckel and his wife, the pianist Wu Han, could offer up a high-flown speech about why, 23 years ago, they decided to leave their West 98th Street rental and move a mile south. They could, no doubt, speak earnestly about the demands of their art and the value of being closer to Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, but palaver is not in their repertoire.

headline: Less Boyish at the Bolshoi
text: Ballet fans love a campy, insidery way of referring to dancers by their first names, regardless of whether they’ve ever met them or would presume thus to address them. Margot, Rudi, Natasha, Lynn, Anthony, Suzanne, Misha, Gelsey were among the darlings of my youth, and today, it’s Wendy, Marcelo, Alina, Herman, Gillian, Sara, Robbie. Most of these are not remotely household names around the world, in the way that Oprah and Brad are. But that’s the point. They’re names in the cliquey household of ballet. To employ first names shows you belong.

headline: James Tobin and Aggregate Supply (Implicitly Wonkish)
text: Thomas Palley argues that mainstream macroeconomists have been looking in all the wrong places for an explanation of the stickiness of inflation in the face of high unemployment; what they should do is consider the old Tobin approach that combines multiple sectors (so that some workers have rising wages even in an economy that’s depressed on average) with downward nominal wage rigidity.

headline: Lincoln Agonistes
text: The summer of 1864 found Abraham Lincoln, and the Union war effort, in a conundrum: The Northern public desperately wanted an end to the war, and yet the two possibilities – a negotiated peace or a military victory – seemed increasingly remote. But if he wanted to win reelection in the fall, he had to show movement on one front or the other.

headline: Brooklyn’s Youngest Monsters of Rock to Publish a Book
text: You may have caught the Brooklyn metal trio Unlocking the Truth rocking out in Times Square last spring – if not, a 33-minute clip of a 2013 performance has become a hit on YouTube – or perhaps at the Coachella festival this year, or as an opener for Guns N’ Roses. If you did, you would undoubtedly have been struck by the contrast between the hefty but polished, high-energy sound the band was cranking out, and the extreme youthfulness of the musicians: the band’s guitarist, Malcolm Brickhouse, and its bassist, Alec Atkins, are 13; Jarad Dawkins, its drummer, is 12, and they clearly have all the moves down.

headline: Trouble Underfoot on Israeli Kibbutz Near the Border
text: SUFA, Israel — Israel’s decision to invade Gaza has its roots just outside of this small kibbutz in southern Israel where open fields and citrus orchards offer a pastoral scene that residents say has long been deceptive.

headline: A Buzzy Hotel Oasis in West Hollywood
text: In West Hollywood, the San Vicente Inn is gradually being transformed by the boutique hotelier Jeff Klein, who is garnering lots of attention for turning the historically gay, seedy hotel into a clean and chic place for the young and beautiful to shack up on a budget (rooms range from $99 to $209 per night). Now known as the San Vicente Bungalows, the 29-room property has undergone basic renovations — like spiffed-up bathrooms, now stocked with Malin & Goetz products — that are attracting the 20- to 30-something international jet set. In addition to bright and cozy digs, guests enjoy free breakfast and can rent beach cruisers ($15 for 4 hours) to ride out to places like Venice Beach and Santa Monica, each just about 45 minutes away by bike. Even the locals are popping in for a swim — access to the pool and newly landscaped grounds is $35/day. Eventually, the now-charming place will get a complete makeover. So T checked into the buzzy little oasis to memorialize things as they stand now, while summer is in full swing.

headline: When Contemporary Poetry Is Your Muse
text: This week, we decided to put together a package of reviews and essays about contemporary poetry. We had strong reviews of recent work by a couple of major American poets, Dan Chiasson and Maureen N. McLane. Our On Poetry columnist, David Orr, wrote a review of a collection of poems by the actor James Franco (“James Franco, Poet”). And this year’s editor of “The Best American Poetry,” David Lehman, proposed adapting his introduction to that volume, which comes out in September and broadly asks what role poetry plays in a technologized world.Moreover, recently, and to some people, amazingly, contemporary poetry has been making headlines. The young poet Patricia Lockwood generated much social media buzz with her poem, “Rape Joke.” She was then profiled in The New York Times Magazine.

headline: There Is So Much That Must Live On
text: This month, in a fifth-floor studio at City Center, I spent part of an afternoon watching 30 minutes of Merce Cunningham’s 1997 “Scenario.” When new, this had been a work both glamorous and difficult. The most famous feature was its radical couture, outfits by Rei Kawakubo (of Comme des Garçons), wonderfully colored and patterned, but with padded bulges that changed the dancers’ outlines and sometimes limited their movements. And its choreography was also one of Cunningham’s more advanced creations in his late, “computer,” phase. (He was 78 at the time of its premiere.)

headline: Movie Review: ‘Mood Indigo’

headline: A ‘Cold Supper’ That Goes Beyond Leftovers
text: The weather is oppressive, sizzling, stifling. At the end of the day, a cook doesn’t feel much like cooking, and the cook’s brood is flushed and cranky. A cold beer and a mediocre takeout pizza won’t improve things much, but they are an option. If company’s coming, however, that may be perceived as less than hospitable.

headline: Everyone’s Here, Now Let’s Innovate
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Officially, the small square in front of the former residence of the archbishop, in the historic center of this elegant Provençal town, is named after the martyrs of the French Resistance. But every summer, the musicians, administrators and theater professionals who flock here for the Aix-en-Provence Festival give it a nickname drawn from the opening scene of Bizet’s “Carmen”: “La Place Chacun Passe” — the square where everybody comes and goes.

headline: Let’s Get Back to Work, Old Chum
text: Jon Voight was ribbing his new co-star, the media-shy Ann-Margret.

headline: With an Original Score, I Thee Wed
text: Last year, when Daniel Knobler decided to propose to Carrie Crowell, a granddaughter of Johnny Cash, he said he “knew from the get-go” that he wanted the music to be something special.

headline: Adieu to That Dapper Detective
text: LOS ANGELES — As David Suchet walks into the green room backstage at the Ahmanson Theater, a half-finished jigsaw puzzle on a table catches his eye. “Someone in the cast must be working on that,” mused Mr. Suchet, who is appearing in a production here of “The Last Confession.” “Personally, I’m not one who particularly enjoys putting together puzzles.”

headline: Musicians Starting in One Place, Then Heading Elsewhere
text: Areni Agbabian

headline: Italian Favorite Tightens His Grip on Yellow Jersey in Dominant Stage
text: CHAMROUSSE, France — The Tour de France shifted from a race of attrition to a race of domination Friday in its first major mountain stage.

headline: A Turbo Brain Tackles Underworld Brawn
text: As one of France’s most successful filmmakers, Luc Besson figured the woman next to him at a Bordeaux dinner party was an aspiring actress, someone like the mayor’s cousin, hoping to get a foot in the door.

headline: Selected Documents Released From the Clinton Archives
text: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon another, smaller trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clinton’s White House.

headline: Dell Begins Accepting Bitcoin
text: Another well-known company is embracing digital money.

headline: Drinking What's Available
text: It’s another primary night. It’s after 11. You are still at your desk because they’re counting absentee ballots in Waukesha County and The Associated Press hasn’t called the race. Finally, the closest challenger concedes, and you’ve filed your story; you and the copy editor would really like a cocktail right about now. But you don’t want it to make you too tired. The last time you fell asleep on the subway home, you wound up in Coney Island.

headline: Judge Rules in Tale of a Soured Love Affair as Told on Anonymous Blogs
text: For all the inquiries they have facilitated into humanity’s highest intellectual realms, blogs have also proven themselves good incubators for petty squabbling, savage back-stabbing and ad hominem warfare of all varieties. The same, of course, is true of academia. So if, as a recent lawsuit alleges, an editorial associate at Cornell University’s Sage School of Philosophy took to the Internet in 2012 to savage a former lover, it may not be surprising that things got out of control.

headline: Every Single Place Has Its Own Sound
text: A strong sense of place informs the music of the composer John Luther Adams, who won a Pulitzer Prize this year, be it the Pacific Ocean, the Sonoran Desert, or the plains of his adopted Alaska. With “Sila: The Breath of the World,” which receives its premiere on Friday in a free joint production of the Mostly Mozart Festival and Lincoln Center Out of Doors, Mr. Adams invites audiences to open their ears to the sounds of their city.

headline: Like What You See? It May be for Sale
text: The American conceptual artist Christopher Williams, whose first retrospective opens July 27 at the Museum of Modern Art, treats photography with very tough love. During a 35-year career, it has been both his medium of choice and the target of his critical thinking. He takes as a basic premise the assumption that in a consumer society, the main purpose of photographs is to sell something — one of those things being art.

headline: Several Styles, All Together Now
text: Just as there are fusion cuisines — and you never know what they’re like until you try them — so, too, there’s fusion dance, in which various styles unite into a new, surprising and, let’s hope, choreographically tasty concoction. Dancegoers can sample the fare of a new fusion troupe when FJK Dance offers its first full New York engagement. Founded by Fadi J. Khoury, the Baghdad-born son of an Iraqi ballet director, the company gave preview performances in April. Mr. Khoury seeks to mix ballet with ballroom, Middle Eastern and jazz dance, stripping away unnecessary glitter from these forms to emphasize the beauty of movement itself.

headline: Big Ticket | Upper East Side Townhouse for $27.25 Million
text: A meticulously renovated neo-Georgian townhouse on the Upper East Side, defined by its multiple outdoor entertainment spaces and an interior-décor ode to blue, sold for $27.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Festival Starts With the Sensual
text: Karim Aïnouz’s “Futuro Beach” is the pungently sensual opening-night film of this year’s NewFest: The New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Film Festival, whose 26th edition takes place Thursday through July 29 at the Walter Reade Theater. The movie is the fifth fictional feature by this Brazilian director, whose sensational 2002 debut, “Madame Satã,” was a fictionalized biography of a notorious nightclub performer and criminal in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: A Salsa Opera Returns Outdoors
text: Larry Harlow’s “Hommy,” a landmark of New York music, was an Afro-Latin answer to the Who’s “Tommy”: a 1973 salsa opera, with lyrics by Heny Álvarez, telling the story of a deaf and blind boy gifted at playing the conga drum.

headline: How Tests Make Us Smarter
text: TESTS have a bad reputation in education circles these days: They take time, the critics say, put students under pressure and, in the case of standardized testing, crowd out other educational priorities. But the truth is that, used properly, testing as part of an educational routine provides an important tool not just to measure learning, but to promote it.

headline: The Trial Ends, the Doubts Linger
text: The entrapment defense did not convince the jury that convicted four men on terrorism charges in New York in 2010, but it is very persuasive in “The Newburgh Sting,” a documentary about the case, Monday night on HBO. Partly that’s because prosecutors and investigators declined to be interviewed for the film, which thus presents only one side. But, mostly, it’s because surveillance video of the men and the informant who egged them on, which makes up a significant part of the film, shows four buffoons who do not remotely fit the portrait of terror masterminds painted by the authorities when they announced their arrests in 2009.

headline: McIlroy Pulls Away as Woods Hangs On
text: HOYLAKE, England — Rory McIlroy made his way around Royal Liverpool on Friday as if the course were a bouncy house, his springy step signaling his sky-high confidence.

headline: Weekend Reading: Your Wall Street Earnings Quiz
text: How well do you know Wall Street’s second-quarter earnings results?

headline: Marry to Make a Match (Not to Beat the Market)
text: In the search for love, are straight men always looking for women who are better looking than they are, and straight women holding out for men who are richer? Or do they tend to pair up with partners who are more on their level? Recent research suggests the latter — and this may have larger implications for how we talk about love and marriage.

headline: Exuding Skill and Warmth
text: BECKET, Mass. — The main attraction of Ballet 2014/Daniel Ulbricht, the touring chamber ballet troupe appearing at Jacob’s Pillow this week, is Mr. Ulbricht and his colleagues, all members of New York City Ballet. When dancers of the caliber and charm of Robert Fairchild, Tiler Peck and Teresa Reichlen come to town, it’s a special event — even if, as is the case here, the town is regularly visited by premier dancers.

headline: Blake Lively, Kate Bosworth and Tory Burch Turn Tech Entrepreneurs
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: New Rule Permits Early Release for Thousands of Drug Offenders
text: WASHINGTON — Tens of thousands of prisoners serving time for federal drug offenses will be eligible to seek early release beginning next year.

headline: Caden’s Car Show
text: The University of Michigan C. S. Mott Children’s Hospital held a car show this month in memory of Caden Bowles, who died last year.

headline: Examining the Growth of the ‘Spiritual but Not Religious’
text: “Spiritual but not religious.” So many Americans describe their belief system this way that pollsters now give the phrase its own category on questionnaires. In the 2012 survey by the Pew Religion and Public Life Project, nearly a fifth of those polled said that they were not religiously affiliated — and nearly 37 percent of that group said they were “spiritual” but not “religious.” It was 7 percent of all Americans, a bigger group than atheists, and way bigger than Jews, Muslims or Episcopalians.

headline: Did You Know Someone on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17?
text: Times journalists would like to learn more about the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

headline: 2014 Mini Cooper Hardtop
text: The Mini is growing up and becoming more BMW-like than ever.

headline: Compiling a ‘Best of the Best’ List
text: The National Historic Vehicle Register was established in March 2013 to compile a record of America’s most historically significant vehicles. It is managed by the Historic Vehicle Association, a group financially supported by Hagerty Insurance, which specializes in coverage for classic vehicles.

headline: Now Verified, a Veteran Is Honored
text: The United States had few military vehicles in its arsenal when in April 1917 it declared war and joined Britain, France and Russia in the horrific struggle that was the Great War. But if America’s supply of tanks and troop carriers was meager, its civilian auto fleet was substantial: More than 1.8 million cars were manufactured in the country in 1917.

headline: Obama to Issue Order Barring Anti-Gay Bias by Contractors
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to sign an executive order on Monday that protects gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender employees from discrimination by companies that do federal government work, fulfilling a promise to a crucial Democratic constituency, White House officials said on Friday. But the directive will not exempt religious groups, as many of them had sought.

headline: A 1918 Cadillac Type 57 in World War I
text: A Presbyterian minister serving with the Y.M.C.A. in a troop support role during World War I took his car with him. The Caddy survives.

headline: Airbnb Unveils Warm Logo as It Gets Cool Legal Eye
text: Airbnb, the online lodging site that has recently provoked the ire of local governments in Barcelona, San Francisco and New York City, is out to win the public’s affection with its new logo — an inverted, loopy heart.

headline: Week in Pictures for July 18
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes the Long Island Rail Road, the World Cup and a preserved frog.

headline: How Murdoch’s Bid for Time Warner Stacks Up Against Other Deals
text: As Time Warner defends its rejection of 21st Century Fox’s $80 billion takeover bid, one of its principle objections has been fairly simple: Rupert Murdoch isn’t offering enough money.

headline: Tennessee Wedding Song
Doctor Accused of Overprescribing Pills Is Guilty of Manslaughter
text: A Queens doctor accused of overprescribing painkillers to two patients who later suffered fatal overdoses was convicted on Friday of two counts of second-degree manslaughter and dozens of lesser charges.

headline: Taking a Spin: Republicans Raid Democratic-Leaning States
text: Today I wrote that Southern black voters could decide Senate control. Coincidentally, my weekly spin of our Leo Senate model, which provides random simulations of this November’s election, shows how Republicans could win the Senate despite a big surge in black turnout.

headline: At 12, Puberty and a Growth Spurt
text: Welcoming the reborn Mini in 2002, Americans couldn’t wait to pinch its adorable cheeks. “Look how tiny!” they cooed, plunking down cash and taking their baby home.

headline: One Ninja Among the Many
text: TESTED 2014 Kawasaki Ninja 1000

headline: A Car Show for Caden, Who Would Have Loved It
text: ANN ARBOR, MICH. — Lance Bowles knew his son Caden loved cars, but he didn’t realize just how much until the summer when Caden was 6.

headline: Love People, Not Pleasure
text: ABD AL-RAHMAN III was an emir and caliph of Córdoba in 10th-century Spain. He was an absolute ruler who lived in complete luxury. Here’s how he assessed his life:

headline: Dislocation, Italian Style
text: “SCUSI,” I said, calling a nurse in the same tone of casual deference used to summon a waiter, trying to ignore the pain that was blaring like a siren in my mind. It was a glorious day in Milan, and I had planned to spend it having lunch with a colleague, visiting a favorite museum, shopping for shoes. Instead, I found myself staring at the emergency room ceiling in the Ospedale Gaetano Pini, which the ambulance driver assured me was the best orthopedic hospital in the north of Italy. “People come from all over to have surgery here,” he said.

headline: Charles Aznavour’s September Concert May Be His Last in New York — Or Not
text: The French singer, songwriter and actor Charles Aznavour will give what may or may not be his farewell performance in New York at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 20. The Garden is promoting the show as Mr. Aznavour’s final New York concert, and a spokeswoman for the complex said, after checking with the singer’s agent, that “this is the singer’s last performance in New York, and is being billed as his farewell performance,” adding that “there are no plans for Charles Aznavour to tour in the U.S. or perform in New York City again.”

headline: It’s 2025. Maternity Wards Are Empty.
text: Television sure seems eager to end life as we know it, or at least disrupt it catastrophically. On Sunday even the normally soft and weepy Lifetime channel joins in with “The Lottery,” a new series that postulates a world in which human beings can no longer reproduce the old-fashioned way.

headline: Maxing Out Gmail Storage
text: Q. My Gmail account says it’s almost full, even though it doesn’t seem as if mail takes up that much room. How can I get more storage in my Gmail account if I need it?

headline: Causes of the Influx at the Border
A Proposal, and a Broadcaster Left Speechless
text: When Vicki Barker was 8 years old, she vowed to never marry. Hearing other girls declare they wanted to become mothers and wives left the little girl from Rumson, N.J., uninspired. The boys’ dreams — firefighter, soldier, police officer — sounded like more fun. She told her family she wanted a different kind of adventure.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Water and Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bahrain and the U.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Europe Wants Apple and Google to Fix In-App Payments Problem
text: Many parents have learned the hard way that many mobile games that are  initially free can quickly become expensive, because they may charge for extras while playing the game. Europe says it is pushing Apple and Google to be more upfront about the potential cost.

headline: Terse, Genial or Blazing, a Bandleader Reveling in His Role
text: Good leadership in jazz is hard to quantify, but you know it when you see it — you can usually sense, in a musician’s judgment and yield and carriage, that some higher instinct has been activated. Sean Jones, whose glowing stature as a trumpeter has accrued over the last dozen years or so, didn’t always embody that quality on the bandstand. He does now, as he showed decisively at the Jazz Standard on Thursday in the opening set of a four-night run.

headline: The War Between Israel and Gaza: Assigning Blame
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dissent Among Mormons
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scottish Independence Is Inevitable
text: LONDON — ONE thing is certain: Whatever the outcome, this referendum campaign is changing Scotland irrevocably. Whether the Scots vote yes or no to independence on Sept. 18, their sense of what is possible for this small nation will have been transformed.

headline: Yo, One-Word Messaging App, Is Valued at Up to $10 Million
text: As much as $10 million.

headline: Technology’s Rainbow Connection
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If it weren’t for the one naked guy, the furries with their articulated ears and the small gaggle of leather-clad members of the Society of Janus, this city’s 44th annual Pride parade in June could have been easily be mistaken for a technology conference.

headline: An Indian Girl Who Just Wanted to Be Puerto Rican
text: By the end of “They Call Me Q,” you’re apt to like Qurrat Ann Kadwani so much that you’ll be doubly disappointed that she hasn’t written herself a better show. Her easy smile and lively eyes can brighten up a moment, but they can’t overcome a shortage of laughs and a wandering story line.

headline: Pedaling a Party Back to Life
text: As if to assure us that they are real people, not superheroes or machines, the members of Pilobolus begin each show by warming up onstage. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, before the program began, Shawn Fitzgerald Ahern fired off a few push-ups, Eriko Jimbo floated into a wide-legged handstand and Jordan Kriston whipped through a series of spiraling falls. The whole group circled up along with someone who appeared to be their stage manager (the technical crew is equally part of this clan), for a chummy preshow ritual that ended with a collective roar.

headline: A Bastion of British Tradition Embraces Technology
text: HOYLAKE, England — In an island nation full of old buildings and old sporting events, modernization is a particularly acrobatic juggling act.

headline: The Faces of Ford
text: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.

headline: Hundreds in Detroit Protest Over Move to Shut Off Water
text: DETROIT — At least 300 demonstrators marched through downtown streets on Friday, protesting a move by the city’s Water Department to force tens of thousands of delinquent customers to pay up or face a cutoff in service. From the Cobo Center to Hart Plaza on the banks of the Detroit River, protesters chanted, “Fight, fight; water is a human right.” Others carried placards that read “Thirsty for Justice.”

headline: Justices Say Utah Doesn't Have to Recognize Gay Marriages
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday said Utah is not required to recognize the marriages of roughly 1,000 same-sex couples there while state officials pursue appeals.

headline: Exceptional Further Lane Estate in East Hampton, New York
text: One-of-a-kind Further Lane estate where every element of this 5-bedroom, 5.5-bath, approx. 7,400-sq.ft. home evokes an “Aman” resort feel.

headline: Breezes Waft, Branches Sway and Bodies Scatter and Swirl
