text: As a choreographer, Shen Wei is driven by nature. In both his dancers and in his structure, it’s all there, just transplanted in bodies: a leafy branch swaying in the breeze, an insect scrambling across a dirt path, powdery clouds floating across a clear sky.

headline: After Tough Years, Elevation Partners Rescues Investment in Forbes Media
text: Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Forbes Media’s sale of a majority stake in itself to a group of Asian investors will certainly bring some closure to the publisher’s founding family, which first put the company up for sale last fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza City, Israel and India.

headline: After a Run of 19 Years, Passing the Baton
text: LONDON — The American conductor David Zinman is a small man, physically — conductors often seem to be — but with a giant profile in the Swiss city of Zurich. People recognize him on the sidewalk. Waiters hover. Strangers wave. And so they might. He’s been the music director of the city’s venerable orchestra, the Tonhalle, for 19 years: a long time, given the speed with which most leading figures in his line of work swap partners.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Clashing Holds on Renaissance Art History
text: What if the Renaissance began earlier and elsewhere? That audacious question kindles David Edgar’s “Pentecost,” a 1994 play revived by PTP/NYC. No less resonant now than when it had its premiere, the drama is a testament to Mr. Edgar’s literary skill and a rebuke to the political climate in Eastern Europe and elsewhere.

headline: If They’d Overthrown the Labour Party
text: LONDON — The “hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death,” as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most terrifying psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you don’t really need.

headline: In Santa Fe, An Art Space Reinvents the Biennial
text: Beginning tonight, the adobe walls of the art space SITE Santa Fe will house a re-creation of an illegal 19th-century New Mexico gambling den, complete with dealers staging rounds of the Spanish card game known as monte. Inspired by the casinos that cropped up during the 1830s New Mexican gold rush, it’s part of a multipronged piece by the artist Pablo Helguera, one of 45 artists in “Unsettled Landscapes,” the latest edition of SITE Santa Fe’s contemporary art biennial, opening this Sunday.

headline: City Politics Abhors a Vacation
text: From 1926 to 1932, James J. Walker — Beau James as he was known — presided over the city as mayor, succumbing to Jazz Age seductions more easily than he did to the demands of municipal governance. Speakeasies, boxing matches, Broadway, mistresses, expensive clothes — these were his pastimes when he found himself in town, but often he found himself elsewhere. During his first two years in office he is said to have taken seven vacations totaling 143 days.

headline: Sass and Slow-Motion Bullets
text: You can always learn something by watching television. On Sunday night, it’s this:

headline: Shakespeare’s Shipwrecked Twins Settle on the Asphalt and Astroturf
text: The Delacorte it ain’t.

headline: Negotiators Agree to Extend Iran Nuclear Talks Four More Months, Diplomats Say
text: Iran, the United States and the five other countries negotiating the future of the Iranian nuclear program have agreed to a four-month extension of the talks, giving them more time to try to bridge major differences over whether Tehran will be forced to dismantle parts of its nuclear infrastructure, according to a statement released early Saturday in Vienna by all seven nations.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Spingold Knockout Teams
text: LAS VEGAS — The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Summer North American Championships taking place here.

headline: Under Cover: Silent Picture
text: Michael Sokolove’s cover story in this week’s magazine describes the downfall of Penn State’s former president, Graham Spanier. Gail Bichler, the magazine’s art director, said that because the article was about Spanier’s silence, she cropped Bryan Schutmaat’s portrait of him. ‘‘We thought focusing attention on his mouth was a powerful way to illustrate this,’’ she said. And Bichler said that showing him in casual dress (he also sat for photographs in a suit and tie) was a way to reflect the personal nature of Spanier’s discussions with Sokolove. The image was shot in color, but it was converted to black and white to give the cover a somber feel and make it more graphic.

headline: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
text: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer.

headline: A Broadway Tale: A Little Web Series and How It Grew
text: Although, as Wesley Taylor says, “show business is the best platform for humiliation,” he and his fellow Broadway performer Mitchell Jarvis have turned their personal and professional setbacks into victories. Their DIY web series, “It Could Be Worse,” about a struggling and somewhat hapless actor played by Mr. Taylor, seems to be doing better in its career than the fictional character at its center.

headline: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
text: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer. New this year are skirts and dresses of Marimekko dotted fabric. There are stripes, too, in flattering diagonals. A whimsical backless jacket is held together with a ribbon at the neck. And then there are the leopards, zebras, pandas and long-earred furry friends who wear the color combo so well.

headline: They’re on a Boat!
text: As the early-evening sun blazed, the old Navy boat gently pushed into the East River and the 32 passengers were mindfully served cocktails, wine in tumblers and beer in cans. Life aboard the Revolution eased to two knots.

headline: Evening Hours | Toasts All Around
text: A week for dancing in the streets and celebrating athletes and artists.

headline: Eileen Ford: Through the Years
text: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.

headline: The Pickpocket’s Tale
text: Wilfred Rose, 58, spent a career studying the pants pockets of New Yorkers, always on the lookout for “a nice stiff wallet” full of cash, or better yet, the fainter outline of a dozen folded bills.

headline: Does Poetry Matter?
text: Sunday's New York Times Book Review featured several new collections of poems. But does poetry matter? Is it relevant?

headline: Eileen Ford’s Legacy
text: When Lauren Hutton first arrived in New York in the early 1960s, there was little to suggest she would soon become one of fashion’s highest-paid models and, later, an alluring actress paired with leading men like James Caan and Richard Gere.

headline: Waterfront Developments
text: When Peter’s Clam Bar first opened in Island Park, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was in the White House, Hitler was menacing Europe, “The Wizard of Oz” was in movie theaters and Island Park’s homegrown politician, former Senator Alphonse M. D’Amato, was a toddler. It managed to stick around for 73 years, until it was ravaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012. In June, Peter’s reopened, under new ownership.

headline: Lost and Found in Space
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — WHEN we think about space missions, what generally comes to mind are large rooms filled with rocket scientists at consoles that control expensive new spacecraft doing unintelligible things. That’s still the norm but, in fact, there doesn’t need to be an entrance exam for people who want to explore space, and we’ve proved it.

headline: Don’t Blame Malaysia Airlines
text: WASHINGTON — ALMOST as soon as the news broke about the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines flight over Ukraine on Thursday, in which all 298 passengers and crew members were killed, people began to ask: What was a commercial aircraft doing over a conflict zone in the first place? Was this disaster somehow the airline’s fault?

headline: Tibetan Leader, a Red Sox Fan, Knows the Value of Taking the Long View
text: DHARAMSALA, India — From his office in the hill station of Dharamsala, where Tibetan exiles have spent the past half-century waiting for the seismic changes that could restore Tibet’s independence, Prime Minister Lobsang Sangay was reminiscing, a bit wistfully, about a world he had left behind.

headline: A Neighborhood Place in the Right Spot
text: Italian food is not hard to come by in Westchester County. Just about every town has at least one pizzeria, and many have several. More ambitious Italian restaurants, those where the wine list includes a Barolo or two and the menu goes beyond calzones, garlic knots and Neapolitan pies, are less common. And good ambitious Italian restaurants are rarer still.

headline: Putin’s Deadly Doctrine
text: OXFORD, England — SOMETIMES, just sometimes, you should pay attention to annoying things said by tiresome people at worthy conferences.

headline: White House Opens Door to Exploring Atlantic for Oil
text: The Obama administration approved guidelines on Friday for seismic searches for oil and gas deposits in the Atlantic Ocean, handing the petroleum industry a significant victory in a bitter dispute with environmental groups over the searches’ impact on marine life.

headline: A Loss (Sabathia, for the Season) Before a Win for the Yankees
text: The news that C. C. Sabathia would have knee surgery and miss the rest of the season was hardly stunning: He experienced pain and swelling the day after pitching for Class AA Trenton on July 2 and was shut down, making surgery the most likely course of action.

headline: Needing Skilled Workers, a Booming Germany Woos Immigrants
text: BERLIN — After just a few months in Germany, Cristina Torres knows she would like to stay here in Berlin, where her husband is studying global production engineering and their 21-month-old daughter can grow up in safety.

headline: A Sumptuous Supper and Setting
text: Luxury at the Mayflower Grace hotel, in the Litchfield County town of Washington, is embodied in its parklike setting, by its two-story antique-laden entrance foyer, and by its spa services that go well beyond massages, facials and miscellaneous scrubs and wraps. Luxury is also evident in its restaurant, Muse by Jonathan Cartwright, where candles and sterling silver salt and pepper shakers adorn linen-draped tables, and veranda seating overlooks an exquisitely manicured garden.

headline: Tom Tierney, Who Made Paper Dolls an Art Form, Dies at 85
text: Tom Tierney, who quite by accident found fame and fortune dressing — and undressing — notables from George Washington to Greta Garbo to Pope John Paul II, died on July 12 at his home in Smithville, Tex. Mr. Tierney, who almost single-handedly revived the lost art of paper-doll making, was 85.

headline: Dust Still Settling in Aftermath of Move by LeBron James
text: Nobody expected N.B.A. free agency to be dull or predictable, and even the leaguewide holding pattern as the game’s top player evaluated his options this month was fraught with intrigue. LeBron James was in control of the process, his decision to return to the Cleveland Cavaliers instantly setting in motion dozens of interconnected moves.

headline: Two Ex-Players Say Players Union Withheld Information
text: Two retired professional football players sued the N.F.L. Players Association for concealing from them information about the dangers of repeated head hits. The lawsuit filed on Thursday in United States District Court in Missouri echoes hundreds of similar cases against the N.F.L. and may represent a new front in the legal battle over concussions in sports.

headline: Ethiopia: Bloggers and Journalists Are Charged as Terrorists
text: Three Ethiopian journalists and six bloggers were charged with planning terrorist attacks during a court hearing in Addis Ababa on Friday morning, nearly three months after they were arrested. The charges, under a sweeping antiterrorism law passed in 2009, were dismissed by the defendants’ lawyer, Ameha Mekonnen, as lacking specificity. “If you read the text between the lines, it doesn’t make any sense,” he said. “It’s nonsense.” Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn of Ethiopia said late Friday, however, that the case had nothing to do with the defendants’ profession. “I don’t think becoming a blogger makes somebody immune, if someone involves into this terrorist network that destabilizes my country,” he said.

headline: Embrace the Fuzz of New Jersey’s Peaches
text: At Demarest Farms in Hillsdale, midsummer brings peach season, when Jason DeGise and James Spollen, the owners, are constantly reminded that the public can be out of touch with peaches in their natural state.

headline: NBC Correspondent Ayman Mohyeldin Is Returned to Gaza
text: Only days after NBC removed him from its coverage of the fighting in Gaza, the correspondent Ayman Mohyeldin will be reinstated and sent back into the region, the network said Friday evening.

headline: Central American Leaders to Meet Obama on Migrants
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has summoned the presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras to the White House next week in an effort to demonstrate high-level cooperation to stanch the flow of migrant children from Central America through Mexico and into the United States.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lake Street Dive, What I’m Doing Here
text: When I heard this I assumed it was an old standard — but no, Rachael Price wrote it, and the performance … well, just listen.

headline: Questions on Funding for Lawyer in Terror Case
text: Just months before a Libyan terrorism defendant is scheduled for trial in Manhattan, a dispute has arisen over who is paying his legal fees and whether his poor health would interfere with resolving that issue.

headline: Israel Ready to Expand Ground Forces
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that the Israeli military was ready for a “significant expansion” of ground forces in Gaza.

headline: Part-Time Schedules, Full-Time Headaches
text: A worker at an apparel store at Woodbury Common, an outlet mall north of New York City, said that even though some part-time employees clamored for more hours, the store had hired more part-timers and cut many workers’ hours to 10 a week from 20.

headline: ISIS Forces Last Iraqi Christians to Flee Mosul
text: BAGHDAD — By 1 p.m. on Friday almost every Christian in Mosul had heard the Sunni militants’ message — they had until noon Saturday to leave the city.

headline: When Settlement Buys Time
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Kevin Turner and Sean Morey played a combined 17 years in the N.F.L. They were never teammates, but they became friends in 2010 when they worked with the Mackey-White Traumatic Brain Injury Committee for disabled retirees. They consulted with doctors studying the effects of concussions on football players. Morey raised money for Turner’s foundation after Turner received a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., four years ago.

headline: From a Local Artist, the Great Outdoors
text: In 2009, Beth E. Levinthal, the executive director of the Hofstra University Museum, received an intriguing call from a member of the family of Don Resnick, a Long Island landscape painter who had died the year before at age 80: Would the museum, the caller wondered, like to be given a few of the artist’s paintings?

headline: A Classroom Leaves the Syllabus to the Students
text: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — The scene in a cavernous building atop a forested hill here resembles a brainy, free-form summer camp, or a loft where twentysomethings meet to pursue esoteric dreams. It does not look like the usual notion of college.

headline: Astros Fail to Sign Top Pick; Holliday Paces Cards to Win
text: On June 5, the night of the baseball draft, Reid Ryan, the Houston Astros’ president of business operations, tweeted a photo of a Brady Aiken jersey in a team gift shop.

headline: Pakistan’s Struggle Against Polio
text: The campaign in Pakistan to contain an uncontrolled outbreak of polio hit an alarming point this week when the nation’s tally of new cases exceeded last year’s total of 93, with months to go in the emergency effort to vaccinate children over fierce opposition from the Taliban.

headline: New Art at Parrish: Theater
text: Since opening its sleek, barnlike headquarters on the East End two years ago, the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill has expanded its cultural agenda to include circus arts, jazz and yoga. Now the museum can add live theater to the mix. This month it will present the world premiere of an adaptation of the 1985 Kurt Vonnegut novel “Galápagos.”

headline: At Long Last, Justice for Ronnie White
text: In Congress, as in life, circumstances seldom collide to allow correction of a glaring injustice. Yet that is what happened in the Senate on Wednesday, when the chamber confirmed Ronnie White for a seat on the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.

headline: General Motors Resists Expanding Victims’ Fund
text: The cars are different, but the circumstances surrounding their recall are strikingly similar.

headline: Arizona: Mom of Boys Left in Car May Be Spared Charge
text: A prosecutor has agreed to drop felony child abuse charges against Shanesha Taylor, 35, a homeless mother who left her two sons in a hot car while she went to a job interview, if she completes parenting and substance abuse treatment programs and sets up trust funds for her children. The money is to come from the $115,000 donated to Ms. Taylor after her case drew national attention.  Bill Montgomery, the Maricopa County attorney, said the deal would hold Ms. Taylor accountable “while also recognizing the best interests of her family.” She is seeking to regain custody of her children, who were placed in foster care after her arrest.

headline: G.M. Rebuked in the Senate
text: A consistent theme in the emerging revelations about General Motors’ deadly ignition switch has been the central role the company’s legal department played in concealing the problem from the public, government safety regulators and purchasers for more than a decade.

headline: Israel’s War in Gaza
text: After 10 days of aerial bombardment, Israel sent tanks and ground troops into Gaza to keep Hamas from pummeling Israeli cities with rockets and carrying out terrorist attacks via underground tunnels. The tragedy is that innocent civilians on both sides of the border are paying the price, once again, and that military action will not guarantee long-term stability or peace.

headline: Padres’ Offense May Go Down as Worst Ever
text: Because of baseball’s long history, there is usually comfort in knowing that as bad as it gets for your team, there is almost always some other club that was worse. But the 2014 San Diego Padres might not have that consolation. At this point, their awful offense is about as bad as any in history, and there are still more than 60 games to be played.

headline: Downing of Jet Exposes Defects of Flight Precautions Over Ukraine
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — As this Southeast Asian nation mourns the loss of scores of passengers aboard another lost Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200, the precautions instituted by the aviation authorities and flight planners to protect commercial aviation along the Russian-Ukrainian border have been shown to be catastrophically insufficient.

headline: Stop. Hey, What’s That Sound?
text: If, as the sound artist Stephan Moore likes to say, the laptop has become the 21st-century folk instrument, then the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah has propelled itself to the forefront of that development, commissioning and bringing to its 90-acre campus an exhibition of sound art featuring 10 works by 11 laptop-wielding artists.

headline: The $300,000 Drug
text: Kalydeco is truly a wonder drug.

headline: For High School Senior, It’s Clarinet First, Then Homework
text: Phillip H. Solomon, a senior at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose, did not expect to win a position as a clarinetist in the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America.  “Every young musician I know had applied,” Mr. Solomon, 16, said.

headline: UConn to Pay $1.3 Million to End Suit on Rape Cases
text: The University of Connecticut will pay $1.28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by five students who charged that the university had treated their claims of sexual assault and harassment with indifference, the two sides announced on Friday in a joint statement.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 18, 2014
The Netherlands, a Nation in Mourning but Mindful of Ties to Russia
text: AMSTERDAM — Flags flew at half-staff Friday in this small but extremely international country, one that is accustomed to standing on the forefront of global cultural debates over such things as gay rights, euthanasia and marijuana policies. But on Thursday, after the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the Netherlands found itself thrust squarely into an unaccustomed role at the center of the realpolitik of the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Next Gold Rush: Legal Marijuana Feeds Entrepreneurs’ Dreams
text: DENVER — Like the glint of gold or rumors of oil in ages past, the advent of legal, recreational marijuana is beginning to reshape economies in Colorado and Washington State.

headline: Presidents Find Occasions, Far More than Occasionally, for Proclamations
text: WASHINGTON — The White House on May 30 issued a proclamation formally declaring June as Great Outdoors Month. President Obama reaffirmed his commitment to preserving the nation’s lands and waters, and urged all Americans to “explore the great outdoors.”

headline: Relaxed Thief Is Videotaped as He Browses
text: There is a white board marked “Food for Thought” inside the office door at Red Rabbit, a business that sells healthy meals for schoolchildren, and every morning an employee jots an inspirational or funny quotation with a marker. The board served a less whimsical purpose on July 4.

headline: With Grief on Top of Grief, Malaysians Are Tested on Flight 370’s Lessons
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Still raw from the loss of one airliner four months ago, Malaysians on Friday confronted the improbable loss of another passenger jet, this time the victim of a conflict far from home.

headline: A Young Mother, Damaged by the War
text: The problem of sexual abuse in the American military system is the subject of “Soldier’s Heart,” a new drama by Tammy Ryan. This sometimes compelling play is currently presented in Union by Premiere Stages, which produced her “Lost Boy Found in Whole Foods” in 2010.

headline: A Mother Asks Obama: ‘Please Remember My Amir’
text: The mother of Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent imprisoned in Tehran for nearly three years, has written to President Obama, asking him to “please remember my Amir” in the negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program.

headline: For the G.O.P., Fine Line Seen on Migration
text: WASHINGTON — In 1996, when a surge in illegal immigration collided with the overheated politics of a presidential election, Republicans demanded a strict crackdown.

headline: Rebels in Ukraine Crowed of Past Attacks, but Deny This One
text: GRABOVO, Ukraine — A blast from a shoulder-fired rocket takes down a Ukrainian military transport plane on its landing approach, killing 49 people. Twenty-three Ukrainian soldiers are slaughtered by Russian-made Grad rockets. An AN-26 military plane is shot down at 21,000 feet, an altitude reachable only by a sophisticated surface-to-air missile with radar guidance.

headline: A Week of Agony, From Eastern Ukraine to the Gaza Strip
text: There are times when the endless crises and conflicts of our times reach such paroxysms of senseless tragedy that the world cries out for a halt.

headline: Across a Grocery Chain, a Labor Protest in Support of a Manager
text: TEWKSBURY, Mass. — It was a highly unusual sight: business executives in suits alongside warehouse workers wearing tank tops, all rallying against changes in the management of their employer, a successful New England supermarket chain. But allied they were this week in an unusual labor action, fallout from the latest chapter in a decades-old family feud that pits two Arthurs against each other.

headline: Where the Lowing Herd Wind Slowly
text: Administrivial Alert! In the Sunday, July 20 main puzzle, there will be a note that reads: “The answer to each starred clue must have two consecutive letters removed before it is written into the grid. These letters will move to a pair of circles elsewhere in the puzzle. (In all cases, new words will be formed.) The nine letter pairs, when properly arranged, will spell an appropriate answer at 72-Across.”

headline: Fleeing Amid Airstrikes, Gazans Find Few Places to Be Safe
text: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip — They fled by night, using their cellphones as flashlights on pitch-black roads as Israeli shells whistled around them. They carried a white flag and dragged crying children at a trot, a family of 25 headed for a relative’s house farther into the Gaza Strip.

headline: Otto Piene, German Artist of New Modes, Dies at 85
text: Otto Piene, a German painter and sculptor known for his experiments in kinetic art and for working at the junction of art, nature and technology, died on Thursday in Berlin, where he was attending the opening of a retrospective of his work. He was 86 and had homes in Düsseldorf and Groton, Mass.

headline: A Dialogue Between Hemispheres
text: An exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich has fostered an unusual cross-cultural dialogue between artists in two capitals of the contemporary art world.

headline: Vikings Say Report Contradicts Many of Kluwe’s Claims
text: The Minnesota Vikings said on Friday that a six-month investigation had refuted many of the charges made by the team’s former punter, Chris Kluwe, who claimed that he was released in 2013 in retaliation for his support of same-sex marriage.

headline: Corrections: July 19, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 9:30 P.M. (History) THE UNKNOWN KNOWN (2013) The director Errol Morris and the former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld square off in a battle of wits and words on topics including truth, power, torture and the Iraq war as Mr. Rumsfeld, above, reads aloud from a dozen or so of the most memorable memos — or “snowflakes,” as they were known at the Pentagon — he composed during his six-year tenure in the administration of George W. Bush. “Yes, it is a probing and unsettling inquiry into the recent political and military history of the United States, but it is also a bracing and invigorating philosophical skirmish,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The tension between those two registers — between hard facts about state violence and devilish abstractions about causes and consequences — is what gives the film some of its energy and suspense.” The film, he added, “is a cat-and-mouse game in which each player thinks he’s the cat, making it both thrilling and disconcerting to watch. It is also a nature documentary about behavior at the very top of the imperial food chain and a detective story about the search for a mystery that is hidden in plain sight.”

headline: Bilbo Baggins Slept Here
text: It’s dinner and a movie … set. The Hobbiton Movie Set in New Zealand, as seen in the screen adaptations of J. R. R. Tolkien’s “Lord of the Rings” trilogy and “The Hobbit,” is offering night tours of Bilbo Baggins’s homeland.

headline: Among the Victims: One U.S. Citizen and a Dutch Student at Indiana
text: To those who knew her at Indiana University, Karlijn Keijzer seemed to excel at everything she did, from her work as a doctoral student in chemistry to her leadership on the university’s rowing team.

headline: Mets Stay Hot as d’Arnaud Delivers Early and Late
text: SAN DIEGO — Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ prized young catcher, might have added a useful tool during his trip to the minor leagues last month: patience.

headline: Income Inequality Is Not Rising Globally. It's Falling.
text: Income inequality has surged as a political and economic issue, but the numbers don’t show that inequality is rising from a global perspective. Yes, the problem has become more acute within most individual nations, yet income inequality for the world as a whole  has been falling for most of the last 20 years. It’s a fact that hasn’t been noted often enough.

headline: Despite Israeli Push in Gaza, Hamas Fighters Slip Through Tunnels
text: GAZA CITY — Eight Palestinian militants emerged from a tunnel some 300 yards inside Israel on Saturday morning, armed with automatic weapons and wearing Israeli military uniforms, the Israeli military said. The gunmen fired a rocket-propelled grenade at two Israeli military jeeps on patrol, starting a battle that killed two Israeli officers and one of the militants, according to the military. The rest then retreated underground, back to Gaza.

headline: Analytics: The G.O.P. Idea Machine
text: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 20 issue of the magazine.

headline: Ukraine Says It Can Prove Russia Supplied Arms System That Felled Jet
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian government said on Saturday that it had proof that Russia had provided the surface-to-air missile system that shot down a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet over eastern Ukraine on Thursday, killing all 298 people aboard.

headline: U.S. Drone Kills 15 Militants in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Fifteen militants were killed early Saturday morning when an American drone struck a compound in the Pakistani tribal region of North Waziristan, according to local residents and a security official. It was the fourth known drone strike in the region since Pakistan launched a military operation there last month.

headline: Scientists Begin to Demystify Hole Found in Siberian Permafrost
text: After a flood of speculation — meteorite collision, methane explosion related to gas drilling, UFO — following the discovery of a gaping crater in the permafrost near big gas fields on the Yamal peninsula in Siberia, scientists are starting to offer more informed views.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, July 20
text: “The first step to building the right organization for our ambitions is to realign our work force.”

headline: Kat Cole of Cinnabon, on Questioning Success More Than Failure
text: This interview with Kat Cole, president of Cinnabon, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Job That Keeps Playing in My Head
text: This is what I remember about my year selling real estate: My boss couldn’t stop singing. Every morning after he arrived at the office in Coralville, Iowa, he would collect his mail, visit the coffee maker, go to the men’s room — all while spouting a medley of 1980s classic rock.

headline: Many Are Knocking, but the Door Stays Closed
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Who Routinely Trounces the Stock Market? Try 2 Out of 2,862 Funds
text: When the stock market rose 30 percent in 2013, plenty of fund managers had a triumphant year.

headline: Avoiding Roommate Shock, Online
text: Before Daniel Stompor arrived on campus last fall for his first year at Northwestern University, he went on Facebook, looking for a roommate.

headline: Sometimes, Early Birds Are Too Early
text: Since the advent of the deadline, procrastinators have suffered society’s barbs for putting off until later what needs doing now. But it turns out that many people appear to be finishing things sooner than they need to get them done. They are “precrastinators,” researchers say.

headline: Your Rights, Buried in Paperwork
text: When shareholders receive takeover bids for their companies, they may feel like celebrating. But what if the buyout price doesn’t fully reflect a fair value for the company?

headline: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Passenger Manifest
text: Here is a list of the passengers and crew members aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 17. The Times is also compiling profiles of the victims. If you knew someone on the flight, you are invited to share your recollections.

headline: Victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17
text: Among the 298 people aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 were a renowned AIDS researcher, a Dutch senator and an Australian novelist.

headline: Renovating a Kitchen as a Renter
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Lights, Camera, Action . . . Vacation!
text: Rome’s tourists are venerated and degraded in “La Grande Bellezza” (“The Great Beauty”), a film by the Italian director Paolo Sorrentino that won this year’s Oscar for best foreign film. Whatever its views of visitors, the movie acts as an irresistible invitation to the Eternal City’s more subtly beguiling attractions, as its suave protagonist and the audience are coolly guided through hidden courtyards, historic palazzos and less-frequented works of architecture.

headline: Struggling to Keep Afghan Girl Safe After a Mullah Is Accused of Rape
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — It was bad enough that the alleged rape took place in the sanctity of a mosque, and that the accused man was a mullah who invoked the familiar defense that it had been consensual sex.

headline: To Prevent Surprise Bills, New Health Law Rules Could Widen Insurer Networks
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and state insurance regulators are developing stricter standards to address the concerns of consumers who say that many health plans under the Affordable Care Act have unduly limited their choices of doctors and hospitals, leaving them with unexpected medical bills.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — You don’t really need me for this. Split Decisions are the easiest variety puzzles to learn because all you have to do is to start dropping letters into the squares and try to make them make pairs of words until you can drop your writing tool and say, “There. I did it.”

headline: Investor Eases Money Pressure on American Apparel
text: American Apparel took another step away from a financial precipice this week when an investment firm bought a $10 million loan that had threatened to set off a string of defaults.

headline: A Family Feud, Uncorked in Spain
text: When Pablo Álvarez began sending invitations to a recent 150th anniversary party for Vega Sicilia, the historic winery he runs in the Ribera del Duero region of Spain, he offered one to his estranged father, David Álvarez, who bought the winery in 1982. The party was sure to be a blowout, with 700 guests — including Soraya Sáenz de Santamaría, the deputy prime minister of Spain, along with fans of the winery like Kurt Russell, Goldie Hawn and Kate Hudson — and with food provided by El Celler de Can Roca, a restaurant in Catalonia that is considered one of the world’s best.

headline: Brothers Provide Italy With Relief on the Golf Course, at Least
text: HOYLAKE, England — Edoardo Molinari stood on a podium in the scoring area answering questions about his second round while, on a television situated a few feet to his left, a live feed of the players still on the course showed his brother, Francesco, finishing his round.

headline: Staying the Course on Iran by Threatening Pain and Offering Relief
text: Behind President Obama’s decision on Friday to extend the Iran nuclear negotiations for four more months is a calculation that the administration has the mix of pressure and incentives just about right: That by keeping the most damaging sanctions, but giving Tehran a taste of what access to its overseas cash reserves might mean, a deal is possible.

headline: Russia Expands List of Barred Americans
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s Foreign Ministry announced Saturday that it was expanding its list of Americans barred from the country, including a congressman and several senior military officers.

headline: No Credit? No Problem
text: Banks and private equity firms searching for high-yield investments have fueled a boom in subprime auto loans to buyers who can’t afford them, including those who recently filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Unlike the Weather, McIlroy Shows No Mercy
text: HOYLAKE, England — Despite ominous predictions and extreme measures, thunder and lightning never materialized to threaten the players during the third round at the British Open.

headline: In a Subprime Bubble for Used Cars, Borrowers Pay Sky-High Rates
text: Rodney Durham stopped working in 1991, declared bankruptcy and lives on Social Security. Nonetheless, Wells Fargo lent him $15,197 to buy a used Mitsubishi sedan.

headline: Jeter, Like Duncan, Makes the Routine Extraordinary
text: Like a runner leading off first base with a notion of stealing second, Derek Jeter leaned his right shoulder in the direction of the players’ private area of the Yankees’ clubhouse. In front of his conveniently situated dressing stall, eager to escape, he said, “I only got a minute.”

headline: The Future of Robot Caregivers
text: EACH time I make a house call, I stay much longer than I should. I can’t leave because my patient is holding my hand, or because she’s telling me, not for the first time, about when Aunt Mabel cut off all her hair and they called her a boy at school, or how her daddy lost his job and the lights went out and her mother lit pine cones and danced and made everyone laugh. Sometimes I can’t leave because she just has to show me one thing, but getting to that thing requires that she rise unsteadily from her chair, negotiate her walker through the narrow hallway, and find whatever it is in the dim light of her bedroom.

headline: With Jet Strike, War in Ukraine Is Felt Globally
text: WASHINGTON — From the start, the telephone call did not go well. Dispensing with pleasantries, President Vladimir V. Putin launched into an edgy and long-winded complaint about the new American sanctions imposed on Russia the day before.

headline: In Mexico, a Stalled Journey
text: While thousands of child migrants from Central America have crossed the Rio Grande to U.S. soil, thousands more don’t make it that far. Many end up detained or broke in towns like Reynosa, Mexico.

headline: Rush to Deport Young Migrants Could Trample Asylum Claims
text: HARLINGEN, Tex. — The first time her aunt in Mexico took her out at night, the young teenager was told they were headed to a party.

headline: 5 Bombs Explode in Baghdad as Dispute Continues With Jordan
text: BAGHDAD — Five bombs exploded in the Iraqi capital on Saturday, killing 30 people, as tensions continued between Baghdad and Jordan, signaling the inexorable spillover of Iraq’s troubles to the region.

headline: Superpowers of the Web
text: Readers respond to a July 16 letter from Marc Rotenberg, an Internet privacy expert, calling on policy makers to examine the business practices of dominant Internet companies like Facebook and Google.

headline: Sticking to His Travel Plans, at Risk of Looking Bad
text: WASHINGTON — As smoke billowed from the downed Malaysian jetliner in the fields of eastern Ukraine on Thursday, President Obama pressed ahead with his schedule: a cheeseburger with fries at the Charcoal Pit in Delaware, a speech about infrastructure and two splashy fund-raisers in New York City.

headline: Midsummer Event, Midseason Form for SEC Fans
text: HOOVER, Ala. — Harrison Flick, 21, stood in a hotel lobby in this strip-mall suburb, wearing a Mississippi State football jersey. He was stoic about being the only Bulldogs fan in a sparse crowd Tuesday, the second morning of the Southeastern Conference’s media days.

headline: The Media Merger Arms Race
text: The news that 21st Century Fox recently offered to buy Time Warner for $80 billion should make clear — if there had been any doubt — that consolidation in the media and communications industries begets more consolidation.

headline: Payday Lenders Set the Debt Trap
text: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has already taken important steps to protect consumers in mortgage transactions and has established oversight of student loans, credit reporting agencies and debt collectors. Now the bureau is formulating rules to protect borrowers from unscrupulous payday lenders. The payday industry bills itself as a source of convenient, short-term loans, but the business model depends on trapping people into borrowing again and again, paying onerous fees as they go.

headline: Bottlenecks in Training Doctors
text: The new head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Sloan Gibson, told a Senate committee last week that he needed $17.6 billion over the next three years to hire some 1,500 doctors, 8,500 nurses and other clinicians to reduce the unconscionably long waiting times that many veterans now endure before they are able to see a doctor.

headline: Shekhar Garde
text: Shekhar Garde is an Indian-born chemical engineer at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. He studies the role of water in the creation of life and is a pioneer in animating molecular dynamics, producing a 3-D Imax film called “Molecules to the Max.”

headline: Who’s Right and Wrong in the Middle East?
text: WITH Israeli troops again invading Gaza and the death toll rising, some of the rhetoric from partisans on each side is oddly parallel. Maybe it’s time to correct a few common misconceptions among the salvos flying back and forth.

headline: Our Love Affair With the Mug Shot
text: A YOUNG man faces the camera, shaved head, white tee. The rigid lines of the jaw and cheekbones are softened by the gentle curve of full lips. The hard tattoos slashing up the neck are sweetened by the fading teardrop inked under one eye. And those eyes: pale blue and looking directly at you.

headline: Real Adventurers Read Maps
text: CALL me a fossil, but when I take a road trip I like to get around by using printed maps. I’ve been licensed to drive for 20 years, and every car I’ve owned has contained a Rand McNally Road Atlas, with the maps of the Northeastern states dog-eared and loosened from their staples. Navigating by map carries over to foreign roads, too. In May my wife and I went to France, where we drove around Provence and dipped a wheel into Italy.

headline: The Parent Trap
text: WHEN I was about 9 years old, I graduated to a Little League whose diamonds were a few miles from our house, in a neighborhood that got rougher after dark. After one practice finished early, I ended up as the last kid left with the coach, waiting in the gloaming while he grumbled, looked at his watch and finally left me — to wait or walk home, I’m not sure which.

headline: Offering Clarity, but Blurring Lines, Too
text: WHEN Nate Silver left The Times last year for ESPN, it was not a happy moment for top editors. The statistical guru and political prognosticator had been extremely popular with readers and had brought a new audience to the paper and its website.

headline: A Popular President
text: WASHINGTON — THE thing about him is, he just keeps going.

headline: And Now for a Bit of Good News . . .
text: From Ukraine to the Middle East, some bad actors — Hamas, Vladimir Putin and Israeli settlers to name but a few — are trying to bury the future with the past and divide people. Instead of focusing on them even more, I prefer to write about a company that is burying the past with the future, and actually bringing strangers together.

headline: The End of ‘Genius’
text: WHERE does creativity come from? For centuries, we’ve had a clear answer: the lone genius. The idea of the solitary creator is such a common feature of our cultural landscape (as with Newton and the falling apple) that we easily forget it’s an idea in the first place.

headline: The Sage Grouse Versus Industry
text: A conservation effort across the West to protect the sage grouse, a bird with an unusual mating call, has put different environmental interests at odds.

headline: What Writers Can Learn From ‘Goodnight Moon’
text: I gave birth to twins a little more than a year ago, and at the baby showers we received many books: colorful board books, big illustrated books, collections of Sandra Boynton and nursery rhymes and Dr. Seuss, but none multiple times except this one: a board book “Goodnight Moon,” a flimsy “Goodnight Moon,” a large lap book “Goodnight Moon,” and an anthology by the book’s author, Margaret Wise Brown. Of course, I thought. It’s that one that says good night a lot. I figured I’d read it before, just a story of going around the room saying good night to stuff, and I thought it was popular as a gift because it’s so appropriate for bedtime and everybody wants babies to sleep.

headline: Frack Quietly, Please: Sage Grouse Is Nesting
text: CASPER, Wyo. — In a new oil field among the rolling hills near here, Chesapeake Energy limits truck traffic to avoid disturbing the breeding and nesting of a finicky bird called the greater sage grouse. To the west, on a gas field near Yellowstone National Park, Shell Oil is sowing its own special seed mix to grow plants that nourish the birds and hide their chicks from predators.

headline: A Golf Hazard on the Way to a Tournament
text: HOYLAKE, England — On the first leg of Gary Woodland’s British Open odyssey, he glanced out the airplane porthole in time to see a baggage handler at Kansas City International Airport haul his golf bag out of a cart, drop it on the tarmac and fling another suitcase on top of it. The sight of the tools of his trade being treated with such little care made Woodland so agitated that his fiancée told him to turn away from the window.

headline: Usher Signals
text: Many ushers communicate during church services using a sequence of hand signals called the “National Silent Uniform System.” Here are some of the central elements of these signals.

headline: Influx of South Americans Drives Miami’s Reinvention
text: MIAMI — As the World Cup played out over the past month, yellow-clad Colombians packed the Kukaramakara nightclub downtown, Aguila beers in hand, shouting, “Colombia, Colombia!” Outside, Brazilians in car caravans blasted samba music. Argentines, some in blue-and-white striped jerseys, jammed into nearby steakhouses and empanada joints. Around town, children filed into Sunday Mass, their jerseys ablaze with their futbol heroes from across Latin America.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 20
text: With two foreign crises — the Malaysia Airlines plane downed in Ukraine and the Israeli ground invasion in the Gaza Strip — erupting, Secretary of State John Kerry will appear on five Sunday talk shows, on ABC, CBS, CNN, NBC, and Fox News.

headline: On Southern Border, Mexico Faces Crisis of Its Own
text: TENOSIQUE, Mexico — For years, Mexico’s most closely watched border was its northern one, which generations of Mexican migrants have crossed seeking employment and refuge in the United States.

headline: In Remote Corners of India, Immunity for Soldiers Who Kill and Rape Civilians
text: MAYAI LEIKAI, India — A dozen soldiers burst through the front and back doors of a small home here in the middle of a July night, dragged Thangjam Manorama into a room and began to torture her. Her older brother tried to stop them and was badly beaten. Her mother rose to defend her and was knocked unconscious.

headline: Pathogen Mishaps Rise as Regulators Stay Clear
text: The recently documented mistakes at federal laboratories involving anthrax, flu and smallpox have incited public outrage at the government’s handling of dangerous pathogens. But the episodes were just a tiny fraction of the hundreds that have occurred in recent years across a sprawling web of academic, commercial and government labs that operate without clear national standards or oversight, federal reports show.

headline: Second Day’s Effort Pays for a Climber From Poland
text: RISOUL, France — For Rafal Majka, persistence paid off on Saturday. The day before, Majka, a Polish climbing specialist, found himself off the front of the final Alpine climb of a Tour de France stage with Leopold Konig, a Czech rider. But the two fell victim to a show of force from the Tour leader, Vincenzo Nibali, who passed them for the win.

headline: Making the N.F.L.’s Biggest Screens
text: Shahid Khan is the owner of the Jacksonville Jaguars, a team that hasn’t made the playoffs since the 2007 season. He is spending $20 million of his own money on the biggest end-zone video displays.

headline: Vows | An Imperfect Beginning
text: Vince Taylor and Rebekah Gordon moved slowly and deliberately from friendship to romance. Because in the balance were Mr. Taylor’s children and the breakup of his existing marriage.

headline: New Dimension in Scoreboard Watching
text: BROOKINGS, S.D. — The seemingly endless prairie that blankets this part of the United States would seem to be an unlikely place for one of the largest makers of sports video displays, Daktronics. After all, the nearest big-league ballpark is a four-hour drive from this town, which has barely enough residents to fill any of the arenas and stadiums where the high-tech screens are fixtures.

headline: Arsenal Refilled, a New Yankee Throws a Gem
text: During his time with the Arizona Diamondbacks, Brandon McCarthy was told by the team to stop throwing his cut fastball, a pitch that had been essential to his success over the years.

headline: Readers Comment on my Middle East Column
text: My Sunday column is about the Middle East crisis and the Israeli incursion into Gaza—but, more fundamentally, about the way hardliners on each side have dominated the narrative and created conditions in which hardliners on the other side are empowered. And the reasonable folks, such as Mahmoud Abbas on the Palestinian side and the Labor Party and liberal civil society on the Israeli side, become somewhat marginalized.

headline: Jury Awards $23.6 Billion in Florida Smoking Case
text: MIAMI — A jury in northwestern Florida awarded a staggering $23 billion judgment late Friday against the country’s second-largest tobacco company for causing the death of a chain smoker who died of lung cancer at the age of 36.

headline: Palestinians Find Show of Support Lacking From Arab Leaders Amid Offensive
text: CAIRO — Three years ago there was a hope that a growing movement for democracy might make Arab countries more supportive of the Palestinians, as governments grew more responsive to the people and their demands.

headline: Before Leaving Tour de France, a Rider Displays a Champion’s Endurance
text: Andrew Talansky, one of the United States’ top road cyclists, never expected to spend the second half of the Tour de France on a lounge chair at his pool in Girona, Spain, with an ice pack chilling his ailing back and gauze covering several spots on his body now missing layers of skin.

headline: Attack Kills at Least 21 Egyptian Soldiers at Checkpoint in Western Desert
text: CAIRO — At least 21 Egyptian soldiers were killed on Saturday when heavily armed gunmen attacked a border guard post near a remote desert oasis, according to an army spokesman.

headline: Always Inflation Somewhere
text: Whenever you point out that the hyperinflation the usual suspects have been predicting for the past 6 years hasn’t materialized, you get a rash of comments declaring that yes it has, the government is just lying about the statistics. One answer — aside from come on, how do you think that works? — is that independent measures, like the Billion Price Index, aren’t very different from the official index. Still, people will point to the price of something that has gone up as evidence that we have lots of inflation.

headline: A Three-Sibling Rivalry Extends to the Pro Ranks
text: As the father of three competitive, athletic sons, Jeff Seager knows well the joys — and the perils — of raising a family around sports. Pickup games could be a problem.

headline: Behind the Tour de France, the Teams Pursue a Quest for Next Year’s Sponsorships
text: GRENOBLE, France — When Gerry Ryan, an Australian businessman, was asked why he owns a professional cycling team, he replied with a wry laugh.

headline: Shake-Up on Opium Island
text: Now is the sowing season for opium poppies in the Australian state of Tasmania. Tractors chug up and down paddocks, pulling elaborate machinery that drills pairs of adjacent, miniature holes in the dirt, and then drops a dozen tiny kernels of fertilizer in one of the holes and a tiny poppy seed in the other.

headline: Moving Parts
text: Administrivial Alert  In today’s puzzle, there will be a note in most versions that reads: “The answer to each starred clue must have two consecutive letters removed before it is written into the grid. These letters will move to a pair of circles elsewhere in the puzzle. (In all cases, new words will be formed.) The nine letter pairs, when properly arranged, will spell an appropriate answer at 72-Across.”

headline: Stranded at the Border
text: Mexico is trying to slow down the flow of migrants coming though its southern border by detaining them, and sometimes deporting them back to its Central American neighbors.

headline: An Honors Assembly for a Coach’s Pupils
text: HOYLAKE, England — With his thinning hair and his thickening waistline, Butch Harmon has a way of blending into the crowd when he follows his players’ competitive rounds on foot. On Saturday at the British Open, though, there was no missing him.

headline: Young South Korean Rolls, Then Teeters on 2nd Nine
text: HOYLAKE, England — As Byeong-Hun An found out Saturday during the third round of the British Open, learning how to contend in the majors is like learning how to ride a bike.

headline: Prized Prospect Turns Into a Must-Watch Rookie, Quickly, for the Reds
text: Against the Pittsburgh Pirates recently in Cincinnati, the rookie center fielder Billy Hamilton, leading off for the Reds, dropped a bunt down the first-base line. The bunt appeared to be poorly executed, hit too sharply to first. The fielder, Gaby Sanchez, fielded it cleanly and intercepted Hamilton’s path to the bag. But Hamilton was gone.

headline: Yehuda Nir, a Psychiatrist and Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 84
text: Dr. Yehuda Nir, a psychiatrist whose childhood was shaped by having to masquerade as a Roman Catholic in German-occupied Poland to escape Nazi persecution, an ordeal that he turned into a well-received memoir and that guided him in treating victims of trauma, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Complaints About Chokeholds Are Focus of Study
text: The city agency that investigates allegations of police misconduct is studying the more than 1,000 complaints it has received in recent years about police officers using chokeholds, the agency said on Saturday, two days after a man died following a police encounter in which the hold appeared to be used.

headline: As They Assess Needs, Mets Show Shortcomings
text: SAN DIEGO — When Travis d’Arnaud slapped a two-out, full-count, letter-high fastball from Joaquin Benoit into right field in the ninth inning Friday night, he did more than drive in Curtis Granderson for the winning run in the Mets’ 5-4 victory over the San Diego Padres.

headline: Champion’s Luck Runs Out at His Favorite Tournament
text: Fabiano Caruana of Italy took the early lead at the Sparkassen Chess Meeting in Dortmund, Germany, by winning three of his first four games, while Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, who has won the title 10 times, had a rocky start.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 19, 2014
Teenagers Zverev and Konjuh Find Success in a Veteran-Dominated Sport
text: Two teenagers each reached the semifinals of tournaments this week, crashing parties that have been restricted to much older crowds in recent years.

headline: In Hospitals Across Gaza, Scenes of Chaos and Grief
text: JABALIYA CAMP, Gaza Strip — The ambulance at Kamal Adwan, the main hospital in the northern Gaza Strip, already had turned on its sirens to move a critically injured man to a better-equipped hospital. Several women blocked its way, one of them clinging to the vehicle and trying to open the side door. Only when she fainted from emotion could the ambulance leave.

headline: Some Backlash in Texas to the Housing of Children Crossing the Border
text: City Councilwoman Heidi Thiess of League City swung into action shortly after she saw media reports of Central American children sleeping in cramped detention centers along the Texas-Mexico border.

headline: Texas Sheriffs Mull Selling E-Cigarettes to Inmates
text: As a way to allow some inmates to get their nicotine fix and sheriffs to shore up tight budgets, county jails across the country have begun selling electronic cigarettes. Though the trend has largely bypassed Texas, jail officials say that could change as sheriffs begin to warm up to the smokeless technology.

headline: A Taste for Craft Beers in Rural Texas
text: ALPINE — More than 400 people gathered this month just outside Alpine in a windswept part of Far West Texas to sample craft beer and celebrate the expansion of the Big Bend Brewing Company.

headline: State Weighs Restructuring Health Plans for Women
text: Texas lawmakers are looking for ways to fill the gaps in access to health care for the state’s poorest women, three years after making sharp cuts to the state’s family planning budget and rejecting a federally financed women’s health program in favor of their own.

headline: Lisa Baker, Gus Steadman
text: Lisa Marie Baker and William Angus Steadman II were married Saturday at North Beach Park in Ferrysburg, Mich. Bryan Robert Paul, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Kristen Bucaria, Daniel Fletcher
text: Kristen Marie Bucaria and Daniel Timothy Fletcher were married Monday in New York. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister who was ordained by the New Seminary, officiated at Cop Cot, a wooden shelter in Central Park.

headline: Marci Doucet, David McGovern
text: Marci Elizabeth Doucet and David Kavanagh McGovern were married Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church on St. John in the United States Virgin Islands. The Rev. Anthony B. Abraham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kathryn Hogan, Joshua Berger
text: Kathryn Patricia Hogan and Joshua Craig Berger were married Saturday at St. Paul’s University Chapel in Madison, Wis. The Rev. Carl Morello, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, with Rabbi James L. Sagarin taking part.

headline: Christina Crowe, Michael Nilson
text: Christina Hope Crowe and Michael Louis Nilson were married Saturday at St. Catharine’s Church, in Blauvelt, N.Y. Bishop Robert E. Guglielmone of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston, S.C., performed the ceremony.

headline: Jaclyn Simon, Brian Whittaker
text: Jaclyn Unis Simon and Brian James Whittaker were married Saturday in Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Joseph Mostardi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas of Villanova Church on the campus of Villanova University.

headline: Aparna Saraf and Omar Isani
text: Aparna Arvind Saraf, a daughter of Dr. Asha A. Saraf and Dr. Arvind N. Saraf of Moorestown, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Omar Ali Isani, the son of Dr. Shaheen Isani and Dr. Alamgir Isani of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Katherine Kurs, a minister at West-Park Presbyterian Church in New York, officiated at the Plaza in New York.

headline: Caroline Boeke and Alejandro Sanchez
text: Caroline Elizabeth Boeke and Alejandro Sanchez were married on Saturday at St. Katharine Drexel Summer Chapel in Harpswell, Me. The Rev. Frank Murray, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jodi Leib, Jonathan Coden
text: Jodi Rachelle Leib and Jonathan Daniel Coden were married Saturday at Temple Israel in West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Harold S. Loss performed the ceremony with Rabbi Paul M. Yedwab taking part.

headline: They’d Bet That Opposites Attract
text: Olivia Tess Cranin and Scott Adam Abramowitz were married Saturday evening at the Bridgehampton Tennis and Surf Club in Bridgehampton, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa Kingston, a friend of the groom, officiated.

headline: Jennifer Lin and Haoming Wang
text: Jennifer Michelle Lin and Haoming Wang were married Saturday evening at La Venta Inn in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. Roger Lundblade, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Emily Sanchez, Charles Ogalin
text: Emily Marie Sanchez and Charles Francis Ogalin were married Saturday at the St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church in Mystic, Conn. The Rev. Kevin M. Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, and the church’s pastor, led the ceremony.

headline: Divya Kumaraiah, Sachin Shah
text: Divya Kumaraiah and Dr. Sachin Jatin Shah were married Saturday in Chicago. Marina Alexandra Birch, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Drake Hotel, with Pandit Sree Aswath, a Hindu priest, leading a traditional Jain ceremony.

headline: Kate Gordon, Matthew Liegel
text: Kate Elizabeth Gordon and Matthew Aron Liegel were married Saturday in Toledo, Ohio. The Rev. Kathleen Guthrie Lonergan, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Toledo Club, in a ceremony that included Roman Catholic and Jewish elements.

headline: Angie Wen, Jeffrey Choi
text: Dr. Angie En Wen and Jeffrey Yatsai Choi were married Saturday at the Helen Mills Event Space and Theater in New York. Patrick Tripp, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Donna Ma and Kenda Gee
text: Donna Ma, the daughter of Ping J. Ma and Peter Y. D. Ma of Seattle, was married Saturday to Kenda D’man Gee, a son of Took N. Gee of Edmonton, Alberta, and the late Sui Kiu C. Gee. Judge Dean S. Lum of the Superior Court for King County, Wash., officiated at Tacoma Union Station in Tacoma, Wash.

headline: Maura Roosevelt and Joshua Fisher
text: Maura Amy Roosevelt, a daughter of Ann M. Roosevelt and James Roosevelt Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., is to be married Sunday to Joshua Louis Fisher, a son of Barbara J. Kent and Danny Fisher of Brooklyn. The Very Rev. Kevin J. O’Leary, a Roman Catholic priest and the rector of the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston, will officiate at Castle in the Clouds, a historic mansion and estate in Moultonborough, N.H., with Dennis P. Geller, a secular humanistic Jewish leader, taking part.

headline: Dominika Rozanski, Andrés DePalma
text: Dominika Victoria Rozanski, the daughter of Anna M. Rozanski and Waldemar A. Rozanski of Manville, N.J., was married Saturday to Dr. Anthony Andrés Rodriguez DePalma, a son of Miriam R. DePalma and Anthony R. DePalma of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Francis T. Maione, a Roman Catholic priest and the groom’s godfather, performed the ceremony at St. Cassian Roman Catholic Church in Montclair.

headline: Just Like in the Movies, Only Better
text: Caitlin Alexandra Johnson and Michael Gerald Dowd were married Saturday in New York. Donald J. Garamella, who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated at the Wythe Hotel.

headline: Elizabeth Brennan, Thomas Brennan
text: Elizabeth Walsh Brennan and Thomas Patrick Brennan were married Saturday. The Rev. Jeffrey T. Duaime officiated at Old St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Jennifer Costanza and Amy Shopkorn
text: Jennifer Anne Costanza and Amy Melissa Shopkorn were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Michael M. McSweeney, the New York City clerk, officiated.

headline: Sara Simmons, Philip Bartow
text: Sara Louise Simmons and Philip Key Bartow III were married Saturday at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Vincent G. Seadale, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Cummins, Todd Rethemeier
text: Jennifer Lynn Cummins and Todd John Rethemeier were married Saturday. Tulis McCall, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

headline: Regina Abramyan, Stephen Oswald
text: Regina Abramyan and Stephen Gerard Oswald were married Saturday. The Rev. Bartholomew Daly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Peace in Manhattan.

headline: Hayley Barna, Fredrik Maroe
text: Hayley Bay Barna and Fredrik Vik Maroe were married Saturday at Locusts-on-Hudson, a private estate and retreat in Staatsburg, N.Y. The Rev. Jude Smith, a minister ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary in New York, officiated.

headline: Kelley Taylor, Jason Baum
text: Katherine Kelley McNeill Taylor, the daughter of Susanne Dolan Taylor and K. McNeill Taylor Jr. of Chatham, Mass., was married Saturday to Jason Denson Baum, a son of Dr. Laura Denson Baum and Dr. Seth J. Baum of Boca Raton, Fla. Cantor Ann Turnoff officiated at Chatham Bars Inn in Chatham, Mass., with the Rev. Dr. Nicholas J. Boas taking part.

headline: Corrections: July 20, 2014
text: NEW YORK

headline: Neighborhood Ravaged on Deadliest Day So Far for Both Sides in Gaza
text: GAZA CITY — The mayhem began in the early hours of Sunday morning in Shejaiya, an eastern neighborhood of Gaza City, where Israeli forces battled with Hamas militants. Terrified civilians fled, sometimes past the bodies of those struck down in earlier artillery barrages. By dusk it was clear that Sunday was the deadliest single day for the Palestinians in the latest conflict and the deadliest for the Israeli military in years.

headline: As Anger Rises Over Crash, Malaysian Government Is Reluctant to Assign Blame
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia lost 43 citizens when a missile blasted Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 from the sky over eastern Ukraine, and the country’s anger is rising toward Russia following reports that victims’ bodies lie uncollected or have been mishandled — especially troubling news to Malaysia’s many Muslims, for whom prompt, solemn burial of the dead is sacred.

headline: With Poncho, Custom Weather Alerts That Say When to Pack an Umbrella
text: Every morning when I wake up, there’s a peppy text message waiting in my inbox, letting me know that the summer storms are over, and that the sky will be blue and clear for the day.

headline: Bodies From Malaysia Airlines Flight Are Stuck in Ukraine, Held Hostage Over Distrust
text: TOREZ, Ukraine — Three wrenching days after the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the bodies of most of those aboard have ended up here, in a fly-infested railway station in a rough coal-mining town in eastern Ukraine.

headline: James Garner, Witty, Handsome Leading Man, Dies at 86
text: James Garner, the wry and handsome leading man who slid seamlessly between television and the movies but was best known as the amiable gambler Bret Maverick in the 1950s western “Maverick” and the cranky sleuth Jim Rockford in the 1970s series “The Rockford Files,” died on Saturday night at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Immaculate Incarceration: A Baby in Solitary Confinement
text: At a time when most infants rock in cradles, take naps on grandma’s shoulder or play bouncy-bounce on a knee, I crawled around in a 4-by-6-foot concrete box the size of a small closet. Instead of the background lullaby from a pull toy in a crib, I would have heard “Chow time!” yelled through the slot in the steel door and then a slam — the food port in our prison cell in solitary confinement. I was born in prison; I spent part of the first year of my life in “the hole.”

headline: 1889: Jack The Ripper Said to Have Connection With Police
text: LONDON — One of the most interesting and, perhaps, significant points in connection with the murder of Alice Mackenzie is one to which much attention has not yet been called. At the time of the August, September and November murders last year the number of constables on patrol duty in what is known as the ‘‘murder district,’’ covered by Commercial street and Leman street stations, was strengthened by 100 extra men from other divisions. There were at that time 300 men in uniform and plain clothes on night duty in this comparatively small area. As the excitement died away this extra force was gradually diminished.

headline: De Blasio and Family Land in Rome, and the Cameras Start Snapping
text: ROME — Mayor Bill de Blasio was having a paparazzi moment.

headline: What Millennials Want Is Cookies Shaped Like Pizza
text: A new survey of young Americans’ political views has some saying millennials are “incoherent” or “confused.” One company, however, knows exactly what they want and is committed to giving it to them.

headline: Kerry Says Russia Trained Separatists to Use Antiaircraft Missiles
text: WASHINGTON — In presenting the most detailed case yet alleging Russia’s involvement in the Ukraine crisis, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Russia had funneled large quantities of heavy weapons to Ukrainian separatists and trained them how to operate SA-11 antiaircraft missiles, the type of system that is believed to have been used to shoot down the Malaysian airliner over eastern Ukraine.

headline: A Parent Answering a Call for Pre-K Teachers Goes Back to Work (and School)
text: Long before her campers tumble out of bed for breakfast, Lisa Martino is huddled over her kitchen table, poring over her graduate school textbooks and clack-clack-clacking on her laptop as she absorbs lessons on literacy and curriculum development.

headline: A Slow Weekend at Movie Theaters
text: “Sex Tape” failed to perform. “Planes: Fire & Rescue” flew a bit low. And the third major newcomer at North American movie theaters, “The Purge: Anarchy,” had a smaller body count than its grisly franchise predecessor. That left the weekend box office down 25 percent compared with the same three days last summer, as the No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada was a hold-over: “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” (20th Century Fox), which took in an estimated $36 million, for a two-week domestic total of about $140 million.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) LAST TANGO IN HALIFAX Distressing news prompts Alan (Derek Jacobi, above with Anne Reid) and Celia (Ms. Reid) to have another wedding ceremony and invite all of their family members and friends. In “Endeavour, Season 2: Neverland,” on “Masterpiece Mystery!” at 9, Detective Constable Endeavour Morse (Shaun Evans) finds the present colliding with the past — and discovers misconduct within both the police force and the upper echelons of Oxford society — when he investigates the cases of a missing boy, a dead journalist and an escaped prisoner in this season finale. And in “Vicious,” at 10:30, Freddie (Ian McKellen), Stuart (Mr. Jacobi) and their gang go clubbing.

headline: At 25, a New King of Timeworn Ground
text: HOYLAKE, England — By the standards of final British Open chapters, this was no major thriller, but it was not the relaxed Sunday stroll around Royal Liverpool that it might have been for Rory McIlroy.

headline: Kerry Expresses Frustration Over Civilian Toll in Gaza
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John F. Kerry strongly criticized Palestinian leaders on Sunday for rejecting a cease-fire plan, but he also appeared — in comments captured by a live microphone — to express exasperation with the high cost in civilian lives as Israel pressed its ground attack on Gaza.

headline: Bill Mulliken, Who Swam to Olympic Gold in 1960, Dies at 74
text: Bill Mulliken, a little-known college swimmer who outpaced national champions and the world-record holder in the 200-meter breaststroke to win gold in the 1960 Olympic Games, died on Thursday in Chicago. He was 74.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Cue Memories
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: 1964: Harlem Riots Flare Anew; 2 Negroes Shot
text: NEW YORK — For the third consecutive night police broke up an unruly, bottle-throwing crowd in the Negro community of Harlem tonight [July 20]. The steel-helmeted, nightstick-waving police scattered the two separate crowds without firing a pistol shot. Neither police nor members of the crowds were injured. Two Negroes were shot and wounded early today in clashes between roving gangs and scores of police. Bottles, rocks and Molotov cocktails rained down from tenement rooftops and smashed in the littered streets. In the weekend of riots, police said that one Negro was killed and 116 civilians and 18 policemen were injured. At least 45 stores were broken into and looted or damaged. The violence, and demands from civil-rights leaders that the city act to protect the Negroes, prompted the mayor’s office today to order a study of complaints of police brutality. Regular meetings between Harlem leaders and city officials were also arranged. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 21, 1964

headline: Today’s Students Don’t Have to Suffer if They Hate Their Roommates
text: Over the last few years, many colleges and universities have adopted online roommate matching programs that help incoming students look for and select their own first-year roommates. Like dating sites, the roommate analytics systems can match people based on preferences like music volume, sociability and even tolerance for snoring.

headline: Malaysian Plane’s Black Box Retrieved
text: The data recorder was recovered from the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine.

headline: It’s a Date. See You in Therapy.
text: “Very good, Martin.”

headline: A Thrilling Sprint Dashes a Dream and Snatches a Victory
text: NÎMES, France — The contrast could not have been greater. Jack Bauer was slumped against a railing, apparently in tears, teammates patting his back. Nearby, Alexander Kristoff was receiving hugs of congratulations for his second stage win of this year’s Tour de France.

headline: SA-11 Missile Unit
text: Ukraine’s Interior MInistry released a video of what it said was an SA-11 missile unit, headed for the Russian border, that may have been used to shoot down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

headline: Hoofing It From Hollywood
text: If you’ve seen a movie in the last 20 years, chances are you know the choreographer Marguerite Derricks’s work, if not her name. Austin Powers’s epic go-go dance through the streets? Ms. Derricks’s idea. Abigail Breslin’s climactic strip routine in “Little Miss Sunshine”? Ms. Derricks was just off camera, encouraging Ms. Breslin to claw like a tiger. Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt’s tango in “Mr. and Mrs. Smith”? Well, Ms. Derricks was Ms. Jolie’s first partner.

headline: A Man, a Van, a Plan
text: JERSEY CITY — A year after its opening, the Mana Contemporary arts complex, on 35 acres here, remains largely unknown to the artgoing public. So does the man for whom it’s named.

headline: This Constant Reinvention Called Life
text: These two things about Amy Bloom’s surprise-filled “Lucky Us” are indisputable: It opens with a terrific hook and closes with an image of exquisite resolution. But that opening sets off a string of serial adventures, and it’s not until the book ends that all the pieces fall into place. Ms. Bloom does not write deep-dish, straightforward yarns for readers who enjoy conventional drama. She writes sharp, sparsely beautiful scenes that excitingly defy expectation, and part of the pleasure of reading her is simply keeping up with her. You won’t know where “Lucky Us” is headed until, suddenly, it’s there.

headline: Out of Tune, and Seeking New Muses
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — When Renée Fleming tweets, she doesn’t confine herself to 140 characters. In the second act of “Living on Love,” a fun and flimsy entertainment at the Williamstown Theater Festival here, she glides into the room warbling sweetly. “Did I just hear the birds singing?” she asks. Then she looses several more soaring notes. “Oh no,” she says, as if surprised, “that was me.”

headline: A Reflection of the Heat, on a Pair of Pianos
text: The emblematic image of Jazz in July, the tried-and-true concert series at the 92nd Street Y, would probably be a pair of grand pianos facing each other across the stage. A New York City summer institution about to begin its 30th season, the festival has always found good use for that setup, drafting an impressive roster of jazz pianists into the service of musical dialogue. Among them are Dick Hyman, who founded Jazz in July and programmed its first two decades, and Bill Charlap, his handpicked successor.

headline: What Unmentionables Cover
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Speaking, once again, of Ian Livengood, we have a debut today by a young man named Matt Fuchs, who met Mr. Livengood at a career day at their high school in Bethesda, Maryland. Mr. Livengood is an alumnus; Mr. Fuchs is still a student there.

headline: U.S. Naval Ties With China Advance, Symbolically
text: The United States chief of naval operations, Adm. Jonathan W. Greenert, visited China’s aircraft carrier last week, a symbolic step in the campaign the Pentagon is waging with Beijing for greater transparency even as the two navies become greater rivals.

headline: Man of Two Faces, One Broken Heart
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — The title role of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” is one of the great Jekyll and Hyde operatic characters: a man of manipulative sneer in public and tender paternal love in private. His dual personalities were aptly illuminated at Caramoor on Saturday evening in a powerful performance by the baritone Stephen Powell.

headline: Unleashing Her Voice, With Ferocity and Finesse
text: Listening to the jazz singer Gabrielle Stravelli is like imbibing a potent cocktail whose flavor changes as you drain the glass. In the first couple of sips, the predominant taste is the sparkling wine that has drifted to the top, for Ms. Stravelli’s bright, rippling voice exudes a natural effervescence. Before long, it darkens, and the heady liquor underneath kicks in.

headline: Revisiting the Facts, After the Convictions
text: The case made — convincingly — by the documentary “The Newburgh Sting” is that the four upstate New York men convicted of plotting to bomb synagogues in the Bronx and destroy airplanes in 2009 were the fall guys in an elaborate, cinematic performance orchestrated by the F.B.I. The film, showing Monday on HBO, offers a competing narrative to the one presented at trial and in the news media by the government. So far, the government’s story is winning: The men are all serving 25-year sentences in federal prisons.

headline: A Fairy-Tale That Rocks
text: Signature Center

headline: Ragtag Musicians Test Their Talent in the Catskills
text: PTC Performance Space

headline: Grand National Teams Reach the Final
text: LAS VEGAS — The 64-board final of the Grand National Teams took place here Sunday between District 9 (Florida) and District 21 (Northern California and part of Northern Nevada).

headline: ‘Deliverance’ to Open 59E59’s New Season
text: A stage adaptation of James Dickey’s “Deliverance” will open the fall and winter season at 59E59 Theaters, that Off Broadway organization announced on Sunday.
