Based on the 1970 novel, which also inspired the 1972 movie of the same name starring Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox about an ill-fated canoe trip through the backwoods of Georgia, “Deliverance” is slated to have its world premiere on Oct. 10 as part of the Godlight Theater Company’s 20th anniversary celebration. Because of the more graphic scenes of the story, approving the theatrical version a “was quite a decision to make,” Peter Tear, 59E59’s executive producer, said by phone. He said that the playwright Sean Tyler, who adapted the story, had done “a tremendous job.” Other season highlights include “On a Stool at the End of the Bar ”(Nov. 14 through Dec. 14), Robert Callely’s work about a family’s reaction to a loved one’s long-held secret. Alex Webb’s “Cafe Society Swing: A True Story,” a musical revue based on the 1940s jazz venue that became New York City’s first racially integrated nightclub, will follow from Dec. 16 through Jan. 4. That will also represent the return of Evan Pappas (“Chorus Line,” “My Favorite Year,”) to New York stages for the first time since 2007, when he was badly injured in a car accident while touring with “On Golden Pond.” “Evan was one of those adored New York performers,” Mr. Tear said. “So people were terribly excited to hear he’s coming back.” Also slated for the season is the Crossroads Theater Company’s production of Walter Mosley’s “Lift” (Oct. 21 through Nov. 30); Little Opera Theater of New York’s performance of Carlisle Floyd’s “Slow Dusk” and “Markheim” (Dec. 5 through 14); and “Beware of Young Girls: Kate Dimbleby Sings the Dory Previn Story” (Dec. 16 through Jan. 4). More information is at 59e59.org.

headline: Regular Gig for Patti LuPone
text: Two years after starring in the first performances at the supper club 54 Below, Patti LuPone has signed on to appear there regularly through 2016. Ms. LuPone, a two-time Tony winner for best actress (“Gypsy,” 2008; “Evita,” 1980), will begin the first of her twice yearly, two-week engagements on Monday night with Scott Wittman’s “The Lady With the Torch,” a collection of torch songs Ms. LuPone originally performed at Carnegie Hall in 2005. The deal makes her the first artist to sign a long-term agreement with the 54 Below, the publicist Keith Sherman said by phone by Sunday.

headline: A New Project for Jolie and Pitt
text: An on-screen reunion is in the works for Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt. Donna Langley, the chairwoman of Universal Pictures, recently announced that the studio had acquired worldwide rights to Ms. Jolie’s next film project, “By the Sea,” which she will co-star in and co-produce with Mr. Pitt. Written and directed by Ms. Jolie, the film was described in a news release as an “intimate, character-driven drama.” It’s been nine years since the couple’s first and last on-screen appearance, in the 2005 action comedy “Mr. and Mrs. Smith,” which grossed nearly $500 million worldwide. Mr. Pitt and Ms. Jolie (above) are each currently involved in World War II-focused films scheduled to reach theaters this year: Mr. Pitt will star as the leader of a tank crew in “Fury,” slated for release on Nov. 14 from Columbia Pictures, and Ms. Jolie’s sophomore directing project, “Unbroken,” based on the true story of the Olympian and war prisoner Louis Zamperini, is set for a Christmas Day release from Universal.

headline: A Fight for the Right to Read Heidegger
text: This spring, the Students’ Union at the University College London banned meetings of a group called the Nietzsche Club, which was formed to discuss the ideas of philosophers who inspired, among others, far-right politicians and leaders of the past, like Benito Mussolini, an admirer of Nietzsche’s work. The Union Council decided that the discussion of such thinkers and ideas would foster a dangerous wave of fascism among its students, and prevented them from holding a public meeting.

headline: Racy Photos Were Often Shared at N.S.A., Snowden Says
text: WASHINGTON — The former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden said in a wide-ranging interview published on Sunday that the oversight of surveillance programs was so weak that members of the United States military working at the spy agency sometimes shared sexually explicit photos they intercepted.

headline: A Bloop Leads to a Blooper, Lifting the Yankees to a Sweep
text: When a batter is facing a pitcher who throws 102 miles per hour, there is not really time for directional hitting. It is the kind of heat that sends murmurs through the crowd during warm-ups. The pop of the baseball when it hits the catcher’s mitt echoes an extra beat, and even major league hitters take notice of the radar-gun readings. At the plate, hitters just hope for the best.

headline: In Gaza, Epithets Are Fired and Euphemisms Give Shelter
text: JERUSALEM — The Gaza-based interior ministry advises its supporters in a YouTube video that whenever talking about the dead, “always add ‘an innocent citizen.’ ” In Israel, the message is quite different: Those same victims are described as “human shields” sacrificed by the “heartless” Hamas “terrorists” that rule Gaza.

headline: Give Us a Bishop in High Heels
text: SANDWICH, England — LAST Tuesday, on the front page of The Daily Telegraph of London, which I buy like thousands of other dementia-fearers because of the kindly crossword, I saw the face of a young woman at the General Synod at York with a bright teardrop sliding down her cheek. I thought, Oh dear! More misery. Newspapers now are only frigates of misery.

headline: Universal Signs Producer of ‘The Purge’ to a 10-Year Agreement
text: LOS ANGELES — At a time when movie studios have sharply reduced the number of suppliers they keep on retainer, one Hollywood producer just hit the mother lode: Universal Pictures has signed Jason Blum, the force behind microbudgeted horror series like “The Purge” and “Insidious,” to a 10-year deal.

headline: Busy Doctors, Wasteful Spending
text: OF all the ways to limit health care costs, perhaps none is as popular as cutting payments to doctors. In recent years payment cuts have resulted in a sharp downturn in revenue for many hospitals and private practices. What this has meant for most physicians is that in order to maintain their income, they’ve had to see more patients. When you reduce the volume of air per breath, the only way to maintain ventilation is to breathe faster.

headline: Abe Reinterprets Japan’s Constitution
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is taking a new approach to Japan’s post-war pacifist Constitution.

headline: I Had a Boyhood, Once
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — AS I write this, my son Sean is outside riding a unicycle while listening to a band called the Cat Empire on headphones.

headline: Want a Word With the Mayor? You’ll Find Her in the Bike Convoy
text: FORT WORTH — On the same day that the world’s elite cyclists embarked on their annual race along the winding roads of England, Mayor Betsy Price  was front and center in a pack of more than 120 riders outside a popular local restaurant, poised confidently on her 18-speed carbon-fiber racing bike.

headline: After Theater in Brazil, Soccer’s Calloused Cousin Takes the Stage
text: N.F.L. training camps open this week. With that summer ritual, the eagerly awaited heathen season is upon us. N.F.L. football is back.

headline: Concern and Support for Iraqi Christians Forced by Militants to Flee Mosul
text: BAGHDAD — A day after Christians fled Mosul, the northern city controlled by Islamist extremists, under the threat of death, Muslims and Christians gathered under the same roof — a church roof — here on Sunday afternoon. By the time the piano player had finished the Iraqi national anthem, and before the prayers, Manhal Younis was crying.

headline: YouTube Stars Sell Target to College Set
text: TODRICK Hall, Ann Le, Tiffany Garcia and Michael Balalis, a.k.a. Mikey Bolts, are unlikely to be household names in households of consumers in their 30s, 40s or 50s. But Target is hoping those monikers mean money as it seeks to reach members of the millennial generation who are shopping for apparel, electronics and home furnishings as they head to college.

text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: One Degree of Separation
text: At the entrance to the Kam Shan Country Park in Hong Kong, a sign told us that if we followed the trail we would almost certainly see wild monkeys. The sign was printed in Chinese and English. Sure enough, a hundred yards in, we ran into a band of the long-tailed type.

headline: Obama to Report Widening of Initiative for Black and Latino Boys
text: President Obama will announce on Monday that 60 of the nation’s largest school districts are joining his initiative to improve the educational futures of young African-American and Hispanic boys, beginning in preschool and extending through high school graduation.

headline: With Composure and a Strong Finish, García Works to Make Up for the Past
text: HOYLAKE, England — As he made his way to the 18th green, Sergio García experienced a sensation that had eluded him in his 17 previous British Opens. He felt no despair, no devastation, no defensiveness. García had been defeated, but en route to losing to Rory McIlroy, he had won a hard-earned prize: contentment.

headline: Wealthier New Yorkers Aren’t Fleeing the City for Tax Havens, a Study Says
text: Sean Hannity, the Fox News prime-time host, threatened last month to leave New York for a tax haven down south. Tiger Woods transplanted himself from California to Florida for the same reason. The actor Gerard Depardieu decamped from France and sought citizenship in Russia after complaining that 85 percent of his income was consumed by taxes.

headline: Alibaba’s I.P.O. Could Be a Bonanza for the Scions of Chinese Leaders
text: It was billed as the biggest private financing deal in the history of China.

headline: Smaller Cable Networks Plan Their Survival Under the Feet of Giants
text: The flesh-eating zombies in AMC’s hit television series “The Walking Dead” are shambling into a land of even bigger monsters.

headline: A Sunday With Friends
text: A group plays cards in the afternoon in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: Court Delays Execution Over Secrecy With Drugs
text: A federal appeals court has delayed the imminent execution of an Arizona man, saying he has a legal right to details about the lethal injection drugs to be used and about the qualifications of the execution team.

headline: Curt Gentry, 83, Co-Author of ‘Helter Skelter,’ Dies
text: Curt Gentry, an author and well-regarded biographer of J. Edgar Hoover who had his biggest commercial success when he teamed up with Vincent Bugliosi to write the 1974 blockbuster “Helter Skelter: The True Story of the Manson Murders,” died on July 10 in San Francisco. He was 83.

headline: The Fiscal Fizzle
text: For much of the past five years readers of the political and economic news were left in little doubt that budget deficits and rising debt were the most important issue facing America. Serious people constantly issued dire warnings that the United States risked turning into another Greece any day now. President Obama appointed a special, bipartisan commission to propose solutions to the alleged fiscal crisis, and spent much of his first term trying to negotiate a Grand Bargain on the budget with Republicans.

headline: Economic Classes in Africa
text: There are more than twice as many people considered middle class in sub-Saharan Africa than there were 30 years ago. But in most countries, the poorer and richer classes grew as well, so income distributions have gone largely unchanged.

headline: Plan to Rescue Troubled Bulgarian Bank Hits a Snag
text: The fate of Bulgaria’s Corporate Commercial Bank, which experienced a run last month, has become murkier after officials failed to agree on a rescue plan, prolonging the country’s worst banking crisis since the 1990s.

headline: Buon Viaggio, de Blasio
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio is in Rome, vacationing with his family. Though any vacation that includes visits with Italy’s foreign minister and former integration minister, with daily photo ops for the traveling press corps, hardly fits the common definition of a family getaway. The de Blasio children, Chiara and Dante, will have a right to feel shortchanged if they are forced to spend more time posing in palazzi for paparazzi than eating gelato.

headline: Aiming at Glass Ceiling, but Not With Her Jump Shot
text: LAS VEGAS — Professional athletes will frequently do almost anything if they believe it will help them improve. That explained why Billy Knight, an overseas basketball player, was home one summer honing his jumper in a Manhattan Beach, Calif., gym with Natalie Nakase.

headline: America’s Test at the Border
text: The crisis of young migrants at the Texas border is a test of American values, one of those surprise exams that history now and then throws our way: Here are 57,000 helpless children. We are a nation of 300 million. Do we spit on them, or give them blankets and beds?

headline: A Lifetime on California’s Death Row
text: “How has it gone on this long?” Justice Antonin Scalia asked a lawyer for the State of Florida during oral arguments in March on a condemned inmate’s appeal. The legal issue in that case had to do with how states define intellectual disability, but Justice Scalia was troubled that Freddie Lee Hall had been on Florida’s death row for more than three decades.

headline: Nearly No-Hit, Mets Score and Then Stumble
text: SAN DIEGO — The Mets spent much of Sunday afternoon being bamboozled by the rookie Cuban pitcher Odrisamer Despaigne and his unorthodox delivery. When they were not flailing at his assortment of pitches, which came from a variety of arm angles, they were often fooled into not swinging at all.

headline: Missouri Alone in Resisting Prescription Drug Database
text: SIKESTON, Mo. — On his office phone at L & S Pharmacy, Richard Logan listened as a doctor’s office detailed how a patient had just left with her third prescription for painkillers in only nine days — and was quite possibly getting more, illegally, elsewhere.

headline: Microsoft’s Top Lawyer Is the Tech World’s Envoy
text: REDMOND, Wash. — Bradford L. Smith, Microsoft’s general counsel, was in Berlin meeting with government officials this spring when a case kept popping up unexpectedly.

headline: Seeing Reasons for Mets’ Optimism, by Squinting
text: SAN DIEGO — So here we are again, the Mets perched on that cliff wall of possibility.

headline: From a Classical Pianist, an App Lets You Graft Your Voice Onto Actual Hit Songs
text: It is not, said the pianist turned software entrepreneur Robert Taub, a karaoke app with video. Instead his new app, Hook’d, creates what he described as “musical selfies,” in which only the voice track sounds like the user.

headline: Africans Open Fuller Wallets to the Future
text: JOHANNESBURG — Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continent’s economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story in the coming years comparable to the rise of the East Asian Tigers in the second half of the 20th century.

headline: Return for Ryder Cup Is Far From Sure Thing for Woods and Mickelson
text: HOYLAKE, England — The early-arriving British Open fans formed a receiving line along Royal Liverpool’s first hole and tried to finagle a greeting from Tiger Woods with their cries. From young voices, old voices, high voices and low voices came a steady stream of good cheer: “Welcome back, Tiger”; “C’mon, Tiger”; “Go, Tige’ ”; “I play golf because of you, Tiger.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 20, 2014
Whirlpool Wants Congress to Ban Class-Action Suits Tied to Energy Star Program

headline: Trying to Slow the Illegal Flow of Young Migrants
text: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — The wave of Central American child migrants heading to the United States in recent months, feeding a humanitarian crisis there, is showing some signs of abating.

text: Mr. Garner slid seamlessly between television and the movies but was best known as the amiable gambler Bret Maverick in the 1950s western “Maverick.”

headline: Riding the Juggernaut That Left Print Behind
text: Even if you aren’t one of those people worried about media consolidation — there are many in that number — the big bolt of lightning last week that pierced a summer of ennui in entertainment and publishing news was hard to resist.

text: Print and digital may have found the ideal place to coexist: the comic book industry.

headline: Dutch Grief Abounds, but Mourning Stays Local
text: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands — The Dutch public television station NOS broadcast solemn images on Sunday of mourners gathering at half-empty churches and at the homes of families who died when the Malaysia Airlines jet on which they were traveling was shot down over eastern Ukraine. From across this small country, people interviewed on television were trying to address their grief and growing anger over a tragedy that has propelled the ever compromise-seeking Dutch into the hard world of geopolitics and war.

headline: Hasbro to Collaborate With 3-D Printing Company to Sell Artwork
text: In the not too distant future, 3-D printers may provide the public with anything from a whole new wardrobe, to meat, to furniture — and even human organs.

headline: Popular Demand
text: TNT starts its TV season in June and consistently pulls in viewers with popular crime and sci-fi dramas like “Rizzoli & Isles,” “Falling Skies” and “The Last Ship.”

headline: Dr. Albert J. Stunkard, Destigmatizer of Fat, Dies at 92
text: Dr. Albert J. Stunkard, a pioneer of eating-disorder research who proved that some people are genetically predisposed to getting fat, died on July 12 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 92.

headline: Despite Bans, the Use of Chokeholds Persists
text: For more than two decades, all manner of chokeholds have been banned by the New York Police Department. Recruits learn not to use them in the academy; officers are periodically reminded of the ban in training materials.

text: Well, that escalated quickly. After meandering all season, serving up aimless misdirection as frequently as Windows 95 flashed the hourglass pointer, “Halt and Catch Fire” suddenly got pretty good.

headline: Havens Are Few, if Not Far, for Palestinians in Gaza Strip
text: GAZA CITY — As civilian casualties mounted on Monday in the Israeli ground invasion of the Gaza Strip, Israel’s military reminded the world that it had warned people living in targeted areas to leave. The response from Palestinians here was unanimous: Where should we go?

headline: Fort Worth Mayor Embraces Cycling as Part of Community Outreach
text: Mayor Betsy Price of Forth Worth created the Tour de Fort Worth, a 21-mile cycling event, to promote healthy living.

headline: Death of a Man in Custody Adds Fuel to a Dispute Over a Policing Strategy
text: Most afternoons Eric Garner could be found around Tompkinsville Park, not far from the Staten Island Ferry terminal, hawking loose cigarettes and making conversation. Police officers, too, were a familiar sight in the triangular spit of green where drug deals once dominated and fistfights and shouting matches still occasionally break out.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 21, 2014
text: “Welcome to Missouri — America’s Drugstore. We aren’t just allowing abuse, we’ve created a business model for dealers.”

headline: Ko Wins Marathon Classic
text: Lydia Ko, 17, broke free from a late tie with So Yeon Ryu, hitting a wedge to 4 feet for birdie on the 72nd hole on Sunday to win the Marathon Classic in Sylvania, Ohio.

headline: Eataly-Style Food Halls Are Taking Over America
text: Ever since Todd English opened his upscale food court and market at the Plaza Hotel in the summer of 2010, the notion of combining communal dining space and artisan grocery shopping has caught fire in New York. English’s endeavor was soon followed by Mario Batali’s Italian food emporium Eataly, where patrons can snack on charcuterie, drink wine and purchase artisanal produce. At the end of 2013 Gotham West Market opened in Hell’s Kitchen with stalls serving ramen, tapas and microbrews, in addition to gourmet foodstuffs and sundries. Downtown, Battery Park residents can now patronize Hudson Eats, yet another swanky, upscale food court. And now, other cities around the country are getting in the game. Here are five new (or upgraded) food halls in Denver, Seattle, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., and Atlanta.

headline: The Baffler Puts Its Archive Online
text: The Baffler, the magazine of cultural criticism founded under the tagline “The journal that blunts the cutting edge,” was a talisman of a certain sort of left-leaning person throughout the 1990s, its self-consciously retro cover spotted in graduate student apartments and editors’ offices and independent bookstores (not to mention at about 1:26 into the video for Veruca Salt’s 1994 alternative hit “All Hail Me”).

headline: New York City to Pay $2.75 Million to Settle Suit in Death of Rikers Island Inmate
text: New York City has agreed to pay $2.75 million to settle a lawsuit stemming from the December 2012 death of a prisoner at Rikers Island after he suffered what the city medical examiner’s office concluded was “blunt force trauma” to the head.

headline: An Actor of Disarming Wit
text: James Garner, a lantern-jawed actor who appeared in over 50 films and was nominated for an Oscar for 1985’s “Murphy’s Romance,” was perhaps best known for his TV roles in “Maverick” and “The Rockford Files.”

text: brook •\ˈbru̇k\• noun and verb

P. Rosenbaum report on their lives since their marriage in December 2012. And “Bachelor in Paradise,” a new series in which unsuccessful alumni of “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette” troll for love in the tropics, is given a sneak peek ahead of its Aug. 4 premiere.

headline: Chinese Meat Supplier of McDonald’s and KFC Gets the Ax
text: Updated, 10:12 p.m.ET| The Chinese outlets of McDonald’s and KFC have stopped using meat from a Shanghai company after a local television news program accused the supplier of using chicken and beef past their expiration dates, setting off an investigation by food-safety officials.

headline: China Reports Battered Moon Rover Still Kicking
text: Jade Rabbit, the rover China landed on the moon last year, continues to function despite severe mechanical problems that prevent it from moving, a scientist on the project told the Chinese state news media.

headline: Russia’s Message on Jet: Conciliation and Bluster
text: MOSCOW — Russia presented a combination of conciliation and bluster on Monday over its handling of the downed Malaysia Airlines jet, with President Vladimir V. Putin seemingly probing for a way out of the crisis without appearing to compromise with the West.

headline: Student Crossword | Energy

headline: Israel Is Facing Difficult Choice in Gaza Conflict
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli leaders have stressed two points in selling their Gaza Strip ground invasion internationally and at home: that they embraced all cease-fire proposals and that troops are targeting tunnels used by Palestinian militants to infiltrate their territory.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Plight of the Sage Grouse and Energy Production
text: In “Frack Quietly, Please: Sage Grouse Is Nesting,” Diane Cardwell and Clifford Kraus report on the “collision course” involving the preservation of a species of bird and the growth of energy production in the western United States.

headline: Russia’s Severstal to Sell U.S. Plants to American Steel Makers
text: LONDON — The Russian steel maker Severstal said on Monday that it had agreed to sell two steel facilities in the United States to two of its American rivals, Steel Dynamics and AK Steel, for more than $2.3 billion.

headline: Me, Myself and I: Exploring Identity Through Self Portraits
text: Claude Cahun is barely recognizable in “Self-Portrait”: Childlike despite her dark hair, makeup and high-heels, she stands in stark contrast to the light tapestry behind her. Looking at her audience, she poses with caped arm raised to display various masks.

headline: New York Today: Not Hot, and That’s Cool
text: Good morning to you on this mild Monday.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Daily Report: Keeping Data Secure Is One Tough Job
text: The profession of chief information security officer barely existed a generation ago. But to combat the growing threat of online breaches, companies and governments are hiring executives whose main responsibility is to make sure data systems are secure, Nicole Perlroth reports. When things go wrong — and they often do — these executives expect to bear the blame.

headline: Swiss Bank Julius Baer to Buy Businesses from Israel’s Bank Leumi
text: PARIS — The Julius Baer Group said on Monday that the amount of money it manages for clients reached a record high in the first six months of the year, and that it was acquiring new businesses from the Israeli lender Bank Leumi.

headline: The Suns of August
text: LONDON — A century on from World War I, nobody wants the guns of August.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The crisis of young migrants at the Texas border is a test of American values,” writes The New York Times editorial board, “One of those surprise exams that history now and then throws our way: Here are 57,000 helpless children. We are a nation of 300 million. Do we spit on them, or give them blankets and beds?” It’s a test the country may be flunking, according to the editorial. In neighboring Arizona, “Hearing that migrant children were being sent to the town of Oracle, a county sheriff instigated a protest that ensnared a busload of bewildered YMCA campers. A disbarred former county attorney running for governor has an ad showing a Mexican flag swallowing up a map of Arizona and the slogan ‘Before It’s Too Late.'” The crisis “emboldens demagogues in Washington” as well, the board writes. “Mr. Obama has the obligation to act the grown-up” when dealing with an obstructionist Congress, “but he can be a tepid ally where unauthorized immigrants are concerned, since he sees the issue through a calculating lens that overlooks the moral urgency to act.” And urgent the situation is.

headline: Farhad Manjoo, What’s in Your Bag?
text: Oh, no. You’re a reporter on assignment and you’re riffling through your carryall. You think you’ve left something behind. Whether you find it can make or break your day. We asked several reporters what they need to do their jobs when they leave home or the office. We’ll share their answers over the next few weeks.

headline: Goodbye to the Republican Wave?
text: Republicans entered this election cycle with high hopes. President Obama’s approval ratings had sunk into the low 40s, and the rollout of the Affordable Care Act had been an unmitigated disaster. In an off-year election, Democrats weren’t expected to fully mobilize the young and diverse coalition that has given them an advantage in presidential elections. Off-years are also when a president’s party typically suffers significant losses.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Sokolove on Graham Spanier’s Epic Fall
text: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about Penn State’s former president, Graham Spanier, following the child-abuse scandal at the school. Sokolove is the author, most recently, of “Drama High,” which comes out in paperback this fall.

headline: In a Tough Negotiation? Try Strip-Lining
text: A few years back, one of our sales representatives at RJMetrics, Shaun McAvinney, was in the midst of a difficult sales conversation. A prospect had tried our product in the past but hadn’t made a purchase. Now the prospect was back and taking another look.

headline: Medicare Advantage Is Not Efficient, but Here’s How It Can Be
text: Medicare Advantage plans — private plans that serve as alternatives to the traditional, public program — have been growing in popularity. One reason is that they offer additional benefits beyond those available in the traditional program but often at no additional cost to beneficiaries.

headline: The Conflict in Gaza Enters a 14th Day
text: The misery continues for both Palestinians and Israelis, as the death toll surpassed 500.

headline: CBS Outdoor in $690 Million Deal for Advertising Assets
text: CBS Outdoor Americas announced on Monday that it had agreed to acquire outdoor advertising businesses from Van Wagner Communications for $690 million in cash.

headline: Asymmetrical Doctrines (Vaguely Wonkish)
text: Are Keynesians and market monetarists symmetric, both in their doctrines and in their political position? Nick Rowe says yes; Simon Wren-Lewis says no. Simon is right here, but in fact for more reasons than he gives.

headline: Morning Agenda: Chinese Elite Tied to Alibaba I.P.O.
text: When the Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group completed a $7.6 billion deal in 2012 to buy back half of Yahoo’s stake in the company, it raised part of the money by selling shares to select investors, notably China’s sovereign wealth fund and three prominent Chinese investment firms, Michael Forsythe writes in DealBook. What it did not detail was the deep political connections of the investment firms, Boyu Capital, Citic Capital Holdings and CDB Capital, the China Development Bank’s private investment arm.

headline: In Takeover Bid, Valeant Complains to Regulators About Botox Maker
text: The ugly takeover battle between Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Allergan got even uglier on Monday.

headline: Wall Street’s New Enforcers Aim to Muzzle Whistle-Blowers
text: Jordan Thomas is chairman of the whistle-blower representation practice at Labaton Sucharow and was a former assistant director in the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Tom Devine is legal director of the Government Accountability Project and co-author of “The Corporate Whistleblower’s Survival Guide: A Handbook for Committing the Truth.”

headline: Yes, We Have No Banana
text: Noah Smith has a funny piece on the hermetic system that is Austrian economics, with its multilayered defenses against any kind of criticism. What gets me in particular, because I’ve noticed it a lot lately, is this:

headline: Rand Paul Talks Tech
text: A successful libertarian politician is a creature of nuance. After all, he is drawing a government salary to get rid of government, without confusing his audience.

headline: Christophe Lemaire to Leave Hermès; Axel Dumas Faces His First Real Test
text: More fashion musical chairs! The Hermès women’s wear designer Christophe Lemaire is leaving “to dedicate myself fully” to his own line. The show in October will be his last.

headline: A New Design, Similar to What Buzz Aldrin Wore to the Moon
text: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Omega.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Ads Promote Tennessee as ‘Made’ for Visitors
text: The summer vacation season always brings a wave of advertising for lodging chains, along with campaigns for destinations that travelers can visit before or after they check into all those hotels, motels and resorts.

headline: 1964: Doctors Call for End to Free Treatment
text: LONDON — Britain’s family doctors have decided to press for an end to free treatment for patients under the socialized health service. The decision, announced by the British Medical Association, is intended to reduce overcrowding in consulting rooms and ease the burden of the country’s doctors. The BMA council’s chairman, J.R. Nicholson-Lailey, said that the BMA did not want these payments collected by the doctor. Mr. Nicholson-Lailey’s statement indicated that the payments might be used to keep persons with frivolous complaints from monopolizing the doctor’s time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1964

headline: Campaign Tries Tapping Into Hong Kong’s ‘Silent Majority’
text: A campaign aiming to deter a mass protest by those who favor a more direct election of Hong Kong’s top leader collected 380,000 signatures in its first two days. That puts it on a path to challenge the more than 700,000 votes of support the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement received in an unofficial referendum last month.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Amanda Benfell joined The Gunn Report, London, as director for communications and marketing. She had been head of press and public relations for the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity and Lions Festivals, London. Camilla Cole, press and public relations manager of Cannes Lions, will succeed Ms. Benfell there.

headline: First for the Press, Now for a Rest
text: Billing itself as “a place to rest, or not sleep at all,” Amsterdam’s revved-up Volkshotel opened last month in the former headquarters of the Volkskrant, one of the country’s largest and most progressive newspapers.

headline: Karl Albrecht, a Founder of Aldi Stores, Dies at 94
text: Karl Albrecht, who with his brother Theo returned from Allied prisoner-of-war camps after World War II to find their mother’s corner shop still standing in bombed-out Essen, Germany, then proceeded to build it into the international grocery empire Aldi, died on Wednesday in Essen. He was 94.

headline: Probiotic Logic vs. Gut Feelings
text: The label on my bottle of Nature’s Bounty Advanced Probiotic 10 says it contains 10 probiotic strains and 20 billion live cultures in each two-capsule dose. The supplement provides “advanced support for digestive and intestinal health” and “healthy immune function.”

headline: A Homeowner’s Refusal to Cash Out in a Gambling Town Proves Costly
text: ATLANTIC CITY — A stand of blossoming lilac trees and a fresh coat of white paint hardly hide the decrepitude of the three-story boardinghouse half a block from the boardwalk. Ripped screens cover the windows that have not been smashed or boarded up. In the kitchen, refrigerators stand open and empty in a row; dirty plates fill the sink. Some guest rooms look untouched, beds made, while bags of trash and piles of suitcases litter others. What appears to be a crack pipe sits on a dresser.

headline: ScienceTake | How an Embryo Grows
text: Mapping what happens to each and every cell as a fly develops.

headline: Tracking Life From Its Smallest Form
text: The earliest stages of life have been the subject of intense fascination for eons. Aristotle, for instance, observed and recorded the development of a chicken embryo in its egg.

headline: An Elk Is New
text: A Roosevelt elk was born at the Queens Zoo six weeks ago and has now joined the four other elk in the herd in the woodland habitat exhibit.

headline: A Style-Setting J.F.K. Appears With a 2014 Congressional Candidate
text: This is not exactly the way people usually recall John F. Kennedy. Wearing spectacular headgear, Kennedy, then a Massachusetts senator, was speaking in October 1959 in Crowley, La., alongside a then-obscure city councilman named Edwin Edwards, who later became the state’s longest-serving governor.

headline: Taking Pledges for a Brooklyn Movie Marathon
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will present a 24-hour film marathon as a way of raising money for its BAM Education program of classroom and after-school arts education, which reaches about 30,000 students, teachers and parents every year. The event is modeled after the marathon walks and bicycle rides for various health causes. Participants must raise a minimum of $250 to join in, and there are prizes for those who raise greater amounts. The marathon takes place on Sept. 5 at 8 p.m. at the Steinberg Screening Room of the BAM Harvey Theater.

headline: Uncooked Tomato and Mint Sauce with Poached Eggs
text: My friend and colleague Clifford A. Wright serves this delicious salsa cruda with grilled salmon. It’s also wonderful with most other fish, grilled, oven-roasted or pan-cooked, and it makes a terrific sauce for foods like cooked grains, the vegetarian burgers I published a few weeks ago or simply cooked green vegetables. One of my favorite uses is in a Mediterranean huevos rancheros: poach an egg, set it on a lightly charred corn tortilla, sprinkle the egg with a little salt and pepper if desired and spoon on the sauce.

headline: Whole Wheat Focaccia With Tomatoes and Fontina
text: Focaccia is a dimpled flatbread that can take a number of toppings, like a pizza but breadier. I used Community Grains whole wheat flour for this half-whole-wheat version, and I’m loving the results so much that I’m ready to start on a week’s worth of focaccia recipes with different toppings very soon. The bread is fragrant with olive oil, a little crisp on the bottom but soft on the top and the inside. It’s a great vehicle for summer tomatoes.

headline: A J.Crew Grows in Brooklyn
text: “I used to have a studio in Williamsburg, until about 1999,” the typography and graffiti artist Greg Lamarche said. “And then it went residential.” Lamarche, whose graffiti appeared on walls throughout northern Brooklyn in the 1990s, is making a return of sorts. His newest (legal) piece is a colorful jumble of found letter forms spelling out J.Crew, which cascade along a wooden barricade outside the brand’s coming store on Wythe Avenue in Williamsburg. Set to open in mid-September, it will be the company’s first outpost in the neighborhood.

headline: Spiced Tomato Ketchup
text: This is inspired by a recipe for a delicious tomato jam in the chef Matthew Kenney’s cookbook, “Matthew Kenney’s Mediterranean Cooking.” My version is not as sweet as his; I decided to call it ketchup rather than jam because to me, it tastes like a richly spiced ketchup, with sweet and sour flavors and a little kick from the cayenne. A long simmer is important for cooking the sauce to the right consistency and for concentrating the flavors. After that, I put the ketchup through a food mill to achieve smoother texture, but that step is optional. I salt toward the end of cooking because the mix will reduce quite a lot and it’s too easy to oversalt if you salt before that happens. However, be sure to use enough salt to balance out the sweetness and bring out the spice.

headline: Heirloom Tomato Concassé with Wilted Swiss Chard
text: Sometimes, I can’t bear to cook sweet heirloom tomatoes. I love this concassé with pasta or grains, but this time, I decided to use it as a sauce for Swiss chard. I steamed the chard to wilt it, heated it in a little bit of olive oil, then piled it on my plate and spooned the tomato sauce on top. It’s a great combo, and now I think I’ll use it as the vegetable and sauce element of a big bowl. A little feta sprinkled over the top would not be lost on this.

headline: Ex-Executive of Autonomy Seeks to Block HP Settlement Over Disastrous Deal
text: Hewlett-Packard sought late last month to take a big step toward laying to rest the turmoil over its acquisition of the British software maker Autonomy by settling three shareholder lawsuits over the deal.

headline: Risotto with Tomatoes and Corn
text: This is about as colorful and summery a risotto as you can get. The tomatoes and broth team up as a rich medium for the rice. Don’t add the corn too soon, or it will develop a starchy texture like the rice. But cook it long enough to bring out its sweet flavor. Simmer the corn cobs for about 20 minutes in your broth to get a great sweet corn flavor.

headline: Malaysia and Australia, Still Seeking Missing Plane, Strained by Second Disaster
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Two of the nations most affected by the loss of Malaysia Airlines’ Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine, Malaysia and Australia, are still actively involved in the search for another Malaysian airliner that disappeared over four months ago, juggling two crash investigations that require the involvement of many of the same people.

headline: President Calls for a Ban on Job Bias Against Gays
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, declaring himself on “the right side of history,” called on Congress on Monday to ban job discrimination against gay Americans as he signed an executive order doing so for workers of federal contractors.

headline: Israel’s Gaza Incursion Sets Off Protests in Europe
text: PARIS — The conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza is spilling into the streets of dozens of cities in Europe, as thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters have depicted Israel as the aggressor and sought to isolate it internationally.

headline: The Difficulty in Holding Executives Accountable
text: It is difficult to determine who is responsible for a corporate decision when authority is dispersed throughout an organization, which means that no one can be held personally accountable for violations.

headline: Why Writers Are Opening Up About Money (or the Lack Thereof)
text: Writers may always have worried about money, but now seems a particularly fertile time for writing about it. Scratch Magazine, launched last year, takes as its purview “Writing + money + life.” The Billfold routinely runs stories on how freelance writers and other creative types “do money.” The novelist Emily Gould opened up about her financial life in a popular Medium essay and subsequent interviews, and The Guardian’s Alison Flood recently reported on the sorry state of writers’ incomes (which, in turn, inspired some critique from Gawker’s Michelle Dean).

headline: The Twelve-Coin Problem
text: Our challenges this week were suggested by Numberplay regular Stephan Peers, an investment banker from Lafayette, Calif. The first is a classic we ran in similar form years ago, and the second is more unusual and a lot of fun. I asked Mr. Peers where he found the two problems.

headline: Obama Denounces Russia and Separatists for Obstructing Crash Site
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday sternly denounced Russia and the separatists it supports in Ukraine for blocking access to the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was brought down last week, declaring that “time is of the essence” to recover bodies and evidence.

headline: It’s Another Perfect Day in Tibet!
text: BEIJING — There’s a lot to admire about Tom Hugo, and not just the washboard abs that are a glaring feature of his Twitter account profile photo.

headline: Dutch Forensics Team Views Bodies
text: Peter van Vliet, the leader of a Dutch forensics team, spoke after inspecting rail cars in Torez, Ukraine, where the bodies of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash victims were being held.

headline: Eavesdropping Hasn’t Harmed Image of U.S.
text: It almost seems as if President Obama has run into nothing but trouble overseas, facing criticism over electronic eavesdropping, drone strikes and his handling of regional conflicts. Yet the image of the president, and of the United States, have suffered little harm, according to a Pew Global Attitudes survey.

headline: The Ultimate Veggie Burger
text: Melissa Clark shows how to make the ultimate veggie burger with the same satisfying texture as a hamburger.

headline: Obama on Plane Crash in Ukraine
text: The president discussed developments in the investigation of the Malaysia Airlines crash in Ukraine and urged Russia to push separatist rebels for access to the wreckage site.

headline: Ukrainian Military and Rebel Fighters Clash in Donetsk
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — A thick plume of dark smoke could be seen rising into the bright blue afternoon sky here on Monday. One man, a passenger in a blue car that was stopped at a red light, said two people in his building were killed in the day’s fighting. He said he ran out of his house in nothing but his slippers.

headline: Weinstein Company Plans to Release ‘One Chance’ on Yahoo’s Free Streaming Site
text: LOS ANGELES — The Weinstein Company said it planned to release the film “One Chance,” about the British reality-show singer Paul Potts, on Yahoo Screen — a free, advertising-supported streaming site — shortly before putting it in theaters.

headline: The Ultimate Veggie Burger
text: I am not a vegetarian, but that hasn’t stopped me from embracing the veggie burger. Not to the exclusion of beef burgers, mind you, but to savor in its own right. I turn to veggie burgers when I crave the hamburger experience (soft bun, chewy protein, lots of spicy condiments) but would, at that moment, rather consume vegetables than meat.

headline: Poised to Be the Best, and Relishing the Challenge
text: HOYLAKE, England — Let’s set one thing as straight as one of Rory McIlroy’s booming drives on Royal Liverpool’s par 5s: He is not the new Tiger Woods. If anything, he is the old Rory McIlroy.

headline: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office Joins Extensive Foreign-Exchange Inquiry
text: LONDON — Britain’s Serious Fraud Office, which investigates and prosecutes fraud and corruption, joined other global regulators on Monday in investigating accusations of abuse in the multitrillion-dollar foreign exchange market.

headline: Texas Governor Bolsters Border, and His Profile
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Monday ordered 1,000 National Guard troops to the border with Mexico, seizing on a get-tough immigration message that foreshadows the approach to the current crisis by his party in Congress and that could position him in another bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Today in Small Business: A Hamster Wheel for Cats
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: 1939: Sign of Life on Mars Reported
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — Dr. V. M. Slipher, director of the Lowell Observatory at Flagstaff, Ariz., who is here to take color photographs of Mars from the Lamont-Hussey Observatory, today reported that camera studies definitely indicate the presence of life on the planet — which in six days’ time will be nearer the earth than it has been for fifteen years. Dr. Slipher’s photographs show a gradual change in the appearance of the planet, he said, which prove the growth or decay of vegetable matter. Scientists have long believed that Mars is a planet where all conditions needed for life are to be found. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1939

headline: 92nd Street Y’s Lineup: Jimmy Page, Amy Poehler and More
text: A centenary tribute to the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas, and an exhibition that includes letters, photographs and memorabilia from Thomas’s visits to the United States, presented by the Unterberg Poetry Center, will be among the highlights of the 92nd Street Y’s wide-ranging 2014-15 season of readings, lectures and discussions.  The Y has a particular affinity for Thomas, who made his American debut there in 1950, and returned to give the world premiere of “Under Milk Wood” in 1953. He will be commemorated in a program on Oct. 26. The exhibition opens the same day.

headline: Pitchfork Festival Style
text: Attendees at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago wore floral jumpers and crop tops to stay cool.

headline: Pitchfork Artists’ Style
text: Pusha T and Isaiah Rashad performed at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago over the weekend. Here is how they dressed at the shows.

headline: Boston Bombing Suspect’s Friend Is Convicted of Conspiracy and Obstruction
text: BOSTON — In the first of the trials emerging from the Boston Marathon bombing investigation, a college classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect, on Monday was convicted of trying to cover up evidence that could have incriminated his friend in the days after the attack 15 months ago.

headline: Rich People Shrug Off High Taxes
text: Despite the common political argument that local governments need to coddle high earners with low taxes, lest they take their wealth elsewhere, rich New Yorkers, at least, seem to accept with equanimity the burden of contributing to civilization.

headline: Paul Singer’s Hedge Fund Expected to Consider Activist Options for EMC
text: Updated, 4:07 p.m. | For years, Elliott Management has taken on progressively bigger companies for its activist campaigns. Now the $25 billion hedge fund has homed in on its biggest-ever potential target.

headline: The Gene That Turns Worms Into Pavlov’s Dogs
text: Like Pavlov’s dogs, most organisms can learn to associate two events that usually occur together. Now, a team of researchers says they have identified a gene that enables such learning.

headline: For Two Slain Americans, Commitment Came Early
text: LOS ANGELES — Growing up in this city’s San Fernando Valley, Max Steinberg was a typical American boy, and not a particularly religious one. But after a trip to Israel two years ago, his life took a radical shift: Just a few months after first setting foot in the country, he returned to Israel, determined to become a combat soldier in the Israel Defense Forces, which he did.

headline: Obama on Banning Gay Discrimination
text: The president discussed the executive order he signed on Monday that prohibits federal contractors from discriminating against workers on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.

headline: Tesco Taps Outsider to Spearhead Turnaround
text: LONDON — Tesco, Britain’s biggest retailer — a grocer being squeezed by premium food purveyors and deep discounters — announced a management shake-up on Monday and warned that its profits would be lower than previously expected.

headline: Obama on Casualties in Gaza Conflict
text: President Obama said Israel has the right to defend itself against attacks from Hamas, but he expressed concern about the rising number of Palestinian civilian deaths in the conflict.

headline: ‘Shakespeare in Love’ Makes Stage Debut in London
text: LONDON — When Tom Stoppard created a play a few years ago out of his Academy Award-winning script for “Shakespeare in Love,” the best picture Oscar winner from 1998, he quickly realized that doing the adaptation was a mistake.

headline: Mighty Little Diggers
text: Q. My backyard soil is so rocky that I often need a pickax to dig a hole, yet chipmunks and moles burrow through with apparent ease. How do they do it?

headline: Doing Business in China Means Starting From Scratch
text: Professional accomplishments define us. I often start my introduction to new contacts by saying, “Hi, I’m Deb Weidenhamer, the C.E.O. of Auction Systems America.”

headline: Beyond Energy, Matter, Time and Space
text: Though he probably didn’t intend anything so jarring, Nicolaus Copernicus, in a 16th-century treatise, gave rise to the idea that human beings do not occupy a special place in the heavens. Nearly 500 years after replacing the Earth with the sun as the center of the cosmic swirl, we’ve come to see ourselves as just another species on a planet orbiting a star in the boondocks of a galaxy in the universe we call home. And this may be just one of many universes — what cosmologists, some more skeptically than others, have named the multiverse.

headline: For Alibaba Investors, the Benefits and Risks of Trusting Jack Ma
text: Buy a share in Alibaba and you place your trust in Jack Ma. The Chinese e-commerce giant’s founder, executive chairman and spiritual sultan will remain a controlling force even after the company completes its huge initial public offering later this year. The $100 billion-plus question for prospective shareholders is whether they can depend on him to always act in their best interests.

headline: Coming Off Neck Surgery, Wilson Is Set For Contact
text: Giants running back David Wilson, who has been sidelined since October because of a neck injury that required surgery, announced Monday morning that he had been given a go-ahead to resume full-contact workouts with the team. The Giants’ first full practice of training camp is Tuesday.

headline: An Eye to the Past Can Help Guide the Future
text: Over time, we’ve come to accept the concept that knowledge is power. In theory, when we have more knowledge, we can make better decisions. But for many of us, there can be a disconnect between knowing something and acting wisely on that knowledge. As you probably know from experience, it happens often with money.

headline: Weekly Quandary: Having a Baby, and Getting a Dog
text: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: Weekly News Quiz | July 15-21, 2014
text: Update: July 28: We’re taking a midsummer hiatus this week. The News Quiz will be back on Aug. 4 and will cover two weeks.

headline: Hospital Agrees to Pay $190 Million Over Recording of Pelvic Exams
text: The doctor wore an unusual pen around his neck. It was really a concealed camera, and for years he secretly recorded women at some of their most private moments, during pelvic exams.

headline: Helping Parents Cope, Leaving Kids Alone
text: My Sunday column, on the (literal) policing of parents who don’t live up to a helicoptering standard of supervision over their offspring’s every waking move, concluded with a particular emphasis on the obligations of conservatives, who tend to support measures that encourage single parents to take jobs, to fiercely oppose policies and practices that then punish such parents when they leave their kids unsupervised. (Parents, for instance, like Debra Harrell, a working mother who recently fell victim to this cruel Catch-22.)

headline: Research Suggests Students Adjusting to New School Lunches
text: While many schools have been gradually improving the quality and nutrition of their lunches in the last few years, the updated standards released by the United States Department of Agriculture (as directed by the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010), which most schools put in effect over the 2012-13 school year, meant larger, faster changes to lunches nearly across the board. Higher-fat milk is gone; schools are required to serve a vegetable and a fruit daily; there can be no trans fat; and half of the grains offered must be whole grains (in the 2014-15 school year, all grains must be whole grains).

headline: Monday Motorsports: Drought Ends for Bourdais, Todd and Stewart
text: Sébastien Bourdais and Mike Conway each won a race Sunday in an IndyCar twin bill in Toronto over the weekend. The victory  in the rain-delayed first event ended a drought of more than six years for Bourdais, a four-time series champion. He finished just over three seconds ahead of Helio Castroneves, the series points leader. Tony Kanaan took third.

headline: Fantex Completes Second Football Player I.P.O., Though Demand Is Slack
text: E.J. Manuel, a 24-year-old quarterback with the Buffalo Bills, had a rough time in his rookie season last year, when injuries forced him to miss six games.

headline: Grooming a President, and Styling Seatmates
text: AFTER I graduated from Ohio State University, I went to see a friend in New York. We went out one night, and I got spotted by a woman who worked for a modeling agency. She asked me what agency I was with. I had no clue what she was talking about. I’m from Vermilion, Ohio, and growing up there was great, but there aren’t a lot of modeling agencies in northern Ohio.

headline: Walkabout: Malaysia Airlines Offers Refunds
text: Fallout Following last week’s Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 disaster, the carrier says it will offer full refunds to travelers who wish to cancel their tickets, while those wanting to postpone their flights can do so without penalty. (CNN)

headline: Credit Suisse and Fidelity to Team Up for I.P.O.s
text: With initial public offerings continuing to stream out of Wall Street’s pipeline this year, Fidelity Investments is moving to ensure that its retail customers can get a piece of the action.

headline: I.D.F. Video of Purported Hamas Attack
text: The Israeli military released a video it said shows several masked gunmen about a half-mile from the Israeli town of Sderot on July 21 before they retreated back into an underground tunnel.

headline: Snee Retires After Two Rings and Too Many Injuries
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The opening day of an N.F.L. training camp is like the first day of school, both a rebirth and a reunion, with the excitement of a fresh start and the cheer found in familiar faces.

headline: A Digital Mozart Book That Behaves Like an App
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival opens on Friday, but if you’ve spent the year wrapped in Bach and Mahler, or the variegated adventures of the indie new-music scene, you may feel the need for a quick Mozart refresher before the festival gets under way.

headline: Rising Death Toll in Gaza
text: As diplomatic pressure for a cease-fire mounted on the conflict’s 14th day, the Palestinian death toll topped 500 and the number of Israeli soldiers killed hit 25,

headline: A Good Night to All, or, More Cowbell!
text: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

headline: Where to Start When Starting a Blog
text: Q. There are so many platforms for blogging out there. Can you suggest a few?

headline: ‘We Shall Overcome’
text: At a memorial performance honoring the folk singer Pete Seeger, dozens performed “We Shall Overcome.”

headline: ‘You’re Not Sailing Alone’: Saluting the Seegers in a Hootenanny
text: Peter Yarrow of Peter, Paul and Mary gave “Down by the Riverside” a line about fracking. Vanaver Caravan, a dance troupe backed by a folky string band, added a verse about income inequality and the Occupy movement to “Union Maid.” The bluesman Guy Davis updated Lead Belly’s “Midnight Special” with references to Dick Cheney and Guantánamo.

headline: A French Port Welcomes an Intervention by Russia’s Military
text: SAINT-NAZAIRE, France — The owner of Norway’s Café is keeping a bottle of vodka chilled in case she gets a visit from any of the 400 Russian sailors temporarily stationed here. The chamber of commerce has put out a brochure for local shopkeepers with Russian phrases. Residents sometimes stop their cars to get a glimpse of the Russians playing soccer or sunning themselves near where their ship is docked.

headline: Beyond Salty and Sweet: A Budding Club of Tastes
text: Sweet, salty, sour and bitter — every schoolchild knows these are the building blocks of taste. Our delight in every scrumptious bonbon, every sizzling hot dog, derives in part from the tongue’s ability to recognize and signal just four types of taste.

headline: In 9 Cases of Police Chokeholds, Punishment Was Rare, Review Board Says
text: From 2009 to 2013, an oversight board substantiated nine complaints by people who said New York City police officers restrained them with a chokehold, a banned tactic that may have played a role in the death of a Staten Island man last week.

headline: More Eyes on the Skies
text: The future, it is often said, belongs to those who plan for it. And astronomers have been busy working the proverbial smoke-filled rooms (or whatever passes for them today) where the destiny of big science is often shaped and crisscrossing one another in airports on fund-raising trips. Now they are about to have something to show for it.

headline: How the Buk Missile System Works
text: Some background on the Buk SA-11, the weapon that was most likely used to shoot down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, and who might be able to operate it.

headline: Lawyer on Guilty Verdict in Bombing
text: Carmen M. Ortiz, the United States attorney for Massachusetts, said she was satisfied with the guilty verdict for Azamat Tazhayakov.

headline: Alibaba Says It Relies on Markets, Not Connections
text: The Alibaba Group responded Monday to an article in The New York Times about the political connections of some of its shareholders, saying the company relies on the market, not on the background of any of its investors, to drive its business.

headline: Malaysia Premier Brokers Deal to Recover Black Boxes
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Prime Minister Najib Razak’s announcement that his government had reached an agreement with pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine, for the transfer of the bodies and so-called black boxes from Flight 17 to Malaysian representatives there, apparently achieved what pressure from far more powerful nations had failed to accomplish.

headline: New Music: Common Has a New Album and Audra MacDonald as ‘Lady Day’
text: COMMON

headline: Businesses Need to Spend More. The Future of the Economy Depends on It.
text: Dear C.E.O.s of America:

headline: New York City Reviewing Rikers Assaults on 129 Inmates
text: New York City’s Department of Investigation has begun a review of scores of cases involving inmates at Rikers Island who were assaulted by correction officers and suffered serious injuries.

headline: Doctor Apologies, Contraceptives and H.I.V., Dosing Dangers, Mystery of Leprosy
text: Medical Mistakes

headline: U.N. Council, With Russia in Accord, Tells Insurgents to Open Wreckage Site
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Monday unanimously passed a resolution that “condemns in the strongest terms” the attack that brought down the Malaysia Airlines plane in eastern Ukraine, called for an international investigation with the United Nations civil aviation agency, and demanded that armed groups at the crash site allow unfettered access.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: How Many Americans Are Lesbian, Gay or Bisexual?
text: As it has for decades, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last week released its annual National Health Interview Survey on the health of Americans. But this year, there was a difference: For the first time, the respondents were asked about their sexual orientation.

headline: Time Warner Cancels Shareholders’ Ability to Call Special Board Meeting
text: Time Warner is playing defense.

headline: The Scene | Kendrick Lamar, Grimes, St. Vincent and More at the Pitchfork Music Festival
text: The ninth edition of the Pitchfork Music Festival, held in Chicago’s Union Park this past weekend, featured a lineup as diverse and influential as the offerings on the music-arbiter site. A young and enthusiastic crowd turned out to see legendary indie acts reunited — like Neutral Milk Hotel and Slowdive, which played its first show in more than 20 years — and catch a who’s-who of indie superstars (Kendrick Lamar, Grimes, St. Vincent) and emerging names (Danny Brown, FKA Twigs, Empress Of). The mild-for-Chicago-in-July weather made for a laid-back vibe — and allowed several headliners to comfortably sport that perennial rock-and-roll staple, the leather motorcycle jacket. The photographer Andres Gonzalez was on the ground to capture the action for T.

headline: Scene City: Martha Stewart’s Toast to Vintage Hamptons
text: Ms. Stewart hosted a dinner party for Dom Pérignon in East Hampton.

headline: Perry Activates National Guard in Texas
text: Gov. Rick Perry said he would use his executive authority to activate up to 1,000 National Guard troops to help secure the Texas border region against “criminal aliens.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Gaza City, Ukraine and Italy.

headline: Yahoo Acquires Flurry to Bolster Mobile Offerings
text: Yahoo announced Monday that it had agreed to acquire Flurry, a mobile ad and analytics company.

headline: Senate Inquiry Faults Hedge Funds’ Tax Strategy
text: Updated, 8:27 p.m. | A Senate investigation has found that hedge funds — in particular, James H. Simons’ Renaissance Technologies — used complex financial structures to claim billions of dollars in tax savings.

headline: Raising a Glass to Chemistry
text: One of the great things about “Breaking Bad” was that it emphasized just how much the magic of intoxication depends on science. Walter White may have been a meth dealer and a criminal mastermind, but he was, above all, a really good chemist.

headline: A Conductor, a Band and a Critical Swath
text: LENOX, Mass. — A critic’s vocabulary is full of two-faced words, admiring in one context and disapproving in another. “Loose” can smile at a pianist’s jazzy flair, or sniff at her imprecise rhythms.

headline: Thomas Berger, ‘Little Big Man’ Author, Is Dead at 89
text: Thomas Berger, the reclusive and bitingly satirical novelist who explored the myths of the American West in “Little Big Man” and the mores of 20th-century middle-class society in a shelf of other well-received books, died on July 13 in Nyack, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Coveting Vintage Discs in a Digital Universe
text: Something unexpected happened to Amanda Petrusich when she set out to explore the “oddball fraternity” of fanatical collectors of 78 r.p.m. records, the increasingly hard-to-find shellac discs that circulated before World War II. At first she was almost repulsed by the avidity of their passion. But when she heard the music of Skip James, Charley Patton, Blind Uncle Gaspard and Geeshie Wiley played in its original format, she fell under its spell, just as the collectors had.

headline: Should You Track Your Child?
text: New devices that track children’s whereabouts have some people worrying about what happens when children are monitored at all times — and their introduction comes at a time when our society’s attitudes toward supervision are already being hotly debated. What does a standard of constant surveillance mean for kids, many are asking, and for their families?

headline: White House Scandals, With Ridicule for All
text: The folks behind “Clinton: The Musical” are said to have invited the former first couple to attend a performance of what is coyly called a spoof of their eight years in the White House. Note to the box office: They’re not likely to show up at the will call window.

headline: A Sleep Apnea Test Without a Night in the Hospital
text: Where was I?

headline: As the City Birds Nod Off, a Crooning Gull Steps In
text: It’s always good to keep the competition in mind when planning a concert. It made sense, then, for the members of the New Juilliard Ensemble, who assembled Sunday’s program of new music for string quartet with flute for the Museum of Modern Art’s Summergarden series, to keep the flute music for last. By then it had grown dark and the birds, which had earlier filled the museum’s Sculpture Garden with their end-of-day chatter, had gone to bed. The birds also slept through the performance of Peter Sculthorpe’s String Quartet No. 14 and could not comment on the verisimilitude of the gull croons written into the third movement.

headline: Investing in Fantasy to Save a Fraying Reality
text: ROME — In its nearly 80-year history, the Cinecittà film studio lured the world’s greatest directors and biggest movie stars to this Italian capital, earning it the title of Hollywood on the Tiber.

headline: Drones on a Different Mission
text: Belize has made a great effort to protect its coral reef system — the largest in the Western Hemisphere — by establishing more than a dozen protected areas. But patrolling large stretches of ocean and coastline and enforcing fishing regulations takes time, people and boats.

headline: Crash of Malaysian Jet Shakes Business Travel
text: ON any given day, there are about 100,000 commercial airline flights, flying more than 50,000 separate routes, around a world where armed conflict is always occurring, somewhere.

headline: Foes of Corcoran Takeover Plan Gain in Court
text: A judge ruled on Monday that a challenge to a plan by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University to absorb the Corcoran Gallery of Art and its college can go forward, dealing an unexpected blow to a complex agreement among the three institutions.

headline: Blind as a Bat: A Case of Mind vs. Body
text: Almost 40 years before the publication of “Mind and Cosmos,” the philosopher Thomas Nagel laid out the difficulties scientists face in trying to explain how the human brain gives rise to consciousness. His essay, as influential as any in the philosophy of mind, is called “What Is It Like to Be a Bat?”

headline: A Love of Land in Egypt’s Farms
text: After experiencing the tumult of the Arab Spring, Laura El-Tantawy returned to her grandfather’s village to rediscover and appreciate the lives of farmers.

headline: A Reassuring American Presence Joins Talks on Climate Change With China
text: The presence of John D. Podesta, former chief of staff to President Bill Clinton and now counselor to President Obama, at the recent United States-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue in Beijing was a surprise. He is not a China expert. But the Chinese like old hands, aides with proximity to the Oval Office, and Mr. Podesta fills that bill.

headline: Youth Is Not Wasted on This Young Orchestra
text: PURCHASE, N.Y. — “Now I know I’m an old geezer,” the boyish 43-year-old violinist Gil Shaham more or less said on Saturday afternoon, using instead a common scatological Yiddish phrase.

headline: Netflix, Growing, Envisions Expansion Abroad
text: Netflix made its first splash in original programming with “House of Cards,” the political drama focused on Washington. Next up, “House of Versailles”?

headline: A Newly Found Mite Is Jenny From the Reef
text: A new species of aquatic mite, discovered in a coral reef off Puerto Rico, has been named in honor of the singer and actor Jennifer Lopez, whose parents are from there. Litarachna Lopezae is a kind of common but little-studied mite known as a pontarachnid. “J. Lo’s songs and videos kept the team in a continuous good mood,” said Vladimir Pesic, a biologist at the University of Montenegro and lead author of the study.

headline: In Performance | Everett Quinton
text: Mr. Quinton plays an eccentric Key West matron in Erasmus Fenn’s camp melodrama “Drop Dead Perfect,” at Theater at St. Clement’s. (In the production Mr. Quinton plays the role in drag.)

headline: Spark for a Stagnant Search
text: One day in 1988, a college dropout named Jonathan Stanley was visiting New York City when he became convinced that government agents were closing in on him.

headline: SZA’s Pitchfork Festival Style
text: SZA, a singer who performed at last weekend’s Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago, explains what drives her onstage look, from pajamas to grandpa shirts.

headline: Meredith Graves of Perfect Pussy’s Festival Style
text: Meredith Graves, the singer for the band Perfect Pussy, talks about dressing up for the stage at last weekend’s Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago.

headline: Light Show That Fizzled
text: Like eager paparazzi, astronomers trained an arsenal of telescopes this spring on the Milky Way’s crowded center, hoping for a once-in-a-lifetime chance to watch an immense gas cloud collide with the galaxy’s supermassive black hole. The shock generated when the cloud smashed into gas surrounding the black hole, 26,000 light-years from Earth, could have produced radio waves, X-rays and a possible brightening of infrared light. But researchers saw nothing.

headline: When Struggling Families Spark Internet Rage
text: Brenda Ann Kenneally is a documentary photographer who works in depressed urban environments, often photographing their residents repeatedly over a period of many years. “Upstate Girls,” her most recent project, began in 2003 when Ms. Kenneally met a teenager named Kayla in Troy, N.Y. Kayla was fourteen and pregnant and asked Ms. Kenneally if she wanted to photograph her child’s delivery.

headline: How Wearable Technology Made Carmelo Anthony a Tech Investor
text: The idea that turned Carmelo Anthony into a venture capitalist came to him during practice with the Knicks last season.

headline: U.S. Advises Americans to Put Off Travel to Israel
text: The United States government on Monday suggested that Americans avoid travel to Israel if possible because of the increasingly deadly Israeli-Palestinian conflict in Gaza and the rockets fired into widespread parts of Israeli territory including cities.

headline: Yankees’ Thinness on the Mound Proves Costly
text: Things seemed to be humming along quite nicely for Shane Greene, the unheralded Yankees prospect who had looked so sharp in his first two starts and now a third, picking up where he left off more than a week ago in Baltimore.

headline: End Partisan Primaries, Save America
text: WASHINGTON — POLARIZATION and partisanship are a plague on American politics.

headline: The Problem With Collective Grief
text: AMSTERDAM — LESS than two weeks ago, the Netherlands was still delirious with the fever surrounding the World Cup. The Dutch unexpectedly achieved third place. Dutch nationalism, usually muted, was briefly turned into mandatory enthusiasm, as the Dutch team racked up victories over Spain, Australia, Chile, Costa Rica, Mexico and, finally, Brazil. On Twitter, a soccer commentator who ventured a few critical remarks about the Dutch team received comments to the effect that he should be thrown out of a plane.

headline: China Tensions Choke Off Tourism to Vietnam
text: DA NANG, Vietnam — The year began well for Mai Thanh Trung, newly employed at a travel company here that caters to Chinese tour groups. Mr. Trung said he regularly greeted charter flights from the Chinese mainland and pocketed an average monthly commission of about $600.

headline: Wreckage Offers Clues on Why Flight 17 Went Down
text: Photographs of a piece of wreckage from Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 offer evidence about what could have caused it to crash.

headline: After Malaysia Airlines Crashes, the Payments Are Piling Up for Air Insurers
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia Airlines’ two crashes in less than five months are sending tremors through the aviation insurance market — not least because the carrier’s $2.25 billion overall liability policy is mysteriously missing a standard phrase that usually limits insurers’ payments for search-and-rescue costs.

headline: U.S. Mentors Prepare to Let Afghan Forces Go It Alone
text: KOH-E-SAFI, Afghanistan — The small and cherubic governor of Koh-e-Safi District was struggling to compute the meaning of the American troop withdrawal.

text: Seven retired N.F.L. players have asked an appeals court to intervene in the proposed settlement between the league and more than 4,500 retirees who say they were not told of the dangers of concussions and repeated head hits.

headline: Boko Haram Rebels Seize a Town in Nigeria
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A major town in Nigeria’s troubled northeast has been taken over by Boko Haram in what local officials said was perhaps the Islamist militant sect’s most significant victory yet in a five-year campaign of violence and terror.

headline: Police Seek Clues in Fatal Shooting of Widely Known Criminal Law Professor in Florida
text: The police in Tallahassee, Fla., are investigating the killing of an internationally known criminal law professor.

headline: Markers on the Road to Understanding the Brain
USA Swimming Calls for Everyone to Get in the Pool
text: Team sports are all about competition, but sports also compete against one another. And one team sport that has been treading water in recent years is competitive swimming, with participation levels in 2013 ranking 17th among 24 team sports, according to the Sports & Fitness Industry Association.

text: The investigations are not complete and pictures can mislead. But it is hard to imagine that the videos show anything but what seems chillingly obvious: a group of New York City police officers killing an unarmed black man, Eric Garner, on a sidewalk in Staten Island.

headline: Obama’s Bold Order on Bias
text: “Our government of the people, by the people and for the people will become just a little bit fairer,” said President Obama on Monday just before signing an executive order prohibiting federal contractors, which employ 20 percent of the nation’s work force, from discriminating against gay men, lesbians and transgender people in their employment practices.
