headline: After 128 Years of Rolling Them, Tampa Is Close to No Cigars
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Some unforgettable places waft into memory on a scent. For Floridians, it may be the sweetness of mangoes in Miami, the salt-sprinkled air of the Keys, the pungency of the Everglades.

headline: Cash Crops With Dividends: Financiers Transforming Strawberries Into Securities
text: His boots were caked with mud when Thomas S. T. Gimbel, a longtime hedge fund executive, slipped in a strawberry patch. It was the plumpness of a strawberry that had distracted him.

headline: Strong Steps on Sentencing Reform
text: In a landmark move, the United States Sentencing Commission, a bipartisan agency that sets federal sentencing policy, voted unanimously on Friday to give nearly a quarter of all federal prisoners the chance to reduce their sentences by an average of more than two years.

headline: Journey Home Finally Begins for the Victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight
text: TOREZ, Ukraine — In the end, they were sent off alone, without ceremony, well-wishers or anyone much beyond a handful of armed rebels on the platform.

headline: Mother Jumps Onto Subway Tracks in Queens to Rescue Her Toddler
text: There are few more accomplished multitaskers than the parents of the New York City subway system. They shepherd and shush, hold the hands of toddlers and haul infants, gently, through turnstiles — all while navigating a train network that can bewilder even the most veteran rider.

headline: Did Dodd-Frank Work?
text: Ralph Nader has written a new book, entitled “Unstoppable: The Emerging Left-Right Alliance to Dismantle the Corporate State.” If you spend any time looking into the current state of affairs with the Dodd-Frank Act — Monday was the fourth anniversary of the law enacted to ensure that the country never suffers through another financial crisis like the one in 2008 — you’d have to say that he has a point.

headline: Flight of the Corporations
text: Are inversion deals a sign that corporate taxes should be lowered so American companies don't leave, or are they an example of self-serving greed that should be banned with legislation?

headline: Ace Favors Fewer Starts to Protect Pitchers’ Arms
text: Yu Darvish and Masahiro Tanaka, old friends and rivals from both the Pacific League in Japan and the American League, met in the tunnel underneath Yankee Stadium on Monday afternoon and chatted.

headline: Medal of Honor Awarded to Army Sergeant
text: President Obama awarded former Staff Sgt. Ryan Pitts the Medal of Honor, the highest U.S. award for heroism, for his actions during the Afghan war.

headline: Baton in This Race Is the Conductor’s
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Down the road from Hayward Field at the University of Oregon School of Music and Dance, the conductor, composer and music professor Brian McWhorter was brooding.

headline: Chinese Team Wins Biggest-Ever Prize in Professional Video Gaming
text: SEATTLE — When the most lucrative video game tournament ever was over on Monday, explosions of confetti blasted from the stage at Key Arena here, as 12,000 spectators cheered from the stadium’s stands. The winners, from a team called Newbee, hoisted a shield-shaped trophy over their heads. They were each $1 million richer.

headline: An Outrage Compounded by Mystery
text: There are still innumerable questions about how Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down over rebel-held areas of Ukraine on Thursday. But nobody contests that the 298 people so senselessly killed deserve far greater respect than they have been shown by the Russian-backed rebels who have controlled the incompetent searches of the fields on which the Boeing 777 came down. The callousness of the rebels and, by extension of their Russian sponsors, is outrageous.

headline: Soldier Who Held His Post Is Awarded Medal of Honor
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor on Monday to an infantryman who by himself held a small outpost in eastern Afghanistan in the battle of Wanat, one of the deadliest conflicts of the nearly 13-year war.

headline: Goodwill Investigating Possible Theft of Credit Card Data
text: Goodwill Industries International, a nonprofit agency that operates thrift stores around the country, said on Monday that it was investigating a potential security breach that may have led to the theft of customers’ credit card data.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 21, 2014
Support for a College Student Grows After a Rape Complaint Is Dismissed
text: With a new school year approaching, administrators, students and alumni at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in central New York are grappling with questions raised by a New York Times article examining the school’s handling of a sexual assault complaint filed by a female student last fall.

headline: Tinderbox Explodes in Wildfires Across Northwest
text: SEATTLE — A cool, wet spring that drew out luxuriant growth in parts of the Pacific Northwest, followed by a ferociously hot and dry early summer, has created a fire-season tinderbox across the Pacific Northwest that exploded over the past week with dozens of wildfires burning hundreds of thousands of acres and forcing thousands of residents from their homes.

headline: She Never Knew Dad, Just His Hit Songs
text: “Does it bother you that your songs are everywhere but you aren’t?” the beautiful dancer asks, lounging in the handsome songwriter’s bed. “No one ever knows who writes the songs, right? Just who sings ’em.”

headline: Foot Used to Keep Rhythm
text: Administrivial ‘Win Valuable Prizes’ Alert! If you plan to be in New York City on Saturday, Aug. 9, and you would like to have the most fun you can have with a sharpened pencil, plan to be at Lollapuzzoola, the awesome crossword puzzle tournament run by Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer. Basic stats: 10 a.m. – 5 p.m. at All Souls Church (1157 Lexington Ave., New York). $25 to pre-register, $30 at the door. They have two skill divisions, a Pairs Division, free snacks, goofy prizes, nonsense banter … and Mike Nothnagel might try catching cheese puffs in his mouth thrown from at least 10 feet away. If the live show is too far away for you, or the timing is just bad — please try the at-home version of Lollapuzzoola. A PDF of all the puzzles from the day can be yours for a mere $10. Click here to register, or to just give Brian Cimmet some more hits on his page.

headline: In Italy, de Blasio Pauses to Meet With ‘Mirror Image’
text: ROME — Maisha Grispino, a college-age daughter of Cécile Kyenge, Italy’s first black national official, was sitting on an immaculate terrace of one of this city’s most exclusive social clubs on Monday when a white woman approached.

headline: A June 2014 Letter From the New York City Department of Investigation
text: Referring a case from Rikers Island to the Bronx district attorney’s office for prosecution.

headline: How It Happens | Carbon Capture
text: To fight against global warming, the world needs to sharply reduce emissions of carbon dioxide gas. A technology called carbon capture and storage can keep the gas out of the environment.

headline: Corralling Carbon Before It Belches From Stack
text: ESTEVAN, Saskatchewan — So much soot belched from the old power plant here that Mike Zeleny would personally warn the neighbors.

headline: Jet Wreckage Bears Signs of Impact by Supersonic Missile, Analysis Shows
text: A piece of wreckage from the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200 that was shot down in eastern Ukraine last week bears telltale marks of small pieces of high-velocity shrapnel that apparently crippled the jet in flight. Riddled with these perforations and buffeted by a blast wave as it flew high above the conflict zone, the plane then most likely sheared apart.

headline: To Talk With Hamas, U.S. Needs Help From a Testy Trio of Nations
text: CAIRO — As Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here Monday night to try to produce a cease-fire in the Gaza crisis as rapidly as possible, he confronted an uncomfortable reality.

headline: Vandals Go on a Spree in Central Park
text: Vandals went on a rampage in Central Park over the weekend, damaging several structures, the police said.

headline: After Decade With Uneven Mets, Wright Turns Introspective for a Moment
text: SEATTLE — Once the Mets arrived here on Sunday night and settled into their hotel, David Wright left for dinner with some of his teammates. As they were walking, he looked back and saw more teammates following them. More joined, and soon, almost the whole team was gathered at a nearby steakhouse.

headline: Turkey: Deadly Clash at Syrian Border
text: A Turkish soldier was killed and two others were injured late Monday in Ceylanpinar, a town in Sanliurfa Province on the Syrian border, after smugglers were prevented from crossing into Turkey and opened fire on a military station, CNN Turk television reported. Some Syrian activists asserted that clashes between Syrian Kurdish rebels and the  Turkish military also left six fighters dead in Syria. Izzettin Kucuk, a Sanliurfa official, confirmed that shots were fired from Syria but gave no details, the semiofficial Anadolu News Agency reported. Turkey is concerned that a strong Syrian Kurdish presence in the border region may inspire separatism. Stray shells and bullets from groups fighting in Syria have killed several residents in Turkey along the countries’ long border.

headline: Arrest in Attack on Police Officer
text: An East Harlem man was charged on Monday with assaulting a police officer after a confrontation early Sunday morning over marijuana, the authorities said.

headline: Study Tracks Millions of Child Brides
text: More than 700 million women alive today were married as children, and about 250 million of them — more than one in three — were wed before they reached 15, Unicef said in a study released Monday, on the eve of an international meeting in London, the Girl Summit, sponsored by Unicef and the British government. It aims to mobilize efforts to end female genital mutilation and child, early and forced marriages. The study said child marriage remains widespread in parts of South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. South Asia is home to almost half of all child brides worldwide, the study found. While an adolescent girl today is about a third less likely to be subjected to genital mutilation compared with 30 years ago because of activism, legislation and changing attitudes, Unicef said that in countries where it is still practiced, parents “continue to compel their daughters to undergo the procedure because of strong social pressure.”

headline: Questions About Tactics and Targets as Civilian Toll Climbs in Israeli Strikes
text: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza — The blast from the Israeli strike was so powerful that it threw an iron door clear over several neighboring houses. It came to rest along with a twisted laundry rack still laden on Monday with singed clothes and a child’s slipper.

headline: Arizona: Execution Case to Be Appealed to Justices
text: A federal appeals court on Monday denied Arizona’s request for a new hearing, by a larger panel, to reconsider the court’s stay of the execution of Joseph Wood, and the state said it would appeal immediately to the Supreme Court to permit the execution to proceed. On Saturday, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit delayed Mr. Wood’s execution, scheduled for Wednesday, until Arizona provides information about the sources of lethal drugs and the training of the administering staff. In previous cases, the Supreme Court has declined to stop executions over similar concerns about drug secrecy.

headline: Strength Is Sought at Rites in Israel
text: HOLON, Israel — It was a scene that played out on Monday at military cemeteries across Israel: Family, friends and comrades in arms, some in uniform fresh from battle, others wounded, gathering in the hundreds.

headline: Medical Workers Face Scrutiny After Man’s Death in Police Custody
text: After Eric Garner died in police custody last week on Staten Island, critics fixed their attention on the chokehold that an officer appeared to use to subdue him during a confrontation.

headline: Businessman Wanted in Fatal South Korean Ferry Disaster Is Found Dead
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s most wanted man, a church leader and businessman whom prosecutors had hoped to arrest in connection with an April ferry disaster that killed more than 300 people, has been found dead, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: President’s Secret to Handling Criticism? Focus, and No TV
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama had to laugh. He had just been asked how he deals with criticism, and something about the question just struck him as funny. Maybe it is because criticism is one thing he sees no shortage of these days.

headline: Home of Cheever, Chekhov of the Suburbs, Is for Sale
text: OSSINING, N.Y. — For all the bleak musings about suburban life in his fiction — the banality and social striving, the emptiness and inebriation — John Cheever had a simple love for his five-acre property here.

headline: Psychiatric Research Revival, Second Thoughts About Consciousness, Take-Home Sleep Tests
text: A family pledges one of the largest private gifts ever for scientific research; why we may never have all the pieces necessary for a theory of everything; sleep apnea tests can now be taken from the comfort of your bed.

headline: Credibility Among Gay Men Gives Leverage to New York City’s New Chief of H.I.V. Prevention
text: At the height of a meningitis outbreak last year among gay and bisexual men in New York City, Demetre Daskalakis, a wiry AIDS doctor and gay health activist, spent late nights and early mornings in the city’s sex clubs and bathhouses. There, he would strip off his leather jacket and, in his muscle T-shirt, talk the men around him into letting him inject them with meningitis vaccines.

headline: Outside Connecticut Fund-Raiser, a Protest Over Christie’s Veto of Gun Control Bill
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — In Iowa, he was celebrated. In Connecticut, he was protested.

headline: A Strike Kills 25 Family Members
text: In one of the deadliest strikes in Gaza, Israel said it was targeting a Hamas operative. But the strike killed 25 other people, including 19 children. Anne Barnard reports.

headline: Word of the Day | concession
text: concession •\kən-ˈse-shən\• noun

headline: Detroit’s Retirees Vote to Lower Pensions, in Support of Bankruptcy Plan
text: DETROIT — Coming to terms with what came to be seen as inevitable, this city’s public-sector retirees have voted to lower their expected pension benefits, a crucial step in the city’s plan to emerge from bankruptcy before the end of the year.

headline: Madeline Amgott, Television Producer, Dies at 92
text: Madeline Amgott, one of the few women to produce news programs in the male-dominated television universe of the 1950s and ’60s, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: Detroit Bankruptcy Vote Results
text: The city’s public-sector retirees voted on July 22 to lower their expected pension benefits after two months of court-required voting.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (ESPN) SLAYING THE BADGER This “30 for 30” documentary, directed and written by John Dower, looks back at the 1986 Tour de France and the rivalry between Greg LeMond, above left, the first American to win the race, and Bernard Hinault, a.k.a. the Badger, right, his friend, mentor and teammate on La Vie Claire. The film is based on Richard Moore’s book, which describes how Mr. Hinault, then the reigning champion, had seemingly promised to help Mr. LeMond to his first victory in return for his support of Mr. Hinault as he struggled in the 1985 tour. But Mr. Hinault repeatedly attacked Mr. LeMond in the race, “because I felt like it,” he said. “If he doesn’t buckle, that means he’s a champion and deserves to win the race. I did it for his own good.”

headline: Chinese Journalist Fired Over Work for Hong Kong Website
text: A prominent Chinese journalist has been dismissed for writing for a Hong Kong website — the first case of its kind made public after the Chinese government warned journalists earlier this month not to cooperate with overseas news agencies.

headline: Chinese Now Prefer Mobile When Going Online
text: For the first time, more Chinese people are gaining access to the Internet with mobile devices than with personal computers.

headline: ‘Rusty’ Niese Gets Little Help From Offense as Mariners Top Mets
text: SEATTLE — Fidgeting, with his hands in his pockets, Jon Niese said his shoulder felt fine. He had just made his first start in 17 days, since he had been placed on the disabled list with shoulder fatigue, and it had not exactly gone well.

headline: Putin’s Remarks on Plane in Ukraine
text: President Vladimir V. Putin, in a video statement, offered conciliatory words about the crisis over the downed Malaysia Airlines jet in Ukraine.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 22, 2014
text: “Valor was everywhere that day, and the real heroes are the nine men who made the ultimate sacrifice so the rest of us could return home.”

headline: Student Crossword | The Declaration of Independence
text: Test your knowledge of the Declaration of Independence by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Credit Suisse Loses $779 Million After Settling Tax Evasion Case
text: Credit Suisse on Tuesday reported a second-quarter loss of $779 million — its largest loss since the financial crisis — as it felt the impact of the settlement of a tax evasion case in the United States.

headline: Chinese Pork Producer Rekindles Hopes For I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — This little piggy is going to the market after all.

headline: Despite Anger Over Downed Jetliner, Europe Shies Away From Sanctions on Russia
text: AMSTERDAM — In cafes across the Netherlands, a new Cold War with Russia had already erupted.

headline: A Blast, a Fire and an Israeli Soldier Goes Missing
text: JERUSALEM — It was around 1 a.m. when the decades-old Israeli armored personnel carrier rumbled into the Gaza Strip on Sunday and headed for Shejaiya, a Hamas stronghold on the eastern edge of Gaza City. Seven soldiers were crammed inside, including Sgt. Oron Shaul, 21, from the Golani infantry brigade, according to Israeli military officials.

headline: An ‘Emotional Burden’ Rarely Discussed
text: The National Center for Health Statistics has published a new report documenting the extent of incontinence among older adults living independently, receiving home health care services or residing in assisted living centers and nursing homes. Buried in the report is an astonishing figure: 37 million seniors who live independently have some type of incontinence.

headline: What the Hobby Lobby Ruling Means for America
text: Last month, as you’ve probably heard, a closely divided Supreme Court  ruled that corporations with religious owners cannot be required to pay for insurance coverage of contraception. The so-called Hobby Lobby decision, named for the chain of craft stores that brought the case, has been both praised and condemned for expanding religious rights and constraining Obamacare. But beneath the political implications, the ruling has significant economic undertones. It expands the right of corporations to be treated like people, part of a trend that may be contributing to the rise of economic inequality.

headline: A Love of Land in Egypt’s Farms
text: Laura El-Tantawy was in her sixth year photographing Egypt when she decided she needed a drastic change. What had started as a project to reconnect with her home country took a decided shift at the spark of the 2011 revolution. Echoing the tumult in Tahrir Square in Cairo, her images had grown menacing and haunting.

headline: Flight Delays Expected to Worsen in Eastern China
text: Severe flight delays that have plagued airports serving Shanghai and other parts of eastern China in recent weeks are set to continue until mid-August, the Chinese state media reported on Tuesday. The air traffic snarl has been caused by the “influence of high-frequency exercises by other users,” China National Radio reported, citing the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Stalking the Shadow Universe
text: The questions below refer to the video “The Shadow Universe Revealed” and the article “Stalking the Shadow Universe.”

headline: Will Iraqi Blacks Win Justice?
text: BAGHDAD — Jalal Dhiyab Thijeel was tall, funny and handsome, qualities that should have made him a popular man in Basra, Iraq, where he lived. But he was also black, one of hundreds of thousands of Iraqis who have been pushed to the margins of society based on their skin color.

headline: Britain to Hold Inquiry Into Poisoning of Ex-K.G.B. Officer
text: LONDON — Almost eight years after Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer turned whistle-blower, was poisoned in London with a radioactive isotope, the British authorities announced on Tuesday that a public inquiry would be held into his death, permitting investigators to explore whether Russian leaders had ordered the killing.

headline: More Bodies Possible at Ukraine Crash Site, Forensics Officials Say
text: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Bodies and the flight recorders from Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, destroyed by a missile last week over eastern Ukraine, were delivered safely from rebel control to this northeast Ukrainian city on Tuesday. Forensics officials raised the strong possibility that the remains of many victims were still buried in the wreckage and that identification could take weeks or months to complete.

headline: ‘Dust & Grooves’
text: Photos from Eilon Paz’s coffee-table book about record collectors.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills Guards at Afghan Police Compound
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber killed at least four foreign security guards on Tuesday, steering an explosives-laden motorcycle into an Afghan police compound and past several checkpoints before blowing up in an area occupied by trainers from DynCorp International, an American military contractor.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Daily Report: Netflix Makes Plans for International Growth
text: Reed Hastings, chief executive of Netflix, made clear on Monday that as growth in the United States matures, his company has set its sights on international expansion, Emily Steel reports.

headline: New York Today: Live From the Line
text: Good morning on this hotter Tuesday.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times editorial board applauds an executive order signed by President Obama “prohibiting federal contractors, which employ 20 percent of the nation’s work force, from discriminating against gay men, lesbians and transgender people in their employment practices.” This is a fulfillment of a 2008 campaign pledge, building on “previous moves to combat unfair treatment of gay and transgender people” that will “have a positive impact on millions of Americans.” The act of signature is especially impressive “because of his refusal to bow to intense pressure to include an exemption that would have undermined the order by allowing groups with religious objections doing government work to continue discriminatory practices at taxpayer expense.”

headline: The Tragic Price of Flight 17
text: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 is a terrible tragedy, but then we were already well aware of President Vladimir Putin’s dangerous meddling in eastern Ukraine. What we didn’t know about is how the airline industry assesses security risks. I would be interested in reading a thorough piece on how the various civil aviation authorities and airline companies decide which routes are safe to fly. How is it possible that some airlines avoided Ukrainian airspace altogether while others did not? Who in the airline industry is accountable for the demise of Flight 17?

headline: Philosophy With a Newsier Edge
text: Peter Catapano, an editor in Opinion, launched the philosophy series The Stone in 2010, in collaboration with the philosopher Simon Critchley. It appears in Opinionator and often draws hundreds of passionate comments. Mr. Catapano has also developed and edited several other series for Opinionator, including Home Fires, Anxiety and, most recently, Menagerie, on the relationship between humans and animals.

headline: When Hiring Employees in Poorer Countries, Difficult Moral Questions Arise
text: Earlier this year, I wrote about the issues I’d encountered while building an outsourced office in another country. We’ve now expanded to a team of 14 in Manila, and we recruited everyone there using processes similar to those we use at home. I’ve worked out of the office there and have come to know each employee. We hold regular team lunches at our Manila office, and the whole company meets once a week by video conference. As a result, I had the impression that we were building a strong company culture across both offices.

headline: Principals in U.S. Are More Likely to Consider Their Students Poor
text: The phrase “soft bigotry of low expectations” is inevitably associated with George W. Bush, who used it frequently. But whatever your politics, the idea has undeniable merit: If schools don’t expect much from their students, the students are not likely to accomplish much.

headline: 2 Banks Forged in Crisis, CIT and OneWest, Are Set to Merge, to a Big Payoff
text: Updated, 8:05 p.m. | For some, the financial crisis was very, very good.

headline: Twitter Acts Quickly on Suspect Pro-China Accounts
text: Talk about prompt customer service.

headline: Inside a Cigar Factory
text: The J.C. Newman Cigar Company in Tampa, Fla., is trying to hold onto its history and business despite proposed F.D.A. regulations that could force it to shut.

headline: Intersection | Nashville’s Quirky Style
text: In Nashville’s 12 South neighborhood, Logan Yandell, a musician, sports several tattoos that celebrate the city.

headline: 1939: Film Stars Tyrone Power, Annabella Are Besieged in Cannes
text: CANNES — Tyrone Power and Annabella, honeymooning film actors, arrived today [July 22] and immediately set off a flutter of excitement from thousands who wanted to see the American film idol and his French actress bride. They eluded all but the first 100 autograph- seekers and escaped to the near-by surf.  The couple since disembarking ten days ago at Naples had been on a leisurely automobile tour through Italy. The couple will leave tomorrow for Le Pyla to visit Annabella’s mother. Later they will see Paris, then sail in August for America to commence work again in Hollywood in September. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1939

headline: Why Bill de Blasio’s Italian Vacation Could Be Good for New York (Fashion)
text: Much hoo-ha in New York recently over Mayor Bill de Blasio’s departure on his almost-10-day — 10 days! O.M.G.! — family vacation to Italy, the gist of it being: This job is too big, and this city too complicated, for its leader to take off for more than a week.

headline: Morning Agenda: CIT in Deal for OneWest
text: The CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses run by John A. Thain, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The deal will bolster CIT’s lending abilities by more than doubling its deposit base. OneWest currently manages $15 billion in deposits, as well as $23 billion in assets, including commercial and home mortgages. It will merge with CIT’s own bank, creating a subsidiary with $28 billion in deposits and $67 billion in assets.

headline: A Power Broker’s World Comes Tumbling Down
text: As both an actor and a playwright, Wallace Shawn, at his most audacious, goes for the jugular, but in sneaky roundabout ways. In “A Master Builder,” a filmed version of Henrik Ibsen’s play “The Master Builder,” which he also freely adapted, Mr. Shawn stars as the despicable title character, Halvard Solness. As is his wont, Mr. Shawn employs insidious sleight of hand to score moral points. Halvard may not be a murderer, but he relishes crushing the hopes and dreams of everyone around him.

headline: In Performance: Everett Quinton of ‘Drop Dead Perfect’
text: This week’s video features Everett Quinton in a scene from Erasmus Fenn’s “Drop Dead Perfect,” a camp melodrama set in 1952 at a cottage in the Florida Keys. Mr. Quinton plays Idris Seabright, a wealthy and eccentric woman whose life with her handicapped ward, Vivien, is upended when a young stranger named Ricardo shows up at their door.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: A colleague points out that the word “deconstruct” has been getting a workout in The Times lately — and not just in reference to opaque French literary criticism. Some version of it has appeared 19 times in the last month, with a variety of connotations.

headline: Comcast Posts a Strong $2 Billion Profit, and Says It’s Done Buying for Now
text: Comcast said on Tuesday that it should be big enough if its $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable goes through and will not need to make any more major acquisitions, even as merger activity intensifies across the industry.

headline: The New Nigerian Email Swindle
text: Call it the Nigerian email swindle 2.0.

headline: Prototype Festival to Bring Three World Premieres to New York
text: “Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now,” an 11-day festival of experimental opera and theater, will present seven new works — including three world premieres and two works-in-progress — in its third season. The festival, which runs from Jan. 7 to 17, is a collaboration between Here, a compact but enterprising arts center in Greenwich Village, and Beth Morrison Projects, which has become a force in assembling new music and opera productions. The performances will be at Here, La MaMa, Joe’s Pub, Trinity St. Paul’s Chapel and the Park Avenue Armory, in Manhattan; and at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.

headline: Stranded in SoHo, With No Phone and No Money
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Supermodel-Approved Downtown Gym Heads to Montauk (and Classes are Free)
text: From acai bowls to hot yoga, Montauk offers some of the most health-conscious happenings in the Hamptons. Now, a popular new downtown gym is entering the mix. This weekend, ModelFIT, the Karlie Kloss-approved workout located on the Bowery in Manhattan, is coming to the Surf Lodge, where trainers will host two mornings of complimentary classes out on the deck as part of the hotel’s summer wellness program. Available to anyone, even non-hotel guests on a first-come, first-serve basis (there’s a limit of 30 people), the one-hour classes will mix cardio with isometric training for long, lean muscles and a strong core.

headline: Kay Hagan Sidesteps Democratic Party Turmoil in North Carolina
text: Having lost its grip on political power in North Carolina, the state’s Democratic Party has the chance to prove its mettle by helping Kay Hagan retain the Senate seat she won in 2008. But internal party disputes have prompted Ms. Hagan to set up an alternative party structure in Wake County to organize and turn out voters.

headline: Billy Joel to Receive Gershwin Prize for Popular Song
text: Billy Joel will receive the Library of Congress Gershwin Prize for Popular Song at a ceremony in Washington in November, James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, announced Tuesday. Mr. Joel is the sixth recipient of the award, a lifetime achievement prize that honors living songwriters whose work, in the library’s description, exemplifies “the standard of excellence associated with George and Ira Gershwin.”

headline: ‘Not the Time for Antiseptic Coverage': Dean Baquet on Covering Violence Abroad
text: Updated, 10:22 a.m.

headline: Britain Moves to Fortify Law to Protect Girls
text: LONDON — Parents in Britain who subject their daughters to genital mutilation will be prosecuted, Prime Minister David Cameron announced Tuesday, a day after new research showed that the number of victims of the practice here is about twice as high as previously believed.

headline: Putting the ‘Known’ in Known Sperm Donor
text: I had been eager to talk to someone like Flannery ever since I had agreed to become a known sperm donor for my friends, Tori and Kelly. So you’d think I would have managed a more graceful introduction to the topic when, after connecting through a mutual friend, she agreed to meet me at an East Village coffee shop.

headline: A Child of the Slum Rises as President of Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Joko Widodo, the governor of Jakarta whose common touch has made him a political phenomenon, was declared the winner of Indonesia’s presidential election on Tuesday, completing an improbable ascent from child of the slums to leader of the world’s fourth-most populous nation.

headline: Georgia Republicans Choose David Perdue as Their Senate Candidate
text: WASHINGTON — After more than two months of intraparty fighting, David Perdue, a former chief executive of Dollar General, won Tuesday’s Republican runoff in Georgia to become his party’s Senate nominee, setting up one of the few contests where Democrats have hopes of taking a Republican-controlled seat in the midterm elections.

headline: The Dark Side of Sharing
text: While some still praise the “sharing economy” as a boon to our cities and our wallets, the term has come to symbolize, for others, a kind of willful ignorance that recasts poverty as an opportunity for innovation. And now, companies may be moving away from the term ‘sharing’ entirely.

headline: When It Comes to Fiction About National Tragedy, How Soon Is Too Soon?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Anna Holmes discuss whether there is an appropriate amount of time to wait before turning national tragedy or trauma into art.

headline: Hackers Find Way to Outwit Tough Security at Banking Sites
text: It is not often a computer hack is named after cheese.

headline: Spain Sells Catalunya Banc to BBVA for $1.6 Billion
text: MADRID – Spain has taken an important step toward completing the cleanup of its banking sector by selling the state-owned Catalunya Banc to BBVA for 1.19 billion euros, or $1.6 billion.

headline: Returning to Service, and Iraq, With Blackwater
text: “Selfless service.” Words that I’ve lived by for most of my life. Words that my brother and sister military veterans know all too well and continue to live by whether in or out of uniform.

headline: Real Madrid Reaches Deal With World Cup’s Top Scorer
text: In the never-ending arms race for the most skillful and lethal feet in the game, Real Madrid, the Spanish powerhouse and Champions League titleholder, which has stars like Cristiano Ronaldo and Gareth Bale, added the young Colombian James Rodríguez on Tuesday.

headline: New Questions on Health Law as Rulings on Subsidies Differ
text: WASHINGTON — Two federal appeals court panels issued conflicting rulings Tuesday on whether the government could subsidize health insurance premiums for millions of Americans, raising yet more questions about the future of the health care law four years after it was signed by President Obama.

headline: A Brooklyn Bridge Mystery: Who Raised the White Flags?
text: The flags looked innocent enough, billowing merrily in the breeze, pure white against a clear summer sky.

headline: Study Adds to Worries Over Use of Hysterectomy Procedure That May Spread Cancer
text: New evidence adds strength to arguments that doctors should be extremely cautious about using a procedure performed on about 50,000 women a year during surgery to remove the uterus because of the risk that it may spread cancer.

headline: Miami Diner, Pioneer in City’s Race Relations, Serves Last Cup
text: MIAMI — While the line of white customers used to snake out the door at Jumbo’s, a 24-hour diner here, black people were served fried shrimp from a takeout window in the back or crammed into a small table in a darkened storage room.

headline: For the First Time, the Master of the Queen’s Music Is a Mistress
text: Judith Weir, a composer best known for her operas – among them, “A Night at the Chinese Opera,” “The Vanishing Bridegroom” and “Blond Eckbert” – has been appointed Master of the Queen’s Music, an honorary position roughly equivalent to that of Poet Laureate. Queen Elizabeth II was expected to receive Ms. Weir on Tuesday, when her 10-year appointment officially begins, the BBC reported.

headline: Researchers Question Expansion of Antarctica’s Fringe of Sea Ice
text: Updated, July 23, 1:40 p.m. | A new study of methods used to track Antarctic sea ice trends has raised important questions about whether recent increases in ice there are, to a significant extent, an illusion created by flawed analysis of data collected by a series of satellites. The news release excerpted below offers a good overview of the paper — “A spurious jump in the satellite record: has Antarctic sea ice expansion been overestimated?” — which was just published in The Cryosphere. The authors are Ian Eisenman and Joel Norris of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and Walt Meier of NASA.

headline: The Importance of Shedding Some Light on Dark Pools
text: Like the old musical said, “You’ve got Trouble with a capital ‘T’ and that rhymes with ‘p’ and that stands for pool.”

headline: In Search for Gay Characters, Don’t Turn to Action or Fantasy Films
text: LOS ANGELES — As Comic-Con International opens in San Diego with its Wednesday evening preview session, one bit of fantasy is likely to be in relatively short supply: the gay superhero.

headline: Abandoning All Stability to Test Fate
text: Renata Adler’s cult novel “Speedboat” (1976) was reissued last year and has caught on among a new generation of readers. It’s having a long, largely deserved moment.

headline: Technology, Aided by Recession, Is Polarizing the Work World
text: The American work force has been growing polarized for decades. On one end, there are highly skilled jobs like writing software or performing surgery, and on the other are service jobs like child care and cutting hair. The jobs in the middle, meanwhile, such as factory work, sales and bookkeeping, are shrinking — one of the reasons for the economy’s slow climb out of the recession.

headline: Obama Sends Aide to Soothe German Allies
text: WASHINGTON — In a sign of just how much German-American relations have frayed, President Obama sent his chief of staff to Berlin to try to smooth over the rupture caused by recent revelations of American spying on its ally, the White House said Tuesday.

headline: In Dublin, Tweaking a High Tea
text: Luxury hotels in Dublin have a reputation for their formal afternoon teas, but the Four Seasons Hotel Dublin recently introduced Tempo Tea, a more fun and less fancy rendition of the ritual.

headline: New Victory Theater to Host 10 New Works for Children
text: The New Victory Theater, a house known for its presentation of works for children and families, also runs an artists’ residency program, New Victory LabWorks, now in its second year. It gives playwrights, performers and artists in other disciplines rehearsal space and support while they assemble new works for children. During the 2014-15 season, LabWorks will host 10 projects and companies, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Who Said It: Beauty-Pageant Contestant, Philosopher or Politician?
text: Jeff Chu’s article in this past weekend’s magazine about Bill Alverson, a practicing lawyer in Alabama and beauty-pageant coach, noted that one of the biggest challenges for pageant contestants is the interview. Alverson ‘‘often suggests Khaled Hosseini’s novel ‘A Thousand Splendid Suns,’ to improve their understanding of women’s rights globally,’’ Chu writes. ‘‘He also insists that they read The Week and USA Today online.’’

headline: Now You Taste It, Now You Don’t
text: I can’t recall the exact date a few years ago when I ate my first ciabatta egg sandwich at Seersucker, in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But I remember precisely how great it tasted and made me feel, which is why I ate it again and again at every possible opportunity.

headline: Wheelies: The Farewell, Mr. Scheele Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Andy Spade on Learning From David Lynch, Amish Clothing and Rene Ricard
text: Andy Spade does many things, all with an intimidating degree of success. He has helped transform the role of “curator” into that of “business strategist,” lending his canny eye to major brands like J. Crew and Target. He is also an entrepreneur, helping to launch the Kate Spade handbag empire, Jack Spade menswear, Sleepy Jones (a line of pajamas and intimates) and, soon, the Boerum House & Home store in Brooklyn. The new shop, a collaboration with Flank Architects, will feature objects from 130 designers. He also produces movies, shoots photographs and makes books. Here, a few of the inspirations that drive this very driven man.

headline: Candidate Rejects Indonesia’s Election
text: Prabowo Subianto, a retired Indonesian Army general, denounced the result of the country’s presidential election and withdrew his candidacy.

headline: Obama Goes to West Coast for 3 Days With Donors
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will spend the next three days helping to fill the coffers of his party’s campaign committees and working to lift the fortunes of two “super PACs” created to help House and Senate candidates in the midterm elections.

headline: Getting From Gaza to Israel, by Underground Tunnels
text: The Israeli military said the focus of its ground operations in Gaza is to destroy the labyrinth of tunnels from the strip into Israel that can be used for launching attacks.

headline: Airlines Suspend Flights to Israel After Hamas Rocket Falls Near Main Airport
text: Airlines in the United States and Europe suspended flights to and from Israel on Tuesday after a rocket fell about a mile from Ben-Gurion International Airport outside Tel Aviv.

headline: In Shake-Up at Sony Pictures, Jeff Blake to Leave
text: In another jolt to its rapidly changing management structure, Sony Pictures Entertainment said that Jeff Blake, the company’s vice chairman and the chairman of its worldwide marketing and distribution operation, will leave on Aug. 1.

headline: Time Warner Deal Clad in the Emperor’s Old Clothes
text: Time Warner shareholders who are pondering whether to surrender to Rupert Murdoch would be well advised to listen to the media mogul’s muzzled minorities. Most 21st Century Fox believers are relegated to owning nonvoting stock in the conglomerate, the same second-tier paper on offer as part of the $80 billion takeover bid for the owner of HBO, CNN and Warner Bros. studios. Despite broad investor overlap in the two companies, the record shows a clear distaste for Mr. Murdoch’s imperialism.

headline: Giving Another Debut Author the Colbert Bump
text: Stephen Colbert has rescued another Hachette debut novelist from possible obscurity.

headline: Not Everyone Is Addicted to Inflation
text: Paul Krugman made a little fun of me in a column last week. He wrote that “market monetarism,” a set of ideas about monetary policy that I once called “the shining success of the conservative reform movement,” had not caught on with any actual conservatives. Over the last few years, market monetarists have wanted looser money and higher inflation. Yet many conservatives still fear inflation and want tight money; in 2012, the Republican Party even added a plank to its platform calling for re-examination of the gold standard.

headline: Fortune Names Alan Murray Top Editor
text: Fortune magazine appointed Alan Murray, the president of the Pew Research Center and a former deputy managing editor at The Wall Street Journal, as its new top editor on Tuesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Startup Guy’ Fashion
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': We Really Are Putting on a Play
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: No-Stick, No-Fuss, No-Fail Rice
text: Kim Severson offers up a recipe for can’t-miss rice, which surprisingly involves the oven.

headline: Rulings on Health Law Are Far From Last Word
text: An appellate court ruling issued Tuesday would be very bad news for the Affordable Care Act if it became the law of the land. But it’s still a long way from a settled issue, as a second appellate decision, issued a few hours later, highlighted.

headline: A Singapore Startup Sells Contemporary Art from Southeast Asia, Without the Intimidation Factor
text: Groceries, books, clothing — we buy everything, it seems, from our laptops and phones these days, so why not original art too? That’s the question posed by the founders of Art Loft, a Singapore-based e-commerce art platform with a focus on connecting emerging contemporary artists, largely from Southeast Asia, with collectors around the world.

headline: 1964: De Gaulle Refuses to Pay U.N.
text: PARIS — During his talks with U Thant yesterday [July 21], President Charles de Gaulle flatly turned down the United Nations secretary-general’s request for payment of French debts to the world organization. U Thant left Paris ‘‘without illusions and without hope,’’ said an official French spokesman today. Thus, despite the warm praise, which Gen. de Gaulle and U Thant exchanged, all hope disappeared that France would pay the $16 million it owes the UN for the Congo operation, an action France opposed from the start. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1964

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Would Address Hamas Demands After Cease-Fire
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday said that the United States was prepared to address the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip and the political demands of the Palestinians living there, but that a cease-fire first needed to be carried out.

headline: London Theater Journal: On Artifice and Oxygen, Earnest and Jeeves
text: LONDON — People often speak of poetic license, but why not theatrical license? Think of the wanton liberties that have been taken with respectable plays over the years in the name of showbiz, box office, star power and intellectual theorizing.

headline: Spitzer Returns, Taking Aim Again at Financial Analysts
text: Eliot Spitzer has re-emerged in the public eye.

headline: In Praise of the Trusty Rice Cooker
text: Every cook has her trusted tools. Those implements that help you through just about any prep process and make the kitchen feel like home. For many it’s a special chef’s knife that sits just right in the hand, a cutting board with the perfect amount of countertop acreage, or maybe a sauté pan that responds to the slightest change in flame.

headline: Fluffy. Tasty. Tricky.
text: ATLANTA — Of the many ways I can be humbled in the kitchen, rice is at the top of the list. I’m not a bad cook but, oh, the pots of rice I have driven to a gummy, scorched grave.

headline: The Whiskey Bar Is Taking a Step Up
text: Multnomah Whiskey Library in Portland, Ore., has a lot of the things you’d expect to find in a whiskey bar — leather chairs, dark wood, a certain amber glow. It also has something you don’t see every day: a ladder.

headline: Senate Panel Takes On Tax Inversions
text: The chorus of voices on Capitol Hill calling for an end to corporate inversions grew louder on Tuesday as the Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on the issue of American companies reincorporating abroad, and legislators proposed new punitive measures against inverted companies.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 4 | A Millennial on Patriotism
text: For five years now, every week during the summer we’ve invited teenagers all over the world to come to our blog and answer the question, “What interested you most in The Times this week?”

headline: Yankees’ Newest Upgrade Drives in the Game Winner
text: At the end of a hectic day in which Chase Headley left the only organization he ever played for to join the most famous club in baseball, the situation called for a moment of calm reflection.

headline: Melodrama in Full Flower (and With a Wink)
text: “Meadowlark,” the Stephen Schwartz ballad from the musical “The Baker’s Wife,” is a classic example of a song from a flop musical that endures and takes on a life of its own as a semioperatic showpiece. It needs a substantial voice to do it justice, and on a recent night at the Metropolitan Room, Marieann Meringolo, a singer who bears some physical and vocal resemblance to Barbra Streisand, delivered one of the two or three strongest renditions I can remember.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief Testifies at Senate Tax-Avoidance Hearing
text: Updated, 8:30 p.m. | Complex financial instruments that the government has said helped the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies claim billions of dollars in tax savings were “extremely important,” its co-chief executive said at a Senate hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Putin Pledges to Help but Sees Limits on Role
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin delivered a short but wide-ranging foreign policy speech on Tuesday, pledging to use Russia’s influence on the separatists in eastern Ukraine while also seeking to reassure his domestic audience that any fallout from the downing of a passenger jet over Ukraine could be contained.

headline: What the Internet Can See From Your Cat Pictures
text: Your cat may never give up your secrets. But your cat photos might.

headline: Champagne Charlie’s Opens at the High Line Hotel
text: Headliner

headline: BATS President William O’Brien Departs
text: BATS Global Markets, the exchange operator, said on Tuesday that its president, William O’Brien, had left the company.

headline: Toronto Film Festival to Include Films by Chris Rock and Noah Baumbach
text: LOS ANGELES — Bill Pohlad, the film financier, directs a biopic, “Love & Mercy,” about Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys, who is played by both Paul Dano and John Cusack. Noah Baumbach writes and directs a story of aging and ambition, called “While We’re Young.” Chris Rock goes one better: He writes, directs and stars in “Top Five,” about a New York City comedian-turned-movie star.

headline: Facts & Figures: Higher ‘Obamacare’ Bills Under Halbig
text: A panel of the D.C. federal appellate court ruled today that the federal government does not have the authority to administer insurance subsidies in states that refused to set up their own exchanges. If the ruling stands—a big if—it could deprive millions of enrollees of the support they need to purchase health insurance.

headline: Russian Spy’s Widow on U.K. Inquiry
text: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of the poisoned former Russian agent Alexander V. Litvinenko, spoke after Britain announced it was opening a public investigation into her husband’s death.

headline: Putin’s Response to Crash Investigation
text: President Vladimir V. Putin discussed the investigation into the Malaysia Airlines passenger jet crash and criticized Kiev and the West for escalating conflict in the region.

headline: Obama Signs New Job-Training Law
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, citing a “skills gap” that prevents many unemployed workers from qualifying for new jobs, signed legislation on Tuesday to bolster federal job-training programs.

headline: The ‘Death Blow’ to Herbalife Promised by William Ackman Falls Short of Its Billing
text: It was billed as the event that would deal a “death blow” to Herbalife. It was supposed to be “the most important presentation” in the career of William A. Ackman, the hedge fund billionaire who has pilloried the company for a year and a half and is betting against its stock.

headline: 10 Tours and 205 Tries Later, Australian Wins a Stage
text: BAGNÈRES-DE-LUCHON, France — Michael Rogers has many cycling titles to his name, including three world time trial championships. But it took until his 10th Tour de France for him to win a stage of the sport’s most prominent event.

headline: Photo Storage by Personality (Yours)
text: Laptop littered with vacation photos? And dare I mention your smartphone? There are dozens of solutions for storing and organizing your snapshots. But how to choose?

headline: After Health Law Rulings, Here Are Possible Next Steps
text: We now have two federal appeals courts that have issued conflicting rulings on a major provision of the Affordable Care Act. Those decisions are not the final word on whether residents of some states will be able to continue receiving financial assistance to buy health insurance. Here are some possible next steps:

headline: Jane Alexander's Bird-Watching Tips
text: Bird-watching, it turns out, is a hobby well suited to film actors, who go to far-flung locations and can have time to kill between shooting.

headline: Exxon Mobil Moves Ahead With Russian Oil Drilling Project
text: MOSCOW — Exxon Mobil, which is assisting a Russian state energy company in exploring the Arctic Ocean for oil and natural gas, took a pivotal step to further this project over the weekend.

headline: A World Teaches and Tugs
text: Enveloped in a sweetness that buffers the depths of its emotions, Hiroyuki Okiura’s “A Letter to Momo” explores the stains of loss and regret on a personality too young to articulate them. Yet the film’s tiniest viewers are more likely to be entranced than distressed by this magical animated tale — Mr. Okiura’s second, after “Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade” (2001) — even if their parents find themselves surreptitiously sniffling.

headline: The High/Low | Tough Sandals at a Gentle Price
text: July in New York means sweaty bangs, sticky skin and seemingly unsolvable fashion challenges — like finding a stylish sandal that’s sturdy enough for watching outdoor live shows, trekking to surf spots at the Rockaways and dancing on Brooklyn rooftops. Thankfully, 2014 has been the year of the comfort shoe in fashion, and the heavy-soled sandal trend that walked the spring 2014 Givenchy runway and carried over into such fall 2014 shows as Céline has now trickled down to two go-to sites for all things cool: Asos and Nasty Gal. Dr. Martens, too, is offering a reasonably priced rendition of the tough sandal. These versions are affordable even for 20-somethings, so take your pick and wear them out for what’s left of summer.

headline: Pizza to Go, and on the Go
text: To Enjoy: A Wood-Fired Pizza Cart That Roams the City

headline: BorderMania Jumps the Shark
text: There is a crisis at the border. It involves tens of thousands of children fleeing Central America. And it is real.

headline: War and Media in the Gaza Strip
text: Alleged gunfire at an Al Jazeera bureau in Gaza on Tuesday was hardly a boon to the Israeli Defense Forces’ public image – and this was only the latest installment in a string of P.R. debacles facing the Jewish state.

headline: A Spinster at the Center of a Madcap Swirl. Cue the Double Entendres.
text: In a sweet 1950s peach crocheted dress and matching bolero, Everett Quinton has never looked lovelier. As Idris Seabright, a lonely and overwrought spinster growing old in the Florida Keys, he laments a storm having wreaked “havoc on my African hibiscus — and my poor bougainvillea,” hitting each syllable with that posh Eastern accent that 1930s actresses favored. When a chord of ominous movie music plays, Idris strikes a terrified pose, and we could easily be downtown at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, where Mr. Quinton and Charles Ludlam starred in the original “The Mystery of Irma Vep” 30 years ago.

headline: Obama on Work Force Innovation
text: The president discussed the bipartisan bill that helps expand opportunity for more workers by ensuring they will have access to the training and skills they need to compete in the work force.

headline: Linda Ronstadt, Brooklyn Academy of Music Among National Medal of Arts Recipients
text: President Obama will present the 2013 National Medal of Arts, the government’s highest award for artists and arts patrons, to 12 honorees at a ceremony in the East Room of the White House on Monday.

headline: Iraqi Police Use Detentions to Blunt Militants
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi security forces on Tuesday said they had briefly detained a woman near the city of Samarra who was said to be a relative of the leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, in part of intensifying campaign to find a lever against the advancing militant group.

headline: Palestinian Family Finds Missing Son in YouTube Video of His Shooting
text: After two days of searching for a son they lost contact with during a rushed evacuation from their home in Gaza City, one Palestinian family was surprised to hear the young man’s voice, calling out for a missing cousin, in video posted on YouTube on Monday by human rights activists.

headline: U.S. Diplomacy in the Gaza Crisis
text: As the death toll rises in the latest round of Israeli-Palestinian fighting, a look at the Obama administration’s strategy for reaching a cease-fire.

headline: Made in House? Prove It
text: PARIS — The black-and-white symbol looks like a saucepan with a roof for a lid. And if it sits next to an entry on a restaurant menu, it signals that the dish is “fait maison” — house-made.

headline: Debt Disaster Dead-Enders
text: I got some correspondence from people telling me to read Rob Portman’s op-ed in the WSJ, intended to refute the growing evidence that the budget deficit has been grossly overrated as an issue. And it is an interesting piece — it’s a very good illustration both of the desperate desire to see a debt crisis, and what happens when someone (Portman, or more likely the staffer who wrote it) tries to be a Very Serious Person without actually understanding the numbers or having followed any of the analysis.

headline: A Youthful Vigor, Flowing Through to His Fingertips
text: There is always a downside in describing a young artist like the brilliant New York-based pianist Conor Hanick as a champion of contemporary music. At 31, Mr. Hanick, who holds a doctorate from the Juilliard School, has won acclaim for his exciting performances of new and recent music with orchestras and ensembles around the world. On Monday night he brought his enthusiasm for contemporary music to the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, at Mannes College the New School for Music, playing an engrossing and, in his own words, “unorthodox” program.

headline: Chaotic Yet Pensive, Pounding the Keys
text: Villa-Lobos wrote his “Rudepoêma” — a 20-minute solo work sometimes described as “ ‘The Rite of Spring’ meets the Brazilian jungle” — as a portrait of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein, a friend who had championed his music. Villa-Lobos said he wanted to portray Rubinstein’s “true temperament” in the work.

headline: Yearning for Performers Who Transcend Victim and Vamp
text: Much about the current Bolshoi Ballet season at the Lincoln Center Festival is unexplained. Since other Western cities have seen this Moscow company’s productions of “Coppélia,” “Lost Illusions,” “Jewels,” why isn’t New York seeing them? All of them would expand our idea of the troupe. And why has the company not brought Evgenia Obraztsova, Ruslan Skvortsov or Vyacheslav Lopatin? Each has made a striking impression in one or more leading roles in recent live broadcasts by the company; Ms. Obraztsova, in particular, is one of the world’s most exquisite classical stylists. You’d think that a troupe that lost Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev in 2011 would be working harder to prove that it has an abundance of remaining stars.

headline: Rehearsal: ‘Slonimsky’s Earbox’
text: Stephan Asbury leads the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra in a rehearsal of John Adams’s “Slonimsky’s Earbox.”

headline: Four Cases Challenging Health Care Subsidies
text: Two federal appeals courts issued conflicting rulings on whether the Internal Revenue Service is allowed to provide subsidies for premiums to people in states that use the federal insurance exchange.

headline: At 50, Festival Is Reunion of Sorts
text: LENOX, Mass. — Whatever became of the composer John Adams?

headline: Love Cruises on Dry Land
text: SinglesCruise.com – a travel agency known for turning ships into potential love boats with cocktail parties, dance lessons and karaoke nights – is taking its solo tours to dry land.

headline: Apple Reports $7.7 Billion Profit on Strong iPhone Sales
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For Apple, the iPhone continues to be the device that makes the company tick.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: LinkedIn Makes Another Deal, Buying Bizo
text: LinkedIn, the social network for professionals, is revving up its deals machine.

text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Ukraine and Syria.

headline: A Parisian ‘Neo-Bistro’ Comes to Town
text: You can’t get mad at a macaron, but with all due respect I’d suggest that there are other French ideas about eating that would benefit New York more than balloon-weight sandwich cookies in sidewalk-chalk colors. We could, for instance, use a few wine bars of the type that began sprouting around Paris about a decade ago.

headline: Microsoft’s Profits Slide on Mobile, but Its Cloud Flourishes
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s new chief executive has said the two most important trends for the company’s future are mobile and cloud computing. But it is doing much better in cloud computing than in mobile.

headline: Cuomo’s State of the State Address
text: In his State of the State address on Jan. 8, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on lawmakers to pass new ethics measures in response to recent corruption scandals.

headline: Commission Urged to Be Aggressive
text: At the Moreland Commission’s first public hearing on Sept. 17, 2013, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, called on the panel to show “toughness and independence.”

headline: When a Museum’s Big Dreams Prove Too Ambitious
text: A rendering of the new Museum for African Art, with its soaring four-story wall, curved ceiling of rare Ghanaian wood and elaborate spiraling staircase, still sits on an easel in an unfinished concrete skeleton facing Central Park.

headline: Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Stay in Provincetown This Summer
text: To get to Provincetown, Mass., you need time and patience, which are easy things to allot yourself when you remember the town’s quaint colonial cape homes, its miles of grassy dunes and the way the light plays off of Cape Cod Bay, making it wink and twinkle like gold in the afternoon and turn to pink glass at sunset. This artists’ enclave and tourist community, where international film and theater festivals keep the town busy between themed weeks, is also a great place to indulge in good food and shopping when you’re not at the beach.

headline: Film Has Crowds Swarming to Beijing House, Haunted or Not
text: Chaonei No. 81, arguably Beijing’s most celebrated “haunted house,” has seen a steady stream of visitors over the years. Until recently, they were a niche assortment — mostly thrill-seekers, urban explorers and history buffs — looking to experience firsthand the lurid tales of the once-grand French Baroque-style mansion, which has long sat dilapidated and abandoned. Foremost among the many legends associated with Chaonei No. 81 is that the mansion is haunted by the ghost of the mistress of a Kuomintang official who hanged herself there after her lover abandoned her following the Communist victory in 1949.

headline: A Dearth in Innovation for Key Drugs
text: There is clearly something wrong with pharmaceutical innovation.

headline: Verizon Slims Down, to Developers’ Delight
text: In the merry-go-round of redevelopment projects in New York — where office buildings turn into apartment houses, and factories into offices, and so on — a utility company has become a timely and reliable source of real estate.

headline: The Top Properties in Hong Kong Housing Resist Market Forces
text: HONG KONG — When the Opus project was unveiled in 2012, its developer boasted that the apartments there, designed by the star architect Frank Gehry, would be the most expensive in Hong Kong — and, by extension, probably the world.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Stanley C. Gale
text: Mr. Gale, 63, is the chairman and chief executive of Gale International, a development company based in New York best known for its work on the Songdo International Business District in South Korea, a so-called smart city, in which the company is a majority partner. It is also developing 21W20, a boutique condominium in the Flatiron district.

headline: ‘Bullets Over Broadway,’ the Musical, to Close Aug. 24
text: It’s been a rough month for big-budget Broadway musicals based on beloved movies. One week after the $15 million musical “Rocky” posted a closing notice, the producers of the $14 million “Bullets Over Broadway” – Woody Allen’s first stage musical – announced on Tuesday night that the show would close on Aug. 24.

headline: Washington Mudslide Report Cites Rain, but Doesn’t Give Cause or Assign Blame
text: SEATTLE — The landslide that killed 43 people in March in the tiny community of Oso, Wash., was in keeping with a history of geological instability in the Cascade Mountains going back thousands of years. But it was also linked to more recent events, including the destabilization of soil from a slide in the same place in 2006 and, possibly, logging, scientists said Tuesday.

headline: An Austrian Company in Gazprom’s Grip
text: LONDON — With tensions escalating between Russia and the West, and Moscow facing the possibility of tougher economic sanctions, few European executives may feel caught in the middle more than Gerhard Roiss.
