text: After having grown up in the United States as an undocumented immigrant, Rufino Santiz Díaz decided to go back to Mexico — and now finds himself caught between two worlds.

headline: Fighting in Gaza Continues
text: The Palestinian death toll rose while the Israeli military said it had struck weapons stores and other infrastructure in Gaza.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Reports Bias by the Police in Newark
text: A three-year federal investigation has found that the Newark Police Department engaged in a pattern of unconstitutional practices, chiefly in its use of stop-and-frisk tactics, unwarranted stops and arrests, and discriminatory police actions, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Familiar Ignition Flaw Leads to Recall by Chrysler of Jeep S.U.V.s
text: Chrysler said on Tuesday that it was recalling an undisclosed number of older Jeep S.U.V.s to correct an ignition-related stalling problem similar to the deadly flaw that has consumed General Motors this year.

headline: Officials Focus on E-Cigarette Ads Aimed at Youths
text: PARK CITY, Utah — State attorneys general must investigate, and consider taking legal action against, e-cigarette companies that appear to be using some of the same advertising tactics that once drew young adults into smoking, a Kentucky deputy attorney general told his law enforcement colleagues gathered here for a retreat to discuss emerging legal issues in states nationwide.

headline: Judge Orders Argentina and New York Hedge Funds to Negotiate
text: Under the looming cloud of a default, Argentina and a group of New York hedge funds that are engaged in a bitter fight over debt repayments have been ordered to meet with a court-appointed mediator “continuously” until the two sides can come to an agreement.

headline: De Blasio Embraces Capri, Even While Avoiding Its Limelight
text: CAPRI, Italy — There was no accidental meeting with Cameron Diaz, Lea Michele or Lindsay Lohan, just three of the celebrities spotted on this exclusive island in the past few days.

headline: Off Alabama’s Beaten Path, Tribute to a Native American’s Journey Home
text: FLORENCE, Ala. — Tom Hendrix spent a quarter-century stacking eight million pounds of sandstone and limestone to honor a woman he never knew.

headline: Putin’s Crime, Europe’s Cowardice
text: TANGIER, Morocco — IN eastern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin has been playing with fire.

headline: Ukrainians, Awaiting International Action After Crash, Fear Complacency
text: KIEV, Ukraine — From the moment it became clear that a civilian jetliner had been shot down over eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people and jolting the world’s attention to the country’s battle with Russian-backed insurgents, many Ukrainians, including senior officials here in the capital, have been awaiting a forceful international response. They are still waiting.

headline: Apple Case Over Labor Code Is Granted Class-Action Status
text: A state court in California has granted class certification to nearly 21,000 current and former Apple employees over claims that the company failed to provide timely meal and rest breaks as required by the law, and sometimes denied workers rest breaks altogether.

headline: The Top Priority: Safety or Vanity?
text: SAN DIEGO — When the bullpen gates open and San Diego Padres reliever Alex Torres is summoned, he takes off in an all-out sprint until he reaches the lip of the infield. Then he abruptly stops and takes a slow, purposeful walk to the mound.

headline: Lenders Offer Low-Cost Services for the Unbanked
text: One woman kept her savings — a $100 bill — in the freezer. Another, a single mother in Texas, said she had only enough extra cash each week to buy one wooden letter, for $3, to spell out her daughter’s name on her bedroom wall. A third, a housekeeper in Brooklyn, lives in a homeless shelter.

headline: A 401(k) for All
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — ONE compelling way to turn the ongoing national discussion on wealth inequality into a tangible policy to help Americans increase their wealth and savings would be to fix what I have long called our “upside-down” tax incentive system for retirement savings. In its current form, it makes higher-income Americans triple winners and people earning less money triple losers.

headline: Prosecutors Are Reading Emails From Inmates to Lawyers
text: The extortion case against Thomas DiFiore, a reputed boss in the Bonanno crime family, encompassed thousands of pages of evidence, including surveillance photographs, cellphone and property records, and hundreds of hours of audio recordings.

headline: Changing Old Antitrust Thinking for a New Gilded Age
text: The trust is back, baby.

headline: Execution in Arizona Is Approved by Justices
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday allowed the execution of an Arizona inmate to proceed, lifting a stay from a federal appeals court that had been based on the secrecy of the state’s lethal-injection protocol.

headline: Fed Is Said to Criticize Deutsche Bank’s Oversight and Reporting Efforts
text: Deutsche Bank’s primary regulator in the United States has found serious problems with the bank’s financial reporting procedures and oversight, a lawyer briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Darkness Falls on Gaza
text: GAZA CITY

headline: Amazon’s Fire Phone: Solid Device Beneath a Layer of Whiz-Bang Frippery
text: When Amazon.com unveiled its first smartphone last month, Jeff Bezos, the company’s chief executive, said the device was partly inspired by one of his favorite childhood books, “Mr. Pine’s Purple House.” In the book, by Leonard Kessler, friendly old Mr. Pine grows weary of the 50 identical white houses, all in a line, on Vine Street. When he paints his house purple, his radical color scheme sets off an explosion of architectural innovation among his neighbors on Vine Street, which apparently has a pretty lenient homeowner’s association.

headline: Cash, but Not Remedial Tools, in Wrongful-Death Settlements
text: On a Saturday evening in July five years ago, Shem Walker tried to roust a bummy-looking guy from the stoop of his mother’s brownstone on Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn. One thing led to another; a second man came to help the bum. Mr. Walker, 49, was shot dead.

headline: ‘Two Countries, No Home’
text: Earlier this year, I met a group of young people in Mexico City who call themselves “the other Dreamers,” undocumented young people taken to the United States as children who returned to their birth countries. Some had been deported, while others had voluntarily returned to Mexico and were working or making their way through college. Many told me of their struggles to adapt to what, for them, was largely a foreign culture. They had left behind friends, family and important parts of their identity in the United States, which for many of them was the only home they had ever really known.

headline: Eyes on Gaza, Tensions Flare in Brooklyn
text: The worshipers, young and old, converged on mosques in Brooklyn this weekend, seeking olive green rugs on which to rest their knees, and pray. One week before the end of Ramadan, prayers rebounded off the walls with even more fervor than usual.

headline: Spartan Hockey Helmets Going Under Microscope
text: BLACKSBURG, Va. — Hockey helmets may be on the verge of a radical makeover, as scientists and engineers at Virginia Tech prepare a rating system that measures each brand’s and model’s ability to reduce the risk of concussion.

headline: Plan for Young Migrants at Impasse in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers are deadlocked on a plan to deal with the surge in migrant children who are filling detention centers along the Mexican border, with both Democrats and Republicans saying Tuesday that it was increasingly unlikely they could reach an accord before Congress leaves town for a five-week recess at the end of the month.

headline: Reaction to Chokehold Death in New York
text: New York state and city officials demanded a full investigation into the death of Eric Garner after he was placed in a chokehold while being arrested by the police.

headline: French Food Goes Down
text: Before my first visit to France, around 45 years ago, I was told that you couldn’t find bad food there if you tried. I was of limited experience, so even a hot dog jammed into a baguette bore witness to that “fact.”

headline: New York City Police Study Use of Force; May Issue More Tasers
text: Days after the death of a man who was subdued by police officers on Staten Island, the Police Department is undertaking a sweeping review of its training and tactics, Commissioner William J. Bratton said on Tuesday.

headline: Celebrities on Scottish Independence
text: Actors, authors and singers weigh in on whether or not Scotland should break away from Britain, ahead of the country’s referendum in September.

headline: Reading the Future of Scotland in the Stars
text: LONDON — Sean Connery is in favor, J. K. Rowling is against. Ewan McGregor and Emma Thompson don’t really want it, but Annie Lennox and the boss of British Airways sort of do. And everyone is dying to know: Where does Andy Murray stand?

headline: An Ominous Health Care Ruling
text: Millions of low- and moderate-income people who signed up for health insurance with the help of federal tax-credit subsidies could find themselves without coverage or facing big premium bills if a destructive decision handed down by a federal appeals court in Washington on Tuesday is not reversed. It would be a crippling blow to the ability of the Affordable Care Act to reduce the ranks of the uninsured with grievous consequences for vulnerable customers.

headline: Painful Progress in Detroit
text: If the measure of a good compromise is that everyone is left unhappy, the Detroit bankruptcy plan certainly qualifies.

headline: Confirmation Hearing Becomes Debate on Veterans Affairs
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers on Tuesday used the confirmation hearing of Robert A. McDonald to lead the embattled Department of Veterans Affairs to debate whether the agency needed more money to remedy its institutional problems.

headline: Hamas Gambled on War as Its Woes Grew in Gaza
text: GAZA CITY — When war between Israel and Hamas broke out two weeks ago, the Palestinian militant group was so hamstrung, politically, economically and diplomatically, that its leaders appeared to feel they had nothing to lose.

headline: Seizing the Day at Ground Zero
text: The sight of throngs of people milling about ground zero so freely, in a spirit of wonder and recreation, is a pleasant shock upon arrival at the National September 11 Memorial Museum, now a booming part of the tourist season. Here, a decade of no-go security and endless reconstruction has yielded to innocent crowds strolling around what was once scorched earth.

headline: Runyonesque Flurry Spans Two Arenas
text: Gennady Golovkin will perform twice on Broadway this week: once inside a theater, and once inside a boxing ring.

headline: For Retirees, Decision on Concussion Settlement Will Not Be a Simple One
text: Class-action settlements are often messy. When enough aggrieved people are thrown together, it is natural that some of them will be unhappy with a deal that is a result of a negotiation between parties trying to avoid a long, expensive trial with an uncertain outcome.

headline: Youth Group Stuck in Israel After Flights Are Halted
text: Like thousands of Jewish children, a group of 25 high school students with the North American Federation of Temple Youth took a summertime excursion to Israel, in their case spending much of their two weeks at Kibbutz Tzuba in the golden Judean Hills outside Jerusalem. They were supposed to fly back to New York on Tuesday night.

headline: Self-Defense or Atrocities in Gaza?
text: Are Israel's actions a necessary and appropriate response to an enemy that won't be peaceful or are they immoral and out of proportion to any threat?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 22, 2014
U.S. Military Is Scrutinized Over Trash Burning in Afghanistan
text: The United States military spent millions of dollars on garbage incinerators in Afghanistan that went unused as tons of trash burned in open piles, wafting toxic smoke over thousands of troops, according to a report released Tuesday by an American watchdog agency.

headline: An Exaltation of Moths, Much-Maligned Kin of the Butterfly
text: LYNDHURST, N.J. — The night was still young and a tad too breezy. But already, more than a hundred people were gathered around a series of fluttering, black-lighted sheets in the middle of the New Jersey Meadowlands, waiting for their quarry.

headline: Nervous Energy on Day 1 as Giants Banish the Past
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With more than 40 new players in uniform, three new coaches and a redesigned offensive system so new that even the head coach has to study it regularly to keep up, the Giants went through their first full day of summer practice on Tuesday.

headline: Hamas’s Tunnels to Israel
text: An underground look at Hamas’s tunnels into Israel.

headline: Complete Freedom
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I love it when I get to introduce you all to some of the wonderful people in crossword puzzle land. It’s tough to get to know many of these people if you are not able to attend the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament or Lollapuzzoola, so allow me to bring them to you. They’re worth getting to know.

headline: Repertory of Fear and Hope
text: Playing your mom onstage would be a challenge for even a seasoned actress. Playing your mom at 14? Yikes! So it’s all the more remarkable that Mona Golabek, who is undertaking this feat in “The Pianist of Willesden Lane,” seems to slip so effortlessly into the persona of her mother, the pianist Lisa Jura, during her tumultuous adolescence in Vienna and London.

headline: They Did This? In Rebel Country, Disbelief
text: SNIZHNE, Ukraine — It was photographed rolling past the Pitstop Market gas station in Torez. It was seen near the city sauna here, and was caught on video creeping up Gagarin Street, past an auto parts store and the Ivushka food mart in the direction of the Russian border.

headline: Player in Dolphins’ Bullying Scandal Won’t Discuss Specifics
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — John Jerry, a prominent figure in the Miami Dolphins’ bullying scandal last year who signed as a free agent with the Giants earlier this year, said Tuesday that he discussed his role in the Dolphins’ case with the Giants before joining the team.

headline: Henry Hartsfield Jr. Is Dead at 80; Flew, With Fortune, on 3 Shuttles
text: Henry Hartsfield Jr., who flew on three NASA space shuttles, including as the pilot of the final test flight of the Columbia and as the commander of the maiden mission of the Discovery, died on Thursday. He was 80.

headline: For Israelis on Edge of Battle, Rockets Put On a Show
text: SDEROT, Israel — The women and children trudge up the dusty hill between dusk and sunset, some with dogs. The men stay long after dark, some with binoculars. It is the closest thing to a front-row seat for the war between Israel and the Gaza Strip, short of combat. Better than being stuck in a safe room somewhere watching those talking heads on television.

headline: Kenneth Noble, Ex-Times Reporter, Is Dead at 60
text: Kenneth B. Noble, a New York Times reporter who covered business and finance in Washington and civil war in Africa, and who headed the newspaper’s Los Angeles bureau during the O. J. Simpson trial, died on Thursday in Gainesville, Fla. He was 60.

headline: Hearings on Water Permits for Indian Point
text: CORTLANDT, N.Y. — A giant power plant that kills tiny fish eggs is leading engineers, government officials, politicians and advocates of all stripes into a fourth year of debate about which side represents concern for the environment, and whether the fish are actually the issue.

headline: ‘Swan Lake’
text: Scenes from the Bolshoi Ballet’s production at Lincoln Center.

headline: Mets’ Late First-Half Optimism Takes an Early Second-Half Hit
text: SEATTLE — The scene that played out in the visiting manager’s office here Monday night had occurred 50 or so times before. Manager Terry Collins, slouched in his chair, crossed his arms, pursed his lips and struggled to explain another Mets loss.

headline: Crises Cascade and Converge, Testing Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after a passenger jet exploded in midair and plummeted to the ground in Ukraine last week, escalating a volatile crisis pitting the United States and Europe against Russia, President Obama’s thoughts turned to Syria.

headline: Investigators Detail Missteps in Verification for Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators working undercover said Tuesday that they had been able to obtain subsidized health insurance under the Affordable Care Act using fictitious identities and false documents.

headline: Report Cites ‘Aggressive’ Islamic Push in British City’s Schools
text: LONDON — First there was an anonymous letter outlining an Islamic takeover of British schools in Muslim neighborhoods ominously called Operation Trojan Horse. Then the letter was found to be riddled with inaccuracies and widely deemed to be a hoax.

headline: Promises of Hope Tarnished by Lack of Change
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — The excitement that flooded this city’s Liberation Plaza two years ago, when Enrique Peña Nieto announced his presidential candidacy amid mariachi bands, young hipsters and swooning women, has not just dissipated. For many, it has curdled.

headline: Turkey: Officers Arrested in Spy Case
text: Dozens of Turkish police officers were detained on Tuesday and accused of spying on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his top aides, news agencies reported. The Istanbul chief prosecutor’s office, in a statement carried by the semiofficial Anadolu News Agency, said the officers had fabricated an investigation into a supposed terrorist group as a pretense to spy on top officials. More than 500 prominent figures have been illegally wiretapped since 2010, CNN Turk television reported, citing the prosecutors’ office. More than 100 officers have been charged with falsifying evidence, illegal wiretapping and espionage, and 67 were taken into custody in a 22-city security operation. Some of those who were detained were involved in a corruption inquiry that ensnared Mr. Erdogan’s close circle and forced four ministers to resign in December, news reports said. Mr. Erdogan has said the graft investigation was driven by people loyal to Fetullah Gulen, a cleric who lives in Pennsylvania and is a former ally who still has influence in various state institutions. Sinan Ulgen, a visiting scholar at Carnegie Europe in Brussels, called the arrests “the latest episode in the war waged against the Gulen community.”

headline: U.N. Warns of Polio Risk in War Zones
text: The United Nations expressed concern about the possible spread of polio in the war-ravaged countries of Syria and Iraq and beyond on Tuesday despite the biggest vaccination campaign undertaken in the history of the Middle East. A report by the World Health Organization and Unicef said that 36 children had been paralyzed by the polio virus in Syria since the disease first reappeared there last October after a 14-year absence. Polio also has been detected in two Iraqi children in Baghdad, and it paralyzed one of them in April, the report said. Although 25 million children under the age of 5 have been vaccinated multiple times in seven Middle East countries under an emergency campaign, the report said many Syrian children missed out because of fighting and restrictions on distributing medical aid. The report said 765,000 Syrian children under 5 live in hard-to-reach areas. Polio, which is spread by feces, was thought to be nearly eradicated a few years ago, but it has spread in some fragile countries this year. In May, the W.H.O. declared a global health emergency because of the resurgence, imposing travel restrictions on Pakistan, Syria and Cameroon because the virus had spread from those countries to neighbors.

headline: Girl, 10, Is Dead After Swimming
text: A 10-year-old girl died on Tuesday evening after she was pulled from the water at Coney Island beach, the police said.

headline: Milking the Money Machine
text: It used to be that the Democratic Party, the party of the little guy, was the party of big money. Up until 2004, the party was dependent on so called soft money – contributions of as much as $10 million from corporations, unions and individuals that were beyond the reach of federal regulation.

headline: Creative Types From Manolo Blahnik to Milton Glaser on Their Favorite Writing and Drawing Instruments
text: Is the pencil over? It’s no secret we’ve turned to keyboards and touch screens to convey our thoughts, complete our work in the office and design everything from bespoke stationery to custom footwear. For most, it’s hard to recall the last time an octagonal wooden shaft rested between our fingers. But for a select set of highly creative individuals, writing instruments are still in high demand. Here, authors, designers and artists ranging from Manolo Blahnik to Milton Glaser share brief odes to the pencils, pens and brushes to which they are devoted, and illustrations to go along with them.

headline: AvantCredit Raises Financing to Lend to ‘Midprime’ Borrowers

headline: How Our Arms Help Us Run
text: How we hold our arms affects how we run, but probably not in ways that most of us would expect, according to a new study of upper body biomechanics. The ideal arm swing may be the one that you’re already using, the study concludes.

headline: Cuomo’s Office Hobbled Ethics Inquiries by Moreland Commission
text: With Albany rocked by a seemingly endless barrage of scandals and arrests, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo set up a high-powered commission last summer to root out corruption in state politics. It was barely two months old when its investigators, hunting for violations of campaign-finance laws, issued a subpoena to a media-buying firm that had placed millions of dollars’ worth of advertisements for the New York State Democratic Party.

text: ROME — The Costa Concordia began its final voyage toward the Italian port city of Genoa on Wednesday morning, two and a half years after it ran aground off a small Tuscan island in an accident that killed 32 people.

headline: Why Do Americans Stink at Math?
text: When Akihiko Takahashi was a junior in college in 1978, he was like most of the other students at his university in suburban Tokyo. He had a vague sense of wanting to accomplish something but no clue what that something should be. But that spring he met a man who would become his mentor, and this relationship set the course of his entire career.

headline: Windows Without Prison Bars
text: When Paulo Demetrick, a 29-year-old federal prison inmate in Virginia, was asked, “If you could have a window in your cell, what place from your past would it look out to?,” his mind began to race. After 11 years behind bars for robbery, how could he think of just one photograph?

headline: 5 Detained in China Over Processing of Spoiled Meat
text: The Chinese police detained five people on Wednesday as part of an investigation into the use of chicken and beef beyond their expiration dates by an American-owned meat processing plant. The factory, in Shanghai, supplied McDonald’s, KFC and other fast-food restaurants in China.

headline: 2 Ukrainian Fighter Jets Shot Down as Conflict Intensifies
text: SNIZHNE, Ukraine — Two Ukrainian Su-25 fighter jets were shot down on Wednesday in eastern Ukraine near the Russian border. The planes were downed in an area of heavy fighting between government forces and Russian-backed separatists, near where a Malaysia Airlines jet was blown out of the sky last week, killing 298 people and drawing international dismay.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Geothermal Industry Grows, With Help From Oil and Gas Drilling
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Geothermal energy — tapping into heat deep underground and using it to produce power — is sometimes described as a forgotten renewable. It languishes in the shadows of better-known sources like wind and the sun, and in 2011 it accounted for less than 1 percent of electric power worldwide, according to last year’s World Energy Outlook.

headline: New York Today: Dispatch From Italy
text: Good morning on this eventually wet Wednesday.

headline: Why Democrats Now Have a Shot in Georgia
text: In 2005 and 2006, two moderate Democratic candidates, Jim Webb and Tim Kaine, won in Virginia with large margins in the Washington suburbs. Their victories demonstrated that there was a new path to victory for Democrats, one that did not depend on winning Southern conservative Democrats, the way Mark Warner did in 2001.

headline: Morning Views
text: “Millions of low- and moderate-income people who signed up for health insurance with the help of federal tax-credit subsidies could find themselves without coverage or facing big premium bills if a destructive decision handed down by a federal appeals court in Washington on Tuesday is not reversed,” writes The New York Times Editorial Board. The ruling, which The Board calls “mindless and harmful,” seized on “poorly drafted” language in the Affordable Care Act to end subsidies in the states that opted not to set up a state health exchange and instead relied on the federal exchange. “It defies common sense to think that Congress really intended that there be no subsidies at all in 36 states,” The Board writes. For now, the outcome is unclear: A second federal appeals court panel ruled the opposite way just a few hours later and the Obama administration is expected to appeal the first decision. “Consumers are expected to retain their coverage and tax credits while this and similar suits in other jurisdictions wend their way through the court system.” In future decisions, The Board calls for “common sense in interpreting the law, not ideological opposition to Obamacare.”

headline: Kerry Claims Progress Toward Gaza Truce, but Hamas Leader Is Defiant
text: TEL AVIV — During a whirlwind round of diplomacy on Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry asserted that progress had been made on forging a cease-fire to halt the bitter fighting in Gaza between Israeli forces and Palestinian militants there led by Hamas.

headline: 1939: League Asked to Save Rights
text: GENEVA — ‘‘Subordination’’ of women in countries which are members of the League of Nations threatens to ‘‘spread like a rot’’ unless the League acts to check it, according to an appeal to the League issued Friday [July 21] by the headquarters here of the World Woman’s Party. ‘‘In Central Europe woman has been deprived of nearly all the rights which she previously enjoyed,’’ the manifesto reads, ‘‘the right to vote or be elected to office and the free right to earn her living.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 24, 1939

text: Scott D. O’Malia, formerly a commissioner on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, has been named chief executive of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association.

headline: In First, Americans Are Nominated for Booker Prize
text: LONDON — Karen Joy Fowler and Joshua Ferris are among five Americans who have made it onto the longlist of the Man Booker Prize, which for the first time is open to writers from beyond Britain, Ireland and the Commonwealth.

headline: Giant Yellow Toad Shrinks Online After Resemblance to Leader Is Noted
text: There was something familiar about the giant yellow inflatable toad, some Chinese noted online, shortly after it appeared in a Beijing park. Part of the recognition stemmed from its similarity to the big rubber duck created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman, which attracted huge crowds in Hong Kong and Beijing last year and triggered knockoffs in several other Chinese cities.

headline: Morning Agenda: Deutsche Bank Rebuked
text: Deutsche Bank’s primary regulator in the United States is said to have found serious problems with the bank’s financial reporting procedures and oversight, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. Jordan Thomas, a lawyer who represents a former Deutsche Bank risk analyst who filed a whistle-blower claim against the bank, said that the regulator, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, sent a letter in December to officials at the German bank notifying them of the findings of its review. American depositary receipts of Deutsche Bank fell nearly 3 percent in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares lost about 0.6 percent in early trading in Frankfurt on Wednesday.

headline: Ex-General in Indonesia to Challenge Election Results, Citing Irregularities
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Prabowo Subianto, the former army general who was declared the loser in Indonesia’s emotionally charged presidential election, will appeal the results to the country’s Constitutional Court, saying that there were widespread voting irregularities, senior advisers to his campaign said Wednesday.

headline: RLM Finsbury Names New Partner
text: Kal Goldberg, a former senior managing director at FTI Consulting, has joined RLM Finsbury as a partner, the strategic communications and advisory firm announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Tiny Club’s Uneasy Rise
text: EIBAR, Spain — This month, Toni Kroos and Lionel Messi played in the World Cup final in front of nearly 75,000 people at Rio de Janeiro’s Estádio do Maracanã.

headline: At Manhattan Preschool, Accounts of Sex Abuse Case Differ
text: Malthe Thomsen, a teaching student from Copenhagen, was rapidly becoming a fixture at the International Preschools in Midtown Manhattan. The beginning of his internship, in February, was celebrated with a lunch in his honor. And he was starting to take on more responsibility, accompanying children on field trips and helping them learn to draw.

headline: Lisa Marie Fernandez’s Beachy Corsican Getaway
text: “As much as I love living in New York, nothing’s better than being by the sea,” Lisa Marie Fernandez says. For the designer and stylist, known for her sculptural bikinis and chic après-beach layers, spending time in exotic maritime locales is not only relaxing, but also a job requirement of sorts. “I love to explore and get inspiration, but also, I like to live and breathe this lifestyle,” she says. “I love holiday clothing — bohemian caftans and sandals and barefoot and bathing suits. I’m really that person.” This month, on the tail end of a summer European trip that included stops in Paris and Capri, Fernandez traveled for the first time to the mountainous Mediterranean island of Corsica. What was originally planned as a weeklong jaunt stretched out to nearly twice that amount when Fernandez found out that her friend Laure Heriard Dubrueil, the owner of Miami’s the Webster boutique whose family has a house on the island, was heading over. “It’s really incredible that you can go to a place so close to France that’s so wild and refined and understated and not polluted with too much of anything,” Fernandez says. Here, she shares snaps and tales from the trip with T.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: China’s Energy Plans Will Worsen Climate Change, Greenpeace Says
text: BEIJING — China’s plans for 50 coal gasification plants will produce an estimated 1.1 billion tons of carbon dioxide per year and contribute significantly to climate change, according to a report released Wednesday by Greenpeace East Asia.

headline: Introducing ‘Smart Luxury’
text: Last week I wrote a post about the designer Tomas Maier and his efforts to define a new fashion niche for his own brand — one that involved designer aesthetics and designer manufacturing, but not designer prices; one that did not cater to the fast fashion or street ’n’ chic or yummy-mummy-beading-at-the-school-gates contemporary sector, or really worry that much about marketing or the runway. And I asked readers to submit possible names for such an approach.

headline: U.N. Rights Panel Votes for Inquiry in Gaza Conflict
text: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council voted to establish an inquiry into human rights violations in Gaza and the Israeli-occupied Palestinian territories at a special session on Wednesday in which the top human rights official, Navi Pillay, said Israel and Hamas had likely committed war crimes with indiscriminate attacks on civilians.

headline: Two Americas on Health Care, and Danger of Further Division
text: UPDATED, Nov. 7: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear King v. Burwell, a case challenging the Affordable Care Act’s insurance subsidies in many states. Our article in July, published after the case was decided by a federal appeals court, explains the stakes.

headline: His Own Godfather
text: It’s just the kind of movie clip YouTube was made for. In the 1965 Frankie Avalon vehicle, “Ski Party,” James Brown and his backing vocal group, the Famous Flames, enter a ski lodge after rescuing a frozen reveler. Resplendent in a white-and-red sweater, tight black slacks, black pointy-toed shoes and a regal pompadour, Brown performs “I Got You (I Feel Good),” giving the lily-white crowd of clapping skiers a taste of the showmanship that had made him a star on the so-called “chitlin circuit” among blacks. Even in a movie as disposable as “Ski Party,” Brown turned a corny scene into genuine entertainment.

headline: Health Problems Lead Owner of Broncos to Cede Control
text: Pat Bowlen, one of the N.F.L.’s longest-serving and most successful owners, relinquished control of the Denver Broncos because of his continuing battle with Alzheimer’s disease, the team said Wednesday.

headline: President Obama’s Fundraising Scandal
text: In exchange for a check of up to $32,400, Hollywood Democrats will be able to hear President Obama speak later today at the Los Angeles home of Shonda Rhimes, the producer of the ABC show “Scandal.”

headline: Board Books Roundup II — Family and Other Animals
text: New board books include Karen Blair’s “Baby Animal Farm” and Yusuke Yonezu’s “Rainbow Chameleon.”

headline: One Writes Online, the Other Doesn’t
text: It isn’t a tawdry, ripped-from-the-headlines tale, though given the societal devotion to all things Internet, it certainly could be. In Laura Eason’s “Sex With Strangers,” a young blogger engages in a lot of the title activity, boasts online of his conquests and turns them into a racy book. He meets a reclusive and serious novelist, Olivia, who’s pushing 40 and frustrated. Each is beyond curious about the other’s very different professional life, and off they go on an unlikely affair.

headline: Rapfogel Is Sentenced for Stealing From His Charity
text: For two decades, William E. Rapfogel met with presidents, governors and mayors eager to support the large social service organization that he oversaw and, some would say, charmed with his earnest charisma. The contrast could not have been more stark on Wednesday when Mr. Rapfogel slumped before a judge in Manhattan and meekly followed court officers to a holding cell to begin serving a prison sentence for stealing from that same organization.

headline: Look, Up in the Sky! (For Price of Superman Debut Comic to Be Auctioned on eBay)
text: A copy of Action Comics No. 1, which featured the debut of Superman, will be auctioned next month on eBay. The comic, which was published in April 1938, is a highly prized piece of American memorabilia and at the time of its debut cost 10 cents. In 2011 a copy of the issue sold for $2,161,000. That copy was believed to have once belonged to the actor Nicolas Cage, who bought it in 1997 for $150,000.

headline: Perdue Wins Republican Runoff in Georgia
text: David Perdue, a former chief executive of Dollar General, spoke after defeating Jack Kingston, an 11-term congressman, to become the Republican nominee for Senate.

headline: Rangers’ Numerous Injuries Shelve a Promising Season
text: As he stood on second base Monday night, the Texas Rangers rookie Jim Adduci had a chance to banter with Derek Jeter. For Adduci, a 10-year veteran of the minor leagues, it was a sort of transcendental moment.

text: Strolling down certain roads in North Riverdale, a leafy neighborhood by the Westchester border in the Bronx, may prompt an intense feeling of “I can’t believe this is New York City.”

headline: Where’s Waldo? Try Napa

headline: Dozens Die in Plane Crash in Taiwan Storm
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Dozens of people aboard a plane flying to a Taiwanese island were killed on Wednesday when the aircraft crashed in bad weather during an emergency landing, Taiwan’s Transportation Ministry said.

headline: Carlyle Is Said to Be Raising New Brazilian Buyout Fund

headline: Can Scientific Advice on Coastal Risk Reduction Compete with ‘We Will Not Retreat’ Politics?
text: The National Research Council, the nation’s top independent science advisory body, has issued “Reducing Coastal Risks on the East and Gulf Coasts” — a smart report that should be read by anyone — particularly elected officials — in a coastal community. Below you can read an excerpt from the news release with a link to the full document.

headline: Wedding Q. & A.

headline: Ghost Towns, Puffins and Unspoiled Views
text: Bruce Miller throttled back the engines of his 27-foot boat and entered the pinched harbor at Ireland’s Eye, an uninhabited, rock-rimmed island that lies eight miles off another, much larger island: Newfoundland. Scattered piles of weathered, gray boards dotted the steep, grassy banks like forgotten kindling. The captain held up a black-and-white 8-by-10 photo that echoed the view circa 1940. Back then, the timber stacks were clearly houses, schooners rested at anchor, and on the farthest hill stood a white church. Now, in the church’s place, a steeple lay in the tall grass. Worshipers last attended a service here in 1965, before a government resettlement policy forcibly moved the 157 residents of the remote fishing village, or “outport,” to larger communities in order to centralize the population.

headline: Kerry Pushes for Middle East Solution
text: Secretary of State John Kerry updated reporters in Jerusalem on peace talks as the death toll continued to rise in Gaza, and then thanked those who mourned for an American killed in the fighting.

headline: What You Get for... $1,750,000

headline: An Elegant New Boutique Hotel in French-Colonial Pondicherry, India
text: India’s sliver of the Francophonie, the region where French is still the official language, occupies a grid of tree-lined boulevards just south of city of Chennai along the Coromandel Coast, facing east toward the Bay of Bengal. Streets bear names like Rue de la Campaigne and Rue Labourdonnais. Buildings in the White Town (also called the French Quarter) are still graced with long verandahs and elegant compound walls, a genteel French-colonial vision straight out of Indochina, inflected with the pastel calm of India’s palm-fringed south. Since 2006 the town has officially been known as Puducherry, but most people here and across India still call it by its original name, Pondicherry, or its loving diminutive, Pondy.

headline: A Chinese Caesar Salad With Umami
text: Mission Chinese Food is a restaurant in San Francisco with an outlet that pops up occasionally in an old stable behind an Italian-restaurant compound in Brooklyn, where it offers a set dinner menu cooked in a catering kitchen that’s shared with the German steakhouse on the corner. One of Mission Chinese’s owners is a chef named Danny Bowien, a skateboardy young man who was born in Korea and raised in Oklahoma City. Bowien cooks punk-rock food to a hip-hop soundtrack. That makes him, functionally, a hippie.

headline: Do Personhood Laws Protect Or Harm?
text: Jessica DeSamito, a Navy vet who had been arrested in 2011 for drug possession, started using heroin again this February after her release from prison. Soon after, she became pregnant. In May, the San Antonio thirty-year-old failed a random urine test administered by her parole officer, and in July, as punishment, she was sent back to jail before being released to house arrest. The same week that Ms. DeSamito was reincarcerated, Mallory Loyola, a twenty-six-year-old with a history of using methamphetamine, gave birth to a child in Tennessee. Two days later, she was arrested and charged with assault – the first woman to be charged under a new law, effective July 1, that criminalizes the use of opiates while pregnant. Ms. Loyola later admitted that she had smoked meth three or four days before the baby was born, and was released on bail.

headline: U.S. Religious Leaders Embrace Cause of Immigrant Children
text: After protesters shouting “Go home” turned back busloads of immigrant mothers and children in Murrieta, Calif., a furious Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, sat down at his notepad and drafted a blog post detailing his shame at the episode, writing, “It was un-American; it was unbiblical; it was inhumane.”

headline: App Smart | Flight Simulators
text: Kit Eaton reviews three flight simulator apps that offer a realistic imitation of swooping and soaring through the sky.

headline: Life in a Jihadist Capital: Order With a Darker Side
text: RAQQA, Syria — When his factory was bombed in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo, the businessman considered two bleak options: remain at home and risk dying in the next airstrike, or flee like hundreds of thousands of others to a refugee camp in Turkey.

headline: Circle the Skies, From Your Smartphone or Tablet
text: FLIGHT simulators are one of the most enduring types of computer games. For years, they were primarily played on traditional PCs, but many smartphones and tablets are now powerful enough to give simulator apps the realistic look and feel of swooping and soaring through the sky.

headline: Béla Fleck and a Johnny Cash Tribute Join an Eclectic Symphony Space Season
text: Performances by the Blind Boys of Alabama; the banjo virtuoso Béla Fleck and the singer Abigail Washburn; and a daylong celebration Johnny Cash, are among the highlights of  Symphony Space’s 2014-15 season. The season also features a concert in which the new-music ensemble eighth blackbird will play chamber works by rock composers – including Richard Reed Parry of Arcade Fire, Justin Vernon of Bon Iver and Bryce Dessner of the National.

headline: Departure Ceremony for Plane Victims
text: Representatives from Australia and the Netherlands spoke at a ceremony for the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 before a flight departed with their remains from the Kharkiv airport in Ukraine.

text: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that they would require railroads and oil shippers to use stronger tank cars to transport crude oil within two years.

headline: Global Rallycross Comes to a Long Island Parking Lot
text: Rallycross, which puts backwoods-style rally driving on a closed track, makes it possible to have a race just about anywhere — in suburban Long Island, for example.

headline: How’s California Doing?
text: The states, said Louis Brandeis, are the laboratories of democracy — although that may not work as well as it used to now that the “I’m not a scientist” wing has taken complete control of the GOP. Still, state experiences can tell the rest of us something. There’s been a lot of talk lately about how the great Kansas tax-cut experiment is doing, namely very badly. But what about the anti-Kansas — California? It’s a state with a Democratic supermajority. Its policies aren’t left-wing in the way Kansas’s are right-wing, but it’s enough of a liberal agenda to have the right frothing at the mouth. So how is it going?

headline: Creative Types From Manolo Blahnik to Milton Glaser on Their Favorite Writing and Drawing Instruments
text: Is the pencil over? It’s no secret we’ve turned to keyboards and touch screens to convey our thoughts, complete our work in the office and design everything from bespoke stationery to custom footwear. For most, it’s hard to recall the last time an octagonal wooden shaft rested between our fingers. But for a select set of highly creative individuals, writing instruments are still in high demand. Here, authors, designers and artists ranging from Manolo Blahnik to Milton Glaser share brief odes to the pencils, pens and brushes to which they are devoted, and illustrations to go along with them.

headline: I Can’t Hear You. The Plays Are Running.
text: For the urban eavesdropper, paradise is a place where it’s almost impossible not to overhear human drama unfolding: a park bench, a subway car, a quiet cafe. But in purgatory — a crowded nightclub, say — the roar of sound makes pantomime of strangers’ conversations.

headline: Quiet Milestone in Project to Bring Croton Water Back to New York City
text: Croton.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ to Return With Season 5 on Jan. 4
text: The fifth season of “Downton Abbey” will begin on Jan. 4, PBS’s president and chief executive, Paula Kerger, announced on Tuesday at the Television Critics Association Summer Press Tour in Beverly Hills. As in previous years, the American broadcasts follow the British screening of the series by several months, a system that allows the most ardent fans of the drama to get information about the episodes – or even copies of the episodes themselves – long before they air in the United States.

headline: Filming Conflict and Culture
text: Ben C. Solomon is a roving video journalist, based in France. He covers a lot of ground; his beat includes reporting in Africa, the Middle East and occasionally Europe. We asked him about his travels and what it’s like to shoot video for a newspaper.

headline: Phone Diplomacy in Ukraine Crisis Lifts Malaysian Leader’s Standing
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — It was not an aide or a diplomat on the phone with pro-Russian rebels, trying to get them to relinquish the bodies and the “black boxes” from the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine — it was the leader of Malaysia himself.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Renewal Still a Work in Progress
text: Raising $12 billion last month now looks like the easy part of Deutsche Bank’s renewal.

headline: A Dietitian Who Won’t Oversell Nutrition to Her Kids
text: We sit down to eat and the bowls of food are passed around. I help my 5-year-old get his food, while my 7-year-old can fend for herself. If they refuse an item, like broccoli, I don’t get into how good it is for them or how it will make them big and strong. Instead, it goes on a separate plate in case they change their mind or want to learn more about the food, which is often new or unfamiliar.

headline: 1964: East Germany Seeks Germans in Poland
text: BONN — East Germany, one of the few countries of the world to suffer a loss of population following the war, is seeking to add Germans now living in Poland to its undermanned labor force. The West German Red Cross said today that East German consulates were carrying on an active campaign in Poland to persuade persons of German extraction to move to East Germany. The campaign has thus far been unsuccessful. However, reports circulated in West Germany that Poland and East Germany were about to sign an agreement for the mass resettlement of 150,000 such persons. Those involved presumably would have no choice over their fate, according to these reports. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 24, 1964

headline: About to Close on Broadway, ‘Of Mice and Men’ to Live On in British Broadcast
text: Reviewing the Broadway production of John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men,” when it opened in April, Ben Brantley wrote in The New York Times that James Franco’s portrayal of George is “a tight, internal performance begging for a camera’s close-up.”

headline: If Judges Campaign Like Ordinary Politicians, Can We Have Impartial Courts?
text: By now it’s routine: Another election season, another round of expensive state judicial elections destined to undermine the core American principle of fair and impartial courts.

headline: Today in Small Business: Amazon’s ‘Unbreachable Moat’

headline: Introducing Managing: Something Had to Change
text: I own a small company near Cincinnati called Finishing Technology Inc. We provide metal finishing services — anodizing, blasting, stainless passivation — typically to parts for food processing equipment (mixers and popcorn machines) and for electrical components (lugs and connectors). Many of our clients are in the automotive, aerospace and defense industries.

headline: Classical Playlist: Herbert von Karajan, Brahms, Tchaikovsky and More
text: HERBERT VON KARAJAN: Choral Music 1947-1958Works by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms(Warner Classics; five discs)Warner Classics has issued a series of 13 box sets of the recordings Herbert von Karajan made for EMI between 1946 and 1984, all newly remastered. This five-CD album of choral works offers Beethoven’s “Missa Solemnis” from the mid-1950s with the Philharmonia Orchestra and a 1947 Brahms “German Requiem” with the Vienna Philharmonic. Of special interest for me is the 1952 account of Bach’s Mass in B minor, with the Philharmonia Orchestra, the Singers of the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde and quite a quartet of vocal soloists: Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Marga Höffgen, Nicolai Gedda and Heinz Rehfuss. This recording, the one I grew up with, harkens to an earlier time of weighty, thick-textured Bach performances. Contrast Karajan’s opening “Kyrie,” which lasts 12:17 minutes, with Philippe Herreweghe’s 1996 account on period instruments, an undulant 9:29! Still, Karajan draws solemnity, depth and character from the score. A fascinating recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Private Equity Giants With a Taste for Auto Body Shops
text: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group are two titans of global finance, with extensive businesses in private equity, hedge funds and real estate.

headline: Inside Man’s Best Friend, Study Says, May Lurk a Green-Eyed Monster
text: Any dog owner would testify that dogs are just as prone to jealousy as humans.

headline: Women’s Project Theater Names New Producing Artistic Director
text: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | Lisa McNulty has been named the new producing artistic director of the Women’s Project Theater, the Off Broadway company announced Wednesday. Ms. McNulty will replace Julie Crosby, whose abrupt departure in June led most of the theater’s advisory board and several members of the theater’s board of directors to quit, saying her departure, after eight years in the position, put the company at risk. The announcement comes after almost 700 people, including the playwrights Paula Vogel and Lynn Nottage, signed an online petition demanding that the board’s chairwoman and chairman resign in the wake of Ms. Crosby’s exit.

headline: A Column of 40 Hearses Meets the Victims of the Malaysia Airlines Crash
text: EINDHOVEN AIR BASE, the Netherlands — A week ago, they had been packing their bags, preparing for conferences, family visits and vacations. Now, they were returning to the Netherlands in coffins, victims of the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, shot out of the skies above eastern Ukraine.

headline: Reaction to Costa Concordia Towing
text: Officials, survivors and residents of Giglio, Italy, spoke after the Costa Concordia cruise ship was slowly towed away from the coast of the tiny island where it capsized more than two years ago.

headline: Brand New Look at the Face of Mars
text: What really lies across the surface of Mars? Rovers have scurried about the red planet for years, drilling, scooping and analyzing for signs of life, past or present. But to really understand the Martian landscape, scientists need to look at the entire surface. What they have needed is a global geologic map.

headline: Open Source and the Challenge of Making Money
text: Remember how the open source software movement was supposed to be like Woodstock, with everybody sharing and everything free? An entire economy where you gave a little to get a lot, in a place of love and software?

headline: 5 Ways To Help Your Kid Not Stink At Math
text: In “Why Do Americans Stink at Math” for this week’s edition of the magazine, I wrote about the latest wave of math reforms, which are both the best chance we have of curing our national “innumeracy” (the mathematical equivalent of not being able to read), and a near guarantee at driving children and their parents understandably insane. As I write in the story, the problem is not the new approach itself. The problem is our widespread failure to help teachers figure out how to teach in the new way.

headline: Leader of Troubled Lab Steps Down, C.D.C. Says
text: The leader of the federal bioterrorism lab in which careless procedures may have exposed dozens of workers to live anthrax has resigned, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Wednesday.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Auditor General Faults Oversight of Natural Gas Industry
text: PHILADELPHIA — Environmental officials in Pennsylvania have failed to adequately regulate the state’s booming natural gas industry, a state report said, reflecting what critics say is weak oversight of the oil and gas industry at a time when drilling is spreading across the United States.

headline: British Souvenirs Made (One at a Time) in Britain
text: Not interested in a double-decker bus paperweight or a William and Kate mug? Consider the “the Real British Souvenir Shop” show through August at the New Craftsmen, a recently opened fine craft shop in the Mayfair section of London.

headline: Google Acquires DrawElements
text: Google struck a small deal on Wednesday, agreeing to acquire a 3-D graphics company called drawElements.

headline: Dole, Slumped but Sharp, Returns to Senate to Push Disabilities Treaty
text: WASHINGTON — Former Senator Bob Dole returned on Wednesday to the institution he once led, his posture more slumped, his legs less sturdy, but his wits still sharp.

headline: Why the ‘Sucker List’ of Jordan Belfort, the Wolf of Wall Street, Won’t Be Released to ‘Inside Edition’
text: The federal judge overseeing the criminal case against Jordan Belfort, the felon depicted in the movie “The Wolf of Wall Street,” had bad news last month for the syndicated newsmagazine “Inside Edition.” He denied its request for a list of Mr. Belfort’s 1,300 victims.

headline: How Senator John Walsh Plagiarized a Final Paper
text: A line-by-line analysis of Mr. Walsh’s 2007 final paper shows that he took much of it from other sources without giving them credit.

headline: Senator’s Thesis Turns Out to Be Remix of Others’ Works, Uncited
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats were thrilled when John Walsh of Montana was appointed to the United States Senate in February. A decorated veteran of the Iraq war and former adjutant general of his state’s National Guard, Mr. Walsh offered the Democratic Party something it frequently lacks: a seasoned military man.

headline: Nibali Still Leads the Pack as Fast Food Fails to Help the Vuelta Winner
text: PLA D’ADET SKI STATION, France — Vincenzo Nibali, the leader of the Tour de France, may seem invincible at the moment, but Chris Horner knows how to beat him. Last year, Horner crushed Nibali in the mountains to become the first American to win the Vuelta a España.

headline: Deutsche Bank Shares Waver on Reports of Regulator’s Letter
text: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank shares slipped slightly Wednesday, and its efforts to rebuild its reputation suffered another blow, after reports that a regulator in the United States had found serious problems with the bank’s financial reporting procedures and oversight.

headline: Met Opera Prepares to Lock Out Workers
text: The labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera took on a new urgency Wednesday when its general manager, Peter Gelb, sent the company’s orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers letters warning them to prepare for a lockout if no contract deal is reached by next week.

headline: Nelson Peltz’s Efforts to Shake Up Pepsi Get Backing of Calstrs
text: Updated, 4:11 p.m. | The activist investor Nelson Peltz has won the support of one of the largest pension funds in the United States in his campaign against PepsiCo.

headline: Pressure Grows on E.U. Regulator to Rethink Google Settlement
text: BRUSSELS — During the past five years, Google has taken a gingerly approach to fighting its antitrust battles in the European Union, nurturing a working relationship with Joaquín Almunia, the bloc’s competition commissioner, and patiently presenting him with three sets of proposals to settle antitrust complaints that it favored its own business over that of rivals in search results.

headline: Stealing a Page From the Boomers’ Playbook
text: When we last checked in with Alice Fisher, Hurricane Sandy had forced her ailing 90-year-old parents out of their ruined co-op apartment in Long Beach, N.Y., where they had expected — with the enthusiastic approval of their two daughters — to live out their days.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Perform, Rehearse, Stagger Home
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: John Walsh: From the Military to Politics
text: Senator John Walsh, Democrat of Montana, was appointed by Gov. Steve Bullock in February to fill the seat vacated by Max Baucus, a six-term senator who stepped down to become the United States ambassador to China.

headline: Stephen Colbert Will Keep CBS’s ‘Late Show’ in New York
text: New York’s status as the center of late-night television was reinforced on Wednesday after CBS announced that its “Late Show," which under David Letterman has been based in New York since 1993, will remain in the city when Stephen Colbert steps in as host next year.

headline: Workman Names Dan Reynolds Chief Executive
text: Workman Publishing, one of the country’s largest independent publishers of nonfiction trade books, has appointed a new chief executive, its first since the death of its founder, Peter Workman, last spring.

headline: Prosecutors Sidestep Race as Trial Begins in Shooting of Black Michigan Youth
text: DETROIT — The trial of a suburban homeowner accused of the shotgun shooting of a young black woman last fall opened on Wednesday with jarring images projected on a large screen before jurors. Renisha McBride, 19, grinning for the camera. And then, Ms. McBride, bloodied and lifeless on a porch.

headline: After Split Vote, S.E.C. Approves Rules on Money Market Funds
text: Regulators on Wednesday imposed new restrictions on a vast market that played a significant role in the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: The Location May Stay the Same, but Everything Else Will Change
text: It’s not quite site-specific theater, but the World’s Fair Play Festival, a collection of short works by well-regarded playwrights, benefits beautifully from its location: the Queens Theater on the grounds of the 1964 and 1939 World’s Fairs. The writers have delivered nuggets that catch the wistful ambience of the place deliciously.

headline: Ángel Corella Is Named Artistic Director of Pennsylvania Ballet
text: The former American Ballet Theater principal Ángel Corella will become the artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet in September, the company announced on Tuesday.  Mr. Corella, who left Ballet Theater in 2012 to devote himself to the company he had founded in 2008 in his native Spain, closed that troupe, the Barcelona Ballet, last year. (The company toured in New York in 2010 and 2012, receiving mixed reviews.)

headline: Remembering a Man Whose Death Made Him a Symbol of a Divide
text: As the sun set over Brooklyn on Wednesday, hundreds of people gathered to mourn a man who died after begging for air.

headline: UBS Being Investigated in France Over Tax Evasion
text: PARIS – UBS, the largest Swiss bank, was placed under formal investigation by the French authorities on Wednesday and ordered to post bail of more than $1 billion in the kind of tax-evasion case that ensnared it in the United States several years ago.

headline: Travels in a Maze in Mexico
text: On the back cover of Francisco Goldman’s new book about Mexico City, two blurbs describe it as funny. Now Mexicans can be very funny, but there is nothing funny about “The Interior Circuit: A Mexico City Chronicle.” How could there be? Dwelling as it does on booze, drugs, corruption, violence and murder, it offers a decidedly bleak picture of one of the world’s largest metropolises.

headline: On Capri, a Chic New Shop Takes a Stand Against Sameness
text: “This whole business was against mass prestige,” explains Helen White in the intimate space of Cabana, her newly opened shop on Capri. In a world in which luxury is becoming ubiquitous and traveling to Asia lands you in the same shops you’d find on Madison Avenue, she is indeed taking a position. Cabana is unique: almost everything in its edited collection of objects and clothes for resort life is not available anywhere else. Many items, from cutlery (bamboo-handled knives emblazoned with the store’s name) to beach bags, are sourced and designed by White and custom-made for the store.

headline: Breaking Cabaret’s Rules, and Just Shrugging It Off
text: What does the torch refer to in Patti LuPone’s scorching cabaret show, “The Lady With the Torch”?

headline: Twist and Plunge on Outlaw Run
text: Take a virtual ride on the Outlaw Run roller coaster at Silver Dollar City in Branson, Mo.

headline: New Twists for Wooden Roller Coasters
text: Wait, a wooden coaster that goes upside down? For many of us who have spent a lot of our childhoods (and adulthoods) at theme parks, the idea of a wooden coaster with a loop or a spiral seems counterintuitive. After all, woodies, as they’re called, are known for their sprawling beauty, not the heart-pounding features that have made modern steel coasters so exciting.

headline: Gilead’s Hepatitis C Drug, Sovaldi, Is on Pace to Become a Blockbuster
text: Sales of the new hepatitis C drug Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in the second quarter, a huge figure that puts it on track to become one of the world’s best-selling medicines but could intensify concerns about society’s ability to pay for it.

headline: Commission for Dead Composer, and Other Pieces
text: Toward the end of Tuesday evening’s concert by the Knights at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park, the WQXR radio host Annie Bergen asked the violinist Colin Jacobsen a question about the last item on the program. Why did he think Stravinsky’s “Dumbarton Oaks” concerto was a good fit for them?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Trumpeter and Mentor Goes With What He Knows Best
text: At the center of the trumpeter Marcus Belgrave’s band on Tuesday night was a nucleus of familiarity, and not the kind that leads to autopilot thinking, but the kind that stays engaged and present, the rare and underrated kind.

headline: The Thrill of a Lifetime, Tinged by Teary Respect
text: At the end of the concluding work in the inspiring concert by the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, the conductor David Robertson spoke to the audience about the “irrepressible enthusiasm and energy” of the young players, ages 16 to 19, in this select ensemble. Even after a concert lasting two and a half hours, a program that opened with a fresh, urgent account of Bernstein’s Symphonic Dances from “West Side Story” and ended with a weighty, richly characterized performance of Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition,” these eager players looked ready for more.

headline: Facebook’s Profit Propelled by Mobile
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Once again demonstrating its mastery of the mobile computing wave, Facebook dazzled Wall Street on Wednesday by posting significant growth in revenue and profits for the second quarter, driven largely by ads shown in the news feeds of a billion Facebook users checking the service on their mobile phones.

headline: Officials on Taiwan Plane Crash
text: Taiwan’s transport minister discussed the search efforts after a TransAsia Airways plane crashed in bad weather during an emergency landing, and the airline’s president apologized.

headline: Shake, Shake, Shake: Let the Best Man Win
text: It’s a story we’ve heard before. In a ghetto best known to the outside world for drugs and crime, young people come up with a new dance style.

headline: Registering History
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “96 Historic Sites Approved by U.S.” appeared on July 19 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Gabby Women, Silent Men? Maybe Not
text: The idea that women talk more than men remains popular enough that it’s accepted in some circles as fact. But over the past few years, some have called it into question — and now new research shows that who talks more may depend on the situation.

headline: A Double-Digit Swing at Grand National Teams
text: LAS VEGAS — Three big events were decided here on Sunday evening.

headline: Tilting at Sunshine
text: It does the heart good to see the Bolshoi Ballet be jolly. On Tuesday night, as this Moscow company danced the first of three performances of “Don Quixote,” you could feel the whole air in the theater change. The opening week of “Swan Lake” at the Lincoln Center Festival had been so dispiritingly overcast, but now here was the sun.

headline: Enter Will, With Tongue Still in Cheek
text: LONDON — Many people, it must be said, prefer the idea of Shakespeare’s plays to the reality of them. Whether they admit it or not, such souls feel that Shakespeare is great for seasoning but indigestible as a main course. They’re often the ones you hear promiscuously peppering their conversation with the canon’s best-known lines or speaking of failed politicians as “truly Shakespearean.”

headline: Speaking Her Language
text: The actress, singer and Nicolas Ghesquière muse Charlotte Gainsbourg, celebrated for her undone Parisian style, has joined forces with the Current/Elliott creative director Serge Azria on a capsule collection that’s out this week. The garments reflect the prevailing perception about the strenuously edited French wardrobe, with its combination of unfussy staples and just-loud-enough statement pieces. There are sharp blazers and raw denim jeans, which, worn together, is very much Ms. Gainsbourg’s look, and layering knits and cotton shirting to mix in. A red leather jacket is one of the standouts, and there’s a pair of mini (read: supershort) shorts that are covetable but may require Gainsbourg genes to pull off. At currentelliott.com.

headline: Photos of the Day: Netherlands and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Netherlands, Gaza City, Israel and India.

headline: New General Motors Recall Covers 800,000 More Vehicles
text: General Motors announced six recalls on Wednesday, expanding beyond the ignition switch defects that have plagued the company, and bringing its total for the year to 60 recalls involving about 29 million vehicles worldwide.

headline: In Chelsea, a Pedestrian-Friendly Night of Art
text: On one evening each summer since 2010, the Chelsea Art Walk has transformed the gallery-rich blocks of New York between West 16th and 30th Streets into a welcoming arena for visitors, connoisseurs and people getting off work to discover contemporary art. It returns this Thursday, July 24, for its fifth iteration, with nearly 100 participating galleries, nine open studios, artists’ talks and, naturally, cocktail ceremonials from 5 to 8 p.m. The event uses the High Line as its central vein, giving visitors the ability to experience a Manhattan sunset from above the busy streets between gallery pop-ins.

headline: At a Spanish Border, a Coordinated Scramble
text: MELILLA, Spain — More than 1,000 African migrants rushed toward the high fences topped with razor wire. They were met by the Moroccan police, who, with the support of the Spanish military police and a Spanish helicopter, thwarted their plan to scale the fences and enter Europe through this tiny Spanish enclave that clings to northern Morocco.

headline: AT&T Gains Customers, but Its Profit Is Slightly Lower
text: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T has made major changes to its phone plans in the past year, and those moves are paying off.

headline: A Smartwatch of the Distant Future
text: Molly Wood reviews LG’s new G watch, which is powered by Android Wear, Google’s new operating system for wearable devices.

headline: No Joke! He’s Topping the Charts
text: At some point last week, Weird Al Yankovic’s Twitter account became unmanageable.

headline: You Don’t Need Glasses to See the Message
text: Once again the question of sex discrimination when it comes to politics and fashion has reared its pundit-baiting head.

headline: LG's Smartwatch Shows Android Wear Operating System Has a Long Way to Go
text: GOOGLE has a new operating system for wearable devices like smartwatches. It’s called Android Wear and it works like a miniature version of an Android phone on your wrist.

headline: Learning a New Language: Challenges and Joys
A Smartphone That Takes the Fall
