headline: “All We Need”
text: A clip from the song “All We Need” by Circa ’95 (Patty Dukes & Reph), which is being played at the Boogie Down Booth underneath the elevated Freeman Street station in the Bronx.

headline: “El Aché De Sanabria (En Moderación)"
text: A clip from the song “El Aché De Sanabria (En Moderación)” by the Bobby Sanabria Big Band, which is also being played at the sound booth.

headline: “Love for Sale”
text: A clip from the song “Love for Sale” by Will Calhoun, who is among several musicians being featured at the Boogie Down Booth.

headline: Playing at Newfest
text: Images from films included in NewFest: The New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Film Festival, which runs July 24-29.

headline: A Graphic Photo Spurns Reflection
text: The image of two Indian girls – victims of gang rape – hanged from a tree has inspired discussion on the use and impact of such a graphic image.

headline: Six Indicted on Hacking Charges Related to StubHub Tickets
text: Authorities in New York indicted six people on charges that they were part of an international crime ring that defrauded the online ticketing service StubHub of some $1.6 million.

headline: Famous Eyebrows
text: Eyebrow trends, like hairstyles, tend to be cyclical and led by women with memorable eyes.

headline: Brow of the Decade
text: When Joni Mitchell warbled that you “don’t know what you’ve got till it’s gone,” she was referring to trees and flowers, but her lament could just as easily apply to the bushy forest of a woman’s eyebrows: Once plucked, the terrain is never the same.

headline: With All Due Deference
text: Given the avalanche of world-shaking news since last week, the shrug greeting the latest chapter in the long-running affirmative action saga at the University of Texas is understandable. Even the usually lively constitutional law blogosphere has had little to say about the July 15 ruling  by which the federal appeals court in New Orleans once again upheld the flagship Austin school’s admissions plan.

headline: The Number That Many French Businesses Fear
text: ÉGUILLES, France — Philippe Plantier, a seasoned French mountaineer, was rappelling down a cliff more than a decade ago when the inspiration struck: He could turn his passion for climbing into a business.

headline: Acetaminophen No Better Than Placebo for Back Pain
text: About two-thirds of adults have lower back pain at some point in their lives, and most are told to take acetaminophen, sold under brand names like Tylenol and Panadol. Medical guidelines around the world recommend acetaminophen as a first-line treatment.

headline: Style in Nashville’s 12South Neighborhood
text: In recent years, the 12South neighborhood of Nashville has undergone drastic changes. The city improved the sidewalks and increased street lighting. More residents and popular businesses, like Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams and the denim purveyors Imogene & Willie, have moved in. On a balmy day typical of Nashville summers, Logan Yandell was relaxing at a local coffee shop, the Frothy Monkey. Mr. Yandell will be moving to Boston soon to further his music studies, and sees his signature Goorin Brothers hat, ostrich-skin boots and tattoos as a way to stay connected to home. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Martha Stewart and Dom Pérignon Are a Match Made in the Hamptons
text: In some places, a neighbor may ring your doorbell with a basket of scones or muffins. In East Hampton, N.Y., how about a bottle of vintage 2004 Champagne?

headline: Mister Sunday Parties at Industry City in Brooklyn
text: Over the last few years, in a dappled grove on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, the weekly Mister Sunday parties built an ardent following as a laid-back disco day camp. This year, forced out of its bucolic birthplace by a real estate development, the party relocated to Industry City, a warehouse complex in Sunset Park. Could it recreate that same mellow magic in its new locale?

headline: S.E.C. Scrutinizes McGraw Hill Over Commercial Mortgage Securities
text: McGraw Hill Financial, the parent company of the Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services, could face an enforcement action related to six commercial mortgage-backed securities issued in 2011.

headline: Fare Thee Well, My Pen
text: The pen is dead. It was murdered by the finger.

headline: Foreign Correspondents in Israel Complain of Intimidation
text: As the death toll mounts and passions spike, the Foreign Press Association in Israel condemned on Wednesday what it called “deliberate official and unofficial incitement against journalists” who are reporting on the fighting in Gaza. That includes “forcible attempts to prevent journalists and TV crews from carrying out their news assignments,” the association said.

headline: New York City Asks Cultural Groups to Help Enhance Municipal IDs
text: The much-heralded municipal identification card announced this month by the de Blasio administration will make it easier for undocumented immigrants in New York City to check out library books and sign a lease.

headline: Fake IDs, Still Coveted, Are Harder to Get
text: What is the true cost of a fake ID these days? Samantha K., a 19-year old college student, is still finding out.

headline: Art, and Handbags, for the People
text: AMONG THE IMAGES inscribed on Jeff Koons’s consciousness is a black-and-white photograph of the legendary art dealer Leo Castelli presenting a bronze Jasper Johns flag to President John F. Kennedy. For Mr. Koons, the moment was a watershed. “People from film, music and other areas of the arts have always participated in the popular culture,” he said. “But before that time, the fine arts had been neglected.”

headline: Pop-Up Shops, Sales and Special Offers in New York City
text: Openings and Events

headline: Poking the Fourth Wall
text: “There are eight million people in New York City, and three million of them are drunk,” said Ben Maters, 24, an actor and bartender at Fat Baby, a multilevel bar on Rivington Street on the Lower East Side.

headline: Candleholders: Waxing Poetic
text: Last year, as part of his work at Heath Ceramics, Tung Chiang designed about 120 candlesticks. They weren’t all intended to be manufactured; it was more of an exploratory exercise.

headline: A Two-Ring Circus
text: COTTEKILL, N.Y. — Five years ago, on a very long train ride from Ulan Bator in Mongolia to Beijing, Kat O’Sullivan and Mason Brown took out a notebook and made a list of all the things their dream house should have. On a recent afternoon here, Ms. O’Sullivan, an artist who makes colorful patchwork sweaters out of other sweaters she finds at thrift stores and then sells them through Etsy, and Mr. Brown, who works part-time for a publisher and plays in a band, dug out the list and read it to a curious visitor.

headline: New Gleanings from a Jewish Farm
text: FALLS VILLAGE, Conn. — Come seek enlightenment in the chicken yard, young Jewish farmer! Come at daybreak — 6 o’clock sharp — to tramp through the dew and pray and sing in the misty fields. Let the fellowship program called Adamah feed your soul while you feed the soil. (In Hebrew, “Adamah” means soil, or earth.) Come be the vanguard of Jewish regeneration and ecological righteousness!

headline: From Beets to the Borscht Belt
text: The annals of Jewish agriculture in the United States are a little like the story of great Jewish baseball players. After you’ve name-checked Sandy Koufax and Hank Greenberg, the conversation becomes terminal.

headline: Twitter, Like Other Big Tech Companies, Comes Up Short on Diversity
text: The technology industry continues to provide evidence that it is not terribly diverse.

headline: A Mad Dash to Points South
text: Over the last four years, the Lamb’s Club has evolved into the Condé Nast canteen. On any given afternoon, you might spot Anna Wintour holding court at her corner table, dining with the CBS chief executive Les Moonves, Tory Burch or Tommy Hilfiger. Nearby, you might find the W editor Stefano Tonchi exchanging a quick handshake with Jason Wu or Michael Kors on his way out. Condé Nast publishers, editors and executives work the dining room every day and bring in as much as “20 percent of our daily breakfast and lunch business,” said David Rabin, an owner of the restaurant on 44th Street.

headline: Polishing the Imperfection
text: By now, it is an almost universally acknowledged truth that affordable apartments near San Francisco are difficult, if not impossible, to find. And overlooked architectural gems? At this point, surely nothing in the Bay Area has been overlooked.

headline: New Ingredients in Classic Cookware
text: All-Clad TK, a partnership with the celebrity chef Thomas Keller, is not a reinvention of All-Clad’s cookware, but a touch-up. Many of the pots and pans in the new line, which is divided into the TK Foundation Set (about $800), the TK Integrity Set (about $1,000) and the TK Inspiration Set (about $1,600), are modified versions of existing products.

headline: The Maya Decorators Had It Tough
text: Grain’s new line of decorative pillows was produced with Maya artisans in Guatemala — the country, as it happens, where the company’s now-married founders met eight years ago while students at Rhode Island School of Design. At that time, James and Chelsea Minola were introduced to the region’s fabric-making techniques, including the use of foot looms and indigenous-plant dyes, and they have been working with the makers ever since. “Colors can vary depending on the season and how much rain they’ve had,” Ms. Minola said, adding: “It’s a little nerve-racking from a designer’s point of view: You can’t match a Pantone chip and you can’t always get it exactly perfect.” This mildly erratic quality, however, is part of the charm of the five textiles in the new collection. The pillows come in two sizes: 16-inch square and 20-inch square, and range in price from $118 to $285. Information: 206-965-9302 or graindesign.com.

headline: A Virtual Collective of New York Designers
text: Last year while attending BKLYN Designs, a trade fair presenting the work of Brooklyn furniture makers, Charlie Miner and John Neamonitis, colleagues at a financial research firm on Wall Street, found a conundrum in the collections they saw. If visitors were attracted to, say, a Shaker-inspired table or hammered-brass pendant light, and decided six months later that they wanted to buy it, how would they find that particular item? “We decided to make the process easy,” Mr. Miner said. In January they introduced WorkOf.com, a website that sells goods by some 60 makers in the New York area, such as Stefan Rurak, a Brooklynite whose Hephaestus chair, pictured ($1,500), is solid ash that has been torched then sealed with oil and trimmed in black leather. Designers who wish to be considered for inclusion can apply on the site. Information: WorkOf.com.

headline: So Down-to-Earth, You Could Spend Time Haggling
text: Chris Attenborough, 36, and Sean Naftel, 31, artists who collaborate as Attenborough-Naftel, have a guiding principle when creating the installations they specialize in. “In our minds, if we’re not having fun, we don’t want to make the art,” Mr. Naftel said.

headline: Horns of Plenty
text: First came the buck, then came the bling.

headline: Discounts at Desiron, Frederick P. Victoria & Son and Aero
text: All new furniture orders are up to 35 percent off at Desiron, through July 31 (the Hudson sofa, shown, is regularly $6,600, is $4,662); 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), Suite 702, 212-353-2600, desiron.com.

headline: With Trade Deadline Looming, Mets’ Colon Is Untouchable Into the Seventh
text: SEATTLE — Bartolo Colon politely clapped his glove, his back turned, as Robinson Cano trotted to first base. Cano had just slapped a single to left with Colon seven outs from a perfect game. Colon adjusted his cap and kicked the dirt. Appreciating the moment, the Safeco Field crowd stood and applauded.

headline: Afghanistan’s Election Result Hinges on a Squabble-Prone Audit
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seemingly endless squabbles are interrupted by full-scale shouting matches. Campaign aides mutter suspiciously about what foreign visitors might be up to. And ballot boxes are piling up, waiting to be cracked open and examined for signs of fraud.

headline: An Idiot’s Guide to Inequality
text: We may now have a new “most unread best seller of all time.”

headline: Paul Ryan and His Poverty Prophet
text: After being chastised early this year for proclaiming that there was a “tailspin of culture,” particularly among inner city men, of “not working and just generations of men not even thinking about working or learning the value and the culture of work,” Paul Ryan is going to take another swipe at an anti-poverty proposal.

headline: For Obama, Protectiveness About Daughters Gives Way to Pride
text: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama moved his family into 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue five and a half years ago vowing to shield his young daughters from the prying eyes of the public and the press.

headline: Let Our Oil and Gas Go
text: AS a young reporter covering energy for The New York Times, I saw firsthand the distortions and inefficiencies caused by the web of regulations that followed the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, and the resulting surge in gasoline prices.

headline: Political Crisis Jeopardizes Future of Bulgarian Bank
text: The fate of one of the biggest banks in the European Union’s poorest country, Bulgaria, remains hostage to a political crisis, which caused the prime minister’s government to resign on Wednesday.

headline: What I Saw on Rikers Island
text: I RECENTLY served 58 days of a three-month sentence on Rikers Island. I was convicted in May of assaulting a New York City police officer as the police cleared Zuccotti Park of Occupy Wall Street protesters in 2012. (I am appealing my conviction.) I got a firsthand experience that I did not seek of what it is like to live behind bars.

headline: 42 Are Killed in Bombings Aimed at Nigerian Figures
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Bombs targeting two prominent Nigerians, a cleric and a leading politician, exploded in the northern city of Kaduna on Wednesday, killing at least 42 people but missing the intended victims, officials said.

headline: Turning Wind Into Electricity
text: With a sprawling network of new high-voltage power lines, Texas is conducting an experiment that might hold lessons for the rest of the United States.

headline: Texas Is Wired for Wind Power, and More Farms Plug In
text: PANHANDLE, Tex. — The wind is so relentless that a week can go by before it is calm enough for a crane operator to install the 30-ton blades atop the 260-foot towers at the Panhandle 2 wind farm here. It’s worth the wait; a single turbine at the farm can produce 40 percent more energy than an average one.

headline: Food Safety in China Still Faces Big Hurdles
text: China has been scrambling to right its gargantuan processed-food ship ever since six infants died and thousands more were hospitalized with kidney damage in 2008 from milk adulterated with an industrial chemical.

headline: American Apparel Names a New Board, Minus Dov Charney
text: American Apparel announced four new members of the company’s reconstituted board on Wednesday, the most recent step in a riveting corporate shake-up that began with last month’s firing of the company’s controversial founder and chief executive, Dov Charney.

headline: Robert Newhouse, 64, Rusher Whose Pass Secured a Title, Dies
text: Robert Newhouse, a hard-working running back for the Dallas Cowboys who played in three Super Bowls and helped win one of them not just with his legs but also with his arm — throwing a game-clinching touchdown pass against the Denver Broncos in 1978 — died on Tuesday in Rochester, Minn. He was 64.

headline: Boeing Earnings Take Hit Over Problems in Air Force Tankers
text: Boeing said on Wednesday that it took $425 million in pretax charges against its second-quarter earnings over problems with the wiring in the refueling tankers it is developing for the Air Force.

headline: Ryder Uses New Campaign to Highlight Array of Services for Businesses
text: RYDER SYSTEM, the truck leasing, maintenance and logistics management company, is introducing its first advertising campaign in almost 20 years to update business leaders on the breadth of its services.

headline: Prosecutors Snooping on Legal Mail
text: Anyone who has ever consulted a lawyer knows that private communications seeking legal advice are confidential. The attorney-client privilege is the oldest, broadest and most important of all privileges in the American legal system.

headline: Philadelphia Man Accused in Nazi Case Dies
text: WASHINGTON — In what will most likely be one of the last Nazi cases on American soil, an 89-year-old Philadelphia man who served as an armed guard at Auschwitz during World War II died Wednesday, just hours before a judge ordered him extradited to Germany in the murders of 216,000 prisoners at the notorious concentration camp.

headline: Iraq’s Imperiled Minorities
text: The Sunni extremists who control large swaths of Iraq recently presented Christians in Mosul with an ultimatum: Convert to Islam, pay a religious tax or die by the sword. The militants gave them until July 19 to comply, and by the deadline hundreds of the city’s remaining Christian families had fled from this cruel choice. The exodus goes far beyond the harm suffered by individual families forced to leave their homes.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Broken Promises
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo ran for office four years ago promising first and foremost to clean up Albany. Not only has he not done that, but now he is looking as bad as the forces he likes to attack.

headline: Quick Action in Chokehold Case Has Shielded de Blasio From Ire, for Now
text: After Mayor Bill de Blasio watched a video of Eric Garner slipping into unconsciousness as the police subdued him last Thursday, he issued an order.

headline: I Was the Sick Passenger
text: I was the sick passenger on the No. 2 train, the one responsible for the line’s delay. It was I who kept New Yorkers from their destinations, and prompted the notice that thanked them for a quality they’re not known to have.

headline: New Rules for Part-Time Work
text: Should there be a law limiting unpredictable schedules for hourly and part-time workers?

headline: Track Team Is Peerless and, Seemingly, Ageless
text: LAKE RIDGE, Va. — There’s no exact blueprint explaining how to build a dream team, but it usually starts with a star, like LeBron James, and backbreaking and sometimes heartbreaking attempts to woo others to create an untouchable superpower that can win championships.

headline: At Hall, a Blank Look Is in Style
text: A baseball cap can be doffed, waved and turned around. It can fly off the head of an outfielder pursuing a fly ball or be pulled down over the forehead to frame a pitcher’s glare at a batter.

headline: G.O.P. Plan on Migrants Calls for Less Cash Than Democrats and Obama Seek
text: House Republicans unveiled a $1.5 billion plan on Wednesday to address the crisis of thousands of young migrants along the southern border, proposing significantly less than President Obama and Senate Democrats say is necessary and setting up a standoff over pushing through the emergency funds before Congress begins its five-week break at the end of the month.

headline: Arizona Takes Nearly 2 Hours to Execute Inmate
text: In another unexpectedly prolonged execution using disputed lethal injection drugs, a condemned Arizona prisoner on Wednesday repeatedly gasped for one hour and 40 minutes, according to witnesses, before dying at an Arizona state prison.

headline: As Much of the World Frowns on Israel, Americans Hold Out Support
text: WASHINGTON — As Israel’s incursion into Gaza enters its third week and Palestinian civilian deaths mount, reaction in the United States has been muted, with polls through last weekend showing most Americans still supportive — in part, analysts say, because of the failures of the Arab Spring to spread democracy in the Middle East. But in a situation long familiar, Israel is losing the public relations war outside the United States.

headline: Wheelies: The Keystone Velocity Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: N.C.A.A. Players’ Winning Streak, Off the Field
text: Leaders of the multibillion-dollar college sports industry, under increasing legal scrutiny over the rights of student-athletes, have begun rolling back some of the most contentious policies regarding amateurism.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 23, 2014
Swindlers Target Kin of Migrants
text: MIAMI — The federal government is investigating how detailed information about migrant children being held at two American military bases wound up in the hands of con artists who are using it to lure unsuspecting relatives into paying hefty sums to reunite their families, preying on people who have been separated for years, according to the F.B.I.

headline: Violent Attacks on Homeless in Albuquerque Expose City’s Ills
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Jerome Eskeets’s last sight before he fell asleep on a soiled mattress late on Friday, on an empty lot speckled by shards of liquor bottles and discarded syringes, was the stars that glistened up above — “a beautiful thing,” he recalled this week, drunk, already, at 9:30 a.m. A cousin lay next to him that night, their bodies warmed by the cheap vodka they had shared. It had been “a good night,” Mr. Eskeets said, until he felt a dull pain on the bridge of his nose, a punch by one of the masked assailants that surrounded them.

headline: A Celebrity’s Welcome in Italy for de Blasio
text: SANT’AGATA DE’ GOTI, Italy — Mayor Bill de Blasio was leaving the cemetery in this picturesque hillside town, where his grandfather was born and his ancestors are buried, when an elderly Italian woman standing nearby made the sign of the cross.

headline: General Manager’s Recipe for Giants: Youth and Speed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — General Manager Jerry Reese said little last year as the Giants decayed. The team was aging and lacked imagination offensively. When the Giants’ record dropped to 0-6, they became the butt of jokes nationwide.

headline: Ryan Feels ‘Incredible’ About Jets, Who Show Lots of Confidence Themselves
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — On the eve of training camp, the Jets checked into their dormitories at SUNY Cortland with the things that would sustain them for the next three weeks: laptop computers and flat-screen televisions, video-game systems and beloved pillows, and, to a man, an unshakable confidence in their prospects for this season.

headline: Control of Senate May Hinge on Georgia Race
text: WASHINGTON — Now that David Perdue has emerged as Georgia’s Republican Senate nominee with his runoff victory, the race is shaping up as a battle of two candidates pitching themselves as Washington outsiders: Mr. Perdue, a businessman caricatured by Democrats as a heartless fat cat, and Michelle Nunn, painted by Republicans as a liberal masquerading as a moderate.

headline: Bolstered by Ruling, Republicans Attack Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress resumed their campaign against the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday with new zeal, fired up by a ruling of a federal appeals court panel that said premium subsidies paid to millions of Americans in 36 states were illegal.

headline: A Rolling Stone Gathers No Moss
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The song on which today’s puzzle theme is based gets stuck in my head a lot for reasons I don’t quite understand, and now that I have solved David Phillips’s New York Times puzzle debut, I will never get rid of it. Thanks a lot, Mr. Phillips.

headline: Israel Says That Hamas Uses Civilian Shields, Reviving Debate
text: GAZA CITY — Militant rockets can be seen launching from crowded neighborhoods, near apartment buildings, schools and hotels. Hamas fighters have set traps for Israeli soldiers in civilian homes and stored weapons in mosques and schools. Tunnels have been dug beneath private property.

headline: Ruling on Health Care Subsidies Puts Coverage at Risk
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Even with a federal subsidy to help cover the cost, Gloria Spottswood has had to squeeze her household budget to afford the health insurance she bought this year through the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Port Authority Approves $90 Million in Upgrades at Bus Terminal
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Wednesday approved $90 million in upgrades to its moldering Midtown Manhattan bus terminal, calling it “functionally obsolete” in its current form.

headline: 8 Are Removed as Queens Library Trustees
text: Eight members of the Queens Library board of trustees were dismissed on Wednesday by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the borough president, Melinda Katz, according to the mayor’s office.

headline: After Tough Competition, Rival Baby E-Commerce Sites in Brazil to Merge
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The online baby and maternal products company BebeStore completed an agreement to acquire its former rival Baby, and was expected to announce the deal this week.

headline: In Downpour, Delay by the Grounds Crew Helps the Yankees
text: As the rain lashed Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night and the grounds crew struggled to get the tarp over the infield, it grew increasingly clear that this normally routine procedure had gone sideways and would affect the outcome of the game.

headline: For Muslims in New York, Observing Ramadan Is a Blend of Rituals Far and Near
text: On a sweltering afternoon, Mohab A. Sewilam worked at his 40th Street lunch cart, serving hot dogs and gyros in the thick of the Times Square crowds. Finished cooking, he handed a hot dog to a waiting customer. But he had not eaten lunch himself this day, or for the previous two weeks.

headline: Crash Victims to Undergo Routine Tests, Experts Say
text: While the circumstances surrounding the Malaysia Airlines disaster in Ukraine are far from ordinary, forensic experts said that the examination of victims’ bodies, now just beginning at a Dutch military base, should be relatively routine.

headline: Over Government Objections, Rules on No-Fly List Are Made Public
text: WASHINGTON — The set of internal rules used by the federal government in compiling terrorism screening watch lists was made public on Wednesday despite Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s assertion that its disclosure would damage national security.

headline: Endless Summer in the Rockaways
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: White House to Begin $10 Billion Rural Investment Fund
text: Wall Street is looking for ways to invest in America’s heartland, and the government is ready to play matchmaker.

headline: States Against E.P.A. Rule on Carbon Pollution Would Gain, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma are among the most vocal Republican skeptics of the science that burning fossil fuels contributes to global warming, but a new study to be released Thursday found that their states would be among the biggest economic winners under a regulation proposed by President Obama to fight climate change.

headline: Photography as a Balm for Mental Illness
text: To the casual observer, Danielle Hark was living an enviable life, with a devoted husband, a new baby and work she enjoyed as a freelance photo editor. But she was so immobilized by depression that she could barely get out of bed. Her emotional state could not be explained in postpartum terms — she had suffered from debilitating depression for most of her life, and ultimately received a diagnosis of bipolar disorder when her daughter was a year old.

headline: One of Marvel’s Avengers Turns to Sign Language
text: The fight for justice can wear on the body. That is something that Clint Barton, the member of Marvel’s Avengers known as the archer Hawkeye, is going to have to learn to cope with. In issue No. 19 of “Hawkeye,” which arrives in stores on July 30, the writer Matt Fraction and the artist David Aja show the aftereffects of a battle that has left their hero with profound ear damage.

headline: U.S. Team Veteran Returns to M.L.S.
text: Defender DaMarcus Beasley returned to Major League Soccer by joining the Houston Dynamo. Beasley, 32, began in M.L.S. with Chicago as a teenager before leaving in 2004. His career has taken him to the Netherlands, England, Scotland, Germany and, most recently, Mexico.

headline: Word of the Day | obsessive
text: obsessive •\äb-ˈse-siv, əb-\• adjective and noun

headline: Rain Cuts Short Once-in-a-Generation Performance of ‘Hommy’
text: One theme of “Hommy: A Latin Opera” — a concept album released in 1973 by Larry Harlow’s group Orchestra Harlow as a salsa rejoinder to the Who’s rock opera “Tommy” — is that what looks like a calamity can be a blessing in disguise. Alas, not so for what was to have been the first performance of “Hommy” in 40 years, produced by Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Wednesday at Damrosch Park. It was a full-scale concert production, complete with orchestral string and horn sections, a core salsa band, a chorus and a procession of vigorous singers. But less than halfway through its one scheduled performance, a deluge and lightning storm shut down the concert.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) PROJECT RUNWAY A new crop of 18 aspiring designers — joined by a favorite from a previous season, chosen by fans via Instagram — will compete for $100,000 from Red Robin, a sewing studio from Brother International, an entertainment center from Samsung, a Lexus and a fashion spread in Marie Claire magazine in this 13th season. But the designers must undergo one final step in the audition process before being granted a spot on the show: to offer a preview of what their spring collections would look like if presented at New York Fashion Week. Heidi Klum, Nina Garcia and Zac Posen return as the judges. And Tim Gunn (above, with Ms. Klum), in his role as mentor, will once again be given the chance to save one designer from elimination. At 10:30, “Undone With @AmandadeCadenet” makes its debut with the model Coco Rocha and the stylist Brad Goreski as guests.

headline: Corrections: July 24, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 24, 2014
text: “We’re talking about whether we’re going to stand at the border and tell children who are fleeing a burning building to go back inside.”

headline: Flights to and From Israel Can Resume, Regulators Say
text: The Federal Aviation Administration lifted its ban on American carriers flying into and out of Ben Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv late Wednesday night, saying it was satisfied with the security precautions Israel had taken to assure flight safety at the airport. European aviation regulators followed Thursday afternoon, lifting a blanket recommendation to European airlines to avoid flights to Israel.

headline: Student Crossword | Endangered Species
text: Test your knowledge of endangered species by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Christians in Wenzhou Fight to Keep Church’s Cross
text: As rain brought by Tropical Storm Matmo poured down around them on Thursday, several dozen Christians, weary after a bloody confrontation with the police earlier in the week, stood guard at Salvation Church in Wenzhou, determined that the authorities would not take down their cross.

headline: Standard Chartered ‘United’ in Its Support of C.E.O., Board Says
text: LONDON — The British bank Standard Chartered on Thursday denied media reports in Britain that it was preparing a succession plan for its chief executive under pressure from investors.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Upheavals Around the World Challenge Obama and U.S. Foreign Policy
text: In “Crises Cascade and Converge, Testing Obama,” Peter Baker writes about the current challenges to United States foreign policy.

headline: Obama Administration Presses for Retroactive Legislation on Tax Inversions
text: The Obama administration is continuing to make its case for legislation that would retroactively strip the tax advantages away from many of the year’s biggest mergers and acquisitions.

headline: A Graphic Photo Spurs Reflection
text: In late May, photographs from a remote Indian village of two teenage cousins hanged from a mango tree spread rapidly and widely online, focusing the world’s attention on the problem of gang rape in India.

headline: Opera of an Artist’s Life, Cut Short
text: BERLIN — Had Charlotte Salomon survived World War II, she might have become a famous artist. Instead, the young German painter was condemned to Auschwitz at 26 and died, leaving behind a semi-fictional diary “Leben? Oder Theater?” (“Life? Or Theater?”).

headline: Sale of Handset Unit Bolsters Nokia’s Profit
text: LONDON — The Finnish telecom company Nokia reported a jump in profit in the second quarter as it benefited from the recent sale of its handset unit to Microsoft for $7.3 billion.

headline: 2 Foreign Aid Workers Are Gunned Down in Afghanistan, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two Western women employed by an international aid organization were shot dead Thursday morning in the western city of Herat, Afghan officials said.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Eurozone Growth Rebounds in July
text: PARIS — The eurozone economy continues its slow recovery, but worries about the Ukraine crisis have begun to cloud the outlook, according to the results of a private-sector survey released on Thursday.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The Sunni extremists who control large swaths of Iraq recently presented Christians in Mosul with an ultimatum,” The New York Times editorial board reports: “Convert to Islam, pay a religious tax or die by the sword.” As a result, a sizable portion of the city’s Christians – a community that has called Mosul home for more than two thousand years  – have subsequently fled. “The plight of the Christians, who are among two million Iraqis displaced by sectarian violence, must not be ignored by a world focused on other crises,” the board urges. “Iraq’s prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, promised to provide aid to Christians left homeless,” but has so far only “made worse the sectarian divisions and created an opening for ISIS to gain a foothold.” The board calls on Iraq’s parliament to choose a new prime minister, one that can “unify the country and lead the military forces to defeat ISIS — as Mr. Maliki is not that person.”

headline: New York Today: Planes, Trains And …
text: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: A Carbon Tax’s Ignoble End
text: SYDNEY, Australia — It will be remembered as one of the most ignoble moments in our history: On July 17, Australia became the first country to repeal a carbon tax.

headline: Australia Offers 50 Police Officers to Secure Jet Crash Site in Ukraine
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said Thursday that his country, which lost citizens when Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was brought down last week, has sent 50 police officers to Europe in hopes that they would be allowed to help secure the crash site in eastern Ukraine.

headline: E.C.B. Says It Has Been Hacked in Apparent Blackmail Attempt
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank said on Thursday that hackers had broken into one of its databases and stolen information about journalists and others, in what appeared to be part of a blackmail scheme.

headline: Hope in the Abattoir
text: LONDON — Freight cars full of bodies shot out of the sky make their way across Europe. After more than two weeks of fighting in Gaza, at least 150 Palestinian children are dead, according to the United Nations. Thousands of Hamas rockets have hit Israel, and 32 young Israeli soldiers have been killed fighting to end this terror. As the poet Seamus Heaney observed, “It is difficult at times to repress the thought that history is about as instructive as an abattoir.”

headline: Daily Report: Mobile Advertising Lifts Profit at Facebook
text: Once again demonstrating its mastery of the mobile computing wave, Facebook dazzled Wall Street on Wednesday by posting significant growth in revenue and profit for the second quarter, driven largely by ads shown in the news feeds of a billion Facebook users checking the service on their mobile phones, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: A Revamped United Makes a Blazing Start
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Before he took his seat on the bench Wednesday night for his first game as the new manager of Manchester United, Louis van Gaal had already made an impact on the club in England.

headline: Investigators Examine Role of Weather in Taiwan Plane Crash
text: Investigators started examining the possible role of stormy weather in a plane crash that killed dozens on Wednesday, a painful reminder of Taiwan’s long history of air transport disasters.

headline: Connecting the Tech World to Everyday Life
text: Molly Wood is a tech columnist and video host. We asked her about her process, her must-have gadgets and what inspires her column.

headline: Could Jenny Lewis Have Been a Hip-Hop Star If Her Mom Hadn’t Said ‘Yo’ So Much?
text: The YouTube gallery on Jenny Lewis is deep. You can see her Corn Pops commercial or watch her appearance on “The Golden Girls” (on which she somewhat surprisingly turns conniving and mean). But the clip I found myself drawn to, particularly after I spent a couple of days interviewing Lewis, was this one, in which her mother appears. Lewis didn’t want to talk much about her mother with me, as I note in the article, but one thing she said over dinner stuck with me, about how she first became hooked on hip-hop when she was a kid:

headline: The Jenny Lewis Experience
text: “They’d put the ‘Do Not Disturb’ sign on,” Jenny Lewis said. We were sitting in a restaurant in Laurel Canyon, not far from her home, and she was describing her early childhood with parents who made their living performing as an itinerant Sonny-and-Cher-style lounge act called Love’s Way. “We lived in hotels,” she said. “My sister and I, they would just keep us in the hotel room, and they’d go down and play.” When Lewis was born in 1976, her parents were doing a stand at the Sands. They split up when she was 3, and her mother — herself the daughter of a dancer and a vaudeville performer — took Jenny and her sister to Van Nuys, in the San Fernando Valley, where she worked as a waitress and struggled to keep her family afloat. “We were on welfare,” Lewis said, before describing the day their fortunes changed, when an agent picked young Jenny out of a crowd at her preschool. “I think mostly because I was a redhead,” she said. “And I was a weird little kid, a weird little tomboy.”

headline: In Ukraine, Spent Cartridges Offer Clues to Violence Fueled by Soviet Surplus
text: With its independence in 1991, Ukraine inherited a huge and unneeded stockpile of arms and ordnance from its former Soviet masters. In the years since, the country’s businessmen, security services and cargo carriers, operating in an environment plagued by corruption, have repeatedly been accused of trafficking the surplus in black-market arms deals to Africa and the Middle East. So it was little surprise that this year, after fighting broke out, that Ukraine felt the sting of what had been its own shadowy trade. Exactly the sort of weapons it has long exported found bloody use on Ukrainian soil.

headline: Suddenly, Convenience Stores Face a Threat: Walmart
text: I have a bias against convenience stores that started when I was seven years old, and my father and I stopped at a Suwannee Swifty to get an Icee. Afterward we drove a couple extra miles to a Piggly Wiggly grocery store to get milk. When we got home, I asked my dad why we hadn’t just bought the milk at the Suwanee Swifty. He said it would have cost us double because the store charged extra for the convenience of being closer to our home.

headline: A Tool to Trace Words Through Time
text: For many New York Times readers, the word “insurgent” has a very clear recent context: the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. But the last decade is not the high-water mark for the use of the word in The Times. The term appeared in a greater percentage of articles in the periods just before both world wars and during the Spanish-American War, according to a new tool created by the Research and Development Lab at The Times.

headline: Why Voters Aren’t Angrier About Economic Inequality
text: Why don’t governments in democratic societies do more to combat income inequality?

headline: Army War College Starts Plagiarism Inquiry of Senator John Walsh’s Thesis
text: CARLISLE, Pa. — The United States Army War College determined in a preliminary review on Thursday that Senator John Walsh of Montana appeared to have plagiarized his final paper to earn a master’s degree from the institution, and it sent a letter to the senator instructing him that an investigative panel will meet next month to conclusively assess any culpability.

headline: Morning Agenda: New Rules for Money Market Funds
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday voted 3 to 2 to adopt a set of new rules for money market funds intended to prevent investors from dumping their shares in the funds during times of stress, DealBook’s William Alden writes. The split on the commission reflected the lingering frustrations still felt by many in the debate about money market funds, a $2.6 trillion industry where ordinary individuals and sophisticated institutions alike put their money.

headline: 1914: Note to Servia May Prompt War
text: Austria-Hungary’s Ultimatum to Servia, the terms of which have now been communicated to the Powers, has fallen like a bombshell upon Europe. Special despatches from HERALD correspondents indicate that the Ultimatum, in its present preposterously brutal form, cannot possibly be accepted by Servia.

headline: G.M. Results Show Financial Hit of Recalls
text: DETROIT — After issuing 60 recalls and accumulating $3.8 billion in costs for vehicle repairs and compensation for accident victims, General Motors is desperately trying to move past the worst safety crisis in its history.

headline: Weather Suspected in Air Algérie Plane Wreck; 116 Are Feared Dead
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The wreckage of an Air Algérie jetliner was found late Thursday in a semidesert area in Mali, and there appeared to be no survivors of the crash, the top military official in neighboring Burkina Faso said Thursday night.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Happy Birthday, Amelia Earhart
text: July 24 would have been the 117th birthday of Amelia Earhart, who disappeared over the Pacific Ocean on July 2, 1937 as she attempted to become the first woman to fly around the world.

headline: Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski Named Artistic Director of Hermès: First Thoughts
text: So all the rumors were right, and a mere three days after announcing Christophe Lemaire was leaving Hermès to concentrate on his own line, Axel Dumas, the brand’s chief executive, has crowned his replacement: Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski, the 36-year-old current design director of the Row. She will start her new job just after the coming spring women’s show season.

headline: Testing the Big Kaboom Theory
text: The age of exploration is upon us. But it’s not in the stars or under the sea. At the moment, some of the most adventurous television series are looking backward, sifting for buried nuggets of history.

headline: Goofy Guy Takes a Galactic Leap
text: NEW ORLEANS — Six weeks in the Crescent City and Chris Pratt has not let one drop of gumbo, one morsel of po’boy, or one crumb of beignet pass his lips.

headline: Wicked Tongues Rule the World
text: LONDON — Members of this nation’s ruling class traditionally high-tail it out of town for the country before summer breaks its first sweat. But I had heard that Henry and Anne and Jane and Katherine and all those Thomases (including the inevitable Cromwell) had reversed that tradition and relocated to the city, where they were said to be thriving.

headline: Stock Market Gains and Deal-Making Lift Profit at Lazard
text: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | Rising markets have given Lazard something to boast about.

headline: Blasts Kill 16 Seeking Haven at Gaza School
text: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip — For more than a week, as the war engulfed their homes, families in this northern Gaza town packed up their belongings and children and headed to the one place they presumed would remain safe: the United Nations school.

headline: Iraq Picks New President to Confront Militant Threat
text: BAGHDAD — Trying to piece together a new government to confront a Sunni militant offensive and growing internal strains, Iraqi leaders on Thursday selected a well-regarded Kurdish politician to be the country’s new president.

headline: Asset Sales Bolster Earnings at K.K.R.
text: Updated, 7:51 p.m. | The private equity company Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is taking full advantage of robust financial markets by selling its holdings.

headline: Breitburn Energy Partners to Buy QR Energy
text: Breitburn Energy Partners is buying QR Energy for about $1.6 billion, a move that it says will make it the largest upstream master limited partnership focused primarily on oil.

headline: Why Weren’t Two Stories in The Times? An Odyssey
text: Are these stories newsworthy?

headline: Ode to Grand Central
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Trusty Old French Spot for Frites on the Upper West Side
text: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: Obama and the Myth of Presidential Control
text: One of the most common criticisms of presidents — especially struggling ones during their second term — is that they have lost control of events.

headline: Mapping the Spread of Drought Across the U.S.
text: Maps and charts updated weekly show the latest extent of the drought in the United States.

headline: Yes, You’re Smart, but Can You Manage Your Time?
text: This interview with Lonne Jaffe, chief executive of Syncsort, a software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Paul Singer Takes Stake in Advertising Titan Interpublic and Pushes for Sale
text: Though two of the world’s major advertising giants tried and failed to merge over the last year, a big activist hedge fund thinks that another big player, the Interpublic Group, should try to sell itself anyway.

headline: Ford Reports Earnings of $1.3 Billion
text: Ford Motor Company issued its first earnings release since the company’s new chief executive, Mark Fields, took the reins, and reported some good news.

headline: Dean Koontz: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The City” is a fan of Marilynne Robinson and Cormac McCarthy: “Both offer voluptuous yet highly controlled language and profound moral purpose.”

headline: This Is What Wealthy Looked Like
text: NEW HAVEN — Over the last several months, some people here have spotted an R.V. rolling down their streets with a man squatting on top, holding a camera he trains down on them as if trying to compile his own version of Google Street View. A few have accused him of being a cop. Others have struck up conversations, and he has climbed down to spend the afternoon taking their pictures.

headline: Casting Announced for New Neil LaBute Play
text: Terry Kinney will direct Heather Graham, Gia Crovatin, Callie Thorne and Frederick Weller in the premiere of Neil LaBute’s new dark comedy, “The Money Shot,” for MCC Theater this fall, the company announced on Thursday. The production is to run Sept. 4-Oct. 12 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, with opening night set for Sept. 22.

headline: As a Neighborhood Mourns, a Call to Improve Pedestrian Safety Is Renewed
text: Dangling over the intersection of West End Avenue and 95th Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a new sign installed by the city warns of no left turns from 7 to 9 a.m., Monday through Friday. “What’s that — it’s nothing,” a man said to the woman next to him one night last week, referring to the sign. “They should make it all day.”

headline: Ukraine Prime Minister Resigns as Key Coalition in Parliament Falls Apart
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk resigned abruptly on Thursday after the governing coalition of Parliament collapsed, creating uncertainty about the makeup of the government in Kiev as it continues its fight against pro-Russian separatists in the country’s restive east.

headline: Walmart U.S. Chief Leaving; Successor Headed Asian Unit
text: The chief executive of Walmart’s United States division is leaving the company and will be replaced by the head of its Asian division, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Bloomberg Hires a Founder of The Verge to Lead Online Initiatives
text: Josh Topolsky, the co-founder of the technology website The Verge, will join Bloomberg as the editor of a series of online ventures it is introducing as part of a revamped journalism strategy.

headline: G.O.P. Congressman’s Plan to Fight Poverty Shifts Efforts to States
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, outlined a plan to combat poverty on Thursday that would consolidate a dozen programs into a single “Opportunity Grant” that largely shifts antipoverty efforts from the federal government to the states.

headline: Spectators to War, West Bank Residents Hail the Hamas Fight Against Israel
text: AL AMARI REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Maher al-Naden, a street cleaner, said he had stopped buying Tapuzina, a popular Israeli orange-flavored drink, and Israeli dairy products.

headline: Barclays Asks Court to Dismiss New York Suit Over Its ‘Dark Pool’
text: Barclays filed a motion on Thursday to dismiss a lawsuit brought by New York State’s attorney general that accused the bank of lying to customers of its private stock market.

headline: Metaphysical Sleight of Heart
text: “Magic in the Moonlight,” Woody Allen’s new film, stages a debate that will be familiar to anyone who has seen more than a couple of the previous 43. There are various ways to characterize the argument: between reason and superstition; between doubt and faith; between realism and magic. On one side is the belief in some kind of unseen, metaphysical force governing the universe; on the other is the certainty, shared by the director, that no such thing exists. Not incidentally — and not for the first time in Mr. Allen’s oeuvre — the opposed positions are advanced by a dyspeptic middle-aged intellectual and a much younger, relatively untutored woman. Among the big jokes this time around: She misattributes a literary quotation and seems never to have heard of Nietzsche.

headline: Sculptures Found in Disputed Art Trove
text: BERLIN — Experts say they have found what they believe to be a sculpture by Edgar Degas, a small marble figure by Auguste Rodin as well as a painting and other sculptures, in the Munich home of Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive German art collector who kept hundreds of European masterworks, many of them possibly looted by the Nazis, stashed in his apartment for decades. Mr. Gurlitt died in May.

headline: Paul Ryan and the Party of Ideas
text: I will probably have more to say about Congressman Paul Ryan’s latest policy proposals on poverty and mobility — both their substance and their possible implications — very soon; either tomorrow or in Sunday’s column, mostly likely. You can read a good summary of the highlights here; for now, I’ll just make two quick and one slightly longer points:

headline: Lively Surroundings for Man and Beasts
text: When Julius Towers arrived in New York in 2003, he rented a place on the Upper East Side. Two years ago, wanting a change, he moved to a one-bedroom in a contemporary high-rise in Long Island City with a postcard view of Manhattan. His rent was around $2,900 a month.

headline: One Room for Many Guests
text: For those who like traveling in groups but want an alternative to the cookie-cutter hotel room with rollaway beds, NYAH (Not Your Average Hotel) in Key West, Fla., has a solution: Each of its 36 rooms can be customized according to the number of guests, thanks to modular furniture that can be rearranged. Gustaf and Jesper Arnoldsson, brothers who own NYAH, came up with the concept for the hotel, opened in February. “We saw that sharing a room was not so much a move to save money as it was about having a unique experience,” Jesper Arnoldsson said in a phone interview.

headline: Britain Brings Corruption Charges Against Unit of Alstom
text: PARIS — British authorities said on Thursday that they had brought criminal charges against a unit of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate that is selling its energy business to General Electric. A five-year investigation, authorities said, found evidence of corruption in large transport contracts in India, Tunisia and Poland.

headline: Venice Film Festival Announces Lineup
text: ROME — “Birdman or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance,” Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s black comedy about a former action hero, will open the 71st Venice Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. It will compete with new films from Abel Ferrara, David Gordon Green, Andrew Niccol and others for the Golden Lion award.

headline: In Portugal, Ex-Chief of Bank Is Arrested
text: MADRID — The problems of Portugal’s most powerful family deepened Thursday when Ricardo Espírito Santo Silva Salgado, the patriarch and the former head of its bank, was arrested and ordered to post bail of 3 million euros by a judge leading a major money laundering and tax evasion case.

headline: With Lead Extended, It’s All Downhill to Paris
text: ARGELÈS-GAZOST, France — Alexander Vinokourov, the manager of Vincenzo Nibali’s Astana team, said Nibali used Thursday’s final mountain stage of the Tour de France to show that he was the “padrone,” or boss, of the cycling world.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Tour of Hospice
text: Before the visit, I had been split in two not by fear of death but by dread of dying — in anxiety, dementia, but mostly in pain from recurrent ovarian cancer.

headline: Conservatives Hone Script to Light a Fire Over Abortion
text: It was not on the public schedule for the Republican National Committee’s spring meeting at the stately Peabody Hotel in downtown Memphis. But inside a conference room, a group of conservative women held a boot camp to strengthen an unlikely set of skills: how to talk about abortion.

headline: A Craig Grant Show and a New Lucy Thurber Play Coming From Labyrinth Theater
text: The Labyrinth Theater Company, an enterprising Greenwich Village group that specializes in new work, will open its 2014-15 season with “A Sucker Emcee,” a one-man show written and performed by Craig Grant. The work is built on a blend of hip-hop, slam poetry and Mr. Grant’s personal recollections, and will be directed by Jenny Koons. It is scheduled for September, a spokeswoman for the company said, but the specific dates will be announced later. The company’s performances are at the Bank Street Theater.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Proposal Hints at Change in Tone on Poverty
text: Something about the new anti-poverty plan from Representative Paul Ryan feels different from his previous efforts to overhaul the system of support for the poor.

headline: Do You Work Too Much?
text: The American economy generally operates on the assumption that the more hours you work, the better an employee you are. But increasingly, researchers and workers themselves are saying that working to the point of burnout can be unhealthy, unproductive, and even dangerous — and some are advocating for large-scale solutions that tackle the problem at its source.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Television Is Muscling Out Movies
text: SAN DIEGO – As the Comic-Con International fan convention got underway here on Wednesday night, it became clear that 2014 is the year of the castle.

headline: Botox Maker’s Bosses Put Money Where Their Mouths Are
text: Allergan‘s bosses have put money where their mouths are.

headline: Today in Small Business: Chief Happiness Officer
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Search and Destroy Thyself Mission
text: An inescapable melancholy pervades the espionage film “A Most Wanted Man,” a smart, bluntly effective adaptation of John le Carré’s post-9/11 political passion play about good, evil and the sins committed in the name of national security. It’s no surprise that the weight of that day and its aftermath hangs over the story, which finds expression in the atmospheric gloom of Hamburg, the port city in which most of the story unfolds, and in the movie’s assembly of crushed and deflated souls. Most of all, there’s the presence of Philip Seymour Hoffman as Günther Bachmann, a German intelligence officer and man of sorrows driven by his uncompromising belief in himself.

headline: Ex-Chelsea Midfielder Joins New York Expansion Club
text: The former Chelsea midfielder Frank Lampard joined New York City F.C. on Thursday, becoming the second European Champions League winner signed by the expansion Major League Soccer club.

headline: A Trophy Wife With a Cheesy Heritage
text: The Spanish actress Marta Milans does not seem like the sort of woman who knows her way around a goat. In “Mala Hierba,” the fiery Tanya Saracho drama now in previews at Second Stage Uptown, Ms. Milans plays Liliana, a Texas trophy wife with “the kind of charm that can’t be taught.” On a recent afternoon, she flounced around the rehearsal room in a see-through shirt and snakeskin sandals. Silver bracelets dangled from her wrist; black polish gleamed from her fingernails.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $275 Million in Mortgage Case
text: Morgan Stanley and securities regulators finalized a $275 million settlement on Thursday stemming from the Wall Street bank’s role in the sale of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

headline: Court Censures Poland Over C.I.A. Renditions
text: PARIS — The European Court of Human Rights ruled Thursday that Poland had violated the rights of two terrorism suspects by allowing their transfer to a secret detention center run by the C.I.A. in Poland, where the two men were tortured.

headline: Study Gives Hope of Adaptation to Climate Change
text: As we pour heat-trapping gases into the air, we’re running an experiment. We’re going to see what a rapidly changing climate does to the world’s biodiversity — how many species shift to new ranges, how many adapt to their new environment and how many become extinct.

headline: Seeing the Child, Not the Disability
text: It had been several months since I had last seen my patient, and even longer since I’d seen his mother. He was 3 and unable to walk or talk, and when I caught his eye, his face broke open into a huge smile, accompanied by the grunting and rhythmic thrusting of his torso and arms that he uses to express himself.

headline: Hermès Names New Designer for Women’s Fashion
text: New chief executive, new designer.

headline: Deadly Tornado Hits Campground in Virginia Two Times
text: A tornado sent towering pines trees crashing into tents, cabins and cars at a popular Virginia campground on Thursday before apparently turning and passing over the site a second time on its way out to sea, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Putting Liberty Island on the Map
text: A team from Google set out to create an immersive 360-degree map of Liberty and Ellis Islands on Wednesday.

headline: Google to Offer Close-Up View of Liberty Island
text: Alberto Elias polished the 15 camera lenses on his four-foot-tall backpack. As he prepared for his trek around the Statue of Liberty, he took a deep lunge and strapped the green, 40-pound Google Trekker onto his back.

headline: Extended Week for MOMA Boosts Attendance
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s seven-day-a-week schedule, which it began in May 2013, has pumped up its already strong annual attendance, according to figures compiled by the museum.

headline: Rising Airline Crash Fatalities Making 2014 Even More of an Aberration
text: Last week, after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down over Ukraine, The Upshot published a chart of air fatalities and noted that:

headline: Deep in Her Gut, She Knows She’s Not Ordinary
text: Thank goodness (or the goddess) for male directors who dig strong female characters. Whatever their reasons, these directors often expand the range of roles women play, whether it’s one of Howard Hawks’s dames calling the shots or one of James Cameron’s. That the French director Luc Besson, an industrious multi-hyphenate, has a thing for femmes fortes has been evident since 1990, when he unleashed a pouty toothpick in “La Femme Nikita,” a delirious, violent fantasy that turned an outlaw into a gun-toting gamine and an exploitable commodity that, in turn, spawned both an American big-screen remake (“Point of No Return”) and a television series.

headline: Even Utopian Citizens Like to Leave the House
text: In the mid-20th century, certain Latin American cities looked like the most modern on earth. Not only was their architecture imaginative, but so was the thinking behind it: ideas, amounting to faith, that design could positively shape civic life across lines of money and class; that art and architecture were inseparable; that while Europe and the United States were the cultural powers of the day, South America had a shot at tomorrow.

headline: Emma Stone and Colin Firth on Working With Woody Allen
text: As Woody Allen maintains his astounding one-movie-per-year pace, the list of actors who’ve appeared in one of his films continues to grow. The newest members of the club are Emma Stone and Colin Firth, who star in the the 78-year-old director’s sumptuous period comedy “Magic in the Moonlight.” In the Cote d’Azur-set story, Firth plays a cynical illusionist with a dry wit and drier worldview who sets out to debunk a woman (Stone) who’s attached herself to a wealthy family by claiming to be a psychic. The two leads spend the film trading barbs among the villas and cliffs of Southern France until eventually — well, you know. The co-stars sat down with T to discuss Allen’s notorious shyness, their terrifying first day and what it’s like to work with a legend.

headline: Ravens’ Rice Draws 2-Game Suspension From Goodell
text: With training camps opening across the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell has begun handing out suspensions to players for various instances of unacceptable behavior in the off-season. Running back Ray Rice of the Baltimore Ravens drew the first punishment, receiving a two-game ban Thursday in connection with an incident in which he was accused of assaulting a woman who was then his fiancée and is now his wife.

headline: In Argentina, Cycles and Cameras
text: The 25-year-old bike touring company Ciclismo Classico has created a spinoff that focuses on seeing as much as doing. The charter destination for a series of photography tours — called TravelVision Journeys — is northwest Argentina. The four scheduled Vision & Vine treks will explore mountain landscape, indigenous communities and high-altitude vineyards. They were developed by Ciclismo founder and enthusiastic photographer Lauren Hefferon, who will co-lead the nine-day trips with the Argentine photographer and documentary filmmaker Ossian Lindholm. Destinations include the  Las Salinas Grandes salt desert, the small cities of Humahuaca and Cachi, and Los Cardones National Park. The first scheduled trip is on Aug. 20.

headline: Spared Sudanese Christian Woman Meets Pope in Rome
text: ROME — Mariam Ibraheem Ishag, a Christian woman whose death sentence in Sudan for refusing to renounce her faith set off an international protest, arrived in Rome on Thursday morning to a hero’s welcome and a private audience with Pope Francis.

headline: Obama Seeks to Close Loophole That Firms Use to Shield Profits Abroad
text: LOS ANGELES — President Obama on Thursday called for Congress to strip away tax advantages that have encouraged a rush of mergers and acquisitions that give companies an overseas base while they maintain their presence in the United States.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Hardware: Smart Garbage
text: There’s a box on a shelf in my closet stuffed with smart smoke detectors, old smartphones, chargers, battery cases, fitness trackers, a Kindle that I sat on and broke and various sensors that have long ceased to detect anything.

headline: Check This Out: Elvis’s Library Card Up for Auction
text: Elvis Presley’s earliest known signature – on a library card he signed as a 13-year-old student in Tupelo, Miss. – is one of the main draws in an auction of Elvis memorabilia to be held at Graceland, the singer’s palatial headquarters, in Memphis on Aug. 14. (The library card was sold at auction for $7,500 – a bargain, you would think – in 2012.)

headline: To Help Mount Giant Time Warner Bid, Murdoch Calls On European Outposts
text: Rupert Murdoch is calling on European outposts to help in his pursuit of Time Warner. The media mogul’s 21st Century Fox is poised to sell its Sky pay-TV arms in Italy and Germany to Fox’s British affiliate, British Sky Broadcasting. There’s strategic logic to the asset shuffle and the proceeds could help sweeten his $80 billion bid for the owner of CNN and Warner Bros. How Mr. Murdoch treats non-Murdoch owners is the linchpin.

headline: Rules for Money Market Funds Arrive, Finally
text: Six years ago, a huge chunk of the financial system nearly imploded, and it took an enormous federal bailout to prevent it from bringing down the whole system. That would be money market mutual funds, which millions of American individuals and businesses use to park $2.6 trillion in savings.

headline: Brooklyn Factory, Japanese Food
text: The wine is in plastic cups, the view of flaking paint, vinyl siding, a tin tub of flowers and graffiti 10 feet tall. It is so quiet on the roof, for a moment we wonder if the people working the cash register downstairs have forgotten we’re up here and have gone home. None of us are in a hurry to find out.

headline: From Kenzo, an Interactive 3-D Virtual Gallery and Fashionable Art Heist
text: Breaking news: an art gallery has been raided and the culprits are fashion models. That, in any case, is the fictional narrative of Kenzo’s new multimedia project, designed to showcase Carol Lim and Humberto Leon’s pre-fall 2014 collection. In an interactive online video exhibition titled “Grace to the Nth Power,” the film director Partel Oliva and the web designers Kim Boutin and David Broner have created a gallery space and “art show” dedicated to the Sudanese-American model Grace Bol. As visitors to the site enter and move around the darkened 3-D gallery, it becomes clear that the artwork inside has been ransacked and replaced by videos showing the thieves in action. One bandit turns out to be the exhibition’s subject, Bol; her accomplice is the male model Sang Woo Kim.

headline: U.S. Considering Refugee Status for Hondurans
text: Hoping to stem the recent surge of migrants at the Southwest border, the Obama administration is considering whether to allow hundreds of minors and young adults from Honduras into the United States without making the dangerous trek through Mexico, according to a draft of the proposal.

headline: Give to Get
text: Being one of a dozen cousins, I have been to many family weddings. They have been ostentatious, wasteful affairs, in my opinion, with thousands of dollars thrown away on useless revelry and gifts. I am the last cousin to marry, and my relatives expect the same from me. But my fiancée and I don’t need toasters or linens. We need a down payment on an apartment. We think putting our money toward that is more prudent than buying a fancy wedding dress or floral arrangements. Is there a nice way to tell our families this and still reap the rewards of a wedding (in cash)?

headline: Thanks for the Taunts, Classmates
text: The tall, attractive, very funny woman across the table was a hit at Sundance this year with her first feature film, the comedy “Appropriate Behavior,” and then was summoned by Lena Dunham to join the cast of “Girls” next season. At 29, she’s having, or is about to have, or maybe can look forward to, a moment. But Desiree Akhavan wants you to know there were some rough spots on the way.

headline: Reviewing Those Uncharted Restaurants: The Romance and the Reality
text: Ligaya Mishan writes the Hungry City column for the Dining section (her most recent column, on Brooklyn Ball Factory, appears here). We asked her about her process and about exploring New York’s five boroughs in search of interesting bites.

headline: Ford Ekes Out a Profit in Europe
text: FRANKFURT — The European unit of Ford Motor eked out its first profit in three years in the second quarter, the company said Thursday, even as it warned that it would probably slip back into the red later this year in part because of slumping sales in Russia.

headline: From Republicans, a New Approach to ‘Accountability’
text: For Republicans, the top concerns about anti-poverty programs have long been: Are they affordable, and do they discourage people from working their way out of poverty? A new plan out Thursday from Representative Paul Ryan’s House Budget Committee reflects a significant change in the way Republicans talk about both concerns.

headline: The Wisdom of the Moving Man
text: No one goes into a move expecting to fall for her mover. I was no exception. This was back in October 2001, when people advertised their services by taping fliers to lampposts among signs for the 9/11 missing.

headline: Yellen Settles for a Slingshot Instead of a Shotgun
text: Has Janet Yellen jumped the shark already?

headline: Why Are We Ignoring a New Ebola Outbreak?
text: Three small, impoverished nations in West Africa—Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone—now demand the world’s attention as the deadly Ebola epidemic spins out of control, killing hundreds and threatening millions. Caused by a highly contagious virus, the disease starts with typical flu-like symptoms, yet most often leads to a horrific death in just a matter of days.

headline: UBS Lashes Out at French Prosecutors
text: PARIS — UBS sounded a combative note on Thursday, criticizing the decision of French prosecutors to place it under formal investigation over allegedly helping French clients evade taxes.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Glossy New Poverty Plan
text: Every year or so Paul Ryan comes up with a glossy new plan to deal with poverty or spending on social programs. The plans never go anywhere, but they’re not really intended to: They’re designed to make the Republican Party (and Mr. Ryan himself) appear more thoughtful than it actually is on these subjects.

headline: 36 Hours in Provincetown, Mass.
text: Perched at the tip of Cape Cod — or at the end of the world, as locals like to say — Provincetown is a quirky beach community favored by artists, drag queens, L.G.B.T. people, heterosexual families from the suburbs and oddballs on the run. Provincetown combines small-town charm with big-city spunk, and it’s nestled among miles of peaceful dunes and seashore. If you want solitude, come in the winter when hardly anyone is here — or anything is open. But if you’re after warm weather and high-season theatrics, arrive in July, August or early September. Be careful about what summer week you choose. Many have a theme, and your Provincetown experience will differ whether you’re here for “Family Week,” “Girl Splash” or “Bear Week.”

headline: An Abstract World That Looks Like Silence
text: JERSEY CITY — “What can be said at all can be said clearly, and what we cannot talk about, we must pass over in silence.” Thus the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein summarized his first, notoriously difficult book, ’Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.” Wittgenstein’s declaration is usually taken to mean that talk about anything metaphysical — God or gods, supernatural phenomena, mystical experience — collapses into nonsense under scrutiny. What’s less often noted is that silence itself can be powerfully expressive.

headline: Bright Passages Along the Northeast Corridor
text: The five-mile stretch of railroad track that slices through some of Philadelphia’s most impoverished areas along the Northeast Corridor is dispiriting. It encompasses a wasteland of abandoned warehouses and buildings missing walls and roofs, neglected neighborhoods and graffiti-strewn passageways. Since mid-May, though, the area has been home to (and a scene on view for train commuters) a Christo-esque installation of seven enormous works of art by the Berlin-based visual artist Katharina Grosse, titled “psychylustro.”

headline: So, Winning Isn’t the Only Thing?
text: Marriages are celebrated. Divorces are granted. Children are born. Parents die. And through all the joy and tumult and change, the Knicks continue to lose.

headline: The Workout Doctor
text: Dr. Jordan Metzl is a sports medicine physician who developed an extreme total-body workout routine called Ironstrength. He now teaches free exercise classes all around New York City.

headline: An Art Project That Lets Regular Citizens Become the Stars of Times Square
text: Ordinarily, only models and celebrities get to have their faces splashed across a giant screen in Times Square, but now everyone has a shot. “I don’t like working with professionals or models, people who are used to being in front of the camera,” says Daniel Canogar, the Madrid-based new-media artist who is masterminding the latest installment of the Times Square Alliance series known as “Midnight Moment.”

headline: The 2015 Sonata Shows That Hyundai Can Play With the Big Boys
text: Driving a ratty car through Greenwich, Conn., a wealthy suburb just outside of New York, just isn’t to be done. But when Hyundai gave a group of journalists a chance to drive the all-new 2015 Sonata there on Wednesday, the automaker proved three things: The car drives very well, it looks good to journalists and rich people won’t be offended by it.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘A Most Wanted Man’
text: Anton Corbijn narrates a sequence from his film featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin.

headline: Ukraine Crisis Is Testing E.U.’s Resolve
text: BRUSSELS — As it pushed efforts to coalesce around tougher sanctions against Russia, the European Union on Thursday was preparing to draw up lists of oligarchs close to President Vladimir V. Putin, working out how it could limit Russian access to European financial markets and studying the risk that Russia would respond by limiting Europe’s energy supplies.

headline: The Workout: Practicing His Own Medicine
text: Many doctors encourage their patients to exercise. But one who follows his own advice – and then some – is Dr. Jordan Metzl, a sports medicine physician at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York.

headline: Soviet Valor, Revised for the ’50s
text: Context is everything, comrade — to use a word carefully expunged from the soundtrack of Lewis Milestone’s 1943 “The North Star” when this wartime extravaganza was rereleased 14 years later, recut and retitled “Armored Attack!”

headline: Hey, Mister, I’ve Got a Park I Can Sell You
text: MAYBE it’s in our bones. That urge to seek water. To go down to the river.

headline: Sketching When the Pencil Requires Ignition
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — “Lee Bontecou: Drawn Worlds,” at the Princeton University Art Museum, is as stimulating an exhibition of works on paper as you might expect from an artist known for “drawing” with a blowtorch.

headline: When Reality Comes With a Score
text: For a certain kind of theater fan, to live life as a musical would be a gift from the show-tune gods. Wake up to an overture. Catch a performance by Chita Rivera and cheerful chorus boys in kick-line formation at the water cooler. End the day with an 11 o’clock number and applause for a job well done.

headline: Subway Inn to Make Its Last Stop
text: New York’s dive bars are living up to their name lately. Because several of them are going down.

headline: 10 Questions for Hillary Rodham Clinton
text: As she ponders a second bid for the presidency in 2016, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton continues a string of media appearance promoting her foreign policy memoir, “Hard Choices.” She spoke Thursday with The Times’s John Harwood on the National Public Radio program “On Point with Tom Ashbrook” about America’s current foreign policy crises, potential presidential rivals and her relationship with the press.

headline: India House Artwork Inspires a New Book
text: India House, a private club in Lower Manhattan founded 100 years ago, has removed much of the art it has displayed over the years, but related documents survive to entice researchers. The art historian Margaret Stocker, a trustee of the India House Foundation and a former curator at the club, is writing a book about Asian and maritime art that has been on view there, while the pieces themselves have been going on the market.

headline: How Was School? Deadly
text: The book-buying public isn’t taking many chances this summer. Established hits like “Gone Girl,” “Unbroken” and “The Glass Castle” remain lodged on best-seller lists. Readers are still struggling to get through “The Goldfinch.” One of the few new authors to gain a toehold is Robert Galbraith, who has the advantage of having been J. K. Rowling in a previous life. And “The Husband’s Secret” by Liane Moriarty continues to sell briskly in hardcover, even though next week will be the first anniversary of its publication.

headline: Feeble Rangers Give Fuel to Yankees’ Sudden Surge
text: The Yankees have not looked like anything close to a dominant team, struggling to hit and at times bumbling defensively. Their injury-depleted starting rotation has exceeded expectations, turning in excellent outings, but it could fall back to earth.

headline: Anton Corbijn Narrates a Scene From ‘A Most Wanted Man’
text: In this video, the director Anton Corbijn discusses a chase sequence from his spy thriller “A Most Wanted Man,” based on a book by John le Carré and featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin. The director discusses shooting this sequence in a film that hey says “is very much NOT a Jason Bourne kind of movie.”

headline: The Muddled Case of Argentine Bonds
text: Thomas Poole Griesa has been a federal judge for 42 years. He has been grappling with Argentina’s debt default for a decade.

headline: Passing of a Video Store and a Downtown Aesthetic
text: When Kim’s Video & Music announced that this summer it would be closing its last store, on First Avenue in the East Village, written tributes ranged from the resigned to the exultant. “Kim’s was this portal into New York City I never came back from,” Eddie Huang, the restaurateur, author and television personality, wrote in a blog post. “Everything in my life, I can somehow attribute to finding Kim’s.”
