headline: The Roar of the Crowd
text: Between 1922 and 1930, a new building went up in New York City every 51 minutes, according to Donald L. Miller. Most of the truly spectacular structures — like the Chrysler Building, with its aspirational steel spire — emerged in Midtown, previously a region of open rail yards and shabby industry. Beginning with the reconstruction of Park Avenue in the early 1920s, Midtown became a destination neighborhood for the city’s ultrarich, eager to abandon their stand-alone Fifth Avenue palaces in favor of contemporary “mansions in the sky.” Alongside the real estate boom came a decadent new night life and a host of more serious cultural diversions, all of them fueled, in Miller’s telling, by a steady supply of ambition, energy and illicit booze.

headline: Amazon’s Ambitious Bets Pile Up, and Its Losses Swell
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Writers are peeved at Amazon. On Thursday, investors became disgruntled too.

headline: Clash of the Items, at a Gallery Near You
text: Heterogeneity and lots of it is trending among the summer’s group shows. The mingling of like with extremely unlike is an increasingly popular curatorial approach, as is arranging them in dense installations. In numerous galleries, works of all mediums, artifacts, and objects of design and craft keep company, often at the behest of outside curators. Different time periods are spanned, disparate cultures contrasted, with all kinds of surprises.

headline: Undercover Portraits
text: Before the dead ends and the false dawns, before the latest revenge killings and Secretary of State John Kerry’s quixotic shuttle diplomacy, there were people who believed that a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians was possible. One of them was a quiet American named Robert Ames, the subject of Kai Bird’s textured and absorbing book “The Good Spy.”

headline: In From the Cold
text: When devouring this thriller about Kim Philby, the high-level British spymaster who turned out to be a Russian mole, I had to keep reminding myself that it was not a novel. It reads like a story by Graham Greene, Ian Fleming or John le Carré, all of whom make appearances, leavened by a dollop of P. G. Wodehouse. But, in fact, “A Spy Among Friends” is a solidly researched true story. The London journalist Ben Mac­intyre, who has written nine previous histories chronicling intrigue and skulduggery, takes a fresh look at the grandest espionage drama of our era. And like one of his raffish characters relaxing around the bar at White’s, that venerable clubhouse of England’s old boys’ network, he is able to play the role of an amusing raconteur who can cloak psychological and sociological insights with dry humor.

headline: Why the Death Penalty Is Doomed
text: Alex Kozinski, a federal judge on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, has gone on the record saying he is “generally not opposed to the death penalty.” But his opinion in a recent case may nevertheless find itself in the history books one day — in the section explaining why the death penalty in America finally ended.

headline: Ringing the Cowbell for Two Suppers
text: LENOX, Mass. — Good help is so hard to find. Particularly in the alleyways and waterways of 18th-century Venice.

text: Signaling a major turnaround in the airline industry’s fortunes, the nation’s three major legacy carriers — American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines — all posted record profits in the past quarter.

headline: Rushing to the End of Adolescence

headline: 5 Soldiers, 3 Afghans and Grisly Atrocities
text: In 2011, five American soldiers were accused of murdering three Afghan civilians for what has often been described in news accounts as sport. The Americans hunted the Afghans, posed in photographs with the corpses (pictures they shared with others) and even took body parts as souvenirs. The soldiers were members of the Fifth Stryker Brigade, Second Infantry Division, which had been deployed in a region near Kandahar. The crimes were ghastly, and seemingly unfathomable. In a 2010 article in Stars and Stripes, a lawyer, Eric Montalvo, representing one of the accused, Specialist Adam C. Winfield, said the entire leadership needed to be looked at, asking, “How was this allowed to happen?”

Those songs, in turn, underscored the Miser’s childhood, so it was Sam Cooke, Aretha Franklin and Al Green who molded his imagination before he ever encountered Bob Dylan, the Beatles, Bach or bebop.

headline: Patricia Esquivias: ‘111-119 Generalísimo/Castellana’
text: As seen in her third solo at Murray Guy, the work of the Venezuelan artist Patricia Esquivias is as much art history or urban archaeology as it is art, and consequently very dependent upon having a visually interesting, historically resonant subject. That is the case here, in a meandering installation that focuses on five apartment buildings in Madrid erected in the late 1950s at 111-119 Avenida del Generalísimo (named for Franco and later renamed Paseo de la Castellana), and Ms. Esquivias’s gradual excavation of their history.

headline: Spare Times Listings for July 25-31
text: Outdoor Readings (Saturday through Wednesday) Summertime, and the listening is easy at the many free literary events in the city’s parks and green spaces. On any given day, bookworms of all ages can find their favorite activity in Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street. Tuesdays mean poetry readings and book club gatherings. On Wednesdays? There are author talks and workshops. Next Wednesday at 12:30 p.m.,  Jason Mewes and Kevin Smith will discuss their illustrated book, “Jay & Silent Bob’s Blueprints for Destroying Everything.” There is also an area for teenagers, children and those interested in community and social issues. A schedule is at bryantpark.org.

headline: ‘This is what sculpture looks like,’ at the Postmasters Gallery
text: The best things about this overflowing group show of sculptures by 16 artists are its freewheeling spirit and sprawling diversity of approaches, materials and subjects, as well as its exclusively female roster. To a degree, these factors balance the weaker, more conventional inclusions.

headline: TicketNetwork Settles Deceptive Marketing Complaint

headline: ‘Displayed’ at the Anton Kern Gallery
text: When you exhibit a work of art, there are two things going on. There’s the object and there’s the presentational apparatus, which might be a frame, a pedestal, a shelf or a vitrine. Also involved are the gallery architecture, the structure of the exhibiting institution and, in the broadest terms, the art world social system. Usually, viewers are supposed to focus on the object and take for granted the apparatus.

headline: 20 Minutes and 100 Years Away
text: “A Stop at Willoughby,” an enduring “Twilight Zone” episode about an advertising executive who abandons modern life at a phantom commuter rail station, shares a kinship with an idyllic corner of Murray Hill, Queens, a Korean-dominated neighborhood east of Flushing. A pink, shingled gingerbread house built in 1891 is garlanded by Catawba grapevines, sunflowers and holly trees, so locked in time you half-expect a gentleman in a bowler hat to glide by on a penny farthing.

headline: A Renaissance Master Finally Gets a Showcase
text: Artists can be eccentric, but the quirks of the Italian Renaissance master Piero di Cosimo were extreme. He refused to allow his rooms to be cleaned or his fig trees to be pruned, living more like a beast than a man, according to the Renaissance biographer Giorgio Vasari. He hated the sounds of coughing men, ringing bells and chanting friars, Vasari wrote.

headline: China’s Plan to Limit Coal Use Could Spur Consumption for Years
text: HONG KONG — Under pressure to reduce smog and greenhouse gas emissions, the Chinese government is considering a mandatory cap on coal use, the main source of carbon pollution from fossil fuels. But it would be an adjustable ceiling that would allow coal consumption to grow for years, and policy makers are at odds on how long the nation’s emissions will rise.

headline: Don’t Teach Math, Coach It
text: MADISON, Wis. — PEOPLE ask me all the time how they can get their kids excited about math. That ought to be a softball for me, because I teach math for a living. I wake up excited about math.

headline: Housing Crunch Hurts Foster Care Oversight
text: Since moving to Odessa, Tex., in September to work as a state Child Protective Services investigator, Juan Carlos Pacheco has had three homes, struggling to find a place he could afford. At one point, he shared a one-bedroom apartment with six people.

headline: Child Care and the Overwhelmed Parent
text: Earlier this month, a mother in North Augusta, S.C., was arrested after authorities learned that she had dropped her 9-year-old daughter off at a nearby park while she worked her shift at a McDonald’s restaurant. That news, along with a flurry of reports last week that she was fired from her job — later found to be erroneous — prompted public debate about the the difficulty of finding and affording child care.

headline: Left Coast Rising
text: The states, Justice Brandeis famously pointed out, are the laboratories of democracy. And it’s still true. For example, one reason we knew or should have known that Obamacare was workable was the post-2006 success of Romneycare in Massachusetts. More recently, Kansas went all-in on supply-side economics, slashing taxes on the affluent in the belief that this would spark a huge boom; the boom didn’t happen, but the budget deficit exploded, offering an object lesson to those willing to learn from experience.

headline: National Guard in Texas Could Get Arrest Power
text: HOUSTON — When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas announced plans to deploy 1,000 National Guard troops to help with the border crisis, it came with a power unexpected by some. By deploying them himself rather than through Washington, he has the power to order the troops to make arrests and apprehensions, something Guard troops in past border deployments have been prohibited from doing.

headline: A Divorce That Thrusts Ken Griffin and Anne Dias Griffin Into the Spotlight

headline: Housing Dispute Puts Quaker University at Front of Fight Over Transgender Issues
text: NEWBERG, Ore. — A growing number of openly transgender students have forced schools around the country to address questions so basic that they were rarely asked just a few years ago, much less answered: What defines a person’s gender, and who gets to decide?

headline: Audit Says New York City Housing Authority Failed to Meet Hiring Goals
text: In awarding millions of dollars in building contracts each year, the New York City Housing Authority is supposed to look out for its own: A certain percentage of workers hired must be public housing residents or low-income New Yorkers.

headline: Anything Goes in China’s Food System
text: The recent revelations that a Shanghai-based meat supplier to McDonald’s, KFC and other chain restaurants used expired chicken and beef in its products serve as a stark reminder that China needs to do a lot more to improve its inadequate food safety system.

headline: Official Vents Outrage at Shelling of U.N. Schools in Gaza
text: UNITED NATIONS — A senior United Nations official on Thursday forcefully rebuffed suggestions that the organization’s lax security had allowed militants to use its facilities in Gaza as a weapons cache and expressed outrage that three of its schools had been hit by shelling in as many days this week, even though the Israeli military knew their precise locations.

headline: Cuomo Held the Strings in a Graft Hunt
text: Among Andrew M. Cuomo’s strengths, conspicuous piety would have to rank near the bottom. For most politicians, holier-than-thou is not a good look, and it is a particularly bad fit for Governor Cuomo. His considerable successes have been based on practical, hand-to-hand, knee-to-the groin political combat, not public sanctimony.

headline: C.D.C. Says Tuberculosis Lab, Shut Amid Exposure Scare, Can Continue Its Work
text: Operations can resume at a government tuberculosis laboratory in Atlanta that was shut down this month as part of a moratorium on handling dangerous microbes, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Thursday.

headline: The Phony ‘Narrow Network’ Scare
text: Republicans contend that the Affordable Care Act is a failure because many of the plans sold on the online health exchanges limit a consumer’s choice of doctors and hospitals. Many plans do, indeed, limit choice — deliberately so, to keep premiums down. But a vast majority of consumers can almost always buy a plan with a broad array of doctors, hospitals and other providers if they are willing to pay more for the policies.

headline: In Joining Lakers, Lin Narrows Focus and Sheds Status as a Sensation
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Jeremy Lin was in Shanghai this month on a marketing tour, surrounded by adoring throngs in Houston Rockets red. Then he got word that he was being traded to the Los Angeles Lakers. He made a quick trip to Los Angeles for a physical and returned immediately to China to finish his obligations.

headline: Greenpoint Commuters, Already Scrambling, Brace for 5 Weeks Without G Train
text: The G train is too slow, goes the common complaint. It is too crowded. At only four cars long, it is so stunted that straphangers must hustle from the station entrance to mid-platform just to make the train, a Brooklyn sport known as the G train sprint. It is so aggravating that some of its detractors say they refuse to date anyone who lives near it.

headline: Gaza’s Mounting Death Toll

Located in the northern Gaza town of Beit Hanoun, it was struck multiple times on Thursday as people who had taken refuge there were gathering in the courtyard and preparing to flee. At least 16 of them were killed, bringing the total death toll in 17 days of war to more than 750, a vast majority being Palestinian civilians.

headline: Nuclear Plants Should Focus on Risks Posed by External Events, Study Says

headline: Defying Syria, United Nations Sends in Trucks Carrying Aid
text: UNITED NATIONS — Empowered by the Security Council to defy what United Nations officials have called an arbitrary aid blockade imposed by the warring parties in Syria, United Nations relief agencies for the first time sent a convoy of trucks carrying food, water purification tablets and other relief supplies across the Turkish border on Thursday into rebel-held areas of Syria.

headline: Boy, 3, Dies After Being Pulled From Pool at Staten Island Day Care
text: A 3-year-old Staten Island boy died on Thursday after he was pulled from a pool at a day care center where his mother was working, fire and police officials said.

headline: Martin Tahse, TV and Broadway Producer, Dies at 84
text: Martin Tahse, a producer whose television shows examining the troubles and traumas of adolescence were frequent features on the long-running series ABC Afterschool Specials, died on July 1 in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Former Venezuelan Intelligence Chief Arrested in Aruba
text: POTOSÍ, Bolivia — Officials on the Caribbean resort island of Aruba said Thursday that they had arrested a former Venezuelan intelligence chief at the request of the American authorities, who have accused him of involvement in drug trafficking.

headline: Tejada Bounces Back After Hit to His Head
text: MILWAUKEE — The fastball hurtling toward Ruben Tejada’s head was traveling at about 94 miles per hour, so he had little time to react. The ball struck him square on his helmet, on the front corner, just above the bill in the fifth inning of Wednesday’s 3-2 win over the Seattle Mariners.

headline: Mr. Tran’s Messy Life and Legacy
text: Truong Dinh Tran led a mostly uneventful life, unless you count spending two years in a North Vietnamese prison, swimming his way to South Vietnam, building a fortune in wartime, fleeing to the United States with a suitcase full of cash and another full of gold, installing himself and his four paramours and their children in a single-room-occupancy hotel on Manhattan’s West Side, becoming a subject of the biggest federal seizure of property related to drug charges in American history, and then donating $2 million to the American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after Sept. 11. When he died, in 2012, Mr. Tran left a fortune valued at $100 million, at least 16 children by five women, one self-described wife, and no last will and testament.

headline: Caseworker Shot Dead by Psychiatric Patient, Police Say
text: A psychiatric patient opened fire at a suburban hospital outside Philadelphia on Thursday, killing his caseworker and wounding his doctor, who returned fire, the authorities said.

headline: Russia: 2 Activists Sent to Prison Colony
text: A Moscow court on Thursday convicted two prominent activists and sentenced them to four and a half years in a prison colony for their roles in organizing a protest a day before President Vladimir V. Putin’s inauguration in May 2012. The protest against Mr. Putin ended in violence between the police and demonstrators. A three-judge panel concluded that Sergei Udaltsov, the leader of the Left Front, had tried to organize “mass riots” in regions across Russia using money provided by a lawmaker from Georgia, with which Russia fought a war in 2008. The prosecutors’ case was partly based on information from a television special called “The Anatomy of a Revolution” that was broadcast on a state-funded television station. Mr. Udaltsov, the most prominent of 11 opposition activists sentenced to prison since the May 2012 protest, said the case was politically motivated. Mr. Udaltsov’s co-defendant, Leonid Razvozzhayev, accused Russian agents of kidnapping him while he was seeking asylum in Ukraine.

headline: After Mets Fall Behind, the Only Uncertainty Is the Margin of Defeat
text: MILWAUKEE — The Mets, as currently constructed, do not appear to be the kind of team capable of coming from behind routinely. They have subtly acknowledged this and seem to have accepted it, citing their lack of the pure power and the consistency up and down the order typically needed to score in bunches.

headline: A Ride Across America | In Idaho, Two Sisters Get a ‘Truck Farm’ Off the Ground
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: A Playful, Design-Centric Gallery and Shop Pops Up in East Hampton
text: Two gallerists, a design retailer and a creative director walk into a bookstore. The punch line? One might imagine a battle of egos, but that’s not the case for Kyle DeWoody, the community-minded owner and creative director of Grey Area, a Brooklyn-based gallery and design consultancy responsible for a series of exhibitions this summer at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller in East Hampton. After Horowitz asked her to take over the street-level and second-floor spaces within his bookstore, DeWoody opted to bring together people like herself — curators of art and tastemakers of design — to expose the talents they were most excited about. Called Grey East, the project has netted a series of splashy collaborations in an otherwise staid beach town.

headline: Word of the Day | potion
text: potion •\ˈpo-shən\• noun

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) WADJDA (2013) A rambunctious 10-year-old Saudi girl (Waad Mohammed, above) enters a Quran-reciting contest with a cash prize in the hope of buying the bicycle of her dreams — a mode of transportation discouraged for women, with which she intends to race a boy — and in the process overcome her reputation as a troublemaker. Heartbreak hovers over “Haifaa al-Mansour’s sharply observed, deceptively gentle film, reportedly the first feature ever directed by a Saudi woman,” with its “decorous, deliberate scenes” hinting at the difficulties facing her gender, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But “with impressive agility, ‘Wadjda’ finds room to maneuver between harsh realism and a more hopeful kind of storytelling. There is warmth as well as austerity in Wadjda’s world, kindness as well as cruelty, and the possibility, modestly sketched and ardently desired, of change.” (In Arabic, with English subtitles.)

headline: Finding a Voice in Words and Deeds
text: Not enough time and too much bulk might have prevented Mayor Bill de Blasio from taking his copy of “Italoamericana: The Literature of the Great Migration, 1880-1943” (Fordham University Press) with him on vacation to Italy. (For wimps, there is a Kindle edition.)

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 25, 2014
text: “I think we need to look at whether we still need these arrests. This is a good moment to re-evaluate what comes after broken windows, now that the windows are no longer broken.”

headline: Corrections: July 25, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: BSkyB Deal Adds to Time Warner War Chest for Fox’s Murdoch
text: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | Should Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox choose to raise its $80 billion offer for Time Warner, it now has significantly more cash to do so.

headline: Student Crossword | Explorers
text: Test your knowledge of explorers by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: R.B.S. Surpasses Forecasts on Drop in Bad Bank Loans
text: Updated, 2:01 p.m. | LONDON – Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that its second-quarter pretax profit nearly doubled as the bank benefited from a decline in loan impairments. The results were better than expected and prompted the bank to issue them a week early.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Weird Al Yankovic Soars to the Top of the Charts
text: In “No Joke! He’s Topping the Charts,” Ben Sisario writes about Weird Al Yankovic’s “Mandatory Fun” and the online marketing strategies that helped it become the first No. 1 album of his three-decade career.

headline: Lloyds in ‘Late-Stage’ Discussions to Resolve Libor Investigations
text: LONDON – The British lender Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday that it was in “late-stage” discussions to resolve regulatory inquiries into its role in setting global benchmark interest rates, including the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.

headline: Meditation on President Obama’s Portrait
text: Dawoud Bey’s photograph of the man who would soon be president was taken on a Sunday afternoon in early 2007, at Barack and Michelle Obama’s Hyde Park home in Chicago. The portrait is at once stately and informal. Mr. Obama’s hands are folded gracefully in his lap. He wears an elegant suit and white shirt, but no tie. He stares intensely into the camera.

headline: French Soldiers Reach Air Algérie Crash Site
text: PARIS — As a detachment of French soldiers reached the crash site of an Air Algérie jetliner in Mali, officials in Paris said on Friday that the accident was most likely weather-related and that the distribution of the wreckage over a limited area suggested that the plane probably hit the ground intact.

headline: British Construction Giants Balfour Beatty and Carillion in Merger Talks
text: LONDON — The British construction and services companies Carillion and Balfour Beatty said late Thursday that they were engaged in preliminary discussions regarding a possible merger.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Prized but Perilous Catch
text: FORT BRAGG, Calif. — Every year, as steady as the tides, lifeless bodies are pulled from the cold, restless water along the rugged coastline north of San Francisco.

headline: Morning Views
text: “These days, even a school — clearly identified as a shelter run by the United Nations — cannot protect Palestinian civilians in Gaza from deadly attacks,” writes The New York Times Editorial Board. At least sixteen people were killed, bringing the death toll to above 750, “the vast majority being Palestinian civilians.” The debate about who is responsible will go on, but “what really matters now is that some way be found to stop this carnage.” The war is “terrorizing people on both sides of the border, fomenting more hatred”; it is now “past time for an immediate cease-fire and for a political strategy that offers the hope of a more stable future for both Israelis and Palestinians.”

headline: New York Today: Finale for a Ferry
text: Good morning on this cool, clear Friday.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon Makes Big Bets as Its Losses Swell
text: Writers are peeved at Amazon. On Thursday, investors became disgruntled too, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: A Troubled Outlook for China-Japan Ties
text: China and Japan have seen historic disputes metastasize into present-day confrontations, and the possibility of resolution seems to be diminishing, according to a new study of tensions between the two Asian rivals.

headline: E.U. Weighs Tougher Sanctions Against Russia
text: The European Union is considering sanctions in response to the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over Ukraine.

headline: Why a Soaring Stock Market Is Wasted on the Young
text: The news media typically covers stock markets using one exceedingly simple frame: Market goes up, good! Market goes down, bad!

headline: China Plans Extension of Railroad to India Through Tibet
text: BEIJING — China plans to extend by 2020 a railroad on the high trans-Himalayan plateau of Tibet to the borders of India, Bhutan and Nepal, according to a report in People’s Daily, the official mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: Following the Tour de France
text: Ian Austen, who writes about Canada for The Times from his base in Ottawa, has also covered the Tour de France for us on and off since 1992. Mr. Austen is a Masters Racing cyclist and rides in road races as well as cyclocross races. We asked him to tell us about the logistics of following the Tour and how it has evolved over the years.

headline: An Owner Talks About Turning Things Around
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners shared their thoughts on the merits of a college education. This post wraps up that conversation, and gives an update on developments at Bari Jay.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 7 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In The Times this week: a slide show, “Toll Mounts as Both Sides Vie for Advantage,” that accompanies the July 24 article “Kerry Claims Progress Toward Gaza Truce, but Hamas Leader Is Defiant.”

headline: Urumqi Authorities Tighten Security on Buses
text: The authorities in Urumqi, capital of the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, have banned passengers on public buses from carrying liquids, lighters and some powders as part of a continuing effort to tighten security following several deadly terrorist attacks in the city this year, a state-run newspaper reported on Friday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Hedge Fund Managers Headed for Divorce
text: HEDGE FUND MANAGERS HEADED FOR DIVORCE | For a decade, Kenneth C. Griffin and his wife, Anne Dias Griffin, were a financial powerhouse, two hedge fund managers who captivated the Chicago social scene, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. But on Wednesday, Mr. Griffin, the head of the $20 billion investment firm Citadel, filed a divorce petition in Cook County, Ill., citing “irreconcilable differences” after 11 years of marriage. Ms. Dias Griffin has fired back publicly, claiming to have been blindsided by the move. Now, the domestic dispute threatens to push the private couple into the spotlight.

headline: Obama Presses Central American Leaders to Slow a Wave of Child Migrants
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday urged the presidents of Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador to exercise what he called their “shared responsibility” to help stem the flow of migrant children toward the United States border, but the Central American leaders said America shares some of the blame for the crisis.

headline: 1914: Servian Nation to Resist Austria
text: BELGRADE — Servia will not shrink from the power of the great Austro-Hungarian Empire, and will reply to force by force. It is a possible case of David and Goliath. Such is the opinion I have gathered here on every side. It may sound at first suicidal on the part of this small country to seek to measure itself against the might of the Dual Monarchy. But the Servians don’t seem to have an atom of fear. Undoubtedly — and the opinion of all military experts who have seen them is the same — the officers and men of the Servian army constitute the best fighting material in Europe. I saw them, at the time of the first Balkan war — three divisions, or 60,000 men, march through Mustapha  Pasha, to the aid of the Bulgarians. Every man had already been in one, two or more actions. Everything one hears and sees leaves the impression that the Servians know what they are about, and that their lack of fear concerning their traditional enemies, the Austrians and Hungarians, is not without good reason. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 26, 1914

headline: Israel Agrees to Pause in Assault on Gaza as Cease-Fire Deal Is Pursued
text: JERUSALEM — Israel agreed to halt its military offensive in Gaza for 12 hours starting Saturday morning amid intense international efforts to seal a broader cease-fire deal and a new explosion of violence in the West Bank, where at least six Palestinians were killed during clashes with Israeli forces.

headline: Taking Triathlons Into the Wild
text: BOSTON — The 46.6-mile Otillo race started as a drunken bet among four friends in 2002. The challenge? Race in pairs from Uto to Sandhamn, two islands in Sweden’s archipelago, which required swimming a total of 6.2 miles between 26 islands and running 40.4 miles across them. The last team to finish had to pick up the winners’ hotel, bar and dinner tabs on the final island.

headline: American Apparel Gets a Token Power Woman
text: This week, Colleen Brown, the former chief executive of Fisher Communications, a Seattle-based company, became the first, and only, woman on American Apparel’s “new look” board. A.k.a. the token woman. Not that the company put it that way, exactly.

headline: Ambulance Chaser in the House
text: You’re a member of Congress, and everyone hates you. You’re likely to be a lawyer — the leading profession for federal legislators — and most everyone hates lawyers, with a Pew survey finding that people rank them at the very bottom in contributing something to society. Is there anything you could do to generate more contempt?

headline: Goldman Sachs Names Ogunlesi New Lead Director
text: James J. Schiro, the lead director of Goldman Sachs, has retired from the board of the Wall Street bank to undergo medical treatment.

headline: Seeing a Supersize Yacht as a Job Engine, Not a Self-Indulgence
text: DENNIS M. JONES was struck by an intriguing coincidence when he took delivery of his custom-built 164-foot superyacht: The $34 million he paid for it was equal to the $34 million he had donated to charity since 2000. The contributions helped the neediest around St. Louis get an education, get healthy or get a fresh start.

text: LONDON — The British telecom giant Vodafone reported an eighth consecutive quarterly decline in revenue on Friday, but said that performance in its European operations was starting to improve.

headline: Why Jack Bauer Is to Blame for ‘Bonkers TV’
text: This spring, WGN America, a national television network based in Los Angeles known mostly for syndicated shows and baseball games, followed the lead of basic-cable channels like TBS and created its first original series, “Salem.” With its period setting, sumptuous costuming and Sunday-night berth, “Salem” might lead the unsuspecting viewer to the conclusion that it aspires to be Emmy bait, until that viewer sits down to watch the series premiere.

headline: Reply All: The 7.13.14 Issue
text: THE POST-POST-APOCALYPTIC DETROIT

headline: Sketched Out on the Subway
text: I was sitting next to someone on the subway who was surreptitiously sketching portraits of fellow commuters. I once spotted someone opposite me doing this, and actually changed cars when I suspected he was eyeing me as a subject. Being present in a public space does not seem akin to offering permission to record your likeness without consent, despite the intended (lack of) audience or purpose of the final piece. Unlike being captured in a tourist’s random photograph, this act seems to involve a level of scrutiny, focus and invasiveness that makes me uncomfortable. Is it ethical to draw someone without his or her permission or knowledge? CHRISTIANA MAVROMATIS, BROOKLYN

headline: My Secret Pepsi Plot
text: In 1988, when my family declared its desire to emigrate, our homeland imposed a brutal discouragement: No person could leave with more than several hundred dollars’ worth of possessions on hand. (What would you take? My mother tried to bring her wedding ring, but it was seized at customs.)

text: Getting the kids ready for glamp.

text: The author speaks with Jessica Gross about her favorite definition of feminism, ‘‘Sweet Valley High’’ and the fetishization of bad writing.

headline: What Do Chinese Dumplings Have to Do With Global Warming?
text: ‘In Sichuan, we’re eaters,” said Chen Zemin, the world’s first and only frozen-dumpling billionaire. “We have an expression that goes, ‘Even if you have a very poor life, you still have your teeth to please.’ ” He smiled and patted his not insubstantial belly. “I like to eat.”

headline: Who Made That Ziploc Bag?
text: “It seems hard to believe it now, but people did not know how to open the bag,” Steven Ausnit, developer of the original Ziploc, recently told an audience at Marquette University. He recalled that sometime around the early 1960s, his company persuaded Columbia Records to try a plastic sleeve with the zipper on top for albums. “At the final meeting, we were all set to go. The guy called in his assistant, handed her the sealed bag and said, ‘Open it.’ I thought to myself, Lady, please do the right thing! The more she looked at it, the more my heart sank. And then she tore the zipper right off the bag.”

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Lucy,’ ‘Magic in the Moonlight’ and ‘A Most Wanted Man’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the thriller “Lucy,” the Woody Allen comedy “Magic in the Moonlight” and the espionage drama “A Most Wanted Man.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Challenges of the City Chicken
text: Robert McMinn, an urban homesteader in New York City, worked to be sure his neighbors and landlords were happy with his chickens.

headline: Operatic Heart of a Chaotic Career
text: When Christoph Schlingensief’s restless, raucous staging of Wagner’s “Parsifal” opened at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany in 2004, it set off a lively furor in a place where aesthetic indignation and artistic debate are a way of life.

headline: Hank Greenberg’s Triumph Over Hate Speech
text: On a central Illinois baseball field in 1931, a 20-year-old minor leaguer named Hank Greenberg was heckled by the opposing team’s third baseman with anti-Semitic insults — language that we in 2014 would call hate speech. When Greenberg could no longer stand the provocations, which were echoed by an angry, roaring crowd, he confronted the third baseman and was rushed out of the park by local police for protection. Greenberg later said the fracas was “scary.”

headline: Heard on the Street: E-I-E-I-O
text: Ruth Harrigan’s modest backyard in Douglaston, Queens, is a testament to efficient use of space, packed with an ambitious vegetable garden, a drum to collect rainwater, a compost heap, a picnic table and a well-loved swing set. And then there are the four chickens and a rabbit named Sugar Daddy.

headline: Feeling For | A Rosy Read
text: “Chasing the Rose: An Adventure in the Venetian Countryside” ($20, Knopf) is a history lesson posing as a beautiful novel. In it, the author Andrea di Robilant recounts his own quest to identify a silvery pink, peach- and raspberry-scented rose that blooms on his family’s former estate in the small Venetian town of Alvisopoli.

headline: 10 International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
text: A slideshow of cultural events around the world.

headline: Letters: The Word
text: The Word

headline: Marlon’s Method
text: The title of Susan L. Mizruchi’s Marlon Brando book is a hassle. You don’t want to be seen with anything called “Brando’s Smile.” You just don’t. I read the book the old-fashioned way — on paper. I read it in restaurants, on the subway and in the park. I read it with the front cover obscured. To dislike the title of the book is to reject its putative premise — that Brando wasn’t just a sexy slob with no technique but an extremely skilled, deeply intelligent, fiercely perceptive “public citizen” who “carefully controlled his smiles.” Mizruchi seems to be making a case that the modus operandi of one of the movies’ greatest performers can be reduced to the strategic concealment of dental work.

headline: Devilish Audacity
text: Not so long ago, giants bestrode the British boards. In that theatrically golden 20th century, the stage could boast those wonderful knights, Sirs John Gielgud, Laurence Olivier, Michael Redgrave and Ralph Richardson. Close on their heels were Alec Guinness, John Mills, Paul Scofield, Trevor Howard and Peter O’Toole, among others. And all along there was that chameleon of genius, Noël Coward.

headline: Reports From the Exterior
text: The same week I began reading Amy Rowland’s debut novel, “The Transcriptionist,” a Malaysian jetliner vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. It’s a testament to the eerie power of Rowland’s fictional world that while I watched and read the news about the search for the plane, hands to my mouth, I wondered: “Who will call this story in to Lena? And can Lena bear it?”

headline: Captivating and Repellent
text: Ben Macintyre’s “A Spy Among Friends,” about Kim Philby, the British spy who served as a double agent for the Soviet Union, is reviewed this week by Walter Isaacson.

headline: Short Stories
text: THE TAO OF HUMILIATION  Stories  By Lee Upton  BOA Editions, paper, $16.

headline: Inside the List
text: Private Lives: America’s most famous literary recluses are back in the spotlight. J. D. Salinger, who died in 2010, is the subject of Thomas Beller’s gentle New York-centric biography, “J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist,” while Harper Lee turns up at the center of “The Mockingbird Next Door,” by the former Chicago Tribune reporter Marja Mills, new at No. 4 on the hardcover nonfiction list. There are a lot of superficial similarities between Salinger and Lee: Born seven years apart, both wrote beloved novels that have endured for decades as staples of high school reading lists — “The Catcher in the Rye” and “To Kill a Mockingbird,” as if you didn’t know — and both quit writing in the early 1960s to retreat into strictly enforced silences. But they probably never met for drinks, to judge from the portrait of Lee that emerges in “The Mockingbird Next Door.” Mills first met Lee and her sister on assignment for The Tribune, and eventually rented the house neighboring theirs in Monroeville, Ala., for a year and a half, during which she had ample time to observe Lee going about her ordinary daily life: eating at McDonald’s, feeding the town ducks, fishing with hot dogs as bait. Contrast those humble details with what we’ve learned over the years about the deeply eccentric Salinger, whose daughter claimed he sat in an orgone box and drank his own urine, and it becomes clear they don’t have much in common after all.

headline: Most Migrant Children Entering U.S. Are Now With Relatives, Data Show
text: LOS ANGELES — The vast majority of unaccompanied migrant children arriving in the United States from Central America this year have been released to relatives in states with large established Central American populations, according to federal data released Thursday night.

headline: Much Ado About Everything
text: I once met a man with magic in his pocket. He was a former hairdresser named Maurice Ward, and the magic was a material he invented called Starlite. He said it was one of the most astonishing thermal barriers in the world and had been tested in high-profile labs, including a British atomic weapons facility, where it withstood several simulated nuclear flashes. Despite its dizzying potential — fireproof airplanes, laser-resistant tanks — Starlite never ventured far out of Ward’s pocket, because he refused to sell or reveal its recipe before his death a couple of years ago. I mention this because it still intrigues me, as a good mystery should, and because it was my first encounter with the head-­scratching, captivating possibilities of man-made materials.

headline: Sneaking Suspicions
text: Lisa O’Donnell’s dazzling new novel transports us to small-town Scotland and into the increasingly volatile mind of an 11-year-old boy. Michael Murray, who narrates the book, lives with his parents and grandmother in Rothesay on the Isle of Bute. As in most small towns, everybody seems to know everybody else’s business. Here gossip is something more than a spectator sport.

headline: An Architect Gets Busy
text: His buildings might not be the tallest, priciest or zaniest. But in New York, the British architect Norman Foster seems to be having a moment all the same.

headline: Those Who Stay
text: Kseniya Melnik’s accomplished debut collection, “Snow in May,” takes us deep into the complex fabric of Magadan, an isolated fishing and mining town in the northern reaches of Russia that once served as a transit center for prisoners dispatched to Stalin’s labor camps.

headline: Radical Inquiry
text: “I love Ellen Willis,” a friend told me upon hearing there would be an anthology collecting the work of the cultural critic, who was also The New Yorker’s first pop music writer. “She makes me feel less embarrassed to enjoy the Who.”

headline: The Wealth of Ideas
text: Before it became a political philosophy, liberalism was not that difficult to define: A person was liberal if generous, catholic in taste or even excessively rotund. Liberal people may not have been universally admired, but few took to castigating them as dangerous to the health of the state. The opposite of “liberal” was not “conservative” but “strict.” When Bassanio tells Portia in “The Merchant of Venice” that he will give her “the dearest ring in Venice,” she replies, “I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.” No one in Shakespeare’s audience would have concluded that the dissolute nobleman with whom she banters stood on the left side of the political spectrum.

headline: Against Closure
text: A while ago, on the planet of the novelists, two warring factions argued over whether or not characters had to be likable. Absolutely not, the frowny-face contingent claimed, arguing that one of literature’s goals is to illuminate the state of being human, in all its flawed glory. The smiley-face tribe took umbrage: What’s the matter with creating characters readers would like to have as friends? But maybe the question of liking or not liking is the easy one. The harder one, maybe, is what should we make of characters who never really allow us to know them? Characters who are in pain for reasons we understand and behave badly for reasons we can comprehend, but who inspire nothing as strong as liking or loathing. What happens when we close a book with neither a shudder nor a smile, but only a shrug?

headline: Off the Reservation
text: As I began Brando Skyhorse’s “Take This Man,” I thought, Ah, another New Agonist! New Agonists serve the kettle corn of memoir, candy you can’t put down. But often, at book’s end, there’s little to do except swap horrors: “Can you believe the part where Brando’s mama tries to drown him in the toilet?” “What about when she tries to put him up for adoption by placing an ad in a magazine?” And so on.

headline: Love Is Strange
text: My inappropriate nickname for A. L. Kennedy is “Dr. Strangelove.” Not because she’s a devious former Nazi played by Peter Sellers in a movie of the same name, but because her work is obsessed with love and strangeness and, in this particular case, with the strangeness of love. There’s also a strangeness in her writing — both her premises and her sentences — that makes it tricky to situate this prolific Scottish author in any particular literary context. She does things her fellow widely prized and widely translated peers do not: compose whole novels in the second person, write BBC dramas, perform stand-up comedy and ponder in prose the existence of such items as a chocolate-flavored condom, as she does in her new collection of stories, “All the Rage.”

headline: World of Our Great-Grandfathers
text: Back in the days when Jews could travel without having to go anywhere — one minute a house was in Poland, the next in Russia — they lived in places called shtetls, defined neither by physical size nor population, possessing mysterious features both urban and rural. Though Christians lived there too, the shtetl tilted spiritually toward Jerusalem, while performing economic services for the Slavic society to which it also belonged, giving it an Eastern European character all its own. Its amorphous nature has made it the subject of easy mythologizing, so that it often pops up in the American imagination as a kind of Jewish Brigadoon where all the villagers are singing, unless they are running from a pogrom.

headline: Insatiable Gaze
text: Was Lucian Freud really a great painter? I’m not convinced. But he looms large in the social history of postwar London, an inimitable figure who crossed paths with everyone from Kate Moss to the Kray brothers. Born in Berlin in 1922, Freud was 10 when his family moved to London (well before his famous grandfather, who escaped Austria only in 1938). He showed precocious talent as a draftsman — and as a troublemaker. Quick with his fists, he was a chronic expellee. Eventually he ended up at a private art school in Essex run by Cedric Morris; when the school burned down one night, Freud took the credit. But he remained a protégé of Morris, one of a series of gay elders with whom the young Freud knew how to ingratiate himself — though he was conspicuously, not to say voraciously, heterosexual. His looks were as striking as his talent, despite Stephen Spender’s observation at the time that he resembled Harpo Marx.

headline: Was Warren Harding, In Fact, a Terrible President?
text: The many scandalous letters that Warren Harding wrote to his mistress, Carrie Phillips, which the Library of Congress is releasing on July 29, are deliciously fun to read. Written from 1910 to 1920, before Harding was elected president, the correspondence has helped inspire reassessments of his time in office. Harding is usually relegated to the bottom of presidential rankings. But he shouldn’t be, according to Vox’s Dylan Matthews and Slate’s Ronald and Allis Radosh. “Harding was hardly a great president,” Matthews writes, “but he doesn’t deserve the overwhelmingly negative reputation he’s developed.”

headline: Decline and Falling
text: Ten floors up in a seedy apartment building on the edge of a city on the edge of a dry continent and a vast ocean, Tim Winton’s antihero teeters on the brink of destitution and despair. In the wake of several storms that have engulfed his life, he’s been left stranded, a fish flapping uselessly on the sand. Set, as so many of Winton’s books are, in Western Australia — “which was, you could say, like Texas. Only it was big” — his new novel, ­“Eyrie,” is a dark but dazzling study of people and places on the edge. These marginal zones are where Winton enjoys spending time, scavenging for driftwood, floats, rope, old sea boots — and characters like Tom Keely, a washed-up environmentalist who’s been unceremoniously ejected from the world of idealism and activism.

headline: A Contender
text: “So much precious time goes by and it seems to me I get so little out of it,” Elia Kazan wrote to John Steinbeck in 1955. “I ask myself is this it? Is this why? Is this what I wanted to do? Is this why I accumulated what dough I have. I feel like a highly publicized meal ticket, some of the time, doing what the hell my wife and family and society expects of me and not at all — since I dont think originally enough — what I’d like to do. I can imagine great excitement to life again. But something prevents my going after it.”

headline: The Special Challenges of Retiring From a Business You Own
text: RETIRING is challenging for almost everyone. But if you’re a small-business owner, preparing to hand your company to your children can create an even bigger knot of anxiety — worries about financial security, the legacy of your life’s work and the prospects for your offspring. The process can touch everything from spreadsheet-driven company valuations to awkward talks about your children’s limitations. It can demand the technical knowledge of a C.P.A. and the soft skills of a psychologist.

headline: New Find Hints at More Feathered Dinosaurs
text: A new dinosaur species, one with feathers, has been discovered in Russia. The finding could mean that feathers were more widespread among dinosaurs than previously thought, the researchers say.

headline: Are Trophies Really So Bad?
text: Those who see the 21st century as a time of unprecedented narcissism frequently focus on trophies: Too many kids get them nowadays, the argument goes, and it’s leading to rampant entitlement and jerkitude. But anyone who’s felt the sting of not getting a gold star (especially in our allegedly gold-star-happy times) may relate to Molly Knefel’s recent examination of the trophy and its discontents.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: India Threatens to Block Global Trade Deal
text: MUMBAI, India — India could put a landmark World Trade Organization deal in jeopardy at hectic negotiations in Geneva after saying that it would withhold support for the agreement unless there was simultaneous progress on resolving a dispute over its food security program.

headline: Addressing Caregivers’ Loss of Retirement Income
text: Earlier this month Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of New York, introduced what she’s calling the Social Security Caregiver Credit Act, intended to increase retirement income for middle-class citizens who must reduce their work hours or leave the work force because of caregiving duties.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: July 25
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from the funeral of Eric Garner, who died after a confrontation with the police on Staten Island, and white flags on the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Today in Small Business: What It’s Really Like to Own a McDonald’s
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Alan C. Greenberg, 86, Dies; Led Bear Stearns in Good Times and Bad
text: Alan C. Greenberg, a risk-chasing Wall Street titan who built Bear Stearns into a global investment banking powerhouse and shared responsibility, many analysts said, for its collapse as America slid toward a calamitous recession in 2008, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MOTHERLAND FATHERLAND HOMELANDSEXUALS,  by Patricia Lockwood. (Penguin Poets, paper, $20.) Lockwood offers a collection at once angrier, and more fun, more attuned to our time and more bizarre, than most poetry can ever get.

headline: A Case of Murder, Streamlined
text: The story of Lizzie Borden — tried and acquitted, yet still often assumed guilty in the 1892 ax murder of her father and stepmother — was a tantalizing spur to artists, inspiring Agnes de Mille’s 1948 ballet, “Fall River Legend,” and Jack Beeson’s 1965 opera, “Lizzie Borden.” While Beeson, who died in 2010, and his librettist, Kenward Elmslie, created a memorably anxious, creepy work, its three acts all but ensured it would remain a rarity.

headline: When Making Sense Was Optional
text: When Jonathan Demme’s Talking Heads concert film “Stop Making Sense” came out 30 years ago, practically everyone agreed that the genre had taken a stupendous leap forward.

headline: Original, and Built to Stay That Way
text: Time has often smiled on the art of Henry Threadgill, a composer, saxophonist and flutist who has followed his own labyrinthine path through the realm of avant-garde jazz. The oldest of his albums, made 35 years ago, retains the spark of an unfolding event: It sounds at times as if it could be made by musicians working today, which probably tells you what you need to know about Mr. Threadgill’s influence.

headline: Bite-Size Flights of Fancy
text: Contemporary dance has a reputation for being adult entertainment. Not so much because of heavy themes or graphic images — which are rare — but because we don’t trust children to get abstraction (which may just be our own internalized bafflement). “The Nutcracker” feels safer.

headline: Defining Visions, on the Road
text: With the East Building of the National Gallery of Art in Washington closed for a three-year renovation and expansion, curators there have organized a series of exhibitions with works from its postwar and contemporary art collection. One show, “Make It New: Abstract Paintings From the National Gallery of Art, 1950-1975,” opens Saturday at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., in its new Clark Center designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando.

headline: Investigators and Their Secrets
text: Blood is everywhere in Season 4 of “The Killing”: flowing off the body of Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos), spackled on the jacket of Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman), splattered at the scene of their latest case like a Pollock in red and white. “We just got to keep our stories straight, Linden,” Holder tells his perpetually glowering partner, now in full-on rattled mode. “No one’s going to find out. No one’s got to know what we did.”

headline: To Pop Legends, He Was a Guitar Hero
text: Rock ’n’ roll cult heroes burn brightly and briefly. Such romantic figures as Nick Drake, Syd Barrett, Gram Parsons and Jeff Buckley recorded just a few tracks before they were gone — literally or figuratively — left to be discovered by later generations of cool kids, forever frozen as young, beautiful and alluringly obscure.

headline: Of Green Day, Green Hair and Still Green Rock Stars
text: The guys of 5 Seconds of Summer — four lanky Australian youths with a taste for pop-punk, notable hair and a following of millions across social media — would rather not be thought of as a boy band.

headline: A Boss Who’s Open to Suggestions
text: LOS ANGELES — In the first few episodes of “Power,” a new series from Starz, one man is shot in the forehead; another is beaten to a bloody pulp; a third is doused with rubber cement and set ablaze. At the center of the mayhem is James St. Patrick (Omari Hardwick), better known as Ghost, a husband and father who manages a swanky nightclub when he’s not stepping out on his beautiful wife, Tasha (Naturi Naughton), or running one of New York City’s most powerful drug empires.

headline: Today’s Hot I.P.O.: El Pollo Loco
text: Updated, 1:39 p.m. | Investors seem to like the taste of chicken.

headline: Rand Paul Stands Out in Courting Black Voters
text: CINCINNATI — After Mitt Romney received just 6 percent of the black vote in 2012, the Republican Party said that it could no longer afford to ignore African-Americans. “We are never going to win over voters who are not asked for their support,” its leaders wrote in a candid election post-mortem.

headline: Against Walter Kasper (II)
text: Back in May, I offered some general comments on the question of communion for divorced and remarried Catholics — which looms over the Synod on the Family scheduled for this autumn in Rome, and may represent one of the defining controversies of Pope Francis’s pontificate — and then wrote what was intended to be the first of two posts addressing Cardinal Walter Kasper’s high-profile case for admitting the remarried to the sacrament. That post offered theological and sociological reasons to be skeptical of Kasper’s broad suggestion, offered in an interview with the editors of Commonweal, that Catholic marriage generally is in a crisis more severe even than divorce statistics would suggest, in which (he argued) possibly as many as half of all Catholic marriages are actually invalid. The second post, which I promised and then didn’t deliver, was supposed to be a detailed response to his specific proposal on communion, which he first presented in remarks to his fellow cardinals in the winter and then elaborated again in the Commonweal interview this spring.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Old Parts at an Old Show
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Graffiti and the Civil War
text: In September 1864, Cpl. Robert I. Hogue was stationed with his regiment, the 8th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, at an unassuming church known as Morgan’s Chapel in Bunker Hill, W.V. Mustered into service earlier that year, the unit had seen hard fighting throughout the Shenandoah Valley that summer. A month later, it would participate in the decisive Union victory at Cedar Creek. But in this interstitial moment, the soldiers had some down time.

headline: Paperback Row
text: CATASTROPHE 1914: Europe Goes to War,  by Max Hastings. (Vintage, $17.95.) This is an excellent chronicle of World War I’s first months, from the initial diplomatic crisis to the fighting in Belgium and France on the Western Front, and Serbia and Galicia to the east. Hastings, the author of “Inferno: The World at War, 1939-1945,” finds the argument that Germany bore principal blame “overwhelmingly strong.” Sean McMeekin’s JULY 1914: Countdown to War (Basic Books, $17.99) opens with a vivid reconstruction of Archduke Franz Ferdinand’s assassination in Sarajevo on June 28, then focuses on the actions of a small group of statesmen — Austrian, German, Russian, French — as they sought to capitalize on the fallout.

headline: Movie Review: ‘A Most Wanted Man’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Most Wanted Man.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Lucy’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Lucy.”

headline: Russia Steps Up Help for Rebels in Ukraine War
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Rather than backing down after last week’s downing of a civilian passenger jet, Russia appears to be intervening more aggressively in the war in eastern Ukraine in what American and Ukrainian officials call a dangerous escalation that will almost certainly force more robust retaliation from the United States and Europe.

headline: In Investing, 'When' Matters Just as Much as 'What'
text: Today I brought you the story of four hypothetical savers to show how timing can be unlucky for some investors who are saving for retirement via the stock market. If you’re building retirement savings little by little over decades, it matters a great deal not just what the stock market or other investments return, but when those returns materialize.

headline: Text and Ride in India
text: PUNE, India — When Praveen Narayan Dusane first started driving an auto-rickshaw in this crowded college town, he had to hustle for every rupee. He could wait hours at a rickshaw stand for passengers. He fought with other drivers and haggled with passengers over the fares. Typically, he earned just 300 rupees, or roughly $5, during a 12-hour shift.

headline: A Mac That Keeps Working, Even in Sleep Mode
text: Q. I thought I wasn’t getting new mail on my phone when I was out running around, but it turns out my new iMac at home was downloading mail even though I put it to sleep. How is this possible?

headline: Taking Stock of Four Years of Dodd-Frank
text: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” was published in May by Yale University Press.

headline: In Context or Out of Step?
text: On West 79th Street from Amsterdam Avenue to Broadway is a remarkable holdover from the late 19th century, two facing rows of townhouses on a wide street. In the Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District, the buildings are almost intact, although four were replaced in the 1970s with a homely apartment house of the same height, 203-209 West 79th.

headline: Tomatoes All Summer Long
text: Once summer tomatoes are flourishing in my garden and at farmers’ markets, capturing their bounty for the rest of the year becomes a weekly ritual. This mostly involves the making of marinara sauce; I try to have enough of it in the freezer to last me through a winter’s worth of impromptu pasta dinners.

headline: On the Upper West Side, a House Divided by Income
text: Even as so many crises roiled the world recently, the news that a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan would proceed with a brand of distasteful social engineering still managed to command international attention. The building, in what is known as Riverside South, a stretch of land reaching below 72nd Street that seems largely like a pop-up location for people who have never heard of Katz’s deli or the G train, had received approval from the city for separate entrances — one for wealthy residents and one for those earning far less who would occupy the project’s affordable units, in a separate wing.

headline: Best Time of Day for a Testosterone Test
text: Doctors often recommend that men with erectile dysfunction have their testosterone measured from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m., because levels are usually highest then and vary over a 24-hour period. But a new study has found that this variation occurs only in younger men.

headline: Letting a Child Make the Small Sacrifice
text: It so happened, recently, that my 10-year-old daughter and I wanted the same thing. It could have been anything — the last brownie, the window seat — but what matters is that there was only one. If our happiness depended on this one thing, there was no way we would both end up happy.

headline: British Prosecutor to Pay $5.1 Million in Case Related to Kaupthing Inquiry
text: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | LONDON – Britain’s Serious Fraud Office said on Friday that it would pay 3 million pounds, or about $5.1 million, to settle civil claims brought by a property developer following a flawed investigation into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing during the financial crisis.

headline: Big Ticket | Park and River Vistas for $30 Million
text: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath apartment with Central Park and Hudson River vistas from the 33rd floor of the tower at 15 Central Park West sold for $30,003,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: At the Wheel, the Balloonatic
text: To many regular passengers on the weekday morning M-8 crosstown bus, Nick Rotondo, 53, is the consummate city bus driver: a seasoned, cheery fellow with a New Yorker’s savvy.

headline: Once an Ornamental Hermit, Now a German Media Darling
text: BERLIN — On a hot summer night here, under the twinkling lights of a spinning disco ball, Friedrich Liechtenstein took the stage in a paisley-print silk bathrobe. “My dear people,” the newly minted German media star said, in a sonorous voice, “If things don’t work out tonight, don’t think of this as an awful show. Rather, I recommend you look at it as if it were a film — one that replicates, very precisely, an awful show.”

headline: French President on Air Algerie Crash
text: President François Hollande of France said there were no survivors in the crash of an Air Algérie jetliner, as the first images of the wreckage site in Mali were released.

headline: John Walsh’s Campaign Sinking Under Plagiarism
text: It’s virtually an axiom in Washington politics that when the establishment declares its undying support for a person at the center of a scandal, that person is about to be thrown under the bus. The latest potential traffic victim is Senator John Walsh of Montana, the retired Army colonel who seems to have plagiarized his master’s thesis for the United States Army War College.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
text: This week, Ben Macintyre discusses “A Spy Among Friends”; Alexandra Alter and Parul Sehgal talk about the week’s literary news; Donald L. Miller discusses “Supreme City”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Transforming the Investment Case for BSkyB
text: “British” Sky Broadcasting is no more. The company is buying sister Sky units in Germany and Italy for at least 4.9 billion pounds ($8.3 billion) in cash from Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox. That transforms the investment case for Britain’s top pay-television company.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
text: This week, Ben Macintyre and Donald L. Miller.

headline: Mark Fisher: A Day Away From the Ninjas
text: While acting in regional theater in his 20s, Mark Fisher often shared workout techniques with fellow cast members, and his advice became so popular that he turned it into a regimen, called “Snatched in Six Weeks.” Two years ago, with residuals from an Allstate commercial, he and his business partner opened Mark Fisher Fitness on West 39th Street in Hell’s Kitchen — and moved into an apartment upstairs. The gym (known as the clubhouse) draws scores of Broadway performers, including Shina Ann Morris, an actress in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” who became Mr. Fisher’s girlfriend. Mr. Fisher, 34, and Ms. Morris, 28, live together in the apartment with Mr. Fisher’s business partner and his boyfriend.

headline: The New Oil Patch: Rail Lines in Albany and Elsewhere
text: In a thorough piece, “Albany Nears Oil-Hub Status as 100-Car Trains Jam Port,” Bloomberg News does a great job of illustrating why New York State has to work swiftly to get a handle on issues related to the oil-by-rail boom.

headline: Taking New Music From Los Angeles to Reykjavik
text: Here is a glimpse of how an enterprising classical new-music ensemble gets projects underway in 2014.

headline: An Exclusive New Club in Paris With a No-Social-Media Rule
text: L’isolé, a bar in the red light district of Pigalle that will open in time for Paris fashion week, translates to “the isolated.” It’s not exactly antisocial, but it does have a strict “No Facebook, No Twitter” policy. Co-founders Guillaume Le Donche and Antoine Galabert want it to be a place with a human touch. “We manage all our communication with prints and real-life networking,” says Le Donche, 27, who honed his skills at Parisian hot spots La Clique, Showcase and L’Inconnu. “With only digital promotion, you’re just lost in the maze of the Internet.”

headline: Is Moore’s Law Less Important to the Tech Industry?
text: The central organizing principle of much of the tech industry is Moore’s Law. In one very important sense, it may be of less value than it once was.

headline: Before Kubrick Was an Auteur
text: Stanley Kubrick, who would have turned 86 on Saturday, was once known professionally as just “Stan Kubrick” — an almost comically breezy abbreviation for the man we know as a titanically exacting director. Then again, Kubrick was only 16 at the time, a precocious boy from the Grand Concourse with a Graflex camera, who had somehow blustered his way into the picture department at Look magazine. For the next five years there, before his movie career began, he held his own with the New York photojournalists of the 1940s, covering street life, prizefights, jazz concerts, stars and starlets, and forging a recognizable style of his own.

headline: Smooth Dogfish Shark: A Threat, if You’re a Clam
text: The Atlantic shoreline has not been the same since June 1975, when “Jaws” opened. For many, the movie’s deep, pulsating theme music remains an ominous reminder that there could be something looking up at us from under our kicking feet. Sightings of great white sharks off our coastlines sell newspapers for weeks each summer — and this year has been no exception.

headline: Stepping Into the Frame in the South of France
text: It was Paul Cézanne who went to L’Estaque first, in 1864. He escaped the gray dreariness of Paris and later avoided army conscription in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 in this sunny shorefront village outside Marseille. From the windows of a rented house next to the little church on the hill, he could look out on the tile rooftops leading down to the harbor, with its fishing boats, and across the wide bay to Marseille, the low, rocky mountains at its back.

headline: 1939: World’s End Because of Mars?
text: The Mexican ‘‘astronomer’’ who has seized on the planet Mars’s approach to the earth to predict the end of the world tomorrow is ignorant of the elements of astronomy, according to Ernest Esclangon, director of the Paris Observatory, who, in a mock-serious vein, yesterday ‘‘authorized a denial’’ of the publicity-seeking prediction. ‘‘Why, in the firmament’s name, should the approach of Mars be a danger to this planet of ours?’’ M. Esclangon told anxious reporters. ‘‘It is a simple matter of planetary motions which brings Mars in line with the earth and the sun every sixteen years, and if this geometrical phenomenon were to be the end of the world every time it occurred, there would have been no world long before this.’’ Mere proximity of Mars to the earth is no menace, M. Esclangon explained, since both planets continue to move in their respective orbits, like ships that pass by each other on the high seas, each on its own course. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 26, 1939

headline: A Turkish Town Where Baklava Beckons
text: The first thing you notice among passengers departing from Oguzeli Airport in Gaziantep, Turkey, is the profusion of shopping bags containing baklava, the intensely sweet Middle Eastern phyllo pastry and nut confection that is a staple of every Turkish celebration. This city of about a million people, in the province of the same name and situated on the Silk Road about 530 miles southeast of Istanbul, claims some 100 baklava shops, which supply 90 percent of the baklava consumed in Turkey. Last December, Gaziantep baklava, which is made with locally grown pistachio nuts, was awarded “protected status” by the European Union, a designation that recognizes a specific local food, protects it from imitators and potentially helps boost tourism to the area.

headline: Hotel Review: Pestana South Beach Art Deco Hotel in Miami Beach
text: Rates

headline: A Secluded Modern
text: Seatuck Cove Farms, a secluded 22-acre estate with 2,000 feet of waterfront on Seatuck Creek and Little Seatuck Creek in Eastport, and panoramic views across Moriches Bay to Dune Road in Westhampton, is entering the market for the first time in 35 years. The asking price is $12 million.

headline: Lots of Paul Ryan’s New Report Is About State and Local Policy
text: Some of the most innovative ideas for conservative reforms are in policy areas controlled by state and local governments. That’s why, beyond its proposals to change how the federal government fights poverty, the new “discussion draft” from Representative Paul Ryan has recommendations in areas you might not associate with him: education, sentencing, parole and occupational licensing, to name a few.

headline: Passions Running to Art, or Infanticide
text: LONDON — You have heard this story before, many times, and it’s never been pretty. A wife devotes her existence to furthering her husband’s career, making countless self-denying sacrifices. And then the bum trades her in for a younger model. The discarded wife gets angrier and angrier and angrier, until there’s truly hell to pay.

headline: Peach Crumble Slab Pie
text: Melissa Clark makes a delicious deep-dish dessert with fresh peaches that is equal parts crumble and pie.

headline: A Stripped-Down Domestic Drama
text: Just why “A Doll’s House” needs stripping down to its essentials, I don’t know, but people keep trying. The new production of “Nora” at the Westport Country Playhouse has a minimalist set and a naked man in the spotlight at the end. “Nora” is the 1981 adaptation by Sweden’s genius film auteur Ingmar Bergman of “A Doll’s House,” Henrik Ibsen’s landmark 1879 feminist domestic drama; Bergman had already eliminated six of the original play’s characters (the children and the servants).

headline: Studs Terkel Audio Archive to Go Online
text: The creation of a publicly accessible digital archive with nearly 5,000 oral history interviews, conducted by the Chicago journalist Studs Terkel, is one of 177 projects awarded a grant this week by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

headline: The Future Looks Peachy
text: The sad truth about homemade peach pie is that there’s never enough.

headline: Indian Air Force Helicopter Crashes, Killing 7
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian Air Force helicopter exploded and crashed in northern India on Friday, possibly after hitting a high-voltage electrical cable, killing all seven people aboard, the authorities announced.

headline: Setting Sights on Long Island and Wars Past
text: Joshua Ruff, the chief curator of the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, has chosen objects of all shapes and sizes for the exhibitions there — including, recently, a large gun sight from a World War II B-32 bomber that Mr. Ruff estimates weighs “about 400 pounds.”

headline: In Queens, Immigrants Clash With Residents of New Homeless Shelter
text: The crowd of 500 included grandmothers and small children, Chinese immigrants and the president of a local Republican club, all shouting that the mayor had trampled their rights.

headline: Long Beach Film Festival Finds a Home
text: After Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the fledgling Long Beach International Film Festival, which had just finished its inaugural year, threatened to collapse before ever fully taking off. A prospective screening site had been destroyed, and without a proper venue the festival could not attract filmmakers and sponsors.

headline: Popcast: Arto Lindsay’s Ecstatic Procession
text: Arto Lindsay, the singer and guitarist who was born in Virginia and raised partly in Recife, Brazil, has been an important if inconstant figure in New York music over the last 35 years.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Kim Philby Case
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Walter Isaacson reviews Ben Macintyre’s “A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal.” Mr. Isaacson writes:

headline: 1875: The Airplane, Still a Flight of Fancy
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: A Hamptons Bistro Gets an Update
text: If there is such a thing as a restaurant mecca in the Hamptons these days, it would mostly likely be Sag Harbor, the quaint former whaling town located north of Bridgehampton.

headline: Top Sprinter’s Crash Ruins Bid for First Stage Win
text: BERGERAC, France — It was another rainy day at the Tour de France with a rider from the American Garmin-Sharp team at the front as the finish neared. But unlike Jack Bauer, who was caught only yards before the finish line in Nîmes on Sunday, Ramunas Navardauskas managed to win alone Friday after a 129.5-mile trek through downpours, thunder and lightning.

headline: Employees Who Leave Increasingly Return to the Fold
text: LeBRON JAMES has been called a king, a superathlete, a traitor. And now that the basketball megastar has decided to return to Cleveland and the team he once abandoned, he’s earned a new moniker he may not even know about: boomerang.

headline: Putting the A in STEAM
text: An arrangement of test tubes containing color-coded genetic material; a wearable garden that purifies the air; an installation inspired by the periodic table — these artworks all incorporate components of STEM, an educational curriculum that is an acronym for science, technology, engineering and mathematics. They are currently among more than 40 pieces on view in “Steam,” a new exhibition at ArtsWestchester’s Arts Exchange.

headline: S.E.C. Says Citigroup Unit Failed to Protect Customer Trading Data
text: LavaFlow, a unit of Citigroup that operates an alternative stock trading venue, agreed to pay $5 million to settle charges that it failed to protect the confidential trading data of its customers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday. The payment includes a $2.85 million penalty that the S.E.C. said was the largest it had levied against an alternative trading system.

headline: A Drop in the Long-Term Unemployed
text: THE long-term unemployment rate, which soared in 2009 to heights not seen since the Great Depression, is finally declining rapidly. The proportion of the work force that has been unemployed for at least 27 weeks has fallen to 1.98 percent, less than half the record high of 4.4 percent reached in 2010.

headline: At Goldman Sachs, the Right Candidate for a Half-Right Job
text: Goldman Sachs has found the right man for a half-right job.

headline: A Greek Summer Treasure
text: In Greece, the summer produce of choice is the sweet, meaty, sun-ripened red tomato. Tomatoes are eaten daily, usually with not much more adornment than a sprinkling of sea salt and a drizzle of fruity olive oil. They can be raw or cooked; either way, they are wonderful.

headline: A Landlord Rents Office Space, and Maybe a Picture or Two
text: Many business owners want their offices to reflect good taste, with fine art on the walls. But they must weigh the cost against the vagaries of the marketplace. A few good years, and the millions come rolling in. A few setbacks, and the banks send a crew to pack up the furniture.

headline: Vick Teaches Smith Virtually and in Reality
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — After a recent morning practice, Geno Smith, the young quarterback who many presume will be the Jets’ starter, recalled the first time he was introduced to Michael Vick, the veteran who could well be his backup.

headline: How to Charge Your Phone in 15 Minutes
text: Say you’ve got 15 minutes in an airport between flights and your phone is nearly dead. What do you do?

headline: Brooklyn Bridge White Flag Culprits Avoiding Capture, So Far
text: The daredevils who scaled the towers of the Brooklyn Bridge and put white flags in place of the American flags there have eluded capture for three days, and authorities said Friday that they were not much closer to finding them.

headline: Documenting Missteps in Death of Peace Corps Volunteer
text: Documents, including emails, letters and investigative reports about the death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer in China.

headline: The 19th-Century Home of Jell-O’s Forefather
text: As the historian of Ringwood Manor, a sprawling country home on the grounds of Ringwood State Park, Sue Shutte often deals with the constant quirks and mysteries of this 19th-century estate.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteers in Their Own Words
