text: To reflect the diversity of experiences in the Peace Corps, The Times asked recent volunteers to share stories about their service.

headline: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death
text: BRENTWOOD, Calif. — Nick Castle had just graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, when he loaded up his backpack with Mandarin-language books and set off for rural China to teach in the Peace Corps. Seven months later, in January 2013, a 2 a.m. telephone call jolted his parents awake.

headline: Ezra Klein Asks the Wrong Question
text: He asks, Why should anyone trust Paul Ryan’s poverty plan? That’s easy: nobody should. This has been another edition of simple answers to simple questions.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: DVF’s Enduring Reign, Louboutin’s Beauty Moment and Zac Posen’s Candid Confessions
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Are You Fluent in Emoji?
text: Find out how well you communicate using emojis in this 10 question quiz.

headline: The Emoji Have Won the Battle of Words
text: It started about six months ago, with a smiley face here and there, a sequence of pictograph red hearts when friends would send baby pictures or a string of blown kisses to say good night. I especially liked the face with a toothy, uncomfortable-looking grimace: “Yikes,” it seemed to say. Perfect for “I’m sorry I’m late!” or “Eek, it’s 1 p.m. and I just woke up.”

headline: Opaque System Obscures Support for Health Care Ad
text: WASHINGTON — The television ad sponsored by the advocacy arm of the National Federation of Independent Business featured a small-business owner in Arkansas, frustrated at what he said were the higher bills he had seen since the Obama administration’s health care plan went into effect — and pointing blame at Senator Mark Pryor, a Democrat considered one of the most vulnerable incumbents facing re-election this fall.

headline: No Time to Think
text: ONE of the biggest complaints in modern society is being overscheduled, overcommitted and overextended. Ask people at a social gathering how they are and the stock answer is “super busy,” “crazy busy” or “insanely busy.” Nobody is just “fine” anymore.

headline: Failure Is Our Muse
text: JULY 8, in case you happened to miss it, was Fitz-Greene Halleck Day, a chance to remember the most intensely forgotten writer in American history. “No name in the American poetical world is more firmly established than that of Fitz-Greene Halleck,” Edgar Allan Poe wrote in 1843. And yet, despite a Central Park statue that still stands in his honor, Fitz-Greene Halleck may now be the most famous man ever to achieve total obscurity.

headline: In Wake of Disasters, an Air Travel F.A.Q.
text: In the aftermath of the shooting of Malaysia Airlines flight 17 last week and the rocket strike near Ben-Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv this week, people planning to fly to the Middle East or on a route crossing Eastern Europe have been left wondering whether or not they could — or should — continue with their travel plans.

headline: We’re Missing the Story
text: LISBON — THE Western news media are in crisis and are turning their back on the world. We hardly ever notice. Where correspondents were once assigned to a place for years or months, reporters now handle 20 countries each. Bureaus are in hub cities, far from many of the countries they cover. And journalists are often lodged in expensive bungalows or five-star hotels. As the news has receded, so have our minds.

headline: Bel Kaufman, Who Told What School Was Really Like, Dies at 103
text: Bel Kaufman, a former New York City schoolteacher whose classic first novel, “Up the Down Staircase” — shot through with despair and hopefulness, violence and levity, bureaucratic inanity and a blizzard of official memorandums so mind-bendingly illogical as to seem almost Kafkaesque — was hailed as a stunningly accurate portrait of life in an urban school when it was published in 1965, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103.

headline: The End of the Cringe
text: Doug Sosnik has an interesting piece in Politico on how “the left” is taking over the Democratic Party. Of course, what he calls “left” would be centrist, maybe even right of center, in most other Western democracies; and I think it’s still true that today’s progressive icons — say, Elizabeth Warren — are to the right of where old-line liberals like Teddy Kennedy were.

headline: Audubon Seeks a More Bird-Friendly Design for the Vikings’ New Stadium
text: As if they did not already have their hands full trying to beat the Eagles, the Falcons and the Ravens, the Minnesota Vikings now have to grapple with ruby-throated hummingbirds, song sparrows and hermit thrushes.

headline: Finally, a Cocktail Congress Can Agree On
text: Next week, the Senate is expected to pass a bill that will keep the Federal Highway Trust Fund from running out of money for almost a year. Nobody’s really happy with the bill, attacked by lawmakers from both parties for including fiscal gimmicks. But at least it means states won’t have to start shutting down existing highway projects on Aug. 1 for lack of funds.

headline: Following a Very Different Path to Marital Bliss
text: Last month, in anticipation of our 25th anniversary, my husband, Daniel, and I pulled out our wedding video, thinking it would be fun for our now-teenage children to see their parents’ partying pre-kids and for my parents to remember what a great party they had given that day. But the viewing party soon resembled a game of “Duck, Duck, Goose,” as my father, now 83, gave the status of their friends in the church as the camera panned over their smiling faces.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Weekend Reading: Waiting on Rupert
text: The only way Rupert Murdoch’s highly anticipated Time Warner bid could grab any more attention is if 21st Century Fox moved its headquarters from New York to tax-friendly Australia.

headline: Broadway’s Musical Chairs
text: Beneath the stage of Broadway’s Al Hirschfeld Theater lies a dark space with a low ceiling — a cross between a suburban rec room and a submarine. Shortly before each performance of “Kinky Boots,” 13 black-clad musicians file to their battle stations, each illuminated by a small light attached to a music stand. The expectant buzz of the audience filters down from a narrow opening at the edge of the stage.

headline: Quick, Sloppy and Expensive Background Checks
text: Running security background checks on government job applicants has become a booming private industry in Washington’s war on terror. It’s such a busy sector that one of the many workers vetting citizens managed to review 15,152 clearance cases in a single month last year. That’s about one and a half cases per minute handled by the employee, not allowing for bathroom breaks.

headline: Remembering Ace Greenberg, Through Good Times and Bad
text: Alan C. Greenberg, who led Bear Stearns through its rise and fall, died on Friday at the age of 86. During his long career on Wall Street, he was known as a colorful character with a penchant for magic tricks and a generous heart.

headline: Front-Wheel-Drive Ingenuity
text: Early front-drive passenger cars had an alarming tendency to slip or stall on steep grades. A crucial challenge in the development of the Ruxton was to accommodate both a lengthy reverse-mounted straight-8 engine and conventional transmission so that as much weight as possible would end up over the front wheels.

headline: Even After Ruxton, the Drama Continued
text: The years after the death of the Ruxton automobile proved eerily circular for the two men most entwined in its checkered history, William J. Muller and Archie M. Andrews. Briefly reunited in a subsequent automotive venture, a final twist pitted them against each other.

headline: Remembering the Ruxton
text: With its pioneering front-wheel drive, low-slung silhouette and cat’s eye headlamps, the multicolored Ruxton automobile seemed destined for greatness in 1929.

headline: Good While It Lasted
text: Ruxtons were beautiful, innovative automobiles, but a little over a year after the first model was produced for 1929, the company was gone.

headline: Not Quite an M Car, but Stirring in Spirit
text: Here’s a tire-kicking experiment: Pay a visit to your BMW dealer. Weave through the sleek wares on display — but tiptoe around that strange blobby thing called a 5 Series GT. Now, stop when you see a window sticker that’s less than $40,000.

headline: Under the Hood, More Than Just Horsepower
text: Detroit’s newest muscle car is best known by the name of the 707-horsepower supercharged Hemi V8 under its hood. The brawniest 2015 Dodge Challenger SRT may as well dispense with the rest of its official nomenclature: As long as its power comes from the Hellcat, that’s what people will call this car.

headline: 2014 BMW M235i
text: The M235i may not be a full-blown M car, but in many ways it performs like one.

headline: The Many Names of Power
text: In automotive marketing, an engine is more than a power plant. It’s a Super-Hurricane, a Fire Dome, a Hemi.

headline: Panama-Crossed Paths, Far From Brooklyn
text: When Erik King was 26, he outfitted an old school bus with bunk beds and surfboards, transforming it into a roving surf hostel, which he drove along the coast of Mexico and Central America for two years.

headline: A Low-Cost Head-Up Option
text: For drivers who have grown dependent on head-up displays to monitor their speed and read navigation instructions, the Garmin HUD+ may be a boon, a disappointment or a bit of each.

headline: Top 15 Fantasy Football Quarterbacks
text: The position is deep heading into the 2014 fantasy football season.

headline: Fantasy Football: Quarterback Primer
text: Strike early, or wait? That is always the great debate when it comes to drafting a quarterback for your fantasy team. The 2013 season gave us 14 passers who averaged 20 or more standard fantasy points per week. Astonishingly enough, that group excluded flashy names like Colin Kaepernick (19 pts), Matt Ryan (18.8), Tom Brady (18.6) and Robert Griffin III (18.5).

headline: Sophisticated, With a Side of Service
text: Many restaurants in downtown Ridgewood, a charming scene full of homegrown boutiques and cafes, open with great fanfare and then suddenly are shuttered. But judging by the robust, enthusiastic crowds, Mémoire, a new, sleek establishment that makes the most of local seasonal produce and an extremely accommodating staff, could have some staying power.

headline: Police Stop-and-Frisk in Newark
text: Philip Montgomery found few cinema-worthy stop-and-frisk moments in Newark. Instead, he found distrust and misunderstanding clouding these encounters.

headline: Friday Night Music: Hotel California
text: For obvious reasons. Also, still pretty great:

headline: Carrie Hessler-Radelet
text: In an interview recorded before The Times learned the details surrounding Nick Castle’s death, the director of the Peace Corps reflected on her volunteer experience and the agency’s future.

headline: A Toast? How About a Toke?
text: Earlier this month, when Ellen Epstein arrived at the Devil’s Thumb Ranch in Tabernash, Colo., for the wedding of her friends Lauren Meisels and Bradley Melshenker, she, like the other guests, found a gift bag waiting for her in her hotel room. But rather than a guide to activities in the area or a jar of locally made honey, the canvas bag contained a rolled joint, a lighter and lip balm infused with mango butter and cannabis, along with this note: “We wanted to show you some of the things we love the best.”

headline: Video: The 2015 Hyundai Genesis Delivers Value, but Not Much Flash
text: The best way to find a car’s strengths and weaknesses is to take it on an extended road trip. I recently did just that with the second-generation Hyundai Genesis, traveling from Seattle to Corvallis, Ore., with my 17-year-old son and two of his friends. Boys are great to travel with. They talk sports, point out cool cars, eat junk food and then retreat to their headphones to listen to music their mothers don’t approve of.

headline: By the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, a Treasure Island
text: Visitors entering the Lowe’s parking lot from Ninth Street inevitably slow to a crawl as they pass by New York Old Iron. Even along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, you don’t expect to see this.

headline: Powerful and Coldhearted
text: I FEEL your pain.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, France and Germany.

headline: Why We're Likely to See More 'Worst' Presidents
text: How much do members of the opposite party dislike whoever happens to be president? A lot, and the feeling seems to be getting stronger.

headline: Kerry Vows to Continue Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that an intensive effort to arrange a seven-day humanitarian cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza had fallen short, but he promised to keep trying.

headline: A Fan’s Essential Jenny Lewis Primer
text: Earlier in my career, I worked as a music reviewer, which, as you can imagine, meant listening to a lot of really bad music. But the first time I heard Jenny Lewis, I became an instant fan. She is an ‘‘indie goddess,’’ as Jeff Himmelman writes in this week’s magazine, ‘‘a stylish performer who defies genre and salts her songs with a sly and off-kilter intelligence.’’ I love that her lyrics transcend the simplistic tropes of pop music. Instead, each song draws you in and tells a story. I’m not ashamed to admit that I cried when I saw Lewis perform with the Watson Twins in 2006.

headline: The Brando, Both a Resort and a Lab
text: Marlon Brando first visited Tetiaroa, a 12-island atoll 30 miles north of Tahiti, while filming “Mutiny on the Bounty.” He bought it five years later, and briefly ran an inn, where he invited conservationists and researchers interested in the South Pacific ecosystem. This month, Tetiaroa continues this legacy with the opening of the Brando, a 35-villa luxury resort and scientific research lab.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Challenges for Amazon’s Cloud Computing Hopes
text: How worried should Amazon be about its biggest hope for the future?

headline: Sing a Song, End a War: All in a Supernatural Camp Routine
text: I plan to change the subject when my 11-year-old daughter asks about “The Lightning Thief,” a new musical at the Lucille Lortel Theater. She was excited to attend, but a last-minute appointment prevented it. To tell her how much fun she missed might be a little cruel.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Animated ‘Star Wars’ Series Aims to Be True to Original Film
text: SAN DIEGO — “Star Wars Rebels,” an animated series that marks the start of the Walt Disney Company’s stewardship of the space franchise, will not be anything like the last three “p” movies — you know, the prequel trilogy that took in more than $3.3 billion worldwide but left many hard-core fans fuming.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
text: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns.

headline: Remembered as Victims, Recast as Heroines
text: One woman’s life is spent mostly in slavery. The other woman’s death comes at the guillotine. The stories of Sally Hemings and Marie Antoinette are a little short on cheer.

headline: Why We Live In Unhappy Places
text: The happiest city in America, at least according to a recent study, is Charlottesville, Va. But that information may not do you much good — the study also found that when we choose where to live, happiness may not matter all that much.

headline: A Squeeze From the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs
text: LAS VEGAS — The 64-board final of the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams was played here on Thursday. The winners were China Red: Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Wu Shao Hong and Zhang Yu. They defeated Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Kerri Sanborn, Irina Levitina and JoAnna Stansby by fewer than 2 international match points after an appeal was heard after the end of the match. The full story will be in Monday’s column.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
text: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns suggesting the charm of a picket fence in a cottage garden. A surprising wash of color appeared on a sanitation truck. But the most striking prints echo protruding oriel-like windows or a building’s narrow red-to-yellow column or the Mondrian pattern on a building in Columbus Circle.

headline: Evening Hours | Everyone Outdoors!
text: Summer traditions to support the arts and those living with AIDS.

headline: No Secret to Creating an Intriguing Cover
text: This week’s cover features three books about spying. After Walter Isaacson agreed to review “A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal” by Ben Macintyre, we decided to hold a slightly earlier review by Mark Mazzetti, of two books on spying, in order to run them together on a spy-themed cover.

headline: Where Snarl Meets Roar
text: Every Friday this summer, or at least when the weather cooperates, a ritual specific to the very wealthy takes place at the East Hampton Airport.

headline: Keeping Secrets in Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES — A ripple of dread rolled through Hollywood’s power publicist ranks in February. For the first time since its 2012 debut, the anonymous secret-sharing app Whisper had ensnared an A-list star.

headline: Russia Sues McDonald’s, Questioning Quality of the Food
text: MOSCOW — The McDonald’s cheeseburger will have its day in court.

headline: New Approach to Being There: ‘Fan-bots’ Will Cheer Korean Baseball Team
text: Starting with childhood visits to dusk summer softball games in East Greenwich, R.I., and then a couple of memorable trips to Fenway Park, baseball always had a visceral feel for me that was never matched on a television screen.

headline: All Tribalism and Treachery, Dude
text: No knowledge of antiquity is required to appreciate “Hercules,” which assumes a low base line from the start. “His father was Zeus, the Zeus,” the voice-over explains, in case you were expecting Dr. Zaius.

headline: Voices and Vulnerability
text: In the origin-myth prologue to “The Fluffy Movie,” a child-size version of the comic Gabriel Iglesias chuckles at “Eddie Murphy Raw,” viewed on a sneaked VHS copy. That may suggest that showboating and shock are in store, but Mr. Iglesias’s style in his first theatrical concert film is grounded in a down-to-earth warmth and a nimble mimicry that bolsters even routine subject matter.

headline: Under Cover: Math Problems
text: Elizabeth Green’s cover story this week about the difficulties of teaching math in American schools was illustrated by Andrew B. Myers, a Brooklyn-based photographer. We went to him, according to Clinton Cargill, a photo editor at the magazine, because he’s ‘‘a strong conceptual thinker, and his pictures have a colorful, playful palette.’’ Recently we put a few questions to Myers about his work.

headline: In Rescue Deal, K.K.R. Provides Financing to Troubled Sand Maker
text: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Friday that it would provide $680 million of financing to Preferred Sands, a company that had been on the verge of bankruptcy.

headline: A Vortex of Samba, Funk, Hip-Hop and Vivid Hues
text: Watching dance at Lincoln Center’s Damrosch Park Bandshell is tricky. While performers look like ants from faraway, if you sit too close, feet have a way of disappearing. Obviously, this is a real hitch. Go for the ants.

headline: Youngsters Who Excel at Robotics and Drollery
text: Amazon broke into original children’s programming in May with “Tumble Leaf,” an animated show for preschoolers that was interesting visually but mind-numbing if you weren’t a preschooler. On Friday, the online service posted seven episodes of its first live-action children’s show, “Annedroids,” aimed at slightly older viewers (4 to 9) and explicitly tied to the so-called Steam curriculum (science, technology, engineering, arts, math). And surprise: despite the educational associations and the preteenage target audience, “Annedroids” is entertaining and amusing, a show that won’t drive an adult crazy. It’s almost worth watching without a 4-to-9-year-old for company.

headline: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely
text: Sarah Patterson, a 27-year-old nurse, suffered four miscarriages over the last four years because of several medical problems, including a condition that causes cysts to form on the ovaries. After her second loss, she said, her husband asked for a divorce because he could not handle the stress.

headline: Fastidious Belgian Detective Bows Out
text: You could almost set your clock by it, if you still had to set a clock. In the final five 90-minute episodes of “Agatha Christie’s Poirot,” the denouement — the long scene in which the dapper Belgian detective Hercule Poirot explains it all to his puzzled audience, including us — arrives reliably somewhere between 22 and 17 minutes from the end. We have reached our destination, intact and on time.

headline: Choosing to Shiver or Not to Shiver
text: The big brains at Discovery Communications apparently enjoy messing with our heads as we search for vicarious relief from the summer heat. One of their channels, Animal Planet, begins a reality show on Sunday that extols the rugged virtues of life in the remote frozen north. Meanwhile another channel, TLC, serves up a series about young people who want nothing more than to get out of there.

headline: Chevrolet Impala’s Air Bags the Subject of New Safety Inquiry
text: Federal auto safety regulators, continuing their scrutiny of air bags, have opened an inquiry into the failure of passenger air bags in General Motors’ 2008 Chevrolet Impala sedan.

headline: Clapper Tells Lawmakers Congressional Computer Activity Won’t Be Monitored
text: Clapper tells Congress that intelligence agencies hunting for officials who make unauthorized disclosures of classified information will not monitor legislative computer systems.

headline: A Cozy Screening, Before It Explodes
text: “Are we on Ludlow between Houston and Stanton?” Maggie Gyllenhaal asked.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Fresh Focus on Siberian Permafrost as Hole Count Rises
text: I had a Skype chat Wednesday about Siberian permafrost in the context of climate change with Marina Leibman, a top Russian permafrost expert who had just returned from examining the unusual crater spotted on the Yamal Peninsula in Siberia late last week.

headline: Classic Italian, With Atmosphere
text: There has been no shortage of Italian restaurants in New Canaan, but Barolo Trattoria and Wine Bar, which opened in February, is a worthy addition.

headline: Under the Tracks, a Kiosk With a Bronx Beat
text: Jazz and mambo flowed along a stretch of the Bronx in the 1940s and for years after. Lined with nightclubs, theaters and catering halls, Southern Boulevard was a musician’s playground.

headline: Watching the River Flow
text: Like the other restaurants operated by the Fort Pond Bay Company — Harvest on Fort Pond and East by Northeast in Montauk, and Half Moon in Dobbs Ferry — Harvest on Hudson, in Hastings-on-Hudson, sits on a waterfront with million-dollar views.

headline: A Syrian Rebel’s Improvised Battery
text: A rebel in Syria, Maj. Abu Al-Baraa, seems to have made significant steps toward developing an improved battery that could put many more shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles into use.

headline: Bill to Legalize Unlocking Cellphones Passes Congress
text: Soon, you will no longer be breaking the law if you unlock your cellphone.

headline: Political Divisions Threaten Kerry-Brokered Agreement in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The political agreement between Afghanistan’s two rival presidential candidates brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry two weeks ago appeared in trouble on Friday as serious differences emerged between the camps.

headline: Grocer Is Open to Buyers’ Bids Amid Turmoil
text: BOSTON — After an extraordinary outpouring by angry employees, the board of directors of the Market Basket supermarket chain said Friday that it would consider offers to buy the chain, including one from the ousted president, Arthur T. Demoulas.

headline: A Proposal for Nonpartisan Primaries
text: To the Editor:

headline: How ... Are ... You ... Feeling ... Today?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Singer Blends Her Devotion to Jazz and the Baha’i Faith
text: One Sunday morning this summer, 10 hours or so after her nightclub gig had ended, Tierney Sutton settled into a molded plastic chair on a small, bare stage. She wore reading glasses and no makeup, a departure from her nocturnal elegance as a jazz singer. Even from a six-time Grammy nominee, this particular spotlight called for humility.

headline: Two Perspectives on Subprime Auto Loans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Plight of Iraqi Christians
text: To the Editor:

headline: Militants Said to Kill Scores at a Syrian Base
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria killed dozens of Syrian government soldiers in an attack on an army base, a Syrian activist group said on Friday.

headline: Solar Industry Is Rebalanced by U.S. Pressure on China
text: Even as regulators continue to wrestle with the protracted trade conflict with China over solar panels, the case has already started to reshape the industry, lifting manufacturers based outside China while also raising prices of panels for developers.

headline: Hotel in Manhattan Ordered to Halt Sale of Time Shares After Buyers Complain
text: The state attorney general moved on Friday to stop the sale of time shares in a Midtown Manhattan hotel after buyers complained of being misled and of having trouble reserving rooms they thought they had paid for.

headline: Why the Border Crisis Is a Myth
text: EL PASO — TO hear the national news media tell the story, you would think my city, El Paso, and others along the Texas-Mexico border were being overrun by children — tens of thousands of them, some with their mothers, arriving from Central America in recent months, exploiting an immigration loophole to avoid deportation and putting a fatal strain on border state resources.

headline: Shootings Redefine Beat of School Police Officers
text: LA QUINTA, Calif. — Once, perhaps unfairly, they fit a Mayberry image. School-based police officers were seen as friendly if a bit over-the-hill, a touch out of shape and counting the days to retirement as they watched children head from the lunchroom to recess. If anything serious happened, they were to lock the building and wait for help.

headline: Sorted Food, a Cooking Channel, Is a YouTube Hit
text: LONDON — When Jamie Spafford, a 27-year-old Briton, passed through airport passport control during a visit to New York a few months ago, the immigration agent seemed skeptical about Mr. Spafford’s stated occupation.

headline: Before Signing, Big Stars Seek a Prize Beyond Fortune and Glory
text: After weeks of excitement, rumor and surprise, the N.B.A. free-agency frenzy has cooled. The two-week window around the beginning of July when most transactions occur is a special time for the players, a majority of whom did not have a say in which team drafted them or where they could be traded. Free agency is when players have almost complete control over where they will play and live, and for what price.

headline: The U.S. Keeps Trying in Gaza; Russia Says, Who Me?
text: THE debate over whether the United States is or should be the global cop is a hardy perennial around the world. But as Israel and Hamas slugged it out in Gaza for the third time in six years, there was America, once again desperately trying to pry them apart.

headline: Hold the Regret? Fast Food Seeks Virtuous Side
text: The numbers were startling: Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill shot up 12 percent on Tuesday after the company reported a nearly 26 percent spurt in its quarterly profit. For the fast-food industry, this was fresh evidence that the world of Big Macs and Doritos Locos Tacos has room for a menu with healthier-than-average food and higher-than-average prices.

headline: In Scarred Chinese Tibetan City, Devotion to Sanctity of Life
text: YUSHU, China — With a set of chopsticks in her hands and a Tibetan prayer spilling from her lips, Gelazomo, a 32-year-old yak herder, hunched over the rocky banks of the river that cuts through this city and hunted for the quarry that she hoped would bring salvation.

headline: Driven | 2015 Hyundai Genesis 3.8
text: Hyundai builds an ultimate road trip machine.

headline: Web Use to Be Unmonitored for Congress
text: WASHINGTON — The executive branch will not eavesdrop on the computer keystrokes and Internet use of members of Congress and legislative staff members with security clearances as part of its stepped-up efforts to prevent unauthorized disclosures of classified information, the nation’s top intelligence official told lawmakers on Friday.

headline: To Save Gaza, Destroy Hamas
text: TEL AVIV — AFTER nearly three weeks of fighting — notwithstanding the 12-hour pause announced early this morning by Israel — it is time to revisit some basic assumptions about Hamas. Until now, Israel assumed Hamas was the “devil we know,” capable of attacks that were mostly a nuisance; accepting its rule over the Gaza Strip was preferable to risking a vacuum of governance like what we see in Somalia and Libya. But Hamas’s reckless violence in the current round of fighting severely undermined this thinking.

headline: How to Control Student Loan Defaults
text: New federal rules that penalize colleges for excessive student loan defaults offer a powerful incentive for schools to educate students on the complexities of the federal student loan program, including the crucial fact that they can delay or make partial payments if they get into financial trouble. Keeping loan default rates low, a new study of nine community colleges shows, is not rocket science: Schools can do it.

headline: New Job Law Misses the Mark
text: The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, recently passed by large bipartisan majorities in Congress and signed into law this week by President Obama, makes overdue reforms to a Clinton-era job-training law. It emphasizes partnerships that bring together government officials, union representatives and employers to identify and provide training for current and future job openings. These have proved successful in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and elsewhere.

headline: Move to Center Divides G.O.P. in North Carolina
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The objective of the Republican Party here last year was clear: Unleash the pent-up conservative revolution in a state where the party had not controlled the state legislature and governor’s office for more than a century.

headline: Israel’s Outspoken Envoy Is Wise to U.S. Ways
text: WASHINGTON — As an undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania, Ron Dermer reluctantly accepted an assignment to argue that Israel should be condemned for its treatment of Palestinians.

headline: Orchestra Faults Met Chief’s Record as a Lockout Looms
text: Facing a potential lockout that could halt work at the Metropolitan Opera when its labor contracts expire next week, representatives of the company’s orchestra sat down with the administration on Friday for their first across-the-table negotiating session since February.

headline: For Cano, a Soft Landing in Seattle
text: SEATTLE — Where’s the defector? Homesick and crying into his organic tea and sashimi?

headline: Broken Windows, Broken Lives
text: How terrible it would be if Eric Garner died for a theory, for the idea that aggressive police enforcement against minor offenders (he was a seller of loose, untaxed cigarettes) is the way to a safer, more orderly city. Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William Bratton responded swiftly after Mr. Garner was fatally assaulted by officers on Staten Island. They reached out to his family, promising to retrain every officer about the rules against using chokeholds. Two officers have been put on desk duty pending investigations.

headline: Ex-Obama Aide’s Statements in 2012 Clash With Health Act Stance
text: WASHINGTON — A former adviser to the Obama administration on health policy made public statements in 2012 that undercut arguments it is now making in court about the government’s authority to subsidize insurance premiums.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 25, 2014
Chamber of Commerce Lost Its Way in Right Turn
text: Twice a year, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce convenes what it calls its Committee of 100 — which is composed of heads of regional chambers and Washington trade associations. They hear about the business climate from the chamber’s longtime president, Thomas J. Donohue, and about the political landscape from Bruce Josten, its chief lobbyist.

headline: Junkyards Feel the Sting of a Visit From a Copper Cable Guy
text: One answer to a question that has vexed transit police officers — where exactly do copper thieves sell their stolen cable? — arrived last month in the form of a dirty, shambling man pushing a shopping cart into a busy scrap yard in Queens.

headline: Plagiarism Scandal Tests a Senator Still Forming a Rapport With Montanans
text: BUTTE, Mont. — Montanans are not quick to get riled up over politics. Here in this historic copper and silver mining town, the big news this week is the kickoff of Evel Knievel Days — the annual summer festival featuring flying motorcycles and other stunts that recall the famed daredevil, Butte’s native son.

headline: A Ukrainian Rebel Commander Veers Off-Script
text: Speaking to Reuters this week about the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, a commander of separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine seemed to veer off script, suggesting that pro-Russia militants in the area, who have denied any involvement, were equipped with a sophisticated antiaircraft missile system and might have fired at the passenger jet by mistake.

headline: Rescuing Creatures for Good Karma
text: Buddhist devotees in Yushu, China, rescue tiny river fish from riverbanks as an expression of the Buddhist reverence for all forms of life and as a gesture to help in their next life.

headline: Ex-Chief of C.I.A. Shapes Response to Detention Report
text: WASHINGTON — Just after the Senate Intelligence Committee voted in April to declassify hundreds of pages of a withering report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s detention and interrogation program, C.I.A. Director John O. Brennan convened a meeting of the men who had played a role overseeing the program in its seven-year history.

headline: Pennsylvania: Carjacker Kills 3 Children
text: Three children died and three women were seriously injured after carjackers lost control of an S.U.V. and plowed across a busy street corner on Friday morning in north Philadelphia, the police said. The victims were brothers ages 7 and 10 and their 15-year-old sister, who were selling fruit for a church fund-raiser. According to the police, the vehicle struck the siblings as they stood at Allegheny and Germantown Avenues with their 43-year-old mother and a 65-year-old woman, who were in critical condition on Friday. The vehicle’s owner, a 45-year-old woman, was also in critical condition. The suspects had forced her into the back seat of her vehicle at gunpoint before the crash, the police said. The suspects, whom the police described as two armed men in their 20s, fled and remained at large on Friday.

headline: Kerry Urges Dialogue in Gaza Conflict
text: In Cairo, Secretary of State John Kerry called for for a seven-day humanitarian cease-fire between Israel and Hamas for the Muslim Eid al-Fitr holiday next week.

headline: Bringing Forth Fruit
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — When last we saw Julian Lim back in February, he opened with the fairly saucy KAMA SUTRA, clued brilliantly as “Position papers?” This time around, Mr. Lim GETS REAL with us, and we are all the better for it. This is mostly a terrific puzzle.

headline: Drowned Boy, 3, Climbed Fence to Get Into a Pool
text: Edward Harris loved his plastic wading pool.

headline: Brewers Fans Forgive as Braun’s Bat Heats Up
text: MILWAUKEE — As the slider Ryan Braun had just crushed landed several rows up in the left-field bleachers, a horde of fans scurried to find the ball. The rest of the crowd roared, and fireworks boomed overhead.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Focusing on Halo, an Anticomics Crusader and ‘The Maze Runner’
text: SAN DIEGO — A stealth-designed warship, its flag flying and sailors lining the deck, slipped through the waters behind the San Diego Convention Center on Friday morning, in full view of the hundreds who were queued up for a discussion of the Halo video game at the Comic-Con International fan convention.

headline: At the Met, 8 Food Carts Stake Sidewalk Claims
text: The curious new exhibit that opened Monday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, cordoned off with barricades, has received 24-hour police protection and drawn no shortage of controversy.

headline: Disturbed Items at Flight 17 Site Add to Growing Reports of Tampering
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — European monitors on Friday indicated for the first time that credit and debit cards belonging to people who died on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine had been moved inappropriately, though it was unclear whether anybody had tried to use them.

headline: Car-Hailing Service, Lyft, Reaches Deal to Operate in New York City
text: Two weeks after delaying its New York City debut amid legal concerns, a car-hailing company that relies on drivers’ private vehicles reached an agreement with city and state officials on Friday.

headline: Gene I. Maeroff, Education Reporter and Author, Dies at 75
text: Gene I. Maeroff, a former education reporter for The New York Times and an author on education issues who found a second career working in the field as a researcher and an adviser, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: The Faces Keep Changing, but the Yankees Just Keep Winning
text: A new face shows up in the Yankees’ clubhouse seemingly every day. The acquisitions have arrived so quickly and unexpectedly that the clubhouse attendants have hardly had time to keep up.

headline: Peering Into Darkness Beneath the Israel-Gaza Border
text: Through a watermelon field, about a mile from Kibbutz Nir Am in Israel, and less than half a mile from the Gaza border, there is a hole in the ground that plunges more than 40 feet into a tunnel that an Israeli officer described as “big enough for a man in full body armor to go through standing up.”

headline: A Syrian Rebel Advance Off the Battlefield: A Longer-Lasting Battery for Missiles
text: Rebels in Syria are designing rechargeable batteries for shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles, a development that could make them more lethal against Syrian warplanes but that also carries potential risks to civilian aircraft, according to a rebel behind the new design and to Western analysts who have assessed his work.

headline: E.U. Seeks Quick Approval for Russian Sanctions
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union accelerated its efforts on Friday to enact a tougher sanctions policy against Russia, including considering steps that would hit broad sectors of the Russian economy.

headline: Mets Stun the Brewers With a Burst in the Ninth
text: MILWAUKEE — Lucas Duda did not take the first pitch he saw in the ninth inning Friday night. One of the most patient Mets, he had been working on being more aggressive earlier in counts. He was the cleanup hitter, after all.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 26, 2014
text: “We want to be the place where the vegan can come for the portobello burger with almond-milk cheese, with the Neanderthal friend who just wants a really good cheeseburger.”

headline: Corrections: July 26, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Epix) THE HUNGER GAMES: CATCHING FIRE (2013) A camera-ready Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence, above) and Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) embark on their victory tour of the Panem districts as the Capitol prepares for the 75th games in this franchise’s second installment, directed by Francis Lawrence from the books by Suzanne Collins. But the champions aren’t safe yet: this new round of games pits past winners against one another in an ultimate death match. Donald Sutherland returns as President Snow, the target in Katniss’s sights; Liam Hemsworth is one of her love interests, Gale Hawthorne; Woody Harrelson is Haymitch Abernathy, the only living Hunger Games victor from District 12; and Elizabeth Banks is Effie Trinket, the tributes’ escort. “ ‘Catching Fire’ isn’t a great work of art but it’s a competent, at times exciting movie and it does something that better, more artistically notable movies often fail to do: It speaks to its moment in time,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Boys (and men) are still boys, of course, including in movies, but the very existence of Katniss — who fights her own battles, and kisses and leaves the boys, only sometimes to save them — suggests cultural consumers are ready for change, even if most cultural producers remain foolishly stuck in the past. It’s unlikely Katniss will lead the real revolution the movies need, but a woman can dream.” The original “Hunger Games” (2012) leads in at 6:30.

headline: Hamas Rockets Strike Israeli Bedouins
text: Many Bedouins in the Negev desert have no protection from rockets fired by Palestinian militants in Gaza, because Israel does not recognize their villages and refuses to build them bomb shelters.

headline: Analytics: Can’t Forget the Motor City!
text: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 27 issue of the magazine.

headline: Pause in the Fighting Gives Civilians on Both Sides a Moment to Take Stock
text: JERUSALEM — When a temporary cease-fire began on Saturday morning, Akram Qassim joined the throngs of Palestinians who emerged from their homes and temporary shelters. But when he reached his extended family’s three-story building, he found only a crater left by an Israeli airstrike.

headline: When Digital Art Is Suitable for Framing
text: Jake Levine, an entrepreneur in New York, likes the kind of art that tends to be popular on the Internet — cleverly Photoshopped pictures, and animated images like GIFs — and wanted a way to get it off his computer and onto a wall, alongside more traditional works like photographs and paintings. But how do you hang pixels on a wall?

headline: David Kenny of the Weather Company: Move Fast, but Know Where You’re Going
text: This interview with  David Kenny, C.E.O. of the Weather Company, parent of the Weather Channel and Weather Underground, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, July 27
text: “These are just phenomenal numbers.”

headline: Heads or Tails? Either Way, You Might Beat a Stock Picker
text: Imagine a world where investors in the stock market have no skill whatsoever. The investors themselves don’t understand this, however, and many truly believe that they are good at what they do.

headline: Steering His Own Schedule
text: Lucas M. Evans, 27, drives a car in Los Angeles for Uber, the ride-sharing service, while pursuing a career as a film producer.

headline: The Typical Household, Now Worth a Third Less
text: Economic inequality in the United States has been receiving a lot of attention. But it’s not merely an issue of the rich getting richer. The typical American household has been getting poorer, too.

headline: Hold the Phone: A Big-Data Conundrum
text: One advantage of being a professor is that you can ramble about your eccentric theories to a captive audience. For example, I often grumble to my graduate students that every time a new iPhone comes out, my existing iPhone seems to slow down. How convenient, I might think: Wouldn’t many business owners love to make their old product less useful whenever they released a newer one? When you sell the device and control the operating system, that’s an option.

headline: A World View of Inequality
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Strategies to Spare the Trees
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Private Equity’s Free Pass
text: For thousands of hobbyists, the local Michaels Stores outlet is a must-stop shop for scrapbooks, dried flowers, crochet hooks, sewing notions and dozens of other do-it-yourself paraphernalia.

headline: Differences in the Dorm
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: That Step Ahead
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: If Marriage Moves Beyond Our Means
text: Two professors of family law, June Carbone and Naomi Cahn, have written a crisp and cogent account — rich with detail and utterly free of legalese — of America’s failure to invest in its children.

headline: What’s In It | Coconut Water
text: When coconut water hit the market, it was billed as a miracle drink able to fight viruses and other ailments. The drink’s marketers have since been legally forced to sharply scale back their claims.

headline: Coconut Water Changes Its Claims
text: When coconut water broke into the American market 10 years ago, it was billed as a miracle drink able to fight viruses, kidney disease and other ailments like osteoporosis. Global sales now reach $400 million a year, and many consumers believe that the beverage has a wide variety of health benefits. But they may be unaware that the drink’s marketers have sharply scaled back their claims.

headline: For Coconut Waters, a Street Fight for Shelf Space
text: Like kale salads and Robin Thicke, coconut water seems to have jumped from invisible to unavoidable without a pause in the realm of the vaguely familiar.

headline: Pentagon Plan Would Help Ukraine Target Rebel Missiles
text: The Pentagon and American intelligence agencies are developing plans that would enable the Obama administration to provide specific locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them for destruction, American officials said.

headline: Now Serving Comfortable and Casual
text: Luxury hotels usually have formal restaurants to match their elegant ambience, but some high-end properties are creating more relaxed and casual dining options for their guests.

headline: Variety: A Grate Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Hear we have another fine acrostic by Emily Cocks and Henry Rathvon, witch, if ewe are paying attention, will remind ewe of the importance of knot allowing yore SPELL-CHECKER two take over completely four yore own cents of correct spelling. I no I don’t. Because that wood bee unprofessional.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: North Carolina’s Misunderstood Cut in Jobless Benefits
text: Since North Carolina effectively eliminated unemployment benefits last year for people unemployed 20 weeks or more, the state has become a symbol in the partisan wars over economic policy. People on either side of those wars have argued that it proves the economic advantages — or damage — of providing the long-term jobless with cash payments.

headline: On State Unemployment Rates, It’s Analyst Beware
text: In an Upshot article for this week’s Sunday Review section, I analyzed the data on employment growth in North Carolina versus South Carolina and argued that there was no evidence that making the long-term unemployed inegible for unemployment benefits, as North Carolina did, spurred more jobs there.

headline: Facing Escalating Violence, U.S. Evacuates Staff From Its Embassy in Libya
text: CAIRO — The United States closed its embassy in Libya on Saturday and evacuated the embassy’s staff under military guard, in what the State Department said was a response to escalating violence in the Libyan capital, Tripoli.

headline: Baseball Hall of Fame Reduces Window for Election to 10 Years from 15
text: Since 1962, candidates for election to the Baseball Hall of Fame have had 15 years of eligibility, as long as they received at least 5 percent of the vote totals by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America each year. But on Saturday, the Hall changed the process, reducing the period of eligibility to 10 years.

headline: Effort to Secure Malaysia Airline Crash Site Falters in Eastern Ukraine
text: KHARKIV, Ukraine — An international push to secure the crash site of a Malaysian passenger jet shot down by a missile over eastern Ukraine stalled on Saturday, with the leader of a Dutch forensic mission announcing that scores of foreign police officers and experts gathered at a luxury hotel here would not start moving toward the site for at least five days.

headline: 1964: Hong Kong, A Tourist Paradise
text: HONG KONG — The wealthy British Crown colony of Hong Kong, checkered with emerald hills, sky-blue bays, and modern architecture, is a tropical tourists’ paradise of sunning, swimming, and spending.

headline: Amid Outcry Abroad, a Wealth of Backing in Israel for Netanyahu
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is stuck between mounting international outcry over civilian casualties from his assault on the Gaza Strip and intensifying calls at home to finish the job he started.

headline: Women as Athletes, Not Accessories, at Least for a Day
text: Female cyclists will race at the Tour de France on Sunday for the first time in 25 years, but anyone who thinks women haven’t been key participants in the sport’s top race obviously hasn’t been watching.

headline: Budding Author and Inventor Emerges Quickly in Giants’ Backfield
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The rookie running back Andre Williams arrived at the Giants’ training camp with a reputation for a bruising rushing style and a workhorse mentality.

headline: Royals Approach Their Destiny in Fits and Starts
text: The Kansas City Royals had one winning record in a stretch of 18 seasons, from 1995 to 2012. It came in 2003, when they were 83-79, and Raul Ibanez was their regular left fielder. Now, after his release from the Los Angeles Angels, he is back as a reserve.

headline: Revered Essays on the Game Lead to a Hall of Fame Honor
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — In 1980, Roger Angell wrote a revealing portrait of Bob Gibson that is one of his most admired baseball articles for The New Yorker. Gibson was in his fifth season of retirement, and Angell thought that people might have begun to forget what a fierce and marvelous pitcher, and competitor, he was. Angell believes Gibson opened up to him to help his chances at being elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, which happened in his first year of eligibility.

headline: Bound by Bridge, 2 Baghdad Enclaves Drift Far Apart
text: BAGHDAD — Al Imams Bridge spans the Tigris River between two of the oldest communities in Baghdad — one Sunni, the other Shiite — and on Ramadan evenings it can seem as if the mosques near either bank are calling to each other as their muezzins sing prayers.

headline: Moore of the Same
text: A few months ago the buzz was that the Heritage Foundation was getting serious after a series of blatant errors and ludicrously biased “research”. The supposed evidence for this turn was the hiring of Stephen Moore from the Wall Street Journal to become chief economist. I was, shall we say, unimpressed.

headline: As Technology Makes Bicycles Lighter and Faster, It’s the Cyclists Falling Harder
text: PÉRIGUEUX, France — In terms of technology, Greg LeMond, the three-time Tour de France winner, was a pioneer. In an age when steel still dominated, LeMond rode bikes made of carbon-fiber composites, then an exotic material mostly used by the military.

headline: Why the Beach Is a Bummer
text: IT is summer, and so, we are repeatedly reminded, it is time for the beach — beach bodies, beach reads, fruity beach drinks in tall glasses festooned with tiny paper umbrellas and fruits skewered on tiny plastic swords. This is an ideal beach of hot sun, warm sand, crystal-clear water that leaves your skin salted. But it is all too often a mirage.

headline: Africa’s Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Rulings on Affirmative Action
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Individual Genius
In Labor, in Chains
text: EARLY one morning in November 2011, Tina Tinen, a pregnant prisoner at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester County, N.Y., woke with painful contractions. Guards called an ambulance to take her to the hospital and, according to her account, shackled her wrist to the bar of a gurney — despite a 2009 state law against shackling pregnant inmates during and after labor.

headline: What Is News?
text: FORT-DAUPHIN, Madagascar — WITH the world going crazy, I tried running away from the news. It didn’t work.

headline: Up From Greenwich
text: WHEN Barack Obama won the White House in 2008, he did so in an unusual way for a Democrat: As the candidate of the rich. He raised more in large-dollar donations than any of his rivals and raked in more cash from Wall Street than John McCain. In November, he won the upper class’s votes: By 52 percent to 46 percent, according to exit polls, Americans making more than $200,000 cast their ballots for Obama.

headline: Why the U.N. Can’t Solve the World’s Problems
text: UNITED NATIONS

headline: The Wrong Approach to Breast Cancer
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — ONE of the nastier aspects of breast cancer is that it doesn’t have the five-year sell-by date of some other malignancies: you’re not considered “cured” until you die of something else. Although it becomes less likely, the disease can come back eight, 10, even 20 years after treatment. I fell on the wrong side of those odds.

headline: When Thrill Rides Are Real Risks
text: EARLIER this month, nearly two dozen people were stranded midair for hours after a fallen tree branch partly derailed a roller-coaster ride at the Six Flags Magic Mountain amusement park in Valencia, Calif. Last summer, a woman was killed at Six Flags Over Texas in Arlington after she fell out of the Texas Giant roller coaster. That same day, a boat on Cedar Point’s Shoot the Rapids water ride in Sandusky, Ohio rolled backward and flipped over injuring at least six people.

headline: Angell in the Outfield
text: ROGER ANGELL takes off his brown J. Press sports coat and blue cap, yanks out his hearing aids, stashes his cane, and sits down for a shave and haircut at Delta barbershop at 72nd and Lex., the same spot he’s patronized for 40 years. “I don’t see Henry Kissinger doing any interviews in a barbershop,” he says dryly.

headline: Andres Amador
text: Andres Amador is an artist who uses the beach as his canvas and a rake as his brush. His sand designs have been commissioned for corporate advertisements as well as countless marriage proposals.

headline: The New Instability
text: OVER the past 40 years, the geography of family life has been destabilized by two powerful forces pulling in opposite directions and occasionally scraping against each other, much like tectonic plates. One is the striking progress toward equality between men and women. The other is the equally striking growth of socioeconomic inequality and insecurity.

headline: Where Reason Ends and Faith Begins
text: STANFORD, Calif. — NOT long ago, I was at an event in which many people, most of them professors, were arguing for the existence of things that many of their colleagues did not believe in. Someone gave a talk in which he explained that he knew that U.F.O.s existed even though all the best evidence for them turned out to be false. Others spoke sympathetically about shamanic healing, reincarnation and near-death visions. But then a woman described her research on what it was like to be dead, which she had based on reports from mediums who claimed to have had the dead speak through them. She cited, as evidence of the benevolence in the afterlife, an Anglican priest, Msgr. Robert Hugh Benson, who wrote a book attacking spiritualism while alive but who, she said, recanted the book after his death in 1914. The group stared at her in disbelief. This, they felt, was flabby-minded.

headline: The World’s Coolest Places
text: TRAVEL season is here, when so many Americans decamp to Cape Cod or the Jersey Shore. All of which is wonderful, and some day I plan to do a 10-part series on the world’s best beaches.

headline: Jets Add Tight End With Insights
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Jace Amaro has received a text message from his father, Bob, every morning for the last several years. The Good Words of the Day, Bob calls it. Sometimes it contains a Bible verse, sometimes an inspirational quotation from someone like Winston Churchill or Muhammad Ali.

headline: A Carter for Governor, Again
text: President Jimmy Carter’s grandson, State Senator Jason Carter, is following in his grandfather’s footsteps by running for governor of Georgia. But his family name is a blessing and curse there.

headline: Grandson Proudly Squirms in Carter’s Footsteps
text: PLAINS, Ga. — Like many candidates, Jason Carter, the Democratic nominee for governor in Georgia, is courting the Jewish vote. But when Mr. Carter, a state senator, declared his “powerful connection” to Israel, it was more than a campaign sound bite.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 27
text: A cease-fire on Saturday between Israel and Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza, allowed families to take stock of the damage of intense violence in the Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will discuss the pause in fighting on “Fox News Sunday” and NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Sought in Vegas, a Swindler Is Dealt a Losing Hand Far From Home
text: BETHLEHEM, PA. — He could have browsed the volumes at the Moravian Book Shop, or dined al fresco at the historic Hotel Bethlehem. But the out-of-towner was looking to take a chance, so he headed instead to the Sands Casino, a glittery, jittery place rising from the old Bethlehem Steel stacks along the Lehigh River.

headline: Nibali Goes Into Finale With Time on His Side
text: PÉRIGUEUX, France — Vincenzo Nibali, who had won four stages of this year’s Tour de France, did not add its first and last time trial to his list on Saturday. The win went to Tony Martin, a German who is the current world champion in racing against the clock.

headline: Echoes of Past Battles on Immigration Ring Through Current Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Up in arms about being forced to provide emergency housing for a flood of immigrants entering the country illegally, voters turned to the ballot box to punish elected officials they faulted for failing to resolve the crisis. The backlash was swift, costing Bill Clinton his 1980 bid for a second term as Arkansas governor in the aftermath of the boatlift from Mariel, Cuba.

headline: Martin R. Hoffmann, Army Secretary in 1970s, Dies at 82
text: Martin R. Hoffmann, a former secretary of the Army who in the 1970s presided during a cheating scandal at West Point and helped usher in the all-volunteer Army, died on July 14 at a hospital in Warrenton, Va. He was 82.

headline: Augie Rodriguez, 86, Half of a Mambo Team, Dies
text: Augie Rodriguez, half of Augie and Margo, the husband-and-wife team who at midcentury helped turn mambo from a sultry social dance into a dazzling public entertainment, died on July 18 in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Carlo Bergonzi, 90, an Operatic Tenor of Subtlety and Emotional Acuity, Dies
text: Carlo Bergonzi, one of the 20th century’s most distinguished operatic tenors, renowned for the refined interpretive taste and keen musical intelligence he brought to his art, died on Friday in Milan. He was 90.

headline: BuzzFeed Politics Writer Is Fired Over Plagiarism
text: The website BuzzFeed dismissed one of its writers on Friday after finding 41 instances of “sentences or phrases copied word for word from other sites” among the 500 stories he had written, said the site’s editor in chief, Ben Smith.

headline: Family Calls for Federal Inquiry in a New York Chokehold Case
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton on Saturday said that he and the family of a New York man who died this month shortly after a confrontation with the police had asked federal prosecutors to investigate the death as a civil rights violation.

headline: Yankees’ Defensive Lapses Help Blue Jays End 17-Game Bronx Skid
text: The Yankees have been able to survive a glut of injuries largely by shifting players around the field, often to unfamiliar positions. When Mark Teixeira strained a back muscle early last week, Manager Joe Girardi put catcher Brian McCann at first base even though he had never played the position in his professional career before this season. Entering the year, McCann had not played first in a game since a travel team tournament in high school.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Disney’s ‘Phineas and Ferb’ to Broadcast Tribute to ABC’s ‘Lost’
text: SAN DIEGO – Calling all “Lost” fans: Damon Lindelof, one of the creative forces behind that late, great ABC castaways drama, has written a special “Lost”-themed episode of the Disney Channel’s animated “Phineas and Ferb.”

headline: Let States Decide on Marijuana
text: In 1970, at the height of his white-hot war on crime, President Richard Nixon demanded that Congress pass the Controlled Substances Act to crack down on drug abuse. During the debate, Senator Thomas Dodd of Connecticut held up a package wrapped in light-green paper that he said contained $3,000 worth of marijuana. This substance, he said, caused such “dreadful hallucinations” in an Army sergeant in Vietnam that he called down a mortar strike on his own troops. A few minutes later, the Senate unanimously passed the bill.

headline: The Public Lightens Up About Weed
text: When Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992, he admitted that he had “experimented with marijuana,” but said he “didn’t like it,” “didn’t inhale it” and “never tried it again.” Whatever the accuracy of that statement, he was accused of pandering to the marijuana-wary voting public.

headline: The New York Times Calls for Marijuana Legalization
text: The federal government should follow the growing movement in the states and repeal the ban on marijuana for both medical and recreational use.

headline: Race in Toyland: A Nonwhite Doll Crosses Over
text: Jade Goss, age 2, looks as if she just stepped out of the wildly popular “Doc McStuffins” cartoon.

headline: What’s My Line?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I had an epiphany while I was munching the BLT I needed to make myself after starting Randolph Ross’s puzzle. I’m heavily influenced by what I see in a crossword puzzle.

headline: The Empty Spaces Left Behind by Malaysia Airlines Crash
text: Across the Netherlands, there are empty houses, empty offices and empty seats belonging to the 194 Dutch nationals who died when Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down.

headline: Taliban Making Military Gains in Afghanistan
text: MAHMUD RAQI, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters are scoring early gains in several strategic areas near the capital this summer, inflicting heavy casualties and casting new doubt on the ability of Afghan forces to contain the insurgency as the United States moves to complete its withdrawal of combat troops, according to Afghan officials and local elders.

headline: ‘Rule Followers’ Flock to a Convention Where Fake Violence Reigns
text: SAN DIEGO — Bursts of machine-gun noise sputtered in a hall where prop assault weapons, slightly used by professional killers in “The Expendables 3,” were for sale. The Suicide Girls, a tribe of tattooed models, were promoting the film “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For.” Among the panel discussions: “101 Ways to Kill a Man.”

headline: Frank Thomas, Noted Slugger, Times Two
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — “You don’t look like Frank Thomas,” the fan said to Frank Thomas, an 85-year-old signing autographs on Main Street.

headline: In the Fields Where Flight 17 Fell
text: Sabrina Tavernise recounts the night of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 disaster in the grass and wheat fields near Grabovo, Ukraine. The beautiful field where it came to rest is quiet now.

headline: Think It’s Hot in Texas? Austin Knows Better (Get Used to 110)
text: At the end of the century, Austin’s average summertime high temperature could be six degrees above today’s average high of 97 degrees. And it may be hotter than 110 degrees in the city more than 20 days a year; even one day that hot is a rarity now.

headline: Candidates Dip Their Toes in Summer Advertising Pool
text: Texans heading to the movies to see “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” might be surprised to see Attorney General Greg Abbott, the Republican candidate for governor, pop up on the screen. Seated in a crowded theater, a smiling Mr. Abbott speaks directly to a camera to his left, while those around him stare straight ahead as if watching a film and oblivious to Mr. Abbott’s pitch.

headline: Texas Gets Love Letter in ‘Boyhood’
text: “Boyhood,” the film shot over 12 years with the same actors, which opened recently in Texas, begins in what the director, Richard Linklater, describes as a “mythical little childhood home that you dream about the rest of your life.”

headline: With Taliban’s Revival, Dread Returns to Swat Valley
text: SWAT VALLEY, Pakistan — As battle rages in North Waziristan, where the Pakistani military says it has killed more than 500 militants, unfinished business from the army’s first major assault on the Taliban lingers painfully in the Swat Valley, at the other end of Pakistan’s Pashtun belt.

headline: In the Fields Where Flight 17 Fell
text: Sabrina Tavernise recounts the night of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 disaster in the grass and wheat fields near Grabovo, Ukraine. The beautiful field where it came to rest is quiet now.

headline: On What Makes One a Reporter in a Digital Age
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: In Ferry Deaths, a South Korean Tycoon’s Downfall
text: SEOUL, South Korea — After all the lavish galas in his honor at landmarks like the Louvre and Versailles, the tens of thousands of devotees following his religious teachings for decades, the hundreds of homes and businesses reportedly stashed around the globe, Yoo Byung-eun ended up alone, his body splayed on its back and rotting in the weeds, empty liquor bottles by his side.

headline: Some Background on Our ‘High Time’ Series
text: The decision to call for the end of marijuana prohibition was long in the making.

headline: Tournament Wins Point to Youth’s Strength
text: Performances at three elite tournaments that ended last week show how much players in their early to mid-20s are now dominating the chess world.

headline: Israel Extends Cease-Fire in Gaza, a U.N. Request Rejected by Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — Under intense diplomatic pressure, Israeli leaders decided late Saturday to extend a halt to hostilities in the Gaza Strip through midnight Sunday, but said their troops would maintain defensive positions and continue to ferret out tunnels from Gaza into Israeli territory.

headline: Woman Fatally Struck After Refusing a Ride, the Police Say
text: A 21-year-old Long Island woman who chose to walk home instead of drive with a friend she thought was drunk was killed on Saturday morning after the friend ran into her, the police said.

headline: Weapons Rule at Comic-Con
text: Attendees of Comic-Con International bring an assortment of “weapons” to the convention hall that are screened by security officers.

headline: In Search for Killer, DNA Sweep Exposes Intimate Family Secrets in Italy
text: ROME — The body of Yara Gambirasio, a 13-year-old student, was found on a chilly day in a quiet northern city in Lombardy in February 2011, three months after she was reported missing following a gymnastics practice. The autopsy showed she had been beaten but not sexually abused, stabbed several times and left to die in a field less than 10 miles from her home.

headline: Blemished Club’s Playoff Bid Relies on a Mound Makeover
text: The Yankees tied a club record Saturday, but they do it so often now that it was easy to miss. Chris Capuano became their 28th pitcher this season when he started against Toronto in the Bronx. The Yankees have never sent more pitchers to the mound in one season, but they have landed on 28 three other times: in 2005, 2007 and 2011.

headline: Blinkers Help a Colt Surge at Saratoga After Earlier Flops
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The Jim Dandy Stakes is the unofficial start of horse racing’s second season for 3-year-olds. The race is an opportunity for the colts who distinguished themselves during the Triple Crown races to build on their accomplishments, and it gives those who disappointed on the big stage a chance to hit the reset button.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 26, 2014
One Bad Inning by Niese Is Too Many for the Mets to Overcome
text: MILWAUKEE — At one point during the fifth inning Saturday, the Mets’ Jon Niese clapped his glove in frustration and tapped his chest, as if to acknowledge that their current predicament was his fault.

headline: Emily Sherwood, Kenneth Ehrler
text: Emily Ann Sherwood and Kenneth Russell Ehrler were married Saturday at Blessed Sacrament Church in West Brighton, Staten Island. The Rev. Joseph V. Arenas, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Sarah Kurz, Edward Barker Jr.

text: Jonathan Andrew Damon and Oswaldo Alberto Luciano are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Castle Hotel and Spa in Tarrytown, N.Y. Stuart B. Chernoff, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, is to officiate.

text: Yonitte Ryger and Jay Benjamin Bikoff are to be married Sunday afternoon at the amphitheater in Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, Conn. Rabbi James E. Ponet, the Jewish chaplain at Yale, is to officiate.

headline: Stephanie Chin-Sang and Matthew Marchant

headline: Margaret Lacey, Brett Allen
text: Margaret Moran Lacey and Brett Phillip Allen were married Saturday at the Woodstock Inn & Resort in Woodstock, Vt. The event was led by Michael Matos, a longtime friend of the groom, who received a one-day license from the state of Vermont to officiate.

headline: Kailee McDonald, George Balagia Jr.
text: Kailee Ann McDonald and George Terence Balagia Jr. were married Saturday at St. Joseph Cathedral in Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Jordan Lenaghan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Leanne Bellar, Seth Gordon
text: Leanne Mary Esther Bellar and Seth Daniel Gordon were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Daniel Weiner at the Four Seasons Hotel in Seattle.

text: Arianne Duskin Kailas and Ross Harris Stern were married Saturday evening at Falkirk Estate and Country Club in Central Valley, N.Y. The officiant was E. Leo Milonas, a cousin of the bride and the retired chief administrative judge of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in New York.

headline: Hayley Cooper, Tyler Schapiro
text: Hayley Beth Cooper, a daughter of Randy Coles Cooper and Stephen A. Cooper of New York, was married Saturday night to Tyler Scott Schapiro, a son of Sue Cohen Schapiro and Michael S. Schapiro of Vestal, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Botton officiated at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

headline: When a Yellow Card Meant ‘Call Me’
text: Tanya Eleni Kalivas and Martha Eran West were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck, N.Y. The Rev. Richard McKeon Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Brittany Breen and Michael Rugarber
text: Brittany Ann Breen, the daughter of Kristine A. Breen and David A. Breen of Yardley, Pa., was married Saturday afternoon to Lt. Michael Thomas Rugarber, a son of Mary E. Rugarber and Paul D. Rugarber of Haddon Heights, N.J. The Rev. Jonathan Dalin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Mary’s Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Carolyn Amole and Ali Simpson
text: Carolyn Davis Amole and Alexandra Hope Simpson were married Saturday in Roxbury, N.Y. The Rev. Diane L. Epstein, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Roxbury Barn, an events site.

text: Alicia Danielle Nance and Dr. Ian Thomas McNeill are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Sanctuary at the Haven, an event space in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. James F. Reese, a Presbyterian minister and the groom’s maternal grandfather, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Anthony Migura, Blair Boone
text: Dr. Anthony Michael Migura and J. Adam Blair Boone were married Saturday night aboard the Aqua Azul yacht on the Hudson River in New York. The officiant was John E. Long, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

headline: Lauren Jones, Marley Watkins
text: Lauren Ashley Jones and Marley James Donald Watkins were married Saturday evening at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. The Rev. John E. Denaro, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Clelia Castro-Malaspina, Michael Gore
text: Clelia Castro-Malaspina and Michael Jordan Gore were married Saturday evening at the Manor House at Pleasant Beach on Bainbridge Island, Wash. Tony Joseph, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Alexandra Levin and Reese May
text: Alexandra Kathryn Levin and Reese Cooper May were married Saturday at the Portland Company, an event space in Portland, Me. R. Gerard McGeary, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Erin Foley and Melvin Chan
text: Erin Rose Foley and Melvin J. Chan were married Saturday evening at the Sheraton LaGuardia East in Flushing, Queens. Lance Brunner, the uncle of the bride and a Buddhist priest, officiated.

headline: Ashley Eyre, Addison West
text: Ashley Hudson Eyre and Addison Randall West were married Saturday at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, N.Y. Howard L. West III, a Presbyterian minister and the groom’s half brother, officiated.
