text: Sally Noelle Davis, the daughter of Lois A. Davis and Dr. Joseph E. Davis of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Gregory Alexander Wasserman, a son of Dr. Herbert Wasserman of Brooklyn and the late Rusty Degenshein Wasserman. Rabbi Matthew V. Soffer officiated at the Boston College Club in Boston.

headline: Meredith Wholley, Kevin Michel
text: Meredith Anne Wholley and Kevin David Michel were married Saturday in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Christopher Collins performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Patrick, a Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Candice Ginsberg, Jonathan Pueschel
text: Candice Shayna Ginsberg and Jonathan Bruce Pueschel were married Saturday evening at the Rhino Garden at the Bronx Zoo. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated.

headline: George Hutter, Eugene Gumbert
text: Dr. George Edward Hutter and Eugene Aaron Gumbert were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Mark R. Collins, interim pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Bizia Greene, Clinton Huling
text: Bizia Catal Holmes Greene and Clinton Henri Huling are to be married Sunday. Judge Helen M. Toor of the Vermont Superior Court is to officiate at Shelburne Farms, an inn and events space in Shelburne, Vt.

headline: Jacqueline de Armas, Marco De León
text: Jacqueline Diana de Armas and Marco Issac De León were married Saturday. The Rev. Joseph Shea performed the ceremony at the Mission San Fernando Rey de España, a Roman Catholic church in Los Angeles.

headline: Maryam Toloui, Jeffrey Zelinski
text: Maryam Toloui, a daughter of Farahnaz Mazandarani and Saed Toloui, both of El Cerrito, Calif., was married Saturday to Jeffrey Allan Zelinski, the son of Cecilia A. Zelinski and Gerald T. Zelinski, both of St. Clair Shores, Mich. Ariana Bennett, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, with the bride’s mother, also a Universal Life minister, taking part in a ceremony that incorporated Persian wedding traditions.

headline: Confident of a ‘Yes’ and a Red Sox Win
text: Emily Pauline Niemi, the daughter of Karen Coburn Niemi and T. William Niemi of Peabody, Mass., was married Friday evening to Thomas Arthur Holden, the son of Martha Healey Holden and Charles E. Holden, also of Peabody. Melanie B. Voros, a New Hampshire justice of the peace, who received a one-day solemnization certificate for the occasion, officiated at Ipswich Country Club in Ipswich, Mass.

headline: Two Killed in Crash in New Jersey
text: A car and a pickup truck collided on the Garden State Parkway on Saturday, killing two women and injuring six other people, the New Jersey State Police said.

headline: Corrections: July 27, 2014
text: SPORTS

headline: Israel Says Its Forces Did Not Kill Palestinians Sheltering at U.N. School
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas went back and forth on Sunday over proposals for a new cease-fire in the fighting in the Gaza Strip, and Israel sought to bolster its claim that its forces were not responsible for the deaths of 16 Palestinians reportedly killed in an attack on a United Nations school.

headline: Assessing the Damage and Destruction in Gaza
text: Analysis of satellite imagery taken before and after the first two and a half weeks of the Israeli incursion.

headline: Sticks and Stones, and a Diagnosis in Words That Can’t Hurt Us
text: To reach my eldest daughter at her elementary school, we have to walk down our street, turn on what Google Maps refers to as “Unknown Road,” cross a bridge over a shallow stream and follow an asphalt path around to the bright red doors of the school. All in all, it’s a seven-minute walk, but with my 3-year-old in tow it can take twice the time.

headline: Troops Move on Crash Site in Ukraine, Foiling Deal
text: ZUHRES, Ukraine — Just hours after the Malaysian government reached an agreement with Ukrainian separatists on Sunday over access to the crash site of a Malaysian airliner shot down in rebel territory, the Ukrainian military launched an operation to recapture the debris fields, again stalling international efforts to secure the site.

headline: 1914: German Emperor Backed Austria
text: BERLIN — All Austrian reservists living in Germany have been summoned to join the colors from today [July 27], and all leave of German officers and soldiers has been stopped. According to a despatch from Vienna, one of the highest personages in Germany — whom, I learn, is none other than the Emperor — is said to have written personally to Herr von Tschirschky und Bogendorff, the German Ambassador in Vienna, telling him to stiffen the back of Count Berchtold, who at that time was all for conciliation with Servia. The result was that the Austro-Hungarian Foreign Minister entirely changed his attitude and prepared the drastic ultimatum to Belgrade.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (WGN America) MANH(A)TTAN John Benjamin Hickey and Ashley Zukerman portray the scientists at the center of the race to create an atomic bomb, and Olivia Williams (above, with Mr. Hickey) and Rachel Brosnahan are their smarty-pants wives, in this fictionalized but fact-based accounting set in Los Alamos, N.M., “766 days before Hiroshima,” as the show puts it. “The atom bomb didn’t just end the war, it forever changed the peace,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Richard Rhodes, the author of ‘The Making of the Atom Bomb,’ quotes Herbert S. Marks, general counsel of the Atomic Energy Commission, who said the Manhattan Project was a state unto itself that had ‘a peculiar sovereignty, one that could bring about the end, peacefully or violently, of all other sovereignties.’ ‘Manh(a)ttan’ provides a cleverly imagined portrait of the men and women who were at the epicenter of that peculiar sovereignty.”

headline: Republicans’ Senate Chances Rise Slightly to 60 Percent
text: For the last month, we’ve been adding one or two polls a day to The Upshot’s Senate forecasting model. Today, we update all 36 races, based on estimates from a YouGov online panel that covers every congressional and governor’s race across the country.

headline: Explaining Online Panels and the 2014 Midterms
text: A deluge of cheap partisan polls has swamped a shrinking number of high-quality, nonpartisan surveys, making it hard to know who is really ahead in many political campaigns. The solution? More nonpartisan surveys.

headline: Man Dressed as Spider-Man Is Arrested After Scuffle With Police in Times Square
text: Spider-Man punched a police officer in the face in Times Square over the weekend, the police said, in the latest episode of children-friendly characters displaying R-rated behavior in front of stunned tourists in the heart of Manhattan.

headline: What ‘The Leftovers’ Says About Climate Change
text: The new HBO series “The Leftovers” is about what happens after 2 percent of humanity simply vanishes from the earth (this is not really a spoiler; however, some follow). This event has obvious religious connotations, which the show explores. But the story may have secular implications, too: The way the characters reckon with their new, bizarre circumstances has something in common with how some are responding to the threat of climate change.

headline: In Coney Island, Weaving a Confection That Tastes Like Long-Ago Summers
text: Every New Yorker has a favorite summertime treat. As a girl, mine was cotton candy, that wondrous melt-in-your-mouth confection that vanishes when it touches your tongue. For me, it still brings to mind bumper cars and roller coaster rides, street festivals and jelly-sandaled strolls.

headline: Your Own Choices for Coolest Places on Earth
text: It’s summer. So my Sunday column is a bit unusual and offers some  travel advice: The “coolest places on Earth,” as I see them. I’m sure some of you disagree with my choices, so post your thoughts below—and include your own recommendations for off-the-beaten path choices for others to take up.

headline: Scarlett Johansson Powers ‘Lucy’ to No. 1 at Box Office
text: Scarlett Johansson punched out “Hercules” at the weekend box office. Her new science-fiction thriller, “Lucy,” was No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in an estimated $44 million and proving that her name on the marquee (and pouty picture on the poster) could anchor a wide-release movie. “Lucy,” which Universal Pictures marketed squarely on Ms. Johansson’s shoulders, cost about $40 million to make and was directed by Luc Besson. The film performed particularly well in theaters with screens marketed as Premium Large Format, which charge higher prices.

headline: Vows | Game for the Name
text: With no clear convention for choosing a last name for their family once they got married, Martha West and Tanya Kalivas decided to battle it out on the soccer field.

headline: Italy’s Vincenzo Nibali Wins the 2014 Tour de France
text: PARIS — Vincenzo Nibali emerged Sunday as the first Italian winner of the Tour de France in 16 years after a race defined by inclement weather and painful eliminations of other favorites.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': A Pitiless Storm, Then the Show Goes On
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses and performs “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: 1939: Britain Set to Deport all Suspects in I.R.A. Blasts
text: LONDON — As the sequel to yesterday’s fatal bomb explosions staged by Irish terrorists at two London railroad stations, the British government was reported tonight [July 27] to be planning mass deportations during the week end of hundreds of suspected members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. It was understood that a warship would be sent on Saturday to Fishguard or Holyhead, the two principal Welsh ports on the Irish Sea, to await batches of Irish men, and women, who will be rounded up for expulsion as soon as the government obtains its unprecedented police powers of search and arrest under the prevention of violence bill, drafted specifically to smash the I.R.A. The measure, rushed through the House of Commons in record time last night, was given a hasty first reading by the House of Lords today. Earl Stanhope, First Lord of the Admiralty and leader of the Upper House, said the government wanted the bill passed by the Peers tomorrow, rather than wait until Monday. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 28, 1939

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Painting the Town Red
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Thierry Henry may or may not play in Major League Soccer beyond this season. That he could probably carry on, if he so desires, until he is 40 (he is now 36) is probably not the point.

headline: Woman Who Helped Start French Cycling Race Ends It With a Win
text: PARIS — Marianne Vos, who already had no shortage of victories to her name, won the inaugural edition of a race whose riders preceded the men of the Tour de France down the Champs-Élysées on Sunday.

headline: At Front Lines, Bearing Witness in Real Time
text: My social media feed has taken a bloody turn in the last few weeks, and I’m hardly alone. Along with the usual Twitter wisecracking and comments on incremental news, I have seen bodies scattered across fields and hospitals in Ukraine and Gaza. I have read posts from reporters who felt threatened, horrified and revolted.

headline: After Losing Province in 2010, Afghan Taliban Strike Back
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A sudden Taliban offensive in the southern province of Kandahar in recent days has led to some of the heaviest protracted fighting there in years, officials said on Sunday. The militants overran a district center on the border with Pakistan, battled government forces near the provincial capital and staged a suicide-bomber attack on a home of the province’s powerful security chief.

headline: Rough Ride for the F-35
text: The F-35 fighter jet was expected to be exhibited at an international air show a few weeks ago — a chance for America to showcase its state-of-the-art war plane, the world’s most expensive weapons project. But, in an embarrassing turn of events, the star-crossed, single-engine F-35 was a no-show.

headline: Legacy Tarnished by His Own Words
text: A Gallup poll in 2010 assessing the nine presidents from John F. Kennedy to George W. Bush put Richard M. Nixon last with a 29 percent approval rating. In a Quinnipiac University survey at the beginning of July, however, Barack Obama had replaced Nixon as the worst president since World War II: 33 percent assigned that unwanted distinction to President Obama; only 13 percent thought Nixon was that bad.

headline: Chasing a Chivalrous Bandit
text: The Hindi movie “Kick” takes pains to assure us that Devi Lal Singh, its antihero hero, is “amazing” and has “impeccable charisma.” Good to know. Otherwise you might think that Devi (Salman Khan), who shakes things up for the fun of it — to feel a “kick” — was another bad-boy narcissist who can’t grow up or keep a job.

headline: Winning Ways at the Spingold Knockout Teams
text: LAS VEGAS — The 64-board final of the Spingold Knockout Teams yesterday was between Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Richard Schwartz, Allan Graves, Boye Brogeland, Espen Lindqvist, Lotan Fisher and Ron Schwartz.

headline: Amid the Destruction, Aftershocks of an Emotional Magnitude
text: During the three years Qi Zhao spent filming “Fallen City,” he captured his subject — the town of Beichuan, wiped out in the 2008 Sichuan earthquake, two-thirds of its people killed and 80 percent of its buildings destroyed — as it slowly disappeared. In time-lapse images, fields of rubble become fields of grass. Part of the old city is turned into an earthquake museum, with railings installed in front of piles of shattered concrete.

headline: Steal by Bautista Helps Blue Jays Overcome Three Yankees Rallies
text: In the race for the playoffs, even a seemingly inconsequential mistake can be the difference between a postseason appearance and a lost season. Should the Yankees narrowly miss a berth this season, closer David Robertson might regret ignoring Jose Bautista at first base in the ninth inning of Sunday’s 5-4 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: An Intricate Combination of Music and Movement
text: Catching the entire performance of Pam Tanowitz Dance at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday took more than the usual effort. After listening to a smart, vibrant set of contemporary music by the sextet Eighth Blackbird in the Damrosch Park Bandshell, I hurried to the opposite end of the plaza to watch the unannounced beginning of Ms. Tanowitz’s contribution. There, engrossed by the dancer Lindsey Jones’s rendering of Ms. Tanowitz’s witty steps, I nearly failed to rush back to my seat in time for the main portion of the show.

headline: Sloshing in Symphonic Waters
text: The 81 musicians and singers who were about to give the premiere of “Sila: The Breath of the World,” an alluring, mystical new work by the American composer John Luther Adams conceived for performance outdoors in Lincoln Center’s Hearst Plaza, began to take their assigned places early on Friday evening. It was quite a procession.

headline: Melodrama, as in Mellow
text: How much good and evil can you take in a night? Watching “Spartacus,” Yuri Grigorovich’s ponderous three-act ballet, is a like being trapped inside a pinball machine and bounced among four protagonists. One team features the noble, valiant Spartacus and the innocently virtuous Phrygia. On the other are the sadistic Crassus and the conniving Aegina.

headline: Sure, You Loved Lucy, but Vintage Has Limits
text: Maybe you’re one of those irritating people prone to complaining, “Why can’t they make shows as good as [name of a vintage TV series] anymore?”

headline: Theater’s New Funding Model
text: Jamie Hendry turned to crowdfunding from small investors to produce “The Wind In the Willows” and in the process also created a new line of communication with his audience.

headline: An Israel Without Illusions
text: JERUSALEM —  Israelis and Palestinians are imprisoned in what seems increasingly like a hermetically sealed bubble. Over the years, inside this bubble, each side has evolved sophisticated justifications for every act it commits.

headline: Adding Fiction to the Fray
text: The fourth episode of “The Honorable Woman,” a serialized thriller that makes its Sundance TV debut on Thursday, opens on a world-weary MI6 officer, sitting at a dinner party where two other guests are discussing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. As the camera zooms in on the officer, the conversation can be heard degenerating into a vulgar, name-calling argument and then a silverware-rattling wrestling match.

headline: Smell of the Greasepaint, the Funds of the Crowd
text: LONDON — As an up-and-coming theater producer, Jamie Hendry didn’t have many investors when he started raising money for a musical based on the children’s novel “The Wind in the Willows.”

headline: Joko Widodo Is Elected President of Indonesia
text: And he has work to do.

headline: A Revolutionary Who Cannot Be Silenced
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — In the opening scene of “Dr. Sun Yat-sen,” a dramatically assured and lyrical new opera in Mandarin by the Chinese-born American composer Huang Ruo that was given its American premiere here on Saturday by Santa Fe Opera, a group of well-to-do citizens in prerevolutionary Shanghai reflects on the state of the country under the Qing dynasty. Turning to face the audience, the chorus sings:

headline: In Every Note, Passion That Needs No Translation
text: It’s the quaver that makes the Ethiopian singer Mahmoud Ahmed’s voice so arresting. He seizes on a note, brief or sustained, and makes its pitch tremble as if its urgency could barely be contained. It’s a show of controlled intensity, and in the course of a song, it happens again and again, making each phrase leap out anew: with sorrow, with anticipation, with a plea. That quaver is coupled with emphatic rhythm and grainy determination in a voice that Ethiopians in and out of the country have prized since the 1970s. Mr. Ahmed’s 1975 album, “Ere Mela Mela,” helped introduce Ethiopian pop to a wider world, and in the 1990s, reissues of his recordings as part of Buda Musique’s “Ethiopiques” series brought him further international attention.

headline: Classical Music Group
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes it’s good to take a macro view of things. If you focus too much on details, you can lose perspective on what’s important. Like family. Family is important.

headline: Fast Talking and a Toast to Desire
text: “Strictly Dishonorable,” the 1929 Preston Sturges comedy revived by the Attic Theater, is an old-fashioned kind of show. You can tell right from its first scene when the speakeasy proprietor, Tomaso (Christopher Tocco), sprinkles bitters onto a sugar cube before adding whiskey, ice and a cherry. Just try and leave this charmer without a fondness for Sturges and a craving for a strong cocktail.

headline: A Pianist and Pedagogue, Saluting a Pair of Giants
text: Those who attended the exhibition “Vienna’s Musical Giants” at the Rose Museum of Carnegie Hall this spring were present, so to speak, at the creation of Brahms’s wonderful Variations on a Theme by Haydn. One invaluable artifact on display was Brahms’s scribbled transcription of the “St. Anthony Chorale” from a divertimento for winds that he and others believed to be the work of Haydn.

headline: Chocolate Factory Announces Season
text: The Chocolate Factory Theater in Long Island City, Queens, will feature nine commissioned United States premieres and two first-time collaborations with other New York City arts institutions in its 2014-15 season, the theater’s organizers have announced. The performances are to begin with Marissa Perel’s return to the Chocolate Factory for the first time since the theater’s debut season in 2005. She will present “More Than Just a Piece of Sky,” a work based on the 1983 movie “Yentl” starring Barbra Streisand. The performances, Sept. 17 through 20, also represents the theater’s first partnership with the annual Queer New York International Arts Festival. Other season highlights include “Rude World,” a duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, in January as part of the Coil festival. And in April, the Chocolate Factory will team up with Abrons Arts Center to present the Bessie award winner David Neumann’s “I Understand Everything Better,” a multidisciplinary work exploring the need to report on calamity and the results of a person’s proximity to death and trauma. Brian Rogers, the artistic director of the Chocolate Factory, said he hoped that a smaller schedule would better allow the theater to serve its artists. “This is our small attempt to value the work of the performers in a different way,” Mr. Rogers said recently by phone. More information is at chocolatefactory.org.

headline: DeGrom, a Key to the Mets’ Future, Is Taking Over the Present
text: MILWAUKEE — No matter how the final two months of the season unfold for the Mets, they will at least have the pleasure of following the progress of their rookie starter Jacob deGrom. The way this season has gone, he has come to represent hope for the future, although he already seems to be the one Met who still has a chance to win something this year: the National League Rookie of the Year award.

headline: It’s Justice and Earth in La MaMa Programs
text: Ecology and social justice will be the focus of La MaMa’s 2014-15 season, the theater’s organizers announced Sunday. With the theme “La MaMa Earth,” the theater’s 53rd season will be inspired by the impact of Hurricane Sandy on local communities, La MaMa’s artistic director, Mia Yoo, said in a statement. Among the highlights are three performances based on Shakespeare’s “The Tempest,” grouped under the collective title “Tempest 3: The Tide is Rising.” That series is to feature the world premiere of a musical adaptation of the play written by Karin Coonrod with music by Elizabeth Swados and starring Reg E. Cathey (“The Wire,” “House of Cards”), Oct. 2 through Nov. 2. Other season highlights include the world premiere of Catherine Filloux’s “Selma ’65,” based on the true story of Viola Liuzzo, a white woman who was killed by the Ku Klux Klan after participating in a civil-rights protest in Alabama (Sept. 25 through Oct. 12); performances by the Belarus Free Theater (April 23 through May 10); and a world premiere by the Venezuelan company Teatro Dramma International (March 5 through 15). More information is at lamama.org.

headline: New Cast Members for ‘Game of Thrones’
text: With the population of Westeros dwindling, HBO has announced that a crop of new characters will enter the fold in Season 5 of its hit drama “Game of Thrones.” The stage and screen veteran Jonathan Pryce and Keisha Castle-Hughes, a best actress Oscar nominee for the 2003 film “Whale Rider,” are among nine new cast members set to join “Thrones” in 2015. While Season 4 brought the demise of several main characters, the coming season will try to fill the void with the Martells of Dorne. Most of the new characters are relatives or associates of Oberyn Martell (Pedro Pascal), the playboy prince who met a particularly gruesome death while fighting on behalf of Tyrion Lannister (Peter Dinklage). Ms. Castle-Hughes is to portray Oberyn’s eldest bastard daughter, Obara Sand. She is to be joined by Alexander Siddig (“Star Trek: Deep Space Nine,” “Da Vinci’s Demons”) as Doran Martell, the ruler of Dorne and older brother of Oberyn, and Toby Sebastian as Doran’s son Trystane. New additions not of the Martell bloodline are to include Mr. Pryce as High Sparrow, a prominent figure in a religious order; Nell Tiger Free, who replaces Aimee Richardson as Myrcella Baratheon; and DeObia Oparei as Areo Hotah, captain of Doran’s guards. The series is expected to return in the spring.

But it is also known for showing little love toward historical and significant old buildings — the city too busy to remember — with no hesitation to tear them down.

headline: Adapting Old Laws to New Technologies
text: American law enforcement officials cannot get evidence located in other countries without the help of foreign governments. But can an American company be ordered by a court to turn over information stored on computer servers located in another country? The Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York will consider that question this week in a narcotics case in which federal prosecutors want access to a Microsoft email account stored in Ireland.

headline: Is Poetry Dead? Not if 45 Official Laureates Are Any Indication

headline: Peter Marler, Graphic Decoder of Birdsong, Dies at 86
text: The conventional wisdom among animal scientists in the 1950s was that birds were genetically programmed to sing, that monkeys made noise to vent their emotions, and that animal communication, in general, was less like human conversation than like a bodily function.

headline: Privacy and the Pool of Information
text: It’s been a while since we all became aware of what the National Security Administration has been up to. But as revelations of government breaches recede and the concerns of daily life resume, the public occasionally needs a reminder. A recent story in The Washington Post was exactly that. It laid out in detail what many had long suspected: that the N.S.A., in targeting foreign nationals, is collecting and storing extremely large amounts of information on many American citizens. This information is not restricted to metadata; it is content — photos, web chats, emails and the like. While United States law prevents targeting American citizens without a warrant (even if it is just a warrant from the secret FISA court) nothing currently prevents the N.S.A. from engaging in this “incidental collection” and no law prevents the agency — and other United States intelligence and law enforcement agencies — from accessing such content without a warrant into perpetuity.

headline: Can Reddit Grow Up?

headline: The Fight Over ‘Impeachment Lite’

headline: Corporate Artful Dodgers
text: In recent decisions, the conservative majority on the Supreme Court has made clear its view that corporations are people, with all the attendant rights. They are entitled to free speech, which in their case means spending lots of money to bend the political process to their ends. They are entitled to religious beliefs, including those that mean denying benefits to their workers. Up next, the right to bear arms?

headline: Karen Walter Goodwin, Producer of Broadway Hits, Dies at 66

Armed with a vibrant personality and keen intellect, she soon found herself in a circle of well-connected, literary-minded socialites, artists and prominent politicians, including the inveterate diarist George Templeton Strong. She was, he wrote, “certainly the most brilliant, cultivated, easy graceful, effective talker of womankind, and has read, thought, and observed much and well.”

All will soon bear the Equinox brand and feature the company’s classes and products.

And after he expanded his business to include surrogacy in India for Western couples grappling with infertility — and then in Thailand, and last year, Mexico — he increasingly took credit for the global spread of surrogacy.

Established in Shanghai in 2002, Spin carries a range of bespoke ceramic tableware designs (from $11 ebony chopsticks to a one-of-a-kind $3,200 vase) using traditional, handmade techniques from Jingdezhen, the capital of Chinese porcelain since the Ming Dynasty.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 8:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE QUIET AMERICAN (2002) Michael Caine in an Oscar-nominated role, stars as Thomas Fowler, a British journalist who flees a loveless marriage in England to live in Southeast Asia and report on the Vietnamese fight for independence from French colonial rule. There, he becomes infatuated with Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen, above, with Mr. Caine) in a relationship that can last only as long as he keeps his job. Then Alden Pyle (Brendan Fraser), an American intelligence officer, comes along. And he wants Phuong, too. “Fowler may be the richest character of Mr. Caine’s screen career,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about Phillip Noyce’s adaptation of the Graham Greene novel. “This great English actor gives a performance of astonishing understatement whose tone wavers delicately between irony and sadness.”

text: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | By many measures, the American economy is improving. But two of the nation’s big deep-discount retailers are betting that a merger will help them compete for the country’s poorest customers.

headline: Daily Report: Reddit Looks to Grow Up Without Selling Out
text: Since it was founded nine years ago, Reddit — a freewheeling online community with an antiquated design where users find, share and talk about web links and photos — has stuck to its own weird guns. You don’t need to hand over any personal data, not even an email address, to sign up and post or view an item. And unlike many other Internet start-ups, Mike Isaac reports, Reddit has never fully embraced the dominant business model of selling advertising to support its free service.

headline: Getting a Loan: Is There a Home Bank Advantage?
text: Our recent story about the changing landscape of small-business lending featured three owners in very different circumstances but with one interesting fact in common: When these owners needed loans, the bank with which they already had a relationship did not offer terms as attractive as those offered by competing institutions.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The Senate is about to begin debate on a bill that could, at long last, put an end to the indiscriminate bulk collection of Americans’ telephone records,” according to an editorial in The New York Times. The bill will “bring needed transparency to the abusive spying programs that have tarnished the nation’s reputation.” Introduced by Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the measure would require the government “to disclose how many people’s data was collected by intelligence agencies, and how many of those people were American.” Perhaps most important, the bill will “create a panel of advocates to argue before the court in support of privacy rights and civil liberties, and would require the court to issue public summaries of its decisions that specifically detail the impact on those rights.” It “represents a breakthrough in the struggle against the growth of government surveillance power.”

headline: China Exports High-Speed Rail Technology to Turkey
text: After having built the world’s most extensive high-speed rail network, China is now beginning to export its rail technology, starting with last week’s inauguration of a high-speed railway in Turkey that links the capital of Ankara to Istanbul, the country’s largest city.

headline: Virgin America Files for I.P.O.

headline: China Removes Crosses From Two More Churches in Crackdown
text: BEIJING — In another sign of the authorities’ efforts to contain one of China’s fastest-growing religions, a government demolition campaign against public symbols of the Christian faith has toppled crosses at two more churches in the coastal province of Zhejiang, according to residents there.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar Tree in Deal for Family Dollar
text: Dollar Tree agreed on Monday to buy Family Dollar Stores for about $8.5 billion in cash and stock, uniting two of North America’s biggest deep-discount retailers, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The deal comes amid pressure on Family Dollar by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who urged the company last month to explore a sale of itself.

headline: The Problem With 'Pay for Performance' in Medicine
text: “Pay for performance” is one of those slogans that seem to upset no one. To most people it’s a no-brainer that we should pay for quality and not quantity. We all know that paying doctors based on the amount of care they provide, as we do with a traditional fee-for-service setup, creates incentives for them to give more care. It leads to increased health care spending. Changing the payment structure to pay them for achieving goals instead should reduce wasteful spending.

headline: Israeli Leader Sees No Quick End to Gaza War
text: JERUSALEM — An informal lull between Israel and Hamas timed for the start of a Muslim holiday collapsed into deadly violence on Monday and Israel’s prime minister signaled no quick end to the three-week-old Gaza war, advising Israelis that “patience and determination” were needed.

headline: The Lessons Thus Far From the Transition to Digital Patient Records
text: Soon after the financial crisis hit, the Obama administration decided to toss into the economic stimulus package a carrot to accelerate the computerization of health care. Within the roughly $800 billion pump-priming project, the health technology initiative could be seen as a modest down payment on the future: about $20 billion in incentives spread over several years to encourage doctors and hospitals to move from paper records into the computer age. The Bush administration had championed the cause, and, seizing a crisis-created opportunity, the Obama administration put up the money.

headline: Zillow to Buy Trulia for $3.5 Billion in All-Stock Deal
text: Updated, 8:05 p.m. | For much of the last nine years, Zillow and Trulia have competed in the online real estate listings market they helped create.

headline: Lloyds Bank to Pay Over $380 Million to Resolve Rate Manipulation Inquiries
text: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | LONDON — The Lloyds Banking Group agreed on Monday to pay more than $380 million to British and United States authorities to resolve investigations into the manipulation of rates, including one used to determine fees paid by Lloyds for taxpayer-backed funding during the financial crisis.

headline: Building a Better College Ranking System. Wait, Babson Beats Harvard?
text: For a long time, U.S. News & World Report had a monopoly on the college rankings game. Every August, the magazine would announce that, once again, Harvard was America’s best college, or Princeton, or, to shake things up, a tie between Harvard and Princeton.
