headline: Raine Takes Stake in Jimmy Buffett’s Margaritaville
text: In its four years of existence, the Raine Group has kept plenty busy with media and telecommunications deals. But its latest investment will tie the firm to a company best known for promoting lazy, boozy afternoons on the beach.

headline: 1914: War Is Declared Upon Servia
text: The Austro-Hungarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs yesterday [July 28] issued the following statement: “The Servian Government not having replied in a satisfactory manner to the Note which was handed to it on July 23, 1914, by the Austro-Hungarian Minister, the Imperial and Royal Government finds itself obliged to take steps to safeguard its rights and interests. It considers itself from the present moment in a state of war with Servia.”

headline: A.C.L.U. and Human Rights Watch Say Surveillance Programs Hurt News Coverage
text: The Human Rights Watch and the American Civil Liberties Union have issued a sharp rebuke of large-scale surveillance programs carried out by the United States government, saying in a joint report that such practices are hindering journalists.

headline: Roasted Corn and Tomato Salsa
text: I’ve added corn to salsa fresca before, but this time, eyeing generous ears of corn on the cob in the market, I imagined it grilled or roasted in a roasted tomato salsa. I used as a starting point the renowned chef Rick Bayless’s terrific roasted jalapeño tomato salsa with fresh cilantro, from a book he published in 1998 called “Salsas That Cook.” After I had grilled the tomatoes and jalapeño under a broiler (you could also cook them on a grill), I grilled an ear of corn, also under a broiler. The kernels take on a beautiful color, and their sweetness contrasts nicely with the charred and picante flavors that run through this salsa. The corn also contributes crunch. The salsa is great with tacos, chips, and grains, and is particularly good with chicken.

headline: ScienceTake | Five-Legged Kangaroo?
text: When Australia’s signature mammal walks, its tail works like a fifth leg.

headline: For Kangaroos, Tail Becomes a Fifth Leg
text: The signature gait of kangaroos is a marvel. As they hop, they seem to float along almost effortlessly on their large, springy hind feet, tail stretched out behind for balance.

headline: Salsa Fresca with Kohlrabi
text: For the past month, I’ve been a guest on the New York Times’s Motherlode Blog, helping out Renee Ruder and her family in Bend, Ore., put more vegetarian meals on the table using produce they receive in their community-supported agriculture basket each week. She received kohlrabi one week and was at a loss as to what to do with it. I had some suggestions for ways to use the vegetable in main dishes, and now I’ve come up with a way to use it in a side. The kohlrabi has a crisp texture much like that of jicama, with a nice cruciferous flavor. This salsa fresca would be welcome with just about any tostada, nacho or taco, with chips, or as a condiment with fish or chicken.

headline: Grilled Mango Salsa
text: I love mango salsa whether or not the mango is grilled, so if you don’t feel like grilling, you can still get a great salsa with these ingredients. Grilling, whether on an outdoor grill, a griddle or a grill pan, deepens the flavor of an already-rich-tasting fruit. I love the contrasts in this salsa: the crisp jicama with the soft, juicy mango; the sweet fruit; the spicy chile; and the grassy cilantro. Serve with fish or chicken.

headline: Opinion May Pose Obstacle for Same-Sex Unions
text: WASHINGTON — Same-sex marriage has had a spectacular year in the courts, with an unbroken run of more than 25 victories. The decisions have become routine, almost monotonous.

headline: Pineapple Avocado Salsa
text: This is a sweet, fruity salsa, with a wonderful array of textures: juicy, sweet-acidic pineapple; soft, creamy and subtle avocado; and crisp and refreshing jicama, with everything set off by the heat of the chiles. The avocado gives a pale green cast to the mix. It looks beautiful with salmon and goes with just about any other fish, as well as with chicken or even fajitas.

headline: Fighting a No-Pets Eviction With Doctors’ Notes and a Federal Suit
text: Outside the brick behemoths of the East River Housing co-op on the Lower East Side is an inscription quoting Sidney Hillman, the labor leader who helped build these affordable homes for thousands of garment workers and others:

headline: Watermelon & Tomato Salsa
text: Watermelon is a refreshing ingredient to use in a salsa. I’ve combined it with tomatoes and jicama here, and the result is a fruity/vegetal salsa with a kick from chiles, lime and cilantro. Like the other fruit-based salsas I’m featuring this week, I like this with grilled fish, especially light-fleshed fish like halibut or mahi-mahi.

headline: With Microsoft in Sights, China Starts to Squeeze U.S. Tech Companies
text: BEIJING — China, once the hottest growth market for United States technology companies, is turning chillier.

headline: Inflation, Unemployment, Ignorance (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Jared Bernstein notes that we don’t seem to have a very good story about inflation and unemployment these days, and worries that this will lead to bad policy — in particular, to premature monetary tightening. I agree, and have a bit more to add.

headline: Paid Leave Encourages Female Employees to Stay
text: A mysterious fact that economists are wrestling with is that the percentage of women in the United States who are working or want to work has been declining, after a decades-long climb.

headline: Five to Follow | Tavi Gevinson’s Twitter, Camille Becerra’s Instagram and More
text: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: U.S. Coal Exports Eroding Domestic Greenhouse Gains
text: Updated below, 12:51 p.m. | A comprehensive and sobering Associated Press story by Dina Cappiello provides a valuable update on how United States policies promoting exports of coal are undercutting domestic efforts to restrict emissions of carbon dioxide, the heat-trapping gas released when fossil fuels are burned.

headline: Reaction to Yukos Court Decision
text: Tim Osborne, director of GML, the holding company created by the Yukos founder Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, spoke after an arbitration court ordered Russia to pay shareholders of Yukos $50 billion.

headline: A New Resource About Parkinson’s
text: Because more than a million Americans, most over 60, have Parkinson’s disease, and because a recent Harris Poll survey indicates that many of them don’t feel well-informed about treatments or the way the disease progresses, let me pass along a new website called Partners in Parkinson’s.

headline: Today in Small Business: Zico Versus Vita Coco
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Jonathan Chait and Cherry-Picking
text: A few weeks ago, New York Magazine’s Jonathan Chait wrote a post that cited the work of Reason Magazine’s Peter Suderman as an example of how libertarian and conservative journalists have spun a cocoon around their readers, making Obamacare’s doom seem perpetually inevitable even as the specifics of their doomsaying tell a story of its gradual success. “The message of every individual dispatch is a confident prediction of the hated enemy’s demise,” Chait wrote of Suderman’s writing, “yet the terms described in each, taken together, tell the story of retreat.”

headline: Pot Shots
text: “The federal government should repeal the ban on marijuana.”

headline: On Set With Melissa Clark
text: Melissa Clark takes viewers behind the scenes of her recipe videos as she bakes a peach slab pie.

headline: Probiotics May Reduce Blood Pressure
text: Consuming probiotics has a small but significant effect in lowering blood pressure, a large review of studies has found.

headline: Roderick Kimball’s Path Puzzles
text: See if you can weave your way through these original puzzles by the Flying Karamazov Brother Roderick Kimball.

headline: Masterworks vs. the Masses
text: PARIS — One cloudy afternoon this month, the line to enter the Louvre stretched around the entrance pyramid, across one long courtyard and into the next. Inside the museum, a crowd more than a dozen deep faced the Mona Lisa, most taking cellphone pictures and selfies. Near the “Winged Victory of Samothrace,” Jean-Michel Borda, visiting from Madrid, paused amid the crush. “It’s like the Métro early in the morning,” he said.

headline: NeueHouse Chooses Historic Hollywood Site
text: LOS ANGELES — NeueHouse, the stylish shared working space in New York’s Flatiron district which collects and exhibits contemporary art, has confirmed that it will be opening its second location, this one in Hollywood, in spring 2015. It has leased the historic CBS radio building and studio on Sunset Boulevard, built in 1938 by William Lescaze, a pioneer of the International Style.

headline: Whether ‘Sophisticated’ Clients of Wall Street Can Also Get Duped
text: It should not come as a surprise that some on Wall Street stretch the truth a little bit – and maybe even a lot – when peddling their wares.

headline: Park Hyatt Aims to Create Personal Luxuries Lists as Part of a New Campaign
text: Park Hyatt, the most upscale of the nine Hyatt brands, is running a new ad campaign featuring the personalized, individual luxuries it offers its guests.

headline: Icahn Gets a Speedy Return on His Family Dollar Investment
text: Updated, 1:23 p.m. | Carl C. Icahn often spends months or even years lobbying the companies in which he has invested. At Family Dollar Stores, he got what he wanted after just seven weeks.

headline: Lost a Fantasy Game? Try Again Tomorrow
text: BOSTON — As with many start-ups, the idea was born from trivia that suddenly did not seem so useless — the statistics of professional athletes.

headline: Gains Seen for Medicare, but Social Security Holds Steady
text: WASHINGTON — Medicare’s financial condition improved significantly in the last year, thanks in part to the Affordable Care Act, but the outlook for Social Security is basically unchanged, the Obama administration said Monday.

headline: German Group Sues to Block European Banking Union
text: FRANKFURT — A group of euro-skeptics that has opposed Germany’s participation in the currency said on Monday that it had filed a lawsuit to block a plan at the heart of efforts to prevent banking crises in Europe.

headline: Just as Dangerous as We Think
text: If the British comedy troupe Monty Python had been commissioned to produce a self-help book, they might have come up with something along the lines of “The Norm Chronicles,” a cheerfully subversive variation on the genre. The authors contemplate not inner peace but outer woe with an encyclopedic guide to life’s risks, among them health care catastrophes, sexually transmitted diseases, auto accidents, plane crashes, mountaineering fatalities, sudden unemployment and the chances that an asteroid will fall from the sky and squash you.

headline: Readers Respond to the Editorial Series on Marijuana
text: We knew from polling data that a majority of Americans, 54 percent, favored legalizing the use of marijuana. Now that we’ve begun publishing an editorial series arguing for an end to marijuana prohibition, we know that a majority of Times readers appear to favor legalization, too, and in far greater numbers than the population at large.

headline: 4 Years Later, Still No Answers in Killing of a Long Island Laborer
text: SHIRLEY, N.Y. — On a cool October night in 2010, two immigrant laborers went on a drinking spree in a stand of trees by the side of a road in this suburban hamlet on Long Island. Beer flowed. So did tequila. By the following afternoon, one of the men was dead, his body lying in the woods. The other was in a hospital bed, badly hurt, with a bladder injury and deep cuts in and around his rectum.

headline: The Things Traders Say, Lloyds Edition
text: By now, DealBook readers know the drill: A major bank reaches a settlement with United States and British authorities over accusations that its employees conspired to manipulate the benchmark rates known as the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, and transcripts of incriminating conversations among traders and rate setters are released. What emerges are often aggressive and vulgar exchanges, at times in a London argot. It can sound like something from a Martin Amis novel or a Guy Ritchie movie.

headline: The ‘Battle Rhythm’ of Helping to Build a Democracy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan – Here come the helicopters again. Blackhawks, flying out of the Kabul night, the gunner hanging out the side, scanning the city from behind the sights of an M-240B automatic rifle. The blades thunder their rhythm throughout the compound, too loud to talk over. They land quickly, spill out their passengers and a few bags, and leave. This isn’t the place to linger.

headline: Faking Death to Survive Another Day
text: Q. Can a fly play dead?

headline: Filipino Rebels Kill 21 Villagers Over Peace Deal
text: MANILA — Muslim rebels in the southern Philippines opened fire on a group of about 50 people who were on their way to a religious celebration on Monday, killing at least 21 and wounding 13, military officials said. The dead included a 2-year-old boy.

headline: Walkabout: Ukraine Air Space Reroutes to Hike Prices
text: Dangerous, and Costly, Skies This month’s air disaster in Ukraine will be costing travelers, and not just to that specific region. Airlines are preparing to hike fares to cover the cost of rerouting hundreds of flights around conflict-ridden Ukrainian airspace. (Skift)

headline: Online Tool for Young Bankers Raises $1 Million in Funding
text: Wall Street firms have been talking about improving the working conditions for junior bankers in recent months. Now, a start-up created by two former financial analysts may help make lower-level employees’ lives a little more bearable.

headline: New Generic Ballot Surveys Don’t Show Signs of Republican Wave
text: One of the big questions of this election cycle is whether it will turn out to be a “wave” election, like the one in 2010, when an upswell of anti-Democratic sentiment carried Democrats out of the House. One of the best measures of whether there’s a wave is the “generic ballot” question. Pollsters ask: Do you want Democrats or Republicans to control Congress?

headline: The Prospect of Other Bidders for Family Dollar
text: As the market opened on Monday, stock in Family Dollar soared on news of an $8 billion deal between the discount retailer and its rival Dollar Tree.

headline: Defiant, Cuomo Denies Interfering With Ethics Commission
text: BUFFALO — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday delivered a feisty and unrepentant defense of his handling of an anticorruption panel he created and then abruptly shut down, after five days in seclusion during which he encountered some of the harshest criticism he has faced as governor.

headline: “Secret Garden” by Sway Clarke
text: A song by the Canadian singer-songwriter.

headline: A Robot Takes a Swim
text: PoseiDrone, a robot whose body was inspired by the bodies of octopus and squid, navigates a rocky underwater world.

headline: Italian Opera Company Experiments With Google Glass
text: ROME – The country that gave the world opera is looking to bring it into the 21st century this week when the cast and crew of a company in Cagliari, Sardinia, will don the wearable technology known as Google Glass to help broadcast a performance of Puccini’s “Turandot” to a worldwide audience.

headline: 3 Officers Are Shot in Greenwich Village; Fugitive Is Killed
text: A man wanted on child molestation charges in California who was working in a Greenwich Village smoke shop shot and wounded two federal marshals and a New York City police detective on Monday afternoon before they fired back, killing him, the police said.

headline: A Tentacled, Flexible Breakthrough
text: LIVORNO, Italy — For years, roboticists have yearned to develop a flexible machine that can explore tight spaces, repair dangerous equipment and potentially even conform to the human body.

headline: Weekly Quandary: Emotional and Practical Advice for Sending a Child to College
text: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: In Latest Concert Problem, Dozens Felled by Alcohol at Keith Urban Show
text: Alcohol was largely to blame for more than 40 people being treated for medical emergencies and another 50 being taken into police custody at a Keith Urban concert outside of Boston on Saturday night, local officials said. About 18,000 people were in attendance at the Australian country singer’s show at Xfinity Center in Mansfield, Mass., about 25 miles south of Boston. Reuters reported that fire and emergency medical crews from six communities were called in.

headline: You Can Buy a Business on EBay!
text: One of my favorite things about writing for this blog is that I get to have interesting conversations with people about things I’ve never considered. Take buying a business on eBay. Never in a thousand years would I have guessed that this was possible.

headline: 1926: Marijuana ‘Is Reported Safe’
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Jeff Gordon Wins a Fifth Race at Indy
text: Jeff Gordon played a late-race restart perfectly and parlayed it into victory Sunday in the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. It was his fifth victory in Nascar’s only annual visit to the famed Brickyard, and the first time a Nascar driver has won five races there.

headline: Using the ‘Public’ Network Option
text: Q. I’ve recently moved to a hotel complex that offers free Wi-Fi to residents, guests and health club members who use its facilities. The network password is known to all who come in the door. How secure is my computer if I choose the “Public Network” setting in Windows 7?

headline: It’s Time to Push Back When Government Controls the Message
text: Rick Santorum was talking — but not quite without interruption. In a 2005 interview with Mark Leibovich, then of the Washington Post and now of the New York Times, the Republican senator from Pennsylvania was describing how he felt at the funeral of Pope John Paul II.

headline: Why Dollar Tree-Family Dollar Deal May Spark a Bidding War
text: Discount retailer

headline: When Competition Obscures Financial Goals
text: Years ago, a friend with an incredibly successful career as a sales representative shared a story about what she and her brother called their W-2 Derby. It’s exactly what it sounds like. At the end of each year, they’d pull out their W-2s and compare who had the higher income. There were even rules for what really counted as income, and there was a prize for the winner.

headline: A Lost World Is Resurrected at Brown
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — If museums are meant to preserve objects forever, then forever ended here in 1945.

headline: New Appraisal Sets Value of Detroit Institute Artworks at Up to $8.5 Billion
text: A new assessment of the potential value of the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts – commissioned by a Detroit creditor that would like to see pieces from the collection sold to settle debts in the city’s federal bankruptcy case – determined that the artworks could be worth as much as $8.5 billion dollars.

headline: Enmity and Civilian Toll Rise in Ukraine While Attention Is Diverted
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — One was a retired cook. Another installed alarms in cars. Another was a cleaner in a grocery store who had gone out to buy ground beef to make her son meatball soup.

headline: Statins Tied to Lower Risk of Barrett’s Esophagus
text: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs are associated with a lower risk of Barrett’s esophagus, a precancerous condition that can sometimes lead to esophageal cancer, a new study has found. Barrett’s esophagus is common in people who have long-term gastroesophageal reflux, or GERD.

headline: Back to Compassionate Conservatism?
text: Peter Beinart looks at the stirrings of economic populism among prominent Republicans and sees compassionate conservatism 2.0, which he argues wasn’t particularly politically successful in its original incarnation:

headline: Appeals Panel Rejects Virginia Gay-Marriage Ban
text: Adding to a year of courtroom victories by proponents of same-sex marriage, a federal appeals court on Monday struck down Virginia’s ban on same-sex unions, upholding a lower court’s declaration in February that the state’s restrictive laws were a violation of basic constitutional freedoms.

headline: Ask Well: Exercise and Weight Loss
text: Question:

headline: Introducing Sway Clarke II, R&B Hitmaker With a Canadian Sense of Humor
text: Who on earth would blend a “Bennie and the Jets” groove, trilling harpsichords evoking the Beatles’ “In My Life” and a dance-floor-quaking bass into an exuberant paean to infidelity? Answer: Sway Clarke II. The song, “Secret Garden,” is one of several by the Berlin-by-way-of-Toronto singer-songwriter that have taken off on the Internet (another is a moody cover of Kendrick Lamar’s “Swimming Pools”) and propelled the singer (who plays his first American show this evening at Bardot’s School Night in Los Angeles) to next-big-thing status. His combination of storytelling and hooks has earned comparisons to the hitmaking likes of Lorde and Frank Ocean, but a streak of naughty humor, often at the singer’s own expense, is uniquely his own. “That comes out of being Canadian,” he laughs. “There’s a reason why great comedians like Jim Carrey and Mike Myers came from Canada. It’s in our DNA to be self-deprecating and funny.”

headline: 3 Killed in a Facebook Blasphemy Rampage in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A woman and two of her young granddaughters were burned to death Sunday night in the eastern city of Gujranwala after a member of their Ahmadi minority sect was accused of posting a blasphemous picture to Facebook, the police said.

headline: Melissa Clark on Her Ingredients for a Cooking Video
text: What goes in to making a cooking video? We asked Melissa Clark, an author and food journalist for the Dining section. Her videos walk viewers through recipes each week.

headline: Citing Fairness, U.S. Judge Acts to Undo a Sentence He Was Forced to Impose
text: Francois Holloway has spent nearly two decades of a 57-year sentence in a federal prison, for serious crimes that no one disputes he committed. There were armed carjackings, and his participation in an illegal chop shop, where stolen cars would be dismantled and sold for parts.

headline: Georgia Files Criminal Charges Against Ex-President
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The general prosecutor of Georgia filed criminal charges on Monday against former President Mikheil Saakashvili, accusing him of abuse of power, largely for his handling of political protests that turned violent in November 2007.

headline: How the Internet Puts You to Sleep
text: Whispering, rustling paper and tapping fingers — more than 2.6 million videos on YouTube are designed to trigger a little-known phenomenon called autonomous sensory meridian response, or A.S.M.R.

headline: Rustle, Tingle, Relax: The Compelling World of A.S.M.R.
text: A few months ago, I was on a Manhattan-bound D train heading to work when a man with a chunky, noisy newspaper got on and sat next to me. As I watched him softly turn the pages of his paper, a chill spread like carbonated bubbles through the back of my head, instantly relaxing me and bringing me to the verge of sweet slumber.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Elizabeth Green on America’s Math Crisis
text: Elizabeth Green, a co-founder and the chief executive of Chalkbeat, wrote this week’s cover story about the Common Core and the challenges in overhauling the way math is taught. The article is adapted from her forthcoming book, “Building a Better Teacher: How Teaching Works (And How to Teach It to Everyone),” which will be published in August by W.W. Norton & Company.

headline: George Lucas Museum Chooses an Avant-Garde Architect for Chicago Site
text: The filmmaker George Lucas has selected an architectural team for a controversial museum of his private collection planned in Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported on Monday.

headline: Moreland Commission Co-Chairman Responds
text: William J. Fitzpatrick, one of the three Moreland Commission co-chairs, released a statement that the ethics panel was an independent body that had “total investigatory decision making authority.”

headline: To Attract and Repel, in Perpetuity
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Nina Arianda and Sam Rockwell must have gotten to know each other real well, real fast this summer. If their impossible mission was to achieve an instant, unfathomable intimacy, that assignment has been more than fulfilled in Daniel Aukin’s knockout production of Sam Shepard’s “Fool for Love,” which runs through Saturday at the Williamstown Theater Festival here.

headline: Deal Allots $17 Billion for Overhaul of V.A. Health Care System
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators announced an agreement Monday on legislation that would allocate about $17 billion to overhaul the Department of Veterans Affairs’ sprawling and beleaguered health care system. But the deal does not give the department everything that officials there have said is needed to fix its problems.

headline: Timing the Call to Repeal Marijuana
text: In February of 2011, The Seattle Times published a very influential editorial calling for marijuana to be legalized. Its impact was significant because it gave mainstream support to legalization at the moment when the state of Washington was beginning a serious debate on the issue. In November of 2012, the state’s residents voted by a 56-to-41 margin to legalize marijuana for recreational purposes.

headline: How Do You Top ‘Spider-Man’? With a Show Based on a Chipmunks Movie
text: The lead producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have two new shows in the works: A musical adaptation of the animated hit movie “Rio,” and a live stage show based on another movie, “Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked.” The producers, Michael Cohl and Jeremiah J. Harris, are also now focusing on an arena tour of “Spider-Man” rather than their original plan to open the show next in Las Vegas, Mr. Cohl said Monday.

headline: Head Down, Quietly Working and Thriving
text: Lucas Duda had the decisive hit, a two-run home run, in a 2-0 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers on Sunday, and after the game, standing at his locker, he was surrounded by about a dozen members of the news media. Did he expect to break out like this? How had he done it? Did this constitute his arrival?

headline: Strong Sales for Broadway’s ‘Aladdin’ and ‘Beautiful’
text: They may have lost the 2014 Tony Award for best musical last month, but Broadway’s “Aladdin” and “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” have emerged as the biggest box office winners of the 2013-14 season.

headline: F.T.C. Publishes Steps for Mobile Industry to Prevent Overbilling
text: The Federal Trade Commission has predicted that the practice of sneaking unauthorized charges into phone bills will only grow worse, so on Monday it published a list of best practices for companies to protect consumers from overbilling.

headline: Out of Wreckage, Lives Emerge
text: A treasure-laden ship that has lain silent on the Atlantic seabed for more than 150 years is giving up some of its secrets, as explorers who have revisited it for the first time in two decades detail in reports on their recovery operations. The sunken hulk, off South Carolina, has so far given up 45 gold bars, 47 pieces of gold jewelry, more than 2,000 gold coins and some 11,500 silver coins.

headline: Airbnb Expands Into Business Travel
text: Updated, 7:01 p.m. |

headline: Donald Sterling Loses Bid to Block Sale of Clippers
text: LOS ANGELES — A judge issued a sweeping victory Monday for Rochelle Sterling, ruling that she had the authority to sell the Los Angeles Clippers to the businessman Steve Ballmer, who has agreed to pay a record $2 billion for the franchise.

headline: For Those Stuck in the Terminal, an Opportunity to Exercise
text: PHILADELPHIA — Dana Donofree had half an hour to wait for her flight to Atlanta and decided to use the time by working out — in a terminal at Philadelphia International Airport.

headline: Greenhill Reports Lower Profit but Exceeds Expectations
text: Advising companies on mergers and acquisitions can be a rocky business, as the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company demonstrated on Monday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Ailey American Dance Theater to Offer Odetta Tribute
text: A tribute to Odetta and several company premieres are among the highlights planned for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s 2014-15 season, Robert Battle, the company’s artistic director, announced today.

headline: Sweet Rides and Good Vibes at an Underground Biker Rally in the Motor City
text: Every Sunday for the past decade, people have been gathering in a sparse corner of East Detroit for an ad hoc bike rally and block party that has grown solely through word of mouth. The event grew out of jam sessions held in a small shed called John’s Carpet Shack that featured local blues and jazz musicians including Otis Williams, the last surviving member of the Temptations. After the organizer, John Estes, passed away and the property burned down in 2008, the event moved to a vacant lot across the street. Since then it has grown into its current form, drawing people from all over Michigan to eat, drink, listen to bands and show off their cars and motorcycles, while organizers, including neighborhood resident Pete Barrow (a.k.a. Big Time Pete), who nominally runs things now, wend their way through the crowd with collection plates. On July 22, police shut down the event for the first time, citing a lack of permits. These pictures were taken a few weeks earlier.

headline: The Injustice of Marijuana Arrests
text: America’s four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties, but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war. The toll can be measured in dollars — billions of which are thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws. It can be measured in years — whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless. And it can be measured in lives — those damaged if not destroyed by the shockingly harsh consequences that can follow even the most minor offenses.

headline: Good News and Gloom for Medicare, Wrapped in a Mystery
text: Medicare got some good news Monday, when the trustees who oversee its finances announced that the fund that pays for hospital care will remain solvent until 2030, four years longer than its forecast from last year.

headline: U.S. and Europe Set to Toughen Russia Sanctions
text: FRANKFURT — The United States and Europe put aside their differences and agreed Monday to sharply escalate economic sanctions against Russia amid worries that Moscow is stepping up its intervention in Ukraine and may be setting the stage for an outright invasion.

headline: The Great Giant Flea Hunt
text: GIG HARBOR, Wash. — In the Pacific Northwest, we live among behemoths — snowcapped volcanoes, towering trees, great splashing salmon and lattes as big as a child’s head. Yet one of the region’s undeniably superlative titans has slipped beneath everyone’s radar.

headline: The Creative Art of Selling a Book by Its Cover
text: Peter Mendelsund often says that “dead authors get the best book jackets.”

headline: In Performance | de’Adre Aziza
text: The actress sings “Are You Lonely for Me” from “Piece of My Heart,” a new jukebox musical about the life of the songwriter Bert Berns. The show is at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

headline: Watched While Sleeping, What We Don’t Know, Jealous Dogs
text: SLEEP DISORDERS

headline: Planting Their Feet in a Soviet Past, From Tone to Style to Repertory
text: Back in the final years of the Soviet Union, New York and London patrons learned that the price of watching Russian ballet companies was to undergo a heightened security process on entering theaters. Currently, however, there’s a preposterous incongruity at the David H. Koch Theater. Bag-checking is standard for its home company, New York City Ballet, but not for guest companies. So no bags were examined for the Bolshoi Ballet’s two-week 2014 season  at the theater, which ended on Sunday.

headline: When It’s Cool To Have Nothing
text: Ditching your possessions is hip right now. The “tiny house” is popular enough that it has its own conference — the next one, in Portland, Ore., promises to be “the biggest Tiny House Conference yet.”

headline: When the Silent Majority Finally Began to Speak
text: Consider 1975. There were 89 terrorist bombings on American soil; two assassination attempts, 19 days apart, on President Gerald Ford; and a Gallup poll finding that 75 percent of American women were afraid to walk near their homes at night.

headline: His Turn With the Past
text: John Michael McDonagh is no altar boy, at least not anymore.

headline: Nabbing a Giant Flea, Treasure From the Deep, Tingling to Sleep
text: Join the hunt for the world’s largest flea; a salvage mission has retrieved historical relics and wealth from the bottom of the sea; starting to look with a scientific eye at A.S.M.R., tingling bodily sensations that some people experience after listening to soothing sounds.

headline: Chefs Move Beyond New York
text: When Gavin Kaysen announced in March that he would leave his longtime position as Café Boulud’s executive chef to open his own restaurant, plenty of people in the restaurant industry — and those who watch it — were surprised. As Daniel Boulud’s right-hand man, Mr. Kaysen was a player in one of the most successful restaurant empires in New York.

headline: Southwest to Be Fined Over Repairs
text: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Monday that it planned to fine Southwest Airlines $12 million for repair violations on some of its Boeing 737 jets, citing some faulty repairs it said the airline made since 2006.

headline: A Singer Drawing Eyes and Ears
text: In music, at least, earnestness is the currency that makes the Internet hum. Think of all those kids staring into cameras and singing their hearts out in hopes of a little attention, buskers with hats in hand. Their purposeful lack of artifice — yes, it’s a pose, but a vulnerable one. True self inside! Just press play!

headline: Eleanor Friedberger, Superchunk and Other Indie Stars at the Merge Records Anniversary Party
text: The influential North Carolina-based music label Merge Records has existed nearly as long as indie rock itself: 25 years. To celebrate this milestone, Merge hosted a long weekend’s worth of concerts and events in Durham and Carrboro, N.C., featuring its formidable roster of talent. Both classic acts (Superchunk, Neutral Milk Hotel) and newer ones (Eleanor Friedberger, Hiss Golden Messenger) appeared. There were nearly as many varieties of fashion statements, ranging from bohemian layers to geek-chic button-downs. The photographer Jeremy M. Lange was on hand to capture the action onstage and off.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Libya and Ukraine.

headline: A Haunted Castle, a Serpent and Tragic Betrayal
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — In the first act of Weber’s seldom-performed “Euryanthe,” the villain, Count Lysiart, briefly turns opera critic. Listening to a plangent aria, he’s less than pleased.

headline: Netanyahu Readies for Long Gaza Conflict
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said the country must be prepared for a lengthy military campaign in the Gaza Strip.

headline: When the Caregivers Need Healing
text: “This has happened before,” she tells herself. “It’s nowhere near as bad as before, and it will pass.”

headline: Podcast: Tingling to Sleep
text: The author talks about her own experience with A.S.M.R.

headline: A Threat to Cambodia’s Sacred Forests
text: In a remote valley in southwest Cambodia, an indigenous group fights to protect its homes from the looming construction of a hydroelectric dam.

headline: Seals Surviving Climate Change Tend to Thrive
text: Although Antarctic fur seal populations are declining because of climate change, their genetic diversity is increasing. Because of food constraints, seal pups are becoming smaller, researchers report based on 30 years of data. But female pups that manage to survive until motherhood tend to be larger, more fit and more genetically diverse.

headline: ‘A Threat to Cambodia’s Sacred Forests’
text: In southwest Cambodia, at the foot of the Cardamom Mountains, is a single dirt road that meanders through the heart of the pristine Areng valley. Ten miles down this road, villagers have set up an encampment to stop a hydroelectric dam project that they fear will destroy their forests, livelihood and heritage.

headline: Don’t Kill the Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON — AMONG the many things that President Ronald Reagan did to promote economic growth was to ensure a level playing field for American businesses abroad — including by supporting an expansion of the Export-Import Bank, which provides financing for the export of American goods and services.

headline: Colonial Folly, European Suicide
text: TURNER, Me. — ONE hundred years ago today, Austro-Hungarian artillery and gunboats on the Danube began shelling Serbia — the first shots of the great cataclysm that over the next four and a half years would remake our world for the worse, in every conceivable way. We think of the First World War as having its causes in Europe, where the greatest bloodshed and destruction would take place. But several of the illusions that propelled the major powers so swiftly into war had their roots in far corners of the world.

headline: Photographing on the Ground in Gaza
text: Sergey Ponomarev has encountered a war routine in Gaza, documenting the destruction and casualties of the latest conflict.

headline: Shipping Lanes Threaten Pacific Blue Whales
text: Two major feeding grounds for Pacific blue whales are bisected by busy shipping lanes near major seaports in San Francisco and Santa Barbara, Calif., a new study reports.

headline: Lost Luggage Leads to Wedding Chapel (but Not Love)
text: THE last five years have been crazy in terms of business travel. At the beginning of the month, I really enjoy it. By the end of the month, I guess it’s fair to say I’m not that fond of it.

headline: Into the Abyss, Music to Remember, Burning Man Planetarium, Intricate Insects
text: August events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Increase Base Salaries for Junior Bankers
text: Morgan Stanley plans to increase base salaries for junior and midlevel bankers by as much as 25 percent, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday, in the latest move by Wall Street to try to improve working conditions for those lowest on the totem pole.

headline: Bipartisan Deal Reached on V.A. Reform
text: Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, and Representative Jeff Miller, Republican of Florida, discussed their agreement for changes in the Department of Veterans Affairs’ health care system.

headline: U.S. Says Russia Tested Cruise Missile, Violating Treaty
text: WASHINGTON — The United States has concluded that Russia violated a landmark arms control treaty by testing a prohibited ground-launched cruise missile, according to senior American officials, a finding that was conveyed by President Obama to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a letter on Monday.

headline: Legalize Marijuana? Responses Vary
Polaris Unveils a 3-Wheel Roadster and Expands the Indian Motorcycle Line
text: Polaris Industries, the Minneapolis-based maker of all-terrain vehicles, snowmobiles and motorcycles, is moving in a new direction: the Slingshot 3-wheel roadster. Although the Slingshot is not an automobile – it does not have air bags and does not meet federal motor vehicle safety standards – Polaris describes a ride that’s a lot like that of a sports car. The chief difference between the Slingshot and a typical two-seat sports car is the layout: two wheels in front and one in the back. Polaris calls it a motorcycle (never mind that it has a steering wheel instead of handlebars) and says that occupants should wear both helmets and safety belts.

headline: Short-Lived Ethics Panel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Payday Lender’s Policies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rights of City Inmates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yanks and the Booker Prize
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disability Rights Treaty
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York City Parking Rules
text: Because of Eid-al Fitr, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Gaza Lull Ends as Both Sides Point Fingers in New Attacks
text: A lull in hostilities in deference to a Muslim holiday unraveled with deadly force at a children’s playground and an area near Gaza City’s main hospital.

headline: Where Ancient Burmese Beauty Balm Competes With Modern Cosmetics
text: MANDALAY, Myanmar — Although Than Than Aye, a street vendor, is a half-century old, few if any wrinkles mar her complexion. Her secret? A yellowish paste made from ground tree bark that she applies to her cheeks, nose and neck after her morning shower and again before bed.

headline: Fuel Depot Fire Endangers Civilians in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Officials warned Monday of growing dangers to civilians from a large and spreading fire in a fuel depot near this city’s international airport, which was sparked by fighting in the area between militias armed with heavy weapons.

headline: That Would Make a Good Novel
text: Sometime in late 2005, on one of our first outings together, my friend Cornelia took me to her favorite used bookstore in Portland, Me. The store, once thriving, was closing its doors. The stacks had been picked over, and all that remained were some used cookbooks and a smattering of other genres. I have had moments in used bookstores when I feel destiny pushing me toward an obscure title, but that day I felt nothing, no sign or vibration coming from any of the odd, unwanted books. But because Cornelia was a new friend and had driven me into the city to show me this store that she hadn’t known was going out of business, I grabbed a beat-up biography of Margaret Mead and took it to the counter.

headline: A Boom in Corporate Travel, as Well as Threats to Safety
text: LOS ANGELES — BOOM times are back in corporate travel, but so, too, is the anxiety.

headline: With Sale of Red Lobster Complete, Chief of Darden Restaurants to Step Down
text: The chairman and chief executive of Darden Restaurants, Clarence Otis Jr., said on Monday that he planned to step down, months after waging an intense fight with activist hedge funds opposed to his turnaround plans for the embattled company.

headline: Are 'Starchitects' Ruining Cities?
text: Are superstar architects, who often work in cities they know little about, creating buildings that don't mesh well with the surroundings?

headline: Pagan High Priest Finds Few Believers Inside an Arkansas City Hall
text: BEEBE, Ark. — Bertram Dahl is a boyish 48-year-old who was raised in rural Arkansas by a Pentecostal preacher. He is fond of wearing loose white tunics; in this land of boots and ball caps, he can seem like a visitor from Luke Skywalker’s home planet of Tatooine.

headline: Inflation OCD
text: Brad DeLong does yeoman work in tracking down a veritable host of right-wing proclamations over the past five years that high inflation is just around the corner, or maybe has already landed but the feds are hiding it in Area 51. But I think he falls short in analyzing the phenomenon, trying to attribute it to bad models or just finding it incomprehensible.

headline: A Prison Routine Turns Deadly
text: Charles Toll died as officers forcibly carried him out of his cell in a Tennessee prison. The case raises questions about when and how the procedure — known as a cell extraction — should be used.

headline: If ESPN Keeps Smith on Air, Message Will Be Loud and Murky
text: ESPN is such a colossus that it was big news when Michelle Beadle challenged Stephen A. Smith over his misguided remarks on Friday about domestic violence. They are ESPN stars, with nearly three million Twitter followers between them. The ESPN ecosystem is such that any misstep by any of its boldface names can start a digital storm, even if the subject is inane — or Tim Tebow.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 27, 2014
text: “The kids who are of color see her as an African-American girl, and that’s really big for them. And I think a lot of other kids don’t see her color, and that’s wonderful as well.”

headline: No War Is an Island
text: It’s amazing how much of the discussion of the Gaza war is based on the supposition that it is still 1979. It’s based on the supposition that the Israeli-Palestinian dispute is a self-contained struggle being run by the two parties most directly involved. It’s based on the supposition that the horror could be ended if only deft negotiators could achieve a “breakthrough” and a path toward a two-state agreement.

headline: Boko Haram Targets Political Figures in String of Attacks
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — A long holiday weekend of kidnapping and suicide bombing, spilling over into Monday, highlighted an apparent shift by the violent Islamists of Boko Haram, with the group now targeting prominent political figures in two countries.

headline: On Subway, Flying Feet Can Lead to Handcuffs
text: The young dancers, Peppermint and Butterscotch, scanned the scattered faces aboard the New York City subway. One caught their eye.

headline: Banks Cash In on Inversion Deals Intended to Elude Taxes
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, recently said, “I love America.” Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, wrote an opinion article saying, “Investing in America still produces the best return.”

headline: When Cell Door Opens, Tough Tactics and Risk
text: NASHVILLE — The August night was hot, but Charles Jason Toll wrapped himself in a coat and covered his mouth to protect against the electrical shocks and gas he thought might come his way.

headline: Circles of Influence
text: Thomas Palley is upset with what I said about wages in a depressed economy, not because we disagree on the substance — we don’t — but because he thinks I gave him and those in his camp short shrift. I plead innocent, but there is a larger issue on which he does have a case.

headline: Teaching Teaching
text: I’m starting to wonder if we’ve entered some kind of golden age of books about education. First came Paul Tough’s book, “How Children Succeed,” about the importance of developing noncognitive skills in students. It was published in September 2012. Then came “The Smartest Kids in the World,” by Amanda Ripley, which tackled the question of what other countries were getting right in the classroom that America was getting wrong. Her book came out just about a year ago.

headline: New Venture Fund Binary Capital Focuses on Mission, Not Just Metrics
text: In 2011, after raising more than $3 million in early-stage funding, Chantel Waterbury, founder of Chloe & Isabel, which makes handcrafted jewelry, was still being hotly pursued by investors.

headline: Venezuelan Officers Linked to Colombian Cocaine Traffickers
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The head of Venezuelan military intelligence was on the payroll of a Colombian drug lord, invested his own money in drug shipments and personally coordinated the shipment of thousands of kilograms of cocaine, according to prosecutors in Miami and New York.

headline: Ace of Lackluster Team Awaits His Fate
text: The Philadelphia Phillies do not seem to recognize what they have become. To judge by their payroll and the track record of their players, they should be contenders. For three years now, the standings have screamed otherwise.

headline: OKCupid Plays With Love in User Experiments
text: Love is not blind, as it turns out. But opposites attract when people think they are similar.

headline: Advocates Shun ‘Pro-Choice’ to Expand Message
text: WASHINGTON — For all the talk about women’s issues in this year’s midterm election campaigns, something is missing. One of the most enduring labels of modern politics — pro-choice — has fallen from favor, a victim of changed times and generational preferences.

headline: Countdown to Lockout for Unions at the Met
text: With just days left to reach contract agreements that would avert a lockout threatened for Friday at the Metropolitan Opera, one complicating factor is that the question is not one of management versus labor, but of management versus labor 15 times over: That is the number of unions at the opera whose contracts are set to expire on Thursday night.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 28, 2014
Spending Big to Fight Big Donors in Campaigns
text: An unlikely alliance of liberal intellectuals, big donors and Republican strategists has hit on a solution to the influence of big money in politics: even more money.

headline: For de Blasio, No Easing Into Work After Break
text: There is rarely a summer lull for the mayor of New York City.

headline: Tunnels Lead Right to the Heart of Israeli Fear
text: NEAR THE ISRAEL-GAZA BORDER — The curved concrete top of the tunnel grazes the dark-brown buzz cut of Lt. Col. Oshik Azulai, putting it 5 feet and 7 inches above the sand floor. The walls are about 30 inches apart — wide enough for two people to squeeze past each other, unless both are in body armor. It is cool in the tunnel, 46 feet under, and dark, of course. Cellphones do not work.

headline: Georgia Democrat’s Senate Campaign Plan, Not Meant for Public Eyes, Is Published
text: ATLANTA — Less than one week after Republicans selected their nominee for a United States Senate race in Georgia, the campaign of the Democratic candidate, Michelle Nunn, was jolted on Monday by the publication of an internal document that charted plans for a contest that is expected to be one of the country’s most competitive and one of the few where Democrats have any realistic chance of retaking a Republican-held seat.

headline: Fast-Break Acclimation for New Net From Bosnia
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There was a visit to the Barclays Center basketball court and lunch at the Peter Luger steakhouse Friday, dinner with Coach Lionel Hollins on Saturday night and a news conference Monday morning.

headline: Port Agency Tells Store to Drop 9/11 Items
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a “great concern.”

headline: Mujer of Mixed Race
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — It took me a surprisingly long amount of time for a Tuesday puzzle to figure out what Timothy Polin’s theme was about, but that could just be me shaking off the remains of my weekend.

headline: Tangled Romances, in Need of Some Pruning
text: A steamy snippet of a telenovela is heating up the McGinn/Cazale Theater, where “Mala Hierba,” a new play by Tanya Saracho, opened on Monday night as part of the Second Stage Theater’s Uptown series. A crisis in the life of a young Mexican-American woman suffering under the thumb of a rich but brutal husband provides the juice in this sudsy but enjoyable drama.

headline: Wah Wah Jones, Versatile Kentucky Athlete, Dies at 88
text: Wah Wah Jones, a multitalented athlete at the University of Kentucky in the late 1940s, who starred on the legendary coach Adolph Rupp’s national championship basketball teams and Bear Bryant’s resurgent football squads — while also finding time to excel at track and baseball — died on Sunday in Lexington, Ky. He was 88.

headline: Short Staff Tries to Cope With Ebola
text: Early this month at a hospital in Sierra Leone, Dr. Daniel Bausch and another physician found themselves alone in a ward with 55 patients infected with the deadly Ebola virus. The nurses had walked out in a dispute over extra pay to take care of the Ebola patients, and some were also staying away for fear of contracting the disease, which has killed health workers.

headline: House Bill Calls for V.O.A. to Support U.S. Policies
text: The House passed legislation on Monday that is intended to clarify the mission of the government-financed Voice of America. The bill would revise the news service’s mission statement to specify that it has a role in supporting American “public diplomacy” and policies. The Senate is working on a similar bill. Opponents off the legislation and many Voice of America staff members said the measure would turn the agency into a propaganda mouthpiece.

headline: Louise Shivers, Conjurer of Rural South, Dies at 84
text: Louise Shivers, whose debut novella, “Here to Get My Baby Out of Jail” — a story of adultery and murder in the Depression-era South — surprised no one more than herself when it was published to wide critical acclaim when she was 53, died on Saturday in Evans, Ga. She was 84.

headline: Iran: Muslims Seek American’s Release
text: Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent incarcerated in Tehran for nearly three years, spent his 31st birthday in prison on Monday, despite new pleas to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for his compassionate release sent from prominent Muslim American figures in his home state, Michigan. Letters from the Michigan chapter of the Council on American Islamic Relations and from the Imams’ Council of the Michigan Muslim Community Council, released by Mr. Hekmati’s family, beseeched the ayatollah to grant Mr. Hekmati a pardon, invoking the tradition of mercy associated with the end of the Ramadan holiday. It is unclear whether Ayatollah Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, has seen the letters. Mr. Hekmati, a former Marine from Flint, was arrested in 2011 while visiting relatives in Iran for the first time. He was tried and sentenced to death for espionage, but the verdict was overturned and he was later convicted of cooperation with a hostile government — the United States — and given a 10-year sentence. Iranian prosecutors have never explained the substance of their case, and Mr. Hekmati and his family have said he is innocent of any wrongdoing.

headline: New Coach Has Giants Huddling in Hurry, or Not at All
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There is a different soundtrack at the Giants’ training camp practices this year, and it stands out against the usual crash of pads and the thump of colliding bodies. It is the singsong voice of the new offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo.

headline: Chinese Authorities Investigate Pegasus, a Unit of Edelman
text: BEIJING — Pegasus Communications, a subsidiary of the American public relations firm Edelman, says that its Beijing office was visited last week by the “relevant authorities” and that it was cooperating with an investigation.

headline: Moon Is Elusive Guide in Calculating Start of Islamic Holiday
text: JERSEY CITY — The four men stood in the fading dusk on Sunday evening at Liberty State Park here, craning their eyes over an expanse of the Hudson River, toward the west, where the sun had set about 10 minutes earlier, and they were now straining in vain to spot a sliver of the moon on the horizon.

headline: Workout Clothes With High-Tech Twist Sell Briskly
text: Gym shirts made of Kevlar. Underpants featuring “anti-odor technology.” No-sweat briefs. Lycra made of corn. And exercise shorts designed with Cordura, a rugged material most often associated with things like car seats and luggage.

headline: Bratton and de Blasio on Shooting
text: William J. Bratton, the police commissioner, and Mayor Bill de Blasio addressed the media after a shooting in the West Village Monday.

headline: How the E.U. Signed On to Sanctions
text: Why Europe had been so hesitant to act but is now set to dramatically escalate sanctions against Russia.

headline: Subway Showtime
text: Trying to make quick cash, dancers and acrobats are common performers on the New York City subway, a tradition the police are trying to reduce.

headline: Creeping Up on .500, Mets Appear to Be Avoiding Any Major Roster Moves
text: The Mets are not eager to be sellers, General Manager Sandy Alderson said Monday, standing in the dugout several hours before the Mets hosted the Phillies. Three days remained until the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline, and Alderson had little definitive information to share. But that statement spoke volumes.

headline: Rhapsody Reaches 2 Million Monthly Subscribers
text: Way back in the streaming stone age of 2001, the music service Rhapsody pioneered the model of selling access to songs online through monthly subscriptions. Rhapsody has long since been leapfrogged by newer entrants like Spotify, but now it is trying to regain momentum with multiple pricing plans and an international expansion.

headline: Gardner Puts On Show, but Yanks Lose Again
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Solving the Texas Rangers All-Star pitcher Yu Darvish was not a problem for Brett Gardner, who continued his surprising power surge against Darvish with his first career multihomer game.

headline: How the Government Exaggerates the Cost of College
text: The government’s official statistic for college-tuition inflation has become somewhat infamous. It appears frequently in the news media, and policy makers lament what it shows.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 7 P.M. (BET) JUMPING THE BROOM (2011) Paula Patton and Laz Alonso play Sabrina Watson and Jason Taylor, lovebirds planning what should be the perfect wedding on Martha’s Vineyard. That is, until Jason’s mother (Loretta Devine), a postal worker with a chip on her shoulder, arrives from Brooklyn at the estate of Sabrina’s uptight parents. “Our family were never slaves,” says Mrs. Watson (Angela Bassett), who likes to converse in French. “We owned slaves.” Mayhem, of course, ensues as the film examines, among other subjects, class conflict among African-American families. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film’s director, Salim Akil, and its screenwriters, Elizabeth Hunter and Arlene Gibbs, “fall back on the tried-and-true staple of the busy nuptial weekend to stage a talk show season’s worth of conflicts and revelations, both serious and comical.”

headline: Aviation Authorities Warn of Severe Flight Delays in Eastern China
text: Flight delays that have plagued China are expected to hit new extremes this week as the authorities announced that air traffic capacity would be reduced by as much as 75 percent on Tuesday in Shanghai. Several other eastern Chinese cities will also be affected.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 29, 2014
text: “It’s not a pleasant thought that you sit one day on the patio drinking coffee with your wife and a bunch of terrorists will rise from the ground.”

headline: Corrections: July 29, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Chinese Officials, Cutting Corners, Add 4 of Them to Running Track
text: There is a reason for building a running track with right-angle turns.

headline: UBS Profit Rises 15% as It Grapples With Legal Matters
text: LONDON – The Swiss bank UBS said on Tuesday that second-quarter profit rose nearly 15 percent despite muted client activity and additional charges for litigation and regulatory inquiries, including the settlement of a German tax investigation.

headline: Deutsche Bank Profit Declines as It Sheds Risky Businesses
text: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, said on Tuesday that second-quarter net profit fell 29 percent because of an overall decline in revenue and the continued cost of recovering from the effects of the financial crisis.

headline: What Is Chris Christie Doing in Iowa?
text: Earlier this month, Chris Christie was standing in the parking lot of MJ’s Restaurant, in Marion, Iowa, holding a news conference. Earlier that day, a Malaysia Airlines jet had been shot down in Ukraine; Israel was launching its ground invasion into Gaza. And here was Christie — a tell-it-like-it-is, straight-talking, no-nonsense Jersey guy — telling about 60 members of the media what he really thought. “Governor Branstad is a role model for me,” Christie gushed, referring to his 67-year-old counterpart from Iowa. Terry Branstad, who is seeking his sixth term in November, is hoping to become the longest-serving governor in the nation’s history. And Christie — who referred to Branstad as a “dear friend,” a “legend” and someone who embodies “what public service is all about” — hoped to perpetuate his dynasty. In fact, he even offered to return to Iowa, over and over, “as often as Governor Branstad wants me to.”

headline: Photographing on the Ground in Gaza
text: Sergey Ponomarev, 33, is a freelance photographer covering the conflict in Gaza on assignment for The New York Times. He grew up in Moscow and Ireland and has previously worked for The Associated Press. He spoke to James Estrin from Gaza City on Saturday evening. The conversation has been edited.

headline: Israel Steps Up Airstrikes in Gaza as International Cease-Fire Efforts Stumble
text: JERUSALEM — As Israel intensified its aerial assaults on Tuesday against symbols of Hamas rule in Gaza and other targets, new efforts were underway to forge a cease-fire, though they were mired in confusion and mixed signals after 22 days of fighting.

headline: BP Profit Rises, but It Warns of Risks in Russia
text: LONDON — BP showed clear signs in reporting earnings on Tuesday that its once-lucrative business in the United States was recovering from the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010. But the oil company also indicated that its large investment in Russia was growing riskier as  economic sanctions against Russia escalated.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Daily Report: OKCupid Experiments on Seekers of Romance
text: Love is not blind, as it turns out. But opposites attract when people think they are similar. So says OKCupid, one of the web’s most popular dating sites, in findings about its users that provide a window into how we chase romantic partners in the digital age, Molly Wood reports.

headline: Coordinated Sanctions Aim at Russia’s Ability to Tap Its Oil Reserves
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Europe kicked off a joint effort on Tuesday intended to curb Russia’s long-term ability to develop new oil resources, taking aim at the Kremlin’s premier source of wealth and power in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine.

headline: White House Pushes Financial Case for Carbon Rule
text: WASHINGTON — Failing to adequately reduce the carbon pollution that contributes to climate change could cost the United States economy $150 billion a year, according to an analysis by the White House Council of Economic Advisers released Tuesday.

headline: New York Today: Films Alfresco
text: Good Tuesday morning.

headline: French Shopping Center Owner Klépierre to Buy Dutch Rival in $9.7 Billion Deal
text: LONDON – Klépierre of France has conditionally agreed to acquire its Dutch rival Corio in a deal that would create the largest owner of retail shopping centers in Europe.

headline: China Says Former Security Chief Is Being Investigated for Corruption
text: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping’s campaign against corruption among the Chinese elite took public aim on Tuesday at its biggest target so far, when the Communist Party announced an investigation of Zhou Yongkang, the former chief of domestic security.

headline: Morning Views
text: “America’s four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties,” writes Jesse Wegman for The New York Times, “but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war.” The measure of that destruction can be estimated in billions of dollars, “thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws,” and in years, “whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless.” Decriminalizing marijuana use at the federal level will, first, eliminate “costly, futile” policing programs and enforcement laws that, each year, cost American taxpayers “more than $3.6 billion.” Second, it is an important step forward in resolving racial disparity in arrests and mass incarceration: “The war on drugs aims its firepower overwhelmingly at African-Americans on the street, while white users smoke safely behind closed doors.” And third, it offers an opportunity for state lawmakers to roll back the psychological and social damage already inflicted on drug offenders, such as sealing records of drug convictions in order to “make it easier for defendants to get jobs and housing after a conviction.”

headline: At McDonald’s Outlets in China, Patrons Ask Where’s the Meat?
text: For vegetarians or pescatarians, the menu in many McDonald’s restaurants across China is suddenly looking very friendly. Gone are the fast-food chain’s signature Big Macs and Chicken McNuggets. Even the beef rice wraps, created specifically to cater to the tastes of the local clientele, are nowhere to be found.

headline: We’re About to Miss a Deadline. Who’s Responsible for This Mess?
text: Here is my frustration: There are opportunities to grow the service lines of our part-finishing business, but we can’t seem to get our arms around them. True, most lines in the plant run well: good quality, on-time delivery. The clients are happy. I am happy. Yet, on some lines there are quality issues, communication issues and delivery issues.

headline: Al Qaeda’s Reluctant Financiers
text: The New York Times obtained this exclusive video of a 2003 kidnapping in North Africa, an operation that led to Al Qaeda’s use abductions to finance its operations.

headline: British Private Equity Firm Rejects Request From Sherborne Investors
text: Updated, 8:13 a.m. | LONDON – The British firm Electra Private Equity said on Tuesday that it had rejected a request by the activist investor Edward J. Bramson for three seats on its board.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Reap Rewards of Inversions Deals
text: The chief executives at JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs have stated their allegiance to America, but these same banks are behind the recent spate of merger deals in which large corporations have renounced their United States citizenship in search of a lower tax bill, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. Investment banks are estimated to have collected, or will soon collect, nearly $1 billion in fees over the last three years for advising and persuading American companies to move the address of their headquarters abroad.

headline: In Performance: de’Adre Aziza of ‘Piece of My Heart’
text: In this week’s video, the actress de’Adre Aziza sings “Are You Lonely for Me” from “Piece of My Heart,” a new jukebox musical about the life of the songwriter Bert Berns, whose hits include “I Want Candy,” “Twist and Shout” and “Hang On Sloopy.” The show, directed and choreographed by Denis Jones, runs through Aug. 31 at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

headline: Bright Passages
text: Here’s another small sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions. As always, humor is well represented, as are reviews and feature stories. But the last two examples make clear that some of our finest writing comes in serious stories written on tight deadlines.

headline: BaubleBar, an Upstart Jewelry Seller, Raises $10 Million
text: Three and a half years ago, two onetime investment banking analysts decided to turn their backs on Wall Street and dive into the jewelry business instead.

headline: 1914: War Fever Spreads in Carlsbad
text: CARLSBAD — The atmosphere of Carlsbad seems surcharged with electricity to-day [July 28], and even the American visitors have fallen under the spell of the restless, excited feeling of being in the war zone. So far as can be seen, Americans show no disposition to curtail their ‘‘cure,’’ with the exception of certain prominent financiers, who will leave almost immediately. Mr. William Schmidlap, of Cincinnati, says that at no time during the forty-four years he has been coming to Europe for a summer ‘‘cure’’ had it been necessary to be provided with a passport, except on the occasion of the Franco-Prussian war. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 30, 1914

headline: Shelling of Gaza Resumes After Humanitarian Pause
text: A top Hamas official’s home was destroyed, and Gaza’s only power plant was also hit overnight.

text: Updated, 3:05 p.m. | The long reach of the New York attorney general’s office appears to be stretching further into Europe.

headline: New York Times Co. Gains Circulation, but Profit Falls 21%
text: Increased investments in digital products and a decline in print advertising weighed on The New York Times Company’s second-quarter earnings, as adjusted operating profit slipped 21 percent.

headline: The Next Big Trend: Buzz Cuts
text: Admittedly, I do not normally take on the role of futurologist, and I am calling this a bit early, but between the new fall ad campaigns and Comic-Con, which ended Sunday, I feel it is a pretty safe bet to say that a major fashion trend this fall and winter will be … drumroll please … buzz cuts!

headline: No Turning the Other Cheek: Suit Over Canceled Tour of ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’
