headline: The D.O. Is in Now
text: The old Blumstein’s department store sits across 125th Street from the legendary Apollo Theater. It’s something of a Harlem landmark, where “don’t buy where you can’t work” protests led to the hiring of African-Americans as the first salesclerks in 1934 and where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was stabbed by a mentally unstable woman during a book signing in 1958. Now a row of colorful clothing and jewelry stores lines the ground floor. But the rest of the building has been gutted and fitted with lecture halls, classrooms, laboratories and a library to house the Touro College of Osteopathic Medicine.

headline: Indian E-Commerce Firm Flipkart Raises Eye-Popping $1 Billion
text: Flipkart, India’s largest e-commerce firm, confirmed on Tuesday that it had raised $1 billion in its latest round of fund-raising, making it by far the largest venture investment ever received by an Indian Internet company.

headline: N.C.A.A. Deal Revamps Head-Injury Care
text: The N.C.A.A. has reached a preliminary settlement in a class-action lawsuit brought by former college athletes to institute wide-ranging reforms to its head-injury policies.

headline: An Old China Store With a Scholarly Following
text: For this series, T asks friends and contributors to share their favorite shops from around the world that sell just a single kind of product.

headline: Bomber Kills Karzai Cousin Who Backed Recent Candidate for Afghan President
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hashmat Khalil Karzai, a cousin of President Hamid Karzai and a powerful supporter of the presidential candidate Ashraf Ghani, was killed by a suicide bomber in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday as he greeted well-wishers at his home, government officials and a witness said.

headline: The Cuckoo Bird and the Baby
text: Typically when I experience a bout of insomnia, which fortunately isn’t that often, I’ll switch on my laptop and start trolling the Internet for animal videos — cats jumping in boxes, goats screaming like humans, sheep jumping over fences — whatever I can find to distract myself until I fall back to sleep.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage, Faster Job Creation
text: The standard argument against a higher minimum wage is that it will lead to job loss as employers, unable to pay more, lay off current workers or don’t hire new ones.

headline: A Health Trade-Off That’s Here to Stay: Lower Cost, Limited Choice
text: Traditionally, there were a few ways that health insurers could keep premiums low for individual health plans. They could select people with no prior health problems, to limit the chances of getting stuck with big hospital bills. They could pare back the services and products they offered to avoid ones that could be expensive, like maternity care or prescription drugs. They could increase premiums or deductibles so their customers would pay a larger share of any eventual bills.

headline: Highbrow, Lowbrow, Middlebrow — Do These Kinds of Cultural Categories Mean Anything Anymore?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Pankaj Mishra discuss whether there is any use in retaining old labels of cultural prestige.

headline: A New Watery Way to See New Orleans
text: A new tour from Gray Line New Orleans shows visitors the watery side of the city.

headline: Auction Could Be Undoing of New Jersey Carousel That Survived Hurricane and Fire
text: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J. — For as long as anyone can remember, two carousels have spun on the boardwalk here, where funnel cakes vie with fried Twinkies and where Snooki cavorted in the reality show “Jersey Shore.”

headline: Intersection | High Line Break Time
text: Marika Emi picked up her minimalist, all-black style from the friends she made while living in New York. Though she has since moved back home to Hawaii, “Old habits die really hard,” she said.

headline: John Lurie Tribute Set for Le Poisson Rouge
text: Le Poisson Rouge is presenting a tribute to the arts world polymath John Lurie that will include four concerts of his music  and two exhibitions of his visual art works. The films Mr. Lurie has appeared in (“Stranger Than Paradise,” “Desperately Seeking Susan” and “Sleepwalk,” among them) are not part of the tribute, but some of Mr. Lurie’s film music will figure into the concert programs.

headline: Warren G. Harding’s Racy Love Letters Unsealed
text: The “return to normalcy” met “not safe for work” this morning, when the Library of Congress made nearly 1,000 handwritten pages of Warren G. Harding’s steamy letters to his mistress freely available online, 50 years after they were sealed by a judge.

headline: Do You Own a Gun? In Florida, Doctors Can’t Ask You That
text: A few weeks ago, I had my yearly physical. As part of her history-taking, my doctor asked if I was sexually active with my wife. Then she asked if I was sexually active with anyone other than my wife. She does this every year.

headline: How Loneliness Can Make You Sick — and Might Even Kill You
text: What does it mean to be lonely? It’s tempting to equate the feeling with a dearth of social interaction, but some people are now saying that it’s more complicated than that — and that true loneliness might be dangerous.

headline: Most in Poll Say Children at Border Merit Relief
text: Most Americans surveyed in a poll released Tuesday said the United States should give shelter and assistance to children from Central America coming here illegally without their parents while the authorities decide whether they can stay.

headline: Coming From Theater for a New Audience: Peter Brook, Marlowe and Shakespeare
text: The Theater for a New Audience’s 2014-15 season will include a mix of premieres and a rarely produced work by Christopher Marlowe, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Amazon Joins With Alloy Entertainment on Digital Publishing Imprint
text: Amazon Publishing and Alloy Entertainment, a book packager and division of Warner. Bros Television Group, are collaborating on a new digital publishing imprint dedicated to young adult, new adult and commercial fiction.

headline: Tracey Emin’s ‘My Bed’ Headed to the Tate
text: LONDON — Tracey Emin’s 1998 “My Bed,” which shows the crumpled, stained sheets of an unmade bed, littered with cigarette butts, condoms, underwear and empty vodka bottles, was described by the artist as representing a time in her life when she was severely depressed.

headline: Senior Guerrilla Leaders Tied to Acts of Persecution After Civil War
text: PARIS — A special European Union prosecutor said Tuesday that senior members of the Kosovo Liberation Army engaged in a campaign of persecution against ethnic Serbs after the 1998-99 Kosovo war, and said evidence suggested that the armed group had targeted a number of individuals after the war to harvest and sell their organs.

headline: The ‘Sharing Economy’ Goes White-Collar
text: The Silicon Valley scene is often known for its shabby-chicness, like a chief executive clad in a hoodie and sneakers.

headline: 1964: 65 Sentenced Over Revolt
text: LISBON — The biggest political trial of Premier Antonio Salazar’s regime ended today with the sentencing of 65 people to prison terms ranging from 17 months to ten years for involvement in an abortive revolt on Jan. 1, 1962. Seventeen people were acquitted. The state charged that the rebellion was planned by former Gen. Humberto Delgado — defeated candidate in the 1958 presidential election and now regarded as the leader abroad of opposition to the regime. The state said Manuel Serra, a former merchant-navy officer who drew a ten-year term, helped organize the plot. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 30, 1964

headline: House G.O.P. Plan on Migrants Falls Short of Obama’s Goal
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday unveiled their plan to stem the surge of unauthorized child migrants from Central America at the southern border, proposing to spend $659 million — well short of the $3.7 billion President Obama seeks — to ease the humanitarian crisis after weeks of internal divisions and just days before Congress adjourns for its five-week August break.

headline: New Legislation Targets Inversions From Different Angle
text: Lawmakers in Washington ratcheted up the pressure on Tuesday on companies seeking tax relief by moving overseas, introducing a bill that would withhold government contracts from companies that undertake so-called inversion deals.

headline: Today in Small Business: Yelp Video
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: MetLife’s Low Profile May Work to Its Advantage
text: Quick, who’s the chief executive of MetLife? That the name Steve Kandarian doesn’t roll off the tongue for almost anyone who isn’t deeply steeped in the insurance business is probably a good thing for MetLife’s shareholders. How he handles his company’s inevitable designation later this week as a systemic threat to the financial industry could change that. A Jamie Dimon-style public spat with regulators would be foolish. Better to speak softly, and keep his relative anonymity intact.

headline: Beyoncé, a Legend of Rock, but Not Fashion
text: LAST WEEK, music history of a sort was made when Beyoncé became the first subject of an exhibition in the Legends of Rock section of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland not to actually be in the Hall herself.

headline: Proposed Rules Expose Rifts Among Bitcoin Enthusiasts
text: A new front has opened in the battle over Bitcoin.

headline: A Battle of the Hamlets
text: “Once you have played it, it will devour you and obsess you for the rest of your life,” Laurence Olivier wrote when he was in his mid-70s. “It has me. I think each day about it. I’ll never play him again, of course, but by God, I wish I could.”

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: Some investors are worried that fighting in the Middle East and the stalemate between Russia and the west could threaten the U.S. economy. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss how these and other events happening abroad could affect U.S. economic growth. Plus, more U.S. corporations are rushing to “invert,” or incorporate in another country with lower tax rates. Could this spate of inversions inspire Congress to change the tax code?

headline: Standing 100 Years? So You Should Sit
text: Because the kippered salmon, the slippery pink lengths of matjes herring and the shiny white sturgeon at the new Russ & Daughters Cafe are the same products you can take home from the old Russ & Daughters shop a few blocks away on East Houston Street, a cynic may say that the restaurant offers nothing more than an opportunity to eat the proprietors’ fish on their plates instead of yours.

headline: Trying to Make the Bet on Video Pay Off
text: Bruce Headlam is the managing editor of video. He oversees a department that The Times is counting on to expand its audience and to generate revenue through ad sales. One of his main tasks: convincing more reporters and editors that video is a critical part of news coverage.

headline: When the College Admissions Battle Starts at Age 3
text: The frenzy over getting children into elite New York preschools is well documented. Parents sweat, barter and bribe to get their 4-year-olds into prestigious early education programs. Toddlers take achievement tests and participate in observed playgroups to prove their potential.

headline: Drug Smuggling Charges for Rikers Island Officers
text: Two New York City correction officers and a former officer who resigned this year have been arrested on charges that they smuggled prescription pills and other contraband into Rikers Island, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Why Can’t the Banking Industry Solve Its Ethics Problems?
text: The financial crisis that nearly brought down the global economy was triggered in no small part by the aggressive culture and spotty ethics within the world’s biggest banks. But after six years and countless efforts to reform finance, the banking scandals never seem to end.

headline: Beauty Guru Tata Harper’s Guide to Vermont, Her Home State
text: From her 1200-acre farm in the Champlain Valley of Vermont, Tata Harper has built a beauty empire. The Colombian-born entrepreneur’s cult organic skincare and aromatherapy products, many made with herbs grown on site, are stocked everywhere from J.Crew to the world’s best boutiques. In August, she’ll launch her first color cosmetics product, Volumizing Lip and Cheek Tint, in three shades. Whether Harper’s radiant glow can be chalked up to her all-natural products or the benefits of rural living, the woman may be her own best advertisement. Just in time for the lazy days of late summer, when urbanites crowd the region’s verdant hills and valleys, Harper shares with T her most inspiring destinations for shopping, dining and relaxing around the Green Mountain State.

headline: A Crowdsourced Sonnet for a Summer’s Day in the Office
text: Back in May, The American Scholar invited office time wasters everywhere to help crowdsource a sonnet, starting with the Dilbert-meets-Shakespeare line “How like a prison is my cubicle.” Each week readers posted suggestions for the next line on the journal’s Web site, which were then winnowed by the poet David Lehman.

headline: $1.8 Million for Ventura in Defamation Case
text: ST. PAUL — Jesse Ventura, the wrestler-turned-politician-turned-television-host, has defied the odds before. More than a decade and a half ago, almost no one thought that a feather boa-wearing former professional wrestler could become the governor of Minnesota. In Mr. Ventura’s latest turn in the spotlight, some people questioned whether he could prevail in a claim that he had been defamed in a best-selling book, given the relatively high legal standard in such cases for public figures — and given Mr. Ventura’s lifetime of vivid, blunt and provocative pronouncements.

headline: Splendor in Solitude
text: ST.-ÉTIENNE-DE-BAÏGORRY, France — On a Saturday morning, this village in the French Pyrenees seems like any other small French town. Shoppers wend through the outdoor market while tourists snap photos. But resounding above the ordinary fray are the cries of young men playing pelote, a game akin to jai alai.

headline: Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Co. Opens in Brooklyn
text: Headliner

headline: Senate Confirms Obama’s Choice to Lead V.A.
text: The Senate voted unanimously on Tuesday to confirm Robert A. McDonald, the 61-year-old former chief executive of Procter & Gamble, to take the helm of the sprawling and embattled Department of Veterans Affairs after a scandal over the manipulation of patient wait-time data led to the ouster two months ago of Eric Shinseki.

headline: McDonald’s Ruling Could Open Door for Unions
text: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board ruled on Tuesday that McDonald’s could be held jointly liable for labor and wage violations by its franchise operators — a decision that, if upheld, would disrupt longtime practices in the fast-food industry and ease the way for unionizing nationwide.

headline: The Required White House Response on Marijuana
text: When the White House issued a statement last night saying that marijuana should remain illegal — responding to our pro-legalization editorial series — officials there weren’t just expressing an opinion. They were following the law. The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy is required by statute to oppose all efforts to legalize any banned drug.

headline: Trulia Co-Founder Rows Across Ocean as Company Is Sold to Zillow
text: As negotiations between Trulia and Zillow intensified in recent weeks, culminating in a $3.5 billion deal announced on Monday, one crucial player was conspicuously absent.

text: To Serve: Great Snacks Make the Party

headline: Fighting Cuts Off Access to Ukraine Air Crash Site
text: ROZSYPNE, Ukraine — The sprawling fields of debris where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed in eastern Ukraine, leaving a gruesome enough scene as it was, took on new macabre elements on Tuesday as the zone became a front line in the war here.

headline: A New ‘Band Wagon’ Coming to City Center
text: The Tony-winning actor Brian Stokes Mitchell (“Kiss Me, Kate,” “Man of La Mancha”) will star in a new production of “The Band Wagon,” to be staged by New York City Center as an Encores! special event in November. The production will be directed and choreographed by Kathleen Marshall. It opens on Nov. 6 at City Center, and runs through Nov. 16.

headline: Langrée Signs On for More Mostly Mozart
text: The longtime directors of two important classical music festivals have extended their contracts, the organizations announced Wednesday.

headline: Kerry Meets Ukraine’s Foreign Minister
text: Secretary of State John Kerry and Pavlo Klimkin, Ukraine’s foreign minister, spoke after meeting in Washington to discuss the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: John W. Mazzola, Former President of Lincoln Center, Dies at 86
text: John W. Mazzola, a former president of Lincoln Center who helped to inaugurate free outdoor events and the “Live From Lincoln Center” televised series of musical performances, while fighting for funds during the city’s 1970s financial crisis, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Judges Block Abortion Curb in Mississippi
text: NEW ORLEANS — A federal appeals panel on Tuesday blocked a Mississippi law that would have shut the sole abortion clinic in the state by requiring its doctors to obtain admitting privileges at local hospitals, something they had been unable to do.

headline: Verse as a Cold Compress for Those of Us on the Verge of Fainting
text: If you take poetry seriously, or even half-seriously, you read the dead-tree editions. Poetry seems tinned and trebly in digital formats, like Brahms’s Requiem played through smartphone speakers.

headline: Ex-New York Councilman Is Convicted in Corruption Case
text: A former New York City councilman was found guilty on Tuesday of taking bribes, orchestrating payoffs and participating in a scheme to help a Democratic state senator run for mayor as a Republican.

headline: Wall Street Bids Farewell to Alan Greenberg, Head of Bear Stearns
text: Alan D. Schwartz, the head of Bear Stearns during its final days in 2008, put his arm around Leslie Moonves, the chief of CBS, who stiffened his bottom lip.

headline: In Paris, a Playful Path Along the Seine
text: A few years ago, Voies sur Berges along the Seine on Paris’s Left Bank was one of the busiest two-lane thoroughfares in the city, with up to 2,200 vehicles passing through an hour. But on a warm afternoon in June, a different scene unfolded on the roadway. Along the water’s edge, a group of children could be heard singing “Joyeux Anniversaire” out of a large white tepee, while a glimpse into the canvas structure revealed a woman holding a candlelit birthday cake.

headline: In a Singapore Neighborhood, Gritty Mixes With Trendy
text: At first, it was the smell that kept people away. In the mid-19th century, farmers in Singapore’s Jalan Besar neighborhood used night soil (human waste) to fertilize their vegetable plots, prompting residents to give the main road the tongue-in-cheek name Lavender — still the name today. Jalan Besar has been on the gritty side of gleaming Singapore ever since, known primarily for its divey karaoke bars, cheap hotels and hardware shops. Lately, however, its low rents have lured design stores, trendy coffee shops and the beautifully restored Kam Leng Hotel. With a new metro line set to open in 2017, residents are bracing for the coming real estate boom.

headline: Elephants, My Brother and Me
text: The elephant didn’t seem particularly confused. It was merely curious. That was the only way to make sense of why, as it meandered down a street in a remote village in Thailand, it had chosen to stick its sizable head into the lobby of the no-frills hotel that I was grudgingly using as my base. My brother Michael and I exchanged glances and smiled.

headline: To Fully Appreciate Frozen Dumplings, I Learned to Make Them by Hand
text: While exploring the rise of refrigeration in China for last weekend’s magazine, I spent an entire day chatting with Chen Zemin, the former surgeon who invented the frozen dumpling in China. During my visit with Zemin, I tasted exotic dumpling flavors of the future and admired a roomful of high-tech machines that fill, pinch and fold dumplings in automated, origami-like fashion.

headline: Activist Hedge Fund Claims Victory at Mining Company Cliffs Natural Resources
text: The results aren’t in yet for the board election at Cliffs Natural Resources, the mining company. But the activist hedge fund seeking control of the board is feeling confident enough to declare victory anyway.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 5 | ‘I Changed My Definition of the Word “Lucky” ’
text: A video related to the Op-Ed column by Nicholas Kristof that this week’s Summer Reading Contest winner wrote about.

headline: Giants’ David Wilson Leaves Practice With Injury in Neck Area
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Running back David Wilson, the Giants’ 2012 first-round draft pick, who had off-season neck surgery, left Tuesday’s training camp practice with what seemed to be an injury to his neck or shoulder. Coach Tom Coughlin described the injury as a burner, a term for a nerve injury that leaves a burning or stinging sensation in the neck or shoulders.

headline: The Right, the Rich and Reciprocity
text: From the pundit’s perspective, the best thing about Paul Ryan’s new proposals on poverty is the way they’ve surfaced some very interesting debates about the welfare state, debates that tend to go underground when anti-poverty spending is just being discussed in the context of the overall fiscal picture and the quest (or not) for a balanced budget. In particular, it’s been interesting to watch Ryan’s liberal critics train so much fire at his blueprint’s support (not as a universal requirement, as I understand it, but as a potential model for states to follow) for a contractual approach to anti-poverty spending, in which beneficiaries draw up customized life plans, set goals and targets, and have rewards and penalties pegged to their follow-through on those responsibilities. The liberal critiques of this idea, from writers like Annie Lowrey and Jamelle Bouie among many others, have been genuinely informative: I feel (sincerely!) like I have a better handle on the left-of-center view of poverty and anti-poverty policy than I did a week ago, and hopefully my future posts on the subject will profit from that advance in understanding.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': The How-To’s of Hub-Bub
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses and performs “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Share Your Experiences as a Female Soldier or Veteran
text: The Times would like to hear from female soldiers and veterans about their deployment.

headline: Obama Says It’s Not a New Cold War

headline: China’s Account of Bloodshed in Far West Is Disputed
text: BEIJING — China’s state news media on Tuesday belatedly reported what was described as a terror attack in the troubled far west region of Xinjiang, where dozens of people were said to have been killed or wounded by assailants with knives and axes.

headline: Australian Cafes Arrive in New York
text: New York is a city of immigrants and their unofficial embassies offering a taste of home: the French bistro, the English pub, the California juice bar.

headline: World Cup Gave Twitter a Big Burst in Traffic
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The World Cup had a second winner: Twitter.

headline: Jaws Open, Monster Storm Hits East Coast
text: The only way to get through an East Coast sharknado is to savor the excess. So many sharks. So many cameos. So much promotional ballyhoo.

headline: At Behest of Judge, U.S. Shortens Man’s 57-Year Mandatory Sentence
text: A Queens man who had been serving a 57-year mandatory federal prison sentence was resentenced on Tuesday to time served, capping a judge’s extraordinary efforts to undo the damage from what he believed was a grossly excessive sentence.

headline: St. John’s Concours Celebrated Virgil Exner Designs and Jet-Age Pickups
text: PLYMOUTH, Mich. — Compared with other prestigious showings of classic and special interest automobiles, the atmosphere at the Concours d'Élégance of America at St. John’s  held here on Sunday, was unhurried and informal, a perfect setting for a casual amble among acres of fascinating automobiles.

headline: Letter From Leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb to a Sahara-Based Militant Commander
text: In a letter from 2012, the leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb reprimanded Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a commander in the Sahara, for a range of offenses, including negotiating the release of two hostages for a “meager price” and without consultation.

headline: Al Qaeda Letter on the Importance of Kidnapping Revenue
text: In a letter dated Aug. 6, 2012, the leader of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and second in command of Al Qaeda, wrote to the leader of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb about the groups’ reliance on kidnapping ransoms to fund operations.

headline: Paying Ransoms, Europe Bankrolls Qaeda Terror
text: BAMAKO, Mali — The cash filled three suitcases: 5 million euros.

headline: Rules of Style | DJ Harvey, Dance-Floor Legend and Man of Fashion, on High-Waisted Pants and “International Hair”
text: If, as the disco act Indeep once sang, D.J.’s can save lives, then Harvey Bassett might be classified as sort of an elite ER surgeon of the profession. A music connoisseur’s music connoisseur, the British-born turntablist known as DJ Harvey has spent four decades collecting records and is frequently flown around the world to play them. A teenage punk rocker turned fixture of the U.K. dance-party scene in the ’80s and ’90s, Bassett has in recent years returned to making his own music (the house-centric album Locussolus, the genre-blending collaboration Map of Africa). His latest project, Wildest Dreams, releases its self-titled debut on Smalltown Supersound today. Its lo-fi psychedelic rock songs were inspired by the mood of Los Angeles and Bassett’s nostalgia for his garage-band youth. “It sounds like the music I was making 40 years ago when I was 11 years old and we wanted to be like Cream or the Jimi Hendrix Experience,” he says. A track from the album, “Rollerskates,” appears here.

headline: She Has Seen Too Much, and It Shows
text: Buried beneath a shlubby wardrobe and a sulky demeanor, Catherine Keener drags herself through “War Story” like one of those exhausted mothers in a missing-child movie. What her character has lost, though, isn’t her offspring — it’s her marbles.

headline: Photos of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Bangladesh and Iraq.

headline: President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to Step Down
text: Emily K. Rafferty, the first woman to be named president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, announced on Tuesday that she was stepping down after 10 years in that role and nearly four decades at the institution, which she is credited with financially shepherding through a period of sustained growth.

headline: In Reversal, Nepal to Allow Cremation of Tibetan Monk

headline: For Hostages of Al Qaeda, Objects from Their Captivity Still Carry Meaning

headline: Investment in Angolan Banking May Prove a Crippling Deal for Portugal
text: LISBON — For Portugal, the oil-producing Angola provided a lifeline during a euro debt crisis that weakened its economy so much that the country had to negotiate an international bailout in 2011.

headline: Falcons vs. Windmills
text: The Flow Country is a wonderfully named patch of peat bog nestled in the Scottish Highlands, and the MacLeod family has lived there for going on four generations. They are a clan of falconers extraordinaire, and their home, Thrumster Estates, is a worldwide epicenter for falconry — an age-old form of sport hunting through the use of trained birds of prey.

headline: Profits Soaring After Disgrace at Cohen’s Hedge Fund
text: Updated, 8:38 p.m. | Three months after his once-powerful hedge fund entered a guilty plea to insider trading charges, Steven A. Cohen is doing quite well.

headline: Evolving on Marijuana
text: Highlights from the Editorial Board’s changing view of marijuana over six decades.

headline: Vintage Hip-Hop in the Hamptons
text: Some surveys indicate that the average American man is six inches taller than his wife. At the Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation’s 15th Annual Art for Life benefit in Bridgehampton, N.Y., on Saturday, it appeared to be the other way around.

headline: Scene City: Vintage Hip-Hop in the Hamptons
text: Russell Simmons hosts 15th annual Rush For Life benefit.

headline: Obama Announces New Russian Sanctions
text: The president, speaking from the South Lawn of the White House, discussed new economic sanctions against Russia amid unrest in neighboring Ukraine.

headline: Cambodia Looks to Put Its Rice on the World’s Plate
text: KBAL GOH, Cambodia — For as long as Cambodian rice farmers can remember, their product has had an unsavory reputation. Tough, dirty and unmilled, it was impossible to cook evenly, and even farmers traded it as pig feed in exchange for cash or better-quality rice from Vietnam or Thailand.

headline: A Film-Noirish Carmen, Down Mexico Way
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — It’s no secret that Carmen is one of the most coveted roles in the repertory of a mezzo-soprano. In fact, Bizet’s sultry, headstrong Gypsy girl, who is willing to die rather than have her freedom curtailed, is such a fascinating character and so richly endowed with great melodies that sopranos covet the part, too.

headline: So Much Doomed Passion
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Lycurgus, the fictional New York town in which much of Theodore Dreiser’s novel “An American Tragedy” is set, was based on Cortland, just 70 miles west of the Glimmerglass Festival here. The plot’s crucial murder takes place in the Adirondacks, which the characters get to by traveling right through this area.

headline: Jason Bauer
text: Mr. Bauer, 44, is the chief executive of Voda Bauer Real Estate, a brokerage and investment firm based in New York that he started this spring with Avi Voda, a longtime broker at Douglas Elliman Real Estate.

headline: Labor Struggles at Metropolitan Opera Have a Past
text: There was the 1906 performance when the great Enrico Caruso sang the title role of Gounod’s “Faust” for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, and the chorus walked out on strike: “Performance Was Queer,” The New York Times reported of the chorus-less opera.

headline: Barry Diller’s IAC to Buy the Princeton Review
text: IAC, the Internet conglomerate that includes online dating and shopping sites, is betting on the business of test preparation.

headline: Punch Lines, Commentary and Rants
text: Last week Weird Al Yankovic’s “Mandatory Fun” became the first comedy album to go to the top of the Billboard charts since the early 1960s. Back then, when the comedy club was still in its infancy, this was more common. Allan Sherman and Bob Newhart both reached No. 1. But if such albums were more prominent then, the scale of the current comedy boom, as well as the many formats available for distribution, mean that there have probably never been more funny specials available than right now. Weird Al’s success may be a sign of comedy’s ascent, but the volume of specials released online, on streaming services and even on vinyl represents a more significant shift in this fertile art form. Here are a few 2014 releases (all available on iTunes) worth your attention.

headline: Carl Icahn Cuts His Stake in Family Dollar
text: After Family Dollar Stores announced a plan to sell itself to Dollar Tree Inc. for $8.5 billion, the billionaire Carl C. Icahn publicly held out hope that someone else would come in and make a higher offer.

headline: Dubai’s Hotel Boom Has Designer Labels
text: DUBAI — The air-conditioning vents in the Palazzo Versace hotel here zigzag like the Versace design. Every piece of the giant, colorful mosaics that decorate the bathtubs is handmade and imported from Italy. Staff uniforms will be designed by the House of Versace.

headline: No Cigars, No Cigar Illness
What Debate? Economists Agree the Stimulus Lifted the Economy
text: Here’s a simple case study making the point that our political debates about economics have become largely unhinged from those among actual economists. Take the Obama stimulus plan, known as the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. If you took your cues from the political rhetoric in Washington — or even from the occasional virulent debate in the economics blogosphere — you would think the whole question of fiscal stimulus is highly contested.

headline: The Battle of the Crater
text: By the end of July 1864, Union forces were entrenched outside Petersburg, Va., a major city south of Richmond. To break the siege, commanders in the IX Corps came up with a novel idea: A regiment of Pennsylvania coal miners dug a tunnel 511 feet long, right up under a Confederate strongpoint, and packed four tons of blasting powder into galleries at its end. When the mine was touched off it would blow a huge breach in the Rebel lines, through which infantry could attack and seize the high ground that commanded Petersburg.

headline: Brooks Sports Moves New Home Closer to Trails
text: SEATTLE — In August, nearly 300 employees of the running shoe and apparel company Brooks Sports Inc. will head to work at the company’s new global headquarters, three miles north of downtown Seattle.

headline: More Financial Struggles for DreamWorks Animation

headline: The Federal Marijuana Ban Is Rooted in Myth and Xenophobia
text: The federal law that makes possession of marijuana a crime has its origins in legislation that was passed in an atmosphere of hysteria during the 1930s and that was firmly rooted in prejudices against Mexican immigrants and African-Americans, who were associated with marijuana use at the time. This racially freighted history lives on in current federal policy, which is so driven by myth and propaganda that it is almost impervious to reason.

headline: The Carbon Dividend
text: AMHERST, Mass. — FROM the scorched earth of climate debates a bold idea is rising — one that just might succeed in breaking the nation’s current political impasse on reducing carbon emissions. That’s because it would bring tangible gains for American families here and now.

text: ESPN suspended Stephen A. Smith for a week on Tuesday for comments that suggested women should avoid provoking men into assaulting them.

headline: Washington Prepares to Host Meeting of African Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — Federal officials have warned government employees here that the arrival next week of 50 African leaders — and their motorcades — will bring city traffic to a standstill during a two-day White House summit meeting about issues on the continent.

headline: Assistant in Cruelty Case Is Rehired
text: Steve Asmussen, the accomplished trainer under investigation for cruelty to his horses, has rehired Scott Blasi, the assistant trainer at the center of the accusations who was caught on videotape speaking profanely and cavalierly about the stable’s injured horses.

headline: Massachusetts: Lawmakers Finalize Bill Aimed at Protesters Outside Abortion Clinics
text: Lawmakers on Tuesday finalized legislation intended to prevent demonstrators from hindering patients and employees who are entering abortion clinics. The bill, proposed after the United States Supreme Court struck down a state law that barred demonstrators from standing less than 35 feet from a clinic entrance, would allow the police to disperse an assembly of one or more that “substantially impedes” passage to a clinic entrance. It would also require those individuals to stay 25 feet away from the entrance for, at most, eight hours after a dispersal order. The bill would also expand the suite of civil actions the state could take if the law was violated. The bill was sent to Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, who was expected to sign it.

headline: Theodore Van Kirk, 93, Enola Gay Navigator, Dies
text: Theodore (Dutch) Van Kirk, the navigator and last surviving crew member of the Enola Gay, the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in the last days of World War II, died on Monday at his home in Stone Mountain, Ga. He was 93.

headline: Colorado Clerk Told to Stop Issuing Marriage Licenses to Gay Couples
text: DENVER — The Colorado Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered a county clerk in Boulder to stop issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, halting the practice a month after a handful of county clerks had defied a ban in the State Constitution.

headline: Loss of Shelter and Electricity Worsens a Crisis for Fleeing Gazans
text: GAZA CITY — When artillery shattered their home near the Israeli border, Ibrahim Hillis, a grandfather, rushed his extended family to the city to seek shelter, but the schools were full and relatives’ houses were already packed with others displaced by the war.

headline: Corcoran Chairman Defends Merger Plan in Court
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the board of trustees of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, which after years of financial struggle is seeking legal permission to dissolve itself into the National Gallery of Art, testified in court here on Tuesday that the 145-year-old museum had essentially lost its ability to attract donors and could not remain a stand-alone institution.

headline: Rutgers and Maryland Get Skeptical Big Ten Welcome
text: CHICAGO — Intercollegiate football made its debut 145 years ago this November in New Brunswick, N.J., a fact that Rutgers, that game’s host, proudly proclaims.

text: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced his first labor agreements with New York City unions this spring, he was sharply criticized for granting long-awaited wage increases in exchange for promises of unspecified though sizable savings on health care expenses.

text: Updated, 6:38 a.m. | Barring a last-minute deal, Argentina will default on billions of dollars of bonds on Wednesday.

headline: Margot Adler, 68, Journalist and Priestess, Dies

headline: Jets Are Asking New Back to Outrun Only Humans
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Last year, Chris Johnson raced a cheetah. Perhaps you heard about it, or watched it, on the Nat Geo Wild channel or the Internet. Johnson did not win, but that is not the point.

headline: Using Cardboard to Bring Disabled Children Out of the Exile of Wrong Furniture
text: Sylvia Maxine VanDunk bent over a carpenter’s workbench on Tuesday morning and carefully slathered a sheet of cardboard with a layer of white glue from an Elmer’s squeeze bottle. Then she laced the cardboard with a coating of clear glue, this one streamed from the barrel of a heat gun.

headline: V.A. Chief Spent Career Seeking Out Tough Tasks
text: After nearly drowning as a child, Robert McDonald was so terrified of water that despite earning dozens of Boy Scout merit badges, he refused to take the swim test to become an Eagle Scout.

headline: M. Caldwell Butler, a Key Vote Against Nixon, Dies at 89
text: M. Caldwell Butler, who as a first-term Republican representative from Virginia wept after he voted to impeach President Richard M. Nixon, whose landslide 1972 re-election victory had propelled Mr. Butler into Congress, died on Tuesday in Roanoke, Va. He was 89.

headline: ‘Maybe in America’
text: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar — I’ve been arguing that the big divide in the world these days is between the world of order and a growing world of disorder. If you’re keeping score at home, the world of disorder just added another country: Libya. America quietly folded up its embassy in Libya last week and left, leaving behind a tribal/militia war of all against all. Not good.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Latest Excuses

text: WASHINGTON — Gun rights advocates have been working for years to undo the District of Columbia’s tough restrictions on firearms ownership. Now they have won a new legal victory — one that has thrown city officials into a tailspin over the prospect of gun owners carrying weapons on the streets of the nation’s capital.

text: AKRON, Ohio — Now that Rory McIlroy has won his third major, his next goal is to claim his first World Golf Championships title this week at the Bridgestone Invitational. In developmental terms, it is as if McIlroy had figured out how to run before he could walk.

headline: Just 2 to 13, Once
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Remember when I said that I was heavily influenced by what I see in the puzzle, and that every time a constructor puts food in their grid I get an insatiable craving for it? Jean O’Conor is clearly taking advantage of me.

headline: In Church Attics, Clues to the Private Life of Early America

headline: Private, Killed 70 Years Ago in the Pacific, Is Laid to Rest
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Pfc. Randolph Allen of Rush, Ky., 19 years old, was among the more than 1,000 Marines who were killed during three days of intense fighting to capture the tiny island of Betio from the Japanese during World War II.

headline: To Arrest Fugitives, Officers Try to Anticipate the Unpredictable
text: When they entered a cramped Greenwich Village smoke shop to arrest a fugitive on child molestation charges on Monday, the three law enforcement officers were well prepared. They had handguns and Kevlar vests, and, perhaps most important, hours of training on the many situations they might encounter.

headline: North Carolina Budget Deal Includes a Raise for Teachers
text: Leaders of the Republican-controlled North Carolina legislature on Tuesday announced details of a tentative budget agreement, including a 7 percent pay raise for teachers in public schools, that could end a monthlong stalemate that has exposed a breach between Republican conservatives and moderates in the state.

headline: Police Bullets Abruptly Ended an Invisible Life, Lived in the Open
text: To many who knew him in New York City, he was simply John, the affable, heavyset guy with a beard and ponytail who sold marijuana glassware and blended easily into the burlesque backdrop of West Fourth Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: Suit Filed Against N.H.L.
text: Another class-action lawsuit against the N.H.L. was filed Tuesday by former players saying that the league took insufficient action to reduce brain injuries caused by concussive and sub-concussive impacts. Jon Rohloff, a defenseman for the Boston Bruins from 1994 to 1997, is the lone named plaintiff in the suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Minnesota. The suit says that the league concealed the dangers of concussion and did not pass rules designed to reduce the risk of brain injury until recent seasons. N.H.L. representatives did not respond to a request for comment late Tuesday afternoon. After a similar suit was filed in April, Bill Daly, the deputy commissioner, said, “We are completely satisfied with our record on player safety, including as it relates to head injuries and brain trauma.”

headline: As Sanctions Pile Up, Russians’ Alarm Grows Over Putin’s Tactics
text: MOSCOW — Russia, facing the toughest round of Western sanctions imposed since the Ukraine crisis erupted, has adopted a nonchalant public stance, with President Vladimir V. Putin emphasizing the importance of self-reliance and a new poll released Tuesday indicating a “What, me worry?” attitude among the bulk of the population.

headline: New York Educators Fight Back on Attacks to Tenure
text: Education advocates in recent days have assailed job protections for New York teachers as antiquated, unwarranted and unconstitutional.

headline: Surgeon General Calls for Action to Reduce Skin Cancer Rate
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top doctor called on Tuesday for immediate action to reduce the rate of skin cancer, the most commonly diagnosed cancer in the country and one that is often preventable.

headline: NYU Langone Medical Center to Get $1.13 Billion in Storm Aid
text: NYU Langone Medical Center, which was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy and had to be evacuated, will receive $1.13 billion in recovery aid, the second-largest award for a single project in the history of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, hospital and federal officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Honoring a Filmmaker in the Shadow of Apartheid
text: DURBAN, South Africa — Unknown among his fellow white South Africans, Tonie van der Merwe was the most popular filmmaker among black audiences in the 1970s and ’80s. He churned out about 400 movies under an apartheid subsidy system established to produce movies exclusively for blacks — with the right political and moral content. In fact, he helped create the system.

headline: Hamels, Repeatedly Finding Strike Zone, Handles Mets
text: This was perhaps Cole Hamels’s last start as a member of the Philadelphia Phillies, the team that drafted him and cultivated him and rode his left arm to a World Series title in 2008. But he did not seem to be in a savoring mood against the Mets on Tuesday night.

headline: North Korea: Images Show Work on Rocket Site
text: North Korea has nearly completed construction of an improved site for launching long-range missiles and appears to have conducted multiple tests of rocket motors for them, the U.S.-Korea Institute, part of the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, said Tuesday in a report based on assessments of recent commercial satellite images. It said the improvements at the site, the Sohae Satellite Launching Station, near the border with China, suggested that North Korea intended to launch “larger rockets with greater ranges and payloads.” The report, published on the institute’s website, 38north, was the latest indication that North Korea was moving toward another launching at Sohae, where it successfully fired a long-range missile in December 2012 that reached as far as the Philippines.

headline: Preserving the Church’s Past
text: Margaret Bendroth, the executive director at the Congregational Library in Boston, reflected on its mission to preserve centuries-old artifacts that come from churches in Massachusetts.

headline: ‘Joe Bullet’ Trailer
text: Tonie van der Merwe was the most popular filmmaker among black audiences in the 1970s and 1980s. He churned out some 400 movies including “Joe Bullet,” a blaxploitation-inspired film.

headline: China Investigating Microsoft for ‘Monopolistic Behavior’
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government announced that Microsoft faced investigation for possible violations of antimonopoly laws, and confirmed that officials had conducted surprise visits to the company’s offices across the country, a statement released late Tuesday said.

headline: Pulling From Their Past, Lakers Turn to Scott to Rekindle Success
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — The reasons the Lakers hired Byron Scott as their latest coach were all around the makeshift stage that was set up on their practice court.

headline: A New Fashionable Tote for the Farmers’ Market
text: “We’re all at the farmers’ market at least once a week,” says Monica Zwirner, the co-founder of the accessories label MZ Wallace, as she nimbly packs her label’s newest offering, a handsome navy blue market tote, full of ears of corn, tomatoes and wild flowers. The “we” to which she refers includes her business partner, the former fashion magazine editor Lucy Wallace Eustice, and Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs, the food writers and co-founders of the online cooking community Food52. The four women have gathered at the Union Square Greenmarket to test drive their first creative collaboration, what they describe as the ultimate farmers’ market tote. After filling it to the brim, they head back to the Food52 studio to whip up a celebratory lunch of tomato salad with corn, summer squash and roasted onions.

headline: A Former Hedge-Funder Finds His Passion Selling Handmade Turkish Shoes
text: When the young entrepreneur Mickey Ashmore was a student at University of Pennsylvania, he wrote a note to himself that said simply “live in Istanbul one day.” Then when he graduated in 2009, Ashmore went to work for Microsoft, where he was offered a position abroad — in Turkey. And it was there, in the city of his dreams, that Ashmore found inspiration for what would become his first entrepreneurial venture: sabahs, slip-on footwear made from high-quality leather stitched to a rubber sole, a craft that originated in the old Turkish bazaars.

headline: Running 5 Minutes a Day Has Long-Lasting Benefits
text: Running for as little as five minutes a day could significantly lower a person’s risk of dying prematurely, according to a large-scale new study of exercise and mortality. The findings suggest that the benefits of even small amounts of vigorous exercise may be much greater than experts had assumed.

headline: More Californians Sign Up for Health Plans, Survey Says, but Holdouts May Be Hard to Get
text: While a new survey of the uninsured in California shows that nearly six out of 10 people were able to obtain coverage in the last year, the findings offer fresh insight into just how difficult it may be to sign up the people who remain uninsured, even after the introduction of the new state marketplaces.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (CW) PENN & TELLER: FOOL US Aspiring magicians perform their best tricks (but only once) for Penn & Teller, who must try to figure them out in this new series. Anyone who succeeds in trumping Penn & Teller (above, from left) gets to perform with them at the Rio Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas. Mark Shorland, Mathieu Bich, Young & Strange and Daniel Madison are up first; Jonathan Ross hosts.

headline: Offensive Outburst Turns Out to Be Just Enough to Lift Yanks
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — If the Yankees were waiting for one big inning to finally ignite a stagnant offense, a seven-run sixth in Tuesday night’s 12-11 victory over the Texas Rangers served as the kick-starter.

headline: Corrections: July 30, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 30, 2014
text: “Why isn’t anybody coming here to pick up the pieces?”

headline: Israeli Shells Are Said to Hit a U.N. School
text: JABALIYA, Gaza Strip — The strikes came in rapid succession. Around 5 a.m. on Wednesday at a United Nations school at the Jabaliya refugee camp, where 3,300 Palestinians had taken refuge from the fierce fighting in their Gaza Strip neighborhoods, what appeared to be four Israeli artillery shells hit the compound.

headline: Spotlight Falls on China’s Former Security Chief
text: Updated, 5:05 a.m. ET| After disappearing from view for months, Zhou Yongkang has returned. The official announcement Tuesday evening that China’s Communist Party is conducting an investigation into the former chief of domestic security prompted an easing of the censorship surrounding his case. While the public may never set eyes on him again, his image is suddenly ubiquitous.

headline: Barclays Posts a Profit, but Inquiries Loom
text: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | LONDON – Barclays said on Wednesday that it swung to a profit in the second quarter, but, like many of its investment banking peers, continued to be hampered by a series of litigation and regulatory issues.

headline: In Search of the Next Andrew Wiggins
text: “Everything’s wrong,” Terrance Williams said, his voice growing raspier with each word. He looked around at the teenagers on his basketball team, many of whom were chewing the necks of their jerseys and staring at the ground. “Shot selection! Body language!”

headline: More on Sleeping Pills and Older Adults
text: Call me nuts, but I want to talk more about sleeping pill use.

headline: Confronting Sexuality and Identity in China
text: Expecting to ring in the New Year at a Beijing bar, Tomoko Kikuchi was stood up by a friend. Instead, she started chatting to Meimei, a drag queen who invited her to a performance at a lesbian bar. As she waited for the show to begin, an argument broke out between two women in the crowd. The show went on: Meimei performed amid flying beers and blood, as if to a rapt audience.

headline: AstraZeneca to Pay Almirall Up to $2.1 Billion for Respiratory Drugs
text: Updated, 9:30 a.m. | LONDON – AstraZeneca of Britain said on Wednesday that it had agreed to pay up to $2.1 billion for a slate of respiratory drugs from the Spanish drug maker Almirall.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Wheelies: The Lighter (but Not in the Wallet) Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: New York Today: Fish and Knish
text: Good morning on this nice Wednesday.

headline: Daily Report: World Cup Gives Twitter a Lift
text: The social networking company Twitter reported strong growth in the second quarter, Vindu Goel reports, driven in part by heavy use of the service by soccer fans around the world during the monthlong World Cup tournament, which spanned June and July.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The European Union agreed on Tuesday to a new and higher level of sanctions against Russia, including the closing of European capital markets to Russian state banks, an embargo on new weapons sales and the transfer of sophisticated oil drilling technology,” says an editorial in The New York Times. “The United States followed suit shortly with measures meant to match the Europeans.” These punitive actions are “designed to exact a heavy price from President Vladimir Putin” for Russia’s escalation of direct involvement in the wake of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash. Compounding the situation are “public charges by the United States that Russia has violated a fundamental arms control accord, the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty.” The editorial states that “economic sanctions are a flawed and double-edged weapon, but, short of armed force, they are the only tools” available to the West to demonstrate that “breaking the rules of international behavior carries a cost.”

headline: China Moves to Ease Home-Registration Rules in Urbanization Push
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government issued proposals on Wednesday to break down barriers that a nationwide household registration system has long imposed between rural and urban residents and among regions, reinforcing inequality, breeding discontent and hampering economic growth.

headline: Tyler Cowen on Inequality and What Really Ails America
text: Is it misguided to focus so much attention on the vast income chasm opening between the very rich and the rest? Tyler Cowen, a professor of economics at George Mason University, evidently thinks so.

headline: What a New Search Tool is Turning Up
text: Last week, The Times’s Research and Development Lab made a search tool called Chronicle available to the public. Chronicle allows users to chart the use of a phrase or word through the paper’s history. Until now, it had been used only for research internally.

headline: The Lawyer’s Apprentice
text: When Chris Tittle meets new people and the topic turns to his work, he sometimes fishes in his pockets and produces a business card that reads “Abraham Lincoln.” Below the 16th president’s name in smaller type the card reads, “Just kidding, but I hope to follow in some of his footsteps.”

headline: Curalate Expands Its Analytic Tools to Cover Facebook, Instagram and Tumblr
text: Last year we published a post about Curalate, a start-up that enabled brands to monitor their visual presence on Pinterest. As online conversations turn increasingly visual, Curalate’s analytic tools tell brands what consumers are saying about them with their photographs.

headline: Telefónica Says It Is in Talks to Buy a Mexican Rival
text: LONDON – The Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica said on Wednesday that it was in talks to buy a Mexican rival in a deal reported to be worth up to $4 billion.

headline: Carlyle, Selling Assets Into an Eager Market, Doubles Its Profit
text: The Carlyle Group managed to double its profit in the second quarter, but Wall Street expected a bit more.

headline: ‘Fury,’ Starring Brad Pitt, a Raw Look at Warfare
text: LOS ANGELES — In the first minutes of the writer-director David Ayer’s “Fury,” about American soldiers slogging through Europe in the final days of World War II, Brad Pitt, as the tanker Don Collier, slides his knife behind the eye of a German lieutenant.

headline: James Wolcott and Frank Bidart Among 2014 PEN American Winners
text: The poet Frank Bidart, the critic James Wolcott and the playwright David Rabe are among the winners of the 2014 PEN Literary Awards, announced today by the PEN/American Center.

headline: Flash-Sale Sites: Do They Still Matter?
text: Some excitement in the business community this week over the news, first reported by Reuters, that Rue La La, the flash-sale site, may be up for sale for $400 million. JP Morgan is said to be advising the company, which lends some heft to the deal.

headline: Morning Agenda: Profit Soars at Steven Cohen’s Firm
text: Three months after his once-powerful hedge fund entered a guilty plea to insider trading charges, Steven A. Cohen is continuing to make an astounding amount of money from trading stocks and bonds, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein writes. His rechristened firm, Point72 Asset Management, which manages $9 billion to $10 billion of his personal fortune, is proving to be nearly as profitable as his former hedge fund, generating a profit of nearly $1 billion, over the first six months of this year. In 2013, SAC Capital Advisors’ last year as a hedge fund, Mr. Cohen personally made about $2.3 billion.

headline: Bouncing Back, Economy Grew 4% for Quarter
text: The United States economy rebounded strongly in the second quarter of the year, shaking off the negative effects of an unusually harsh winter and stirring hopes that it might finally be establishing a solid enough footing to put the lingering effects of the recession squarely in the past.

headline: Children Replacing Dogs in Walt Whitman Park
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Tears, and Anger, as Militants Destroy Iraq City’s Relics
text: BAGHDAD — When the Sunni extremists ruling Mosul destroyed the shrine of a prophet whose story features in the traditions of Islam, Christianity and Judaism — the most important of nearly two dozen marked for destruction by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria in the first seven weeks of its reign — small groups of residents gathered to mourn.

headline: Looking for Inspiration? Rejoice, O Mobile Poet!
text: FEAR not, fans of poetry: The app world has not left you behind. Some will even help you write your own poetry.

headline: App Smart | Writing Poetry
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will help you discover, read and even compose new poems.

headline: Square Plans a New, Chip-Friendly Credit Card Reader
text: For the entire credit card industry, everything old is about to be new again. And Square, the e-commerce start-up, wants to cash in on the opportunity.

headline: De Villiers May Gain an American Audience, Posthumously
text: When Gérard de Villiers died of cancer last fall at age 83, he left behind a publishing legacy that any best-selling novelist would envy. In his lifetime, he published more than 200 espionage novels, which often hinged on and in some cases anticipated major geopolitical events. He grew even more prolific toward the end of his life, writing five books a year.

headline: Strong Growth in G.D.P., but Some Caveats
text: Well, that’s a nice surprise. Gross domestic product grew at a 4 percent annual rate in the second quarter of the year, far better than the 3 percent analysts had forecast, and a sharp turnaround from the 2.1 percent contraction (previously thought to be 2.9 percent) of the winter-weather-stricken first quarter.

headline: Gazpacho: Not Hot and Not a Bother
text: The simple chilled soup is perfect for steamy August days.

headline: Russia Scorns Sanctions; Ukraine Army Forges On
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The day after the European Union and the United States announced expanded sanctions against Russia over the conflict in eastern Ukraine, Moscow remained defiant, the Ukrainian Army remained on the offensive, and an international team remained unable to reach the crash site of a Malaysian jetliner.

headline: New York’s Abortion Protest Law Is Praised by Justices, but Few Others
text: A crowd of abortion opponents converged on Zena Khan outside of the Choices Women’s Medical Center in Jamaica, Queens, on a recent Saturday. As a blurred mustard sun broke through the morning haze, Ms. Khan sped past posters depicting dismembered fetuses, flip cameras trained on her face and protesters demanding that she get back in her car and leave.

headline: Comic Con
text: The “man with a plan” is a common character in television dramas like “House” and “White Collar.” These cunning schemers take risks their advisers always seem to question. Just when it seems they’ll have to face the consequences of their criminal or unethical actions, they make a clean getaway, because ultimately their motives are good.

headline: Do California’s Gun Laws Prevent Gun Deaths?
text: Do gun-control laws prevent gun deaths?

headline: Britain Upholds Ban of Defunct Hedge Fund’s Former Chief
text: LONDON — A British tribunal has dismissed an appeal by Alberto Micalizzi, formerly chief executive of the defunct London hedge fund Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, who two years ago was fined and barred from working in the financial sector in Britain.

headline: Scenes of U.N. School Attacked in Gaza
text: Christopher Gunness, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency spokesman, discussed the deadly shelling at a school at the Jabaliya refugee camp, where 3,300 Palestinians had taken shelter.

headline: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Crash Tests More Small Cars
text: Among the most recent group of 12 small cars to undergo the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s small-overlap frontal crash test, only the Mini Cooper Countryman earned the highest rating of Good.

headline: Wall Township, N.J.: Off the Beach, Still at the Shore
text: Joe Pilla wanted to move his family closer to the beach. Jamie Petagna and her fiancé were looking for a house with a sizable property that they could move into together. Jennifer Vourlos had decided to become a homeowner, but needed to find something she could afford in the rather pricey part of New Jersey where she works. All three were able to achieve their goals in Wall Township.

headline: A Debate About Plagiarism as The Times Investigates a Case
text: Here are a few of the realities of journalism in the digital age: Cutting and pasting an encyclopedia sentence into one’s notes, and then changing a few words around for a story is simple enough. And what’s almost as simple is comparing those sentences with a digital search.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,700,000
text: TOPSAIL BEACH, N.C.

headline: 1889: Natives Hate the Germans
text: The Germans, up to the present hour, have achieved little on the East Coast of Africa. Some native towns along the coast have been destroyed and the flag of United Germany floats on the walls of Bagamoyo; but the natives sullenly refuse to have any dealings with the invader, and all the efforts to induce them to come in and trade have hitherto failed, notwithstanding the vast sums of money that have been and are still being lavishly squandered by Captain Wissmann to purchase at least an appearance of friendship with the black men. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 31, 1889

headline: Why We Love Dinosaurs
text: The defining amusement park ride of my childhood was not Space Mountain, not It’s A Small World, not even the now-rebranded Submarine Voyage. It was a few miles away at Knott’s Berry Farm: I speak of Kingdom of the Dinosaurs.

headline: House Hunting in ... Scotland
text: A RENOVATED VICTORIAN ESTATE IN SOUTHWEST SCOTLAND

headline: The Vienna Sound
text: The Vienna Philharmonic has retained a distinct sound that sets it apart from other orchestras in the 21st century. Its uniqueness is attributed to an unusual combination of instruments and style.

headline: Q. and A.: Exploring What’s Behind the Battle Over Argentina’s Debt
text: Argentina is on the verge of defaulting on billions of dollars of government debt. It has reached this point after years of battling a group of New York hedge funds that have been demanding full payment on bonds that defaulted in 2001. The battle has already rocked international debts markets and may affect the economies of other countries in the future. Below are answers to questions about the fight, which has taken complicated twists and turns over the years.

headline: I Say ‘Gross.’ They Say ‘Cool.’
text: I suppose, on some level, it was really cool.

headline: After Deadly Clash, China and Uighurs Disagree on Events That Led to Violence
text: BEIJING — More details emerged Wednesday about a bloody clash between Chinese security forces and ethnic Uighurs in the country’s far west two days ago, suggesting that dozens of people died when a protest against government policies turned violent.

headline: Today in Small Business: Buy Nearby Guy
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Viennese Horn
text: Wolfgang Vladar demonstrates the “round” sound of the Viennese horn.

headline: The Viennese Waltz
text: Rainer Honeck, a concertmaster in the Vienna Philharmonic, plays an excerpt of music in two different ways. First, in its strict three-quarters time — as written. Then, in the Viennese style.

headline: The Viennese Oboe
text: Clemens Horak and Stuart Breczinski demonstrate the distinct sound of the Viennese oboe used by the Vienna Philharmonic.

headline: Stealth Single Payer
text: The Kaiser Family Foundation has a new survey (pdf) on Obamacare in California, and it’s full of remarkably good news. For those who haven’t been following this, CA — with its now-dominant Democratic Party — is where Obamacare was implemented the way it was supposed to be implemented: the website worked pretty well from the beginning, Medicaid expansion was implemented, and the state worked hard on outreach. It was also a place that really needed reform: the uninsured were a high percentage of the population, and an individual market without community rating meant that the mere hint of a preexisting condition was enough to prevent coverage.

headline: Senators Offer Bill to Curb Campus Sexual Assault
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators on Wednesday introduced legislation designed to curb the startling number of sexual assaults on college campuses. The measure would require schools to make public the result of anonymous surveys concerning assault on campuses, and impose significant financial burdens on universities that fail to comply with some of the law’s requirements.

headline: A Camera Meant Never to Lose Its Focus
text: In 2006, Ren Ng, a graduate student at Stanford, published a doctoral thesis outlining a revolutionary technology in photography that almost seemed like an illusion.

headline: Eurozone Banks More Open to Lending, Survey Shows
text: FRANKFURT — Banks in the eurozone are more willing to lend to businesses for the first time in seven years, a survey by the European Central Bank showed on Wednesday, raising hopes that one essential component of economic growth could be starting to recover.

headline: The Case Against a Mammoth Frick Collection Addition
text: New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission would do well to turn down the Frick Collection’s proposed expansion, which imagines replacing a prized garden on East 70th Street in Manhattan with a clumsy addition. The city should avoid another self-inflicted wound, and there are other options.

headline: Religious Conservatives Embrace Pollution Fight
text: WASHINGTON — The Rev. Lennox Yearwood punched his fist in the air as he rhythmically boomed into the microphone: “This is a moment for great leadership. This is a moment for our country to stand up. This is our moment.”

headline: A Taste of Barcelona’s Evolving Dining Scene
text: Conventional wisdom has it that dining out in Barcelona means bouncing from one Michelin-starred restaurant to the next, with chefs like Ferran and Albert Adrià and Albert Raurich leading the way. But as the Spanish economy has suffered in recent years, the fine-dining scene has hit its share of road bumps. Tourism, in large part, has been able to sustain many of the great temples of Spanish cuisine, though not all have survived. Can Fabes, a restaurant outside of Barcelona that earned three Michelin stars every year from 1994 to 2011, closed in August, while Madrid’s two-star restaurant Sergi Arola Gastro closed months before, after owing back taxes (though it has since reopened). Albert Adrià has even gone as far as to say that “the high gastronomy formula doesn’t work now.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Coppervine in Chicago
text: As a boy in San Francisco, Don Sritong refused to eat chocolate chip cookies without milk. “The decadent richness and gooeyness of the cookie is cleaned up by a crisp glass of milk,” said Mr. Sritong, describing his early fascination with food and drink pairings, now matured for adult audiences as the focus of his new Chicago restaurant, Coppervine.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Lamée in Vienna
text: Rates

headline: Different Ring, Different Fight
text: For that distinctive minority whose tastes run to both boxing and theater, there is now a promising alternative to “Rocky,” the Broadway musical scheduled to close this month. It can be found in the flyspecked training ring of the Rock and Anvil Boxing Gym, which has been assembled at 59E59 Theaters for the New York premiere of Brett Neveu’s “The Opponent,” opening on Aug. 7.

headline: Many Reasons to Offer 401(k)s (Including Owner’s Retirement)
text: Soon after Sabina Gault got her public relations firm up and running in 2008, she asked for a show of hands from employees interested in having a company 401(k) plan. The consensus? “Nobody wanted it,” said Ms. Gault, whose firm, Konnect Public Relations, based in Los Angeles, had just a few employees at the time.

headline: Valeant’s Cost-Cutting Ethos May Yet Give Wall Street Indigestion
text: Updated, 6:33 p.m. | Wall Street bulls love Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ lean business model, but there are side effects they aren’t aware of that might give them pause.

headline: Air Force Plans Shift to Obtain High-Tech Weapon Systems
text: WASHINGTON — In an acknowledgment that the military may be pricing itself out of business, the Air Force on Wednesday called for a shift away from big-ticket weapon systems that take decades to develop and a move toward high-technology armaments that can be quickly adapted to meet a range of emerging threats.

headline: 1964: President Johnson Jolts Kennedy Camp
text: WASHINGTON — President Johnson’s swift and final dumping of Robert F. Kennedy tonight [July 30] was a bitter blow to the attorney general that brought to an end a gay and glittering era that became known as ‘‘the New Frontier.’’ It really ended with an assassin’s bullet in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963. But it had been kept alive in the person of Robert Kennedy, the brother of the slain President. Tonight, just an hour after Mr. Johnson had abruptly ruled him out of the vice-presidential nomination, the attorney general issued a terse statement saying ‘‘it is the President’s responsibility to make known his choice.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 31, 1964

headline: Snapchat Said to Have Had Talks With Alibaba on Potential Investment
text: When Snapchat spurned takeover interest from the likes of Facebook and Google, investors scoffed at the audacity of the photo messaging service. But the start-up may have the last laugh.

headline: Understanding Gaza: Correspondents Suggest What to Read
text: The war between Israel and Hamas has entered its fourth week. We asked Times reporters and editors who are covering the current conflict and those who have covered previous conflicts in Gaza to recommend what to read to better understand the history of the region.

headline: Libertarians and Reformers
text: My Sunday column divided American conservatism’s would-be populist reformers into two camps, “reform conservatives” and “libertarian populists,” and tried to briefly describe the overlap and distinctions between the two. I’ve made this distinction before, and like any binary it’s in some sense artificial: You could easily fold both groups into a broad reformist tendency, or disaggregate them further into smaller camps. But I do think the typology is pretty useful, for various reasons — one of which is that it helps clarify two of the gravitational pulls (from very different directions) that today’s conservative reformers need to at least partially escape.

headline: Brooklyn Museum to Offer Free Admission to Visitors Under 20
text: The Brooklyn Museum’s suggested general admission fees for adults will increase to $16 from $12, and entry for visitors 19 and under will be free starting Sept. 3, the museum announced on Wednesday.

headline: Is There a Fair Way for Employers to Match 401(k) Contributions?
text: By offering a company-sponsored 401(k) plan, small-business owners can improve their odds of recruiting and retaining employees — and also make it easier to save for their own retirement in the process.

headline: Teaching a Child to Wrangle, Not Reject, Rage
text: My elementary-age daughter wants to wear a skimpy skirt to school. I make her change. My middle-school son who recently smoked marijuana wants to hang out with a friend. I say no. I refuse to sign consent for my 16-year-old to get a tattoo. What do I get? Angry children who may persist until I’m mad in both senses of the word. “Parenting will eventually produce bizarre behavior, and I’m not talking about the kids,” said Bill Cosby.

headline: Bank of England Sets Tough Rules for Banker Bonuses
text: Updated, 6:00 p.m. | LONDON — After years of debate among global regulators and lawmakers about how to structure pay to curb reckless risk-taking, the Bank of England on Wednesday announced some of its toughest restrictions yet on bonuses while introducing new rules intended to hold managers more accountable for problems.

headline: First Data Buys Start-Up for Virtual Gift Cards
text: First Data Corporation, a payments processing giant, is hoping that virtual gift cards will aid its quest to return to profitability.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names New Vice Chairman in Global Capital Markets
text: Reza Moghadam, formerly a director at the International Monetary Fund, is joining Morgan Stanley as vice chairman in its global capital markets division, the bank announced on Wednesday. He will assume his new role in the fourth quarter.

headline: The Moon Is (Slightly) Flat, Scientists Say
text: Forty-five years after astronauts landed on the moon, scientists say they have finally discovered its true shape: slightly flattened, with a bulge on one side.

headline: Clashing Visions for Old Rail Bed (Just Don’t Call It the High Line of Queens)
text: More public transit. Better public spaces.

headline: Dozens Feared Dead in Mudslide in Western India
text: NEW DELHI — More than 150 people were trapped Wednesday when a massive mudslide swamped a village of 40 homes in western India during heavy monsoon rains, and officials said they had little hope of rescuing many of those missing as weather conditions were likely to worsen Thursday.

headline: The Upside of a Wimpy Handshake
text: Weak handshakes are often frowned upon, but they may be healthier than firm ones. A fist bump, though, may be an even healthier choice.

headline: Meeting Fails to Forestall Catalonia Secession Vote
text: MADRID — The leader of Catalonia, the region that accounts for one-fifth of Spain’s economy, told Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy during a meeting on Wednesday that he would go ahead with a vote on independence in November that the central government in Madrid has vowed to block.

headline: Wrist Injury Forces Rafael Nadal Out of Two U.S. Open Tuneups
text: Rafael Nadal’s prospects of repeating last year’s remarkable run on North American hardcourts were dealt a significant blow Tuesday when he injured his right wrist in practice.

headline: Hyundai Recalls 880,000 Sonatas for Shifting Problem
text: Hyundai is recalling about 880,000 Sonatas from the 2011-14 model years because of a shifting problem with the automatic transmission, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: A Sound Shaped by Time and Tools
text: How different do great orchestras really sound from one another in the 21st century?

headline: Useless Expertise
text: Justin Wolfers calls our attention to the latest IGM survey of economic experts, which revisits the question of the efficacy of fiscal stimulus. IGM has been trying to pose regular questions to a more or less balanced panel of well-regarded economists, so as to establish where a consensus of opinion more or less exists. And when it comes to stimulus, the consensus is fairly overwhelming: by 36 to 1, those responding believe that the ARRA reduced unemployment, and by 25 to 2 they believe that it was beneficial.

headline: Bank of America Raises Its Mortgage Settlement Offer
text: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the bank’s sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis. The two sides, however, remain far apart on crucial issues and a settlement remained elusive late Wednesday, even after the bank significantly raised its offer.

headline: Detective Injured in Greenwich Village Shootout Leaves Hospital
text: Mario Muniz, the New York police detective who was injured in a shootout Monday in Greenwich Village, was released from Bellevue Hospital Center on Wednesday.

headline: Tax Inversions Spinning Out of Control
text: Inversions are starting to spin out of control. A quest for tax savings has made digestible overseas targets attractive to United States buyers. Hospira’s potential $5 billion deal for a Danone unit highlights a fresh supply, for “spinversions.” The odd combination also reflects the perverse incentives distorting corporate decisions.

headline: Fed, on Target to End Bond Buying, Stresses Concerns on Jobs Market
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve affirmed its commitment to stimulate the economy on Wednesday in a policy statement that said labor market conditions remained well below the level that most of the central bank’s officials consider healthy.

headline: Justice Department Ceases Effort to Return Ancient Mask to Egypt
text: It looks like the Mask of Ka-Nefer-Nefer is staying at the St. Louis Art Museum.

headline: An iPhone Case Ready for Hollywood
text: DAVID BASULTO, a high school teacher in San Marino, Calif., thinks you could do a better job with those photos and videos shot on your iPhone and iPad.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela Turns Heirloom Jewelry (Including the Classic Engagement Ring) On Its Ear
text: During his time at the helm of his namesake label, Martin Margiela only gave interviews via fax and refused to be photographed. Despite his departure, Maison Martin Margiela still operates under the same ethos.
