Recently, after a three-year absence, the Paris-based fashion house decided to venture back into the realm of fine jewelry — and to speak anonymously via email to T about it. “It seemed like the right time to reopen this side of our creative world,” a nameless representative from the house wrote.

headline: China Charges Leading Uighur Scholar With Separatism
text: BEIJING — Authorities in the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang have formally charged the Uighur scholar Ilham Tohti with separatism, a serious crime that carries a potential death sentence.

headline: David Wilson Sidelined as Giants Await Evaluation of Injury
text: Giants running back David Wilson, who had off-season neck surgery, will not practice for the remainder of this week and will be held out of Sunday’s Hall of Fame exhibition game with the Buffalo Bills after sustaining a neck or shoulder injury in practice Tuesday.

headline: Steady but Slow Remains the Story of This Recovery
text: The latest G.D.P. report is less interesting for its accounting of the second quarter than for what it tells us about the future path of economic growth.

headline: Olympic Pictures of the Day, Feb. 15
text: The third day of competition featured the action-packed downhill and the climax of the graceful pairs figure skating.

headline: 5 Seconds of Summer Opens at No. 1
text: A few years ago, the wavy-haired teenage guys in the Australian band 5 Seconds of Summer were unknowns in the sea of YouTube, uploading videos of themselves giggling their way through Chris Brown covers.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: CALIFORNIABy Edan Lepucki393 pages. Little, Brown and Company. $26.

headline: Arab Leaders, Viewing Hamas as Worse Than Israel, Stay Silent
text: CAIRO — Battling Palestinian militants in Gaza two years ago, Israel found itself pressed from all sides by unfriendly Arab neighbors to end the fighting.

headline: Met Opera Proposes Federal Mediator for Labor Talks
text: With time running out before a lockout of its workers threatened for later this week, the Metropolitan Opera proposed on Wednesday that federal mediators be brought in at the 11th hour to facilitate negotiations with several of the company’s unions.

headline: Another Avenue to Reach Policy Makers: Taxicabs
text: WASHINGTON — The epiphany hit Jeremy Robbins, appropriately enough, while he was riding in a taxi in the nation’s capital.

headline: Mao’s Sarcophagus and Other Constructions
text: “We’re just humble workers, and we can’t defeat physical laws,” a character named Zhou says in the central story in Jack Livings’s stunning debut collection.

headline: Graffiti the Owner Asked For
text: “Life Is Beautiful” is scrawled in bold relief on the side of a brand-new apartment building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, pink paint dripping down from its giant letters. But unlike some of the nearby walls of graffiti, this tag was done at the behest of the building owner.

headline: How the Federal Government Slows Marijuana Research
text: Politicians who don’t want to take a clear position on marijuana legalization often say more research is needed on the effects of consuming the drug. Hillary Clinton called for more research just last month on CNN.

headline: Sarah Kane Play Among Offerings at St. Ann’s Warehouse
text: A production of the British playwright Sarah Kane’s “4:48 Psychosis,” by the Polish company TR Warszawa (Variety Theater in Warsaw), is among the highlights of the 2014-15 season at St. Ann’s Warehouse, the presenter of experimental theater and music in Brooklyn. (The playwright, whose best-known work, “Blasted,” took 13 years to make it to a New York stage, wrote “4:48 Psychosis” shortly before she committed suicide in 1999.)

headline: Two Dozen Companies on Board for Fall for Dance
text: Fall for Dance, the annual festival at City Center, will include performances by 24 dance companies from around the world for its 11th season. World premieres will be performed by the Mark Morris Dance Group and Music Ensemble and Pontus Lidberg Dance, the Australian Ballet and Lil Buck.

headline: Lifted by Economic Growth, Obama Speaks Optimistically of Policies
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — President Obama on Wednesday delivered an optimistic report about the effects of the administration’s policies in spite of congressional inaction, buoyed by the announcement that the economy grew more than anticipated in the spring.

headline: U.N. Says ‘Evidence’ Points to Israel in Gaza School Attack
text: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said on Wednesday that “all available evidence” suggested that Israeli artillery had hit a United Nations school in Gaza full of civilians who thought they were in a safe zone.

headline: Mets Rout Phillies, Making Their Case Ahead of Deadline
text: For almost a month, General Manager Sandy Alderson had stressed the importance of these games as he evaluated where the Mets stood, with the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline drawing nearer. He seemed to be evaluating not whether the Mets were legitimate contenders, but rather how close they were to contending.

headline: The Paris Hotel Scene Gets a Glitzy New Player
text: At the new Peninsula Paris Hotel, not far from the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe, workers are frantically hanging paintings and placing umbrellas on the rooftop terrace in preparation for this Friday’s grand opening.

headline: You Can Hate Your Job, But You Still Have to Deal With It
text: There’s a lot of advice out there about how to find the “perfect job.” But getting a job at all is no easy feat — and even if you manage to get one you like, you’re all but certain to have bad days. Enter another strain of career advice: how to help you handle your job better, including the parts of it that might not be perfect.

headline: In Search of the Conservative Artist
text: Earlier this month, Adam Bellow wrote a cover story for National Review calling on conservatives to contest the terrain of American culture more fully by investing more heavily in the arts — up to and including including “writing programs, fellowships, prizes, and so forth,” together with new “production and publishing companies and distribution platforms for music, film, and other forms of conservative-themed entertainment.” (Bellow has founded his own imprint, Liberty Island, dedicated to publishing fiction with conservative, libertarian, and “contrarian” themes.)

headline: A Billionaire at Play
text: J. Paul Getty enjoyed his vast fortune but also lamented its downsides, including being viewed as a penny-pincher if he didn’t provide a big tip.

headline: Hijuelos Novel to Be Published Posthumously
text: For nearly 12 years leading up to his sudden death last fall, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Oscar Hijuelos worked obsessively on a novel that few people knew he was writing. The book, an intensively researched 859-page historical novel about the friendship between Mark Twain and the Welsh explorer Henry Morton Stanley, was a departure for Mr. Hijuelos, who is best known for chronicling the lives of immigrants.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Summer North American Championships in Las Vegas
text: Sunday was the last day of the Summer North American Championships, held in Las Vegas.

headline: August in New York, at a Discount
text: New York City in August: If you’re spending money, you’re doing it wrong.

headline: Times Issues Editors’ Note in Response to Plagiarism Charge
text: In an editors’ note responding to allegations of plagiarism, The New York Times said on Wednesday that a reporter in the culture department had improperly used a section from a Wikipedia page without the correct attribution.

headline: Beyond Jets and Sharks, a Turf War of Dominoes vs. Dog Runs
text: Gentrification has come to Harlem: the wine bars, the refurbished brownstones, the swanky potato chips at the corner bodega. You can catch a close-up view of that kind of transition onstage in Seth Zvi Rosenfeld’s play “Handball,” in Marcus Garvey Park.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Iran and Ukraine.

headline: Moelis & Co. Beats Expectations in First Quarter as Public Company
text: The boutique investment bank Moelis & Company beat Wall Street’s expectations for its first quarter as a publicly traded company.

headline: City in Summer? Must Be Mozart
text: Surely, it was no coincidence that on Tuesday afternoon, just in time for the opening night concert of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall that evening, Lincoln Center announced that the French conductor Louis Langrée’s contract as the festival’s music director had been extended through 2017. The news was not surprising.

headline: All the Feelings Remain the Same, Despite the Time That’s Passed
text: The last time Henry Threadgill brought a group to the Village Vanguard, around 24 years ago, I remember experiencing moments of ultra-clarity there, real highs of listening life, when you know that a genuinely original piece of music is slipping by faster than you’d like; but you are not fazed, because you are drinking it dry.

headline: Obama Plans New Scrutiny for Contractors on Labor Practices
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to sign an executive order on Thursday that could make it harder for companies that violate wage, labor and anti-discrimination laws to win federal contracts, administration officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Corcoran’s Merger Plan Draws Fire in Court Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — Two widely divergent views of the financial troubles of the Corcoran Gallery of Art — which is seeking legal permission to alter its trust and dissolve itself through a merger with the National Gallery of Art — emerged in sometimes contentious testimony in the District of Columbia Superior Court on Wednesday.

headline: Irish Arts Center Announces New Season
text: A new monthly music and literature residency organized by the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Paul Muldoon will be featured in the Irish Arts Center’s fall season, the company announced on Wednesday. The series, which runs from September through December, will include readings by the authors Joyce Carol Oates and Zadie Smith, among others, as well as music by Mr. Muldoon’s band the Wayside Shrines.

headline: S.&P. Says Argentina Has Defaulted
text: Updated, 6:59 a.m. |

headline: Dancing and Hoping to Win Fans for Life
text: There was nothing unusual at the New Victory theater last week in a request to turn off electronic devices, except that it was directed at audience members not entirely versed in theatrical etiquette. When the lights went out, they howled. When someone fell, they laughed. In silent sections, they started clapping a beat. In between selections, they tested out moves.

headline: Top Long Jumper Loses Ruling on Prosthesis, Reviving a Debate
text: The debate over whether disabled athletes using prosthetic devices should compete alongside able-bodied athletes took an unusual turn this week when a German amputee long jumper qualified for next month’s European Athletics Championships in dramatic fashion, only to learn that his national federation would not place him on its roster because officials deemed his prosthetic leg advantageous.

headline: Energy Companies Rethinking Russia After New Round of Sanctions
text: LONDON — The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over eastern Ukraine — and the tougher round of sanctions against Russia that followed — is prompting some big multinational energy companies to take a fresh look at the ramifications of the crisis.

headline: What Science Says About Marijuana
text: For Michele Leonhart, the administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, there is no difference between the health effects of marijuana and those of any other illegal drug. “All illegal drugs are bad for people,” she told Congress in 2012, refusing to say whether crack, methamphetamines or prescription painkillers are more addictive or physically harmful than marijuana.

headline: Senate Opens Debate on Bill to Halt Surge of Migrants
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats opened debate Wednesday on an emergency measure to help stem the flood of young migrants from Central America, though they still face two uphill votes — another procedural, and one of final passage — before they can head home for the five-week August recess having passed legislation to address the crisis at the southern border.

headline: More Than Words Can Say
text: A new crop of statement tops, those dressed-up pieces you wear with tailored pants or jeans for a night out, is trickling into stores. After seasons of logo tees and slogan sweatshirts, the new tops, with striking shapes and pretty, feminine details, look fresh and appealing. The tuxedo style from the French label Atto, for example, would be elegant with cropped trousers at an evening event. As would the flannel shirt with feather trim by Alessandro Dell’Acqua for N0. 21. Think of them as a party on top, business on the bottom.

headline: Allison Williams to Play Peter Pan on NBC
text: After a wide search, NBC has found the Peter Pan for its next live musical production—and it didn’t have to look too far from home.

headline: Beatific Broker Tested by Slaughter and Spies
text: The timing of “The Honorable Woman” could not be more disturbing.

headline: Pangolins Are ‘Being Eaten out of Existence,’ Conservation Group Says
text: Pangolins, the scaly anteaters prized in China and Vietnam for their culinary and medicinal uses, are “being eaten out of existence,” a conservation group warned this week.

headline: A Buzzy New Shanghai Restaurant Designed by Shigeru Ban
text: Amid Shanghai’s futuristic mass of gleaming glass and rising towers, an airy, understated two-story new restaurant called Calypso offers a welcome reprieve from the shiny and new. A collaboration between the Pritzker Prize-winning Japanese architect Shigeru Ban and the design firm AvroKO, Calypso is a freestanding bamboo-clad jewel box of a building tucked into the high-end Jing’an business district. Ban’s riff on traditional Chinese design was partially inspired by a former residence of Chairman Mao Zedong next door.

headline: Why Impeachment Talk Is a Wedge Driving the G.O.P. Apart
text: A useful definition of a wedge issue is one that unifies a party while splitting the opposition.

headline: Kansas Democrats Turn to Data in Governor's Race
text: If Kansas Democrats can defeat Sam Brownback, the Republican governor, in November — and that’s a big if, given the state’s conservative tilt — they’ll need help from Republican voters to do it.

headline: House Approves Bill to Expand Veterans’ Access to Care
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved legislation to expand veterans’ access to health care, acting on bipartisan outrage over long waiting lists, falsified reports of health care improvement and a crush of new patients from the wars ending in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Wikipedia Begins Taking Donations in Bitcoin
text: Bitcoin has found another taker.

headline: Treatment Choices for Breast Cancer
Civilian Casualties in Gaza: Who’s at Fault?
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Votes to Sue Obama for Overstepping Powers
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to sue President Obama for overstepping the powers of the presidency — a move that has angered conservatives who call it insufficient, emboldened Democrats who say Republicans are being vengeful, and further eroded much of what is left of bipartisanship on Capitol Hill.

headline: Protests by Immigrants Against a Shelter in Queens
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Ultimate Adventure’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Boeing to Build Biggest 787 in the South
text: Boeing said on Wednesday that it would assemble the largest of its three 787 Dreamliner jets only in South Carolina, rather than splitting the work with a plant in Washington State as it has for the first two models.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Honorable Woman’
text: “The Honorable Woman,” a mini-series starting Thursday on Sundance TV, stars Maggie Gyllenhaal as a British-Israeli businesswoman.

headline: Saving for Retirement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Former Top Spokesman for N.Y.S.E. to Join Public Relations Firm
text: A former top spokesman for the New York Stock Exchange, Robert Rendine, is moving to the public relations firm that handled the Big Board’s sale to the IntercontinentalExchange.

headline: The F.D.A.’s Blatant Failure on Food
text: EVERY year, antibiotic-resistant infections kill at least 23,000 Americans and make another two million sick, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  That’s why a recent ruling by the United States Second Circuit Court of Appeals is so appalling.

headline: Back From Paris, With Beauty Trophies in Tow
text: Who needs the beauty floor of Le Bon Marché? Walk a few blocks in nearly any Parisian quartier and you’ll spot the electric-green cross of a pharmacy stocked with beauty elixirs used by generations of Frenchwomen. But if you want to browse one of the largest selections (with some of the lowest prices), head to what was once an unlikely grooming destination: St.-Germain-des-Prés, that hotbed of 1940s existentialist philosophy.

headline: Bargains at Canvas, Bobby Berk and Broadway Panhandler
text: All goods at Canvas are at least 15 percent off, through Sunday (a Palm Leaf Basket set, originally $70, is $21); 123 West 17th Street (Sixth Avenue), 212-372-7706, canvashomestore.com.

headline: AMC Said to Be in Talks Over Stake in BBC America
text: AMC Networks, the home of AMC, SundanceTV and IFC channels, is in talks to acquire close to a 50 percent stake in BBC America, the United States television network owned by the commercial arm of the BBC, according to people briefed on the discussions.

headline: Infant Chic
text: Nursery Works is introducing a collection of cribs it claims is unique in the annals of infant bed design. No one “does the kind of experimentation with materials and design you see in the adult furniture world,” said Matthew Grayson, the senior designer for Nursery Works. “We wanted to be the ones to push the limits.”

headline: Finding Art That Speaks to You
text: I don’t know much about contemporary art, but I know what I like. Actually, I don’t really know what I like. ArtKapsule, a London service co-founded by Elaine Ronson that recently extended to New York, is for people like me, with blank walls and exhaustingly endless possibilities. For a $250 consultation fee, I first received a questionnaire designed to reveal my taste. Then, Ms. Ronson, a delightful Glaswegian, and one of her consultants, Wayne Northcross, came to my home, looked around and chatted with me about my needs and $5,000 budget. They showed me about 45 images of contemporary artworks. “We want you to look at the art and imagine that it’s a shape-shifting alien who’s desperately trying to communicate with you, but it’s using means that are beyond any language that you’ve ever encountered before,” Ms. Ronson said. Her point was that if you know a piece is trying to tell you something, you’ll strain every sense to understand it. Instantly, I went from feeling that contemporary art thinks it’s better than I am to feeling it was trying to embrace me.

headline: Weave to the Beat
text: It was while she was earning a degree in textile design that Nadia-Anne Ricketts discovered a connection between music and weaving. “When I used to weave, it felt like I was playing a piano,” said Ms. Ricketts, the founder of BeatWoven, a London textile company. “I realized that it was very similar in terms of counting, and the mathematics.” Working with the help of a software designer, Ms. Ricketts developed a computer program to translate audio patterns into woven ones. The result, she said, “looks like a sound wave, but it’s been granulated.”

headline: A Hint of Coco
text: Last week, the renovated Georgian Restaurant opened at Harrods in London, with furnishings inspired by Coco Chanel. “With this collection, I asked myself, ‘How do I bring elegance into today’s world without looking dated?’ ” said Christopher Guy Harrison, a British furniture maker who designs under the name Christopher Guy, and who based the collection, called Mademoiselle, on pieces from Ms. Chanel’s suite at the Ritz Hotel in Paris. Soft contours, metallic glimmers and lush velvet are features of his seven chair and five banquette styles. The collection also includes mirrors, mosaics and a copper statue of a Georgian aristocrat.

headline: Everyone Into the Kitchen
text: In 1976, while Johnny Grey was still in architecture school, he cooked up a “punk Gothic” kitchen for a friend. It was the opening salvo in his war on cookie-cutter kitchens. With encouragement from his aunt, the renowned cookbook author and shopkeeper Elizabeth David, he designed what he calls “sociable kitchens” and promoted the principles that make them work. Today considered one of the world’s most influential kitchen experts, Mr. Grey, 63, estimates that he has produced more than 500 kitchens, and his company, in Hampshire, England, takes on about 20 projects a year. A recent example — a pool house with cooking capabilities in Cambridge, England — piqued our interest during these dog days of summer. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Low Stools, High Art
text: In the same way that other people might stock up on extra towels or bottles of wine, Christine and John Gachot like to keep a stack of low stools on hand at their weekend house on Shelter Island, N.Y.

headline: Nothing Fancy
text: If Brian and Jill Faherty’s home looks a little like a catalog, there’s a good reason: Mr. Faherty is the owner of Schoolhouse Electric & Supply Co., the lighting and housewares company based in Portland, Ore., and his ranch-style house here is where most of the catalogs are shot.

headline: Britain’s Crime of Complicity
text: LONDON — THERE is something almost reassuring about the enduring ability of the British establishment to place itself beyond parody. This month, as the government announced an inquiry into historical allegations of child sex abuse by leading political figures, Parliament pushed through a broad surveillance bill with the justification that tapping everybody’s cellphones would, among other things, help the state catch pedophiles.

headline: Age of Identity
text: “Hair is political.”

headline: Street Style on the High Line in New York City
text: Marika Emi and her boyfriend were recently strolling along the High Line park in Manhattan on a visit from Hawaii. Ms. Emi was dressed head to toe in black, looking more like a native New Yorker than many of the other colorfully dressed tourists who frequent the park. “The funny thing is, I’m from Hawaii but people ask me if I’m from New York when I’m there,” she said. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Digital Photography: A Look Back
text: Twenty-five years ago — before people were taking pictures with cellphones — the future of photography was explored at a workshop where photographers encountered early digital tools.

headline: A Mother’s Ambitions
text: If I’m lucky, I might have as long as two hours to work. I riffle through the stack of research articles on substance use, pull out a few relevant ones, and begin revising my paper’s introduction. I’ve just gotten in the groove when a sweet singsong voice drifts over from the room next door: “Mommy, I have to go to the baaaa-throom!”

headline: G.E.’s Retail Finance Arm Raises $2.9 Billion in I.P.O.
text: General Electric‘s retail lending arm, the financial power behind the private-label credit cards for the Gap and Amazon.com, raised about $2.9 billion in its initial public offering on Wednesday, as the industrial conglomerate moves to shrink its once-enormous finance division.

headline: Piercings Are Back, Subtle and Sophisticated
text: A few years ago, Sarah Slutsky found an online photo of a delicate gold hoop pierced midway through the ear cartilage. “I kept looking at it,” she said. “I was an assistant at Vogue at the time, and after one stressful day, I said, ‘I’m going for it.’ ” She took a friend along to get the piercing. “That was 2011,” said Ms. Slutsky, who is now a fashion stylist. “I felt like we were pioneers.”

headline: Investigators Warn of Possible Perils in Fall With Health Site
text: WASHINGTON — The federal health insurance marketplace, a centerpiece of President Obama’s health care overhaul, still suffers from serious problems, raising questions about whether it will be ready to enroll millions more people this fall, federal investigators said Wednesday.

headline: Summer Shades at the Makeup Counter
text: Summer blooms are at their seasonal peak. Some new roses, peonies and poppies are available now at beauty counters.

headline: Design, With a Gritty Past
text: In a superheated real estate market, Toronto’s Queen West residents embrace specialty shops and loft apartments, while regretting the flight of artists and the loss of affordable housing.

headline: Digital Divide on the Wedding Aisle
text: Welcome to your first Wedding 2.0.

headline: Drawing Ire, Not Artists
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — The setting was pastoral, eight gently rolling acres on a water-lily-flecked lake with two dainty islands. Overlooking it was a modestly elegant Tudor-style house built in the 1930s, with a brood of 19 Rhode Island Red chickens, a colony of honeybees and a burly but amiable German shepherd named Brady.

headline: When Is ‘Prefall’? As Soon as You Want It to Be
text: Clarissa Bronfman has no use for hoary fashion strictures. Ms. Bronfman, a jewelry designer and lanky social figure, was casting a covetous eye on a leopard-spotted Dior dress at a gussied-up yard sale in the Hamptons last week. True, the dress represented the designer’s prefall line. “But I’d wear it right now in the city,” Ms. Bronfman said.

headline: Paying With Your Phone
text: Molly Wood demonstrates how apps from PayPal, Starbucks and Google can help you make purchases with your phone, and explains why you can’t do it everywhere yet.

headline: Easier Ways to Make Payments With Smartphones
text: AT this point, smartphones are practically permanent attachments to our hands. But that quickly changes the moment you need to pay for something at a store and you take out a credit card.

headline: Looking to Rub Elbows With the Kardashians
text: Kim Kardashian and her sisters Kourtney and Khloé did not make an appearance at their Dash pop-up store on Jobs Lane in Southampton, N.Y., on Saturday afternoon, but you could find their likenesses on many of the products, and their aesthetic everywhere.

headline: Four Square Blocks: Toronto
text: The Queen West Art and Design District of Toronto occupies the sweet spot between scared off and priced out.

headline: Between a Loft and a Hard Place
text: TORONTO — First came the manor houses, then the mental hospital, then the stockyards. By the end of the 19th century, the part of Toronto known today as Queen West had had more reversals of fortune than an entire season of “Dallas” (the original or the new version).

headline: Sweat-Free SoHo Style
text: Women keep their clothes loose, lightweight and stick to light colors to stay cool throughout the sweaty New York City summer.

headline: The Looks of Summer
text: Girls in their summer outfits stride on. Even if those dresses these days can be a bit of a mishmash.

headline: How the House Decided to Sue Obama
text: Ahead of a summer break, House Republicans have moved forward with plans to sue President Obama.

headline: The Looks of Summer
text: Many people regard the Irwin Shaw 1939 short story, “Girls in Their Summer Dresses,” through the haze of affectionate nostalgia, but its plot is really quite devastating. A young married couple, Frances and Michael, take a post-breakfast walk down lower Fifth Avenue that soon goes south metaphorically as well when she observes him checking out other women. They repair to a bar and knock back three glasses of brandy apiece while the husband, prodded by his wife, expounds on his greed for the bountiful “picnic” of female pulchritude on display in New York and she cries hopelessly. Seventy-five years after that story was first published in The New Yorker, a descendant of the Brevoort, where the couple lived, still stands. But their argument would probably play out not over Courvoisier but coffee with hearts etched into the foam on top, or complicated green juices. If Michael’s leers turned into actual overtures, he might be excoriated on Twitter for street harassment (#HollaBack); safer to examine his quarry on Tinder instead. Frances might be too engrossed in her own iPhone to even notice.

headline: Senators Stand Against Sexual Assault
text: A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation aimed at limiting sexual assaults on college campuses and improving the response to them.

headline: Moment (Click) by Moment (Click)
text: AGE 34

headline: The Stylist Makes the Man, and the Dandy
text: I divide my life into the years B.C. and A.D. — meaning Before Clothing and After Dresser.

headline: Luxury That’s From Africa, and for Africa
text: Around the time the recession rolled through Europe and the luxury consumers left standing fled from logo-mania and toward the “authentic” and the “rare,” Hanneli Rupert, a South African artist living in London, said that she began to notice “lots of African influences in fashion.”

headline: The Moonlight Mile in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
text: “We have three serious passions: whiskey, beer and music.” That’s the ethos of Garry Embry’s new bar, the Moonlight Mile, which serves more than 150 American whiskeys and a rotating selection of 12 craft beers. As for the music, not only is the place named after a Rolling Stones deep cut, but there is a rock-heavy jukebox in the back where patrons can play their favorites free.

headline: Under Armour Heads Off the Sidelines for a Campaign Aimed at Women
text: ADVERTISING for Under Armour tends to feature elite athletes competing on fields, but to promote its women’s line the athletic apparel brand has a new commercial starring a nonathlete.

headline: New York State Sheriffs Shying Away From Immigration Detention
text: The New York State Sheriffs’ Association has recommended that its members refuse requests by federal immigration authorities to hold foreign-born detainees for additional time so that they can be investigated for immigration-related offenses.

headline: Our Blind Spot About Guns
text: If we had the same auto fatality rate today that we had in 1921, by my calculations we would have 715,000 Americans dying annually in vehicle accidents.

headline: Ending Prohibition 2.0
text: I haven’t written on it, but the Times editorial board has been doing a major public service by pushing for marijuana liberalization. Read the intro to the series, with links to the articles.

headline: U.S. Bars Travel by Top Venezuelan Officials
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The State Department said on Wednesday that it was imposing travel restrictions on Venezuelan officials whom it considered to be responsible for human rights abuses during recent antigovernment protests.

headline: Labor Ruling on McDonald’s Has Business Worried
text: After a federal agency’s decision that McDonald’s is jointly liable for the employment actions of its franchise operators, businesses across the United States were puzzling over the decision’s potential reach. Many feared that they, too, might fall under that broad umbrella.

headline: Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy Have Jack Nicklaus in Sights, at Greater Distances
text: AKRON, Ohio — In the four-month gap between World Golf Championships events, Tiger Woods has played six competitive rounds to Rory McIlroy’s 38.

headline: None Dare Call It Impeachment
text: Let’s talk about something cheerful. How about impeachment?

headline: Celebrating a Matriarch of Old New York
text: Ten pallbearers were not required to guide the coffin bearing Maureen Spillane down the aisle of the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus in Midtown on Wednesday. But that was how many men stepped forward, barely fitting along the sides and rear. This day, her generation of Hell’s Kitchen Irish saw the passing of royalty.

headline: From Schoolhouse, to Symbol of Servitude, to Dust
text: ATALISSA, Iowa — The old schoolhouse on the hill had announced the farm town of Atalissa to the Iowa flatness for more than a century. But a couple of weeks ago, the prehistoric claw of a John Deere excavator took its first swipe, and soon the building existed only in the landscape of memory.

headline: Filling Stomachs to Open Minds on Immigration
text: STOCKHOLM — Last year, when Ebba Akerman, 31, was teaching Swedish to immigrants in the suburbs of this city, she ran into one of her students on the train and asked him whether he enjoyed living in her country.

headline: Patagonia Surfing Wet Suits Go Green
text: A new kind of bio-rubber could change the way surf companies make wetsuits.

headline: What’s Behind the Possible Met Lockout
text: With a lockout increasingly likely, the show may not actually go on this fall at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Nordstrom Buying a Website for Men’s Wear
text: “Guys hate shopping,” said Brian Spaly, the chief executive of Trunk Club, a shopping website for men, “but love to look good.”

headline: Angels Were Way Ahead of the Trade Deadline
text: BALTIMORE — The closer thrives on responsibility. His job, almost always, is to preserve the work of his teammates. They give him a lead, he keeps it, and with enough victories the team plays into October.

headline: Defying Death in Utah Arches: A Thrill Too Far?
text: MOAB, Utah — No outdoor pursuit is too crazy for this desert town built on red sandstone and adrenaline. Mountain bikers careen off rocks. Climbers string lines between towering rock spires and dance out over canyons. People build oversize slingshots and launch themselves skyward, recording every scream and scene to post online.

headline: At Patagonia, the Bottom Line Includes the Earth
text: VENTURA, Calif. — Early on a recent Friday, Mitch Taylor, a local surfer, paddled out at County Line Beach off the Pacific Coast Highway near Malibu, wearing a new Patagonia wet suit. After carving a few waist-high waves, he gave it a positive review, pronouncing it indistinguishable from other high-performance gear he had tried.

headline: Banco Espírito Santo Posts $4.8 Billion Loss
text: MADRID — Banco Espírito Santo on Wednesday reported a first-half loss of €3.58 billion (or $4.8 billion), the largest ever for a Portuguese institution, wiping out the bank’s €2.1 billion capital cushion and forcing it to raise new funding.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 30, 2014
Kim Kardashian, an Unlikely Mobile Video Game Hit
text: A Kim Kardashian smartphone game sounds like a joke waiting for a punchline. But Ms. Kardashian and the maker of Kim Kardashian: Hollywood are laughing all the way to the bank.

headline: Archbishop, Under Fire Over Abuse, Apologizes but Says He Won’t Resign
text: The Roman Catholic archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis, under fire for the way his diocese has dealt with sexually abusive priests, apologized Wednesday for his conduct but rejected calls for his resignation.

headline: Sorrow in the Stands
text: Hoops love is a New York City affliction, and to play it above the rim, to shoot and run with the best, you couldn’t tell James Williams there was much better. Williams, known to everyone as Stixx, was 6-foot-8, blessed with a lean frame and a sweet lefty stroke, and he scored easily enough on more than one N.B.A. star in the city’s summer leagues.

headline: Businessman Says Former Virginia Governor’s Wife Sought Money
text: RICHMOND, Va. — The wealthy businessman at the heart of the government’s case alleging that former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife used his office to enrich themselves took the stand on Wednesday and began describing how he provided the couple with a river of cash and gifts.

headline: Suicide Bomber From U.S. Came Home Before Attack
text: WASHINGTON — When Moner Mohammad Abusalha drove a truck packed with explosives into a restaurant in northern Syria in May, American authorities conceded that they knew little about how a young man who grew up a basketball-obsessed teenager in a Florida gated community had become a suicide bomber.

headline: Quest for Demilitarization of Gaza Is Seen Getting Netanyahu Only So Far
text: JERUSALEM — After years in which Israel’s prevailing approach to the Gaza Strip was a simple “quiet for quiet” demand, there is growing momentum around a new formula, “reconstruction for demilitarization.”

headline: Despite the Loss of a Star, Liverpool Is Hoping to Build on Its Success
text: At nearly every stop during Liverpool’s preseason tour in the United States, Manager Brendan Rodgers has been asked how he planned to replace the star forward Luis Suárez, who was sent to Barcelona for $130 million shortly after the World Cup.

headline: We’re Living in It
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a puzzle about SPACE. It involves the most commonly-touched key on your COMPUTER KEYboard and, interestingly enough, it also involves the STAR WARS CANTINA. Because, and say it with me, both are SPACE BARS.

headline: Reading Between the Sheets
text: “Who are you?”

headline: Payola Figure Is Charged in Gambino Betting Ring
text: Joseph Isgro’s résumé tracks a peculiarly American life, a roller-coaster ride through Hollywood and the underworld, with associates ranging from rock stars to mobsters.

headline: Roddick’s Doubles Comeback Is Dashed
text: To help a friend ease back into the spotlight, Andy Roddick decided to make a comeback this year at the United States Open, where he was a champion in 2003.

headline: A Long Slate of Mayoral Candidates Hints at a Rapidly Changing Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — There were 19 candidates on the scorecard for the mayoral forum at the Acts Full Gospel Church here last month. Fourteen of them actually showed up, primed to speak about their plans for public safety and job development, far in advance of the election in November. They are seeking to unseat the incumbent, Mayor Jean Quan, one of the few familiar faces on the panel. As for the others, it was sometimes hard to keep track.

headline: Video Released of U.S. Bomber in Syria
text: Jihadist video released from Syria featuring an American suicide bomber, Moner Mohammad Abusalha, provides new details into his mind-set before he died in an attack in May.

headline: First Lady Praises Leaders for Progress of Girls in Africa
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama on Wednesday praised the efforts that African leaders have made in improving educational opportunities for girls, but she emphasized that barriers remained and pledged American support in removing them.

headline: Banned Munitions Still in Use, Report Says
text: Cluster bombs, internationally banned weapons that can maim and destroy indiscriminately, not only have been frequently used for the past two years by government forces in the Syrian civil war but also appear to have been deployed this year by antagonists in the South Sudan and eastern Ukraine conflicts, the director of a leading disarmament advocacy group said Wednesday.

headline: Argentina Finds Relentless Foe in Paul Singer’s Hedge Fund
text: The hedge fund firm of billionaire Paul E. Singer has about 300 employees, yet it has managed to force Argentina, a nation of 41 million people, into a position where it now has to contemplate a humbling surrender.

headline: Arthur Shafman, 75, Importer of Mummenschanz Troupe, Dies
text: Arthur Shafman, an ambitious concert and theater producer who spotted an obscure Swiss mime troupe at a cafe in Zurich in the 1970s, brought it to Broadway and watched it become one of the longest-running shows in history — Mummenschanz — died on Monday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Jay Maeder, 67, Newspaperman Who Wrote ‘Annie’ Comic Strip, Dies
text: Jay Maeder, a columnist and editor for The Daily News and The Miami Herald and the last writer of the comic strip “Annie,” died on Tuesday at his sister’s home in Houston. He was 67.

headline: Russia: Officials Deny Violating Treaty
text: Russia denied on Wednesday accusations by the United States that it had violated a significant arms control treaty by testing cruise missiles. The statement from the Russian Foreign Ministry accused Washington of airing old grievances and using “megaphone diplomacy” to try to score political points during the Ukraine crisis. It said that problems stemming from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty were “not new” and that Russia also had concerns about American weapons tests, including of missile defense systems slated for deployment in Poland and Romania, as well as armed drones. The Russian statement did not refer directly to an American demand that it allow a delegation to visit Moscow immediately to discuss the United States’ concerns. But the Foreign Ministry said Washington had previously rebuffed Russian attempts to get an explanation about its questions.

headline: Libya: Benghazi March Protests Militias
text: Residents of the eastern city of Benghazi marched Wednesday in protest against Islamist militias, the city’s dominant force for years, in a burst of public fury a day after the Islamist fighters seized a local special forces base. Residents marched to a hospital, temporarily routing fighters from the extremist militia Ansar al-Shariah, who had been providing security for the hospital. But the militiamen fired on the civilians when they tried to approach the special forces base, scattering the demonstrations. Protesters said they were especially angered after the leader of Ansar al-Shariah declared Wednesday on the radio that Benghazi was an “Islamic emirate.” Violence in Libya has sharply escalated in recent weeks, in Benghazi and in the capital, Tripoli, where rival militias have been fighting for control of the international airport. Several countries have closed their diplomatic missions, and thousands of Libyans have fled to neighboring Tunisia in recent days.

headline: Man Is Charged in Sale of Pills Linked to a Death
text: In the weeks before the Electric Zoo music festival last year, Jeffrey Russ and two friends pooled more than $1,000 to buy dozens of pills that they planned to take themselves and share with others as they bounced to the thudding bass on the grassy fields of Randalls Island.

headline: With Time Dwindling to Make Trade, Yankees Show They Need Help
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, was still making calls to try to improve the team as the hours before Thursday’s nonwaiver trade deadline dwindled.

headline: Décor at Gracie Mansion Now Fits de Blasio’s Style
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio never looked comfortable amid the formal interiors and ornate staterooms of Gracie Mansion, the museumlike residence where he and his family moved this week. Century-old chandeliers and antique cabinets are not exactly in keeping with the populist de Blasio image.

headline: A Rookie as Feisty as She Is Steady
text: Anna Cruz packed two bags for a trip to New York in April to participate in the Liberty’s training camp, expecting to be back in Spain with her family after two weeks. After Cruz’s first practice, Coach Bill Laimbeer and his staff selected her as a starter in the backcourt, extending her stay through the summer.

headline: 14 More Brooklyn Convictions Linked to Scarcella Are Examined
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office has identified 14 more cases on which the former New York City police detective Louis Scarcella worked, expanding the scope of the office’s broad inquiry into Mr. Scarcella’s work.

headline: Skydiving Student Killed in Long Island Jump
text: A New York City correction officer was killed and his skydiving instructor was critically injured during a tandem jump on Wednesday on Long Island, the authorities said.

headline: Governor’s Office Suspends 40 Tax Preparers for Not Filing Own Returns
text: The governor’s office announced on Wednesday that it had suspended 40 tax preparers who, despite their profession, did not file personal income taxes.

headline: $350 Million for New York’s Affordable Housing Effort
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday announced a commitment of $350 million of public and private funding to pay for the renovation of 7,500 apartments, in what he called a “major step” toward his 10-year goal of 200,000 new or rehabilitated homes for lower- and middle-income New Yorkers.

headline: Suit Seeks to Make Sidewalks More Accessible for Disabled New Yorkers
text: Arguing that New York City’s streets are often inaccessible for the blind or those in wheelchairs, a group of advocates filed suit against the city on Wednesday for what lawyers called violations of federal disability laws.

headline: RTL Group, a European Content Producer, Buying Majority Stake in Online Ad Company
text: The RTL Group, a big European media company, announced on Thursday that it had purchased a 65 percent stake in SpotXchange, an online video advertising start-up.

headline: GetYourGuide, a Tourism Start-Up, Raises $25 Million in Financing Round
text: A start-up hoping to do for tourism what OpenTable has done for much of the big-city restaurant business – helping it gain popularity on mobile devices and the web – has just received a big vote of confidence from investors.

headline: Checking In From Home Leaves Entry for Hackers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The same tools that help millions of Americans work from home are being exploited by cybercriminals to break into the computer networks of retailers like Target and Neiman Marcus.

headline: Bothered by a ‘Gummy Smile’
text: Susanna Miller-Pence’s teeth weren’t the problem; her gums were. When she smiled, her upper lip stretched up so high that a ribbon of pinkish gum was exposed, giving her a so-called “gummy smile.” She hated it.

headline: Live From the Public Library: Joseph O’Neill, Joyce Carol Oates and Dr. Funkenstein
text: The novelist Joseph O’Neill, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the cartoonist and filmmaker Marjane Satrapi and the musician George Clinton — yes, Dr. Funkenstein himself — will be among the headliners at the fall season of Live From the NYPL, which begins on Sept. 16 at the New York Public Library.

headline: U.S. Attorney Warns Cuomo on Moreland Commission Case
text: In an escalation of the confrontation between the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over the governor’s cancellation of his own anticorruption commission, Mr. Bharara has threatened to investigate the Cuomo administration for possible obstruction of justice or witness tampering.

headline: E.W. Scripps and Journal Communications to Merge, Then Spin Off Newspapers
text: E.W. Scripps and Journal Communications, the publisher of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, said on Wednesday that they planned to merge and then spin off their combined newspapers, leaving behind a company focused on broadcast television.

headline: ‘Pension Smoothing’: The Gimmick Both Parties in Congress Love
text: The Federal Highway Trust Fund is set to run out of money. If Congress does not put more money in the fund by Friday, the federal government will start reducing its payments to states for highway projects, and some construction might stop. So the House and Senate are fighting over how to get money in the fund, and the fight has boiled down to “pension smoothing,” a budgetary gimmick worthy of Rube Goldberg.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE QUEST Grueling challenges, narrative storytelling and special effects collide as 12 people are transported to a fantasy world of dragons and ogres, where they are declared Paladins, defenders of a noble cause. They must compete to save the besieged kingdom of Everealm — with the surviving contestant earning the title of the One True Hero — in this new series whose masterminds worked on “The Lord of the Rings” and “The Amazing Race.”

headline: Statins May Speed Wound Healing
text: Statins, the widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs, may have a role in surgical wound healing, a new analysis suggests.

headline: Deep-Pocketed Bayern Munich Is Open for Business in U.S.
text: Bayern Munich, the mightiest of the clubs in Germany’s Bundesliga, picked an appropriate time to begin building a year-round presence in the United States.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 31, 2014
text: “It feels like you’re cliff-diving, but you’re looking down at a solid rock foundation.”

headline: Editors’ Note: July 31, 2014
text: The Inside Art column on July 25, about a planned exhibition of the works of the Renaissance painter Piero di Cosimo, started with a description of the artist’s life and eccentricities. That passage improperly used specific language and details from a Wikipedia article without attribution; it should not have been published in that form. (Editors learned of the problem after publication from a post on FishbowlNY.)

headline: Separating the Flies From the Tigers in Beijing Zoo Corruption Case
text: Updated, 4:16 a.m. ET| Among the panoply of officials to be targeted in China’s continuing crackdown on corruption, the case against a former deputy director of the Beijing Zoo has raised the most unlikely questions.

headline: BNP Paribas Posts $5.8 Billion Loss on U.S. Settlement
text: Updated, 7:03 a.m. | LONDON – The French banking giant BNP Paribas reported a record quarterly loss on Thursday after it recently agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty for doing business with countries on which the United States had imposed sanctions.

headline: Lloyds Bank’s First-Half Profit Fell 63% on Legacy Charges
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that its profit declined 63 percent in the first six months of the year as the bank set aside 1.1 billion pounds for a series of regulatory issues.

headline: Santander Profit Rises 38% as Loan Losses Decline
text: LONDON — The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday that its second-quarter profit rose 38 percent as the bank benefited from an improving economic environment and from declining charges for bad loans.

headline: The Kids Who Beat Autism
text: At first, everything about L.'s baby boy seemed normal. He met every developmental milestone and delighted in every discovery. But at around 12 months, B. seemed to regress, and by age 2, he had fully retreated into his own world. He no longer made eye contact, no longer seemed to hear, no longer seemed to understand the random words he sometimes spoke. His easygoing manner gave way to tantrums and head-banging. “He had been this happy, happy little guy,” L. said. “All of a sudden, he was just fading away, falling apart. I can’t even describe my sadness. It was unbearable.” More than anything in the world, L. wanted her warm and exuberant boy back.

headline: Digital Photography: A Look Back
text: I was there when the first shots were fired in the Photographic Digital Revolution. There were no rifles 25 years ago on Martha’s Vineyard, but there were strange-looking prototype cameras that captured images with small sensors and saved them on floppy disks.

headline: Emergency Efforts in Africa to Contain Ebola as Toll Rises
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — As the death toll mounted from the worst outbreak of the Ebola virus, West African leaders quickened the pace of emergency efforts on Thursday, deploying soldiers and authorizing house-to-house searches for infected people in an effort to combat the disease.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Meda to Buy Italian Drug Maker Rottapharm for About $3 Billion
text: LONDON – The Swedish drug maker Meda said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay about $3 billion in cash and stock for the family-owned Italian drug maker Rottapharm, less than a month after that company pulled its plans for an initial public offering.

headline: Cease-Fire in Gaza Conflict Takes Effect as Talks Are Set
text: NEW DELHI — A 72-hour humanitarian cease-fire in the Gaza conflict negotiated by the United States and the United Nations took effect Friday morning, a diplomatic bolt-from-the-blue that will suspend the bloody 24-day military campaign and set the stage for arduous negotiations between Israel and Hamas over a more lasting truce.

headline: New York Today: Endless Summer Race
text: Good morning on this cloudier Thursday.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Continues Its Slide
text: FRANKFURT — Inflation in the eurozone fell in July to its lowest level since 2009, according to an official estimate released Thursday. But separate figures showing a drop in unemployment provided some reassurance that the region was not yet on the brink of a destructive downward price spiral.

headline: British Fraud Office Reaches Second Settlement in Inquiry Over Icelandic Bank
text: LONDON — Britain’s Serious Fraud Office said on Thursday that it had reached a second settlement in a series of civil claims brought by two brothers after a flawed investigation into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing during the financial crisis.

headline: Morning Views
text: Federal law enforcement policies on marijuana use are out of step with scientific consensus, writes Philip M. Boffey for The New York Times. “Marijuana is far less harmful to human health than most banned drugs and is less dangerous than the highly addictive but perfectly legal substances known as alcohol and tobacco.” Mr. Boffey concedes that marijuana isn’t an entirely harmless substance: “The potency of current strains may shock those who haven’t tried it for decades, particularly when ingested as food. It can produce a serious dependency, and constant use would interfere with job and school performance. It needs to be kept out of the hands of minors.” But on balance, “its downsides are not reasons to impose criminal penalties on its possession, particularly not in a society that permits nicotine use and celebrates drinking.”

headline: Recalling the Horror of the Flight 17 Crash Site
text: Sabrina Tavernise is a science reporter and former foreign correspondent. A Russian speaker, she was sent to cover the conflict in eastern Ukraine. She was one of the first journalists to arrive at the scene of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash. This week, she is back at home in Washington, D.C. We asked her about the challenges of reporting on the crash.

headline: Brad Maiorino, Target’s New Cybersecurity Boss, Discusses Being a ‘Glutton for Punishment’
text: Brad Maiorino sounds like a man unfazed by military hackers in Shanghai or cybercriminals in Eastern Europe.

headline: Second-Chance Med School
text: Sitting around an outdoor table at the Red Crab, a restaurant on the tropical island of Grenada festooned with palm trees and fiery bougainvillea, a dozen aspiring doctors bashfully conceded that they had been, at best, near misses when it came to getting into medical school in the United States.

headline: China Harasses U.S. Tech Companies
text: China has opened what appear to be politically motivated antitrust investigations into American technology companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm. Foreign companies operating in the Communist country could be in for more intense harassment than ever before.

headline: Daily Report: Checking In From Home Is a Boon for Hackers
text: The same tools that help millions of Americans work from home are being exploited by cybercriminals to break into the computer networks of retailers like Target and Neiman Marcus, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Credit Suisse Is Facing Inquiries Over Its ‘Dark Pool’
text: LONDON – Credit Suisse on Thursday became the latest big financial institution to confirm that it was facing regulatory inquiries over its private stock trading platform, known as a dark pool.

headline: British Construction Giant Balfour Beatty Calls Off Merger Talks With Rival Carillion
text: LONDON – The British construction and services company Balfour Beatty said on Thursday that it had called off merger discussions with its rival Carillion after a dispute over whether a consulting business that had been put up for sale would remain a part of the combined company.

headline: FTI Consulting Names New C.F.O.
text: David M. Johnson, a former executive at the mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae, is joining FTI Consulting as its chief financial officer, the business advisory firm announced on Thursday. He will take over the role on Aug. 25.

headline: Shell, ENI and BG Report Strong Earnings
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that profit for the second quarter rose 206 percent to $5.3 billion, reflecting gains from asset sales under its new chief executive, Ben van Beurden, as well as improved performance in exploration and production.

headline: 1914: Jean Jaurès Assassinated
text: M. Jean Jaurès, the French Socialist leader and Deputy of the Tarn Department, was assassinated last night [31 July] in a café in the rue Montmartre by a man whose identity is unknown and who declares that he was actuated by patriotic motives.

headline: Kering’s Acquisition of Ulysse Nardin Means More Than You Think
text: The announcement Wednesday that Kering, parent company of Gucci, Balenciaga, Stella McCartney et al., had bought the independent Swiss watch brand Ulysse Nardin was largely overshadowed by its announcement the same day that its second-quarter revenues had beaten analysts’ expectations, in part thanks to soaring sales at Saint Laurent.

headline: Yee-Ha! Space Cowboy Rides to the Rescue
text: Talking about directing in blockbusters is sometimes nothing more than wishful thinking. Most are such impersonally operated machines — dedicated to the business of brand storytelling — that they tend to obliterate any whisper of individuality. That there’s a palpable directorial sensibility in “Guardians of the Galaxy,” along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons. Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America and U.S. Far Apart on Deal
text: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the bank’s sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. But the two sides remain far apart on crucial issues, and a settlement remained elusive late on Wednesday, even after the bank raised its offer.

headline: Adidas Issues Profit Warning Tied to Ukraine Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — Shares of Adidas, the German sportswear maker, plunged 13 percent on Thursday after the company said it would miss its profit targets for the year, in part because of problems connected to the crisis in Ukraine.

headline: Inquiry Into Poisoning of Ex-K.G.B. Officer Opens in Britain
text: LONDON — At a time of icy relations between Britain and Russia, a senior judge in London on Thursday opened a high-profile public inquiry into the poisoning death of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, saying that allegations of Moscow’s involvement would be “of central importance.”

headline: After a Series of Setbacks, Target Chooses an Outsider as C.E.O. for the First Time
text: Coming off a series of setbacks, Target named a new chief executive on Thursday, bringing in an outsider to lead the company for the first time as it looked to right itself. The move casts aside Target’s longstanding custom of promoting top executives from within the company.

headline: End of Ramadan in Queens
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Wozniacki Is Lining Up for New York Marathon
text: The aftermath of a failed relationship: Rory McIlroy walks 18 holes; Caroline Wozniacki runs 26.2 miles.

headline: An E-Commerce Emporium for Locally Made Goods
text: For four years, Peter Smith watched as chain stores replaced mom-and-pops in his neighborhood of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. “A Dunkin’ Donuts took over the pharmacy and they were tearing down great old buildings for a Whole Foods,” recalls Smith, 32, who recently moved to quieter precincts in Greenpoint. “At the same time there were these great brands coming out of Brooklyn. The problem was that people just didn’t know about them.”

headline: Making Work Fun Is Not About Table Tennis and Paintball
text: You know something that is often overlooked in business? Having fun at work. No, I am not talking about the make-believe fun of team-building exercises and paintball scrimmages and company picnics. Most of that is a waste of time. I’m talking about making the actual work fun so people take pleasure in doing it.

headline: An ABC Veteran Is Named ‘PBS NewsHour’ Producer
text: Sara Just, the Washington deputy bureau chief for ABC News, has been named executive producer of “PBS NewsHour,” the first major change to the program since it was acquired by the public broadcaster WETA at the beginning of July.

headline: Wisconsin Justices Uphold Union Limits, a Victory for the Governor
text: CHICAGO — The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a law that significantly limits collective bargaining rights for most public workers, dealing a decisive blow to labor unions in the state and handing Gov. Scott Walker a crucial victory in an election year.

headline: Taking Your Teenagers to Kyoto
text: In a Japanese tea ceremony, you’re supposed to bow to the server; rotate the cup to the right; have the sweet bean paste cake before the bitter powdered green tea; and finish in three and a half sips. Slurping is encouraged.

headline: 36 Hours in Green Bay, Wis.
text: Few cities evoke a single notion in the minds of locals and visitors alike as does Green Bay. This is Titletown, home for nearly a century to the Green Bay Packers, a place where streets are named Lombardi Avenue and Holmgren Way, after former Packers coaches. On Sundays during the fall, the streets empty out, as residents (the lucky ones) fill up Lambeau Field. The remaining six days of the week are spent discussing the game just played and sizing up the next. It’s hard to begrudge the city its love of its home team. Green Bay, with a population of 100,000, is by far the smallest metropolis to boast a professional football team, and the only one with a publicly owned franchise. The Packers are, indeed, Green Bay’s, and no one else’s.

headline: Break in Fighting Lets International Team Reach Site of Ukraine Crash
text: SHAKHTYORSK, Ukraine — International monitors finally reached the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine on Thursday, after being blocked for days by fighting in the area between Ukrainian troops and pro-Russia separatists.

headline: The President Could Boost Wages, If He Wanted To
text: At a planned White House event on the economy this Thursday afternoon, President Obama should use his remarks for more than huffing and puffing about the strong economic growth in the second quarter.

headline: A Delicately Managed Face-Lift for a Paris Beauty
text: Updated Aug. 5 after hotel reopening.

headline: Oaktree Capital Earnings Fell 55% in Quarter
text: Updated, 1:19 p.m. |

headline: He Feels Good, Sometimes
text: If musical genius is a gift randomly bestowed, it requires intense monomaniacal cultivation to reach fruition. Witness James Brown, a.k.a. “the hardest-working man in show business,” as portrayed indelibly by Chadwick Boseman in the viscerally explosive biopic “Get On Up.” A monumental egotist, perfectionist and harsh taskmaster with a streak of paranoia, Brown reigned as the absolute monarch of his personal kingdom, answering to no one but himself.

headline: Amy Bloom: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “Lucky Us” would like to invite Sappho, George Bernard Shaw and James Baldwin over for a literary dinner. “It’s not clear to me that everyone will get along.”

headline: A New Volunteer Program for L.G.B.T. Travelers
text: Global Volunteers, a non-profit organization providing aid to communities around the world with the assistance of short-term vacationers, has launched International LGBT Volunteer Vacations, the first volunteer vacation program directed specifically at L.G.B.T. travelers.

headline: Israel on Destruction of Gaza Tunnels
text: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, and Moshe Yaalon, the Israeli defense minister, discussed their efforts to complete the destruction of Gaza tunnels used by militants.

headline: Feeling as if I Failed the Patient
text: On bad nights, I jolt awake at 2 a.m. and settle in for what will be two hours of tossing and turning as I ponder the mundane (did I remember to pack a belt for the meeting I’m flying to in the morning?), the profound (will my children grow to be happy and contributing adults?), and the prophetic. On this night, I thought about the patient I had been treating for three years for leukemia. I would be seeing her in clinic in a few hours, and I had a bad feeling about her disease.

headline: Synchrony Shares Open Flat After Largest I.P.O. for Year
text: Shares in Synchrony Financial, the North American retail finance unit being spun off by General Electric, opened largely unchanged on Thursday after it raised about $2.9 billion in its initial public offering.

headline: In Portugal, Central Bank Moves to Clean Up Banco Espírito Santo
text: MADRID — Portugal’s central bank stepped up efforts to clean up the troubled lender Banco Espírito Santo and end its family control after the bank reported a stunning first-half loss of $4.8 billion that will force it to raise more capital.

headline: From Townhouse to TriBeCa, the Hard Way
text: As their family grew, Benjamin Berkman and Boji Wong knew they would need more space than they had in their two-bedroom Battery Park City condominium.

headline: On Eventful Day, the Action Begins With One Ace and Ends With Another
text: In one of the more dizzying days in recent baseball history, 12 deals involving 37 players were completed Thursday before the 4 p.m. deadline for trades without waivers. All-Stars and prospects and many players in between were on the move in a flurry of activity that could change the landscape of the pennant races.

headline: And the Moral of the Story Is: Keep It Positive
text: The slower pace of summer means more time to tell stories to our kids, whether it’s around a campfire or in a car on the long, long trip to our vacation spot. We tell these stories for many reasons: to entertain, to pass the time, to share adventures from our own past. And sometimes we tell stories in order to make a point.

headline: Alda, Burnett, Dennehy and Farrow Among Roster of Stars for ‘Love Letters’
text: Alan Alda, Carol Burnett, Brian Dennehy, Mia Farrow, Diana Rigg, and Martin Sheen will be among the rotating actors this fall and winter in a Broadway revival of A.R. Gurney’s play “Love Letters,” which will begin performances Sept. 13 at the Nederlander Theater, the producers announced Thursday.

headline: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert Take Aim at Tax Inversions
text: Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “The Colbert Report” mocked the growing trend of companies seeking to elude taxes through overseas mergers.

headline: Argentina Official on Failed Debt Talks
text: After debt talks collapsed, the economy minister of Argentina, Axel Kicillof, characterized the negotiations with an American hedge fund as extortion.

headline: A Panorama of After-Hours New York, From the Brooklyn Band Bear in Heaven
text: An error message on a friend’s broken TV set inspired the title of the band Bear in Heaven’s fourth album, “Time Is Over One Day Old” (out Aug. 5 on Dead Oceans). “The sentiment, and how it randomly came into our world, seemed connected to our state of mind at the time,” says Jon Philpot, the frontman. The album alternates between revving synths and drifting melodies, and between two lyrical ideas: outer space and inner travel. It’s an accessible brand of art rock that often gets the band compared to fellow Brooklynites like the National, Grizzly Bear and the Antlers. “We’re too weird for the straights and too straight for the weirds,” jokes the guitarist and bassist Adam Wills.

headline: Posthumous Album by Robin Gibb to Be Released
text: An album of unreleased, and in some cases, unfinished songs by Robin Gibb – including his final song, written and recorded shortly before his death in 2012 – will be released in September. The album, called “50 St. Catherine’s Drive” (the address of the home on the Isle of Man where the singer was born in 1949) was compiled by Gibb’s widow, Dwina Murphy Gibb and his son R.J. (who co-wrote several of the songs),  the BBC reported.

headline: On the Border, Who Gets to Be a Refugee?
text: A poll by the Public Religion Research Institute asked Americans whether they thought children illegally crossing the United States border from Mexico “should be treated as refugees and be allowed to stay.” Sixty-nine percent of respondents said “yes,” according to The New York Times’s Julia Preston, and “about a quarter of Americans in the survey, 27 percent, said the minors should be ‘treated as illegal immigrants’ and deported to their home countries.”

headline: Fortress Investment’s Results Are Buoyed by Private Equity Gains
text: The Fortress Investment Group, a publicly traded alternative asset manager, said on Thursday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, aided by sales of its private equity investments.

headline: Falling Glass From Midtown Office Tower Injures 3
text: Three people were hurt Thursday morning when a window shattered and fell from the 18th floor of an office building on West 57th Street at Avenue of the Americas.

headline: In Real Estate Listings Deal With Zillow, Trulia Bears Most of the Risk
text: The success of Zillow’s $3.5 billion acquisition of Trulia may depend not on an “and” but an “or” that the parties put in their acquisition agreement to deal with antitrust issues. Not only that, but the deal leaves Trulia the loser if the merger fails on antitrust grounds.

headline: Inquiry by C.I.A. Affirms It Spied on Senate Panel
text: WASHINGTON — An internal investigation by the C.I.A. has found that its officers penetrated a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee in preparing its damning report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program.

headline: 1964: Rusk Bars Threat to Soviet Ties
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Dean Rusk vetoed firmly today a suggestion by Sen. Barry Goldwater that the United States try to extract ‘‘concessions’’ from the Soviet Union by threatening a break in diplomatic relations with Moscow. The United States does not and will not yield to ‘‘pressure or threats’’ when its vital interests are involved, Mr. Rusk said, and it would be ‘‘unrealistic’’ to think the Soviet Union might do so. Without mentioning the Arizona Republican presidential nominee by name, Mr. Rusk, who usually avoids partisan political issues, said he does not foresee any shifts in the near future in U.S. policies abroad. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 1, 1964

headline: Tell Me About Your Next Job
text: This interview with Jon Bischke, the chief executive of Entelo, a recruiting software platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Requests for User Data Rise in Twitter’s Latest Transparency Report
text: Twitter on Thursday released its bi-annual transparency report, detailing the number of requests for information the company receives from government agencies around the world.

headline: Interpreting ‘The Maids’ Through a Shifting Societal Lens
text: Jean Genet’s creepy, sexy play “The Maids,” which had its premiere in 1947, has never gone out of fashion. But in the last several years, it has been riding a new wave of interest, with revivals in Europe and Canada and mash-ups like the Off Off Broadway ensemble Sister Sylvester’s forthcoming “The Maids’ The Maids,” whose cast, according to the company, will include two professional housekeepers.

headline: Sadistic Fantasy in a Fun House Mirror
text: It was a particularly brutal murder. In 1933, the French domestics Christine and Léa Papin killed the wife and daughter of their employer, gouging out their eyes while the women were still alive and knifing their thighs and buttocks.

headline: With Eyes on Seats in Maryland and West Virginia, Politicians Cross Borders
text: CHARLES TOWN, W.Va. — Only 30 miles and the Potomac River separate this bedroom community in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains from Frederick, Maryland’s second-largest city.

headline: Protests Thwart Israeli Troupe at Edinburgh Festival
text: A run of “The City,” a hip-hop musical being presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe by the Incubator Theater, a company based in Jerusalem, has been halted after one performance after protests on Wednesday. A demonstration organized by the Scottish Palestine Solidarity Campaign, reacting to the violence in Gaza, forced organizers at Underbelly, the presenting site, to call off the rest of the run there, saying the demonstration was disturbing other productions at nearby performance spaces.

headline: In Final Hours, Metropolitan Opera Extends Contract Deadlines for Unions
text: The Metropolitan Opera postponed a threatened lockout late on Thursday night, saying that it had done so at the request of a federal mediator who was brought in at the 11th hour to try to salvage its contract negotiations with the unions representing its orchestra and chorus.

headline: 50 Shades of Blue, Green, Everything
text: Art and adversity are old friends. When Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, currently the subject of a poignant exhibition at Galerie Perrotin  on Madison Avenue, were starting out as artists, straitened circumstances meant they had to take house-painting jobs to pay the rent. They found themselves fascinated by houses, colors, even the names of colors: subjects that became the focus of a joint career that continued until Ms. Ericson’s death from brain cancer in 1995 at the age of 39.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Lawyers
text: Are legal apprenticeships a good way to avoid excessive law school debt and create different perspectives on the law?

headline: Li Out of U.S. Open With Knee Injury
text: Li Na started this year well, winning titles in Shenzhen, China, and at the Australian Open by the end of January. Shortly before her 32nd birthday in late February, Li reached a career-high No. 2 ranking.

headline: A Jaguar F-Type, Modified for Tour de France Duty
text: PARIS — The team cars following the riders this month at the Tour de France were, for the most part, large and sensible station wagons. But there was one notable exception. During last Saturday’s time trial, as riders raced against the clock, the British Sky team appeared with a modified Jaguar F-Type coupe to carry its riders’ spare bikes and wheels.

headline: Tesla and Panasonic Agree to Build Factory in U.S.
text: Tesla Motors announced on Thursday that it had an agreement with Panasonic to build a large-scale battery plant in the United States.

headline: Today in Small Business: Time to Give Raises?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: F.D.A. Acts on Lab Tests Developed In-House
text: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Thursday that it would start regulating medical laboratory testing, saying that tests used to make important treatment decisions must be vetted and validated before they go into use.

headline: Keep the Met Open
text: Whatever happens in the bitter negotiations between unions and management at the Metropolitan Opera this week, here’s the bottom line: don’t shut the doors, even briefly.

headline: When the Fourth Wall Is Nature
text: IN the final scene of the Public Theater’s production of “King Lear,” now in previews and opening on Tuesday at Shakespeare in the Park, the bereft Lear enters, bearing his dead daughter in his arms.

headline: Google Details Problems With Handling Right to Be Forgotten Requests
text: LONDON – Google says complying with Europe’s so-called right to be forgotten ruling is getting complicated.

headline: San Diego Symphony Names Chief Executive
text: The San Diego Symphony has appointed Martha S. Gilmer, for many years a mainstay in the administration of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, to be its chief executive, starting in September.

headline: What to See and Do in Montreal, From the Local Designer Arielle de Pinto
text: The Montreal-based designer Arielle de Pinto has perhaps single-handedly made crochet cool again through her signature knitted metal jewelry and footwear, sold at such stores as Dover Street Market. And though she is not Québécois, the Toronto native moved to the poutine capital of the world in 2003 and by now is probably as close as any transplant can get to the real thing. With the Osheaga Festival happening this weekend and the Francophone capital’s fleeting summer in full swing, now is, she says, the perfect time to visit. “Montrealers save it all up in the winter and let it all out in the summer,” she says. “It’s two months of perpetual rejoicing.”

headline: More Polls in Arkansas, but No More Clarity on Senate Contest
text: Arkansas is one of the states where we could really use more rigorous, nonpartisan polling. Three new polls came out this week, and they’ve done little to help clear things up.

headline: Wheelies: The Payload Policy Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Why Crucial Vaccines Are Sometimes Unavailable
text: When cases of a potentially fatal strain of meningitis began cropping up at Princeton last year, university officials trying to stop its spread could recommend little beyond precautions like frequent handwashing and not sharing beverage containers.

headline: Inversions May Be the Least of U.S. Corporate Tax Issues
text: A couple of home-grown tax breaks in the United States are making inversions look like a diversion. The American authorities are letting Windstream designate its telecommunications cables as real estate, qualifying them for tax breaks. And a partnership will shield assets of the energy firm Hess from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Upstart French Telecom Iliad Bids $15 Billion for a Majority Stake in T-Mobile US
text: Updated, 8:14 p.m. | Sprint and T-Mobile US have been slowly dancing toward a $32 billion merger of the third- and fourth-largest cellphone operators in the United States. Now a French upstart wants to break in on the cozy couple.

headline: Grab a Seat, Prepare for the Sizzle
text: Ears, jowls, belly. They come brined, blanched, shattered and fried, each tip blackened and alchemized, each pocket of fat approaching liquefaction. A raw yolk idles on top. Stab it and churn. This is sisig, the greatest pork hash — arguably greatest pork dish — on earth. Say the name with two flicks of the tongue, somewhere between a whisper and a hiss.

headline: Having More Than One Set of DNA Carries Legacy of Risk
text: The family seemed to defy the rules of genetics.

headline: Rebellion Inside G.O.P. Scuttles Vote on Border Bill
